review_body: We were only meant to be here 3 nights but due to COVID 19 ended up spending 5 nights here before flying home early. It’s a fantastic hotel 5 star! Staff were all wonderful and I even got the most delicious birthday treat on arrival. The hotel was extremely clean and the staff proactive prompted you to use the hand sanitiser when re entering the hotel. Really easy to get around from here, we walked a lot but there is still plenty of public transport near by. I will stay here again and I highly recommend it!

We sprung for a premium twin room with Executive Lounge access. The room was excellent with a good bathroom. The lounge was very nice, but I would suggest that the hotel expand its menu of evening hors d’oeuvres and mix them up a bit. What they served was ok, but not the same thing every night. The staff were all excellent and very friendly.

We flew into Narita airport and got a quote from a taxi for over $200 so we went to the bus and they only charge half price for kids under 12 and free for 4 yr of lap children so it was perfect. The bus came regularly and dropped us off right in front of the hotel so it was really convenient. The lobby was beautifully decorated with these hanging dolls for a festival and there was tons of hand sanitizer. We checked into two rooms and they gave the kids these toiletry bags with little slippers and toothbrushes and they were so cute! The kids loved the robes in the room and the view of the metropolitan building. The rooms were big and didn’t feel like other hotels we stayed in Shinjuku. Great location as it was close to the shinjuku station and we had a great time finding the udon restaurants at 8 in the morning. We didn’t eat at the restaurants in the hotel but they looked really nice. I recommend the updated rooms.

We stayed for a couple of nights and were very happy with our room - not super luxurious but had everything we needed and was clean and comfortable. The location is excellent and we had a surprisingly good brunch in one of the hotel restaurants. One issue we had was that on the Saturday evening we were keen to have a drink in the hotel before going out to dinner but every single bar was either full (!!) and not allowing anyone else in or had not yet opened and we were gobsmacked that we couldn't have a drink at any bar in the hotel before we went out to dinner! We eventually had to wait quite some time but managed to get into the smoking area of the bar on one of the top floors and the view was spectacular!! We were extremely lucky because only one person smoked more than one cigarette and we weren't too close. They need to halve the size of the smoking area and open it up to non-smokers because the smoking area was almost empty and the non-smoking area was packed full - not a sensible use of space.

What an outstanding place.The experience we had was above and beyond, everything from the entrance to the hotel to leaving the hotel was fantastic.Everyone was extremely friendly and very accommodating and helpful.The rooms were amazing.Hotel is located in a great area.The view from our rooms was breathtaking.

We stayed here for two days prior to a Princess Cruise. This hotel is crazy expensive! Our room was so small we had no place to put our luggage. Lunch for 6 people (burgers and fries) was $250.00. So not worth it. The hotel is huge, members of our party got split up and the staff could not have cared less. Such a disappointing start to a vacation. Try to avoid this one.

This is my 2nd time to stay at this hotel. The staff were very polite and professional. Despite the room is a standard type which was not spacious, it was neat and tidy, and especially with good view. We could have a panoramic view of Metropolitan Government Building！It was also convenient to access Shinjuku Station to take JR to anywhere you like.

Keio Plaza Hotel is located in an ideal place in Tokyo. Near enough to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku, and yet situated in a quieter part of Shinjuku without the distractions of the city life. The hotel has excellent restaurants that cater to the different tastes of its guests, and the service team is superb. It's about 2-3km away from Yoyogi Park - a great place for a morning run or simply a walk in the park. The Meiji shrine/garden is just a train stop away from Shinjuku and a wonderful place to be in quiet meditation, in the heart of the city. Next to the Meiji Shrine is Harajuku - the iconic place for shopping and unique Japanese pop culture.

Our family stayed here for 6 days in February. Fabulous location, great amenities and breakfast plus the room size was very reasonable. We liked the free shuttle bus to/from Disneyland plus the luggage service to deliver our luggage to the hotel.

Shinjuku is very huge and you can get lost here easily if you don't know the way. Keio Plaza Hotel is on the opposite side of Takashimaya where the bus terminal is closer and where all the major shopping destiantions are. I would recommend using the department stores to navigate around instead of going through the Shinjuku train station. Keio Plaza is close by Nishishinjuku, where Odakyu Railway is closer

Room was of a reasonable size with a queen bed, writing table and a lounge chair. Bathroom was small but functional - toiletries were provided and the toilet seat was heated (very useful as the weather was quite cold). Bed was not exactly plush, but it was comfortable enough. Housekeeping can be improved (I noticed hair in the bathroom that is unlikely to be mine). Front desk and concierge service standards were generally very good. The hotel also provides airport limousine service (3200 yen, one way from hotel to Narita) but it stops at various hotels to pick up passengers. There is also a free shuttle service to Disneyland. Location is good as it is near Shinjuku station.

Its a big hotel, staff are friendly (as all japanese people are) rooms were comfortable (3x in our room) and clean, we asked for non smoking room as we were told some rooms really smell. We ate out all the time as the prices in the restaurants looked expensive, Starbucks was only around the cnr (not that im a fan of this mob) and surprisingly they made really good coffee to start the day and there are a lot of little restaurants close by that are good. The hotel isnt far from Shinjuku Station about a 8min easy walk, we found there is a underground walkway to the east side of Shinjuku station if the weathers wet, it maybe a good option

This is the second time we have stayed here within a week. The location is excellent for accessing the train network, shops, & restaurants. There is great access to Shinjuku Station via the West Gate. Walking distance to Memory lane, The Robot Restaurant, and the Metropolitan Government Building which has a viewing platform in each tower that is free of charge. ``The rooms varied greatly between our visits from very good to very average. The front desk staff are largely incompetent and indifferent to any concerns/questions you have during checkin and through out your stay. I joined their executive membership program. It is not worth the time it takes to complete the application. Overall the value is poor as there are many hotel options in the area of Shinjuku.

As said in the title, the location is convenient - walking distance to Shinjuku station and even Shibuya itself if you don't mind a bit of walking. 2 mins walk from the hotel, you'd arrive in a series of alleyways full of yummy authentic japanese eats.The room is nice with a view, spacious and everything else that comes within your expectation from a hotel of this level.Every morning, we had a buffet breakfast at Glass Court (we had 3 choices but preferred this one for its varieties of food). However, you'll want to be there before 9.30 to avoid queue. Also, the Luxe Lounge on 34th floor in the South Tower gave us a nice breathing space to have a drink and snack with a view overlooking tokyo before heading out for dinner after a long day of sightseeings. As well, having english newspaper delivered outside your door is a nice touch. We spent 4 or 5 days there from memory and didn't have anything to complain.

The Keo Plaza Hotel was great! It's close to Shinjuku Station, has excellent service, and it's very comfortable - I would definitely come back.SleepingI came for Christmas week with my family of three. We originally booked a deluxe room from an online travel site. Since there were three of us, we requested a 3rd bed, which the hotel provided. The entire week we were there, we slept comfortably without any issue. I'm easily awakened by noises, but I was able to sleep easily at this hotel. There were no late night noises, or disturbances at all. I will say that the beds were quite firm - so if you're used to a medium or softer bed, please take that into account. WiFiThe Wifi in the room worked well. We watched HD movies on my iPad, and also played online games with a laptop. The speed is about average, but it was enough for my needs.FeaturesWe had a"Superior" room with 3 beds: 2 Double beds and 1 Roll-away bed. (Note, for the roll-away bed, we had requested it during reservation.) It wasn't huge, but large enough for us to feel at home, and definitely larger than other hotel rooms I've seen in Japan. It came with typical room ammeneties: refrigerator, closet, robes, towels, slippers, toothbrushes, and other toiletries. There were three electrical outlets that had U.S.-style sockets, and USB charging ports. There's a safe that's easily operated, but unfortunately it could not fit my 15inch Laptop. On the main dresser, there was a smartphone that could be taken while exploring the city, but we never took it out of its charging dock. (I didn't want to carry another device while on foot.) Near the bathroom was the airconidtioning/heating panel. This was easily operated and we kept it on the warm side since it was quite cold in Tokyo at the time.BathroomLike many hotels in Japan, the room comes with a bidet-style toilet which I love. The best part: the seat was always warm - no more cold seats! There were enough towels and toiletries for all three of us to spare. I really liked the shower's water pressure - it was powerful, and not weak at all.Local AreaThe Keio Plaza is within 5-minutes walking distance to the busiest train station the world - Shinjuku Station. This is a huge plus because the station not only allows for easy-access to mass transit, but it contains a vast amount of shops and restaurants. What's more, there's many convenience stores on the streets nearby to buy everyday items, cheap meals, and access to ATMs. (There's a convenience store in the hotel as well.) Also, the surrounding area around the station has even more shops and restaurants to explore (especially on the east side). Being so close to all these services, stores, and restaurants really helps when you walk all day long. ServiceThe staff we talked to were polite, respectful, very attentive. My Japanese language skills are limited at best, so it was great that everyone we spoke to knew English well. There's always several people in the main lobby who will help direct you to the appropriate desk (check-in, check-out, concierge services, shuttle to airports, taxi, money exchange, etc.)Traveling between the airports to the Keio Plaza Hotel:If you're traveling from Narita or Haneda Airport, there's multiple ways to get the Keio Plaza Hotel and back. We took the popular Airport Limousine Bus from Narita. Alternatively, if you are traveling during a busy season, you may want to avoid the traffic on the roads and take a train. (We arrived on Christmas Eve, and car traffic going into Tokyo from Narita turned a 45 minute trip into a 2 hour ordeal for us.) Besides the bus services, there are multiple trains that you can take to the hotel. You just have to be resigned to pushing your luggage around and walking from Shinjuku station to the hotel itself. When I come back to Shinjuku in the near future, I will definitely have this hotel in mind. It has excellent service, location, and ameneties.

7 Min walk to JR Shinjuku which also connects to subway, use the west exit its all under ground so go to the lower level. Large hotel 1200 rooms and popular with tour operators, hotel also offers a conference center. strict on check in time and we had to wait around but were able to leave bags and wonder until check in opened. Staff very friendly, limited English by some but that didn't stop them from trying to help. Hotel is apart of the limo bus transfer from Haneda airport and also has the Disney bus picking up be sure to book seats early for Disney with the concierge. Lower floor has multiple dining options we didn't opt for breakfast but lines looked long at places.store to get bread and snacks was great when long day trips were being done.Room was spacious with complimentary bottled water, bathroom amenities were great. TV has few english channels.Hotel also has JTB / Sunrise Tours in lobby for any day trips that still need booking.Overall we enjoyed our stay and would stay again

Excellent location. Multiple restaurants and food options. Close to shops, train stations, public transport. Airport limousine service available to and from doorstep. Polite, courteous and helpful staff. Complimentary cellphone for the stay is a super bonus! Will definitely go back there!

The Keio Plaza is located a 7 minute walk from Shinjuku station. The room was spacious and the hotel provided a full size baby cot complimentary which we found was rare in Tokyo. The bed was comfortable and they provide lots of amenities.The limousine bus stops off at the hotel which was an easy way for a family to get from Narita to the hotel.The staff are fantastic! The check in and check out were quick and easy. The restaurant staff are lovely and great with kids. The food was delicious in Jurin and in room service. We would stay here again.

This place is a luxury hotel with good service staffs. Room is clean and full of amenities. You can even find skincare set, tooth brush & tooth paste, soap, shampoo, conditioner and lotion all in your bathroom! And the house keeping will keep your room clean and fill your amenities for everyday. We were staying in a room for 3 people, we heard about the hotel that it is old and has been popular for a long time. When we arrived at our room, It was new renovated very new beautiful modern style. We like it!

We needed two rooms as we were traveling with two teenage children. Interconnecting was not an option but we had rooms next to each other. The location of the hotel was good but the hotel was expensive and dated. Beds were comfortable but bedding was oddly put to together (a series of covers that slid apart, opposed to a single doona) and towels were somewhat scratchy.also could do with a second rail to hang the second towel.Our experience here wasn't terrible but for the price, age and feel of the hotel we wouldn't stay again.

Prior to booking at keio we contacted the hotel to ask which floors had been renovated as last time we were here three years ago they were doing renovations. We were advised to book the superior rooms as they were newly renovated rooms which they definitely are not! Stayed here three years ago and the room was newer than the one we have been put in even though we requested one of the newly renovated ones. Was told by reception that these are renovated but they are old dated and the bathroom is smelly. Just came from a beautiful hotel in Kyoto that was half the price and ten times better. Overpriced and definitely getting tired. Very disappointing with the staff handling at reception

The staffs are very friendly and their service is very good. The hotel is located in the prime place that it makes your shopping easy. Metro near by helps you to cover all the places. The hot chocolate makes the breakfast menu complete. They have improved in their English communication as Olympics 2020 is on its way. Weather was too cold but manageable. We can shop winter clothes at a good price in UNICLO which is very near to the hotel... More importantly the wash room in the hotel is so good, u will feel the difference.. overall enjoyed staying at Japan...

Stayed for 4 nights for my first experience to Japan and chose the Keio Plaza due to its location in Shinjuku but also as the airport limousine from Narita drops you off here so saves lots of hassle in trying to find especially as we arrived late.Firstly some help for tourists, if you plan on using the airport limousine check your return time as we had to be at the airport 3 hours before (our departure time was 9AM) and the first bus leaving the Keio Plaza is 5.55AM or 6AM etc this also does not take into account other stops and all in all takes 2 hours minus traffic so this was a little hiccup. On arrival as I only purchased the one way limousine bus to Keio, I was checked in by a very helpful young guy who quickly assigned the room and welcomed us and advised to speak to the concierge about a return to Narita as they know more information.A girl took our cases to the room and was very polite, room was nice - bathroom a little dated but good size room and had all the basics you need. For the price you would expect a little more I think but I’m used to travelling and this is a city so typical business hotel to give you an idea.We then ventured out and on the way out I spoke to the concierge as the front desk suggested but found him to be very unhelpful to us. He just pointed at a slip with the Narita bus times on and said no earlier ways to Narita. I was then thinking I would have to pay £100 for a taxi but decided to do my own research and you can visit a website called Keisei Highway Bus that goes every hour to Narita from Tokyo Station. Why the concierge do not have this information is bizarre as it should be there job to be helpful but he was disinterested and just posted to the limousine bus slip. So if you are leaving super early to Narita or you have a very early flight then this could be a helpful option for you.Breakfast was good, just what you need a selection of western and Japanese (omelette station and bacon, sausage, cereals etc) and you get daily coupons.ATM is in the convenience shop on the same floor as breakfast restaurant so easy to get cash at the hotel. Hotel have umbrellas as well for rainy days so speak to the bell boy/station.Definitely download the Tokyo subway map it’s a godsend. Also we purchased a 48 hour metro pass which is great and this you can buy from shinjuku station (you can buy at Narita separately but it’s cash only) .... at shinjuku station, it’s easy to purchase and is activated only when you first use it. If you buy a metro pass, it can only be used for metro lines and not JR lines. Essentially they are both at the same place but when you are going through with your ticket just remember not the JR pass this will save you lots of hassle.Location is excellent ... 5 minutes to Shinjuku station main area.The staff at the hotel were lovely, from breakfast staff at Jurin to reception. Like previous comments the concierge needs to be more helpful and approachable and also know better information like the other bus and not just give you a slip and say nothing. This caused us a little worry and was unnecessary.FYI we booked the Mount Fuji tour via sunrise tours based at the hotel (worked out at £100 each) was very good and guide was lovely.We also ended up taking the NEX express train from Shinjuku to Narita, the first one is at 05.55AM but takes one hour and there is no traffic obviously so again I done my own research on this and hope you find the info helpful.Thanks Keio team

We enjoyed our stay in this hotel. The staff was friendly and helpful. Room was very clean and location was great. Breakfast was fantastic and we had a choice of different restaurants every morning. We had accessed to the member's lounge where we had a good view over the city.

A very large hotel and close to everything in Shinjuku - about 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku station, 15 minutes walk to Golden Gai, Omoide Yokocho, Kabuchiko. We booked a Plaza Superior Queen room in the South Tower and it was very spacious. Room was clean and, contrary to some reviews here, it was nice and modern. Breakfast was a choice of Western buffet, or Western & Japanese buffet, or Japanese a la carte (3 different restaurants). The rate was surprisingly reasonable for Tokyo.Late checkout was available until 1.pm for JPY 5,500 or 3pm for JPY 11,000.A major bonus is that the Airport Limousine bus drops off and picks up at this hotel, the concierge can make the booking for you.

I was very dissatisfied with the lack of flexibility of the Supervising Manager during my check-in. After a red-eye flight I was checking in at 7AM and had to check out the same day at 3PM effectively staying at the hotel for only 8 hours. In stead of accommodating through my one night booking, the manager insisted on having me pay up 10,000JPY for early check in. I paid 1,5 days for 8 hours use, and the hotel was able to re-rent out my paid room for one more night... I like the location and cleanliness of the Keio Plaza, but the lack of accommodating was unfortunately representative of Japanese bureaucracy and inflexibility. Giving guests a feeling of being welcomed and treated fairly should stand above whether the booking IT System can or cannot process irregular cases such as my early check-in / check-out. 残念です。

This review is for the Team Ceremony only, not the hotel. The experience was poor overall. The host was rather condescending and insincere from start to finish. I imagine this is primarily patronized by foreigners who are looking to learn more about traditional tea ceremony, so you'd think they could at least convincingly fake that they enjoyed teaching you and wanted you to have an enjoyable time. Unfortunately I cannot recommend this and encourage you to try another option for traditional tea ceremony--there are many.

Keio Plaza Hotel is a big hotel with 720 rooms, 12 restaurants, a convenient store, spa, etc... What asurprise as we discovered Mount Fuji in front of us when we opened the curtains in our first morning. We were in the south tower, on the 21st floor in front of Tokyo City Building. At that level (and higher) the two towers of the building are separated by a large space so that we could see Mount Fuji by that clear morning. A good start in Tokyo!Restaurants are nice but very expensive. There is a Starbuck very close to the hotel and many littlerestaurants around. Our rom was very clean, comfotable and quiet.That hotel is very close to the Subway Oedo-line Tochomae. As we were in the subway after 10 am, it was not too crowdy.

we were staying at the Premier Grand room, which was rather spacious and everything at the hotel was simply elegant and lovely. Breakfast at the club lounge and at the lobby restaurant were both scrumptious and lots of varieties. Only thing is, the queue can be quite long for the buffet breakfast at the lobby restaurant, then again, you can also opt for other breakfast choices at the hotel. We had breakfast at one of the Japanese restaurant and was great too ! Oh, Great view at the club lounge too, also great for relaxing / chilling after a long day. Location wise, 10-15 mins walk to station. I tried looking for kids activities for my 5 yrs old, but nope, nothing. The hotel has a day care services (chargeable) but we did not try. So can't comment. There is no kids club or activities for kids, either. They do have direct shuttle to Tokyo Disneyland thou. Still highly recommended ! my kid was very entertained by the view and the food at the lounge. :)

Stayed in this hotel when typhoon Hagibis hit Japan. On the day that we checked out, we were informed that we can no longer proceed to the next leg of our journey as the railways and roads were badly damaged. We had no choice but to stay a few more days in Tokyo. The hotel front desk was kind enough to extend our stay although it was fully booked then because of the ongoing Rugby World Cup. The room price was much higher. But still we are grateful that they accommodated our request to extend our stay. Keio Plaza has many positive points. Perfect location to explore Tokyo as it is next to Shinjuku station. The hotel service is good. It is very convenient if you're coming from either Narita or Haneda as there is an airport shuttle that can bring you to and from the airport. One downside is the room as it's dated and needs a lot of improvement. However, we were fortunate to stay for two nights in one of the newly renovated rooms. The price is much higher though. Will definitely stay in this hotel in my future trips to Tokyo.

Wasn’t sure when I was booking hotels what was a good location near the train station, night life in Tokyo. Keto Plaza got the bill, a bit expensive but the room while small by US standards, was large but Japanese standards and was updated (even had a bidet and warmed toilet seats great surprise). We used the airport limousine shuttle that took us directly from Narita airport to our hotel. Was able to book our returning from their hotel very easily. Breakfast buffet was just ok but there was a lot to choose from. Exceptional service. Everyone was so helpful and did their best to anticipate our needs. Definitely a bit pricey but I am glad that I booked it for our first time in Japan.

Stayed there 3 times for 8 nights in total over a 3 week period..Huge hotel with no character but ticks most boxes for a Central (good location) city hotel. The whole check in experience is more like being at a large airport, concierge was very helpful, service mostly very good, breakfast way too expensive, nice rooms with a comfortable bed and tea and coffee facilities and all 3 rooms were quiet. Good to have the complementary lounge with our room but it is very basic, some fresh milk for the tea and coffee rather than powdered milk for example wouldn't go amiss and maybe some simple non junk type food to eat.
user_name:
Arotake
Royal Tunbridge Wells, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed at the Hyatt in Tokyo in 2017. Someone recommended Keio Plaza and I decided to try it out. When I checked in, I reminded the hotel of my upgraded booking for which I paid an extra $1k for. I also checked that the room could sleep 3. I was also booked on the plaza luxe floor with access to the lounge. On check in, I was told the extra charge for my third guest and to show his passport when he arrived a day later. The reception did not know of my access to the lounge and I had to show my emails. It was unexpected because all this should be in the system. I got my room and it was NOT the upgraded room I paid for. I had to call down and asked. I waited for a reply and after some time I was shown to the correct room per the photos per my booking per the extra charges I paid. Things did not improve. When my third guest came, I dutifully went to reception showed the passport and wanted to pay the extra per day for the 3rd guest. The reception said no. It was not permitted. This was exasperating because I arranged a larger room at more costs to cater for 3. After some to and fro I gave up and booked another room. At an exorbitant costs. I then had the horrific experience of the duty manager whom I requested to assist with reservations for dinner. He was unpleasant and not at all helpful. This was a complete contrast to the fantastic service I had with Hyatt. The duty manager and concierge were extremely polite and helpful. Not so here. I also had an issue with the q at breakfast. It was a long wait and when we got in at 9:35 am after waiting for 25 min, we were told that we had to leave by 10:15 am. The point being that if you cater to these huge numbers, perhaps arrangements can be made for the q to stop at a certain time. Or maybe arrange alternative seating areas. The WiFi was also problematic. You had to key in a long password each day. All in all I must say it was not a pleasant stay.

We stayed here for our winter vacay. The hotel is quite crowded with the check in line quite long but the staffs worked very hard so they can help us fast. We stayed in the main building. The room's wall was quite thin as we can heard people chatted beside our room and from outside the room. The bathroom was clean although it's quite small but we are ok with it. The hotel location is walking distance to Shinjuku station, it took us around 15 minutes to go there. But if you go across the hotel, there are lots of restaurants, convenience store and entertainment places (arcade,etc). My nieces stayed at the South tower which is the new tower. It was very nice as it has bigger room and not too noisy. But we will def going to come back here again because of the location and the value of money. They also provide the limousine bus from and to the airport.

First booking a male receptionist is not friendly so we wrote complaint ticket.Second booking we like to do checking procedure at 13:00 is not allowed and no room for us until 17:30 without any compensation.It is so ridiculous and staff didn’t say anything.Keio plaza hotel Tokyo is so nice as google comment? We are so sad about this bad experience.

Good location, nice hotel, friendly staffs, easy to walk around for foods or shopping. The hotel is very clean, beautiful, they have a cell phone for you to use while you stay in Japan. It’s in your room and Free to call. We took bus from Narita airport and the bus drop off/pickup us in front of the hotel. Therefore, it is very convenient.

Very old hotel & needing to upgrade rooms & rugs!Old Hotel, musty, dirty rugs, smelly toilets (we even bought deodorizer & it didn’t work). Due to musty rooms & rugs; our allergies from dusty & possible mold made us sick. Beds were hard like sleeping on box springs!Our regret was wanting to stay at a Japanese hotel vs staying at a Hyatt or Hilton! We learned.

A very good hotel for all sorts of purposes. Easily reachable from both airports via the bus/limousine service. Check in is very strict. You arrive too early then you’ve to wait before you’ll get the keys for your room. The room themselves are OK, all sorts of amenities that you’d expect from such a category of hotel area available. Several breakfast options, restaurants and the like are all in the building. Within walking distance is an area with lots of restaurants. Very recommendable

Location was relatively close to Shinjuku Station West Concourse. We found our way easily after getting off the JR train. We stayed on the 28th floor which had a clear view of the city as well as the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. Room was clean and newly renovated with a nice variety of amenities which included L'occitane toiletries. The bath sugar cube was a nice touch to unwind after a long day of exploring the city. Size of the room wasn't large but it was good enough as we could open two luggages at a time. We would choose to stay here again!

This is a great hotel - it's big and bold and the staff know exactly what it's all about - but, at the end of the day, it's just a bit soulless. I really hate to say this, as we enjoyed our stay here (and the C&T bar is really first class and some of the Floor 2 restaurants are great!) but, there we are.

My sister and I stayed 4 nights in November to attend my nieces 40th birthday celebration. To our delight we received an upgrade to our room! Our twin bedroom was spacious, well appointed and with a lovely view of the city. Staff were very accommodating - we phoned for a knife to cut a cake and we received plates, napkins and a presentation plate as well! Laundry service prompt. Walking distance to the amazing Shinjuku Station and a lovely park.

We had a wonderful anniversary trip in Tokyo - thanks to the more than “spot on” hotel service at Keio Plaza Hotel. Keio Plaza Hotel is “spot on” in almost every aspect that we care about. The room was not big but it has everything slightly more than our expectation. The temperature was right with a moderate humidity, the room was clean and tidy, the water pressure and temperature of the shower head was just right and stable and we are amazed that there was electric plug and mobile phone charger INSIDE the safe so that my computer and phone will be ready for service after our trip during the day time. The restaurants are also very SPOT ON in every sense. The quality and quantity of the breakfast buffet was just right and the fact that it was breakfast didn’t comprise its quality. Everything tastes just right for what it is supposed to be. It is an amazing experience and this hotel is for those educated travelers who demand everything to be just right. We will write separately for the restaurant which we went in this trip.

Hotel is located near the Shinjuku Station and near to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observatory where it is a free observatory where public can queue to visit the observatory. Photos posted are the views from our room and the hotel lobby.

Very convenient to get here from the Airports by the Airport Limousine Bus which has a direct stop at the Hotel Entrance. If you can't take the Bus, then the Train will drop you at Shinjuku Station which is 10 mins walk from the Hotel. Conveniently located just on the outside of the bustling Centre of Shinjuku, this is a Old hotel with a Huge Reception and Lobby and several restaurants and feels like a Shopping Mall itself. Very busy with people all around and has several category of rooms from small to medium to large. We were located in the South Tower on higher floor (Plaza Luxe category) which gives you beautiful morning and night views of Tokyo and free access to the Lixe Lounge on the top floor for drinks and snacks all day long. Rooms are decent enough for 2 people and I wonder where would we fit the kids. May be they have seperate family room categories. Breakfast is nicely spread with many options among the restaurants and many metro locations access around the hotel connecting you very well to the entire city. Staff is very supportive and helpful and very clean hotel though some of the fittings especially in the bathrooms feel old and needs minor refurbishments. Overall a great stay if you plan to stay in Shunjuku and want to conveniently wander around the city though you might have the option of some smaller trendy boutique hotels in the area. Shinjuku is the place to be for all the action in Tokyo from restaurants to clubbing to nightlife to gaming.

My 2 sons and I stayed for 4 nights in December while touring. Shinjuku is a good base from which to explore Tokyo, within easy walking distance from the hotel to Shinjuku station. Just bear in mind that Shinjuku station is actually a collection of multiple stations with over 200 entrance/exit points, requiring a bit of planning - would suggest Google Maps which gives you the line, direction etc and best entry point.The hotel is very large but amenities and service were very good. We had breakfast included in our rate (recommended) but otherwise did not use the restaurants which seemed very expensive and unnecessary given the huge variety of options nearby

Paid quite a lot for a dated club room in the south tower. The club lounge is not open in the morning until 10am so you can’t get a morning coffee. Gym was very small and not really very well equipped. The hotel didn’t have a great atmosphere I’d stay somewhere else next time.

International hotel of quality. Stayed in the main tower block. Rooms clean and comfortable. Selection of breakfast restaurants catering for all palates. From the upper floors, you can sneak a glimpse of Mount Fuji on a clear day.Sky bar is worth a visit in the evening for a great view of the city.Excellent walkway through to the station -

Keio Plaza Hotel is in an excellent location near Shinjuku station which allows easy access to all of Tokyo. The room was very spacious and modern, and provided a "Handy" cellphone for guests to use both in and outside the hotel.The bed was comfortable, and the view from the 38th floor (Grand Premier room) was amazing. The room was quiet and very dark at night with the blinds closed, which is always appreciated. Staff was very courteous and helpful.Breakfast at the Club Lounge on the 45th floor was good; I did not try the other breakfast options.The toilet had a motion-activated light which is very annoying for someone who wakes up at night to use the toilet. I do not want the light on in that case! Fortunately, switching off the "master" switch also deactivated that light, so I was able to get around it, but it would still be nice if there was a more obvious way to disable the light. The master switch is also by the door, so not ideal to have to switch off the lights that way before getting into bed.If you are not familiar with Shinjuku station, finding your way to the hotel can be difficult if you arrive by train. This is perhaps more a problem with Shinjuku station than the hotel, however. :)

We stayed at the Main Tower, Superior room....had 3 beds & still spacious....location is great!! Accessible to most subway lines.... many stores & restaurants nearby.... took the Disney bus shuttles too!!! They even provided extra travel adapters too!!!

Stayed in Plaza Superior King rooms in the South Tower. Rooms (while not renovated and hence the design may be regarded as slightly dated) are a good size by Tokyo standards, and are very clean and functional. Noise insulation between rooms is however poor, I can always hear my neighbour if their TV is on or when they are talking a bit loudly. The street the room faces is quiet at night, being an office district, so no worries about traffic noise. Other than that, no other grouses for the close to 2 weeks we stayed. Location is good. About 5 mins walk to rows and rows of more than competent eateries and assorted convenience stores at Nishishinjuku, and about a 10 min walk to an entry point into the Shinjuku station. The station is massive so it may realistically take you another 5-10 mins to locate the line you wish to take.We picked the South Tower over the Main Tower because of the view of Mount Fuji, possible only on days with clear skies. It took a week before the mist cleared and we were rewarded with it.

I chose this hotel firstly because of the location (right near Shinjuku station) and secondly because of the room and bed size.The room itself was great, far larger than any other hotel room we had stayed in in Tokyo, also we opted for the large bed, so my wife, two year old and I could all sleep in. The bed was huge and there was so much room we felt like we had loads of space.The room was also a really good size so despite there being three of us we never felt cramped at all.We arrived early from London and they let us check in a few hours before the 3pm check in time that was massively appreciated.All in all a great find and we would definitely stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo.

Large room with complimentary bottles of water. Mini bar, wifi, safe. Bed and pillows very comfortable. Lots of outlets and charging ports. U.S. plugs will work in the outlets. Shampoo, conditioner and body wash are provided. No body lotion.There are three different restaurants for breakfast- two with western breakfast, open with Japanese breakfast. Nice selection including an egg station.Fitness room is adequate with treadmill, bikes, steppers and free weights.Staff very helpful.

I stayed for 3 nights in a Superior room in the south tower during a 2 week Japan trip Pros:- Large room especially compared to other rooms in Japan- Reasonably comfortable bed (most hotel beds i slept on in Japan were amazingly hard)- A few HD English channels, it was nice to have the news on in the background as i got ready in the morning and for bed - Great location... close to a ton of shops/restaurants/parks/museums and walking distance to Shinjuku Station- Nice view from the South Tower (some complain that it’s dominated by the Tokyo Government building, which it is, but i was happy with it)Cons:- Excessive noise from the adjacent rooms and from above (a family was staying above me and the hours of stomping every morning and night drove me absolutely insane... i could also hear talking from the room above and the room next to me... i would expect better sound insulation from a hotel that’s ~$300/night)- Dated and small bathroom (it was acceptable, but I had better bathrooms in other Tokyo hotels that cost half the price)- WiFi is metered to 1MB/s, not great if you’re dealing with large files for work or looking to stream HD video All in all, if i were to stay in this area again i would probably try somewhere else in the same price range... e.g. the Hilton, Hyatt, etc. The sound issue alone is enough to make me look somewhere else as waking up and going to sleep to the sound of stomping everyday significantly affected the quality of my stay. It’s nice to have a big comfortable room, but there are other hotels that offer that for this price

Had a comfortable stay,from a mere staff down to a single ussher they're all approachable and friendly. The rooms were spacious,neat and a very clean feel beddings.Well ventilated rooms perfect to chat and relax.We had a good breakfast, an awakening delicious scrambled eggs were served.A unique experienced indeed! Highly recommended.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel for five nights. The hotel is located in slightly off the busy part of Shinjuku. In the same parameter with Hilton and Hyatt hotel. Check in time is at 14.00 and they are quite adamant in enforcing that. But guests can keep their luggages with the Bell Captain while start exploring Tokyo.Service is professional and friendly. The room is relatively large for Tokyo size. Very clean establishment.We had a very comfortable stay and we highly recommend this hotel

Located in the Shinjuku area and near the station this quality hotel could not be located better for a trip to Tokyo.The room are on the small side but well equipped. The bathroom has the usual Japanese washing toilet. There is an area next to the hotel which has a collection of good resturants making them an alternative to the hotel expensive resturants. At busy times expect to queue for breakfast but the food is of a good standard. The scrambled egg was noticeably excellent as not many hotels can cook creaming scrambled egg

It was very overwhelming to focus in on hotel rooms in Tokyo as there are so many. We opted for the Keio Plaza as it was close to the train station and seemed to be on the more "quiet" side of Shinjuku, yet still within walking distance of the hustle and bustle. The hardest part when arriving at Shinjuku station via the Narita Express was finding the West Exit during the evening rush hour, but after locating it, it was a breeze. It is also right between shinjuku station and another local subway line has an entrance on the other side so it was convenient to be close to these for sight seeing. The hotel is huge, with a few different exit/entry points, so sometimes it was easy to get lost as far as which exit you went out of and which direction you need to go to get where you were going but otherwise we loved everything about this hotel as our first pit stop in Japan. There are a lot of different room options which was overwhelming. When booking through a third party site, I recommend going to the hotel site as well and comparing descriptions there to see what differences there are between room types. We ultimately decided on the Superior Twin Renovated Room in the Main Tower. Check the square footage and room floor plan on the hotel site to make sure you're getting what you want. There were also renovated rooms in another tower, but those didn't have the larger bathroom that we wanted. This was the largest room we had in our time in Japan and most set up like a western style room. The bathroom was large as well with great toiletries and a great tub that I took advantage of after long days of walking around. We had a gorgeous view out of our window of the government building as well. Only real complaint was the beds were pretty hard. I actually prefer a firm bed, but this was really firm. This seems to be common in Japan though.Overall, great stay and would definitely chose this hotel again.

I've stayed at this hotel several times over the years, and on our way back to the states we stopped here for three days in Nov 2019 The room was good sized, and was recently renovated which made it very nice, however their check out time is 11am, and I respectfully requested one hour till 12pm, and was told I could go later, but at a 5,000 to 6,000 yen extra charged. As a club member of Keio Plaza club I felt I should at least had the courtesy extended to 12pm. As this was denied even though we were paying over $600 US per night, I will not ever be staying here again. Have never had such treatment around the world, and as a Hyatt Platinum member, or Hilton gold, across the road I could have gotten a late check out till 2pm. In April we stayed at the Palace Hotel, and was very well treated in true Japanese hospitality unlike this hotel.

Stayed for three nights at Keio Plaza.Located very close to the main rail and subway station of Shinjuku.Lovely room, good breakfast and nice staff.Only negative is the breakfast arrangement, probably the breakfast area is too small for the number of guests, especially in the peak hour.Long queues which occasionally means that you are asked to go to a different restaurant on the 44th floor which is not as good.

stayed here for 3 nights after staying in 2 other hotels ( Ikebukuro and Akasaka). This is by far the best hotel. I stayed in the main Tower and the room was very large ( twin bed with sofa, business desk with TV, makeup table etc ). I felt happy coming back each night to the room where I have plenty of room to rest comfortably. More than enough room to open up my 2 huge luggage on the floor at the same time. It is slightly more expensive than the other 2 hotels I stayed but comparing the comfort level and closeness to Shinjuku station, the extra monet is well worth it. The hotel was well maintained and the staff very helpful.

Arrived at 6pm at Narita. Got our luggage and got the next NRT express to Shinjuku. Had a lot of luggage and was easily able to navigate our way to hotel on foot. You can walk outside heading west from West exit at the mall or take tunnel which is one floor down.Check in was a breeze and got upgraded to Premier grand room. Very nice clean room. We stayed 2 nights and hotel is great home base for seeing Shinjuku and easy to hop on subway or green train to get anywhere you need to. There are numerous breakfast options and we enjoyed them all.Checkout arranged for baggage transfer to different Tokyo hotel for $35 which I thought was reasonable. We left for Hakone for 1 day and didn’t want to lug around everything.

We arrived via the N'exarita stopping somewhere in the Shinjuku train station maze. Exit West main exit side, Keio is a 7-10 min walk. We stayed in the South Tower and rate incl. Exec Lounge access, great for planning our day or relaxing with a coffee after a days sightseeing. Unknown to us when we booked the hotel back in Jan 19, our stay in early October was also the England Rugby Team's Tokyo base for the weekend of their pool match v Argentina. We found out when Eddie Jones San entered the lift as we exited. We then saw Jack Knowell and family plus Tom Curry, post Argentina game at breakfast. We have them their personal space exchanging simple "hellos". Room, being one of their premium rooms was pretty much perfect. Like every hotel we stayed at, great bathroom freebies. It was a huge double bed. Breakfast, included in our rate, was quite an extensive choice. Fried eggs were cold though, a common thing in Japan but you can ask for hot egg omelettes etc.The sky / top floor bar was a great place to end your day, open late, cocktails beers etc. Superb view of the night skyline across Tokyo. Had some great conversations with Japanese and other guests.We had our wifi hub delivered to the hotel and they also arranged forwarding of our main luggage to our next stay in Kyoto. No traumas.Overall I would recommend the Keio Plaza, it was pricey but perfect location. We did not eat at the hotel but that is generally what we do, eat what and where the locals eat.

Just checked in today. Disappointed with my room in the South tower, it is very old and dated. Wish I had known the difference between the South and Main tower rooms before I booked. It is a very busy hotel and it does not have the hospitable feel some other reviews talked about.I feel that it is very expensive for the room I got.It is a bit of a walk (20mins) to the main Shinjuku area, but near to the Shinjuku station.

We stayed 5 nights and highly recommend as a base for a Tokyo stay. The rooms were well appointed and clean. There are two Towers in the Hotel with magnificent views of the city. Easy walk to Shinjuku Station and all the shops. We enjoyed walks to all the surrounding parks. Breakfast choices were plentiful and on the weekends they served breakfast on a high floor which had a spectacular view. Plenty of options for restaurants etc for dining close by. Plenty of convenience stores close by and we ate at Curryudon Senkichi which is close to the hotel - it was excellent.

We stayed at the Keio during the Rugby World Cup so I understand the room price being at its peak but the breakfast, although quite nice was way too expensive. And to pay $18 for one coffee is outrageous. The bar on the top floor offers a beautiful view. The rooms were nice but not fantastic. Good location

Stayed there for 7 days and it was homely and comfortable. Within walking distance from food areas at Nishishinjuku. Nearest station was Tochomae and it was very convenient for us as a family to move about from one place to another. They have a minimart at the hotel which was great for us with kids who are forever hungry. Hotel is away from the of the Tokyo city crowd, very quiet and peaceful at night yet safe enough to move about. Overall, pleasant stay and would stay here again if we ever get to Tokyo.

We were staying for holiday as a family. The room was quite big and very clean, and as we expected the service was excellent. Definitely will recommend to our friends. The lounge was excellent with a lot of variety to choose from.

The rooms are terribly outdated and the queues for breakfast are quite long every day.They also desperately need to upgrade coffee facilities at breakfast as there is only one small slow machine and there is often a queue of more than 5 people deep in the Jurin. We never tried Glass as the queues were always long and staff pushed everyone to Jurin.However, the biggest issue is the wifi is terrible and getting on (if the device is successful) takes many attempts to get to the authentication server. I would say it is the worst wifi of any hotel I have ever stayed at. Eventually I switched to tethering off my phone to 4G and paid for roaming just so I could work. We never had any issues with any other hotel in Japan during our stay.

Stayed here for closed to a week and there were shuttle buses from airport to the doorstep of the hotel.Very comfortable stay and the staff were friendly. They even provide free brolly in the event of rainy days. Room was big for japan standard. Walking distance to Shinjuku train station with convenience stores nearby.Also if you are heading to Disneyland from this hotel, they have free shuttle service which was very convenient as it saved our hassle to plan for the transports.Would definitely come back again.

First things first - this hotel is not cheap. However given all the plus points, and the fact that this is Tokyo after all, and in the heart of Shinjuku, the premium price is somewhat warranted. Location of hotel is fantastic. The subway station is just outside the side entrance. The main Shinjuku station is just a short walk away via a covered walkway. The airport limousine bus stops right in front of the hotel entrance. This hotel is a Disney Good Neighbour Hotel, hence there’s a free shuttles bus service to and from the theme park. My husband and I, together with our friends who were also hotel guests, were very happy with this extra perk! My husband and I stayed 8 nights in the newly renovated superior room in the Main Tower and loved very thing about it. At 34sqm, the size is generous for Tokyo standard. Love that the bathroom has a separate shower area next to the bathtub. The bed is firm, just the way I like it. We were there when Typhoon Hagibis made landfall and were holed up in the hotel the entire day. Had lunch buffet at Glass Court. While the selection is not as extensive as some buffets we’ve been to, it was a good meal nonetheless. Special mention goes to Ms Tanaka (apologies if I got her name wrong. She wears a Brazil flag in her lapel.) who assisted us with our DisneySea ticket amendment. She was patient and gave us her undivided attention. She also reprinted our tickets after the amendment as a gesture of goodwill. She definitely made our day!

Keio Plaza was recommended by a friend and it did not disappointment. We stayed in the south tower on level 32 and had a great view of Mount Fuji (yes it was 2 very clear days!). The room was modern and very spacious for a Tokyo hotel. We had buffet breakfast included in our stay and it was well worth it. We opted for the western buffet, however there was a choice of Japanese restaurant for breakfast. Check in and check out was very easy. The hotel is in a great location. Close to all the shops, restaurants and Shinjuku train station. We also loved the complementary free transfer bus to Disneyland - it made the experience really seamless and accessible. Overall I do believe this is 4 star hotel providing great service and amenities. I would stay again.

We stayed here in October 2019. It is a clean hotel and the location is very good. However, our room was a bit dated for the price. There were long queues for check-in. The room cleaning service literally changed the sheets and towels, they didn’t clear away used tea cups or replace them. The food in this hotel is extremely expensive which is unfortunate. We had 3 club sandwiches and 3 coffees which cost €100. I gave it 3 stars as I was disappointed with the quality of this hotel for the price. It is a perfectly good hotel to stay in but is over priced.

We booked this hotel in Tokyo based on many online resources/reviews. It was recommended because of the size of the rooms, price and good location. We also had read that we should choose a room in the South Tower for the view, but we quickly found that wasn't necessarily good advice, since the Tokyo Government Building blocks most of the view from this side of the building, and the rooms have not been renovated in this tower.We arrived at the hotel around 11 am and after a long wait in line at the front desk, we were told we couldn't check in. (We had requested early check in made our reservation.) We pressed it--saying we just wanted to check in, drop off our luggage, and leave to tour some of Tokyo (planning to come back later in the day to go to our room) and finally, they allowed us to "sort of" check in and store our luggage, but that took a few more steps to do. When we finally got in our room we found it nicely decorated, but not as large as the pictures indicated, and definitely not as nice as what we paid for, or as nice as what we'd experienced in other parts of Japan that we had just been to. Yes, it was on a high floor with a sliver of a view, and it had nice amenities (although not the l'Occitane toiletries as promised) AND it was the only hotel we stayed at in Japan where we actually got ONE bed rather than two--but I must admit I was disappointed.The bed was very uncomfortable and hard, and the internet was a little difficult to access. We ended up getting help with that, but it wasn't self-explanatory. The bathroom was small, but had a nice shower with good water pressure. The lobby and main areas were very nice and there were plenty of elevators available for our use.The hotel is in a quieter area of Shinjuku which is nice, but it's a bit of a hike to/from the main train station (about 15 minutes), particularly at the end of a day of walking. They offer a bus service to the two Tokyo airports for a fee. (We paid $32) They also have tour services onsite, which we didn't use, but it was a nice feature.If I were to stay here again, I'd be sure to get a renovated room, and I might even splurge and get a club-level room, just to have a little more bang for the buck.

Very large hotel very busy during our stay and seemed to have many inexperienced staff. Lots of facilities. Standard rooms adequate but a bit dowdy. Coped very poorly with breakfast crowds and Long delays in queue for same. Hopelessly inadequate service in late night bar BRILLANT. Huge delay in getting any service, light snacks arrived after one hour and were cold. Full tray of drinks spilled over my party. No reaction from management to this despite the guests being drenched in beer etc.

Whilst we ended up with a room type that was less in quality than booked, this was Agoda’s error, not the hotels. The hotel kindly provided an upgrade & were genuinely upset for us & sought to resolve amicably

We stayed at this hotel during the 2nd leg of our honeymoon. The hotel is centrally locates and close to late night restaurants. We were able to walk from Shinjuki station with our luggage to the hotel. Rooms aren’t large nor fancy as we are in the heart of Tokyo, but all washrooms have washlets which surprisingly was a great experience! For the price we paid it was great value!We’d definitely stay at this hotel if and when we return.

Some Hotels lose the personal touch when they are extremely large. Our experience here was helpful and welcoming, despite staff having to deal with the additional impact of the anticipated Typhoon Hagibis. We ended up staying an extra night but had to move rooms - initially we were in a standard and somewhat compact room, and then moved to a larger room which was much more comfortable but came at a price!The bar on the 45th floor is worth a visit for the views, and we did eat in one of the restaurants on the day the Typhoon arrived, which was very nice although predictably very expensive. As someone else mentions, there are lots of other options for eating out, both local food and brands such as Sizzler, which was only a block away.

The room was a fair size but the floor space was limited - we did not want to unpack for two nights - so we had trouble finding enough room to lay out our suitcases. Quality was good though. Shower was powerful enough and the toilet seat was wonderful - warm seat and a built in bidet. It tuned out these were quite common in Japan. The breakfast buffet was very good. The hotel has a gym and I believe a pool but this was closed after September. The lobby was majestic and the hotel was very swish. Some of the restaurant prices were astronomical however so we ate out and there are literally hundreds of eating options within a fairly small radius of the hotel. Overall a very enjoyable stay.

We were a bit hestitant regarding our booking as we learnt there were renovations occurring but we needn’t have worried. Rooms clean and comfortable; ours were Standard Rooms, no noise and hotel is located close to lots of different areas to explore. Hotel is a bit dated but this didn’t worry us. Check in easy, staff very courteous. We ate at Jurins as we arrived late at night after taking the Limousine Bus from Narita Airport which dropped us at the door. We also ate breakfast there. Fairly pricey but then most hotels are. Good middle of the road hotel to stay at and once rooms are all renovated, worth staying there.

We had a lovely welcome on arrival & got a large room allocated to us(which is great for Tokyo). Decoration was very dated - there seems to be quite a difference between 'normal' and 'club' rooms? We were on the 20th floor and had a good view. I think that when paying over £300 per night there should not be a charge for breakfast or for use of the pool!(apparently) We stayed in a number of hotels during our trip- the majority being better quality accommodation & value.

We had to change our plans for our onwards journey due to a typhoon hitting Japan, so we picked this hotel for the night. Great location, alright rooms and abundance of restaurants to choose from. Most of all - great staff. Kudos to them for making us all feel relaxed. Easy check in, check out and good friendly service from the staff - I would stay again:)

Originally booked a standard room, which there are v few pictures of on the website. Be careful as these rooms are v poor quality. Beds as hard as tables, bathrooms very small and basic; these room would struggle to get a 3 star rating in the UK After 2 nights we decided to upgrade to a standard premier room which was about 15/20% more. The quality difference is over 100% better. Nice bright spacious rooms, nice modern bathroom, own floor for breakfast. These are the pictures you see on the website. The location of the hotel is great.We were here during the rugby World Cup so the cost was eye watering, so am unsure of whether it was good value for money as everything was v expensive during this period.Would we stay again - definitely not as we felt slightly tricked by the standard rooms. If you do decide to stay here pay the extra amount and get a better room.

It’s a five star hotel in a very good quite location in Shinjuku . Interior is very wide with very artistic decoration. You can get all tours of your desired destination from here.very helpful & courteous staff.

Within a ten minute walk of Shinjuku train station so easy to get anywhere in Tokyo from the hotel. The hotel staff were great and keen to help, taking and keeping luggage at the start and end of our stay. The rooms were very high quality, clean and well furnished as well as quite spacious compared to other hotels in Japan. We didn't eat in the hotels restaurants, as there were so many other places nearby, but they seemed very popular particularly at the weekend. The neighbourhood is quiet, not much traffic and quite green for somewhere so close to Shinjuku station, so would definitely recommend staying here if visiting Tokyo.

We had a premier grand room on the 39th floor. It was excellent - huge bed, comfy pillows, nespresso machine, excellent shower, big tv. With the Premier Grand we had access to the lounge on the 45th floor for breakfast - had a great Western selection - eggs done anyway you like, pastries, fruit, yoghurts, cheese etc. Location wise, 5 minutes from Shinjuku station (take the West Concorse exit!), near plenty of restaurants and nightlife. I think it was where the England RWC team were staying as we saw George Ford in the lobby!

Keio Plaza is right at Shinjuku Station. As such, it serves as a great base for Tokyo travels. But the prices keep ramping up and the rooms (I'm assigned) seem to keep getting smaller. This time it seems I had a convention of families who had adjacent rooms, yet decided to party in the hallway on a routine basis. Overall, I recommend, but maybe take a look at the tower/room choices to get the room (size) of your liking.

The hotel is magnificent in an old world style, the airport bus stops right at the hotel. Big selling point, plus the underground tunnels link it right to the train station. The bed is huge sleeps three easily: towels, pillows, kimonos all magnificent quality. Try the skytop lounge for evenings drinks for a magnificent view. Not cheap but totally worth it.

The location is super good as it is situated right in the heart of the Shinjuku where it is so near to the train station with the most lines in the city. It is easy access to food, shopping and transport which are all nearby. The rate is not cheap per night because of its location.

We visited Japan for our honeymoon (and the Rugby World Cup), and found the Keio Plaza a very nice place to start our tour of Japan. The room were very modern, with everything (blinds, lights etc) controllable from the bedside table. The hotel were very accommodating, allowing check in at around 1000, advice on travelling to Rugby matches, and even a welcome gift as it was our honeymoon.The 45th floor bar had spectacular views of the city at night, whilst on a clear day (we had none of these...) you can see Mount Fuji from the 45th floor breakfast lounge. Ideally located just a five minute walk from Shinjuku Station, as a result, pretty much everywhere in Tokyo is only half an hour away!

We stayed at the Keio Plaza for 6 nights in September 2019. This hotel runs like a well-oiled machine. From the moment we checked in, everything was perfect. The staff were all very welcoming and helpful, most of them spoke English too which was helpful for us!Our room was on the 29th floor and was quite spacious (I was warned that Japanese hotel rooms tend to be small!). They also provided a whole array of amenities, everything from face cleanser to a hair brush.There are 3 restaurant options for breakfast and there really is something for everyone here. I think Glass Court had the best selection. My only complaint is that the glasses for the juice/water were quite tiny!The location of this hotel is also really convenient, there is an underground walkway that connects to Shinjuku Station right next to the hotel.100% would recommend, would stay again if visiting Tokyo.Also, it's right across from the Metropolitan Government Building which has a free observation deck on the top floor! Well worth a visit too!

This hotel's staff was so helpful. We had a layover for 22hours. And wanted to do as much as possible. Airport Limosine drops off at hotel...super easy to get tickets at airport. The check in was very helpful and they helped me look info a evening food tour. Rooms were very comfortable. Excellent beds, hot showers with good pressure. Easy to book bus airport limo back to catch plane. I'd be happy to stay here again.

It is the second time that we visit the Keio Plaza in Tokyo. Our stay was just perfect: nice room on the 29th flloor, beautiful view on the Metropolitan Building, plenty of amenities that were replaced every day, spotless room, quiet environment and very close to Shinjuku Station through a pathway. Helpful staff. Ask for a renewed room.

Stayed here as part of a tour of Japan. Lovely room. Excellent dinner in the Aurora restaurant, they were very accommodating as I don’t eat fish. Breakfast buffet in the Jurin was also excellent. Would definitely recommend this hotel.

Arrived late at night, and had excellent room service sandwiches. Hotel restaurants were quite expensive so mostly ate out. Did have a couple of excellent meals there though. Good outdoor swimming pool - had to go down to reception to cross to the other tower of the hotel though. Clean and efficient hotel. A good central base to explore Tokyo. Stayed for five days before moving on. Go to the travel office early to book day and half day trips - most coaches stop outside. Taxi rank at entrances too. Have Sunrise tours and JBT travel. We went on a day trip to Mt.Fuji and a half day to the fish market and sushi making class which we'd highly recommend. Can walk to the shops, restaurants bars etc nearby. Very safe area. Short walk to the very busy Shinjuku train station for the Shinkansen trains.Also, worth going to to the viewing tower in the Metropolitan Government buiding opposite - it's free!! The hotel has two main entrances opposite each other on two streets which can be confusing.

We stayed here for four nights to watch early World Cup Matches. It is in a great location, good room service and very nice high quality rooms. The bathrooms is a perfect combination of Western and Japanese. It is worth getting the breakfast vouchers.

5 stars:The Airport Limousine stops right in front of the hotel.Concierge desk provides excellent services. Spacious room (booked a superior originally and got a subsequent upgrade).3 Stars:So-So front desk service. Don’t know why the front desk did not get us a porter while other receptionist called for a porter for other guests.WIFI did not work for our entire stay. Hotel website said 10% discount for the hotel guest to dine in their restaurants. When I went for the breakfast buffet and asked for guest discount, I was told the discount is only applicable for dinners. The hotel should make it clear. I gave 4 stars overall because the concierge guy went back and forth helping us with our luggages at our check out date. Otherwise, 3 stars, no doubt!
user_name:
JupiterM6
New York City, New York

review_body: It is my second stay here. (First one in 2014). Keio Plaza is a good hotel, big, place for conventions, lots of people around. But they manage to provide a very good service to everyone. Staff is attentive and accommodating. English speaking personnel always available. Price a little on the high side (Rugby World Cup may be?). One star dropped due to inconsistent wifi service (state of the art 5 years ago, iffy at best nowadays).

We come across a "manager" who provide NO SERVICE at all!!! It is very bad a hotel like Keio has him!We approach him wanting to ask a question. He pick up a phone say nothing. I stand there, wait a minute or two. He keeps holding the phone but say nothing!

My husband and I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel for four nights. A friend had recommended it. This hotel was a great base to explore Tokyo for the first time. It’s in a great location close to Shinjuku Station on the non-seedy side of Shinjuku. The hotel has a great selection for breakfast and you get to choose between three restaurants. We stayed in a renovated standard king room which was modern and clean but super small and a bit hard to stay in with two large suitcases. If I returned to Tokyo, I would stay in the hotel again, but would upgrade to a larger room type. We stayed in Tokyo for 1 night prior to returning to Australia and I wish we had stayed here rather than the Shinjuku Granbell.

The Keio Plaza Hotel was the last hotel that we stayed in Japan and it was a real disappointment. The rooms are small, amenities are few, the staff is very business like and not anywhere nearly as friendly as our other four hotels in Japan. The internet was intermittent, which was hard to believe given that the country seems so technical logical sophisticated. I would not recommend this hotel.

The room is so spacious and the views incredible. Very convenient location exiting at the train stations west exit. Love the lounge and the check in process. I’m sold and will stay here on any future trips. The attention to detail to the rooms and ammenities is top notch. I only checked in yesterday but so far am loving my stay here, my only regret is that I didn’t book for longer, but that gives me a good reason to come back to explore vibrant Tokyo and stay here again.

This place is 5 min walk from Shinjuku station west exit. Get your Suica card before you arrive-it comes in handy! Nice lobby with some shops. I bought one of the fancy dolls in Abiste store. A few souvenirs from gift shop. Lower level has convenient store and restaurants. Glass court was great breakfast buffet so definitely get that included. And hours are from like 5-10 am. Cool but expensive bar next to Italian restaurant. It was lounge-y and you can smoke in there. Teppanyaki restaurant is expensive but good-but be warned it’s not like American teppanyaki restaurants where the cooks are loud and entertaining. The cooks there don’t put on a show and don’t really talk. Top floor bar has great views!

Booked 2 rooms for 3 nights and enjoyed the location. Within 5 mins walk, great and affordable restaurants & shops are available at the Shinjuku station vicinity. Had superior rooms in the main tower. Although aged, the rooms & toilets are very well maintained & clean. Asked for adjoining rooms with internal door but was not given. Newspaper provided each morning was not requested but given. Restaurants on 2F are extremely pricey. Funny that 2F is below Lobby floor - thought that it would be above. A local park with excellent kids playground facilities is within 10 mins walk. The Metropolitan building with complimentary access for a scenic view of Tokyo from atop is just across the road. Airport limousine bus from Narita stops at the hotel lobby which is very convenient. Disappointed that staying adult guests have to pay USD20 to use the pool. During morning peak hours, waited more than 1/2 hour for the customer service desk served by 2 people. Should be at least manned by 3 for such a huge hotel. Hotel staff were all otherwise very professional and well trained.

What a great way to start our family holiday together ,our room was 5 star.Both myself and my wife enjoyed the sky bar lounge..very relaxing. the food at breakfast downstairs was varied and well cooked.Pool is over priced and wouldn't recommend it , but overall a great experience.

Centrally located large hotel in Shinjuku. The hotel has concierge service, 4 restaurants plus sky bar lounge, 24hr convenience store, money exchange and ATM machine. WIFI and breakfast included. Beds are comfortable, air conditioning and safe deposit box. Two complimentary 500ml water bottles included every day. Five minute walk to Shinjuku subway station, bars, shopping and restaurants. Green Yamanote line will cover all the main tourist spots.

Typical monster 5 star hotel. Inflated prices shiny floors etc but wait for it....I am 82 years old and obviously have stayed in over a thousand hotels in dozens of countries but this one wanted to charge me 2,000 yen for a dip in their pool!!!That is nearly $AUD 30! Unbelievable. Never in my life have I been asked to pay for a swim in a hotel pool.

Keio Plaza has everything and a lot more to have an excellent stay in Tokyo. We stayed in the Premier Grand Rooms which are amongst the largest. It’s not cheap but money well spent. The only downside is it’s did not come in connecting rooms but the kids were put right next door and in fact they said that they were happier it wasn’t connecting!One of the key reasons we stayed at Keio was the free bus to Disney. It was a time saver. This was key to get to Disney in good time and comfortably instead of the busy trains and still be in the heart of the city to get the bright lights Tokyo vibes. Just remember that you have to book the hotel’s bus seats about a month or more before you arrive to guarantee seats on the bus but as we went to Disney Sea during the week there was lots of room. The rooms were big. The feedback of many other hotels we researched were how small the rooms were. However, the Premier Grand rooms at Keio were big for any country. I liked the fact that the toilet, wash basins and bathroom (with both shower and bathtub) were separate sections of the room so time is not wasted waiting for the other person. These bathroom areas were also big and well laid out. And all the gadgets! You knew you were in Japan with the technology. Bluetooth bose system, lots of chargers, plug adapters and a portable WiFi device that we heard you can take anywhere with you to have free WiFi but we had our own so never tried it. Even the toilets were full of gadgets like opening for itself when you come in. The WIFi did have a two step login process that did not work well with iPhones so we had to call their IT help desk a few times. And it showed that they were prompt to arrive. A drawer full of toiletries that in other hotels you had to ask for like combs AND hair brushes, shavers, toothbrush set and boxes of stuff I didn’t open. Breakfast was great and the chef whipped up all kinds of omelettes - even the Benedict style which was a hit. The Premier Grand room had its own check in area, lounge and breakfast area so we never experienced the crowds on the mornings. There were some busy days where you had to wait a 5 - 10 minutes to be seated but things flowed and there were great views. We did try the other more general eating area when we had to get up earlier for the Disney bus and it wasn’t crowded that day and food was great, varied and well presented. The hotel had lots of additional services that made things very convenient. The Japanese seem bent on keeping you comfortable and keeping you happy. If you don’t look pleased about something they try to remedy it right away. The Concierge did all the research you needed and calls which you need if you don’t speak the language, there was a well known on-site tour company, a luggage service company to transfer your luggage to the next hotel etc. etc. Unlike other hotels in Japan, the English of the staff at Keio was very good and was a relief that they understood me. Try calling hotels in Japan on to get info and you’ll soon see what I mean. We tried the tea ceremony experience offered by the hotel. That was an excellent cultural experience and the host was wonderful and authentic. One tip is to sign up as member of Keio Plaza. I am not sure on the criteria but I got some discounts on the room rate. The hotel was right opposite the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observatory which offers a free viewing deck and had great views. The hotel is about 10mins walk to the Shinjuku train station which is main train hub in Tokyo so you are well connected. Sometimes this walk was a hassle so we took taxis if we were not in the mood to walk. Just bear in mind that most taxis in Tokyo take only 4 persons so if you are more than 4 then pre-book a large taxi or you have to take 2 taxis. I decided to cut short my stay by a day as we did everything we wanted to do in Tokyo so wanted an extra day in Kyoto. I gave the hotel a few days notice and they didn’t make it a problem and organized the refund without fuss. I really can’t praise enough this hotel and their wonderful staff. The Premier Grand room experience, Disney bus, excellent level off English and so many convenient services in one place made it a hotel I would highly recommend.

Location, time and person details: -manager desk (small desk in front of the reception hall),-7:20p.m. 2th september 2019-burned skin, tall man in a tuxedo.Facts:-We asked the hotel manager to make a phone call for a dinning restaurant reservation for the 14th of September. ( all foreigners we know who difficult sometimes is to book things on your own because of the language).- the hotel manager DENIED TO HELP US since by that time (14th sep) we haven’t planned to stay in the same hotel so we will not be his guests anymore. He had a fake smile and was unkind and mean. Come on, I was your guest on the 2th september, if i asked you to make a reservation for the 14th, you have to do it. I do not understand and it is nonsense.You expecte from this kind of hotels excellence in cooperation and not this kind of greedy behavior, and the worst of all from the manager itself. However, the other stuff was more respectful, kind and helpful.

The intimate tea ceremony in the Sho-fu-an room on the 10th floor of Keio Plaza was a real highlight of our visit to Tokyo. The tea master was friendly and informative. The room itself was beautiful, able to accommodate traditional Japanese style or a Western style seating for those who have bad knees. It's a great intriduction to a special part of Japanese culture.

Nice hotel, great location, friendly staff. We would stay here again. Central to all the hot spots around Tokyo.
