Our room (for around $100AUD more per night) gave us access to the luxe lounge, which we used most nights and it was probably the highlight of the hotel for us.The luxe lounge is located on the 33rd floor and has good views out over the city. Snacks are provided & change throughout the day (cheese and dessert later in the night etc), they are very basic (the hotel could definitely improve the selection). Soft drinks, juice coffee provided all day with a good range of beer, wine & spirits provided for two hours during the evening. There are a great range of restaurants directly under the hotel if you don’t feel like moving too far. The buffet is one of the best hotel budgets we’ve ever had with a great selection. Train station is close by. (Photo of luxe - late night selection)

My wife and I booked in here before and after a cruise. Keio Plaza Hotel is in a Great location only a few minutes walk to Shinjuku station and subway.Provide bottled water in room and nice size rooms.Have a few different eating place and a few cafe and 7/11 across the road. 5 minute walk and there are heaps of eating places.You can book tours down in lobby.It is a very busy Hotel.Bus leave to airport from hotel.Only downfall is you cannot book in until 2.0pm.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza for 8 nights with my children while visiting Tokyo and we were very happy with our room and facilities.Location: the hotel is literally across the street from the West exit (Shinjuku Station). We took the JR Narita Xpress train from Narita Airport to the hotel it was a breeze! Being steps from the Shinjuku station also means easy access to all the different districts/activities Tokyo has to offer. It is also a great location for teenagers with lots of big malls, cool restaurants and arcades. Everything is 5 to 20 min walk from the hotel.Room: our room was big enough to fit 3 twin beds (bigger than our twin beds in North America) and we still had space to line up our suitcases on the wall with plenty of room to go by. The room was equipped with a two seater bench and a table, a mini fridge and a kittle. We were on the 23rd floor with a beautiful view of the Metropolitan Building. Bathroom was decent and very clean.Facilities: there are approx 6 restaurants in the basement but we did not try any. As for the pool: I took my son to the « Sky » pool on one occasion and was shocked to find out I had to pay 2,200 yen to use the pool facilities; that was one of the biggest disappointment. I would have turned around but it was 45 degrees outside and my son was excited so we stayed and paid the fee. It was such a waste; the pool is small, the pool AND the area around are very dated, and there are no views but a few concrete walls. Staff: everyone was very helpful. The concierge made, at our request, dinner reservations for us throughout our stay and the cleaning staff would regularly check in on us toward the end of each day to make sure we were satisfied with the cleaning. Great convenient hotel for families, I would definitely recommend!!!

This international deluxe hotel offers a high standard hospitality service. The high number of employees makes service efficient. Everyone is on their toes. If you look disoriented, from nowhere there is someone next to you offering assistance. The restaurants are also very good in their own rights. Expensive prices but the quality and service offered go to par. The Sushi was astounding. You can come to this property with just your clothes. Everything else is provided. From ear cotton swabs to pijamas they think of everything, even toothbrush. Never have I seen this before. The rooms in the old building are better than the new South Tower. The location allows for strolling, shopping and other places to eat. Rate varies from 195.00USD plus tax. It's worth it. There are many other services in the hotel for guests convenience.

Very elegant hotel . Have 7 restaurants and bars and lounges . Provides free shuttle to Disney land . It is centrally located to most attractions . They have Japanese breakfast and also western breakfast. The rooms are big and very good. The hotel staff speaks English. The price of rooms is good. Value for money . Highly recommend for families .

Very big hotel in the middle of city. Very nice location near department store. Room size is OK. Very clean. The hotel is very buay though, full of people with tour I think. Overall very nice stay. Will definitely come back here if we visit Tokyo.

We spent 4 nights here before getting on a cruise. The location was pretty good-near to a major subway stop. Room was fine-hotel was crowded and there were signs up about delays in getting elevators. We found the hotel restaurants to be over priced and rather mediocre. Several nights we were exhausted (from the heat/humidity) and it was all we could do to get to a hotel restaurant-very disappointing. We found a nearby Starbucks and that was where we went for breakfast.

Stayed here for 6 nights recently. Great location in Shinjuku. 5 minutes walk to malls and train station. It's also a drop-off and pick-up point for the Airport Limo bus service. hotel also provide free shuttle service to Disneyland/Sea.so, it's convenient.room was spacious enough (bearing in mind rooms in Japan may be smaller than in other countries). They are clean, large very comfy bed and pillows. great housekeeping job.stayed at level 29, so had a great viewstaff are polite and prompt and able to accommodate requests without much hassle. My daughters' room was not very near ours. Requested to shift nearer. the staff called office and made the change immediately. All done with just 1 phone call and within 5 minutes.checking in and out were fast too.kudos to team.suggestions for improvement.1) have a night light system where we can control the brightness;2) shuttle service from Disneyland to pick up at 9pm instead of current 7pm (too early). the next timing is 10.50pm. OK i guess, but could be very later for some;3) more Eng TV channels pls;thanks.Azlan

We had the best rooms in the hotel, called Premier Grand (or so). The rooms were great, the view could have been better, despite me specifically asking for the best view possible (oh well). Everything except the following was on par with a great 4 to average 5* hotel:1) we chose the hotel because of great on-site dining. We stayed for 5 nights and were unable to dine in their “better” establishments, such as sushi or teppanyaki. Alegedly they were solidly booked but whenever we passed through, most seats were empty.2) housekeeping was not great. They left some dirt on the back of the shelves throughout the 5 days we stayed. The quality of bed linen varied. And during the only day we needed to stay in for the afternoon, they left all our three rooms until late and made us leave and go out.3) the pool had a weird regulation, not allowing people with earrings on. Both my daughters and me have earrings fixed so that they’re impossible to take out. When I explained this, they countered by saying that it would be unfair to other guests who had removed their jewellery to let us in. After some discussion, they brought us plasters to stick on our ears to cover the earrings. The plasters eventually fell off in the water, but since we had them in the first place, everything was all right. Weird.4) several times I came accross a very strong request to bring in all the key cards. If we’d not complied, there were fines to be levied. Again, weird.Overall, it is a hotel I would recommend. However, for myself, I would try to look at other options in the 4-5* better priced range.To end on the good note, we were really pleased with the services in the Premier Lounge. Breakfasts were great, even if sometimes quite crowded. But particularly look for the very knowledgeable, efficient and courteous Ms. Ishikawa, who had great recommendations for us and was able to solve almost anything for us.

easy access to major landmarks in Shinjuku, great access to the metro and JR lines, many shops and restaurants around the areas. only issue is the area is crowded and full of people. great for couples or family with young kids.

Excellent luxury hotel with good amenities and world class onsite dining.Be aware: if you have a lot of heavy luggage, there is a decently long walk to the hotel from Shinjuku Station. There is even an underground passage with weekday access to a moving walkway but that is not operational in the evening or during weekends.

I love this hotel! It's very nice inside, and the shopping on the lower floors is excellent. I really enjoyed the cute radio in the night stand in the room. I shared the room with a friend and we both had plenty of room, which is not something you can often say at Japanese-style hotels. My Japanese teacher's comment was that she had "dreamed of staying in a hotel like this." The nearby area is very convenient too with shopping, food, and entertainment.

Our room was clean and pleasant. The bed was a little firmer than I'm used to but fine. The location of the hotel was fantastic. It is connected to the Shinjuki station (via tunnels) and across the street from the Tokyo Metropolitan Building which has an amazing observatory on the top floor (that is free to go up!). We enjoyed the breakfast buffet at the hotel restaurant and were delighted by the variety and quality of food offered - both traditional Japanese fare and American/European. Of all the Japanese hotels we stayed in, this one had the best fitness room equipped with cardio machines, free weights and a few weight machines.

If you have read about our disater with the first hotel, this is where we ended up. We had learnt our lesson on children and bed arrangements in Japanese hotels and we copped to it. No way we were giving our money to the other hotel! Now, I have read some oft he other reviews here and I do agree with much of what is said about the hotel. Our experience was extremely courteous staff during a busy evening period and a willingness to explain all about the rooms and fees including showing us diagrams of rooms and bed sizes. We were welcomed to book using a web app, nad staff came to find us the moment the booking came through. In that time, thaey had arranged the third bed for our room (three king singles), placed our bags on the trolly, delivered them to the room, and we were in! Given the previous couple of hours, it was a relief. If you had seen the wife's distress at the other hotel, you would know how I felt.This really is a typical mid-high level hotel. It was expensive, but then again, these hotels are expensive in Japan but is is backled up with good service, amenities complimentary items and even an English language copy of the Japan Times at the door in the morning. All the expected facilities are there, including numerous resturaunts, cafe, bakery and a great little convenience store on the lower level. The hotel is accross from the municpal bulding with it's free observation deck and you can walk to and from Shinjuku station completely undercover. We also chose to book a Mt Fuji tour from the hotels tour office, whic depated from the hotel but dropped us at Shinjuku at the end. Great for finding dinner! We didn't eat in the hotel as that was not the experience we wanted and we felt the prices were a bit inflated. Checkout was smooth and quick. I really did like the staff here. Room was a little cramped with the extra bed, but that was our problem, not the hotels. Great bathroom, with a huge tub, lots of hot water, amenites and even hte mirror was heated over the basin so you could shave in the fog. Tea and coffee facilities were ther but no milk or sugar. I think this is just a culture difference and not a cost exersize. This part of Shinjuku goes pretty quiet after dark so no worries with road noises etc. Overall, a nice stay but expensive. Probably a lot cheaper as part of a package tour, which semed to be most of their bsuiness.

The hotel was quite large but we did not have to wait long for check in and out. The rooms were spacious, considering its Tokyo. We stayed in the renovated room which was modern (many USB ports) and clean. Room service was also good and generally the service was nice. Location is also decent, 10 mins from the main station. Definitely would return!

Check in was cold and quick although there wasn’t much guest around when we checked in. Having arrive from Kyoto, this wasn’t comparable to smaller boutique hotels where check in is warm and personal as this is a big hotel after all.Was disappointed as we didn’t get the nice amenities seen in reviews here and when my husband called to request to change room, intending to upgrade if necessary but was immediately turned down citing there are no rooms available. Room was basic, service could have been better. Only consolation was the location which it’s not in the midst of all the hype yet not too far away.

This is the typical convention-type hotel. It's huge with multiple towers and fairly centrally-located. While it has many restaurants and services on-premise, they are all very, very expensive versus walking a block or two away.We stayed here because we felt that it was going to be a premium experience. It wasn't. It was just an average, but expensive experience. I would not stay here again.It is absolutely not a 4.5-star hotel. My room and the common areas were extremely dated. I suspect you can stay nearby for half the price, get a better room in a smaller hotel, and at least an equal level of service.The location, however, is fairly central to many restaurants and the train station.

My family and I stayed here in June for 4 nights (3 adults, 1 toddler). We booked this hotel based on the reviews and photos we've read and seen online. While the hotel is rated 5 stars, the room itself didn't feel like 5 stars. The room especially the bathroom felt outdated. Yes the room is clean and fairly spacious for Japanese standards, it just didn't quite meet my expectations considering it's rated 5 stars and it was the most expensive hotel we booked on the trip. Our room was on the South Tower and we had a view of an empty building. The toiletries and Handy phone were pretty cool. The complimentary shuttle bus to Disneyland & Disneysea was very convenient too. Although you need to book this in advance as it's very popular. The hotel's location is pretty good too. Very close to restaurants, shops and JR station all within walking distance. (However, JR station is not as close (on foot) if travelling with loads of luggages and small children.) There's plenty of restaurants in the hotel itself, some shops, an art gallery and a convenience store. The staff at front desk is friendly, helpful and professional. Unfortunately, we didn't get to see the swimming pool as it was still close and they only open it during the summer months. We only missed it by a week! I would probably stay here again but would check other options.

My family and I spent 2 nights here at this hotel. We chose to book this hotel based on comment on expedia and after knowing that it had an airport shuttle parked right in front of the hotel (and partly bec of L'occitane ) But after I booked, I came to read more review on TripAdvisor and realized that I need to go back for room upgraded since there normal rooms seemed to be the ones that get all the complaint. After upgraded to newly decorated room, I found out that at the price I paid, my family and I could booked the rooms at Hilton Tokyo with same area. But nothing could ne done since it is refundable. Once we arrived at the hotel, it seemed that everything about this hotel had it cost. We ask for late check out since we had a shuttle at noon, they asked us to pay. We parked our car for 35 mins, we had to pay. Rooms were new with quite a generous space. But the service was so so. Nothing impressive but nothing terrible to complain about. But might not repeat our booking.

After reading all the amazing reviews about this hotel, we were excited about arriving. However, the hotel did not live up to these. We have never written a review before and never normally complain. But the way we were treated and the smell of our room, we thought we had too.When we arrived the lady at the desk was lovely, the lobby itself was very impressive too. The lady even gave us a free box of chocolates as it was our honeymoon. We went up to our room looking forward to a bit of time to relax before heading out. As we entered the room we were greeted with a very very strong smell of smoke. It was as if someone had spent the last couple of days smoking in it. We went back out of the room to check that it was definitely a non smoking room, which it was, as there was a no smoking sign on the door. My husband went back down to the lobby to mention this to them and see if we could switch rooms. He was told to come back after 17:00 and they would sort it. They sent a man up to the room with a machine, we weren’t quite sure what it did, but it honestly made it smell worse. Feeling optimistic that it would be sorted during the afternoon, we went out for a bit. When we got back we headed up to the room to see if it still smelt of smoke, it smelt just as bad. So my husband went back down to the lobby. On returning he mentioned that it was a waist of time, that he shouldn’t have bothered as the only response to his questions was no and that apparently we booked a smoking room. Bearing in mind the room we were given when checking in was a non smoking room made me question what was being said about this. The staff had refused to change our room and refused to compensate us. So we felt a little annoyed and thought we would wait until the morning and see how the smell went. However, this was not the case and it got worse. During our time at the hotel we weren’t able to sleep through the night and would wake up coughing because of the smoke. The smell of smoke got everywhere and wasn’t very nice at all. I am glad we only booked this hotel for 3 nights. I wouldn’t recommend this hotel to friends and family. There are lots of nicer hotels in and around Tokyo, I would strongly recommend you book these.

This hotel is quite well situated and the lobby and common area are nice. The rooms however fall short. Our room, although spacious for Tokyo, had stained carpets and a badly stained bath.The breakfast, while offering a fair variety of food, is only okay. We had better breakfasts whilst staying at the Sunroute, a much cheaper hotel.The gym also falls short offering very limited equipment and dumbbells only up to about 5kg. We did not even try the pool area as at an additional cost of 2000 yen per person for each use, we felt it was I unreasonably expensive. I have never stayed in a hotel where you are expected to pay extra for pool use, although I believe it is common in Japan. Overall the staff were polite and the room was spacious and clean, even though it was in need of a fair amount of attention. Not terrible but not fantastic.

An excellent hotel, very good location in Shinjuku, fairly priced for the quality of the property and services. Several restaurants are located within the hotel. Not a 5-star property but an excellent hotel and value. Recommended

My husband and I stayed here in Tokyo, and were very happy with the quality of the hotel. We stayed in the South Tower in a standard room, which was simple but a comfortable and clean place to rest. Right when we first got to the hotel, I noticed my phone was missing, and Inoue at the front desk was able to call the company for the shuttle we had taken from the airport to help find it. My phone was back in my possession that evening and I was very grateful for Inoue's help since it would have been difficult to navigate the language barrier myself.We received breakfast coupons for each day of our stay, and found each of the 3 restaurant options for breakfast to be very enjoyable. It was a great value to have breakfast included, and the food was very good. I also used the Disney shuttle service to go to and from the park, which was quite comfortable and convenient.Overall, it was a very nice stay at this hotel, and we found it to be pleasantly quiet at night. It's located close to several subway stations, so it made for a great place to stay while we were in Tokyo.

We visited the Keio Plaza for the Cindarella dessert buffet.There were some hot and cold savoury options and lots of sweet items. There were a great choice of drinks that were included in the price. The desserts were delicious and very nicely presented.

We've been choosing Keio Plaza as the hotel of choice for the past 17 years. It all began with my dad who also chose to stay at KEIO 40 years ago. We travel to Japan almost every year (sometimes 3x a year). This time we stayed at KEIO for a week and it was horrible / bad. Bed linens were dirty / stained. There was a piece of tissue paper on the carpet by the entrance of our room since day one (the housekeeping maid never both to vacuum?). Black stains found by the bath tub, faucet, sink, even toilet bowl (again housekeeping maid never both to brush the toilet bowl throughout out stay. The carpet on the 2nd floor where the restaurants are is getting dirty / stains. Worst one is the service / manners provided by the front desk. We asked if we can have a late check out (check out at noon instead of 11am), they offer no apology / 'sorry for the inconvenience', but bluntly stated there will be an additional 4xxx yen for the additional hour. There's no recourse, no explanation, nothing, just the additional fee if we wanted to stay 1 extra hour. Of course we decided not to despite the amount of business we brought to KEIO throughout the years starting with my father 40 years ago! This hotel has great location in Shinjuku, but the service, manners, cleanness have gone down drastically especially last few years. We are seriously considering giving our business to another hotel next time we go to Tokyo. (breakfast at the Super Buffet restaurant was a rush for food)

A drop site for the Friendly airport limousine bus which made it convenient and much much cheaper than a taxi.Check in was fast and cheerful. The room that I was given was much more spacious than I anticipated. Maids did an excellent job.The facilities for a 6000 plus conference were as good as can be. Excellent A/V. Very efficient/helpful staff. I asked for an iron/ironing board the first day and they didn't take it away over the next 3 days.Multiple good on-site restaurants though expensive as one would expect in Tokyo. If you prefer to go local/cheaper there are plenty of small restaurants within a 5 minute walk towards Shinjuku station. The "business office" is primitive and unstaffed. For 100 Yen you can print up to 4 pages by bringing a USB and exact change (no change)This is not in the tourist end of the city and the tours (two) offered by the separate travel agency were not particularly attractive.Checkout was effortless. They issued my bus ticket for the airport as I had called ahead the day before to make the reservation with extension #6. It took 3/4 hour on a Sunday to reach the international terminal.

This hotel is walkable from Shinjuku station despite how large the station is and its numerous exits.The room was based in the south tower and was spacious with a decent size bathroom which included a shower/bath and the wizz-bang Japanese toilet. Outside the bathroom was a small wash basin and wardrobe which contained the room safe.The bed was large for a double and very comfortable. The room also included a couch and work desk.My room overlooked the Tokyo metropolitan building which is across the street.Location wise, Shinjuku station is a 10 minute walk away and Omoide Yokocho, Kabukicho, and Shinjuku Golden-Gai are close by as well. Restaurant wise, I only ate breakfast at Jurin Restaurant which was predominantly western buffet style restaurant with some Japanese and Asian options. The food was outstanding with a wide variety of hot and cold dishes, pastries, salads and cold cuts of meat. It was surreal one morning when a minor earthquake hit Tokyo (the floating floors dimmed the impact of it). The Main Bar was the only place I experienced a drink at the hotel and the bar staff were exceptional.Location wise, there is plenty of dining options at the hotel or in the local area, plus the joys of Shinjuku are all in a walkable distance (10-20 minutes) depending upon where you want to go to.

This was my first time at Keio Plaza and definitely not the last. I was little skeptical before making my reservation mostly because of some of the negative reviews but after spending 7 nights I became a big fan. I stayed at their Premier Grand club floor with access to the lounge including breakfast and pre dinner snacks. Pros for the room: high quality men and woman skin care, high quality bath amenities, high quality iron/steam (practical for business folks), amazing view, high quality bedCons: bad WiFi connection. I had to reconnect every hour and sometimes every 30 minutes, its very annoying, especially when you are in business trip and have video call. The room is little small, if you are a couple and have lots of clothes and two big suitcases.Pros for the hotel: well located, very nice staff, very helpful. The breakfast at the lounge was high quality and the omelette chef was great and an artist. The afternoon snacks was outstanding with an amazing choice of wines (five star level). Cons: I like to swim but their outdoor pool was very cold, they even told me to not try to get in. That's too bad for such a great hotel. There are half a dozen restaurants at the second level, I try some of them including Jurin and I was not impressed.Overall: Excellent hotel with high quality amenities and services, well located

The manner of the front desk staffs was terrible, bad services, , the hotel is old , noisy, unstable air condition , I need to wait half hr to wait to fix it , it’s expensive, still need to take walk at lease 10 -15 minutes to the shopping area , I will never choose this hotel again!

We got a good deal on a room at Keio Plaza. This hotel is in a great location because you don’t deal with all the noise of Shinjuku as this is about a half mile from Shinjuku station where all the activity is. Had a blast, great hotel service and super friendly staff. They went above and beyond to make sure that we were comfortable.Additionally, a lot of the tours, which save you a ton of time and allow you to see way more than you would be able on your own, leave from the lobby.

My daughter and I are just now checking out of our premier grand room and I can’t say enough wonderful things about our room and staff! We stayed for 4 nights and we received 8 coupons for free breakfast, used in your choice of 4 restaurants. Breakfast was yummy but hot choices never changed in 4 days. I would suggest a bit of variation to breakfast buffet in the glass house. Our room can equipped with modern furnishings throughout and included and iPad and a “handy” mobile phone for your usage while in Tokyo. Free local and international calls on the phone!! The amenities in our room were wonderful top end soaps and lotions. The beds were very comfortable and the bathroom was clean and very modern! We used the premier grand lounge each night for drinks and loved the staff!! Everyone was so kind and helpful! My only gripe was the food in the lounge in the evening never changed. Maybe add a little more variety. Otherwise, the lounge was superbly wonderful!!Thank you Keio staff for your hospitality!! We will definitely return soon to your beautiful country!!

Stayed at Keio Palza Tokyo in June and we enjoyed every moment in this wonderful hotel. The location of Keio hotel is just near to Shinjuku Station. I landed in the evening in Tokyo Narita Airport and took a very simple and easy train Narita Express from Narita airport to Shinjuku Station. In Shinjuku take the west exit and follow the Gouverment Building sign. The easiest way to find Keio Hotel is to look for pillar with “D” letter. When you find D60 in the left is Keio Plaza Hotel.The check in was completely Japanese (very gracious and very fast) and I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the room as I had heard all rooms in Tokyo were very small.The staff are friendly and helpful in every way. The room was bright, well decorated and had some fantastic details, not only the usual toiletries with a large assortment of toiletries (hotel supply an elastic hair band HOW COOL IS THAT) but shoe shining cloths, power adaptors, supply of mineral water every day and a wonderful Japanese toilet with heated seat. I would love one of those at home! Beds and pillows were very comfortable.Very rich breakfast in 2 different styles Japanese and Western style. I tried every day some Japanese cuisines and it is very good. Udon and soup of day are two best thing I have at breakfast. Also the algae are something unusual to eat.One of the amenities in the room is the free use of a smart phone with internet. Phone is located in the room on the desk. There is free Internet on it and Google Map was very helpful in big city of Tokyo. Phone will ask for a departure date and later tell you that it will erase all personal data after date you check out. Everything was in English. Free use of a smart phone is definitely a plus.I would like to thank to all of the staff from Keio for making as an enjoyable stay, and a special thanks to Ayaka Hagi and Shingo Kobori for helping me.Keio Plaza Hotel makes a great landing pad for our first Tokyo visit. I would definitely stay again when I return. Hope to see you soon.美しくありがとう

Spent the better part of a week at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku in June, and the wife and I were both pleasantly surprised. We weren't sure what to expect, given the property's age, but we were very impressed throughout our stay. The service was excellent, the room much larger than we expected, a fantastic view from our room, and VIP treatment at the Luxe Lounge every day during our stay. We opted for a Plaza Luxe room with Luxe Lounge access, which gave us a high (33) floor room in the South Tower. We were very impressed and surprised by the size and spaciousness of the room, along with the breathtaking view. In the foreground was the impressive Tocho complex, with Mt. Fuji standing watch in the background. It was really pretty cool. The complimentary snacks, drinks, etc. served in the lounge were great, and the service was excellent. They obviously make an effort to treat the guests like VIPs. We obviously paid a bit more than a standard room, but it was definitely worth the minimal extra cost. Service throughout the hotel was truly exceptional. Another pleasant surprise was the location. We expected it to be further from Shinjuku station, but it turned out to be a short, straight, 5-minute walk at most. And right through the bustling Shinjuku west-gate area filled with stores, restaurants, and bars. In terms of transportation access, the location really can't be beat. Extremely convenient, in fact. Plenty to do, see, eat, and drink just steps from the hotel.The wife and I both agreed that Keio Plaza will be our new home-base from now on for all future trips to Tokyo.

We booked a triple room on an Amex platinum discount, having 1 free night for every 3 nights booked. Upon arrival, we were given non-renovated rooms in the old South Tower. Room was old, small, dusty (I couldn't stop sneezing everytime I'm in the room, which was quite abit given I try to sleep 8 hours a night) and dingy. Nothing at all like what I saw on websites and most photos posted by other travellers who got the renovated rooms. Perhaps these are non-promo full price paying guests. Toiletries were also not the Loccitane ones as advertised in many photos. When I enquired, I wasn't given a satisfactory response. The bell girl who was helping me with the enquiries was however pleasant and tried her best to help.Check in time was not at all flexible with many guests waiting in the lobby for 3pm. I was carrying a newborn who was fussy after a 8 hour flight and it was not at all fun standing in a lobby with a screaming baby.At check out, I asked an old gentleman (who looked like the manager of the bell counter) for help with the vending machine to buy bus tickets. He looked at me and ignored me, walking off mumbling... I was shocked. Also, I had to do some repacking and weighing of my luggage (carried away shopping) and was very happy to hassle with the carrying of luggage in and out of behind the counter (with a newborn strapped to me). However when a male white guy came, the old gentleman bell boy manager of some sort very quickly carried the weighing scale out for him unprompted! Goodness... I then sat and observed his behavior to other guests and noted similar trends. Unkind to anything other than white males...Not a hotel id recommend at all. There are many other more decent options in the area like Hyatt.

New property, room was top the line up-dated, great Wi-Fi, front desk very helpful and friendly and they speak English. Great location 5 minutes walk distance from train station and Kyoto Tower, lots of shopping, shrines, places to eat. Loved Kyoto + Loved this hotel

My first trip to Tokyo and after A LOT of research (and price comparisons) on where to stay I landed on Keio Plaza Hotel. And I am soooo very happy I did. What an amazing place! Terrific location near a major subway stop that goes everywhere. Rooms are incredibly clean and maintained by a great staff. You are treated like royalty by everyone. They noticed it was my birthday and there was chocolate with a birthday card in my room. How cool is that?? Convenience store on the ground floor. Several very good restaurants. GREAT city view from the rooftop bar. I had some computer trouble (with the internet) and they had someone in my room to deal with it in minutes!! One of my favorite things about this place is that they give you a smart phone to take with you during your stay. You can make FREE local and international calls on this phone. Yes! True! Amazing! I didn't believe it myself until I got there....and it is real. I mean, you can't talk for an hour from Tokyo to NY but you can stay in touch with folks. What a treat!! (Why don't more places do this?) My one and only "complaint" about the place is the rather inflated cost of breakfast....$30+. Though, I have to admit, it is a petty great buffet with all kinds of food. (Tokyo is an expensive city, so you just go with it!) I cannot wait to go back to Tokyo and this is the only place I will stay.
user_name:
Fuzzy525
New York City, New York

review_body: Its a huge hotel in Shinjuku. We got a Club room and the room’s spacious and clean. Its a short walk to the restaurant strip in Shinjuku and a 10-min walk to Shinjuku station. The lounge is a bit plain and basic but offers a great view of the city. Staff are nice. We booked the Mt Fuji tour and the meeting place was in this hotel, very convenient!

Just checked into the hotel and was served by a lady who was impolite and unlike any check-in staff we've met. She was pissed off and showed her unhappiness after we insisted for a baby cot. After she directed our request to another man, my wife thanked her and she did not even bother to smile and thank us back. There was no service provided by her whatsoever. The man who took over from her brought us up to our room and he was so much more polite and patient with us.

We stayed here twice. Our first room was in the South Tower. The room needed a renovation and the carpet was dirty. The view was spectacular. We had a view of Mt. Fuji. Our 2nd stay was a few days later. We had a room in the main tower. The room was clean and updated. We had an ironing board/iron, L’Occitane shampoos and soaps, an air purifier, nicer towels, robes and slippers. Our view wasn’t as nice but the room definitely was nicer than the South Tower. If you can book a room with breakfast, the Glass Court buffet is worth it. Great selection of foods. The hotel is convenient to a lot of restaurants and a few blocks from the train station. There is a bus that takes you to Disneyland and Disney Sea. Reserve seats early and be certain about return times. They don’t allow you to take an earlier bus back to the hotel if you’re tired and didn’t book that exact time. The airport limousine bus stops at the hotel. We had a super early flight. The bus pick up didn’t work for us. We ended up paying $300 for a taxi. We could’ve taken the train but the times didn’t work for us either.

Firstly I must say that the hotel was excellent in responding to my emails and got back to me with very good detailed information and got back very quickly. I was disappointed when we checked in by the person who checked us in. They were the only ones who seemed not very friendly. The first impression is a lasting one. The concierge was So Very Helpful in helping us plan our activities. The location is good and we walked to and from the train station. We thought the breakfast was way too expensive but we just ate at the train station and there is a lot of variety there. We had a nice view from our room.

Keio Plaza (South wing) hotel is a great place to stay and is within walking distance to shinjuku JR and shops. The hotel staff are friendly and they can communicate fairly well in English :). The breakfast spread is good and delicious. Sheets and towels are clean. Will definitely stay there again when in shinjuku area.

I stayed at Keio Plaza for 3 nights at the end of my trip in Japan. I arrived to Shinjuku Station around 7pm on a Friday and it was very very busy. After I felt like I was walking around in circles in order to find my correct direction, I realized how close this hotel really was to lots of sights and transportation options. There’s a very busy couple blocks of restaurants/stores which was daunting to walk through solo at night but I quickly got over that. Check in at Keio was easy and my room was clean. I can’t remember if I was in the Main or South tower but I was pleased with the accommodations. Word to those who want to use their airport shuttle...book upon your arrival! I didn’t think the 6:15 AM shuttle on a Monday AM to Haneda would be booked but it was for me! I ended up having to take an earlier one to play it safe...oh well. Happy to answer questions!

The concierge was the least bit helpful. I don’t know if it was because of a language barrier or if they literally only help with booking things inside of the hotel but they wouldn’t help me find a cake for my sisters birthday (that was outside of the hotel) or call our tour company when our private transfer was 15 minutes late. Apparently, it is not their job.The WiFi is HORRENDOUS. It’s a 4 step process and you have to log back in every single time. It’s also unreliable.This is definitely a three or four star hotel. There is absolutely no service. The cake we had for her birthday as well as dirty plates and cutlery were sitting there for two whole days before we finally checked out. No one cleaned it.The beds are hard as rocks. We slept on futon on the floor at our ryokans and that was a great experience, but these mattresses at Keio plaza...terrible! These were my worst nights of sleep during our entire month-long trip.You are just one of the masses here. There is no special touch.We booked through a travel agent so we had breakfast included...and let me tell you, the breakfast buffet is meh.Would not recommend this hotel if you’re looking for a spectacular experience...or an experience at all. (Go to a ryokan for that.)Great for literally just sleeping, other than that I wouldn’t spend any time here.

Location was central in Shinjuku area. Underground access to subway was within short walk from hotel. Direct airport limousine stop with complimentary Disney resort shuttle for hotel guests.Check in and check out service were swift. Service was prompt but at times a little stern.Had a family room with 4 beds and 2 toilets at main tower. Very suitable for families with kids in tow.

Stayed quite a few times here In the past if you book yourself not as a group then you pay more but get good rooms If in a group the standard rooms are quite small and you hear your next door neighbour in the shower or watching tv the sound just carries Be aware of checking in 1500policy not before We had an event that started at 1400 being held at the hotel for 160 people followed the next day with another event in house still no early check in at 1330after arriving at 1230 from Korea I think if you are doing major events over 2 days a bit of flex would help especially when checking out at 6 in the morning on departure date

Keio plaza hotel is a very good hotel in Shinjuku. It is located in the quieter part of Shinjuku but very convenient to explore Shinjuku by foot and well located near subway stations so it is easy to travel to other parts of Tokyo.The hotel itself is very good. The staff were very helpful and nice. The room and the facilities were great. The pool was not open during our stay but the lounge was very nice and the view from the room and from the lounge is perfect.Highly recommend!

We had the superior south triple room. It’s very new even with 3 beds, it’s spacious. Check in was fast. It was so easy to book the airport limo at the bell counter at the lobby. located around 7mins walk from Shinjuku Station, it maybe a little confusing to walk from underground.

Always stay at this hotel when I travel for business to the Tokyo area. During my stay they were renovating the gym. That’s a good thing because it wasn’t a great gym for such a nice hotel. Am looking forward to staying again!

Location of the hotel is not that close to the Railways depends on where you are going. Room was not clean at all, hairs were everywhere inside the bathroom and dirts were found on curtain when checking in. Apart from the Lady checked us in was good, other staff was unhelpful and rude. The wheel of my suitcase was damaged, I asked some help from Information Counter, the western guy just showed me somewhere on a map with a building‘s name but without specify the shop’s name, do you expect your client to carry a big suitcase hanging around the city to find an uncertain place for fixing the suitcase. You need to log in the hotel WiFi every time when you return to hotel! Lastly just required half an hour or one more hour of extension on departure, the aged man at the Information Counter just replied you “can not, it’s a charge”with a cool face! I understood that it might be your hotel policy but would you please reply in a courtesy manner. I do not expect such experiences would happen in a hotel with a star! It was my first time stayed in this hotel and also it would be the last time too! You can have a lot of choices on hotel selection if under this price! I absolutely will not recommend to any of my friends!

This was my second business trip to Tokyo and my first stay in this hotel. At first I wasn't sure if it was a good idea to switch from my previous experience (Hilton) which was excellent. After staying there for 6 nights I can say confidently that it was a very pleasant experience. The only take was one day where I had to wait to get have my breakfast. Other than that...don't hesitate. Excellent location and excellent service.

I remembered there is a Tokyo Marathon happening when we stayed and it feels like winter. A bit long walk to the MRT but the rooms are spacious. We also had the best high tea in this hotel. They have tours and malls near by.

We stayed 3 nights at the Hotel Keio plaza in order to take in the Sumo Championships and had a very pleasurable experience. The hotel was spotless throughout and all staff were extremely smart and so polite and helpful. The public areas are very spacious and beautifully furnished.Our room was large and very well equipped with toiletries and had 2 types of beautiful robes for us to relax in. Like all other hotels that we stayed in, there were no little milks for Western tea-crema was available but how vile is that? However I did get used to drinking roasted tea as it came-still trying to like green tea!!Breakfast:- There was an extensive choice of either Japanese or Western food, and you could eat in any of 3 restaurants (2 western/Japanese and 1 Japanese). My only complaint which seemed to apply to every hotel that we stayed in on the tour was that the western hot choices (sausage and bacon) were luke warm and we English do like our food hot!!! The hotel has its own bakery and so not surprisingly pastries and bed were extremely good.We thought the location was great-only a short distance from the train station and from restaurants and shops in the City-also very safe to walk about.There were some lovely shops within the hotel and a very handy supermarket on ground level which stops open long hours-perfect for getting food if you've had a long day and need something to munch on or to get a drink.All in all, a really pleasant experience and I would recommend this hotel without hesitation.I cant say if this is a mid range or luxury hotel as the costs were paid for by the tour company.

excellent hotel, flawless,15 restaurants, you name it you got it, different rooms to choose with different themes, free smart phones during your sejour, luxury toiletries and pyjamas.great place to stay

Stayed for 4 nights, first time in Tokyo. Nice hotel in good location. Easy to get to from Shinjuku station. It wasn't cheap, but you get good value. Our room was large and well appointed. Everything you needed was there. Would stay there again.

We stayed here for 3 nights. It was not cheap. The pool was closed. The rooms are clean but tiny. There was no storage space at all (literally). The breakfast was very average and the staff were reasonably trained but their English was varied but verging on the poor. Staff need training. The Wi-fi was shockingly bad and really spoilt my stay as had work to do and needed support from Hotel on 3 occasions. This should not happen. The location is excellent but would probably not stay again. Overpriced!!!

We stayed for just a couple of nightsand I think it is overly priced. The bathroom fixture has an old design and some black spots are seen in some of its corners. We took a triple sharing room and need to rearrange the furniture to have better mobility around the room and because it was blocking the way to the door. We stayed at this hotel for several times but we were never greeted ‘welcome back.’ Though the staff is very helpful and the location is near Shinjuku station.

Keio Plaza is a nice hotel. Breakfast was great, room was spacious (twin room), bathroom was ok (I’m 6’4” so most showers in Japan are tricky, and moreso when over a bath!). Dinner in the hotel was expensive. Hotel was near to amenities and shopping. Provided hypo-allergenic pillows and duvet when needed. Staff were polite and helpful. Dinner in the restaurant at the top is not as expensive as it looks (we laid the same amount for dinner as we did for an alcoholic drink). Their fish and chips are to die for in that restaurant!!

Let me qualify my review. First, this is the second time I stay at this hotel, 11 years apart. Second, I reserved a Premier Grand room. Shinjuku is the place to stay in Tokyo as it is the center of all activities: subway, restaurants, shops, entertainment, etc. The rooms are big considering it is Tokyo and they are amazing in terms of the use of space. Make sure to open all the drawers in the room as they contain pyjamas, robes, amenities, iron, safe, slippers, etc. The toilet (closet) door as I would call it opens automatically and the toilet/bidet gets ready for use which is great but somehow annoying to anyone else sleeping in the room. The service is impeccable from the time you arrive till you leave. The breakfast at the Club Level is superb and the service very attentive. As for the restaurants, we did not use them as I remember a Kobe beef dinner 11 years before that cost me 250$ per person: still the same price today. You can step just out of the hotel to a horde of restaurants at very reasonable prices.A piece of advice: become a club member (free) """"before""""" you reserve. The savings are great.

A previous visit to Tokyo involved staying in two hotels with microscopic bedrooms so it was pleasing to appreciate a decent sized room.Our room (1210) on floor twelve was clean and comfortable with bright colours and a reasonable size bathroom.It is a massive hotel complex so do not expect great personal service but it is only a short walk from the impressive Shinjuku station and there are a myriad of eateries in the vicinity.Breakfast is a very good choice of both Western and Japanese options but it can get very busy so worth arriving early for. We also had a late evening snack in the all day dining restaurant which was also very good.We would certainly stay here again if in this part of Tokyo.

We stayed at Keio Plaza Shinjuku in 2015 and 2017 and were quite happy with it. This year (May 2019) we booked the same 33 square meter room in the North tower.Gone were the L'Occitane products. The great mattresses had been replaced with inferior, thin, too-soft mattresses. What used to be the wonderfully fluffy, absorbent towels were now coarse, older towels. The room cleaning this time was also not up to an acceptable standard.This hotel has a great location, with Tochomae Station our "jumping off point" for the Tokyo subway system. However, we cannot see ourselves at Keio again for our next holiday in Tokyo. We are at a loss why the huge downturn in quality! The price was the same as prior years, averaging just slightly more than ¥30,000 per night (over our 7 night stay).VERY DISAPPOINTING!

Located just a few minute walk from Shinjuku train station and across the street from the Tokyo Metro Building this was a nice, clean, conveniently located hotel. I needed a triple occupancy room and we were able to book a room with 3 full size beds and still have plenty space to move around in. One suggestion for any hotel these days that ask for conserving water by not washing towels and linens daily...they need to provide towel racks in the bathrooms if they want us to hang our towels. This one didn't have any except one on the shower room door. Otherwise, the stay was great with loads of restaurant choices and a convenient store on property.

There are a lot of hotels in Shinjuku. Some people would like to stay closer to JR station, some people would like to stay closer to Kabukicho. My personal choice is making balance between good location and spacious room. So I try Keio Plaza Hote this time. I have to walk about 8-10mins from JR station to the hotel. You can choose to take airport limousine directly to hotel from Haneda or Narita Airport. I booked a larger newly refurbished room as size is 35sqm (it’s quite spacious room in most Tokyo hotels). The room is located at 29/F but the view is not that good as there are quite a lot high rise buildings around (you can see the room view picture I uploaded). The lobby is large and grand but not a modern stylish type. The check in process is smooth. The reception man provided basic smile and information that I needed to know eg the breakfast restaurants, Wi-Fi, checkout time etc. Once entered to the room, the decoration is the same as shown on trip advisor. It’s clean and tidy as most of Tokyo hotels. The room provided bottled water and instant green tea and coffee packs. There is a multi charger for use. The bathroom is good and quite spacious so that you can take a good bath then enjoy self made onsen to relieve your tired body after shopping or walking for a whole day. The toilettes are from L'OCCITANE. The brand is good with refreshing lemon smell but it will not give you bubbly feel after apply on the body (I personally do not prefer this type of shower gel). There is a tiny cube of bath salt provided for bath. Bed and pillow are ok to me and I don’t have any compliant about it. After sleep, the most important is breakfast. My wife is very picky about the hotel’s breakfast. There are 3 restaurants you can choose. One is American style, one is Japanese style and the last one is mixed buffet style. Surely, we choose the western-Japanese buffet breakfast. You may need to queue outside the restaurants for a short while as it’s quite busy. The variety of food is ok, there are 2-3 cold cuts, 2-3 simple cheese, 6-8 types of danish or bread, Japanese rice, udon, miso soap, Japanese fish, omelet, fruits, salad. It’s ok but not surprising. The quality of food is up to standard, not bad but not the best. I need a cup of good coffee but the coffee provide is too acidic and I like coffee which is strong and nutty. May be most of the coffee in Japan is relatively weak and easy. There is swimming pool and gym room in the hotel. But I am busy in shopping and sightseeing, so I really don’t have time to try the gym room for 3 nights stay. Tokyo is big! Shinjuku is the main place to go shopping and eating. If you don’t like shopping, you can choose to stay in other places. I do recommend Keio plaza hotel Shinjuku but please book a larger newly refurbished room.

Hotel was arranged by our tour operator, gate 1 travel. Very nice and super clean hotel. Many restaurants and amenities within the hotel. Very close to other points of interests in Tokyo Courteous and efficient staff. Tour operator was well organized and also has a desk within the hotel

I stayed here for 4 nights in May 2019 as a city break leisure trip.The hotel is very conveniently located in Shinjuku, lots of bars, restaurants and entertainment in walking distance. Nearby authentic Tempura and Tepanyaki makes it a food lovers dream. Hotel food and drink and breakfast is pricey, but loads nearby including breakfast much cheaper.The hotel is very clean and modern. My room was clean, quiet and had a lovely view. Features in the room as expected. Staff all very friendly overall a fantastic stay and I would recommend highly for adult couples.

I visited this hotel in April, and again in May.Keio Plaza will definitely be “home” when I arrive in Tokyo. The stay in May was at the end of visit in Japan, and I cannot think of a better place to spend the last night before a long journey home.Located in a an area close to shopping, transportation, and a park close by. Several restraints, an art gallery, and a very well stocked gift store.There are three restaurants open for buffet breakfast. Really nice to start your morning. A newspaper is left at your door each morning. Many elevators to move you between floors. Nicely decorated comfortable rooms.So many extras in the rooms. If you forgot your toothbrush or comb-no need to worry. The shower products were really nice quality. Very comfortable beds.I will be making this my hotel of choice when visiting Tokyo.

Stayed two nights here with my wife. Great hotel. The staff were very helpful and polite. They did not charge anything for storing our luggage here for 2 days when we went to Kyoto. The room was surprisingly large. It's also very clean. The mattresses were very comfortable. Good amenities - free phone for us to take around and use. No charges for local or international calls. The hairdryer is powerful. The hot water came on within a few seconds. The bidet is very useful. There is even a CD player cum radio. Would be really good if they provided an iron and ironing board. Many high quality restaurants within the hotel. It is within 2 mins from Tochomae subway station and less than 10 mins from Shinjuku station (exit West gate to go to hotel). There are many eateries and shops in the Shinjuku station area. There is also a very big departmental store with a big supermarket at the station.The bus to and from Narita and Haneda airports stop at this hotel. Very happy with our stay. Highly recommended for travelers.

A first class hotel with excellent service. Very useful smart phone mobile WI-FI they encourage you to take with you around the city. Restaurant options were a little pricey. The location was great for exploring Shijuko

Good hotel Maybe the rooms were small but they had tea in the rooms.The result!Save money easily with !: maxdeals.mlI liked the fact that they were providing a news sheet for each room. Also good, it is close to the Uniqlo store, Starbucks and MacDonald's

My husband, 4 year old daughter and I (6 months pregnant) stayed here in December 2018 as our first stop in Japan. Wow, what a fantastic hotel. The staff were incredibly helpful; providing us with maps and directions to certain destinations and giving our daughter a little kids welcome pack with toothbrush, toothpaste, wash cloth etc. We were always greeted with a warm welcome and nothing was too difficult for them. The foyer is beautiful and was obviously decorated for Christmas which was great for photos. There are two main entrances/exits to the hotel; both lead to great adventures but the one furthest from the reception desks is convenient for the train (Shinjuku station is a 5 min walk away), shopping centres (5 minutes walk), 7-Eleven (1 minute walk), Starbucks and Hooters (2 minute walk) as well as other fabulous eating places and shops. The rooms are spacious (we stayed in a Plaza Superior King Room in the South Wing) with a super king bed, a separate table and chairs and enough room for us to have our 3 large suitcases open and still walk around! The bed was comfy (and that’s saying something coming from a pregnant lady) and all amenities were great. There’s a laundromat within walking distance so you don’t need to pay exorbitant fees for hotel laundry facilities) - ask the hotel concierge for a map to the laundromats within the area.This hotel also offers a free shuttle to/from the DisneyLand although we didn’t use this service.I would highly recommend this hotel for its convenient location, helpful staff and fantastic rooms. We enjoyed it so much that every time we went travelling (Kyoto, Disney, Takayama, etc.) we kept coming back in between as our central location in Tokyo.

Very good location, easy access to train station. Friendly front desk and guest relation. Bus tour meeting point. Need to login WIFI every day. Not good value. Breakfast at Level 2 is better than level 42. Long queue after 8am. Will try different hotel in next trip.

I and my 6 y.o son stayed in this hotel from 3-9 May 2019. On shinjuku station, take EXIT 7 then once you go out from the stairs (facing yodobashi building) turn right, walk straight until you see starbuck and walk straight again until you see the hotel (it is located exactly 5 minutes walk from shinjuku station as long as you take exit 7).We stayed at main building room 2625 facing metro tokyo government building (highly reccomended to ask the room facing it as the view is spectacular and you can even see Mt. Fuji from your window if you are lucky, we saw it on our last day, loved it).We didn't take breakfast, and the price of breakfast on 3 restaurants offered is quiet pricey (3500 yen/person and mostly japanese style). Lots of places nearby shinjuku station to have breakfast anyway. The staffs are ok, not having warm touch as common in big hotel but very efficient. We booked free shuttle to disneysea upon arrival and took limousine bus to Haneda airport from lobby. We'll be back !PS : There is also Tochomae station 5 minutes walk from hotel where you can take subway oedo line directly to Tsukiji market.

the rooms are big and the service is truly exceptional! we left our items out, which i wouldnt recommend and the cleaner put them in the safe for us, lever her code and asking us to change it once we arrived. loved it!
user_name:
YoliTeresa
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Unfortunately Gate 1 tours does not get the best rooms for their customers. None of the ones on the website look like our dated 1970s room. I tried to upgrade to the executive lounge privileges with same room and was told that’s non-allowable. However they are selling executive lounge rooms on the website. When is staying at the Hilton nearby, if you wanted executive lounge privileges, you could pay for it with a 5000 Japanese yen upgrade.

My review title could be better, but it was the first thing I thought of to describe our experience. We have stayed at a Keio hotel before, which was in Saporro and we enjoyed both our stays so we decided to try the Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo. I booked the hotel via Booking.com and the price was reasonable with a clear description of the rooms available. We landed in Narita airport and took a JR express train to Shinjuku station and walked to Keio hotel. I read on the web that the hotel is connected to a subway but we decided to walk outside as it was a very pleasant day. The hotel is situated near the government buildings with easy access to the Keio new line. It is also in the proximity of a number of restaurants and shopping malls.

I stayed at Keio Plaza for 9 nights in April. Check in was fine; room was clean and kept clean all week. Staff accommodating and spoke English. We ate at Jurin Restaurant and the Skye Bar and also had room service. The prices are high compared to what you pay to eat in town; however, it's a different dining experience. The food, however, was good.Convenient complementary bus service to Tokyo Disney which we used, and Sunrise Tours has a desk in the hotel and the trips leave from there.Subway/train station a few blocks away and on the other side of the station is nightlife.Would definitely stay again.

We went to Tokyo with our teenager son and stay at Keio Plaza Hotel for 7 days, before we continue our trip to Kyoto and Osaka. The hotel provided us a room with 3 beds of 120x200 cm size, comfortable for family of 3. Although it is a 5 star hotel, the look and feel quite standard. The hotel is located just in front of Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office where you can see Tokyo from its 45th floor observation deck. Subway station is within walking distance (around 10 minutes walk) and if you take one day tours, most of the them have gathering point nearby the hotel. The hotel provides pick up shuttle bus from aiport and vice versa, free shuttle bus to Disney, and also lugage transfer service. My suggestion is not to come to Tokyo during Golden Week, as the hotel price almost double and the route to tourist destination areas such as Hakone, Hitachi Side Park, etc. was so crowded and hence you will spend more time on the road...

Good quality typical 4 star hotel. Very big well organised, excellent staff. Rooms are well appointed with bath.kettle and safe. About £2oo per night.Typical buffet breakfasts with 3 dinning rooms to choose from.one being Japanese which I did not try.Bell boy system was exceptional.Handy for the town and station, a few minutes walk away Tokio is a vast concrete jungle with not that much on offer, subway & rail system to tax the mind in getting about. Its all rolled in with Yokohama having a population of 26 million people, Houses are squeezed in between the many skyscrapers. Traffic seemed light by London standards but apparently moring is very expensive.its all very expensive by UK standards especially ladies shoes, Expect to pay £10 for a couple of coffees and a cake.

With 1440 rooms you'd expect to be permanently squeezed but, other than the lifts early on a weekend day, this does not happen. Even then the activity is not too constricting. Just busy. Squeezy.The counter staff are efficient and courteous. The Guest Relations/ Duty Manager's desk even more so. The rooms are spotless and more than adequate at a reasonable price. Breakfasts in a choice of one of four restaurants is outstanding. A well managed but not overly long queue signals weekends. We chose to eat in the light,bright Jurin garden restaurant and loved itLate check outs are available for about $25 an hour in two hour blocks. There is an efficient and regular one hour coach service to Haneda Airport at a fraction of the taxi cost.There are good little eating places within a five minute walk and on the other side of the hotel is the Government Building with free access to the viewing platform on Level 41. We didn't even dare enter Shinjuku Railway Station which has over 60 access points and millions of travellers every day.The only issue we had was WiFi which is reset by the hotel at midday every day. For us, techno dummies, that meant a daily trek down to the desk to have 2 ipads reset. On occasions it was fast but not always. At booking time, many weeks ahead, we had to push to be guaranteed a non smoking room.Whilst Japanese courtesy is well known this hotel takes it to new highs. They really mean it.

Spent 3 nights at this hotel as a pre-cruise choice...fantastic start to a wonderful intro to Japan. Thoroughly taken care of upon arrival by Arrival staff (Front Desk, Baggage). Easily efficient in-processing with utmost courtesy & respect. The room was very clean, well appointed, and outstandingly serviced each day (courtesy water as well). Our touring schedule in town precluded any restaurant utilization other than Western breakfast buffet. That was outstanding: many good choices, hot/fresh food, great service and extremely interested in our visit each time. Check out was also an easy, efficient process. While it is a very large and busy hotel downtown....their courtesy, respect, and professional service never wavered in quality. Hotel is also within 10 minute walk of busy train/subway station which is safe and convenient to your stay. Great place to start a visit of Tokyo and onward.

Keio Plaza Hotel is a very huge hotel in great location. Since it is a big hotel, the lobby is always busy. Also, there was a line for the Super Breakfast buffet at 8AM. We booked a room above 20 floor in the South Wing. It was worth the money. Every morning during our stay, Mt Fuji showed with her snow capped cone. The size of our room was big enough for the three of us. Staff service was excellent.
user_name:
MarieSylvia
New York City, New York

review_body: Mediocre choice for a Gate 1 Discovery Tour, which is supposed to use higher end hotels. Huge, impersonal and needs updating of guest rooms. Rock hard uncomfortable twin beds Most frustrating issue was the WiFi- took at least ten attempts each time to connect. Disconnected itself constantly. Only mentionable aspect is the included breakfast - huge buffets with many choices.

we booked this hotel for the conceige services as it is very hard to book restaurants in Japan. every inquiry took two days to get back that I got so frustrated and called from new York to follow up on my reservations. someone from the club lounge conceirge told me to wait as they will email me the reply while I was on the phone. I snapped! I had to ask them to tell me the answer over the phone if I did or not get any reservations. I voiced my frustration and concern- guess what no answer! not even apologising- I do not recommend this hotel! poor customer service!!!!!!!

I stayed on two different nights in the same week. The rooms were both described as Twin Superior but on my second stay I was informed at check-in that it was a renovated. It was much nicer. The bathroom was a big step up from the unrenovated one. The hotel is located very close to Shinjuku Station so it is a great spot. The staff are very efficient and polite. The breakfast buffet quite expansive and very good.

This hotel is huge and seems to be booked by lots of tour groups including the Gate 1 Travel group we were with. They have a policy that you can't check in until 2 PM and they really stick to that. So no matter if the rooms are ready you will end up in a very long, very slow check in line at 2PM along with everyone else. There are even chairs set up in the reception area along the wall with lots of people sitting in them waiting to check in. The bed is very hard and if you sleep on your side, your hip will complain. The bathroom is OK with the Toto Washout toilet and tub and separate showers area. Since this is such a large hotel the breakfast lines are also large to get into one of the three breakfast restaurants (two are western style and one is Japanese style). To handle the crowds, the breakfast is also served on the 4th floor and sometimes on the 44th floor in conference rooms that have breakfast set up in them. The bars in the hotel look like the place is used for first date night for couples who are just getting to know each other. I would not stay in this hotel again due to the crowds. There are a lot of restaurants in this hotel in the lower level but they seem to be really expensive for what you get. There are lots of cheaper restaurants a few blocks away.

My first impression of this hotel was over- crowded and too many tour guests staying; however, underneath it all, the guests do their tour early in the morning, just like rush hour, and it is an interesting sight. This is not a bother at all.Receptionists all work like robots, and very professionals ( i mean it in a good way). There are trash cans in the lobby, which make us very difficult to throw any trash sometimes that are laying around the sofa from previous guests.Our first stay was in the South tower for three nights, and I highly prefer the triple room here. It is much spacious and has an extra sink in the powder room. Our second stay here was in the Annex tower, which is an older room, smaller, and not as fresh smell . Actually, it is a twin room, but they added an extra bed. (You see the difference?)What I love about this hotel:1. They provide an extension outlet for charging.2. Located nearby pharmacies, coffee shops, Family mart, restaurants, and karaoke places.3. They cater to quick check-out counters.4. Excellent breakfast choices.I would certainly stay here again for next trip to Tokyo. There are so many things going on around this hotel.

We have to stay in this hotel from our March tour group, the first impression is there's too many people needed help from the staff. Only a few spoke English good enough to assist the guest for their need. We tried their Japanese restaurant the first night & there's hardy any service & food wasn't up to their reputation especially their own country's cooking. Rooms were clean but not nice, dated & dark. When it come to breakfast time there's always long lines even inside the dinning areas have plenty of empty tables( it's a buffet breakfast) which don't requirer personal attendance.

I booked Keio Hotel based on many positive reviews on TripAdvisor. And my experience told me I was definitely wrong. I should stay away from this hotel.First of all, the staff is not professional. My family (2 adults and 2 kids) got into the lobby with 4 big pieces of luggage. Interestingly, the staff was just standing there and did nothing. Regarding the service at the check-in counter, what I could feel is that this hotel should NOT be rated 4/5 stars. Cold and work without enthusiasm. All the staff should be trained again. Upon seeing our rooms, I was definitely sure that the hotel should NOT be rated 4/5 stars. The room was dusty and the bathroom was ancient. Buffet breakfast was another disaster. I saw a waiter yelling at another Italian guest and poor and limited variety of food. Eventually, we went to Starbucks in the next day morning. Location is the only selling point for this hotel. Because of this ONE and ONLY ONE advantage, they don't have to worry about business and they don't need to provide necessary service to their customers.

I booked one Saturday night through hotels.com and paid over $400 a night. There were 3 of us and we were given 2 beds that seemed to be smaller than a regular full bed. The hotels response was to make a mattress up that was on the floor. We passed on that and my husband & I shared a small bed while our 15 year old slept on the other. The size of the bed would be completely forgivable - Japanese people tend to be under 6 foot tall, so that is understandable...however, the comfort of the bed WAS NOT. It was the equivalent of a pull out mattress cushion - rock hard and thin. I barely got any sleep. The bathroom really needed updating too - a very dated, ugly color with a very low shower head. The only pluses - a cell phone (although we rented a pocket wi-fi so we didn't need it) and an okay view. The lobby of the hotel is beautiful - wonderful huge bouquets of flowers, beautiful crystal chandeliers, etc. If I slept in the lobby, maybe I would care about those things but I slept in a rock hard thin mattress for $400. What a total rip off - how this hotel can have such high reviews is beyond me. When I told the staff before I left about the miserable room, I was sent a letter of apology and told that if I tried the hotel again, I should ask for the "right kind of room" - not sure what that meant - like a room with a bed that is acceptable?!? That's what I would expect for this price range. Stay anywhere other than here!

The best thing about this hotel is the location. It is very close to Shinjuku station and the great food and nightlife in this area.Our experience (my wife and I) was that is is too big, too impersonal, too focused on catering for large tour groups and is average quality in a lot of areas. The service was average (unlike the superb service we received all over Japan), the rooms are average (tired and needing a refurbishment, showers with a shower curtain in a five star hotel in 2019, seriously?), the food for breakfast was very average, in terms of quality, variety and flavour. We paid extra for Luxe Club rooms with give us access to drinks and refreshments in the club room. Again this was average. We have used these types of facilities in different hotels and in different countries and this was the worst. Poor variety fo drinks, poor and limited variety of food. Especially highlighted having had a similar room at the Sheraton Hotel in Hiroshima and their club room was outstanding.I also joined the Executive CLub which in the end gave me no benefits, it was a waste of time and effort. I won’t be staying here again or in any of this group’s other hotels.

We are a couple who stayed here for 4 nights in early April. The location of the hotel is great. There's lots to see and do within walking distance, and the Shinjuku train station is only a couple of blocks away. The people working at the hotel were very friendly and willing to help with your needs. The room was very well designed, perhaps a bit small by north american standards, but I expect it was good sized by Tokyo standards from talking to other travellers. The bed was a bit firm, and my wife had difficulty finding a pillow that worked for her. That said, housekeeping was very accommodating giving us a few options there. I would definitely recommend this hotel for someone staying in the Shinjuku area.

This hotel is always extremely busy at a very convenient location. We used to stay here a lot before because it has frequent airport limousine directly between both Haneda & Narita Airport and it has free shuttle bus to Disneyland. We stopped staying in this hotel since we have grown out of the Disney age. For our return to this hotel, everything is still good except the doona. The doona is not inserted in a doona cover, instead it is placed between two very slippery sheets that means while you inevitably move when you sleep, the sheets also move so the doona that every guest has slept with will touch you which we find very unhygienic!

Keio Plaza is very, very near to Shinjuku Station. The hotel is a First Class Hotel. The rooms are spacious, modern and very clean. The staff are attentive to your questions and needs and English is not an issue. Also the location is very near to Shinjuku Center which has many restaurants. Also the Airport Limo from hotel to Narita and Haneda begin from Keio Plaza.

This is a hotel which caters to large groups and business people. With that qualifier it does a very good job of taking care of its guests. We were a group of 14 and immediately upon arrival we were taken to a separate area by one of the reservations staff who had all of our room packages prepared - very nice afet a long travel day. We all had "Luxe Rooms" which are on a higher. Our first impression of the room was that it was a little small for an upgrade and the carpets could use a cleaning. These were minor issues when we came to appreciate the quality and comfort of the bedding and the excellent bathroom and shower. There is a heated mirror which is very convenient. In the desk drawer there is a power cord pre-fitted with most international adapters, as well as a charging cable, again fitted with most sizes of connections which was very goodUpon arrival we wanted a light dinner and the best option seemed to be Jurin, the hotel restaurant which had both Asian and Western options. They do not seem to do either any better tha adequately for dinner so this was a little disappointing. The next morning for breakfast there was a very long line for Jurin, which is the best option for those wanting a wide range of choice. We were worried that we migt not make our tour, until hotel staff approached the people in line and advised they had opened one of the banquet rooms on the 44th floor with a breakfast buffet. This showed great forethought and was a very good breakfast with amazing views. The second day day we ate in Jurin and it was a very good breakfast with both Asian and Western selections.Overall this is a very good hotel

The hello kitty room was totally gorgeous and order the room service hello kitty breakfast. It was totally amazing. Reserve in advance as fill up quickly. You can also book a package for puroland tickets too but you need to check the opening hours of Puroland before you book this package.

This hotel was well located and very close to good facilities like the subway. It caters for very large groups of tourists and the hotel is very busy right thoughout the day.Breakfast at either of the hotel restaurants is a bit of a challenge from lining up to gain entry and then to navigate your way through the buffet stations as a couple of hundred other guests do the same thing.The rooms are well maintained and are adequate for your overnight stay and were comfortable.Overall a good quality four star hotel located in a good location, just be aware that it is a very big hotel with large tourist groups staying there which creates some pressures due to the number of people.

the hotel is in a good location, nice entrance cum lobby. The room is of a good size for Japanese standard. However, the pillows and bed were not comfortable and I did not sleep well. There was a hairpin under one bed that was there before we check in and that stayed there until our departure, so unsure about how they clean the room...

It is a nice hotel and it is in a great location.The room is spacious and clean. We weren’t so impressed with staff at reception and difficulty with communication.Long queue to check in and had to sit in row of chairs by reception .

We loved this hotel, great location, close to subway, close to great restaurants ( check “Piss Alley”), clean and the staff was very helpful and of course, very respectful. Safe to walk around at any time and explore the neighborhood by foot.

The location of this hotel is good, not far from the subway station. It is next to the twin towers, which have observation decks on 45th floor with breathtaking view of Tokyo. The hotel itself is modern, with spacious rooms. But the hotel is so big that the three restaurants it has are not capable to accommodate its guests during the morning breakfast hours.
