One has to wait in line for 20 to 30 min to be admitted. It is a real inconvenience if you are traveling with a tour group and are not expecting to lose so much time in the morning.

I have chosen Keio Plaza hotel over many other hotels i checked more than once because of the position, reviews and rooms. My choice was well made!I travelled with my mother, we arrived from Haneda airport by using the limousine bus, that was a cheap and right option, they were organised and very precise, once we arrived we had the bellmen ready to welcome us and once we entered for checking in while waiting there was a member of the staff that gave us the map while the bellmen were taking our luggage with them giving us a number.Checking in was fast, we received all the basic information and we finally got our room in the main tower on the 24th floor, view was awesome and we also received a welcome writing on my bed with 2 little presents.Room was good, not small like i expected, bathroom was small yes, but i understand the japanese standards are different from italians so i was ok with that, there were so many accessories inside that i couldn't need for more :)First day we used the room service, food was great, of course prices were high and over average but considering it's a room service and a 4 stars maybe i can understand..however think twice before ordering..outside there are many nice and less painful restaurants :)Hotel infact was located very close to shinjuku, near also to the metro station and all the main attractions i wanted. I loved the breakfast at the glass court and was not the only one having breakfast, however it was the most crowded as it was in my opinion the best:) We also tried the japanese one and another one but the first in my favourite list is the glass court, doesn't matter how much i have to queue. Staff in there was very nice and attentive to our needs so i have nothing to say about that:)People that complain about the lobby crowded they should really stay at home, because they have no experience of travelling..this is a very busy hotel as there are many rooms and many people check in and check out at all times, so it's pretty normal, if you choose a hotel is for sleeping not for staying in the lobby to care about people passing or disturbing your sight..come on.. All the staff was lovely starting from the bellmen that make exceptional efforts to take care of our luggage even when raining.The ony complain was sunrise tours that wrote in our website they offerend 22% discount on shinkansen tickets and when i went to their office in the hotel they told me to go to shinjuku station, so what is the point of making a discount if after you send me to the station to get the ticket at the original price? They don't understand english very good and they write wrong in their website considering they don't supply tickets.Overall i am very happy about this hotel and i would surely come back!!!!!!!!!!

PROS: The hotel is on the JR Yamanote Line, which is perfect if you have a JR Rail pass. We travelled to Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ueno, Nippori quite a few times and it did not cost us anything since we had the JR pass.The hotel is near 7/11, Family Mart and a lot of shops and restaurants. The Japanese family mart closest to the hotel on the same side (going towards the station) is by far the cheapest, but they are all cheap for food and drinks.Reception speaks English and are helpful. The Tokyo guide is really good (located near the elevator).Shampoos, conditioner, body wash are all lovely. They provide toothbrushes and razors.Towels are in the cupboard but are on the smaller side.Reception ''loan'' travel adapters for a 1000Yen deposit, which you get back when you return it.ALL hotels in Japan have a 3pm checkin but they all store luggage for free.CONS: From the street to reception there is a flight of stairs and no elevator. But there is an elevator to the rooms. But the man on reception as we checked out helped us carry our luggage down the stairs.Bathroom is small and you will need to adjust the shower head so it points down on an angle otherwise it will shoot straight ahead. There is a step up to go inside bathroom.Rooms do not have 3 beds, so a triple room is a double bed and a king single. The walls and windows are thin. We could hear other guests and people outside at night.

My mom and I stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel for four nights while exploring Tokyo. We liked the location, as we were a close walk to Shinjuku and Shinjuku station, and a 35 minute walk to Harajuku. We also liked that we could control the temperature in the room and that we were given a bottle of water daily. Generally speaking, it’s nice that you can safely drink water from the tap in Japan. We liked the breakfast options, both Kagara and Glass Door. There was a good variety of food options. We did not like that we could not check in before 2pm (not ideal after flying a red eye from California and landing at 4:30am) and they were very strict and rigid about this. We also did not like the wait for breakfast daily. It seems like no matter what time we arrived, there was a 15 or more minute wait for the Japanese and American buffet at Glass Door. It was also not our preference that the hotel was loaded with tourists and the lobby was seemingly always packed with foreigners. This is not the hotel’s fault, but it is a large hotel. If we had to book again, we may prefer a smaller, quieter hotel or Airbnb.

Really good hotel location, very close to Shinjuku station and walking distance to Kabuchio district. stayed 4 nights , had breakfast every morning, choice of 2 restaurants, busy but not over crowded. Good selection of foods, hot and cold. The Sky lounge is good for night food and/or drinks, not cheap but reasonable and great views. The room was smallish but very comfortable , recommended

We stayed in two different rooms at this hotel and had completely different experiences. The first part of our stay was in the upgraded Main Tower on the 30th floor. The place exceeded my expectations since other friends kept saying how small hotel rooms were in Japan. There were 3 beds and plenty of walking space. We had every amenity you could think of and the room was worth every penny. I loved the bathroom too, just beautiful. We ended our trip back at Keio Plaza and booked a room in the South Tower. Yikes what a difference! That’s the only reason why the hotel didn’t get a 5 star rating. I wish I took pictures of our second room to show the comparison. I don’t want to say too much because I really did like the hotel and the staff, but let’s say I took a shower with my sandals on. It is well worth it to pay extra for the Main Tower.

This hotel is simply stunning and beautiful! The service is truly amazing! The rooms, restaurants, and location are excellent. I will defiantly be back, and it is highly recommended! They offer tea ceremonies and over 11 restaurants featuring food from all over the world! Western style breakfast & more!

We arrived at this Hotel at 9.00 am and were told that we cannot check in until 2.00pmWe were really disappointed in this after a 12 hour flight but we have since found out this is normal in Japan and they do not budge on itAfter the initial disappointment we were shown to our room and were very happy with itThe bed was large and the room spacious.I was most impressed with the facilities they provided Iron ironing board kettle and tea making plug adapter which was most useful and a phone with google maps to take out with you and also make free calls to the UK amazing The Hotel is very well situated and the trains are easily accessible and also walks to local sights Would really recommend staying here when in Tokyo

We stayed here for our first 2 nights in Japan. The hotel has an amazing location in Shinjuku. Just a short walk to the station. I was with my 2 teenagers and we had a Superior triple room. I loved this. We each had our own bed!! There was ample room and the washroom was modern. The room was immaculately clean. We had the buffet breakfast which was fabulous. great selections and delicious coffee. Would highly recommend and stay here again

The rooms are very nice and well appointed. The bellboy was wonderful, he set up the WiFi for two phones and two WiFi so we didn’t have to figure it out.The lobby is always bustling and it’s in a great location.

Summary: Good price and spacious rooms for Tokyo. Near Shinjuku train station. Very nice breakfast buffet. A bit old facilities.One should take note that the hotel is in a business district and is a business hotel with a bit old furnishing.Check-in was fast and we were able to check-in early. The hotel is less than 10 min walking distance from Shinjuku, which is a very convenient starting point for day trips out of Tokyo.The furniture and carpets are a bit old, but nothing dramatic. Although the price is not cheap, the rooms are a good size for Tokyo and we were able to open both suitcases on the floor without problems.Breakfast buffet was fantastic.

Really had to use the lifts as hotel is about 45 levels. Breakfast queue of about 15 minutes was only minor annoyance. Stunning floral displays in public areas and great city views from our room on 16th floor. Comfortable and clean with lovely attentive polite staff. Wouldn’t eat dinner though at those prices as I’m not rich enough to chuck money away. Enjoyed my two night stay. Would recommend.

We booked a last minute getaway to Tokyo and stayed at this property. I have yet to read an accurate review of this hotel. For starters this is a very large property which translates to lines everywhere. There is a line to check in, a line to check out, a line to get on any elevator(and yes the elevators are exceedingly slow). There is a line to have breakfast at the standard buffet restaurant. This is not a short 4-5 person line, we are talking lines that wind around and double back and last twenty to thirty min before entering the restaurant. Yes, it cherry blossom season but deal with it. Hire more staff there are tables, they are just all dirty and not cleared for folks to sit down. There is a line to the hotel bathrooms in the lobby and restaurants. There is a line to drop off luggage with bellman. There is a line to retrieve said luggage when needed. U get the idea. Once you overcome the lines, you will be greeted by a front desk which does not speak English well. The attendants are robotic and any requests will be handled in halting, uncomfortable broken English with inaccurate and useless information so don't waste your time. Just look up your question on the internet.The rooms: as we booked last minute we knew we would have to switch rooms mid stay. We booked two rooms per night and stayed in a Deluxe room first, and later the Superior renovated room. Their standard rooms are Unrenovated and we didn't stay in one. The Deluxe room is fully renovated, meaning the bathroom has been done. The Superior 'renovated' room (south tower)has an old bathroom with a cheap single layer bathroom shower curtain and peeling, tarnished gold bathroom fixtures, old caulk and old tile. Bathroom amenities in the superior renovated rooms are likewise cheap, with no name soap and small bottles of cheap watered down shampoo. In the deluxe category you get L'occitane products.The beds: in both room categories the beds are hard, with a thin mattress cheap mattress overlay and uncomfortable scratchy sheets to wrap it all up. There is no boxspring and its surprisingly cheap feeling. Despite exhaustion from an all day flight I woke up in the middle of the night because the bed was just too rough. Booking: we booked directly with the hotel (native speaker) and it still took me hours to get a confirmation despite calling back several times to request the email confirmation. The reservation dept have inconsistent, incomplete inventory information when called directly. Their room availability differs on line with the LHW website (side note: hotel caliber does not belong with this group), and that deviates from inventory on Booking.com so check everything if you bother to stay here.Service: pretty fake and did not have one actually useful interaction. We extended our stay by a night. We did this by using booking.com because calling the front desk directly led us to believe they were sold out which was just plain wrong. With our booking, com reservation we went downstairs the day we were scheduled to check out to inform them we would be staying longer. The front desk told us we could not remain in the same room although it was the same category we extended in. We were told they still had not gotten our booking.com reservation though it was hours later as well which also makes no sense but whatever. We were told with unwavering certainty that our present rooms were already allocated to another party coming that day, and so we had to 1) check out and return our keys 2) pack all our luggage 3) bring our own luggage down to the storage desk 4) check in again to obtain new keys 5) grab our bags again from the porter in the afternoon. So we do all of that (which was pretty annoying,) only to find out later that we... wait for it, were going back to the SAME room. So we go back to the same room only to find out that it was NOT even serviced that day. Its a mess, with unemptied trash and food leftover (albeit from us), towels strewn about. So now, at 8pm at night we are waiting for Housekeeping to clean the room for the first time. Another annoyance would be the knowledge that though we also asked for Adjacent rooms all over our reservation we were confidently told there were None. While standing in the hallway and waiting for Housekeeping we watch two new sets of guests roll into the two Directly adjacent rooms with their luggage, which we had asked to occupy since we were traveling with underage kids. So basically everything we were told was a total unapologetic LIE and inaccurate. Everything we had to do that day (check in, check out, pack our bag etc) was unwarranted and wasted a great deal of our time. I called their General Manager (Mr. Sakamoto) who eventually came up with his side kick. (native speaker here)- I understood what he said in Japanese which was basically that this was a pretty messed up situation. I asked to be moved. (no dice, hotel was full, sure,,, ok). It took them another half hour to clean the room. Mr. Sakamoto never comes back. I am given a box of $5 cookies as some sort of gesture from the side kick, which is a joke and just punctuated their lack of understanding even further. In the interest of moving on with our night we let it go. But, we clearly should have been compensated for the evening. We booked two rooms a piece for 4 nights, and the whole place was pretty much a disaster bursting at the seams with too many tourists and too little time to actually provide decent service, and a great deal lost in translation. I would not recommend this hotel, at the Deluxe category, club concierge, or any level as there are too many flaws from the moment you walk through the door. The GM should be re-trained in hospitality. At any other property in the world, our experience would merit more than just a perfunctory deep bow and token box of cheap crackers.

Stayed here for 7 nights in end of March for the cherry blossoms season.. Great location, 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station.. Big rooms for Tokyo standards, 3 breakfast restaurants to choose from.. fantastic in-house convenience store. Disney neighborhood hotel which provided free shuttle to Disneyland.. Airport limousine at your doorsteps.. Easy check in and check out. Seriously, what else can we ask for?

So just married, we wanted to venture back to Tokyo for our honeymoon mainly to see the Cherry Blossom.Overall- Hotel is clean and beds comfortable however rooms where slightly smaller then expected, particularly the bathroom! Hotel is rather large and we stayed up on the 29th floor (premium floor) which means again busy periods you can be waiting a while for elevators. If you stay close enough to the lifts this also can get noisy within certain times! Staff were not particularity helpful although to be fair language barrier/culture didn't help! Even though on honeymoon there were no specific efforts to acknowledge this which was a shame.Check in- fine, receptionist a little rude and direct but I am sure meant well. Paid no attention at all to the fact we were on honeymoon and did not go through details at all which meant we were unsure of a lot of things and timings throughout our stay e.g. breakfast, late hours dinning and the fact we had lounge access meaning free snacks and drinks late afternoon! Wish we had worked that one out sooner! She did however accommodate an hour earlier check in time for us which we were grateful for.Food- due to the season and number of guests breakfast in the morning often meant a long que- waiting time can be up to 15 mins in some mornings. Get there early. Food was average and meal times where often crowded with lots of food running out quickly. Bread always went early and with a bakery within the hotel selling fresh bread you would have thought getting more was easily accessible. I am dairy free which was often a challenge within the restaurants in hotel.Location- With high season means high prices of course. Hotel was in a good location within Shinjuku shopping districts and business area. Not far from Shinjuku Gyeon Park which means you can get there early and avoid major ques!In summary, a comfortable hotel for a short stay, rooms clean but dated and old and by no means luxurious. Staff as friendly as they can be as fairly rushed off their feet most of the time. Gym and Salon not worth a visit at all. Good location and lots of shopping in walking distance.

Stayed here for 3 nights before our cruise. Great base for exploring the city as close to Shinjuku station. Room was spacious and well appointed. Beware of the bar, costs and arm and leg to drink there!

One of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. We were on the 37th floor. Our view was phenomenal. We could see Mt Fuji in the distance. Our night time view was amazing. We ate breakfast on the 45th floor. Very small and less crowded than elsewhere in the hotel.

This was our second time staying at the Keio Plaza having stayed March/April 2018 for the Cherry Blossom. Last time we had some issues with the lack of soundproofing and we had to swap rooms but it really didn't help; this was in the main tower. This time was the South Tower, room with free access to the lounge, as last time. Soundproofing still remains a major problem - I'm a light sleeper and you often hear noise from the room above which is frustrating for such a hotel. The hotel has lots of amenities (some we perhaps don't need), a great little lounge, but the main attraction is its proximity to Shinjuku station; Nishishinjuku is fabulous with lots of places to eat, a post office to withdraw the much needed cash, and both metro and train connections. Very easy to navigate. The views from the hotel are also very good. TYes, the hotel could be perfect if they could sort the soundproofing but having spent 14 nights, then 15 nights, we're due to spend a further 6 nights there in July 2019, so we must like it there. The only other downside is that it's so big you don't build any relationship with the staff.

This is a large hotel with lots of guests, hence very busy. Although not that close to where the tourist actions are (ie, Kabukicho), this is more than compensated by our huge, clean and very comfortable room. The room was so much larger than we could ever expect from a Tokyo hotel. The beds are firm and comfortable, the toilet is clean although slightly dated. A couple of minutes walk outside the main lobby are so many restaurants one is totally spoilt for choice. And it is only a 10 min walk to Shinjuku Station. The only ‘complaint’ I have is that our floor (Level 31) is centrally heated so that we could not select air conditioning instead of heating. We found our room quite warm on arrival. This was quickly rectified by the helpful housekeeper who promptly brought us a rotating fan which did the job for us. Oh, and I think it was a bit cheeky of reception to ask for JPY500 to provide us with a new room access card to replace one we had misplaced. This is the first time I have encountered this practice, having stayed in many hotels around the world. The staff were always friendly and helpful. Room cleaning does a great job and quickly too. They would clean our room even through on one day we placed our make up our room sign outside our door so very close to the 3pm cut off time. A special mention needs to be made for the concierge who not only helped us book our dinner because the restaurant only spoke Japanese, but also ended up referring us to a fantastic yakiniku restaurant and booking it for us. Touché. We stayed for a total of 8 nights, and I would stay here again next time I come to Tokyo.

We stayed here in March 2017 and had a very pleasant experience. Hotel is HUGE, and a little dated, but really clean. The staff were very friendly and accommodating. Our room was a Plaza Luxe Double and had a really great view as well as being spacious, especially for Tokyo standards. The bathroom was decent. Would definitely stay here again and would recommend anyone travelling to Tokyo to consider this hotel. Location wise it was close to Shinjuku station (about a 10 min walk give or take), with lots of restaurants and bars along the way.

We just spent 3 nights here. We were expecting a tiny small room - but no! Our room was spacious, modern, extremely well designed, with nice windows, free wifi, room safe. The bathroom was super impressive - very high tech ... of course - it's Japan! The toilet had more controls than I have ever seen before ... very fun, heated seat! The shower was awesome, the layout of the bathroom perfect. We were in Shinjuku so about 4 stops on the train to Tokyo Station. That didn't bother us at all. Shinjuku itself is very bustling, with lots of shopping and restaurants, lots of people around! Staff at the hotel - not the warmest, but still, we really enjoyed out stay and recommend it! Great value - no doubt due to time of year.

We stayed in the Premier Grand - Deluxe Twin room with the Club Lounge Access. Upon arriving at the hotel the staff immediately took care of our luggage and directed us to check in at the club lounge instead of the main lobby. The check in process was quick and professional. All of the staff members at Keio Plaza were consistently polite, warm and very helpful. The room was spacious and extremely clean, and the amenities were of high quality. The room also had an amazing view of the city. We were very happy with all aspects of the room. In addition to this, the club lounge which also had a beautiful view had a delicious large range of food for breakfast, tea and bar time. They had a good selection of tea (which we love) and even had takeaway cups available for us to use. The service from the staff was always attentive and fantastic. They were also very kind and organised a dessert platter for my friend at tea time and when we went to their restaurant for dinner. I cannot praise this hotel enough, the extra cost of the grand premier room was well worth it. An excellent way to end our Japan trip.
user_name:
tract003
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: After 1.5 weeks enjoying smaller, intimate hotels and ryokans in Kyoto, Magome, Tsumago, and Matsumoto, the Keio Plaza Hotel was a bit of a shock to the senses, as was Tokyo’s Shinjuku Station, our first stop in the massive Tokyo. We had little choice for a Saturday night stay, as so many hotels close to transit stations were booked. The Keio had tons of guests everywhere. Tour groups, conferences, was there also a group of figure skating competitors from around the world? Golly. We were a solo family and paid a premium for a basic room on the 26th floor. After a long walk through Shinjuku Park (wonderful but so crowded on a Sunday) and the streets of restaurants and shops, I needed to rest my very tired feet and recently replaced hip. There was no where to sit. The lobby was absolutely packed. But you know, there was so much floor space in that massive hotel, you’d think additional couches would not be difficult to provide. I’d suggest staying away unless you’re with a tour group that could get you a more reasonable room rate and ensure a place to rest, even if only in the tour bus parked just outside.

I really liked most everything about this hotel. The location was great, the staff were very friendly and helpful, the room was a good size, the elevators worked well, and the breakfast options were excellent. We had a Plaza Superior Double in the south tower but unfortunately, the bed was very hard and I woke up with a sore back every morning. We were here for six days and I tried to purchase a heating pad for my back, but I don't think they have these in Japan. No one understood what I was looking for. If you like a firm mattress then this hotel is for you. If not, you may wish to look elsewhere.

Excellent hotel rooms and bathroom are grat especially on the higher floors great vieuw especially you are on the executive floors with entrance to the lounge on the 45 th floor great breakfast and happy hour with wine and snacks.Nearby shops and rstaurant and the main railwaystation.Good internet access. You can also book tours in the hotel.

The Keio Plaza is all around excellent - Very helpful, polite staff. Check-in/Check-out was nice and easy.Location is ideal, about 7 mins walk to Shinjuku Station or 5 mins to less crowded Tocho-Mae subway station (15 -20 mins to get to Shibuya or Harajuku-Omotesando area). Restaurants, many many restaurants, as well as a ton of shopping, just a short stroll outside the hotel and all around Shinjuku area. The hotel room was very spacious and clean. Stayed in the South Tower, with the Tokyo Metro Govt office (night/day time observatory deck, go check it out for free!) right outside our window.We ate at a couple of the breakfast buffet spots at the hotel restaurants (Jurin and Glass Court) and they were all equally great! Hotel Wi-Fi was available and pretty good but we also got the pocket Wi-Fi - highly recommend as we had internet all the time anywhere we went... (Pupuru Wifi - order online). Complimentary use of mobile phone was handy as well to make local calls if needed and google maps of course.Nice big hotel, with 24 hr convenience store, pool and gym.. quite a busy place..but would definitely stay here again. Tip - if coming from airport, there is a Airport Limousine bus that stops at the Keio Plaza door. Takes a little longer (1.5 - 2hrs) than the train but saves from dragging your luggage around the streets... which we saw a lot!

It was fine as a hotel. The only problem was that the first 3 nights I stayed in a smoking room which was smelling very badly of smoke. Yes I get it, it was a smoking room but they could take steps in order to air the room better. The other nights the room was fine (it was non smoking). The breakfast was fine, maybe they could have more choices in bread

we will stay 5 days in this hotel and it was awesome, rooms are very clean and useful, there are to many facilities to use. there are lots of things nearby. you only walk 100 meters to main station so you can access every place immediately

Fantastic hotel located an easy 5 min walk from Shinjuku station and mall. Plenty of places to eat within that 5 min walk. The rooms were decent sized with good beds and showers. It was also just a 5 min taxi ride to the nonstop neon-blaring red light and entertainment district. Whether you are looking for a cat bar, a strip club, robot bar, arcade place, meals, drinks, movies...you can find it there. Very eye-opening and fun to walk around.

This was my husband and daughter's first time to Tokyo and it was amazing! Our trip was in relation to the Tokyo Marathon and this hotel is an excellent location right by the start line. The Keio Plaza is all around excellent -close to transportation and restaurants. The hotel room was very spacious and clean and the staff was so helpful! We ate at several of the hotel restaurants and they were all equally great! Wi-Fi was available but we got the pocket Wi-Fi which a highly recommend as we had internet all the time. Being a first time visitor to Japan I was really nervous the language but it was not a problem - most of the locals seems to know enough to help you or will go as far as to walk you to where you are going(within the location). The subways signs were also in English which made it super easy to explore. From our arrival at the Narita Airport it was smooth sailing - we took the airport limo service round trip and it was easy and reliable. We took a tour which was so convenient as pick up was right at the Keio Plaza. I can not say enough about the polite and helpful nature of the locals and everything is so clean! We are already planning our next trip.

Traveling for the first time we were skeptical about our stay... but after reading the reviews we decided to stay at Keio Plaza... and it was GREAT decision !The rooms were spacious, restaurants were great, the location is amazing... closer to station and a lot of restaurants! The best part was... they had a phone with data plan with international calling made available for us during the entire stay !!!! It was of great use !!!

My friend and I went to complete our Marathon Majors Six Star Finishers medals by completing the Tokyo marathon. Stayed four nights at this great location for the start of the Tokyo Marathon. The staff could not do enough to meet our needs from coming to our room to fix the techie problems with OUR personal IT equipment. The free WiFi needs to be logged on every day but our dodgy phones needed help so within five minutes of a call to the Front Desk, a member of staff came up to our 38th floor room to fix it.There is an in house massage service providing the right blend between a deep tissue sports and a form of holistic Japanese massage - really good value for money and they come to your room on time when you book them.Interesting powered blinds looking into the glass bathroom wall took us by surprise as did the fancy WC.A well stocked fridge was tempting but we just put our own stuff in it. A great selection of teas with generous top ups was just what we needed after the cold wet marathon.The Club lounge on 45th floor (I cannot remember now) had a fantastic range of foods too.If I had a question mark it would be that the Gym for the size of the hotel was rather small.

First visit to Tokyo and my husband booked this hotel for 4 of us. 2 adults, one late teenager and 5 year old. Easy to get to from Narita airport. We took the airport limousine bus which dropped us directly outside the hotel. The rooms were very spacious which I believe is scarce for Tokyo but the room easily fitted the 4 of us with a spacious bathroom and wardrobe with plenty of storage. Very clean and tidy. Quiet hotel in the business area but only a short walk to the city centre with plenty of shops and restaurants nearby. We also signed up for some day trips and the pick up and drop off point were about 5 minutes walk away. The hotel made it easy for us to get the airport limousine bus back to the airport when we left as it had dedicated staff for this service on site. My LO got his own kids sized slippers in the room too which was a nice little touch. Happy to go back to this hotel on our next visit.

Fabulous hotel. Great location (once we got our bearings)Very clean room.Great choice of restaurants both around the hotel and inside the hotel itself.Very helpful, polite staff.Would definitely stay here again. Tip - if coming from airport, there is a bus that stops at the door. Takes a little longer than the train but saves negotiating station when just off the plane.

Huge hotel with many rooms and 12 restaurants. Three options for buffet breakfasts. I had a room upgrade on a high floor which was perfect. Small bathrooms but that is expected for Tokyo. Location is good and friendly staff.

Perfect location for Tokyo Marathon start line. My wife participated and the short walk ensured that we had plenty of time for breakfast and since it rained we didn’t have to leave too early.We didn’t use much of the amenities but there is a small gym and a couple of restaurants in the hotel

The hotel lies in the heart of Shinjuku, close to restaurants a crouded shopping area and a lot of restaurants. So location top marks. Check in very fast professional all set in advance. Courteous and polite. Rooms are large by Tokyo standards equipped with all amenities from safe to hair dryer complimentary water as you wod expect. Beds are very large and comfortable. The buildind is a skyscraper so very much business like. Not charming, but functional and somewhat smart. The area of excellence of this hotel is breakfast, multiple restaurants which offer a vast selection of food for all imaginable tastes, and quality is top notch. What can I say more. Business like ospitality japanese style. I could have hoped for more.

I was greatly looking forward to staying at this hotel - it was the last of my 14 day trip to Japan. Upon check in, it was very crowded, rushed, and we went without a proper greeting. The rooms themselves were by far the worst of any of the other hotels we stayed at (all 4 and 5 stars). Outdated and small bed. We were looking forward to the pool with our daughter but it was closed.The positives were the breakfast buffet and location. Perhaps it was a poor experience due to the Marathon but if I could do it again I would with out a doubt stay somewhere else.

I stayed in 2 other hotels across Kyoto and Hakone over the week as well, and there was nothing in either of them that this hotel didn't have, besides a hot spring (which, simply based on geography is no fault of this hotel). Location wise, this hotel is in a safe area that is walking distance to the business district, entertainment district, and train station.Most importantly though, they went above and beyond when holding my luggage for 3 days as I travelled between hotels. The name tag of my bag broke off at some point without my realization, and I'd lost the tag they gave me to reclaim the bag. Combined with the language barrier, it made for an arduous process to get my luggage, yet they pulled through and had many methods to handle the problem calmly, professionally, and kindly.

After a long trip we arrived at the hotel in the evening and were told that despite the terms in our reservation (i showed the front desk my reservation confirmation) we would have to pay an extra $1000 for our stay. I am Asian fluent in both English and Japanese and the person at the front desk must have thought that I don't speak any Japanese since I spoke to him in English at first. When he spoke to his manager over the phone he was very impolite when he talked about us and our situation assuming that I didn't understand the conversation. We walked out right away and will never return. Shame on you.

This hotel was beautiful and comfortable. It has everything you could need in the building, a convenience store, nice shops, many restaurants of many varieties and even a few museum like exhibits. The staff was friendly and efficient. We even could see Mount Fuji from our room in the South Tower. Many trains close by as well. There is a nice bar on the top floor of the North Tower.

On arrival our room wasn't ready as we had arrived early morning and check-in wasn't until 2pm but they were very accommodating as we were travelling with my 5 yr old daughter so we only had to wait about an hour or so. Our room was very clean, tidy and spacious. Room service was very efficient for example we asked for towels and they delivered them to use each day so we didn't have to keep asking. I have never experienced such quick and efficient room service before! When we called within 5 minutes someone was knocking at our door with our request! Great service. The hotel has great restaurants and amazing views of Tokyo lights from some of the restaurants on the higher floors. I would highly recommend this hotel.

We stayed on the 37th level and had access to Level 45, so really this was an amazing experience. It is a little pricy, however rooms are top notch and everything is laid on. Staff are attentive and having access to Level 45 was well worth it.The views are expansive and the location is ideal for exploring Tokyo as Shinjuku-Ku station is only minutes away. Also easy access via the limousine bus to the airport.

The hotel is located in the heart of Shinjuku. The lower level of the hotel leads to the underground walk ways east to Shinjuku station. The 2 underground tunnel system has moveable walkways going east and west. About 7 minute walk to the station The hotel rooms have a very large bath tub and hand wand shower. Excellent heated toilet. The beds and pillows were a bit to firm. Large tv with limited channel selection. Has excellent free in room wifi and the room comes with a portable cell device. Has a tea kettle and mini fridge. Beautiful hotel with many good restaurants, some quite expensive. Excellent location and easy walking distance to many traditional Japanese restaurants. Royal host restaurant is across the street and is like a Japanese Denny’s. It is really good. Very good concierge and extremely helpful and polite staff. Our room was on the 28 facing the metropolitan building

Great location very near Shinjuku station making it easy to get around Tokyo. Many restaurants nearby and shopping. Rooms are great and the lounge was nice to visit for a break. Rooms are very comfortable and I loved the bath products - grapefruit smell!

We stayed here twice during our visit to Japan. The front desk of the hotel was difficult to find at first, but I believe we entered from the wrong side of the building. There are really comfy seats to sit in while you wait to get checked in, and front desk staff were very efficient with the large crowd checking in. On the first stay we were in a Plaza Luxe Corner King room. I advised the hotel when booking that we were staying for a special occasion and we were presented with a nice chocolate cake gift at check in. Our room was spacious and modern. We also had access to the club lounge included in this room. The views from the lounge were amazing and there was a variety of snacks and drinks provided. On the second stay we were were in a Princess Kitty room. This room was very highly priced, but for a Sanrio lover, it was a must even for a short stay. The room comes with all sorts of Princess Hello Kitty items, such as sofa, kettle, wallpaper, and also includes some items you can take home like bow water bottle (the same as found at Sanrio Puroland), pink & purple slippers, and of course the Hello Kitty dolls. I have heard these change on occasion, ours had on yukatas in the same pattern that was provided in our room. The location of the hotel is about a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku station (mostly through covered tunnel, and another smaller station is about a 3 minute walk in the opposite direction (forgive me, I forget the name). The Metropolitan Government building is a very short walk. There are so many dining options in the hotel. Unfortunately we only ate there during breakfasts. Our favorite place was Jurin, which had buffet style and chefs who cooked different items at request every morning. I cannot remember all of the options, but one morning there were omelets. We liked Jurin more mainly due to the atmosphere in the morning - it was bright and the large windows provided great people watching as everyone was heading to work. We also liked Glass Court, though the lines were often much longer than Jurin, and I found the atmosphere not as good. Both restaurants offered western & Japanese style breakfast foods.

Great Location in Shinjuku, walkable to restaurants and shopping.The Airport limosine bus service stops at this hotel - so if you fly into Haneda you can catch the bus straight to the Hotel which is very easy to navigate and depending on the time of day can take 30 mins to over an hour.We had a triple room - stayed there twice during our 2 weeks in Japan - the second room was much larger than the original one we stayed in - both were in the South Tower.We had booked the Hello Kitty (themed) room which was going to be a treat - but the hotel contacted us and told us that it was being renovated so disappointingly we missed out Good for a family, close to the JR and subways stations. Great location.

Smooth Japanese efficiency, attentive staff, choice of restaurants, spacious and comfortable rooms, difficult to fault! The breakfast choice was excellent, the club restaurant on a higher floor had excellent views and comfortable seating. The Japanese Teppan Yaki restaurant on the first floor was the best I have ever visited, but expensive! The hotel is easy to walk from, in one direction to shopping streets filled with choice, and in the other to parks to walk through - although the month we visited it was too hot to do so for long! It is a large hotel, however, which means a sense of character, or homliness, is lacking. But for a comfortable, efficiently run operation, it succeeds. And the Teppan Yaki restaurant is to die for!

Great hotel with fantastic sized rooms as we needed a triple . Room service tasty and not too pricey. Breakfast buffet a bit overpriced for basic items . Chosen for location as most day tours picked up from hotel and limo bus drops to door . Quiet clean and spacious . But of a walk to main Shinjuku restaurant area and esp when lugging suitcases to the train .

Spent three days at this hotel. Was a little dated compared to Cerulean Tower (previous hotel) but free tea/coffee in room PLUS make enquiries when booking about access to Luxe lounge which was a hidden gem. TV had some channels with subtitles in English and as I was poorly for a couple of days this was a luxury and meant I had something to watch whilst stuck in room. There are lots of shops etc around the hotel and again just five minute walk from town. We had an amazing view from our hotel window of Mount Fuji.

Keio Plaza hotel is in the Shinjuku area which is central and easy to get around close to transport. Rooms are clean and comfortable. The hotel does provide a shuttle to Disneyland and Disney sea but these need to be booked prior as they do fill up.

My family and I went on a skiing holiday and stayed in Shinjuku for 3 days and we arrived at Haneda airport at 5am and artived at the hotel by 630am and the staff members (about 3) at reception did not acknowledge us even though we were the only ones there and I had to go to one of them directly. They informed us that check in is at 2pm, which is fair enough but there was no place to sit and wait for 7 hours and have two kids with me and hardly any sleep. Staying at this hotel isn't cheap and we had two rooms and moving onto a bigger room the next day. They did not accommodate us at all and we checked in at 1.30pm! Needless to day we did not stay here when we returned to tokyo after our ski trip, first impressions lasts!!!

Granted that Japanese hotel usually charge extra for second guest, charging 6000 yens per night is simply too much.Other than rooms are big, this hotel has no other plus point. There are many hotels in Tokyo which are newer, cheaper and nearer to train station.

Wow what a great location this hotel is in everything's in walking distance yet it's in a nice quiet area with the government building direct opposite great to go to the observatory deck and see the whole oh Tokyo for free only problem with this hotel was the bed was rock hard and the walls were paper thin rooms were average size TV really didn't work too well a little overpriced also the views from the room were exceptional

The hotel is near the Shinjuku station which around 5-8 mins walk. The The reason to choose this hotel for this trip is that the hotel is a Tokyo Disneyland Neighborhood hotel and have direct shuttle bus to Disneyland. So if you are going to Tokyo Disneyland and you may want to think about to stay in this hotel. Also, Shinjuku station was a big interchange station to many of the train line. Nice and clean room and the staff makes it one of my favorite hotel choice.

This was the 3rd time we had stayed here. We always like the close proximity of the hotel to the JR Shinjuku station as well as the spacious room. We liked the well prepared refreshments at the Club Floor before and after our shopping trips. Splendid, comfortable and clean hotel! Have a fantastic nice view too.

Check in staff were very pleasant but slow.Room was about $450 for 3 single beds. Very basic. Cabinet style bathroom.Room service was okay.Basically it served a need, arriving late into Shinjuku and departing early the next day.It was a moderately tough walk with loads of bags and ski gear, coming off the 10 hour flight.I'm sure there are nicer rooms, but otherwise I wouldn't stay here again unless dire need.

Found this one of the best stay. The ambience, the location, the staff, everything is great. I stayed on 32nd floor and view was amazing. In the morning was able to see the Mt. Fuji directly from my bed.stayed here for 6 days and it was Amazing experience. The hospitality was great though language is problem as very few English speaking staff but still they go out all the way to resolve your issue. I had not given full five stars for the reason being room felt little small but all other things covers up this.location everything in just 5-10min walk. Station is just across. Lounge on 34th Floor was with great city view. And again staff are so polite and helpful. Than you Keio people for making my trip wonderful and memorable.

We stayed here for four nights in January 2019. Whilst our room did not match the lovely pictures online, it was clean, comfortable and larger than expected. Yes the carpet was stained and the furniture a little dated the view certainly made up for the minor cosmetic flaws. The hotel itself us enormous, the staff are incredibly friendly and helpful. They even called our next hotel 8n Hakuba on my behalf to sort a couple of issues.The hotel lobby is stunning with a gorgeous chandelier and a fabulous flower arrangement. A convenience store on the lower level of the hotel was an added bonus. The hotel is in a convenient location and a number of tours operate from the hotel, as well as a free shuttle bus to disneyland. I will definitely consider staying here again.

I booked the Keio Plaza based on the photos show here on Trip Advisor. I'm a single mum, travelling with my 3 children so had booked interconnecting rooms. The staff at reception were really helpful and the kids and I went up to our rooms excited to start our holiday in Japan. Upon seeing our rooms my excitement turned to disappointment. Both rooms were very old - the carpet was stained, the beds very low to the ground with beige covers and the bathrooms were ancient. Nothing like the pictures I had seen!I went back to reception to voice my disappointment and frustration at being allocated rooms which were NOT like they displayed online. After almost an hour the reception staff finally agreed to move us to 2 superior rooms - which still didn't look as good as the pictures online and were not interconnecting - for a reasonable additional cost. So, while reception did finally move us to rooms that were OK, it was a very disappointing start to our holiday. If you are considering booking this hotel make sure you triple check the room type you are booking to ensure you are not disappointed!

A hotel doesn’t get nearly 4000 excellent and good reviews for nothing,we are checking out today after staying here twice in the last 12 days,we had a few days in Kyoto in the middle,which I also highly recommend .The hotel is just amazing,very big,1500 rooms,I think,check in is very professional ,nice,polite,easy.We stayed in a luxe room,approx $500 a night,worth every cent,if you’re travelling a long way,spend a little extra and get one of these rooms. you have access to a private lounge which gives you coffee,tea,refreshments and snacks all day,and drinks,beer,wine etc from 5pm to 7pm,all included in your room price,plus you get a mobile phone,free to use for your stay,includes unlimited international calls,messages etc,very useful ,especially when you’re out sightseeing,also very useful for the train and underground system.There are three choices of venue for breakfast,including a western style buffet which we had most days,all good,except the toaster is in desperate need of an upgrade,it’s too small and too slow for the volume of people using it,toast has to go through 2 to 4 times,with all settings on full.There is a seperate tour desk which is very good for any enquires on tours or bookings you want to make,also as well as reception being open 24/7 there is a duty managers desk,which normally has two duty managers and this is very convenient for any general enquires you may have,all in all we had a wonderful time here at Keio Plaza,if we come back we would not stay anywhere else,and we will recommend to friends who are coming this year and next to stay here.

This hotel is amazing! I was met by a very friendly doorman who took care of my luggage while I checked in. The front desk staff was very friendly and accommodating. I ordered room service on the first night and there was no language barrier at all. I also tried out their Teppanyaki restaurant and was amazed at the wonderful food and service I received. The rooms are a little pricey but it was well worth it in my mind.

Family of 6 in Tokyo for Christmas before flying north to Niseko skiing for New Year. We were 3 generations, stayed at Keio Plaza. it's a very large hotel. Location is great, close to train from the airport and easy walk to many other places. Had 3 standard rooms, one with connecting door. Just normal hotel rooms, but perfectly fine. Hotel staff were excellent and helpful. Didn't eat at the hotel as it was expensive, but very close are many options to eat well and cheap. Lots of 'Must Do' places in the area. Underground was easy to use and very close. We caught the Narita Express from the airport, and it goes to Shinjuku Station beside the hotel. it's a maze of exits but several on the west side come out near the hotel. was a 5 minute walk using google maps.

Firstly, I must say that this hotel is well located in all the sightseeing and shopping districts of Tokyo. Our room was rather small and the check in staff were rather abrupt and rude. We had an infant with us and the female porters were the redeeming feature of the check-in process as they cheered up our son. It’s a huge hotel and we feel that we were just a number. I feel there is better value in some of the bigger hotel chains nearby. This was our second choice as our first was booked out. It was recommended to us by a friend. Positives include being close to the station and the free Government Building Observatory located across the street!Shinjuku has many things going on, so do yourself a favour and eat out rather than eat the at the in-house restaurant.

This is a large 1,000 bed hotel, so you can expect that it is less personalized but highly functional and efficient. Rooms are spacious and everything is clean and comfortable.Things get a bit busy during breakfast which is spread out over three restaurants which you can choose from but be prepared to wait a short while to be seated. Once seated however, the breakfast spread is good.Location wise, walking distance to the Shinjuku shopping area and right above the train station, which was very convenient.

This place is in a great spot, walking distance to Shinjuki and within 1km of Shinjuku train station. Very comfortable, friendly staff, beds were reasonable, a bit hard for my liking. Tea & coffee making facilities, plenty of USB charging ports. The rooms are smallish, but by internet searching, this was one of the bigger places available. Would certainly use this hotel again

Great location, hotel is a little dated but has everything you need to be comfortable. Short stroll to restaurants. Family room size was very generous, even by western standards. Close to train station. Good family option at reasonable price.

We stayed at this hotel for 5 nights. Great location, right above a subway station and in Shinjuku, an area that offers lots to see and do. The room was spacious enough and clean, with a great view of Tokyo (we were at the 29th floor). The hotel itself is huge, with multiple restaurants and facilities (also a convience store); that’s also a flaw, because it feels “impersonal” at times. The staff was helpful enough except when asked to make a reservation in Kyoto (our next destination): they refused with no second thoughts. Also, the level of English wasn’t always on point. I would definitely recommend this hotel for a pleasant stay in Tokyo.

We had booked this hotel for 7 nights ,we chose this hotel as we found this to be located next to Shinjuku Station which was About a brisk 7/10 minutes walk from the hotel .the location was great and Shinjuku Station being near was a boon , we took the Narita express from airport to shinjuku after getting our Jr pass issued from their office at narita airport ,We reached shinjuku from narita in approximately 90 minutes and made our way to the hotel .On reaching the hotel we found it to be bustling And having a huge lobby , which must have been grand at one time but now needs renovation, check in was efficient .We had booked the renovated superior rooms Which are on the higher floors , the lifts are fast and frequency is good. The newly renovated rooms at 300 USD wereSmall and disappointing but I guess you have to keep in mind that Tokyo is an expensive city. We had breakfast a couple of days during our Stay breakfast is average for the price of 2700 yen and it shuts at 1030. Have the breakfast at glass house it was the best compared to the other restaurants. The problem in this hotel is it feels as if all the Staff is just running around to complete their Work without actually listening and understanding what the guest needs they allSeem overwhelmed with the work can’t figure out why.One night I took my daughter to the Italian Restaurent for pizza I don’t think I have eaten a worse pizza than this, the staff in this place was also pretty cold and unwelcoming.If you need to stay here it shud be only for location , apart from this nothing else worth remembering about this place .On the return to narita airport we took the Airport shuttle from our hotel to naritaVery good service which takes you directly to Narita after making a couple of stops at Nearby hotels .

We stayed in suite on 36th floor and absolutely loved it. Nice view, great location, good pajamas, nice yukata robes, soft slippers and perfect pillows. Good selection of coffees in the room. Breakfast was tasty, stuff friendly. Spacious bathroom, Would stay again!

Location wise it is quite convenient. It is a short 15 minutes walk to the train station. The check in queue is long but the whole process is efficient. The rooms are very spacious for japan standard. The bed and pillow are very comfortable. The bathroom is spotlessly clean and spacious as well. Excellent service and will come back here for sure.

Check-in was a great welcome from the staff which had attention to detail and made us feel like at home. we stayed at one of the suites which had amazing views to the city's skyline and sunrise in the morning. perfect stay in tokyo!

The Keio Plaza hotel was fantastic to stay in. We had two rooms for our family of five. One room with a queen bed and one room on another floor. If you want connecting doors ( not sure if they even exist) or to be next door to another room make sure you have the same style room. Also make sure you request a NON SMOKING room. The hotel is a five/ten minute walk to Shinjuku Train Station and all the shopping you could possibly want. Shinjuku is a hive of activity, as is the Keio Plaza. Others have posted it’s too busy, well it’s a huge hotel but we always found the staff eager to assist with any questions we had. You can even walk almost the entire length of Shinjuku under cover to the train station. Our rooms were very clean every day, despite the best efforts of our youngest to make a mess every night. The cleaning staff did an amazing job on our return the room was immaculate againRoom service was a little on the high side in price but quality was good. We didn’t have breakfast, choosing to eat at the Royal Host Cafe two minute walk from the hotel. On Saturday mornings there is a local market in the park opposite the hotel. Lots of fun, lovely walk in the Shinjuku Park, temples, water features and such. We would gladly stay at the Keio Plaza again due to its location, price and wonderful service.

I’ve stayed a number of times at the Keio Plaza hotel- it’s never been particularly memorable. However this time I booked the “Club Floor” rooms without realising it. As soon as we got to the lobby check in desk, there was a sign indicating that Club Floor rooms (known as Premier Grand) check-ins were on the 45th floor. They quickly ushered us up to check in which also meant we were able to avoid the queue downstairs with the hoards of tourists in their lobby. There are just so many people, tourists and locals alike, in the lobby and everywhere all the time. The place is literally swarming.We sat down to a hot towel and a tea, and they checked us in whilst we relaxed in the lounge. After sorting out a minor misunderstanding with the booking (done through another large booking website) they gave us the keys to our room. You access your floor with a mere tap of the room key on the four panels located around the lift so you don’t need to clamber for the button panel in the front which I thought was a nice touch. This was especially useful as the lifts got quite busy due to some end of year sales event being held on multiple floors in the hotel whilst we were there.The rooms themselves were SO much nicer than the other floors. They were spacious and airy and still smelled new (and not foosty or smoky). The shower/bath tub room was large and separate from the toilet. Needless to say, the amenities were top notch- they had everything you could possibly need from cleansing milk to hair gel. Even the slippers were fluffier.Breakfast came with the room and we had the choice of all the restaurants in the hotel but decided to have it on their club floor lounge area for the spectacular views and to avoid the madding crowds. Although the selection wasn’t huge, their egg station was excellent (or should I say eggcellent). The lounge area, replete with hot and cold refreshments, was opened until 10pm at night- this was a great place to convene before setting off in the morning or in the evening before dinner. Check out was a breeze and all done on the 45th floor. They helped us book our airport limousine bus tickets and handled all the luggage. We were able to sit in the lounge and enjoy a coffee until we had to leave for our bus.Honestly I was never particularly fond of the Keio Plaza hotel- it was just convenient and nostalgic for the parents but this trip made me look at it in a different light. It was probably one of the best hotel stays I’ve had in Tokyo. In short, I would highly recommend you shell out extra for the Premier Grand rooms or choose a different smaller, newer hotel with fewer guests.

We were going to stay at Hotel Gracery but thank god we didn't (that area is way too crazy busy). This hotel is walking distance to the best neighborhoods to visit, and also the Shinjuku train station is connected by a tunnel to the hotel which has trains and subways to everywhere else you might need to go. It is big; but has lots of restaurants within the hotel and the food is really very good. Rooms are super clean--more 3 star than 5 star (not marble bathrooms but very clean and comfortable) and the money you save on the rooms can go towards eating out. Highly recommend.

This is a busy hotel with many international guests--walking around I heard American English, Australian English, Chinese, French, and other languages. Lots of families with kids. Rooms are very tastefully decorated and well laid out to maximize the use of space. Two complimentary mineral waters per day plus tea bags, instant coffee, and a good electric kettle were nice amenities. You do hear some noise from hallways and other rooms and the street (sirens) but probably 90% of the time was quiet.Staff speak English, some better than others.We got the buffet, although I wasn't sure I would use it, but it ended up being a nice option. Decent selection of fruit, cereal, pastries, several hot dishes (veggies, rice, potatoes), an omelet station, and a machine that made good lattes. We could load up before heading out for the day and then only need a small lunch or snacks until dinner. However many cafes and convenience stores are nearby if you don't want the buffet. The main buffet (which had noodles and dumplings as well as Western breakfast foods) often had a big line but the "American" one never did.Overall a clean, pleasant hotel in a convenient location.

RoomsWe had Plaza Luxe Corner King room on the 33rd floor in the south tower. The bed was comfortable, the room was clean, the air conditioning was good.Please note, I went through this entire trip advisor thread and there are some really contradictory comments about the main tower vs the south tower. I didn't have any problems with our room in the south tower.WifiWifi was free with our package, the speed was very slow sometimes.StaffHelpful and friendly. Eri from guest relations was especially great!LocationThe short walk from the hotel to the train station takes you through the area with all the restaurants the locals frequent after work.There is a bus which goes from the hotel to and from the airport which is well organised.

We (man woman child) stayed here one night so we could experience the hello kitty room while in Tokyo.The room was a bit on the expensive side but it was a fun experience in an awesome hotel. Let me say that part again - this was an awesome hotel. The hotel looks amazing and there were people waiting to help us with every part of checking in and getting into our room. The room itself was great - come on, it’s hello kitty themed - and the facilities were exactly what you would expect of a hotel of this caliber.In addition to the great collectibles we got from staying in the room, we also got tickets to puroland. The staff spoke English to a very very reasonable level - no complaints. When it was time for us to leave, they called us a taxi and got us situated in it. We will stay here again.

We are back again after 2 years. Chose the same type of room but this time, it wasn't good as previous even though i booked at least 4 months in advance.Same bf spread like 2 years back !No personal touch even though we are repeated guests and paying premium price for the rooms.

In my view, this hotel is not really a five star hotel. The lobby seems rather worn out and massified. We stayed at the Grand Premier club level, which was better but not of the quality of the clubs of other hotels. Rooms were a bit small even at the Grand Premier level. The breakfast was fine. The ladies at the reception of the club room were helpful with reservations. There were a couple of men at the entrance of the club that seemed like security and were not nice at all. Hard to understand why there is a need for a threatening security people at the entrance of the club. The bell captain at the lobby was not helpful at all: I asked for the service to transfer the suitcases to another hotel and just told me to look it up on the Internet. By chance I asked the ladies at the club reception and they were able to arrange everything. There is a travel agency at the lobby level with very friendly and helpful staff. The Teppanyaki restaurant was very good and interesting but perhaps overpriced. The hotel is probably good for families with kids.

I would rarely give 5/5 for a hotel, which means I would want to come back here each time I visit this location. Keio Plaza Hotel is conveniently located just a short walk from Shinjuku station. The hotel rooms are newly renovated, the have everything in it including bottled water, proper toilet and facial tissue paper, and yukata for your convenience. The staff at all level give very high quality service 24/7, you only need to ask, or sometimes be surprised at their initiative. You can opt for Japanese breakfast set instead of the international buffet, which is very pretty, elegant, fresh and tasty. They have helped us make our stay very pleasant and organised, like this is a home we are familiar with and a home we want to come back to.

Great accessibility near Shinjuku station, The hotel is big, and triple rooms are spacious which is hard to find in Tokyo. Check in was a bit slower, but very helpful and friendly staff, excellent facilities and amenities, nice and clean spacious rooms with view of city., bathroom was also spacious and complete with everything we need and most of all clean. Wifi was fast & reliable, has a free handy/phone for 4G internet use while out in the streets. Breakfast has many choices Western & Japanese buffet which was great and we have no complaints. Everything was great from hotel made our stay in Tokyo very pleasant for a family with a toddler and child. 10/10 will stay again, and suggest this hotel to anyone going to Tokyo. Only suggestion to the management is to lessen the use of plastic bottles on water and soap for environmental purposes.

I chose the hotel for the location so that my parents would be able to find it easily and it was definitely easy to find for them. However the hotel itself is old and needs upgrading though it was clean. For the price it would be more attractive if there was some upgrading and modernisation done for the rooms. Otherwise the staff were great and many spoke good English which is a plus point. Best way to get to the hotel is to come out of the west gate walk to keio plaza hotel exit across from the electronic store and cross the road. You will pass rhe airport limousine bus stop. Walking straight will get you to the hotel. There are a lot of eateries just down from the hotel along that walk so convenient to get dinner even late at night.

Keio Plaza HotelWe were a family of 2 adults and 2 children (8 and 4) and we had booked this hotel for our Tokyo portion of our Japan trip during 1st week December. This is a large and busy hotel which caters to many tour groups and so we always notice crowds of people moving about at the lobby areas. The staff, however, were plentiful and always at hand to assist.LocationKeio Plaza is located at the Shinjuku west area and is about 10 mins walk from Shinjuku Station. It is located amongst office buildings and it is very near to the Tokyo Metropolitan building where you may head to have a bird’s eye view of the city. There is a fully covered walkway which starts from one of the entrances of the hotel and leads you all the way to the west entrance of Shinjuku Station. This was very useful as the walkway was lined with travelators making handling children and luggage a breeze.RoomWe booked a Standard Twin Room which was large by Japanese standards. They had placed 3 beds even though it was a double room but there was enough space to open large luggages and for children and us to move about. The toilet was well equipped with all the necessary toiletries and also had the “space age” toilet bowls which came heated and with all the bidet controls for washing. All of these were clean and polished making our stay pleasant. They also provide a complementary Smartphone which you can take out during your stay at this hotel. This made navigating using Google Maps a breeze as well.FacilitiesThe hotel has a direct shuttle service to Tokyo Disneyland which was very convenient. You need to reserve seats using their Keio plaza website beforehand and they will hand you the shuttle tickets upon check in. The hotel has 6 restaurants and a convenience store (konbini). We only tried the breakfast buffet restaurant which was reasonable. There are also some Indian and Turkish restaurants which are within walking distance of this hotel and the food at those places was good too.ServiceThis was a busy hotel but the service we received was top notch. I have to commend the Bell Captain and team who were always at hand to assist me with keeping luggage before check in as well as luggage transfer between hotels from Tokyo to Kyoto. Even at 11pm at night, there are a few of them always moving around to ensure that everyone is attended to. They brought our luggages to our rooms, guided us on the room facilities and handled the luggage transfer process for us. All I needed to do was to pass the address of the hotel to them and they did all the work. Overall, our stay here was just for 2 nights and we had booked this primarily for the Disney Shuttle as well as the location being relatively near to Shinjuku Station. We enjoyed our stay thoroughly and we would recommend this hotel for its service and efficiency.

1) Convenient Location, walking distance via covered walkway to Shinjuku Train Station (except for a short distance between the Hotel and the entrance to the walkway)2) Nice, clean, comfortable hotel. Range of rooms to suit your budget. Although it must be said that Tokyo Hotels are generally more expensive and smaller.3) Direct Highway Express Bus to and from Narita and Haneda Airport.4) Friendly helpful staff.

My wife and I staid here for a week at the beginning of December, for her birthday. The hotel is in a perfect spot in the best district of Tokyo to stay as a tourist. Many things have been said by others already so I will leave you my top tips: 1) Do catch the Limousine bus from either Narita or Hadena airports- it’s £21 each way , comfortable, efficient and goes right to the hotel . Make sure you go online and buy the ticket from the airport to the hotel at least one day before you arrive. Tickets back to the airport can be bought from the hotel concierge 2) If you book a deluxe plaza room you get high floors with excellent views, go to the south tower, larger room and access to the 34th floor lounge with free drinks and snacks - highly recommend 3) don’t worry about breakfast - there are plenty of local cafes - use the exit the other side to the main entrance, cross the road and take your pick - we particularly like Pronto - second turning on the left as you walk up the pedestrian walkway directly opposite the hotel - a quarter of the price charged in the hotel 4) if you use the same entrance and walkway you will arrive at Shinjuku station in less than 10 minutes , take a left and walk to all the shops and nightlife. 5) taxis are very expensive - use the tube- it’s cheap and efficient - signs are all in English - a bit daunting with the amount of people - but easy after the first go!! 6) The hotel provides a smartphone free of charge in your room for your use - has local information , sat nav for walking around and free local and international calls - excellent service 7) standard of English at hotel reception and concierge is very good , elsewhere very little English spoken - signs are in English but you have to do a lot of pointing at English menus , which are widely available 8) we didn’t eat in the hotel , menu is available in the room but prices are hideous, local restaurants are plentiful and much cheaper , when choosing a restaurant don’t forget to look up- many are on the upper floors, we found some excellent Japanese restaurants that were on the upper floors. 9) the hotel bell boys at both entrances will supply you with an umbrella if it is raining 10) Tea and coffee is supplied in your room, there is a fridge, just go to the local 7 Eleven and buy a small carton of milk . 11) The hotel is a pick up point for many of the major tours - another great reason to stay here- it’s professional and easy to join these tours, staff are in the huge lobby area and are looking out for people joining tours12) all staff we interacted with were excellent, efficient, polite and professional. The hotel is nearly 50 years old but is immaculate , our room was clean, modern and in great condition13) I would recommend booking some tours with English speaking guides. We booked through the Viator app and everything ran like clockwork. I recommend the night pub crawl - my favourite tour - Mount Fuji , hakone and bullet rain, full day Tokyo tour. Do the Tokyo tour as soon as you can after arrival , it allows you to get your bearings of the city. The sky tower in Roppongi hills is something you can do yourself on the tube - 10 stops directly on the tube and is recommended . The robot restaurant is bizarre but entertaining - an acquired taste but a must do!! 14) Do walk to the park in Shinjuku , it is excellent Tokyo is amazing if you haven’t been before - a shoppers paradise- but not cheap. Don Quiotte is a great discount retailer that sells just about everything and cheaper than the flash department stores - it’s crazy busy and cramped aisles though!! There are just about every flavour of kit kats available - you have to try them If you go to Mount Fuji in the winter wrap up warm , it was -10 at 2300m Enjoy your stay

My friend recommended me to Keio Plaza hotel due to its larger room and accessibility to amenities and transport system. It really was a great stay for my family indeed.In general the hotel was traditional in style. Rooms were large and can accommodate to to 4 people with comfortable large beds. There is a day sofa and study area for admin work and even simple meals. Beds are comfortable with headboard that has USB and power sockets. Sound proofing wise I would not advise for light sleepers like me. As this is kinda of a popular hotel for families do expect some form of thumping noise from your neighbours around. LolBathrooms wise could be a little "small" for taller guys as I can touch the bathroom ceiling without stretching my arms to full.Hotel is fully equipped with convenience store and a wide selection of restaurants. JR and local subway are just a stone's throw away. Overall, I had experience a happy stay in Shinjuku. Overall

Keio Plaza is located in an area called Shinjuku. We personally liked this area as it feels like more of a business district with lovely pastry boutique shops and easy access through the JR railway to other places. The hotel is comfortable and the room is clean. There was plenty of choice for breakfast. We were a bit disappointed about the amenities particularly the gym and no access to an indoor pool. We would however recommend the hotel as staff were also helpful!

Perfect place to stay if this is your first time visit to Tokyo! Near to everything you need! Easy access to almost of the tourist destinations. Love the add on feature of the handy phone! Do not worry if you need extra luggage space, they have boxes available at the concierge!

Whilst we stayed at the Keio for 4 nights we effectively got to Narita airport as the 2nd flight Hong Kong to Narita so we arrived at the hotel at about 11 pm after a lovely ride with the Tokyo Airporter.We had a van to ourselves for 19000 yen and the traffic moved quickly at that time of the night.We stayed in a renovated premium room with love views of Tokyo and the countryside.The staff were charming, breakfasts were great. My husband still had work to do so he used the lounge to work when he had the opportunity. The one staff member said that it was the largest and highest club lounge in Tokyo.The room had so many amenities - 3 section. L' Occitane shampoos etc, another section for hair accessories and the the third section including toothpasteToothbrush etc.Very comfortable bed and bath.The Keio is very close to Shinjuku station.Close to a lot of convenience stores a Starbucks and the Keio Department store which had lovely merchandise.We bought Japanese SIM cards at Yodabashi and went back but the Sims never worked as we could get the numberOf the Sims- language problems.My husband could have stayed at the Hotel for 10 days working at the club with little outings into Tokyo ,.

Second time back in Tokyo after 14 years. Stayed in the Princess Kitty room 2250 (these room availability was not released until about August) for my November stay.We stayed 4 nights, a tour company, Inside Japan booked these rooms for us. The hotel did not send a final invoice to Inside Japan, and Inside Japan did not realize to follow-up. Needless to say, during check-in, we were kept waiting around for nearly 90 minutes before front desk assigned us a room. They were able to get in touch with Inside Japan about receiving final payment.We were triple occupancy so it was basically a third bed in a double bed room. The room is as you'd imagine, very Hello Kitty. According to the website, there were certain things you can take with you such as the bathroom amenities, the slippers, the desk note portfolio and the doll on the bed. There was complimentary "bow" shaped water bottles nightly. The amenities were replenished nightly with house keeping. Oddly, the Hello Kitty doll was not replenished after the second night. I was expecting to receive a doll each of the 4 nights we stayed there.The room has a HEPA filter, humidifier, room safe, tea/coffee making facilities, plug pin for various adapters, a scale, 2 sinks, yukata, night dress shirt, hair dryer and free WiFi. Amazingly, complimentary use of cell phone with data and certain calling allowance including international cities. No bar soap though, only liquid soap.Spacious room, good shower with perfect water pressure and draining.Our room rates included breakfast so we tried all 4 options available including room service with a Hello Kitty spread. Glass Restaurant provided the most abundant options and that's why it always has a long line (go early or you risk waiting a long time). The Japanese breakfast was also very good.This hotel is worth the splurge.
user_name:
Tardykat
New York City, New York

review_body: Perfect location for getting around on foot!You can walk to almost anything if you like getting steps in. We walked to Robot Restaurant and then all the way to Shibuya crossing. Near transit as well. Hotel has a mini-Mart on the lower floor with snacks and cheap quick meals. We stayed in a premium club level room which was huge for Tokyo standard! Breakfast was 10/10!I appreciated the high end amenities inside the room, the free smartphone to use, and the great views of the city.We also took the shuttle to Narita airport right from the hotel which was easy and much cheaper than cabbing it.

Arrived late at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo in Shinjuku because it’s a Friday. According to our airport transport driver, Friday night traffic are usually heavy. Glad that Check in was swift. Staff was great as she bothered to tell us how to connect to the hotel WiFi, how to use the traveler phone in the room etc. One thing to note is that during this period, they will turn off the central air condition and this made the room very stuffy. We requested for a fan and an air purifier which they promptly brought to our rooms. Thumbs up for their service.

I had made my first trip to Japan for leisure and was accompanied by my brother as he could speak basic Japanese.
