I had booked the hotel via a travel agent from Singapore and I was initially provided a regular 3-star hotel and after reviewing the amenities, I asked my travel agent to upgrade my accommodation and was given Keio Plaza Hotel.CHECK-INWe had arrived at the hotel at about 5pm (local Tokyo time) and it was approximately a 40 minute drive from Haneda International Airport to the property. There were many front desk staff manning the counters and check-in was swift. They only requested for our passports and our room was already available and prior to going up, they made sure to explain every detail to us, to ensure that we have a complete stay. It took no more than 10-15 minutes to complete check-in. Almost all of the front desk staff can speak English. Even the concierge services boys can speak basic English.ROOMI booked a standard room because I was out of the room most of the time and I was pleasantly surprised that the room is spacious, very clean and had comfortable beds. They didn't have extra pillows in the cupboards unless you were staying in a triple room but a call down to guest services was all it took and they quickly sent us extra pillows. The bathroom was also clean with good shower foam etc and I must add that the highlight of the bathroom was the "smart toilet". There was heating on the toilet seat as the temperature while I was in Tokyo (morning) was about 9 - 13 degree celcius and coming from Singapore, that kind of temperature was extremely cold. There was the bidet too and rear end dryer.BREAKFASTI believe almost all hotels in Japan would use the breakfast coupon system as the hotel in Osaka that I had stayed in also used breakfast coupons. In Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo, there was three options of restaurants that we could visit for breakfast; (1) Western, (2) Japanese and (3) mix Japanese and Western. The first few days, we had taken our breakfast at the Western restaurant which had a shorter queue and as the name implies, the spread catered to the Western palate and the bread spread was large. LAUNDRY SERVICEI had used their laundry service and it was efficient. If you submit your laundry was washing before 10am, it would be ready within the same day by 6pm unless it was heavy laundry. This is unlike hotels in Malaysia or Singapore where they would only return the laundry the following day and this is the efficiency of the Japanese people. The laundry would be wrapped nicely in a plastic bag individually and you can have the option to starch your laundry as well. If the shirt has a collar, they would put a cardboard bowtie to keep the collar "standing and crisp".OTHERSThe hotel is walking distance to Shinjuku Train station and also Keio Department Store (huge department store with 5 floors that links to the tran station). Walking to the train station took only 10 minutes from the rear entry. The Tourist Information Centre to activate our JapanRail Pass was opposite the train station, also walking distance from the hotel. Convenience is definitely a plus point for choosing this property for your stay in Tokyo, Shinjuku. As I was travelling to Osaka on check-out, there was a luggage transfer service at the hotel lobby, at the concierge area. We dropped off our luggage before 5pm and it was delivered to Osaka the following day and when we arrived at our Hotel in Osaka, it was already there waiting for us and when we checked-in, they handed our bags to us. The concierge staff can speak basic English, which makes conversing with them easy. There are many convenience stores (Lawsons) nearby and some open 24 hours as well. OVERALL & RECOMMENDATIONI enjoyed my stay in Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo and on my next trip to Japan in 2019, I'll definitely stay at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo. I would also personally recommend this hotel. Unfortunately, it's a little pricey but the stay would be an enjoyable and relaxing stay..!! Thank you Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo and I look forward to my future stay in 2019.

This is one of the busiest hotels in Tokyo and has almost 1500 rooms !! It is a Luxury hotel with 11 restaurants, near Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. It is also roughly 30 to 45 mins from Tokyo airport.At any point of time we could see at least 500 to 750 business people in the lobby either waiting to check in or check out or part of some conference at the hotel ! It is at the heart of Tokyo so provides a great opportunity to go out and observe Tokyo social life. Ideally located with lots of restaurants and shops nearby and is also close to Nishi-Shinjuku station (7 to 10 min walk)!

Sadly we only had one night here, en route to the airport and home. We were feeling sad to leave Japan after our first visit and an unforgettable three weeks, but were cheered up by a sumptuous and luxurious stay.We had pushed out the boat for a 'Premier Grand' room - which was fabulous. It was very spacious and so well appointed. We could have managed a few weeks of that! In addition, it was on the Club Floor, with a lovely lounge where we could relax and enjoy a few nibbles and drinks before dinner. We could have got used to that too!As with all the hotels we stayed at in Japan, the staff were attentive, friendly and helpful.There are numerous restaurants. We had a simple meal in the 'Jurin' and found it to be very good.

We stayed in the south tower and we could see the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building across the street. Location is great because it is near the train station and there is already tons of things to eat, see and do in the vicinity. The hotel is also one of the stops on the airport limousine bus routes so transferring to and from the hotel was a breeze. The room is clean and spacious enough. There are cable charging points right next to the bed. Toiletries provided are adequate although housekeeping standards vary from day to day but nothing that is enough to bother us too much.The hotel provides a phone for each room which you can use for free to make calls and surf the web when you go out. There is actually quite a fair bit of useful information that you can access on the phone including activities, places to eat, etc. Do make use of it if you don't have a firmed up itinerary.There is a convenience store which opens till late within the hotel as well as a pharmacy cum souvenir store with a pharmacist who speaks a little English. She is patient and helpful in spite of the language barrier.

The rooms are clean, well stocked, and large for Tokyo standards. The hotel is located close to Shinjuku stations, which makes it very convenient for travel. Transfer to and from both Tokyo airports is easy, with the hotel being one of the dedicated stops for the airport express buses. Staff were friendly and proficient in English. Overall a lovely hotel in Tokyo and would stay again.

Very nice hotel, service has been improved since the last time I was here. Breakfast is average. should be better for hotel at that price. cheap processed-cheese, could be better... Service is very good !Renovated rooms are very nice. This is a huge hotel, so when it is very busy, it can be really hard to get good service, fortunately, this was not the case this time. Big selection of restaurants.

We were so happy with this hotel. We booked it through our agent. The service was great. They gave us a free phone to make phone calls and take with us so we would not get lost. They were so helpful with everything. I would definitely book again.

Our stay at Keio Plaza Hotel was excellent. The service from start to finish was great. The hotel location is really good because it is walking distance to Shinjuku station and also Nishishinjuku which also features a lot of local and tourist food and shopping. We utilized the Disney Tokyo Shuttle which is complementary for hotel guest. This is also a stop for the Airport Limousine Bus Stop which makes it easy for arrival and departure. The rooms are really spacious, clean, and luxurious. They also have tour services which can be booked in the hotel lobby and the tours depart from the hotel. We would definitely stay here again.

We just checked out of Keio plaza on our way back to the sirport. We have stayed here for 3 nights and last week stayed overnight as well before we took off to Kyoto . This hotel from amenities to staff were superb. We have stayed on many of our travels with international recognized brands like four seasons , ritz Carlton, and many of L./W.hotels and this hotel is up to par if not a notch higher when it comes to details. We did stay at club level which we usually do when we travel to get the extra comfort and amenities associated with the club.The staff spoke English well and always had extra person supervision in case a staff member was noted to have some difficulties. Leave it to the Japanese when it comes to details of space dynamics and better utilization and you would realize why we were completely satisfied.Besides the usual bath robes that one traditionally sees in hotel there were his and her pijamas and his and her night robe. Of course Japanese style both. Are you kidding !!That was amazing details. The lights aC outlets were abundant and carefully separated to create different needed environment.Besides the traditional toilet area that shuts down for privacy via a sliding door, the light turns on and toilet seat opens UP. As you walk in!!!!And heated as well.Details ,details,ddetails Too many to mentionOverall we were extremely satisfied with location as well in shinjuku district in Tokyo .We give this hotel 5 + star for service5+ for amenities as wellAnd when back in Tokyo hopefully for the 2020 olympics we will reserve no where else but here

We stayed at this truly 4 star hotel as part of a tour group. The facilities were excellent and the staff went out of their way to be friendly and helpful notwithstanding that this is a very busy hotel. The rooms were spacious and very comfortable with every amenity you could wish for and of course the brilliant Japanese toilets!! Our deal was bed/breakfast and we were really impressed with the variety of food, always fresh, that was available and catered to every taste. There was a queue to get in but the efficient staff soon made sure we were seated. Thoroughly recommend this hotel!

Just a fantastic hotel.. Made us feel so welcome, no request was too much.. We speak NO Japanese, but we never felt like we were misunderstood... Thanks Team.. When we get back to Tokyo, we will stay here.. 5 stars all around!

I stayed many times at the Keio.It's really a nice hotel providing everything you might expect from such luxury venue.The bar at the top of one tower, bathed in a light blue atmosphere is a nice place to enjoy the scenery.It's located very close to Shinjuku station.

I have stayed in Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku a second time. My first stay was very memorable (in September 2016) because we - my husband and I - were surprised with an upgrade at the new wing, (as we were first given a smoking room, I think). On my second time - 3 of us women friends - were billeted in the main building. As before, the room was clean, spacious, complete with very good amenities, and comfortable bed. I like the location of this hotel as it is close to the shopping and restaurant areas; and accessible to the parks if you had time to go. The downside of the hotel (which may not be all that bothersome because it is very spacious) is the big crowds of tourists gathering to wait for their tour buses. I also noted that the staff seemed rather formal and unsmiling as they seemed to be quite very busy handling many check-ins. But otherwise, they assist you as needed.

there was a beautiful view from our room. comfortable accommodations. very good service. breakfast at jurin is delicious. always happy to stay here. one comment. it is hard to connect to wifi, and you need to reconnect every day

Great location across from the government building and close to many things. Easy to walk to the Shinjuku station - maybe a half mile - and lots to do. We found our room quiet and the line for the buffet breakfasts moves very fast. There is food there for everyone!

Stayed here as part of Titan Travel - Essence of Japan Tour. Had to request a room change on our first night as one of our twin beds squeaked and creaked at every turn which would have made sleeping difficult. Were eventually found an alternative room after a chap came and tested the mattress. Next room looked identical and we overlooked the "Twin Towers" council building opposite. If it hadn't been for the paper thin walls (we could hear couple next door chatting away and also their TV) we would have given the hotel a higher rating than 3. Also, although there are a few restaurants, we didn't feel that queuing for breakfast was very good. On second morning we were in a queue with 45 people ahead of us! Not good when you have a coach to get on at a set time.

My boyfriend and I booked two nights at the Keio Plaza Hotel as we wanted a hotel that was close to Shinjuku station and had a direct stop off the airport limousine bus from Narita Airport. Upon our arrival we were struck by how HUGE this hotel is, two giant towers with many different room types. It was hard to tell the difference from one room type to another but we were given a large, spacious room in the new tower with large windows. The bed was giant and while a bit firm, was comfortable. We appreciated all the items provided free of charge (toothbrush, hairbrush, hair ties, etc) in the bathroom which were restocked daily. I used the gym twice which was not tucked away in the basement of a hotel which is usually the case, but had giant windows overlooking the street which was cool. Machines were precor: nice, new and never too crowded. We didn’t opt for breakfast but there are several nearby coffee shops and places to grab a bite. We also appreciated the two water bottles refilled in the room daily. Check in and check out was easy, the location was great (8 min walk directly intoShinjuku) but far enough from the chaos of the busy station. Overall a nice, central experience.

We stayed at the hotel twice in 2011 and just paid a return visit for two nights.This really is a huge hotel and while service has been consistently very efficient it is far from personal. I chose Keio Plaza again primarily because of its location. I prefer Shinjuku to the other big Tokyo hubs and Keio Plaza is really well located close to Shinjuku station. It takes about 8 to 10 minutes to walk. You can walk through the streets between the hotel and station or use a well lit covered walkway between the two, which avoids the need to negotiate traffic and is a boon in bad weather. The walkway has a moving belt 'travelator' for most of the way although it only operates one way (ie you can use it when travelling from the station to the hotel but not in reverse). It is well worth checking the location of the walkway with staff.This time I booked a renovated Queen bed room in the South Tower and had a complimentary upgrade to a King Bed room. The room was spacious and well equipped. There is a fair sized room safe. There is also free WiFi which works well but is complicated to access initially. On arrival the porter who sees you to your room will probably offer to set up WiFi for you and I suggest you accept.There are a range of restaurants in the hotel and if you include breakfast in your booking you will be given vouchers which you can use in one of four different restaurants. My recommendation is to use 'The Glass Court' buffet restaurant which caters for a good range of both western and Japanese food styles.One other consideration. If you take a room in the south tower you have a reasonable chance of getting a view of Mount Fuji between the towers of the municipal offices across from the hotel (see picture attached).

I stayed here for 6 nights with a friend and we thoroughly enjoyed our stay here. The staff were very hospitable and helpful whenever we asked for any requests. The hotel is huge. We stayed in a deluxe renovated twin which had a great view of the city. The room itself was spacious unlike many in Tokyo, and very clean.Buffet breakfast had a combination of Western and Japanese options and there was plenty to choose from. We also had a drink at the hotels skybar which I would thoroughly recommend!All in all a great stay in a good location!

Everything is perfect except the WiFi - old fashionned passwords changing every day - you need their help!!Note that the swimming pool is only a summer outdoor.The shops are numerous as the restaurants in the low level. The area is next to a restaurant walking large old area, and you can walk to the hot Tokyo by night ( kabukicho ).The views from the room are great and the rooms are large, for a Tokyo hotel

The location, room and amenities in this hotel are fine. Rooms are clean and well appointed (even in the old tower where I stayed). Sushi at Kyubei (restaurant on the 7th floor) is a must-try. However, the hotel was bursting at the seams, and staff and facilities seemed stretched. My colleague and my experiences with the front desk were mixed, there were long queues for breakfast, and wifi refused to work most of the time. It may be a different experience when it's less full.

I have stayed here for a few times previously. The hotel is giantic with two separate towers, Main and South towers. The top few floors at the South Tower, called Plaza Luxe rooms are nicely done with desent room size and comes with special access to the Luxe Lounge with free tea time with snack during the day, and beer and wine at night. The night view from the lounge is great. I will suggest you to become EIC member with free membership. You will receive a deeply discounted rate if you book the room online directly. One thing, the hotel is huge with more than 1,400 rooms. The communication between staff is not so good. I was given a room. When I went to the room, the door to the room was open and a staff was changing a light bulb in the bathroom. Called the front desk but it took 15 minutes to make the issue streight. A free newspaper delivered to the room was not my favorite one so I asked the staff to change after the day 1. The day 2, no change, and so on. A little mishap. I say it is still nice enough hotel with great location, if you do not mind walking through 200 plus of the group tour guests jamming the main lobby.

The rooms are spacious, clean and comfortable. Excellent breakfast with a very wide range of foods available. The location is good, many places are within easy walking distance. Also well placed to use public transport.

My wife and I stayed three nights at the Keio Plaza, and enjoyed the experience. It's a very large hotel (1,450 rooms), and spent a few years as Tokyo's tallest building in the early 1970s. Despite its size, we didn't experience long waits for elevators, check-in or check-out, as the hotel seems well-organised. There are 18 food and/or drink venues in the hotel, each offering different styles of cuisine, although we didn't actually try any of them as we spent our time exploring other culinary options in Tokyo.Our room on one of the higher floors had a nice view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Tower. I had specifically requested a non-smoking room, because the hotel offers some smoking rooms, so keep this in mind when making a reservation. The room was clean and reasonably sized (not huge, but I think it was only a standard room and the hotel has many other options). The bed was comfortable and the WiFi worked efficiently (they give you a specific login code that you have to re-enter every 24h). Good shower pressure. One particularly nice feature: the rooms come with a complimentary smartphone that you can take out + about in Tokyo for internet access on the move (it asks you to acknowledge T+C if you lose/damage it), and you can use the phone for domestic and some international calls.The hotel is located a few minutes' walk from the central west exit of Shinjuku station. When coming straight from the station there's an underground passage that drops you out right by the hotel, and when coming from other main Shinjuku areas (e.g. Kabukicho / Golden Gai) it's relatively easy to navigate above ground past the station and walk over to the hotel, so there's no real need for taxis/subway in that area.Overall I would recommend the Keio Plaza, particularly if you can search around and find a good deal.

This is a nice but very busy hotel. Its location is really good, close to many restaurants, shops and shopping centres. We were not able to check in when we arrived at 5 pm due to the room was not ready. However, we were invited to have a free drink at the 36 floor lounge with a wonderful view! It is good that we were able to select breakfast among three restaurants but had to lineup for each one we tried to get in.

This hotel is in the Shinjuki area (about 10 minute walk from the station). Lovely hotel and we had a large well appointed room and bathroom. Breakfast was included and although there was a queue most mornings it moved very quickly. The choice of food was fantastic - something for everyone. The staff were extremely helpful especially the concierge. If you go out the back entrance to the hotel there are lots of authentic restaurants at reasonable prices.

We stayed here for 4 days. This hotel is in the center of Shinjuku, capital of Tokyo. It isnear the shijuku station, and lots of shopping area. Room is big for Japanese standard, bed is comfortable and breakfast here is good.it has a lot of restaurant. This is also meeting place of many of tokyo tour group due to its location. This hotel is highly recommended.

An old school hotel with everything that one would want. Pleasant staff and good service. Would stay again if in Tokyo. The metro is very close and there is a super little park nearby. As it is next to the government building, the free viewing floor is just a few steps away. Shinjuko station is also within easy walking distance.

We arrived at the Keio Plaza Hotel after traveling for over 24 hours, so needless to say we were exhausted The room was nicely decorated, the views were amazing and we enjoyed our stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel. The staff were very helpful and helped us with a couple of different things we had questions about, really going out of their way to assist us. Our bed was extremely comfortable and we slept very well!

We stayed here for four nights during our holiday to Japan. We were in the main tower and our room was pleasant with views of the Metropolitan Government building. The bed and pillows were comfortable, slippers as robes provided. Shower was adequate and as a first time visitor to Tokyo the heated toilet seat was a wee treat. Lots of towels and toiletries. Tea and coffee making facilities in room. It is a huge hotel and with that come a bit of the impersonal but the staff were welcoming and helpful. Whilst we did go to the Sky lounge for a nightcap, which was lovely, we didn’t explore the hotel properly until our last day. Discovered lots of nice looking restaurants in the basement. The location is great. It is a minute walk to the neon of Shinjuku and 5 mins to the station. We had a very comfortable and enjoyable stay here and would recommend.

Location is good,if you include breakfast with your stay at the hotel,3 choices of Restaurants for breakfast but you need to come early because there is usually a queue. If you stay at the main building and you booked for a standard room,the room is clean and the toilet as well but it’s needs to be refurbished ,obvious stained on the carpet it needs shampooing and the walls shows peeling off of paint,it’s an old hotel,they don’t include robes if you booked a standard room,but I requested because for the amount of money you pay it’s not cheap even for a standard room,good thing they provided me with robes. The thing that compensate of our stay is the staff of the hotel,very accommodating,helpful and make their way to help you out and very warmth,will I come and stay again in Keio? Yes I will

We enjoyed our stay in Keio. Our room is very spacious, larger than other hotels we stayed in Tokyo. The location is about 8 minutes walk to Shinjuku station. The hotel staff is friendly. We also tried two dining places in the hotel which both are decent. I would recommend this hotel for its location and room size.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza with a 10 month old baby arriving after a 11.5 hour flight from London at 7:30 am. We were worried our room might not be ready until normal check-in time in the afternoon, but they had it ready for us! We highly recommend staying in one of their Club Rooms which gave us access to its Club Lounge and their private concierge service. It was amazing being able to check-in at their Club Lounge on the top of the hotel's tower whilst having some breakfast from their buffet. The food options at the Lounge were also perfect for our baby and they were able to provide baby friendly alternatives when we asked.There were so many on site restaurant options which were great when we were dealing with a hungry baby. I loved using their new baby room which had private cubicles and sofas. This made changing my baby and feeding her very easy and comfortable.  The convenience store at the hotel's basement floor was also a life saviour when we had to find some emergency diapers and wipes!

Strategic position near Shinjuku station. It is a very big hotel, for sure not a family one.Check in and check out very fast. Info point professional.Our room was very comfortable with an appropriate size, on the 32nd floor with a nice view.It could be taken into account for a stay in Tokyo.

Keio Plaza was a very accommodating hotel that was perfect for our family. There were a multitude of dining options — varying levels of formality, varying wait times for breakfast, different cuisines and different price points. Breakfast opened early in the morning, helping those of us with jet lag and Disneyland buses to catch. Jurin, Glass Court, Tempura and the convenience store all had their merits. I was really impressed when one morning the staff set up an alternative breakfast room in the Sky Lounge when the line for Jurin was around 20 min. A woman informed us while we were in line and helped us to get there. By doing so, our family was able to eat a good, thorough breakfast before our tour began. The South Tower renovated rooms were significantly nicer than the Main Tower rooms. We stayed in both. The staff also speaks very good English and many westerners seem to choose this very hotel. While not in the heart of Tokyo, it was a great place for our family to stay and I would recommend it.

We stayed twice at the Keio Plaza Hotel with a trip to Hakone in between the stays. We were given room upgrades both times with the “newly renovated” class room on the second stay wow-ing us.Check-in was very smooth.Getting here and back to Narita is super convenient (and inexpensive) with Friendly Airport Limousine (the bus actually stops at this hotel).Getting to Shinjuku Station is super easy either walking on street level or using underground walkways.Close to Nishishinjuku restaurants. Easy walk to Kabukicho. Short distance from Takashimaya and Lumine Est (where we like to shop). We even walked to Yoyogi for taiyaki.Right next to Metropolitan Government Building for excellent Tokyo views.Bell Captain friendly and efficient - we left our luggage at hotel during trip to Hakone.We can’t think of a better place to base a visit to Tokyo.

The location of the hotel was ideal for getting around Tokyo, and especially so with a direct bus link to the hotel's front door with the limousine bus service from both Narita and Haneda airports.My room on the twentieth floor had a spectacular view of the Government Offices, the highest buildings in Tokyo at 45 floors.The room was extremely quiet, spotless and compact, with a small bathroom and plenty of hanging  space in the wardrobe. While the water pressure in the shower (over the bath) was excellent, as were the towels, the lack of space to store one's cosmetic/bathroom accessories was not ideal.The bed was not particularly comfortable. As I was staying for five nights, I asked to pay for an upgraded room with a better mattress, but was informed that all rooms had the same mattress.Room lighting was excellent, and there were numerous power points.Hotel staff were uniformly pleasant and helpful.Breakfast in Jurin, the western buffet restaurant, was disappointing. There was plenty of choice, but the hot food was always lukewarm, and the choices for fruit (unpeeled) and bread were unpalatable. At least, there was an omelette station, but the only choices for additives were ham and cheese. The coffee was undrinkable.

Check in service staff were so rude , we paid high premium for 2 x 3 night stays and seriously got nothing but rude , beligerent attitudes from the check in staff on both occasions. We did not get the room we paid for on either visit but as we paid in advance we had no choice but to accept. Staff would not look at our documentation or even offer an apology or explanation on why we didn’t get the requested room. As we paid approx $500 a night we were very disappointed to be treated like 2nd class citizens. The restaurant staff were no better. Having said that the rooms were spacious and clean and the cleaning staff were professional and friendly . Would I stay again ...absolutely not, we have TRAVELLLED the world and this was the worst customer service we have ever encountered. Worst hotel experience ever.

My wife and I spent 2 nights at the Keio Plaza hotel in early November. Both times we stayed overnight in premium level rooms which had a separate place to check in (on 45) as well as a separate area for the included breakfast. The premium rooms I believe are floors 37-42. The room itself was large and comfortable with a incredible view of the city. The tub and shower area were great and we drew multiple baths while we were there. There is a social time from 5-7 PM each evening on the 45th floor which had a nice selection of food, wine and beer. Be sure to go to the more comfortable (left) side opposite where the food spread is laid out as there are comfortable couches, sake and draft beer available vs just the tables where they serve the breakfast. The breakfast is good and I suggest trying the eggs Benedict if you like that. One thing we really liked about the hotel was the surprisingly inexpensive in room massage option for ~50 minutes. The hotel will do it for 2 people at once if you call far enough ahead of time. We found one night we could get 2 people massaged at once with 90 minutes lead time and the other we could only get 1 masseuse with 3 hours lead time. All a question of availability I guess. It cost something like ¥5000 per person for 1 hour which is a great deal! It is a bit of a PITA to book as you need to call the front desk and get transferred around a few times until you get the “massage desk” and their English is subpar but, take my word for it, it is well worth it. The staff on the 45 floor is pretty good about making dinner reservations if you tell them where but IMHO not very good at making recommendations. Use TA to find where you want to go and then show the front desk your first and second ranked suggestions on your phone and have them call on your behalf. The two nights we were guests of the hotel we had them get us reservations at the fancy sushi restaurant in the hotel (which was delicious but very expensive) and the second night we asked them make reservations for us at a highly rated but far less expensive sushi restaurant 3 blocks from the hotel. I think I might be hesitant to stay at the non premium portion of the hotel as it seemed like every time we ended up in the first floor lobby or in the shopping sections on the first few floors it felt very crowded and unpleasant. The premium experience was great and not terribly expensive and the views are killer. If this helped you to make a choice, please don’t forget to click on the helpful button below the review.

We stayed here for a holiday in Oct 2018. Was a great little hotel, got a lovely view from our window and the staff were friendly. We ordered room service though for dinner and we came back from our day out and no one had come to collect the bowls and plates. Eventually when they did collect the plates the following day, they left a hot chocolate there that I didn’t drink, and took the rest. So by the next day our room smelt like off milk. Regardless of that, it was a nice stay. Room was small, but that’s to be expected. Nice and close to the train station.

This hotel was in a great location near to the station in Shinjuku. Our room had a fabulous view out over the city and was very comfortable. We had breakfast each day which was more than adequate and set us up for the day. The Sky Lounge was great and also had fabulous views over the city from it’s 45 th floor position. Every bit as good as the Observatories across the road!!

Airport express bus dropped us right at the Hotel which was definitely convenient and a time saver! The room was good, though not great! They have two restaurants for breakfast and both had a wide array of dishes to choose from. It’s conveniently located in the heart of Shinjuku area though I thought it was priced a tad bit high!

We thought this hotel was ok, but it is like being at a bus station.It is always busy in the lobby reception area. You do not feel comfortable walking through crowds of people.The staff are busy and have no time to even greet you each day. If you want to request something in your room you line up with the new guest which takes too much time.The lifts are often crowded with guests and cases.The rooms are ok, but the bathrooms are very small, with the ususl shower in the bath.Not a great hotel.

Just in front of Tokyo Government building in a quite neighborhood of busineess companies and good hotels Keio Plaza has two towers with a modern architecture.The lounge in ground floor it is very pleasant and big.The reception is very kind and good but something bureaucratic with a lot of explanations that are written .gThe rooms are big and have all we need.In south tower we have a good vision of Tokyo Government building.Breakfast in restaurants is quite good and room service has a lot of choices and is very fast.The negative point of the hotel is that is situated in a area without mouvement at evening, but it is not far to go to Shinshuku Station ( a 15-20 minutes walking) or a cheap taxi course.In short: a good option.

Would have given 5 stars if they would have indoor pool. Fitness center is basic. Breakfast buffet is good. With 3 resto to choose from. The rooms are large enough so if you shop a lot, room for 4 large suitcase to spread across the floor. As is standard for Japanese Hotel, clean. A short walk to shopping areas is nice to have. Nice views too!

We stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel for two days prior to cruising around Japan. The hotel is comfortable (except for the pillows). I nicknamed them Rocky and Rocky II. Great location, really nice staff. Onsite restaurants are expensive, that said it is a short walk to the nightlife and restaurants in Shinjuku.Overall a very pleasant experience.

We opted to stay at Keio Plaza Hotel for our four night stay in Japan largely for its fantastic location. Much of what we wanted to do was between the Shinjuku and Shibuya areas so this location was perfect for us to fit in all the sights in a short amount of time. The hotel is huge and has so much to offer in itself I wish we had an extra day or two just to experience it all. The property is split into two towers. We stayed in the South Tower which is the older of the two and found the rooms to be clean, spacious and suitably appointed. We were in a corner room on a higher floor and had wonderful views over Tokyo. The beds were really comfortable and the amenities provided were the most generous I’ve come across, which included the standard items plus different kinds of face cleansers and moisturizer, toothpaste, razor, a hair brush and so much more. Each tower has a lounge on the top floor offering guests complimentary beverages and snacks. There are several newspapers available in various languages. Their flat white coffee from the machine in the lounge was one of the best I’ve had; I think the milk was a sweet cream…so good. Staff were polite, helpful and communication was not an issue. The property offers many different dining options right on site. We ate at the Kagari Restaurant which was a wonderful experience, I’ll review that separately. There is a convenience store on site as well which was handy. This property has a few speciality Hello Kitty decorated rooms which my husband was not keen to stay in but they were kind enough to show to me since one was available. The attention to Hello Kitty detail was impressive so if you’re a fan you might want to consider this option. In addition to all the restaurants and bars the property can organise a selection of experiences right on site including a tea ceremony, flower arranging, origami and the opportunity to experience wearing a full wedding kimono. Unfortunately, we didn’t have enough time to book an experience but would definitely consider it on our next trip. We did take the shuttle organised by the hotel back to the airport which was hassle free and not too expensive. Aside from the great location, this hotel had a nice balance of making overseas visitors feel comfortable without compromising the authentic Japanese experience. We would definitely consider staying here again.

I've stayed here on several occasions. It is a top notch hotel, classy, very professional and courteous staff, in a Great location! A bit expensive. Great amenities! I highly recommend this outstanding hotel! I stayed there between 2003-2012. I only clicked on November 2017 because I couldn't go back any farther. I'd stay there again if they could lower prices or offer a great package deal! Beautiful hotel with shopping and restaurants!

We had a 4 day trip to Tokyo and stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel in Shinjuku, near the largest railway station on the planet. Lovely hotel, vast but great facilities. Staff were extremely helpful and polite, the location is great for exploring Tokyo and beyond. One tip for transfers from Narita to the hotel is if you booked via Expedia bring a hard copy of the voucher for Narita or you end up paying 3,100 yen per person one way, although the wonderful girl based at the hotel working for Airport Limousine Coaches used the image on my smart phone, contacted the office and in less than two minutes cleared my return journey. Another tip is take the Keio Plaza South Tower option of a pass for the luxury lounge, great view nice nibbles and drinks all included. Don't miss the Samurai Museum or a walk round the area north of the station.

This is a really nice hotel and is situated in a great area. The staff are friendly and the beds are comfortable. However, the bathrooms are made of a cheap plastic which feels like it will break if you lean on it. The hotel offers free transportation to/from Disney which is a major plus.

This is a 4 star hotel with 5 star service. Lodging is nice and comfortable, location is wonderful, it is situated in an office area so it is quiet but only 1 short block away is the restaurant district with lots of wonderful local food. Book the club floor or luxe room (the top 2 floors in the South Tower), you get separate check in and out area. This is a huge hotel so that is a big plus during rush hour. Hint, sign up for the loyalty program.

Put up here for the night when our cruise was delayed by a typhoon. Luxury hotel, must be good it was being used by the tennis stars at the Japan Open. Enjoyed having breakfast with Marin Cilic (well near him). Basement full of restaurants catering for all tastes. Close to the lively entertainment areas in Shinjuku. Wouldn’t have minded if our cruise had been delayed a few more days!If we ever came to Tokyo again would try to stay here.

All in all, it's a good hotel. Good location near Shinjuku train station. Very big but well maintained. Our rooms were comfortable. Breakfast was good. Staff is trying to help when needed.The only reason that I'm ranking the hotel just 4 and not the maximal 5 rank, is because it seems that when the hotel is fully booked then service becomes slow. There are no ice machines in the floors, you have to call room service. I had to call twice and wait for 20 minutes till they brought us ice. In the mornings we had to stand in line for 10-15 minutes till we got a table for breakfast in one of the hotel's restaurants.

The Keio Plaza is conveniently located near the Shinjuku Station. It is especially great on rainy days with an underground passage to get to the station.We took the airport limousine bus from Narita Airport and it conveniently brought us to the front door of the hotel. Check-in took awhile since it was so busy, but the staff was very well organized. Our room was on a higher floor which gave us a great view. The room was average in size, large enough for a king sized bed, desk and sitting area. The bathroom had all the amenities you could ever need, but overcrowded the vanity. Plenty of closet space with enough hangers for a couple days stay.The hotel is very large, could be confusing if you're not paying attention. There are several restaurants (very pricey) and convenience stores.The staff at the customer service desk were very friendly and helpful. They all spoke English which made it very easy on us. The people at the bell desk were very nice, but not well as good in speaking English. The night we checked in a bell boy stopped us just to be friendly, asking us what we ere planning to do in Tokyo. I thought it was so cute, and happy to have the conversation with him. He seemed so eager to practice his English and also learn about the world outside of Japan.The hotel was located across the street of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Buildings. We took the short walk to take in the view of the city from the observation deck. Great "free" view of the city, one that would cost a lot more at the Skytree. At the end of our stay, we decided to take the limousine bus service back to Narita, Again, so convenient, you can purchase your tickets from the bus desk (located near the bell desk), and he bus stops outside the front door. Overall, the hotel was very good, but very pricey.

Normally I don't usually stay at such pricey hotels, but I decided to stay at Keio Plaza Hotel for a few nights in Tokyo for my first solo trip, and to Japan. Keio was in fact a practical choice because after a 24 hour flight I knew I would be exhausted and I wanted the most direct way to my hotel - Keio fit the bill.Check-in was great. The front desk up graded my room to a superior room to accommodate my request for a higher floor. I even had an extra bed in my room. It was so spacious and I felt good in the room. The bed was extremely comfortable.On the basement level were all the numerous restaurants offered by the hotel and a fantastic convenience store that was even better than 7-11! I made sure to make a stop at this store every day during my stay at the hotel. The store also sold nice quality souvenirs.I didn't partake in the breakfast offered by the hotel (glad I skipped this cus the line ups every morning for breakfast were insane), but visited a couple of places across the road. The Tokyo Metropolitan Building with the observation deck was right beside the hotel, and two subway lines were close by. Tons of restos were literally across the street.Definitely a great stay at Keio Plaza Hotel.

We stayed for 3 nights and were very pleased we had booked this hotel which is within walking distance of the Shinjuku Ststion. The front counter staff were all very polite, helpful and respectful. Our room was quite large and the Hotel provides a 'Handy' phone which allows free international calls to limited countries and the phone is for guests to take with you when you explore the city - what a bonus!Make sure you explore all the floors including the lower level and find the delicious icecreams in the Gift shop!!

This is a high quality hotel with prices to match. The rooms are large and modern and the service is impeccable. All desk staff speak exceptional English and nothing was too much hassle. Located close to two stations and taxis are readily available

We stayed here as part of a tour with Unique Japan Tours and were quite happy with the choice. There are 3 restaurants to choose from for the included breakfast. Glass Court which is a mix of Western and Japanese which was really good. The next day the line-up for Glass Court was quite long so we ate at the Western restaurant - Jurin. The fruit selection was poor and the omelettes weren't particularly good. The next day we tried the Japanese set menu restaurant - Kagari. The food presentation was amazing. it was all very tasty. Now this is the way to eat! The rooms are comfortable and clean. The only other negative is the bar downstairs - Brilliant Bar sells cigars, so the room smells of smoke.

The hotel is large and busy - popular with tourists including tour buses. Large lobby area seems to be always crowded. Location of the hotel is good, about 10 minutes walk from the Shinjuku station. Check in was efficient and staff was friendly. Breakfast food was very good except it had long lines most of the time. It has a number of good restaurant including a very good Chinese and an excellent Japanese restaurant. Bar lunge on the 45th floor has an very nice view. Plenty of shopping near the station,Rooms are very clean and comfortable. Bathroom is small.and due to lack of any exhaust, fogging of the mirrors is a problem.

My family (5 adults, 1 child & 1 infant) stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel for 7 nights in 2 rooms.We arrived early and the idea of an early check in was not entertained for any guest arriving early.Upon arrival to our room, the booking had requested a cot for our infant but there was only a rail on a bed. Not really appropriate for an infant. There was also not an allowance of a bath towel for the infant. In saying that the room and bathroom were both a good size for a family and also had usb charging points.We did love the smart phone to get around with WiFi and the shuttle bus to Disney.The staff were super friendly and very helpful. The bell captain was also helpful with the bags and providing umbrellas.Whilst the hotel was not in the heart of Tokyo, is was close to stations and there were lots of eating options around.

I have stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel at Shunjuku in three different ocassions. The first time with my daughter, the second time with a friend and the third time with my son. And Keio Plaza has ruined other possible hottels for me. Why would I stay elsewhere when Keio Plaza Hitels puts you smack in close proximity with Shunjuku Train Station, Bus Station, small, traditional Japanese Udon, Sushi, Curry restaurants, a coffee shop, a department store a discount gadget store and a government building which you can gk to and climb up to their observation deck and see a 360 degree view of Tokyo. There are three breakfast places in the hotel plus a French Restaurant and fine dining Teppanyaki Restaurant and a Tempura restaurant. There is a tea place, and a lounge bar in the ground floor. There is a convenience store on tge lower ground floor where you can but myriad assortments of Japanese food which they can heat up and you can bring to your room. There is the pool and the gym. It is walking distance to Takashimata Department Store and Tokyu Hands.I cannot say enough about Keio Plaza Hotel except to ask you to try it. You will be too spoiled to try other places. I know I am.

Hotel was awesome and staff was really helpful.Only small detail was service in Sky bar wich was not on the level with rest off the hotel. Get that fixed and it will be full 5 review next time.. Other than that: Location, rooms, services, food, connections, view, atm downstairs, airport shuttles.. All great!!

.Hotels in Japan can either be incredibly modern with amazing service, or they can be like something leftover from the 70's in need of an update. The Keio Plaza Hotel is such a place. It has no heart and feels terribly old-fashioned. It's somewhere to sleep and little else. There's no desire to linger in the lobby, which I believe is the heart of any hotel.I had a Club Level room. The room was smart and more modernised than the rest of the hotel, and it had great views towards Shinjuku. The bed was good as was the shower /bathroom. But the wardrobe space was ridiculously small, and there was nowhere adequate for empty suitcases despite the room being a reasonable size by Tokyo standards.What was kind of sad is that the Club Level has a very large inviting lounge with fabulous panoramic views - one of the biggest I've encountered on my travels. But despite the hotel being full I only ever saw 3 or 4 people in it. So it's rather soulless, which is sad. The food offerings and drinks were sufficient.If you need to be near Shinjuku then the location is excellent. It's walking distance to Isetan, Takashimaya, etc. I sadly had no option but to check-out early as the hotel lost its WIFI for over 12 hours during the daytime, so I was rather at a loss to communicate with my Japanese clients via computer who use software to communicate with me in English. The loss of WIFI for a period of time is unacceptable in a large Japanese hotel in the heart of Tokyo. So I moved on to another hotel, which fortunately for me was much better on many levels.There's absolutely no reason for me to ever return to the Keio Plaza. There are far superior Tokyo hotels to be found. But it was a perfectly acceptable hotel dependant on your needs. There was nothing wrong with it, it just felt rather dated, and not able to deliver the Tokyo experience I enjoy. I would rather pay more and leave a hotel with a memorable experience, than pay less and have something mediocre..

Granted you’re going to be outside of the hotel exploring Tokyo way more than you’ll be inside, but when you’re inside it’s great.I came to Tokyo with two friends but I ended up splurging a little bit for myself and found myself checking into this hotel by myself. Granted the check in is a little later than most flights come in but there’s enough to do around the immediate area that it wasn’t an real issue. You can leave your bags with them so that definitely helps.I was there for 6 nights and every time I came back from our adventures the room was tidied up with my stuff basically untouched. I booked the renovated double standard with a breakfast package which was great, with such a huge selection of breakfast I left the hotel every morning stuffed. Fair warning, the breakfast is early so with Kabukicho a 10min walk away don’t be fooled into having a late night because you’ll find yourself rushing to not miss breakfast. However I’ll admit the late nights were an absolute treat with the great view that I had from my room.The staff was very warm and helpful with any questions I had about Japan and locations.

The hotel is situated in a small area of greenery close to public transport and eating and entertainment precincts. A relaxing hotel with many amenities, good breakfast buffets and a wonderful top floor bar with great city views. The service was always provide with a smile and a bow.

The room was clean and had a luxurious feel to it. The room did not feel small even though it had 3 beds; one of few hotels with 3 beds. Bed size good for a single person, but a squeeze for a couple.Our room includes breakfast, and we could choose to dine at three different restaurant, one serving American breakast, another a more International spread, and one serving traditional Japanese breakfast. The breakfast spread was good and of good quality. We didn't get round to try the traditional Japanese breakfast though.The room also came with a free to use phone - it had a data plan so we could use it to navigate, check train times, Google map, etc ... Shinjuku station was about 7mins walk away.There are many restaurants - about 5mins away, so getting food was easy.We enjoyed our stay very much!

My husband and I began our Japan adventure in Tokyo, choosing to stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel for four nights based on several factors: the convenience to Shinjuku station and restaurants, the size of the rooms, the provided cell phone and shuttle services. After returning home and staying in two other accommodations in Kyoto and Fujiyoshida, I can confidently say this was the crown jewel of comfort. Not only did we receive two water bottles each day (so appreciated when trekking across Tokyo) and have a great view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Building, I personally enjoyed the Shiseido and L'Occitane en Provence amenities, along with a deep tub for the provided bath bombs for the end of each day. We also used the ATM in the convenience store several times and picked up cheap snacks when we were too tired to eat a full dinner. In addition, I want to thank the individuals in housekeeping because our room was ALWAYS perfect by the time we returned back. On our next trip, we will stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel and take day trips to other locations, so we can continue to enjoy the comfortable accommodations and hospitality.

We stayed for 7 Nights and chose the Luxe Double Room with "free" access to Lounge. Room was a good size and very comfortable. The reviews of the hotel all suggested that it was a good location but we found it a little tiring to walk to all of the action. Our view was good though (West - I think) and facing the Tokyo Metropolitian Government building. To the side of this building we could just make out Mt Fuji in the distance which was a real bonus to see.We didn't get a chance to dine at the hotel as there were too many other dining options to try but the hotels offering did look good.We utilised the Lounge a couple of times but found it restrictive with alcoholic drinks only provided from 5-7PM. Also, the food offering was restricted to nuts and a few little snacks.There was no hot food provided on the days we were there which was disappointing.On our last day our check out was 11:00am while our flight home from Haneda was for 10:00 PM. The hotel provided a baggage minding service (free) as well as a shuttle bus service to the airport (NOT free but worth it). We wanted to be able to shower after our day out but before our flight but the hotel would not accomodate us on this which was also disappointing.Overall though it was still a good hotel and we would stay here again if they provided a shower facility after checkout.

A short walk to Shinjuku Station and across from the Government Building where you can ride the elevator to either the north or south observation floors. Exceptional service from the staff. Take local subways or trains to see Tokyo and surrounding areas. There are many local sights to see within walking distance of the hotel.

Love the Disney shuttle bus directly from hotel especially the trains map in Tokyo are rather complex. Conveniently located near the train station. Airport Limousine stops here too! Room service breakfast was so good that we had it for 2 mornings. Price on the higher side but definitely worth the price.

We have visited Tokyo four times in the past year with each stay lasting 10 days to 2 weeks. On all four visits, we stayed at Keio Plaza Shinjuku mostly because of its location with direct access by limousine bus, proximity to our favourite restaurants, shops and public transport. Breakfasts at the Glass Court included good choices of Japanese and western food and service from the reception, guest relations, concierge, and housekeeping have been satisfactory. On our most recent visit, a couple of issues came up. We experienced neglect from front line staff and had noise and water leakage problems in our room. Sudoh-san, the Director of Guest Relations, took care to resolve all those issues smoothly and graciously. Although guests have good reasons to expect decent service, Sudoh-san’s response surpassed our expectations. We are thankful for his making our stay at Keio so pleasant despite omissions from a few staff. Keio remains our choice of accommodation in Tokyo.

Stayed in the Kitty Town Hello Kitty room for one night! Very fun experience with a nice breakfast, however it is VERY expensive for what you get. The bathroom we felt was very old and outdated and the beds very hard.

My Husband and I would like to extend our heartfelt thanks to Keio Plaza Hotel for the pleasant stay in Tokyo. We were truly amazed with the excellent service provided by Mr Kaneko , Mr Sugimoto and the Driver of Airport Limousine bus 351 on 8 Sep 1:15pm (sorry we didn’t get to know your name) who helped us to recover our smart phone left behind in the bus, on our way to Haneda airport.We made a call to Keio plaza hotel when we discovered the phone was misplaced and within the next hour, the phone was delivered by the driver in his next trip to the Airport. We were simply amazed with the efficiency and service quality.Travelling with our 2 young children, we booked a triple room and stayed 3 nights at South tower. Rooms were newly renovated, clean, spacious and comfortable. Free shuttle bus service to and from Tokyo Disneyland. 5mins walk to Shinjuku station. Checking in & out was a Breeze. Highly recommended hotel for your stay in Tokyo.

If you want a hotel with everything, more restaurants than you can visit in 3 days, workout facilities, pool, and activities - this hotel has those things. The food is good, but quite frankly very expensive. A walk toward the Shinjuku station will find you cheaper versions of all foods sold in the hotel, sushi, shabu shabu, teppanyaki, tempura, etc.The air conditioner in the room worked well, but the bathroom is a little cramped, with most of the counterspace taken up with amenities. Toto washlet toilet seat if you are into that experience.

We stayed 4 nights in September. Front Desk workers could have been a little more accommodating. Choice of breakfast options is great. Very pleasant room with a wonderful toilet. We feel like we have the cleanest rears in Japan. Many of the hotel workers should be reeducated in the quality programs Japan is famous for.

I attended a conference at this hotel and the service was genuinely shocking. Especially for Tokyo where service at top end hotels is usually superb. Dismissive and unhelpful during the event almost aggressive at the drinks reception - constantly pushing and ordering guests around. Completely unacceptable. To be avoided - there are so many better venues in Tokyo.

I’m in and out of Japan for over 13 years . And many time visited Kiel plaza This time it was a real disappointment. Room did not smell good . Extra 1 your in check out they asked 4300 Yen , are you crazy ? Why ? Flexibility is not as it was. I was in this hotel so many times in the past. This time it was a real disappointment. I had an hour or 2 and wanted to go to the pool , not flexible charging about 2000 yen minimum and for what ? The service is NOT as it was Sorry to say cannot recommend any longer on Keio

We had a wonderful 5 night stay here. Everything about our stay was perfect. We booked a premier grand room which was on the 39th floor. We had a fantastic view of the city from our room. The room was very comfortable and spacious. The attention to detail was great, everything little comfort had been thought of to make our stay perfect. There was a great selection of amenities in the bathroom. We had breakfast on the club level lounge and the breakfast was very good, plenty of options. All the staff were very helpful, friendly and extremely polite. The hotel was an easy walk to the Shinjuku station,shops and restaurants. We would not hesitate to stay here again.
user_name:
Bev C
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: Its a large busy hotel with a good selection of restaurants. The rooms are adequate and comfortable. Its a short walk to a station and there are several streets nearby with bars, shops and restaurants. We would stay again if in Tokyo.

This hotel is ideally located to the train station and a reasonable amount of shopping.The hotel is clean, the staff have limited English but are helpful.The BIG BUT..we found the beds and pillows extremely hard (like concrete) and the made it difficult to get a good nights sleep.Room service is very expensive for very ordinary quality of food.The hotel can be very busy with group bookings and requires patience when wanting to use the lifts.If returning I would try another hotel.

Stayed here at Keio Plaza based on recommendations on Trio Advisor with my wife whilst on holiday trip to Japan. Large hotel near Shinjuku station so location very good for access to train /subway and bus transport for the whole Tokyo city. Also the area around is lively with lots of shops and restaurants In terms of hotel itself it’s a large and largely anonymous tower block building with a good range and amenities although restaurants especially are very expensive even if you use discount vouchers that hotel gives you on arrival . So we didn’t use any of them The main bar on lower ground floor is ok but also pricey and not particularly attractive lacking any kind of window or view . The Sky Lounge on the 7th floor is an exception with a terrific view over the city and is well worth visiting notwithstanding the price of drinks . Both bars ( like many places in Japan)still allow smoking so be aware of you find this unpleasant . Other amenities such as their open air swimming pool ( a reason I booked in the first place ) are perfectly fine although I find it very difficult to understand how they justify an additional quite steep daily charge ( something like £17) fo use of the fitness / spa facilities . Also the pool doesn’t open until 9 which isn’t terribly convenient t for business or leisure travellers who like me like to get an early morning swim in to start their day . Rooms are fine , clean and reasonably sized but not in any sense new or modern and maybe considered somewhat tired in terms of decor . Staff are polite and efficient although not exceptionally helpful or particularly friendly. So would have to say overall impression was mixed . This was Hotel we liked least on our tour of Japan and I would only give it a cautious recommendation and probably would look elsewhere next time I had the pleasure of visiting Tokyo .

I attended an event over a three day period here without a hitch; both the service and food were good. Everything ran like clockwork and staff went out of their way to assist. The view from my room was lovely and I was within walking distance to shops and restaurants.One thing that stands out was that the hotel was clean; the room spotless, yet, I never saw or heard any Housekeeping staff. It was great having a "convenience store" on the lower level and shops on the main floor where you could purchase postcards and have them mailed internationally from the front desk.Would definitely stay here again.

Wow - this hotel has gone downhill. Definitely would not recommend for business. Not sure I would recommend at all. Room carpet dirty. Service average But the worst thing is fitness center. It's tiny and from dark ages. C'mon get with it people want to keep fit these days. Anyway I will not be back. Plenty of other hotels around with better cost performance.

Stayed 1 night at the hotel. Check in was very easy. Make sure you get to the right elevator bank, they have 3 different depending on the floor you are on. Staff were very friendly and helpful with questions about the area. If you want to use the pool you have to pay for it. Not the only hotel in town that charges for the pool.

We stayed in the South Superior TwinVery good location. You can shop and eat in little restaurants nearby - erspecially in an shopping arcade over the street where the locals eat. We found one little restaurant where smoking was allowedBig and nice room, bathroom a little bit smallStaff perfect.5 restaurants, bars, pool, spaPhantastic view over tokyo at night from the Sky BarTo the Ginza take a cab - 7 minutes.

I had a perfectly fine stay for 2 nights in a barrier free or universal room. I used a shower chair that was provided and put the shower chair in the bath. The room was very spacious with a great view. I was happy that the barrier free room was on a high floor.

Location is very good, the quiet side of Shinjuku and a 10 minute wander to the west side of the station. Easy check in, nice clean and decent sized room and bathroom. A selection of food and drink places within the hotel complex. Likes: The Sky Bar for the view and also the selection of Japanese whisky (if youre a fan). The Main bar is also very good.Overall service - all the staff I dealt with were great. Ability to get to/from the hotel via trains and taxis is very very good. Dislikes:A Y2000 to use the pool - I have never seen a charge like this in any full service hotel I have stayed in and to be honest that is amazing on top of the room rate.Late check out - asked for an additional 2 hours for a late check out. Only way is again to pay a hefty fee. This is the first time I have been asked to pay for 2 extra hours in any hotel in Japan. I did like the overall experience however it feels like the management have made some decisions without realising how that feels to users.

I stayed a few days in Tokyo at this nice hotel. It was in a good location, very nice staff, friendly and speaking sufficient English. However, the hotel is too large, crowded too (in july). If you come back from a tiring trip day, it is hard to enter your own hotel with even more craziness. The rooms were ok, although nothing special, considering the price.

Well located hotel for Shinjuku. Many years ago, it was a great hotel to stay in, but now showing its age. Being a huge hotel, it is still efficiently operated.Check in was fast though we arrived late in the evening so was not expecting a queue. No bell captains at this time of night.Room service was fast for some late night snacks.Rooms are looking old and tired. Stain on carpet and the toilet fittings are looking more 3 star level now. Room sizes are average for Tokyo standards for hotel of this level.Breakfast restaurants are good, though Glass Court has wider variety buffet and has longer queue. Jurin usually has no queue. There are many restaurants near the hotel that are better priced and better quality. In the hotel, avoid Kagari restaurant on level 2 at all cost. It has the worst service and least selection and below average food of any Japanese restaurant I have been to in my 40 years of travelling to Japan. Kyubey on the 7th floor however is outstanding but expensive. The reception staff are all friendly, polite with average level of English. For assistance, the duty managers or guest relations officers at the desk diagonally opposite the reception are very helpful. Overall it is an aged hotel still functioning well but needing some update. The location for JR rail and metro is good, and for Shinjuku it is a decent hotel to stay in if you get a good bargain rate somewhere online.

Last month we found ourselves at the Keio Plaza once again, having stayed there in 2014. Our stay was faultless, apart from not being able to check into our room until after 3pm. However, on checkin, we were upgraded to a Superior room. Yay for that,Keio Plaza is an enormous hotel, occupying two multi-story buildings and a basement restaurant precinct. Our room was huge, larger than most living rooms, and I was pleased to find a suitable pillow on the bed. There was a seating area by the window with a view to the Metropolitan Government Building, and a handy desk area with a mobile phone which we could use for domestic and international calls. There was also efficient free wifi and suitable plugs to charge our various devices.The buffet breakfast was quite adequate, and the restaurant was beautifully set out.However, the best thing about the Keio Plaza is the covered walkway that takes you to Shinjuku West station. Easy access to JR trains and Tokyo Metro which we employed for siteseeing during our stay.Thank you Keio Plaza. We will be back!

Keio Plaza is a large hotel in the Shinjuku area in Tokyo. The rooms are spacious and well designed. Our room overlooks the pool and a large open area. The lobby is always well staffed and checkin went quickly even with a large group ahead of us. Amenities in the room are Wi-Fi, a little "office" desk, fridge, hair dryer, coffee/tea with a hot water kettle, and a little pack for make-up removal in the bathroom among standard items. Most hotels in Japan provide toothbrushes, hair brushes, razors in addition to wash items. The hotel is conveniently close to both the main Shinjuku and Nishi-Shinjuku stations. We walked a block to have dinner in a vibrant area where the streets were lined with restaurants that served grilled meats, sushi, seafood and Chinese, Turkish and Indian food. We picked a ramen and udon eatery. The minute we stepped out someone asked, "Did you eat already?" disappointed he couldn't not bring us into his restaurant. You'll see people hanging out in the area on their phones or with friends in large numbers.
user_name:
Joy M
San Francisco, California, United States

review_body: Best part of hotel is location, fairly good amenities. Was charged 2,000yen to use pool, 10:30am is to early to close buffet breakfast. Found beds hard, but most staff were super friendly and helpful. Again location is the best!!

My first and most memorable detail are the hard beds. Was OK. But I would probably not return. Breakfast buffet but not sensational, more focused on asian guests than western. Need a bit of a remodelling, seems like one enters the museum. Good location. In front of the 2020 Olympic committee, which is lit up at night. Lines of people at reception both for check in as for check out. Ok service, but nothing to write home about.

Room was much bigger than expected for Tokyo, with excellent amenities. Not a great value -- the room rate was high, but worth it for the room size, as we were a party of 3. We really liked the location -- just a few minutes' walk from the Shinjuku station, but in a quieter area of office buildings and manicured plazas. We didn't try any of the restaurants in the hotel, as there were many options very close by. Tour buses and the airport bus do pick-ups and drop-offs at this hotel, which is super convenient.

If you have booked a room at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo, you can enjoy FREE shuttle bus to Tokyo Disney Resort. Free shuttle bus to Tokyo Disney online reservation must be proceeded before you check-in. The Reception Staff of Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo will hand you the shuttle bus ticket(s) when check-in.

I visit Tokyo frequently and stay at this hotel for convenience. Mediocre accommodations but clean and very centrally located near Shinjuku station. The breakfasts are buffet style with throngs of people choosing from the somewhat edible options offered. More of a barracks dining feel than a served meal. Functional but certainly unmemorable

Was invited for a dip in the outdoor pool of this massive hotel which is somewhat a Tokyo institution. It is huge and slightly overwhelming . The decor is from another era and needs a total facelift ! It is a very very beautiful building , but everything is from the 1970s-1980s ..... the pool is perfectly located surrounded by Shinjuku skyscrapers and has so much potential, but it again is old fashioned . The attendants are over zealous , was asked to remove my sunglasses in the pool .... which even though I understand, was annoying ; then the deck chairs are cheap plastic ....the pool attendants wear really ugly uniforms which look like a provincial family sports facility - there are no drinks allowed at the pool , it’s kind of a Family type atmosphere and not chic !! Great situation , wonderful location - surrounded by stunning skyscrapers , though not for the chic minded traveller .. when compared to Hotel pools like The Shilla Seoul , this pool is not of this era !! The charge of 4000yen seems a bit steep for the standard of design !! Also the awful blue towels which have seen better days don’t cover the lounge chairs ..... one thing I really hated was the Terry towelling rugs on the changing room floors which were not clean !! the drinks in the bar were served with awful Kombini type sandwiches and the sparkling wine was flat .... again the furniture , And even the Zen garden seen from the bar looked like a display at a homecenter . The waiters had 1950s pomaded hair , and the uniforms fitted really badly .. its a shame that such a Tokyo landmark is NOT OF THIS ERA

My husband and I booked this hotel for 3 nights post cruise through NCL. The cost to stay there was £400 per night so we expected luxury! Well we were totally and utterly disappointed! We realise that the price charged could have been due to the cruise company also making a profit and have contacted them regarding this matter however the whole experience at this hotel was pretty dreadful. We were transported to the hotel by coach from the ship ( including a city tour) and when we arrived outside the hotel there were no porters available to take the cases of any of the passengers , so all of our cases were left lying on the pavement while we were herded into the hotel to join the longest Hotel queue for check in we have ever seen. When, after an hour, we arrived at the desk we were told by a receptionist who spoke little English, that as we had booked through NCL we couldn’t check in there but at a different area. We were not alone at experiencing this! Possibly NCL should have made us aware of this! We had to find our own luggage( piled up in the lobby) and take it with us as no porters were yet available! When we eventually got our key we were full of anticipation to see our luxurious room! We could not have been more disappointed! The room was basic at best. It was small and cramped with not a single thing to recommend it! We have had much better in a Premier Inn in the U.K. at a fraction of the cost. The safe was in a cupboard at floor level so we had to go on to the floor to use it ( not ideal with arthritis)! As we were on the 18th floor the view was interesting especially at night with the city lights on. We headed out to explore the area and to be fair the hotel is in a fairly interesting area of Japan but there are very few shops to browse. There are many little diners ( we had uncooked Chicken in one), chemist shops and electrical outlets but not much else. The station however is within easy walking distance , though the station itself is so vast that it is hard to find the correct platform etc. As people who have travelled widely we are generally able to make ourselves understood or be able to read signs etc but there is very little English spoken or even understood so it makes things a little difficult! When we went for breakfast on our first morning we again had to queue for ages. The breakfast room was crowded and the buffet style breakfast was pretty average. The next 2 mornings we chose to eat in the American diner within the hotel as it was not so busy and the food was reasonably good. We ate in that restaurant in the evening and it was quite enjoyable! The service was pleasant and efficient and as residents we were given a discount. We went up to the bar at the top of the hotel for a drink as there is a great view of the area but as we were not eating there, we were not offered a window seat and we found the staff quite brusque and unfriendly! When we explored the hotel further we discovered gorgeous ( very expensive) restaurants on the basement level. The decor is very attractive in the public areas. There are also little shops with an ATM available in one general store where we bought some souvenirs and gifts so in that respect the Hotel was good. There is also a travel agents which can arrange tours but they were not suitable for us. The Hop on/Hop Off bus isn’t!! You have to get on at the office near Central Station in Central Tokyo and do the full round tour!! Unusual!! We are still undecided whether we like Tokyo or not! Maybe we need to return one day to make a decision but we certainly won’t be returning to the Keio Plaza as our overriding impression of this hotel is one of disappointment.

Booked thru Japanican.comBooking # 5758402087Hotel: Keio Plaza Hotel TokyoPeriod of Stay: July 28, 2018 to July 31, 2018Review:Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo has direct access thru the subway, so we did not get wet during stormy weather on our check in date. And that was the number one criteria I always look for before I even consider. Accessibility is most important. Check in was fast and we were lucky to be able to have a room upgrade with a gorgeous view of the Tokyo Government Bldg ( bldg lights up during evening). We were also allowed early check in because the room was ready (fortunate indeed). Tip: reserve your Limousine Bus Seats with Concierge for departure date. We bought in advance our return to airport bus seats at Narita during our arrival (they have promos like free 24hr subway cards) Everyone speaks very good English. For Breakfast we had choice of 3 different restaurants, one serving Japanese breakfast, American Buffet, and another one which I recommend is the Glass Court serving both American & Japanese Buffet Breakfast. Service was very good considering the big size of the hotel and its many clients. Elevators were fast. They offer complimentary Smartphone in our room which you can take out on tours to access internet and get free calls everywhere. Beds were very comfortable. Rooms were large, clean and good branded toiletries were provided. I would truly say that for the experience we had with Keio, the high price we paid was commensurate. We would definitely recommend this to our friends. I only thing that bothers me is that when I arrived home, I called my credit card company to check the transaction with Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo, there appears a double charge for our 3 nights stay... I hv inquired on japanican.com about this on Aug 2, 2018, because that is where I booked the hotel and I have not received any response up to this date of uploading this review... I hope that Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo people gets to read my review soon, and I have indicated my booking reference on top. I would have rated Keio a perfect 5 if not because of this double charge.

We travelled as a family of 3 including our 4 year old daughter and we were happy with our choice to stay at Keio Plaza. The Hotel is in a great location with fabulous restaurants within the complex as well as within walking distance. Shinjuku Station - a major train station is close by. Hotel staff were very attentive and we would definitely stay here again given the opportunity.

Spacious rooms , nice bathroom amenities , excellent , helpful staff . A rare Japanese hotel with an outdoor pool . If you join the hotel loyalty program you get free pool access . We had club rooms which were very reasonably priced and the lounge access was very good . Staff in the lounge were lovely and good range of drinks . Food was small canapés and cake but very tasty . Very good range in the big Breakfast restaurant .
