We also tried the Japanese breakfast room which is nice and quiet .There is a free shuttle daily to Disney .Very short walk from Shinjuku station , either street level or underground ,just make sure you come out the west exit . There is a tunnel from the station with travelators to the back entrance of the hotel . Very helpful when you are pulling heavy luggage .Exit west and follow the signs to the tokyo government metro building , next to the hotel , which has a free observation deck until 10.30 pm .

The hotel is all about volume so it’s processes are very impersonal. The most impersonal (by experience) hotel we stayed in throughout Japan. We had previously stayed at Park Hotel in Tokyo (none of the issues encountered below). The check-in process is slow leading to queues. WiFi is inconsistent. The swimming pool is an additional cost - per person per visit. So a family of 4 need to pay almost £50 if they use the pool per day! Outrageous. Concierge (bell captain) is under staffed. Always a queue and other staff members pass by without getting involved. Creates the impression of ‘not my job’. Not a guest-focused hotel. Flight Boarding Pass - I asked if this could be printed. Initially I was told it was not a service the hotel could offer (which was completely unservice-like!) and then told that on this occasion only! The lifts got very busy - signs were put out warning of problems. Too many people. Breakfast queues can be awful so get there early - though the breakfast itself was excellent. Disney Shuttle - excellent service with plenty of choice on departure and return times.

Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo in the Shinjuku district which Is the most popular shopping and entertainment spots in Tokyo.Centrally located & only 5-minutes walk from Shinjuku Station, this luxury hotel provides very comfortable accommodation and rooms are big, by Japanese standard.As 1 of the "Tokyo Disney Resort Good Neighbor Hotels", they offer complimentary shuttle bus service directly from the hotel to Tokyo Disneyland and Tokyo DisneySea which is a luxury, especially when travelling with small children

The rooms are nice. and even if i was yhe only one booked in the room.. it had ammenities and towels fit for 3 people. and this is not normal in japan. specially in tokyo. Rooms are big and clean. Service is ok... and the view is nice.Its also strategically located in shinjuku with a mall just a few blocks away. However... its quite far from the center of shinjuku. But over all.. super nice place.

My wife and I recently spent three nights at the Keio Plaza following a cruise and as per everyone else in Japan the staff were exemplary .The food was excellent and the decor sophisticated and uncluttered.However charging $25 per day to use the pool was a real jaw dropper.

A big hotel right in the middle of Shinjuku. Several restaurants to choose from, quite big rooms and easy to navigate. Try the Sky Bar - it has a magnificent view over Tokyo. The only thing missing is a more equipped fitness-room. The hotel is highly recommendable.

I stayed in KEIO Plaza during my final leg of tour of Tokyo after checking out of Tokyo Disney Land. KEIO has a shuttle at about 4+pim pickup from Tokyo Disneyland and the shuttle is available if you are a stayin guest or planning to check-in on the same day you board the shuttle. It is convenient and direct transfer. For a mummy with two kids in the tow, this was the best option! I joined the KEIO membership and booked the room with 3 beds at members' price. The check-in was a breeze and best part, there was even lounge access for members. Although snack varieties were lacking, the lounge oversee part of the city and offers a tranquil place to rest after a long day out sightseeing. There is a Tochomae station within minutes of the hotel. This is a quieter and more convenient alternative to the Shinjuku station.

good hotel maybe the rooms were small but they even had tea in the rooms . I liked the fact that they give news paper for every room . Also good location , it is near an Uniqlo store , a Starbucks and a MacDonald's

Located nearby JR Shinjuku easy to move around Tokyo city. Accommodation room size spacious. Disadvantage is Swimming pool chargeable at 2000Yen/adult though you stay at the hotel. Breakfast buffet is at 3000Yen/adult at the Jurin American style breakfast restaurant

Keio Plaza is an excellent hotel in a great central location to the Shinjuku station. It is a big complex with 2 towers and large common areas and a floor or two of restaurants and shops.However, importantly its on the door step of the Shinjuku Train Station(s) and has easy walking access to many, many restaurants and shops. We'll stay there again next time around.

I’m in charge of a project where we have to travel to Japan quite often. After the very bad experience last time where we had to check in and checkout many times because the hotel cannot plan during busy periods, this time I requested to have a paid early check in. However when I arrived after a long haul flight on 16 July at 08:30 am there was no room available. The hotel did not even offer a drink, a place to work or even a place to shower. Fortunately some of the people in my team checked in the day before so I could shower in their room. Now waiting in the Lobby when so can checkin but I also need to travel for meetings. I hope I can check in before. We have a meeting with the sales team of Keio plaza on Wednesday 18 July and I am going to explain what happened and may say that this is the last time my team stayed here. This Keio plaza hotel is very unprofessional and not service minded. Very bad indeed, especially after a flight from Amsterdam to London to Tokyo for many hours I did not expect such very bad treatment.

Hotel was enormous and felt like a tour group or business hotel rather than having a particular personality to it. We were disappointing to discover that they charge extra to use the pool (not something that was clear when we were booking through the site and definitely would not have stayed here and paid the cost if we knew this in advance). Most disappointing was the check in experience as we discovered about the pool charges and hotel staff were completely unwilling to do anything to accomodate us. The manager jjust kept re-stating that everyone must pay and it was between us and Wotif to work out and nothing to do with them. Perhaps a cultural difference in customer complaint resolution in Japan compared with other hotels around the world, but certainly started off our trip feeling we weren’t getting value for money within the hotel or personalised service from the staff.

We use to mame a booking for non-smoking room, but front desk mentioned they run out of smoking room and not available to offer us a non-smoking room.We said we have make our request in booking, but front desk said they could only try but no guarantee! We thrn request for an upgrade which we are willing to pay, but they still saying no.We said we go to the smoking room and see if we can accept, but then not only the smell, we found beddings with stain and toilet seat with cigarette hole!We then go to front desk and request for change room but still having no no no. So finally we check out and stay in another hotel. The result is we spended HKD6600 for this experience without refund!This is the worse experience I ever have in Japan and won't reference to those hotel photos in any web.Not everything in Japan is nice and decent ! 我地本來訂非吸煙客房，但係前台話佢地無哂非吸煙房，只可提供吸煙房俾我地。我地話我係預訂時提出我地的要求，但係前台話佢地只能嘗試不能保證！我地要求升級房間同願意支付差額，但佢地仍然拒絕！咁我地唯有去吸煙房睇吓，係咪真係接受唔到啦，但一入到房，不單係氣味，我仲發現床上有污漬，個廁所蓋仲有個煙洞！然後我地去前台要求更換房間，但佢地只係答no no no。最後我地只能即日退房住另一間酒店。結果係我地為呢個[驚惶酒店]體驗花咗HKD6,600而不穫退款！呢個係我係日本遇到最差既經歷，亦唔會再信任何網站上既酒店照片。不是所有日本的都係好！

So grateful to find this hotel last minute after our Airbnb was cancelled 1 week prior to our arrival to Tokyo. We booked 2 rooms - 1king bedded & 1 w/3 twins. The generously sized rooms were well appointed with luxury bath amenities. The hotel’s location was ideal just 2 blocks away from the train station but in a quiet neighborhood. I highly recommend this hotel with it’s modern decor & reasonable prices.

We spent 4 days at Keio Plaza in the beginning of our japanese journey. Situated next to Tokyo govenment building in a quiet block but only a few hundred metres from the busy Shinjuku scene. Large room, nice view from the 22nd floor windows and 45th floor bar. Many restaurants if you are too lazy to exit this large hotel complex. Anyhow we will return to this hotel for our last couple of days in Japan. This is an OK place to stay in this price category.

‘My family stayed at a unit with 3 queen beds. It was big, beautiful and clean A bit expensive but it worth it! The hotel had a convenience store inside, restaurants and souvenir shops were just outside the hotel. It provided shuttle service to Tokyo Disney and to & from the airport. Hotel staff were nice & accommodating. Highly recommended!

We have stayed twice before, the first time was very so so, second time in July 2017 got lots of improvement and this time was great.We booked Deluxe Newly renovated room instead of Superior south like before, first quite worry because the location is at the Main Building which is rather old that south wing.But the room reservation was very kind and has accommodate all our request (high floor and quite room)We've been given corner room which is very quite and cozy with the new renovation.The toiletries was luxurious (LOccitane) and the shower is magnificent with massage sprayer for our tired body and feet.The cleaning service staff was great, our room was always as clean as the first time we checked in.Only complaint is the breakfast buffet at Glass Court was closed at 10.00 AM and it is too early due to on holiday, we used to get up quite late.Overall the stay was great and Keio has improved a lot in services in these last two years.

the room was big for tokyo standard, however i was assigned the south tower "older" rooms so things were a little dated. am returning in August, will definitely book this hotel if i get to enjoy special rate again!

My all time favorite whenever I stay in Tokyo. Conveniently located in the vicinity of Shinjuku west station, right on top of one of the most popular metro line Oedo Tochomae station and accessible by airport limousine bus. What's more, their room is relatively big and have a wide mix of restaurants and bars at affordable price. One of the most impressive service is the concierge. Everyone speaks good English and is very gelpful. My special thanks to Mr Mori where he's been there to take care of me and all my troublesome requests since many years ago. So glad to see him still there, an icon representing the highest quailty of customer service. Please say hello to him and you will definitely be impressed by his manner and service.

It's been years after I came back and stay in the hotel again. Still as good as before.I stay in the main hotel with great view over the city of Tokyo. Very clean room and bathroom. Excellent choices of breakfast at 3 different restaurant. Excellent attention to details by the restaurant staff. I hope I will comeback soon.
user_name:
Gregorius S
Greater London, United Kingdom

review_body: Although the hotel is rated is 4/5 star hotel. Unfortunately, over crowded and overpriced hotel. Front desk/ line mangers absolutely lucking costumer service. Room is so dated...breakfast is poor quality and staff barely speak English. I would not recommend. Probabably would rate as 2 star hotel.

Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku is a 5 star hotel in the heart of Government building and Shinjuku station.The hotel itself is big, maybe because it is established several years ago (Hotel in Tokyo typically small due to lack of land)The room are quiet spacious and the service is very good.The staf are very helpful and professional but due to the size of the hotel, you will meet wide range of people from tourist, business person and government official.I have tried several of their restaurant and they are quiet good. As value of money, this hotel is pricy, but if you can affort and you want to stay in Shinjuku, then this hotel might be a good choice for you

Nice zen like fee to the rooms. Ignore the lobby and head straight up to your room for great views out over Shinjuku. We did not eat at the hotel, however it was always busy. Bathroom is very small...and while I would prefer a separate shower/bath (they are right next to each other) the bathroom still felt nice. Put it down to the Japanese touch. All the mod cons in a calm quiet space. They also use l’occitane amenities as a added bonus.Location is amazing. Easy to find on the train from the airport and good connections to travel around Tokyo. Would stay again. Is expensive but everything was expensive. Was happy to pay the price for the room and location.

This is an excellent located hotel from the Shinjuku station, you can walk easily from the station to the hotel no matter the weather, there is a under passage to the hotel very convenient. I checked many others and finally decided this was my best option in the Shinjuku area.

We stayed for three nights in two different standard rooms. We loved the location and thought the breakfast buffet was terrific! The rooms were very nice and quite spacious for Japanese hotel rooms. This is a nice hotel for families looking for a convenient location in Tokyo.

We stayed at this hotel for six nights in June, 2018. Stayed in two different rooms: Standard twin room, and premium double room in South Tower. Both rooms were clean, comfortably appointed, quiet, and pleasant. The higher floors offer a great view. Our room faced west, and we were able to see Mount Fuji one evening when the sky was clear, a rarity in Tokyo. Service at the hotel was all-around excellent. Everyone was pleasant, professional, and helpful. We did not have any problems of any kind.We ate breakfast in the Glass Court restaurant. They had a good selection of both Western and Japanese breakfast items. Quality was good. Not great, but good. Price was quite high, as is typical of hotels in this price category. We had a room rate which included breakfast; otherwise, we probably would have skipped due to the price point.Location is very good. About seven minutes walking time to the western entrance plaza of Shinjuku Station. There are tons of restaurants, shops, etc. in this area.The hotel itself, as well as the Shinjuku area, was quite large and crowded. If you are looking for a more sedate experience, another area of Tokyo might be more suitable. But if you like Shinjuku or need to stay in this area, I recommend Keio Plaza hotel. I would stay again.

My husband and I stayed here in April 2017 for almost a week. This was a beautiful hotel, felt luxurious but in a business hotel way. The hotel has a number of restaurants and a mini supermarket which is very useful. It is near enough to Shinjuku Station to walk to comfortably but I wouldn't want to do this with luggage. The hotel rooms were larger than most in Tokyo but the hotel is on the more expensive side so you pay for the space. The toiletries provided in the bathroom were better than any I have received before :) Enjoyed our stay here.

I like so much this hotel because have a excellent location, the travel agency (cancunajapan.com) help me a lot with the requirements than i want.This hotel have everything in one place if you don't have much time to buy something fast. I recommend you totally!! Also the staff are amazing!! Thank you so much for this experience.

Excellent hotel located a few blocks from Shinjuku train station. Clean and comfortable rooms. Firm beds. Friendly and helpful staff. Lots of dining options on the property but we enjoyed most venturing out to local restaurants nearby. Stayed here for 2 nights after travel from US in preparation for a Princess Cruise. Glad we got here early to start becoming accustomed to time change. Tours of Tokyo and Mt Fuji can be taken right from the hotel. A good stop for our family of 3!

We stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel last November for 4 nights during our first trip to Japan. We traveled with 2 young children ages 3 and 6. Choosing a hotel in Tokyo is a daunting process with so many options and a wide range of price points. Ultimately, I chose Keio for its central location next to the Shinjuku train station, capitalizing on having fewer train transfers with two youngsters on hand. (We would be traveling to Hakone from Tokyo and Shinjuku was easily linked to Tokyo or Shinagawa JR stations if you have a JR pass). It is also a direct stop for the Airport Limousine route. The other big draw was the free shuttle to Disneyland/Disney Sea, as the reality of making multiple train transfers during rush hour morning to get to Disney with two youngsters was probably going to be a nightmare. (On Hyperdia, that train commute to Disney would have taken about an hour.) That being said, when we arrived, it was impressively upscale with full bell service when we walked in the door. The room was much larger than I expected (and read about compared to other Tokyo accommodations). We had three double sized beds in a room plus a comfortable size bathroom. The room was clean and had cute kid toiletries for the kiddos. It was walking distance to large malls (about a 10 minute walk to Keio Mall), which I used to pick up take-out dinners at the basement food floors when the kids were too jetlagged to go out to dinner. Also, it's walking distance from Shin Udon, which was the BEST udon we had while in Japan! The neighborhood was lively and energetic at night, felt very safe to walk around and browse the many food options. As I mentioned, it's walking distance to Shinjuku train station, which is a JR station as well as a local subway station. Beware the size of this station - it often felt like walking through and airport terminal and is easily half a mile walk from one end to the other end, but I digress. The hotel itself did not have many affordable dining options, except for the small minimart on the basement floor where I picked up some onigiri for some light snacks. Every staff member we encountered were extremely helpful and spoke English fluently. We were very happy with our choice and would stay here again!

The reason I chose this hotel is its location. It takes less than ten minutes to get to the Shinjuku Station where you can do all types of shopping or go to other districts and cities easily. Being a 4 star hotel, the size of my twin room is not small. It is big enough to open 2 pieces of luggage on the floor, but the carpet is a bit worn out. Just need to caution about its hotel stringent policy. I booked a twin room without breakfast for my friend and me via an online hotel website (not the official hotel website). When I checked in, the hotel staff told me that my booking was only for one person and I had to pay extra near 6000 yen per night, irrespective of the fact that I booked and paid for a twin room. I explained to the hotel staff that I paid for a twin room when booking and I expected it would allow two persons to stay in the twin room. Unfortunately, my assumption was wrong. They insisted that I had to pay the extra fees because I did not mention that there would be a double occupancy during my booking. They did not care about the fact that the room I paid was a twin room for two persons. As long as I changed the occupancy, I needed to pay the extra. I felt cheated and was disappointed with this heartless hotel.

Stayed here before Suppose this time the only criticism is as I had a bus for the airport at 545 in the morning there is no option for breakfast or a coffee in the hotel from 5 onwards which is a pity Room this time was a good product versus last stay large corner room in the south tower

Very convenient location,well priced with host of facilities...you cant asked more ...its backed by wonderful hospitality...Front office is keen to help you all out ...if its is trains,metro or restaurant or places to visit. The utility store in the lobby floor ...people are very helpful..I had terrible diarrhea and the two old ladies helped me out patiently and passionately.Rooms are well sized,clean and house keeping is excellent.Overall an experience to remember !!

I have stayed at Keio plaza twice now on business trips. This place is centrally located and walkable to a large number of restaurants, department stores, train station, even a great park and a Shinto shrine. There is a limo bus from both Narita and Haneda airports that drops visitors in front of the hotel. The hotel itself has an interesting array of restaurants. The staff is very friendly. The beds are comfortable, rooms are modern, clean and provide decent views of city. Few minor inconveniences: rooms do not have an iron to press clothes, hotel strictly enforces 11AM checkout time (additional hours are charged on hourly basis) but the hotel provides facility to store luggage free of charge so that's a bonus.

Went on a family holiday trip to Tokyo in the second week of June. Key places of interest we wanted to visit were Disney Land & Disney Sea, Harajuku, Shibuya and of course Shinjuku. Having had a wonderful memories of Keio Plaza Hotel years back, of course including the convenience of shuttle service to Disney and easy access to Shinjuku Station, I naturally chose Keio Plaza for this trip and booked and paid for 3 rooms without much thoughts. When there, I noticed the hotel has aged a little and there were no standing showers. Despite, it made up with the excellent services. Upon arrival, the guest relation / concierge were there to receive us. Check-in was a breeze and we were up in our rooms in less than 15 minutes. The excellent services were all round, making arrangement for my transportation were simply effortless and the staff were extremely polite. Food from room service were great and house keeping was amazing swift, thorough and clean. Keio was rather generous with the toiletries. Even in my last day and after check-out, the Concierge were still dishing out excellent services: I wanted to change my schedule to make a trip to Mitsui Kisarazu outlet mall meaning affecting transportation arrangements and all! It was a Saturday and last minute re-arrangement of transportation is impossible in Japan. However, the 2 Concierge (a foreign and a Japanese lady: sadly I did not catch their names) were extremely helpful. They contacted a numbers of transportation providers and unbelievably managed to accommodate my new schedule. Got to say Great Service!!!

My husband and I landed on this hotel in Tokyo as a result of its location and reasonable prices. It is a short walk to Shinjuku station, which easily connects you to the JR lines as well as several local train lines. You can pretty much get to any place in Tokyo from this station.After reading several other traveler reviews, we decided to book the South Tower as it seems that these rooms were recently renovated, and I was very happy that we did. We booked a "Superior Queen" room and it was quite large, especially for Tokyo where rooms are notoriously small. One evening we stopped for a cocktail on the top floor lounge with gorgeous views of Tokyo. We also ate at one of the hotel restaurants, but I would recommend other options in the area instead. Overall, I was very happy with our stay and would probably book it again.

It was a wonderful experience.Pluses:1. The rooms were very spacious, and clean. 2 Bathrooms modern fittings, and lovely amenities.3. Limo bus from the airport comes straight to the hotel.4. Great breakfast spread.5. The day trip desk is right at the hotel, and many sightseeing trips start from here.6. Very friendly guest relations desk.7. We had a quadruple room as we have 2 kids.One tip is to book early as the quadruple rooms sell out pretty quickly.8. Best part is the location right next to Shinjuku station with many great restaurants near by.Hope to stay here again on our next trip to Tokyo.

We were a family of 4 staying in the hotel for 2 separate stints over a 2 week period. We stayed in a room with 4 separate full size beds and 2 bathrooms. Room was adequate in size - bigger than I was expecting after reading some of the other reviews. Service was good. Easy access to Shinjuku station. Decent breakfast and dinner buffets. Did not have a good meal at the Chinese restaurant (Nan-En) there - food was bland and they refused to add tofu to my daughter’s stir fried vegetables (she’s a vegetarian). Would definitely not recommend that restaurant. Otherwise, both stays were pleasant. There are nicer hotels in Japan but this one wasn’t bad to begin and end our trip.

After cruising around Japan for several weeks, my wife and I wanted to spend a week based in Tokyo so we could visit friends and my wife’s relatives. The Keio Plaza Hotel was an excellent choice. A nice modern hotel, centrally located in the popular Shinjuku neiborhood near subway and train connections, and in addition to convenient restaurant facilities (albeit expensive) in the connected lower level mall, adjacent to many blocks of small excellent inexpensive and moderate priced restaurants of whatever Japanese cuisines one might be interested in.

I booked a room for two adults and a 15 year old but when I checked in I was told that my room was booked for two adults and a child under 5 years and was told I needed to pay an additional $59 a night. Because of the language barrier, I didn't get anywhere explaining that I booked the room to include a 15 year old so I agreed to pay the extra amount. To make things worst, I was charged an addition $18 (which was not on the final bill) and I have no idea what this charge is for but I refuse to contact the hotel for I feel I will not get anywhere.Other than the issues with my room charge, this is a beautiful first rate hotel with a convenient location.

If location is important, then this is the hotel for you. It’s about 7 minutes from Shinjuku Station, but if you don’t know the area this could take you quite a bit longer when you arrive. The station is enormous and quite difficult to navigate. Research this before you arrive. The hotel is absolutely enormous, but doesn’t seem to have any heart. There are multiple entrances and exits, not to mention different buildings. There are multiple restaurants within the complex, but I didn’t get the feeling that they had anything to do with the hotel. Breakfast is located within two of these. I opted for the western orientated option and was happy with the choices and value for money. My room was a long way from reception. It was large and very clean, although the bed was very hard. It was also quite dated. More than that, it was bland; not a single piece of art on the walls.All the staff I encountered were very professional, but there was no warmth here.Overall, this is a well located and efficient hotel. It is very bland and lacks personality. This would be fine if it was an airport hotel, but it is not a warm introduction to Tokyo.

Excellent hotel which is centrally located and offers nice and quiet rooms. We booked a new club floor „Premier Grand“ Deluxe King room with free access to Lounge. The room was very nicely and smartly furnished for its size. The wardrobe is a bit small for a longer stay and we missed some hooks for the bathrobes and our jackets to be able to hang them up outside the wardrobe. The lounge access was definitely a big plus and made the room „bigger“ as such. We also enjoyed the breakfast, tea time and cocktail offers/selection at the lounge. Depending on how we planned our day we either came back to the hotel for the tea time or for the evening cocktails. The staff at the lounge are very attentive and super friendly and made our stay a perfect experience.Also worth mentioning is the free Handy you receive during your stay and which you can take out with you. It served us several times very well, especially when we got lost and needed google maps.

Horrible experience and I regret not reading the other reviews much earlier before deciding. The smoking rooms are considered standard rooms so we definitely are feeling a bit cheated that it was not stated clearly on the website. Understand the limitations of having full house and hence not possible for changes but definitely not liking the lack of empathy and disinterested service staff. Definitely an awful start to our holiday.

For Hello Kitty addict like me, this is the best place to be. We booked one of the 4 Hello Kitty room at half price through hotel booking site. Right from the Narita Airport, we took a Limousine bus and alight in front of the Hotel. It is centrally located and you can find shops and restaurants nearby.

The Keio Plaza is a great hotel for exploring Tokyo. The rooms are a good size, comfy beds and nice and clean! Make sure you request a non-smoking room (if you are a non-smoker), we asked to switch rooms due to this and this was done quickly and efficiently. Breakfast is good and there is a good selection to choose from! Staff were really helpful and made the start of our trip really great!

Situated in the Shinjuku ward of Tokyo, this luxury hotel with two towers is very clean, modern, and welcoming and most likely has everything you may need. Staff is extremely polite and helpful. Public transportation is everywhere nearby., including the busiest train station in Japan.Rooms are adequate in size, beds are comfortable, toiletries are provided (and replaced when needed), and there's a small refrigerator. There are eight restaurants open for meals serving Asian (Japanese, Korean, and Chinese) French, Italian, and Western foods. There are gift shops, a small fitness center, a candy shop, convention center, and meeting rooms. Surely a good choice. Please give a like if this is helpful or you like the review. Thank you.

Clean, comfortable room with generous bathroom amenities.Great accessible location close to station, eating places and shopping. Also close to a peaceful park. Customer service was excellent.This is a large busy hotel. Whilst expensive good value for money compared to similar luxury hotels nearby.

Booked Deluxe King room with Club Lounge Access. On arrival we were taken straight to the Club Lounge on the 43rd floor where check-in was completed effortlessly in a very relaxed atmosphere after being given drinks and canapés. We realised then that this was no ordinary hotel. Rooms are amazing - great views over city, high quality and large range of toiletries, very clean, in-room iron (not always experienced in Japan), very powerful shower in wet room, Location is very close to Shinjuku Station so access to the rest of the city was easy. We used the Club Lounge for breakfast and evening drinks. Breakfast is a high quality buffet with a chef for omlettes and cooked eggs plus a selection of a la carte items. Evening drinks include canapés and provided a relaxed start to our evenings as we watched the city light up after sunset. All staff extremely polite and just have to repeat how helpful the Club Lounge staff were for anything we needed. Next time we visit Tokyo we won't bother looking at other hotels as this provided a perfect start to our tour of Japan. Would definitely recommend the extra expense of the Club Lounge.

I booked this hotel because it was the pickup location for my day tour with JTB Sunrise Tours. To my surprise this hotel was great and I would definitely recommend staying here! The hotel staff knows basic English so they can help answer your questions. The hotel has multiple restaurants and a convenience store. There's also a 24 hour grocery store nearby that's a 10 minute walk from the hotel (Maruetsu Petit Nishishinjuku).It's about a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku Station and a five minute walk from Tochomae Station (Oedo line). The walk to Sinjuku Station isn't long. It only feels long if you take a route that has a lot of cross streets.The room was great and it had a nice view. I wish my room came with an iron and ironing board. You have to request for one if you need it. I did not get the breakfast package when I booked my room. On the day I wanted to eat the buffet breakfast at the Glass Court, I was able to pay there. The breakfast was good and if you think you'll eat breakfast at the hotel everyday, I would get the breakfast package.The airport limousine bus stops at this hotel. To return to the airport using the airport limo, you must ask someone at the bell captain desk to reserve a seat on the bus for you. Check out is at 11 am, but if your flight is later, you can ask the staff at the bell captain desk hold your luggage until your flight. I had to leave Tokyo for Narita Airport at 1 pm, so I asked the staff at the bell captain's desk to hold my luggage from 11 am to 1 pm. I just walked around Shinjuku until I had to leave.The only con I have is with the hotel WiFi. If I tried to connect to the WiFi using my smartphone, my WiFi connection was slow or the connection would sometimes drop. (Note: You're supposed to be redirected to a login page every time you try to connect to the WiFi. Save the web address for the login page because sometimes it does not display automatically when you open your browser.)

This hotel is perfect for people that are traveling from US. There is transportation from Narita straight to Keio hotel. The location is close to Shinjuku train station, you can walk every where. Will book again

Stayed here a total of three nights on a recent Mother and sons trip. As Mum had some mobility issue, we checked to see if hotels in Tokyo had wheelchair accessible rooms. Fortunately for us, Keio Plaza had 8 Universal Rooms that fit the bill nicely. The universal rooms are larger with handbars and special seats in the bathrooms. While beds are electrically adjustable. We couldn’t be any happier or rather Mum couldn’t be any happier. The Keio Plaza is an older property that is quite well known both in and outside of Japan. Many international visitors were noticed. In addition, it is also where some Japanese couples choose to hold their weddings. Do watch out for the happy couples especially on Saturdays. Located in Shinjuku, it’s a short walk to Shinjuku station and all the shopping malls. And plenty of eating places near by although the hotel also has some excellent restaurants. In addition to being a stopping point for the Airport Limousine bus, as a Disney partner hotel, there are daily buses to and back from Tokyo Disneyland. But do get your tickets early. WiFi was good throughout. Service as always was excellent although given the size and popularity, the lobby can get rather busy and so best give yourself extra time.

I have been to TYO for my business trip late May and I found this hotel is very comfortable and convenience for Shinjuku train station. (10mins walk) Airport bus is available to HND 1230YenThe breakfast offer is nice (I have tried the Japanese plus America buffet, better have your breakfast before 0730 or it will be quite crowded.) The Gym room 24hrs access, (not very big but enough for running) Lounge service at 34F(closed at 2200) is the best part for my stay. Fantastic night view which is wonderful after a busy working day in TYO. The atmosphere is so relaxing which you can enjoy yourself with the snack and drink or having the happy hour with 2 guests.The hotel is located at the government office side which is very clear and quiet, at the same time within 15mins walk you would explore the exciting lifestyle in Shinjuku and great variety of restaurants there.I would recommend it is a good choice for both business or travel purposes.Lounge service at 34F(closed at 2200) is the best part for my stay. Fantastic night view which is wonderful after a busy working day in TYO. The atmosphere is so relaxing which you can enjoy yourself with the snack and drink or having the happy hour with 2 guests.The hotel is located at the government office side which is very clear and quiet, at the same time within 15mins walk you would explore the exciting lifestyle in Shinjuku and great variety of restaurants there.I would recommend it is a good choice for both business or travel purposes.

Hotel is clean spacious and modern. I stayed two different times over two weeks and found renovated section standard room better appointed than older larger 'better' room. Be careful to select renovated room when making reservation. The staff are super friendly and helpful. My only negative is the 'gym' on the 7th floor. I travel a lot on business and rely on a good gym for early morning pre-business day workouts. They gym is disappointing.

If you request a kremato ( Milk pod ) because you don't like powered milk the Keio will charge you Y100 even if you are paying over Y30,000 a night and hold Executive Prime gold card, and no English tea bags unless maybe in a Club room . Toilet paper free I think in all rooms !!I ask the young girl on check in, could you have some milk pods sent to my room please ? NO you must phone from your room . So much for service 0/10Phoned the number....wrong number ...phone another..yes you can have but a charge of Y100 each...WHAT ... I am paying over Y30,000 a night ( £200) and you want me to pay for a milk pod ? YES.Down to the Duty Manager Guest Relations....Mr Tohru HigashiI am not the typ of person that shouts or loses his temper ...told repeatrdly, wait a min while trying to explain the situation. Am told thoes are the rules and Y100 each.So much for service 0/10. needs to go on a course on how to deal with clients .Its now not the milk its the principle of the charge.Down to the desk in the morning and request to see number 1 man.So many managers its unbelievable....Next Director of Guest Relations, Ms Kaori Hashimoto, knew the story but still no milk pods !!! Have to speak to another Department ....WHAT !!!!The NEXT day a bag of milk pods arrive, no English tea bags.But no cups in the room, Cheif House keeper arrived Junji Sakai.... Sorry !!!By this time have given up on th will to live and want to move Hotels.Wondered why so many negative reports on this Hotel.I now know why. Have stayed many times at this Hotel while passing through Tokyo.WILL NEVER stay again....hard work all over a milk pod.Keio get your act together, will now stay at the Hyatt jus down the road where we have stayed , they dont charge for milk pods....its called service !!!

Recently stayed on one of the upper floors of the Keio Plaza Hotel for a week long business trip. The room was spacious, nice and clean, bed incredibly comfortable, with great views of the local skyline (picture attached). The bathroom had good quality luxury items, with razors, shaving cream, good quality shampoo and shower gel. Rather a novelty is the heated toilet seat, probably only what to expect in a high end Japan hotel. My choice of room had access to the lounge, which opened at 10am each day (long after I'd left for my meetings), which is a shame as I am used to being able to grab a quick breakfast and coffee in the lounge when opting for this facility. However, in the evening small hor d'oeuvres are served, along with a choice of both alcohol and soft drinks, between the hours of 5pm and 7pm (this facility is only available with certain rooms). Not as generous and worthwhile as European and American hotels that have lounge access, but nice after a long day - no telephones are permitted in the lounge.The hotel is conveniently situated to the Shinkjuku train station and also the coach from the airport stops nearby.Staff all courteous and pleasant. No complaints.

First time visiting Tokyo. Great location. Staff friendly. Breakfast was great However the hotel is huge - divided into different wings - so reminded me of one of those monstrosity hotels in Las Vegas. Kept getting lost as so many entrances and exits. However it is in a calming location in the middle of total chaos.

Stayed at this hotel in April. The room was lovely- well-appointed and comfortable. The staff were pleasant, courteous, and accommodating. There were several different restaurants on site. They were fun to explore. The view of Tokyo from the room was amazing. I will stay here whenever I visit Tokyo.

The hotel is conveniently located close to the Shinjuku train station.This is the only good thing I can think of bout this hotel. I stayed in this hotel some years ago, as far as I can recall service was not bad. This time it was totally disastrous. To sum it up, unfriendly and unhelpful staff. They have zero concept about what service is all about. I believe management has to take full responsibility because it was not just one single incident, but a couple of them within a three night stay.. It is in their corporate culture. Due to its convenience, they don't have to worry about business so they couldn't care less about service any more.

This was our first hotel on our trip to JapanCheck in very good only thing I did not like was that we got to the hotel from Australia at 11am and could not check in till 2pm which was quite tiring to wait around, but once in the room was beautiful We just got the standard but the view was beautiful. We had the 25th floorThe thing that most impressed was the amenities. 2 of everything and the hair ties which was so goodWe also got use of a smart phone with complementary calls text etc. This was so good especially when we went out on tours etc.I used it twice International to call my daughter.We also had the Afternoon Tea on the 45th floor.Would definitely recommend this hotel

Stayed here for 8 nights. This is a very good business hotel in a very good location in central Shinjuku. Location feels calm even though it is so central. Rooms, cleanliness and attention from staff is top. The view from our room on 25th floor over Tokyo skyline by night was amazing. Very convenient airport transfer with direct buses/coaches to the hotel. Location very close to shopping districts, restaurants and Shinjuku station. On the downside the swimming pool was closed and is only open in summer (this was in May, when is summer??). And the whole atmosphere is a bit unpersonal and - but the hotel delivers the goods

Me and my wife stayed at the Keio Plaza for 3 nights. We arrived at the ungodly hour of 1 in the morning but was friendly received and check in was quick. We were disappointed when arriving at our floor and smelled the smoke. We immediately requested a room on a smokeless floor and it was quickly sorted out. The room was nice and big with a lovely well-appointed bathroom. It had a bath with a shower inside the bath. We were very happy with the toilet that had a warm seat and all kind of nifty settings. The bedding was amazing, and the towels were fluffy. I must stress that this is a huge hotel. You are just a number, but that did not worry us. Breakfasts were comprehensive and Western tastes were also catered for. The hotel is perfectly positioned to visit many shows and the nightlife is stunning. They were very helpful with options to get to the hotel from the airport so late at night. If you can afford it. It is the place to stay.

Great hotel - prices are expensive.But the renovated floors have great rooms.the Bar on 45 has great views of the city and is popular with locals.defiantly a great place to stay.unlike other place in Japan - if the room is free they will accept you when you arrive - which is a big plus

They have a great breakfast (American & Western style). Again, they have their won twist on American food. For example, their club sandwich is made with egg salad. So strange! Rooms are quiet and spacious. Love their bathroom. However, they have the same problem as the last two hotels we stayed at. There are no English channels, except for the one or two channels that will play an English show. When you watch CNN, they turn off the voices and a Japanese person translate the news show. Really annoying! When you need ice, you have to call room service to get ice, whereas the other two hotels we stayed at, you could simply go down the hall and get your own ice.

Our room was on the 24th floor in the south tower. We didn’t realize it until our last day but we had a direct view of Mount Fuji. It was just hidden behind some cloud cover for all the prior days. The room was very large, very comfortable and extremely clean. The lobby check in was fast and efficient. Everyone was friendly and tried their best to communicate with us. You couldn’t ask for a better location for visiting Tokyo. It’s only a few short blocks away from the Shinjuku train station. But those few blocks between gives you the serenity and peace from the maddening pace of the rest of Tokyo. We are New Yorkers and found Tokyo to be far more intense then our little city called New York so we appreciated the tranquility by the Keio plaza hotel.They have a tour desk that can arrange for many different tours of the city and day trips. Also a big plus is that you can take the limo bus from Narita airport directly to and from the hotel.In the lower level they have a convenience store that stays open very late and has many snacks, drinks, and even souvenirs. All for about the same amount you would pay at local 7-Eleven convenience stores.They also have many restaurants on that level. We did not eat at any of them but they all looked beautiful.If you are trying to decide on a hotel in Tokyo, this one is a no-brainer because you will have a comfortable stay if you choose the Keio plaza hotel.
user_name:
michelef147
New York City, New York

review_body: So I’ve stayed at four and five star hotels across the world and the reason I stay at higher star hotels is because of the service and ‘go out of way’ environment that hotels like these provide amongst cleanliness and comfort. However at Keio Plaza Hotel, I was astonished at the lack of quality service, the lack of understanding or empathy towards their customers. I had asked for a late check out by one hour due to my train being a few hours ahead of the check out time and was told I would have to pay ¥4000 to do so. The check out time at this hotel is fairly early and at 11.00AM and no matter the times I asked, and even spoke to the hotel manager at the time hoping for a solution, I was given a firm no. I felt that the staff were inhospitable and unwelcoming and I would not stay in this hotel given another opportunity.

A quality hotel to stay. Service staff are friendly and helpful. Room amenities even includes USB socket for charging, adapters provided, 2 complimentary mineral water, warm toilet seats and yukata (sleep wear).Seemed like check in time is strictly 2pm but you can deposit luggage with them. Overall a comfortable hotel to stay in!

A nice hotel with extremely friendly and polite staff who were very helpful . The breakfast in their restaurant Jurin was extensive and good but they do offer breakfast in their other restaurant as well The Glass Terrace . It was near the Shinjuku station. There are cafes nearby in Shinjuku if one wants to eat out . Good shopping centers like The Keio dept store are close by .The rooms were comfortable and the view was excellent from our room on the 32 nd floor .

This hotel was in a amazing location, with great Japanese restaurants within 5 minutes walking distance. Right next to train station which was great. The staff were very friendly and spoke good english, a very clean hotel with great facilities. Also has free transfer to disney land which saved us a little bit of money. The room came with a handy phone which was free, it was great and saved us getting lost around the big city. The only downfall to this hotel was the bed was uncomfortable and our room was located right next to the elevator which was a little bit noisy. I would definitely recommend staying at this hotel.

I have had amazing experiences at Keio Plaza hotel, staying at the Premier Grand with access to club lounge. Experiencing true customer service at the lounge, GREAT hotel room amenities... just blew my mind away. You can almost stay at the hotel without bringing anything... they have it all for you.Modern room (the Premier Grand, not sure about ordinary room). One of the best quality I ever stay. It is comparable with Fairmont, Kempinski, Fraser and the like

Hotel location was excellent & within walking distance from Shinjuku station. The Narita Express was a convenient way to get there from the airport. The hotel is also a short taxi ride to the Golden Gai area in Tokyo.We stayed on a high floor in the main building. There was a good city view but we all found the rooms rather small and claustrophobic. The bathroom looked like one of those fabricated units, very dated and the shower was in the bath - no walk in shower! So for us the room was the main negative aspect of our stay. We had access to the Luxe Lounge in the South Tower. The canapé offering in the lounge is very limited though they offer a good range of drinks including Japanese whiskey. Be advised it closes sharp at 7:00PM and reverts to a tea lounge.Breakfast could be taken either in the Glass Court or Jurin - both on the 2nd floor. The Glass Court had an excellent buffet offering, helpful staff and it offers a comfortable setting. By contrast Jurin has a more Western food offering and is decidedly less attractive. There can be an occasional queue at the Glass Court but it does move quickly.The main bar called 'Brilliant' is inviting and service very attentive. Unfortunately the pool only opens in Summer (July-Aug) but there is apparently a charge to use the pool! Subject to comments above on the room, happy to recommend the hotel given its location.

Substandard for the category. I stayed with my family in 3 rooms on a repeat visit after having been satisfied previously, but this time was not a positive experience. I did not get the room. I had reserved; as a Krio Executive member I am supposed to have certain amenities that i was told they could not offer, for example: instead of early check-in we were made to wait hours, well past standard check in time because rooms were not ready; I was downgraded from the room I had reserved and paid for without any adjustment; instead of late check out I was told it would be $80 to extend one hour until noon; the room was shabby: TV was not working properly; front desk staff was not helpful or very pleasant for that matter. Overall the location was good and the building was OK but it is very hit-and-miss with this place and this will be the last time I ever stay here. For nearly $4,000 in room charges for our stay we can do much better in Tokyo.
user_name:
Chimborazo2
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We stayed at this property for 4 nights, it's huge hotel with 3 restaurants to choose for breakfast plan, I recommend you go with breakfast at this property. The location close to all the shopping, restaurants and night life

Nice, large hotel near the Skinjuku station. This is a busy convention-type hotel located across the street from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. (Tip: The government building has two free observation decks with great views of Tokyo.)The hotel has a non-smoking tower, so all rooms in that tower are smoke-free. There are several dining options located in the hotel, which are crowded. Highly recommend making reservations if you are interested in a specific cuisine. Hotel service is professional and helpful, rooms are clean.

I’ll start with the positives.The hotel was very tall and had a nice view. Also the personnel are very polite and helpful.Unfortunately the hotel is starting to get old. And it should be upgraded technology wise. We lived in a 3 star hotel close to Tokyo central which was better and more modern I think.

Here for two nights at the start of our Japan tour, very clean, friendly staff and the location is central for all major sights, good size rooms, comfy bed and good sized bathroom, we were on a breakfast package and it was a buffet with lots of choice western and asian, drinks and food in the hotel restaurants bit pricey, we went out for takeaway style and local beer, always find its better to mix with the local people rather than the cold business atmosphere you get in high star hotels, would recommend this hotel especially for its location

Great hotel in Shinjuku. Pleasant staff, exceptional rooms and good location. The beds are a good size compared to some hotels in Japan, recently renovated too.Breakfast buffet is also good, covering both Western & Japanese cuisine.Would stay here again!

Stayed here for 4 nights in a Double Superior and room size was pretty good for Japan. We had Breakfast included in our rate and there was 3 restaurants you can pick from - we liked the glass court the best. Hotel and staff are very friendly and loved our little 19 month old. Housekeepers were Great too!Good location it's in the quiet part of Shinjuku , but lots of places to eat outside the hotel. Only about 5-10min to the station.Pool was closed as it only operates in Summer season. Would definitely recommend staying here.

Right in the heart of the city. This hotel was beautiful and very clean. The staff was very kind and professional. The gym was nice and the hotel had anything you could need. It was close to the train restaurant and local shopping. I will definitely look to stay here again.

What an amazing country Japan is; history, culture, food, old world and ultra modern. We loved everywhere we visited, caught the cherry blossom, the Takayama spring festival, a clear perfect view of mt Fuji, wore full kimono and tried on some Samurai armour! We loved the surprisingly quiet and calm cities, the gardens. The island of Miyajima stopping overnight in a traditional ryokan hotel surrounded by beautiful forest with deer wandering by, wearing traditional clothing to dinner and sleeping on futon on tatami flooring, enclosed by decorated rice paper sliding doors is the most unique and unforgettable experience.Loved it.The Keio Plaza Hotel was the first hotel we stayed in in Tokyo. Lovely rooms and a fabulous first night dinner at the kagari restaurant in the hotel, serving a delicious Japanese meal with; sushi, tempura, sukiyaki and various elements, all served gracefully in a very smart traditional style restaurant. Just the perfect start to a wonderful experience.

The hotel is perfect to visit Tokyo: location is at a walking distance from Shijuku JR station, one of the main Tokyo trasportation hubs. Rooms are perfectly sized, will all the amenities you may desire, including a room dedicated mobile, with free internet access and local calls. Excellent breakfast: its practically impossible dont find what you like, either continental or Japanise. Around Shinjuku station, lot of restaurants for your dinner. Rooms cost not negligible but good bargain for Tokyo and the service provided. If you like, there is a luggage delivery service: you may send your luggage to the next destination in Japan, for a convenient cost: very useful if you plan to use JR pass, since difficult to travel with big trolley/bags on JR fast trains.

I used to love staying at Keio Plaza hotel every time I visited Tokyo because of the convenience location and that they have airport shuttle bus to and from Haneda airport. My hubby and I stayed 4 nights. The night before check out....we wanted to ask the receptionist for late check out till 11.30am as we knew their check out time is 11am. The lady receptionist was very rude telling us off that if you pay, you can have late check out, no pay no late check out. I have felt that some of their young Receptionists at check in counters are quite rude and they do not know what customer services is all about!!!!!. Well , maybe during our stays it wasn’t our lucks then meeting rude remarked staffs. The bell boys and girls are very good except for the Receptionists
user_name:
GohPauline1200
Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei Darussalam

review_body: This hotel is a huge and comfortable five stars hotel. It's located at the heart of Shinjuku area. You can find plenty of restaurants and minimarts nearby. Staffs were great and helpful. We stayed 2 type of rooms for our trip, the main wing with renovated room was really nice, modern and functional. The old room (right wing from lobby) need a major renovation but overall is fine and comfortable. Overall of this hotel is great and probably the best hotel in Shinjuku area.

Great hotel in a great location, with the best staff Nice clean and big rooms.Super service minded and helpful staff.Bell captain is the best and most helpfully I ever meet.Close to every thing you want, and easy access to airports and metro.Nice calm area packed with superb eating places in all categories Will be back in 3 weeks.Recomended and will return.

We stayed here for three nights and right from being dropped off from our transport the service was amazing.We felt like we were the only guests and we were extremely important to all the staff. The porters helped us to our room pointing out all emergency features,they then set up the internet on our devices. Before they left they helped us all to put on our slippers. Toiletries were enough that you could have come without any of your own and they are replenished daily. Jurin for breakfast was a little expensive but you could not fault the service or the excellent food. This motel is ideally positioned a short 700 m walk to the main Shinjuku Station and shopping precincts. We must compliment the Management and their staff for making our visit to Tokyo amazing

My wife and I recently visited Tokyo, staying for 10 days at this Hotel. It was a good choice. The proximity to 2 close railway stations made transport quite accessible; yet the hotel is located slightly outside the hectic streets of Shinjuku - offering a quiet relief at the end of a busy day. Highly recommended.

Ok, I have to say, I lucked-up in finding this place out of the thousands of hotels in Tokyo. Shinjuku is an awesome area, with awesome food, and a great nightlife. Keio Plaza is just a few minutes walk to the Shinjuku train station which easily connects you to any part of Tokyo or the rest of Japan.We had a Deluxe King on the 36th floor, main tower, with Luxe lounge access. The room was a perfect size, extremely clean, and had just the right amenities. The bathroom had every kind of toiletry you could imagine, including an awesome bidet toilet seat. The desk area included a Nespresso machine, hot water kettle, and even a power strip with multiple power adapters! They thought of everything! The bed sheets were extremely soft although the bed was a bit firm. I still slept well though.The property has several restaurants, a convenience store, and other shopping on the lower levels. It took me a bit to figure out coffee is sold hot, in cans, in the convenience store but it tasted great. The Luxe Lounge in the south tower was nice, quiet, and had great amenities as well. I never went for happy hour but stopped by earlier in the day for snacks and a great view of the city.The staff: Ok, you will not find a more pleasant and hospitable staff anywhere in the world. I think this is an aspect of Japanese culture but the staff at Keio Plaza were outstanding!! We were treated like royalty, by the front desk, housekeeping, and the lounge staff. The staff really helped make our trip very memorable.Keio Plaza has it all - Location, Staff, Comfortable Rooms, and great prices.

I hadn't read reviews of this hotel, but had gone with its overall rating. The reviews MUST have mentioned all the tour groups staying there which, of course, meant a crowded lobby, queues for breakfast and an overall feeling of impersonality. Yes, staff members were always civil, but not one was actually FRIENDLY, so we were not made to feel particularly welcome.Our plaza luxe room was large and comfortable, but had no artwork on the walls, again leading to a feeling of impersonality. There seemed to be a wifi problem: my phone wouldn't hook up at all and my wife's emails from there weren't received until we changed hotels; however, our iPad was fine.We had access to the Plaza Lounge - like our room, in the south tower, NOT the main tower where the good lounge and best rooms are - where the drinks for the 2-hour bar time were fine but the food disappointing. On one of our 3 visits, EVERY canape contained fish - to which my wife is HIGHLY allergic. To the staff's credit, they did find a few non-fishy ones for her, but it should not have been necessary.The hotel is, however, only about a 10-minute walk from Shinjuku station. We stayed in the area, in fact, because the next train we were using left from there AND it is on the direct line from Narita Airport. There are SO many restaurants and cafes around that you're spoilt for choice, so it's a great nightlife spot.So, if you LIKE tour groups, or are in one, certainly stay here, as you'll feel at home. We don't, and weren't, and didn't.

Pretty well situated in Shinjuku , about 5 mins walk to Shinjuku Station. Its in a quiet area with shops nearby. Hotel is clean and functional. Rooms are quite well spaced in comparision to other hotels around Tokyo. House keeping is very meticulous so clean rooms etc. Restaurants are quite pricey. Check-in is pretty slow because the hotel has high occupancy judging by the numbers of people seen at check-in.

We were looking forward to staying in a five star hotel for a night but were very disappointed with the old fashioned decor and the lack of amenities in the room. No robes in the room and very basic toiletries. Bathroom was extremely small with no storage space for toilet bags etc. A good location next to shinjuku station but nevertheless we were disappointed with the lack of any sort of luxury.

We arrived early from overnight flight. Was hoping for early check-in as the hotel lobby was busy with people checking out constantly. We eventually got a room at 1pm. Waited for 6 hours. People sat around hotel waiting to check-in. Booked superior room. Good size for Japan. Slightly tired looking room but fine. Beds and pillows really comfortable. Convenience store in hotel has everything you need at good prices. Lots of restaurants although we never bothered because a 2 minute walk from hotel and you’re in the middle of everything. Great location. Quiet rooms.You can get a shuttle bus from HANEDA airport direct to hotel every half hour or so for around $11.We stayed 1 extra night in a deluxe room. These rooms are small. If you want a cup of tea in the morning in a deluxe room, be prepared to pay around $12. In the superior room you get tea free. Deluxe room no tea. Strange. Cheap room service, e.g. 4 croissants and 2 toast with jams and butter $16ish. (Which makes $12 for 1 tea odd)!Overall, bit pricey for what you get ($400AU) per night but it is what it is. Friendly staff.

We spent 4 nights at the Keio Plaza. The room was small but very clean. The breakfasts were excellent with a choice of Japanese or Western food. The staff were very friendly and helpful. The hotel is situated in a good position for both the train and the metro. Highly recommend the hotel.

Good views across city, if at front of hotel and high enough can see Mt. Fuji in distance. Excellent buffet breakfast. Perfect location to walk to gai district and discover hundreds of bars and restaurants. TAKE A MAP!!!! Observation platforms (free) in government building opposite. Local park with shrine worth a visit .. 5 mins. away.

We recently stayed in a new Club Floor Premier Grand room. Wow. Spacious with style and a great view. Separate toilet, separate shower with bath that had a glass panel you view the view whilst showering. Crisp, clean and comfortable beds. We were on the 41st floor with a view of the Government Offices - which you can visit for a great view of Tokyo - free. The Hotel was fully booked but check in was quick. For such a big hotel, the lifts for these floors were always available with no waiting. Access to the Club Floor as part of the package was excellent. Breakfast on the 45th floor with a view of the park was nice. Delicious food and drinks were available throughout the day. The subway is close and the Shinjuku station is about an 8 minute walk. Lots of nice eateries close to the hotel. We had our clothes laundered by the hotel - exceptional service. We ate one night at the Yamanami Teppan Yaki restaurant - exceptional. Sunrise Tours leave from Keio Plaza, so it is convenient pick up venue. We took the Mt Fuji and Hakone tour. We got luxury in a great location. Highly recommend.

The hotel’s location is convenient. Sunrise Tours desk within the hotel made it easier to join Mount Fuji tour straight from the hotel. Also it is a Disney partnered hotel. So we go free accommodation to and from the hotel in a comfortable bus.

The Keio Plaza hotel is a large skyscraper hotel near Shinjuko Station and the lovely Shinkuko Gyoen National Garden. The rooms are spacious and comfortable and have coffee making facilities. However the café downstairs that serves Western breakfasts is expensive ($40 each) and our hot buffet was stone cold on cold plates. We complained and were given a full refund - credit to the restaurant manager. Other than that no complaints. There are lots of shops nearby towards the station including a 7-11 that does sandwiches.

Lovely clean modern hotel with good views from the top (47th) floor but sadly only in one direction. However, you can walk across the road to the Government buildings and go to the much higher Observation Towers, which are completely free to visit, for a great panoramic view.The loos in the rooms are very high tech with a degree in IT needed to operate them !We felt that there was not enough restaurant space to cope with breakfast for all the residents as each morning we had to queue to get in. The buffet breakfast was pretty good as was the set evening meal.

We chose Keio Plaza because the day tours we were booking started from this destination (Sunrise Tours). It is a lovely big hotel, and the staff are friendly and hospitable. We had a room on the 20th floor, and could see the Tokyo Metropolitan Gov. Buildings. It is in a great location- right next to Tochomae Station and Shinjuku Chou Park. We went to the Metropolitan Gov. Buildings observation deck three times during our stay for great views of Tokyo at different times during the day. 7/11 is close by for quick breakfasts and snacks but there is also a small convenience store in the basement. We found a laundromat Excel 2 close by. We splurged a little staying at Keio Plaza, but enjoyed our stay.

Our family of four had two rooms on L20 of the Keio Plaza Hotel. The rooms were fairly compact but quite adequate for our needs. The hotel is on the 'office' side of Shinjuku - right opposite the soaring Government Offices (which have free viewing levels on the top of both their north and south towers). It's about a 7 minute walk from Shinjuku station. There is also a subway station (Toca-mae) about two minutes walk. We found getting around easy - enough signs in English and staff happy to help out.There are numerous eateries nearby especially towards the station and on the other side of the rail line in an area called Kabuki-cho-neon. I think this means the 'Neon Light District' - it's certainly terrific at night with those neon lights blazing and huge screensWe didn't have the buffet breakfast - instead heading to a nearby bakery for delicious goodies each morning. One evening, my wife and I went to the Hotel's Saki Bar. This was awesome. We were the only people there. The drinks waiter took so much time to explain the various types of Saki - we had a sparkling then a chilled and finally a warm Saki. Each so different - the food accompaniments were also great. On our final day we had the High Tea on L45 of the Hotel. The views are great and High Tea is terrific. Unlike many others we've been to, you can try numerous different types of tea during your three hour visit. The food on the trays was excellent and varied. Highly recommend this as a treat and also recommend that you book - esp if you want to get a table at the window.Another useful service is the bus service to Haneka International Airport. The bus starts at the hotel and takes about an hour to get to the airport. Make sure you book a seat on the bus at the time you require as some services get booked out.

Nice hotel, great location. Tochomae station is right next to the hotel. Shinjuku station is up just a few blocks. We weren’t able to reserve, but the buffet restaurant in Keio is apparently very popular and one of the best rated. Gets booked quickly, so make reservations. Rooms were average size to America which was nice. 711 located inside the hotel on the lower level and a few other restaurants so very convenient.

We are very grateful to the front staff Miss Miyaka for her kind assistance in changing our reservation. We live in Canada for a few years now and have forgotten that in some country there are still smoking rooms and non smoking rooms in the hotel. We booked through Expedia and didn't pay attention and ended up booking a smoking room. We only discovered it while in the train station upon arrival in Tokyo from Osaka. On checking in, we pleaded with Miss Miyaka to give us a non smoking room. It was around the Easter period with the start of the Cherry Bossom season and the hotel was fully booked. She did her very best and eventually got us a non smoking room. We were really grateful. I have asthma and will not be able to tolerate a smoking room and we would have to look for another hotel etc.The location is very convenient and close to the station. We took the Ghibli studio bus tour which pick us up from Keio Plaza hotel. There are many restaurants in the hotel and we tried the Kaiseki meal at one of the restaurant.The hotel complex is huge so ask for the direction. The back entrance is very close to the train station. But we didn't know and came in through the other entrance and a roundabout way!The room was pretty standard, clean and functional. We were out a lot and mostly back just to sleep. I comment their customer service and will stay again in future.

The hotel is surrounded by commercial buildings in Shinjuku. The streets nearby the hotel are quiet at night but it takes only 5-minute-walk to the station and the shopping area. Due to the long queue, we didn't try the hotel breakfast and we went to the cafes nearby like Tully's Coffee or McDonald. This is the my time to have newspaper everyday from a hotel. The service is caring. There are staffs staying at the entrance helping the guest to take the luggage and helping the guest to deliver the luggage to the room after check-in.There was 3 people including me staying here for 6 nights. We have enough space to pack 3 big baggage at the same time. According to the internet photos, our room was originally a double room so it would be more spacious if there were only 2 people. The room was cleaned very well. There is a handy in room but we didn't need it. However, I believed it really helps some of the guest. Only one thing was disappointing was some our thing was cleaned away after room cleaning. We brought our own comb. We thought that they would only clean the rubbish in the rubbish bin so we didn't put back the comb and only put it on the table. And we found that they cleaned it away. We can only say that their staff clean the room completely. HAHA

Rooms are very good, but location is quite a walk from the shinjuku station and the main shopping area. Good neighbor bus to Disneyland is a plus point. Lobby area is big but a bit boring. Hopefully they can provide shuttle services to the shinjuku station (for people with big luggages like me)

We stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel for 4 nights and would highly recommend. The rooms were a great size, staff were very helpful and the buffet breakfast in the Jurin restaurant was great. The location is fantastic, a 6-8 min walk from Shinjuku station and all the shops

First of all I would like to stress that the majority of staff at this hotel are all quite helpful, however there are other areas that need improvement.The most glaring to me is their check in. We arrived at the hotel around 11am, we fully understood that we could not get in the room until after 2pm, however we thought we could at least go through the check in process of passport/credit card details to save time later as we were tired and wanted to get into the room as soon as possible. But no this was not allowed we would have to come back at 2 although they could hold our bags, so after lunch we were there right on 2pm. Unfortunately so was everyone else, with a queue snaking around the length of the front desk we finally were given our passes at 2.45 and were told our bags would arrive shortly. One hour later they were still not there so I went down to the baggage storage and they were brought up immediately.The room was ok although what was annoying to us was that for 3 of us, my wife, myself and son, they would not give us a double room with roll away, they had to give us 3 single beds !. Apparently this is what happens when 3 are in the room at the Keio Plaza. I also get that many Japanese people prefer harder beds but one of our beds was like trying to sleep on concrete, really uncomfortable and not a great nights sleep was had. Otherwise the room was basic but well kept.We used Lumine and Glass Court restaurants on the lower level and the Aurora sky lounge, all were very nice particularly Lumine.The Keio Plaza is obviously a hotel for groups, so there were big numbers and tour groups continually walking around the very busy lobby area. With the large numbers it certainly takes away from the sophistication of a initially polished looking hotel.Position wise it is perfectly located to Shinjuku and other restaurants. It is approx 8-10 minutes walk from the metropolis of Shinjuku station and no more than 5 minutes from Tochomae station.All up a good hotel but to me lacks a wow factor and one that I would recommend more for groups than families.

very unprofessional handle guest complain especially Mr chino and Mr Miyazaki. not listen to client demand and not find the solution for client. not helpful my bad experience with mice 5 star hotel. I am a group organizer stay here almost 5 groups and not happy they assign my group to have dinner at banquet room without telling. I ask to give more choice either normal restaurant or banquet but they insist this is final cannot do anything. Recommend to stay in other hotel chains not the local if look for working with professional staffs.

We stayed for 5 nights in a double room. Size of room was decent, enough room to unpack bags and still have room to move about. Bed was very comfortable and free wifi worked well. Free shuttle bus to and from Disneyland/DisneySea was really great. Only downside is that check in took a very long time, upwards of 30 minutes. We arrived after the check in time yet our room still wasn’t ready. The lobby was constantly busy too. But overall it was a comfortable stay, good location near the train station.

This hotel is hard to review.To begin, they provided a restricted cell phone in our room which we could take on our excursions into the city. The geographic map service with associated directions was well used. One could make calls back to several countries, including the States with it.Most of the other hotel services were what would be expected from a high priced hotel.HOWEVER - the food service was horrible. We arrived in the early evening local time after a 24hr trip. Exhausted we wanted a quick bite to eat. The only thing that the hotel customer service desk would offer was "we have several good restaurants in the hotel". Even the least "upscale" of them was more than we were prepared to deal with. Fortunately we found a convenience store in the hotel which had prepackaged sandwiches which hit the spot. Customer service had not mentioned it to us, Fortunately we encountered another guest who had had the same lack of service a couple of days previously who told us about it.Secondly, breakfast was included with our room, and they did have 3 different breakfast buffet restaurants. However the lines were out of the restaurant and down the halls - about 30 minutes waiting for each one. This happened every day we were there. I would expect a luxury hotel such as this one to be able to deal with such regular crowds.All in all this hotel did NOT meet the all the expectations of a luxury hotel.

One of choice in Shinjuku area! The Hotel has very large lobby are and nice decoration. Room’s size is also ok if compare to others. I would love to recommend to others for their’s visit in Shinjuku area.

This is a well-established with 1,000+ rooms hotel.Good location. Short 5-10 min walk from Shinjuku station West exit.The room is in good size with 3 single bed, clean & neat.Plus point: Airport limousine service stop right at the hotel & complimentary shuttle bus service directly to Tokyo Disneyland and DisneySea. (Advance booking)

We were part of “Great Rail Journeys / Travelmarvel tour group and found the location, Breakfast, and Service to be 100%. Close to Metropolitan Govt Building which has great views of Tokyo and Shinjuku Gyeon Gardens with fabulous Cherry Blossom.

This is my fifth or sixth stay at Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku, Tokyo.The Keio never fails to impress with its immaculate grounds and lobby, everything shines. Staff is multi-lingual and very friendly to boot, so don't be afraid if your Japanese is poor or nonexistent.We stayed in the renovated rooms on the 31st floor. Large firm King bed, great pillows, small fridge, kettle, TV, and in tradition with Japanese culture - impeccably clean and well-maintained comfort. The Keio is located about three blocks from the JR Shinjuku station and about 10 minutes to Keio Department store. Takashimaya Times Square is about 15 minutes away. Airport Limousine stops at hotel. Very convenient!The Keio is a great deal if you book on their website in advance, it costs like a 3 star but feels closer to a 5. Great for first time visitors or old hacks ;) I love the Keio!

This is a really good location in Tokyo. Convenient to subway train and walking distance to popular sites and architecture. Easy Walk to Memory Lan (Piss Alley) and to KabukiCho among other popular areas. View of the Cocoon Building and Government Biulding. Excellent restaurants and breakfast at Glass House Cafe.
Spacious, clean and modern roomsExcellent locationExcellent service at reception Western or Japanese breakfastsSometimes there are long lines at the entrance to the dining roomGood value for money

Pretty old hotel and bad service. I have chosen this hotel to stay for 10 years but now I have really disappointed with the hotel. Today I informed the staff at front that the window of my room (2024) main wing is very noisy because of the windy. It made me couldn't sleep wholen last night. I think it's because window's rubber seal is too old and not fit to the window. So, when it got windy, the window had been shaking and made noise. When I informed to staff at front, there was no apologize from him and he just said it may be happened in every rooms. I really disappointed with his answer. So, please avoid this hotel as possible as you can.

The location for this hotel could not be better. It is close to the station and also many eating places. The rooms are a fair size and have all the facilities you need. We spent two nights here. The first day we had breakfast in the main restaurant which was very good. The next day we had breakfast on the 45th floor which had excellent views.
