There was a choice of both western and Japanese food. The staff were all very helpful. If you stay at this hotel be sure to go over the road to the observation decks in the government building and also the park. The only down side to our stay was that we arrived at lunchtime after a 12 hour flight and 8 hour time difference to be told that we could not check in and must wait until 4.00pm. This hotel has very strict check in times.

Spent 3 nights here at the start of an organised tour of Japan. This is by far the largest hotel we have ever stayed at and the lobby is like a major train station in the morning with all the tour groups gathering. Room was very pleasant and well equipped although beds were definitely on the firm side. Hotel shops are good and plenty of choice of restaurants albeit somewhat expensive but this is easily avoided with the plethora of local eateries just around the corner. The one failing was organisation at breakfast where a 20 minute wait was as much about their ability to quickly clear and relay tables as it was the number of people choosing to eat at 7 am.

The hotel is huge and the rooms are very small, but comfortable. excellent location: opposite the Tokyo municipality which has great and free observatory (a must). short walk to Shinjuku park (a must) and Shinjuku center. Shinjuku metro station near the hotel. Great place as a base to explore Tokyo area. large que for breakfast, but the breakfast is excellent

Stayed here for four nights with my two teenage sons. This hotel is huge so there are lots of people in the lobby most of the time. Tour groups leave from here which is handy if you are on these tours just be sure to check where to check in for your tour as we were waiting in the wrong place until we asked. Service is professional but not above and beyond in that no information or maps etc. were offered. The room was a good size and well cleaned. There was a complimentary smart phone but with our pocket wifi we didn't use it (highly recommend the pocket wifi for Japan as there is not much wifi available). The toiletries were disappointing, just really basic. The shower was okay but not great. The beds were comfy which we appreciated later after we'd experienced just how hard Japanese beds can be! The area is clean and beautiful which we found relaxing. Just across the road from the Shinjuku station exit is a lovely area with restaurants and waterfalls and tables and chairs outside, even music playing! We ate here at Starbucks, Freshness burger and Sizzler which was so handy. The Tokyo government building is next door with the towers free to go up and volunteer guides to tell you all about what you can see from up there. There is a cafe up the south tower where we had lunch, quite tasty and options for picky eaters. When we were there the north tower had a toy shop which was a great place to pick up cute souvenirs. Shinjuku station is an easy walk and links you to anywhere you want to go in Tokyo especially with a prepaid card like Pasmo which makes it easy. The convince store inside Keio has a cash machine that takes foreign cards which was super handy. We never ate at the restaurants in Keio as they were very expensive but there is plenty nearby as I've mentioned. Great location and comfortable hotel but unless you pay more for premier floor etc. it is not luxurious.

I did stay at keio 3 times. The last stay was the worst experience. One good thing about the hotel is that the location is great, in Shinjuku, close to the trains station walking distance to restaurants, bars, shops. They have good restaurants and bars (the one on the top of the hotel is particularly impressive) but they are quite expensive. Not a problem since you could walk to an area with a lot of places to eat/ drink. Front desk is quite strange- they really don't care about you. I know that they are a huge hotel but still they are processing you in a very mechanical way, no interest for your issues. Very strange. I tried to communicate with them but they made very clear to me that they don't care about what I want. There are 2 types of rooms: "'old" ones and the "new"ones (redone recently). The old ones have old furniture and they really look used. The rooms are very clean. Breakfast is good and you could choose 3 restaurants that offer this service.Since is a quite expensive hotel I believe that the value for money is really not there. On the other hand Tokyo is a great city and the people are very nice.
user_name:
Emilian131973
New York City, New York

review_body: Had a great stay in this hotel. Room looked like it had recently had a new makeover. We stayed in the premier grand area. (Executive lounge). Very well done with excellent food. Breakfast was western style but you can also order a Japanese breakfast. Super busy hotel in the lobby. Lots of tourists.

I have travelled worldwide and have never been in a hotel who could not manage to have you stay in one room. This hotel let’s me move to 3 rooms in a 5 night stay than when I come back and stay 9 nights I also need to move to 3 different rooms again. Never in my life have I experienced this. This means that this hotel cannot properly manage its rooms and has no proper Systeem to do this. This is very customer unfriendly and shows that this hotel is not flexible. For the first 5 days I have no option. The next part of my stay I will need to find another hotel because this is not acceptable and is just bad management.

From the time we got out of our taxi to the time we left the hotel,we were always impressed by the welcoming professionalism of the staff. Everything else went perfectly well. The rooms are spacious , clean, well lit and beautiful. We had everything we needed in the room and in the bathroom. For breakfast we had different choices and the food was as good as was the friendly and smiling faces of the staff. The location of the hotel was so practical as it is so close to the center of the city and not so far from transportation stations.

A great location in Shinjuku, although it is on the quieter side of Shinjuku near the government offices. Another plus is that it has the airport limousine shuttle which is very convenient. If you are like me, do not want to drag/carry your luggages through Tokyo's multiple stairs to get on the Narita express or train to Haneda. The concierge even helps with the arranging for the luggage to be loaded on the bus. A bit pricey but you definitely get what you paid for in terms of service, bigger and better rooms. Love it, and will definitely come back to this wonderful hotel in Dec trip.If you are taking the train and in Shinjuku main JR station, aim towards the south side of the Shinjuku station (south bus terminal ara) and look for exit B1. It is also conveniently located near Tochomae station. A bit further is an 8 mins walk to JR Yamanote Line (circle train line).

Could find no faults - most helpful staff, rooms were spacious, amenities were plentiful and varied in the rooms. Ate in hotel one evening which was fine and the other night in Sizzlers restaurant in an adjacent complex which was very good and reasonable.
user_name:
Gordon and Step... T
York, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo in June 2017 for 5 days. The hotel is conveniently located in the center of a busy financial district with many restaurants in the surrounding area. It is a walking distance to the train/subway stations. We took the bus from the airport and it dropped us off in front of the hotel. There is a free bus transportation from the hotel to Disneyland and back. We choose this hotel because it is a beautiful hotel with an easy access to local transportation.

We stayed here for 4 nights with our children aged 7 and 9 and had a great experience. We had a luxury forth room. There was so much space, it was great. The amenities provided were superb, we were given water every day and the room was spotless! We found the breakfast excellent and everyone tucked in happily to the huge range available in the glass house. We missed this breakfast when we moved to other places on our trip! The hotel is conveniently located a short walk from the station and getting around was easy. I would definitely recommend this hotel to families. The only downside was a limited amount of space to store clothes for the 4 of us so we were living out of our cases a bit. However, this was a small price to pay and didn’t affect our enjoyment at all.

The Keio Plaza is only a few minutes covered walk away from the West exit of Shinjuku station. It is 45 floor tall and a magnificent bar tops it all. Here you get what you pay for. The basic rooms are nice, but rather congested; the luxury rooms with restricted access are a lovely way to stay in Tokyo. Breakfast is served at three separate and independent restaurants. We used the excellent Jurin. If you don´t include breakfast when booking rooms, the breakfast comes at Y 2 700.
user_name:
thauken
Puerto de la Cruz, Spain

review_body: We were booked here for one night by our travel agent who assured us it was a quiet location away from the crowds and busyness of Shinjuku. And they were right, the hotel is on a quiet lovely tree lined street about 5 mins from Shinjuku station. However, the hotel seems to cater to LOTs of very large tour groups which creates extremely long lines and some chaos at check in, buffet breakfast, the public bathrooms and the bell captain's desk. The lobby is oddly set up in 2 rows of straight backed chairs; so waiting for service is also not particularly pleasant. The staff try their best, but are clearly overwhelmed with the masses of guests who all show up about the same time.Breakfast was nicely presented, well flavored and plentiful; although again v. crowded. The restaurants in the hotel are v. high priced so walk to the Shinjuku area for reasonably priced meals. Rooms are comfortable, great views, and well apppointed although the carpets are bit tired and worn.If you get an amazing rate, go for it. But if you are splurging try somewhere else.

The Keio Plaza is located a brief walk from the Shinjuku train station so it’s very convenient. Our corner king room was very spacious & nicely appointed with bath amenities. Breakfast is almost exclusively buffett style. The food is ok, while the coffee may be the best I had in Tokyo as it is quite strong. FYI - quite a few large tour groups come through so the lobby can become very crowded, while the line for breakfast can get long. However, if the breakfast queue gets too long, the hotel opens an overflow buffet upstairs, admittedly with fewer selections.

It's very big we got on club lounge suite it was excellent. If you don't get club rooms it's crowded expect to line-up for breakfast. Massive crowds for tour groups. Buy a great place to see Tokyo. If you need electronic stuff it's the place to be. Great eateries too. Everyone goes out of the way to help you. Love the city and love the people. Trip #2 it gets better everytime.

Friendly staff. Large hotel. Tokyo is definitely a faster pace than Kyoto. Close to shopping, restaurants and Shinjuku Station. From Shinjuku Station you can connect to anywhere in Tokyo. Decent breakfast buffet.
user_name:
Ron N
Sacramento, California, United States

review_body: Service here is worthy of a veteran in the hotel scene in Tokyo. Room has view of Mount Fuji on clear days and near many shopping centers and restaurants. Airport limo stops right at the hotel for convenience

We stayed in double and triple rooms. Both were very comfortable good size very clean with everything you need in the room. Walking distance to Shinjuku station shopping and restaurants. Take into consideration that this is very big hotel. The guest center is very helpful. If you looking to relax in a 5 star room after a long day - this is for you.

Amazing location, walking distance to everything. Few minute walk to Shinjuku Station where you can go anywhere. Very clean and reasonable rooms for the price. Staff was very accommodating and friendly. HIGHLY Recommend staying here! We love Tokyo very much and will definitely stay here again.

Good hotel. Stayed South tower. Clean. Comfortable beds. Room size OK. Great location re Shinjuku station. Lots of places to eat within 5 mins walk as well as 7.11, pharmacy, etc. Mini mart in hotel for basic essentials. Ate breakfast and dinner at different place outside hotel each day after first day. Much cheaper than hotel and food was good quality. Hotel dinner on level 2 good but far too pricey and breakfast average and 3 times price of outside cafe. Only other issue is waiting for lifts from 730 to 9 in the morning. Would definitely stay again.

We book Premier twin room at 41th floor, and there have a premier grand lounge that provide breakfast, lunch, tea set and Bar time. So I call this is a surprise. I guess the hotel was redecorated , and offer some Premier grand rooms for travelers. We checked in at 45th floor and then down to 41th . I think we can saw Fuji Mt if we were arrange on another side in which is the opposite of government office.

We stayed at this hotel on our last day in Japan. On the one hand, it is a giant hotel with many business customers. On the other hand the little touch in every detail really touched me, which is something most hotels of similar price range in US cannot compete. From the toiletry items in the bathroom, to the cell phone rest near the bed, I can see how they actually think about the travelers' need when they design the place. There are many restaurants and a bakery downstair that offer great selection of food if you do not want to go out. Across the street, there is also a plaza full of restaurants and a Starbucks. From here, we walked to Shinjuku Station, Keio department store, and Shinjuku Gyoen. Definitely a great place to stay when you visit Shinjuku.

I stayed in Keio Plaza in October 2017 and March 2018. I stayed in Southern Tower in October which I was not impressed, either the room or the services.This time in March I booked a renovated room which located in Main Tower, that is a lot better. The room was a lot bigger and spacious (I stayed at 25/F). Location wise, the hotel is perfect. It is close to all lines of trains; it's also the dropping off and picking up point of limousine bus to and from Narita airport. It is just next to the streets full of restaurants and bars; and department stores. It is also close to the gathering point of local trips; and also shuttle bus station to outlet.There is a gym in the hotel which is free to use. Not bad.The breakfast in Glass Court is good but the line for it is always long.There's a convenient store inside the hotel too. Can pick up a cup noodle after mid night if you are really hungry.For convenience I think I will choose this hotel again.

This hotel is a good option if staying in Tokyo. It is within easy distance of Shinjuku station via an underground subway which even has a moving walkway. There are numerous restaurants in the immediate vicinity and the hotel itself has a number of options for good quality food. Our only complaint was that the bed was very hard. We asked others about that and it seemed we were the only ones with this problem. When we complained about it the bed was remade with soft underplays which solved the issue. The room was otherwise very clean and comfortable. Staff were extremely attentive and we can really recommend the Alice in Wonderland High Tea-delightful!! All up it was a good stay!

This is a very nice hotel but it takes some getting used to finding your way around the lobby and shopping/restaurant area on dif rent levels.. It is sutuated in a good location with shops and restaurants within walking distance. Rooms were clean and comfortable with large bathroom with all the toiletries. Beds were a little too hard for my liking

My partner and I stayed on the 29th floor of Keio Plaza Hotel for 5 nights. The room was newly renovated, and for Tokyo, fairly spacious. The bathroom had a lovely soaker tub.The hotel staff were friendly, knowledgeable and fluent in English. They helped us to plan our stay, including a trip to Tokyo Disney via the free shuttle from the hotel.The hotel is located a short distance from a major train line, and a stone’s throw from the core of Shinjuku. In terms of negatives, the elevators at the hotel are a bit slow and sometimes too packed to board. There’s no in-room coffee maker - only a kettle and coffee filled filters which made for some pretty terrible coffee. (That said, Starbucks is a 3-4 minute walk from the hotel.) The TV only had a few English channels (mostly news), but this suited us just fine as we are news junkies and we didn’t spend too much time at the hotel anyway.Overall, we were very happy with our stay and would highly recommend the hotel to others.

Stayed there for 4 nights. Room is tired and expensive for what they provide. Cons:1. The shower head can’t be stabilized as the holder has lost its grip and kept slipping down the bar. 2. There’s only green tea making sachets, no coffee or tea. 3. They did not clear the used mugs daily leaving it there even though they replaced with clean new ones. 4. Pillows are too soft, not comfortable. 5. Tv remote to change the channels up or down didn’t work. 6. Shampoos, conditioners and bath gel came in tiny little bottles meant for one use. Pros:Location is good. If you use a tunnel fr level 2 of hotel, it’s a 7 min walk to Shinjuku JR/Subway Station. If you walked in the open from the front lobby, it’s 5 min walk. Lots of eateries and convenient stores around. Keio Mall where the stations are in the basement is just two streets away. Hotel/airport transfer stops right in front of lobby. You just have to reserve your seat and confirm the time to depart at the bus limousine counter a day before.

The hotel is in a very nice and quiet location in Shinjuku, with many good dining and shopping options within a 10-15 minute walk. While there is a subway entrance right beside this hotel, you may need to explore other options for taking the train to and from the airport if you ave a lot of luggage, since the entry with immediate access does not have lifts and has elevators that move in only one direction. The Airport Limousine Bus from both Narita and Haneda is an option, it stops exactly at this hotel.Checking in was easy and efficient. The hotel is one of Tokyo Disney Resort's Good Neighbor Hotels, so they have a free shuttle service to and from both Disney parks. Do note that you have to reserve your slot in advance, and the trip takes under an hour.The room was simple and larger than most other hotels I've seen in Shinjuku. Housekeeping was okay, and if you need anything even during odd hours, they are usually at your door within 2-3 minutes after your call. The free Wi-Fi was strong, although having to log in daily is a bit inconvenient.The checkout process was also easy, although trying to call for baggage assistance about an hour before our airport transfer was an exercise in futility.On the whole, it was a good stay. No major complaints, but nothing to give high praise about, either.

We chose to stay in this well reviewed hotel because of the Club Lounge and supposed location. Pros: good staff and an early check in. Room a good size for Japan with great views of the city from the 30th floor. Very clean, plenty of hanging space. Good Guest Relations desk with excellent staff with good English.Cons: Club Lounge was small (there's another one on the 45th floor for higher grade rooms - not clear on the hotel website). Only one western-style restaurant with good value meals. Hotel at least 10 minutes walk to any shops, train station etc. Canapes in Club Lounge very disappointing - way lower standard (and choice) than many other lounges we've stayed in. Plenty of booze on offer. Room is small - only holds around 40 people. We would definitely stay here again though.

Per the title. Couldn't check in a nanosecond before 2pm. Was 'upgraded' but not sure what that meant since the desk was Dusty, there were dried waterstains in the bathroom, hair on the scale. I guess without the upgrade we would have been handed a mop? Our room maid was excellent...interestingly, having spent a lot of time in Asia, I'm surprised at how weak the English language skills are in Japan ( and this hotel) as contrasted to much of the rest of Asia/ Southeast Asia. Hotel was ok...Tempura restaurant was VERY, very good but too pricey to consider it a good vakue.

Two seperate stays of 3 nights then one night in a Luxe level room.Check InI arrived early due to flight times. I was not expecting to be granted an early check in, but I was hoping it could occur. Unfortunately I was dealing with a Robot. The only answer I received was that check in is at 2pm. I asked is that because a room was not available, and the same 2pm answer was repeated. I left my luggage with them and went to explore Shinjuku. I returned at 1.30pm and was greeted by a very pleasant young lady who checked me in. She asked if I would prefer a queen room instead of a double. I answered yes as that is what I have booked. She overlooked the breakfast vouchers. Small things but at the price I was paying, they should not occur. No explanation about restaurant opening times, access to the Luxe lounge etc.On my second check in, I was checked in by a young man with very limited English. I was given a double room, but I was past caring as I had an early start.The Room.I am not sure what is Luxe about the room, but it didn’t feel Luxe. Small in size, limited TV channels, a shower over bath etc. Warning if you are over 190cm tall. You will have to bend right over to wet your head. Unfortunately the door to the room allows a lot of hallway noise into the room. If you have noisy neighbors, don’t plan on a good sleep. Bed was comfy, pillows were ok. One of the highlights was power and phone adaptors supplied. Not sure if they are in lower level rooms or if they are part of the Luxe package.The Luxe Lounge.Not very big, so I can imagine that it would get crowded at peak times. I only went in twice at off peak times and there is a range of drinks and snacks on offer. Nice, but if you are hoping for a full blown executive lounge, you will be disappointed. If you want to get a decent coffee in the morning, unfortunately the lounge only opens at 10am. It was ok but I question the value.Breakfast.I was excited as I was looking forward to a buffet similar to what other countries in the region offer. It was ok, but not at the expected level. The disappointment was instant coffee only. There is a reasonable coffee machine in the Luxe lounge but only instant in a restaurant. Strange! Once again I question the value.Check Out.I lucked out here too. I questioned the rate per night and all I received in return was “talk to your travel agent”. Absolute and total brush off. Had she spent 5 minutes going over the invoice, everything would have been different. There is a quoted rate per night plus there are fees/charges/taxes per night. This could have been handled better, but I was dealing with another Robot.No issues on the second check out.Overall.The hotel is in a great location. The Limousine bus picks up and drops off at the hotel. Nobody was rude, but there is no warmth from the staff. All in all I would say it was just OK. Would I stay here again? Yes! But in a normal room and I will have breakfast outside the hotel. I find it difficult to see the value in the high end product and price.

Stayed at this hotel twice and this year we are going back again. Nothing else to add... Very clean, comfortable. Service always excellent. Staff is extremely helpful. Food is good. Location is great.

This is a beautiful hotel with beautiful, helpful staffs.We stayed here for 2 nights. It was a short trip but we had a very pleasant time We had such a great time at the hotel and plan to revisit when we go to Tokyo.

Since we booked the tour as a package with the flights with only a few days to spare before leaving, the only available room was at the Premier Grand floor. It is very spacious with two deluxe beds, a shower area and a separate toilet area. It's very comfortable and everything you could need is there. Amenities are L'occitane. Staff is courteous and extremely helpful. Booking a premier grand room allows access to the club floor. We didn't book daily breakfast but we could have daily breakfast and afternoon tea at the club/lounge. They do not change the menu selection daily but it's quite good if you're too tired to go out and eat in a restaurant. Access to Shinjuku station is great --- u just have to walk about 5-7 minutes. Tochomae station is just below the hotel while Nishi-shinjuku station is very near with a walkalator during office hours. Overall, this place does not disappoint.

Only few minutes walk to shinjuku station.you will find a lot of restaurant and shopping place on the way to shinjuku station.They have a big lobby and several restaurants inside the building.They also provide free shuttle to disneyland/sea.Love it!

I read that this hotel is just 4-star but the service is definitely 6-stars for me. I was not able to do some relative comparison yet but my wife told me it's a little bit expensive to stay here. However, I stayed here for four exciting days. Anyway, the hotel is located a few hundred or even a thousand meters away from the bustling Shibuya area. The location of this hotel is rather strategic---it is very close to just about everything. You a 7-eleven store just a few meters away from the lobby. You have a nice coffee shop called Excelsior Cafe which was I think inside the Mitsui building (?)Everything is nice about this hotel. The water system works. The room service attendants are most old people yet they do their tasks with exceptional detail. The breakfast food (Western) is kinda limited (it's buffet but the choices are somewhat limited), but for a guy like me, it's okey. You gonna love staying in this hotel. It is like you feel that you are being taken cared of.

That was my third stay ay Keio. I had quite a good experience before. Location is very good, easy to get to the metro lines and a lot of restaurants, shops, shopping malls close by. Hotel is very big, has a lot of cafes , restaurants. It is very clean. Restaurants are very good but expensive. Furniture in some of the rooms is quite old ( there are ‘“ new” rooms and “old” rooms). This time I had a strange experience with front staff- twice I asked them about changing the room. They couldn’t care less, never got back to me and were not interested at all in my issue. Of course, I could understand if there is not possible to solve a problem but at least you try something. My feeling is that the hotel is a very big processing operation and you may or may not get good treatment. Tokyo is a fascinating city and Japanese people very nice.

Not a single one of these room pictures shows the style of room we had. We got told on check in there was no non smoking rooms available, so we were put in an "upgraded" single bed in the main tower. I'm guessing the upgrade just meant the actual floor size of the room as this room was decorated in the 1980's, clearly in need of a renovation. Like I said, not a single image on here or their website shows the style of room we had. For good reason, it was terrible. When we phoned reception to say we weren't happy we got told because we booked through Expedia we selected a "non renovated" room. There is no option to select a non renovated room; clearly if you don't book through their website you get left with the poorer rooms.The only reason this hotel gets a two instead of a one is because it's close to the train station. I would not recommend this hotel to my worst enemy.

This hotel had all the trappings and was well located. I chose to venture out on my own for dinner at one of the nearby local restaurants and had a lovely fish dish (cooked!).I actually didn't spend much time in the hotel--preferring to do some sight-seeing.

Had a really lovely stay here. Great place, room and excellent service/staff. Nothing really negative to say about it at all. Highly recommended.It is a little bit more of a walk from Shinjuku station than we realised but most of it is through really interesting shops and restaurants.

We stayed at this hotel with our 13 years old Daughter. We had a room on the 25th floor of the southern building. The room was big and comfortable and had the highest maintenance level.The service was top notch in every level of interface with us.- check in / out- laundry service (although we paid around 130 USD for two bags of laundry).- room service- restaurant staff- bell boyThe food was great. We could choose from three restaurants for breakfast (western, Japanese and mixed). The quality and variety were of the highest standards.We are one evening in the Japanese restaurant and for us it was a unique cultural experience, like going to a Kabuki theater...the food was great. On another night we ordered room service which was freshly made and delicious.The gym was ok. Not big, however accessible.And besides that, the location - minutes of walking from Shinjuku Station gave us the edge of traveling all around Tokyo.We think this hotel is highly recommended when in Tokyo.המלון מומלץ בחום. שווה את הכסף.

My partner and I splurged a little on the Grand Premier Club Floor at Keio. Our bedroom was amazing. The view of Tokyo city was breathtaking from our room. The bathroom had a large window that looked straight out at the view of Tokyo city, which was very relaxing after busy days running around Disneyland/DisneySea. The bed was very comfortable and we actually wouldn't stay anywhere else after being here. The hotel offers a free shuttle to Disneyland and Disney Sea. Is close to the train station. Staff are very friendly, speak very well English and are just a phone call away. The buffet breakfast had a large variety of Western and Japanese food. We stayed in Osaka after this and wish we didn't start our trip off somewhere that made everywhere else look like a 2 star hotel.

Comfortable and classy hotel in the heart of Tokyo and within walking distance to most places of interest.My room catches the magnificent view of the entire DIET building with surround japanese garden around its surround ground.

We dined at Glass Court this morning for our breakfast and was seated against the wall in one of the booth seats near the buffet line for Japanese dishes. Another family of 6 was seated next to us with 3 young children. At the end of their meal (around 10:30am) and with the restaurant more than half empty because it closes at 10am, the three kids started running around the tables nearby. I was seated next to them browsing my phone n my younger 3yo son was seated next to me. Suddenly a waiter walked towards me and in a loud exasperated tone, said in broken English “We have guests eating breakfast. The children cannot run around. Is ok?!?!” Then he stomped off before I could even say that these weren’t my kids running around. While I empathize with the service staff n try my best to keep my own boys in check in public places, I do not appreciate being yelled at by a service personnel. Furthermore, these were not even my kids. When I approached the restaurant manager to complain, the offensive waiter came forward to apologize while his manager stood smiling nonchalantly behind him. As someone who works in the retail industry, I do not think the manager’s behavior is appropriate as well. He clearly understood English as he was seating all the guests with a quick overview of the buffet options, and answering any questions they had.We stayed in 6 ryokans and this hotel in our 10-day trip. This hotel is by far the worst experience in terms of service. I will never stay here again or recommend this place to friends. It is at least an 8 min walk to the nearest station according to google maps so it’s not even that convenient.

Rooms are quiet and new. I have been there couple times and rooms in the Main Tower are nicer than South Tower. Main tower rooms were pretty new and big. Breakfast is so good, so many different options where do you want to eat and what kind of food. I had lounge access and i liked it, the view is really nice from the lounge and it is nice to go to drink some coffee/tea there. Restaurant top of the Main Tower is really good!!!

This is a very clean, well run hotel. We don't normally stay in a hotel as large as this, but it was fine. The staff are all very courteous and polite and helpful. Check in was easy. Transferred here on the bus from airport. Very easy.

The only problem we had was, we had a fairly long wate to check in, due to our very early arrival time, however we managed to find a very nice gentleman who checkus in a couple of hours early, and he really appreciated how tired we must have been, with the hanging around.The hotel is close to trains and bus hub.Breakfast is very well catered for ALL tastes.Although a very busy hotel it not noisy.We recommend this hotel.

I was hesitant to book at first because of the price (around $200 a night) but after reading lots of great reviews, the amenities it provides, and its close vicinity to the Shinjuku station, I decided to splurge and reserve this place for 5 nights. It was probably one of my best decisions to make for a late night credit card purchase because this hotel was ABSOLUTELY amazing for our first time stay in Tokyo! My fiance and I stayed here in mid-February (off season) and the staff was incredibly nice and accommodating. We stayed in the South Tower in the Plaza Superior Queen room, which seemed to be quieter and less people than the Main Tower. The room itself was spacious, with a safe box (bolted to the closet) and, on a clear morning, we can see a hint of Mt. Fuji in the distance. We also got a free upgrade when we stayed here a second time at the end of our trip, which was so nice of them! We even checked in at ten minutes before check-in time and we got our upgraded room within minutes. The bathroom also provided shampoo/conditioner/body wash that wasn't generic and I think the lotion was from Crabtree and Evelyn.One of the BEST things about this hotel is that it provided a 'Handy' phone (actually named 'Handy') where you can use to travel basically anywhere using Google Maps, so we didn't need to use our sim and data to navigate around as much. You can't go on the internet with it, but can make international calls for free.Also, it was very easy to get to and from the two main airports (Narita and Haneda) because the pick-up/drop-off for the airport limousine bus is at the main entrance. Plus there is also a 'Good Neighbor Shuttle Bus' to Tokyo Disneyland (free but need to reserve in advance) which we used.The location is also close to Starbucks, 7-Eleven (our go-to place for breakfast and snacks), and many restaurants. Plus, the Shinjuku station is a main station so you can basically take any line (local, JR or Tokyo metro) to go anywhere in the city. We also felt safe walking around the neighborhood in the early morning and wee hours of the night.If you want convenience, relief, some luxury, and great service, this hotel would be right for you. My fiance and I are racking up credit card rewards to stay here again (we got 3 nights free from our travel reward points) in the near future because it was probably one of the best hotels I have stayed in my life.

Front desk staffs are robotic and inflexible. Cold and work without enthusiasm which is so unlike Japanese. Room is old but clean. Sound proof is bad as you can hear people on the corridor. Stay somewhere else. You won’t be able to feel the true hospitality of the infamous Japanese in this hotel.

I visited this hotel in early Jan 2018. There were 11 of us in the group. I understand it's a busy time just after New Year so waiting half an hour in the queue to check in was probably not unreasonable. Also given that we were a large group, it might take longer than usual having to go through 11 passports. However, I still couldn't believe it took one and half hours before we were given the keys to our rooms. Despite the long waiting period, we were given the wrong number of rooms and the wrong number of beds per room. Meaning we all had to re-shuffle between several floors. Not fun with little kids in our group after a couple hours standing like sardines in the bullet train.The inconvenience and lack of customer service did not end here.1. On our first night at Japan, we stayed at the Hyatt in Osaka. My son left a teddy bear there and the hotel was kind enough to inform us and offered to courier the teddy bear to Keio Plaza. The courier cost 800 yen. Brilliant service from Hyatt! The check in person who took 1.5 hrs to check us in, couldn't charge 800 yen to our room and continued to bug us after we got sorted in our rooms for payment as we were rushing to get to a tourist venue before it closed thanks to the super long check in process. Meanwhile, there was still a huge queue at check in. 2. The process of returning the keys from the incorrect rooms also made me feel it was not worth bothering at all. We thought we do the right thing by returning them as soon as we realised the mixup. In return, they tried to charge us for extra keys and breakfast vouchers they didn't give us.The lack of efficiency and customer service is profound. You would not expect this sort of treatment for the price you pay!!!On the only positive note, the customer service lady we raised the issues with, and her manager, were very apologetic, but we got the feeling it's not the first time they've heard the problems.

Every time I travel to Tokyo, I usually stay in Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo. This hotel near the Shinjuku Station, you can reach this hotel by NEX from Narita airport, or limousine bus directly from the Narita/Haneda airport, too. Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo have free shuttle bus to go to Disneyland, this service is very good! Their staffs are nice, polite and helpful! The room is clean and comfortable!This hotel provide a free mobile with voice and data plan! It is great!!

Stayed at the Keio Plaza recently for 5 nights. Chose it for its central location in Shinjuku, which is a great neighborhood for general Tokyo tourism. Right across the street from the Tokyo Metropolitain Government building with its popular observation tower, it is also right next to Shinjuku station, a main subway hub. And this is key, because the best (really the only) way to get around Tokyo, and in fact, all of Japan is on the well-organized, efficient and low cost subway and train system. My initial thought on the downside of the Keio Plaza is that it is a massively large hotel with tons of rooms and people milling about the huge lobby at all hours. I think they must have over 10 restaurants, so lots of facilities, but I was worried about the hustle and bustle, which is why I usually pick smaller, boutique hotels. HOWEVER, we alleviated this problem by booking the Premium Club floor, which are several floors in the top part of the hotel, thereby giving us access to a special facility on the 45th floor, for check-in, concierge services and private breakfast area. Much quieter and certainly more upscale than the masses lining up for the buffet breakfast in the lobby. Our breakfast buffet was lovely, and they also served free cocktails and hors-d'ouevres between 5-7 pm. The room we had was spacious, well-designed, new and lovely. It really had everything we needed. So in my opinion the upgraded Premium Club is the only way to go at the Keio Plaza. Turned it from a 3.5 star hotel to a 4.5 star hotel.

I chose this hotel mainly because of the location. Location wise is not good, yes there is an underground passageway to the subway (you need to use the back door which no one in th the hotel informed me) and passageway to JR station (again the hotel back entrance to reach the JR station) but it’s a long walk to reach the JR/Subway gate (10-15 mins walk).Upon check-in, they won’t allow you to check in until 2 pm. You can only drop your luggage, definitely no check in allowed. Service upon check-in was good, but checking out was different matter. I found that Japanese hotel staff tend to be cold and reserved. As a hotel located in the middle of Tokyo with foreign visitor staying in, wouldn’t be nice to ask the guest how was their stay etc. I brought heavy suitcases after check out yet no one asked me did I need help with suitcases and I’ve to ask the hotel doorman by myself that I need to get the taxi (again, no warm service)The bathroom is dated, you feel like going back to the 1970s with low ceiling and yellow color wall painting. Bedroom mattress are hard and just okay. Certainly this hotel needs much improvement both in rooms and services. And some people said they got Loccitane bathroom amenities, what I got just hotel branded bathroom amenities.In my opinion, there are other hotel in Tokyo with much cheaper price and centrally located. Did I feel the stay was worth with the price I paid? Certainly no. Will I go back? I don’t think so.

I spent the night in keio plaza for 5 nights, when I came to see the facilities are very good after check in is finished we look for information to the reception how we tomorrow to Factory Outlet Gotemba an officer look confused just give the bus schedule, then we asked how get tickets back him confused could not give a definite answer and back we asked the solution to get there with another vehicle we were not responded to even doing other work and we were ignored. We as foreign guests were very disappointed with the behavior

The hotel was OK, but the room was not great. Everything was dated. Their restaurants were really expensive. The hotel is well located. The service was good in general, except for the concierge. I lost the opportunity to visit the Imperial Palace because of misinformation from the concierge personnel. Maybe another hotel in Tokyo could be a better option.

My first visit to Tokyo for the marathon and this hotel is placed directly opposite the start line of the marathon, so ideal location. Located in Shinjuku, it’s about 5 min walk from the main train station, and many eating & drinking holes are across the road from the hotel.The hotel itself is very big, and obviously very busy that weekend. I was in the Main tower floor 31, so little noise from outside and also a non smoking room. The room was quite large and had everything that was needed, fridge, kettle, etc. The bed is large and on the firm side, bathroom adequate with the usual toiletries. I had breakfast included in the package, so dined in the Jurin restaurant each morning. Yes it was very busy with sometimes a long queue, but the queue moved quickly and the food was plentiful and tasty.I found all of the staff to be very pleasant and helpful, with the check in staff proficient in English and more than happy to help, despite being very busy. Maybe they respond better to customers being polite to them rather than being surly, as some other reviewers have commented?The only negative, and one that is common everywhere in Tokyo that we are no longer used to in England, is the fact that you can smoke in the hotel. The bars were smoky, and a little on the expensive side, as you’d expect for this grade of hotel. The only reason it didn’t get 5 stars from me.If I was to visit Tokyo again, I’d have no hesitation in staying here again.

We came back to Tokyo and naturally booked with Keio Plaza Hotel again after a wonderful experience. They did not disappoint of course. You can use breakfast coupons at the Japanese breakfast set restaurant, not only the main breakfast area. That’s a big plus as they make very good effort to make each day’s breakfast a bit different. KPH is also a location for airport limousine pick up and drop off, as well as the starting point for many bus tours. You can get all the info you need from the concierge. For us we chose free and easy of course. We will definitely be back again. Oh try the premier room, it’s really very good value!

Warm welcome from the hotel and really nice services every question that I asked they very active with my doubt and good suggestion I asked their suggestion to went to Kawafugiko they suggested us very clearly even they trainee staff they answer me very well and best choice to go to Fuji Mt. room was very large and nice bed feel so comfy and very nice room with good location in downtown of shinjuku very comfortable to go for shopping and bus transfer from the airport sent us directly in front of the hotel that very easy for the one who go to Tokyo first time , There are 3 breakfast outlet that we can choose and may things to eat. Staff nice and friendly, helpful. Hotel allow us to leave lugged at the hotel even I already check out. I really appreciate that

We had 1 night to stay in Tokyo at the end of our ski trip and were looking for somewhere to stay that was both great quality accommodation and with easy access to the train station, shinjuku and the shopping centres in the area. We had a 4 bed 2 bathroom, room and found it very comfortable. The optional shuttle to the airport was also very helpful and easy. Would happily stay here again

Very large hotel with large number of restaurants, shops etc but absolutely no soul. Had one meal in hotel which was pleasant but very expensive otherwise spent little time in the place. Staff not friendly and at check in tried to fob us off with a smoking room despite having booked non-smoking. Offered to move us after one night into non-smoking and clerk became unfriendly when we insisted on non-smoking for full stay. Eventually found us a suitable room after a long wait.Location was handy for Shinjuku station and Marathon start.Room clean and well maintained but mattress like a slab of concrete.

I stayed here one night before transferring to the Hyatt where I normally stay. The Tokyo Marathon was the next morning and it was difficult to find a room as the race start was right in the area. Later I was attending a conference at this hotel.All in all, it is an ok hotel and with a good rate, it can be a decent value but the rooms and service are a bit lacking. They initially placed me into a room that reeked of cigarettes but fortunately they were able to transfer me. The next morning the hotel was absolutely crazy with all of the marathoners so that may have influenced my opinion, but compared to the Hyatt or other hotels, there are better choices

Best location for tokyo marathon as the start line is just in front and save the runner a lot of energy. The hotel is strategically located near metro oedo line and easy access to everywhere interesting. Nearby lots of restaurants and pharmacy and supermarket and a 5 min walk to a garden if you want to do some running. Make sure ask for a non smoking room if you are a non smoker. The bed is hard and the wall is thin. So depend on which floor but at night might be a bit noisy. The concierge is very helpful and friendly. There are plenty of restaurants but quite pricy.

Great hotel with an excellent location - very close to the station of Shinjuku.I stayed here when I ran the marathon and it’s steps away from the start line - literally steps!Breakfast restaurants are very good and the rooms are all very clean. Be aware the rooms are charged on a per person purpose basis so if you’re booking on a hotel website make sure you select the correct number of people and not just the room to share.

I arrived on Wednesday, 21 February 2018 at 7.30 pm. I have specifically asked for a non smoking room due to my asthma problem. The front desk staff agreed and gave me the key for 2137. I am awaiting for my other colleague which according to the hotel system has the problem of mistaken booking. Finally I was guided to my room and to my surprised it was a smoking floor. My colleague whom almost did not got the room got the non-smoking room. When I complained the staff just ignore it until another staf joined the conversation. The duty manager did not do any action, just sorry, finally we were promised to be moved on the 23 February for the non smoking room. On that day I returned the key and left all my luggage at room 2137 to be moved to the non smoking room which yet to be determined. When I returned at 7 pm, I was given the key to the room 1150, another surprised come, somebody else room!! I asked the same duty manager and she become frantic, nobody knows where my luggage were moved. Waiting for another half an hour than finally they found my luggage at room no 1917. The room is old and very basic compare to the other 5 star hotel in other countries. Bed is pretty hard, pillow is not soft enough. When you sleep in a smoking room, all your pajamas and under wear will be smell of tobacco. Fortunately I was out all day till late at night. On Friday, 23 February I have breakfast at 10.18 in Jurin which closed at 11 pm, all the bread baskets were empty, nothing left behind and the choices of food are very limited. Before check out I asked about the effect of Tokyo marathon to the limousine bus to Haneda, nobody can answer it, until an English speaking staff from abroad come out and explained to me.Terrible experience. I will never ever return to this hotel anymore.

We stayed in this hotel during the Tokyo marathon as part of a marathon package (the Start is literally in front of the hotel). The hotel has very big rooms and spacious bathrooms all very modern ( we were in the main tower). The usual amenities are available but no Yukatas. The breakfast restaurants are not dimensioned to withstand the number of guests when the hotel is full, there are long queues everywhere unless you go very early or very late :past 10.30am. So really not worth including breakfast. The hotel is also not especially family friendly, adding a bed for a child (7) will cost you 45 euros per night. During our 2 week stay in Japan this was our least preferred hotel but the priciest ! Overall if not for the marathon, I would not select this hotel, there are other conveniently located hotels with maybe smaller rooms but all the same amenities and cheaper.

Great location! Absolutely love the shopping nearby! Would love to come back again. Taking time to shop n eat is a great way to spend your time here. Many stuff to buy too. Convenient to move around from here

The hotel is pretty large with a lot of visitors' traffic and no personal attention. Service was just fine. Breakfast was standard and pretty noisy. The few restaurants options with a nice quality bakery are good and very convenient with a Japanese flavor.

I stayed in Keio for total of 7 nights, the first 3 nights I was given old floor (level 21) with smoking room although I have requested for non smoking room, the front desk told me because the hotel is full, but on my second stay I was given main tower with non smoking room and so much newer and better in everything, even the toiletries are from loccitane and a pair of yukatas are provided in the room. No smoking smell and newly refurbished room, nice bathroom and bed. Remember to choose main wing of the refurbished one of the hotel. Breakfast Buffet is always long queue especially the japanese buffet restaurant so you can’t be having breakfast if you are in a rush (catching flight or tour schedule)It has a direct access to shinjuku station but its a long walk to the main JR lines. Amazing amenities, overall a happy stay

This hotel has been around for years but they still manage to provide great service and the refurbished rooms are spacious and comfortable. Love the bathroom which is large and you can move around without bumping into things. We stayed on the 36th floor and lounge access is provided at the south tower. The lounge is small but cosy. The other highlight of this hotel is the short walk to the Shinjuku JR station with the many malls, restaurants, shopping.

This hotel was beautiful. It was in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo, where there are many shops and dining options. It’s about an hour from the airport, but it’s in a perfect location if you have tours booked. The rooms were very clean and the view was beautiful. I was very happy with this hotel, with the exception of breakfast. There were multiple types of breakfasts served in separate dining areas (Japanese breakfast, American breakfast, etc.) I didn’t like the fact that they were separated. I’ve stayed at hotels in Asia where the same variety of breakfast was served buffet style in one dining area. Enjoying a variety in this manner, especially when breakfast is as expensive as it was, makes it worth paying for. Hopefully, this can be taken into consideration for future guests.

Great location in the quieter part of Shinjuku. We got the room at a great deal and were pleased with the size and features. Bathroom has a mirror that doesn't fog up and lots of amenities. They even offer a cellphone to borrow during your stay!

I was pretty excited to stay here, especially after reading reviews. I must say, I was a little disappointed. The location is excellent, close to train and everything else you need, and Shinjuku is a fun place. The hotel itself for the price, is old and lacks a lot, including informed and well English speaking staff. I guess I expect a highly rated large hotel in Tokyo to have staff that can recommend certain places when asked, or understand certain requests such as extra bed, however not the case. The rooms are large, especially for Japan standards. The bathroom just falls short for a hotel calling itself a "luxury" hotel. It's basic at best. The restaurant Kyubey is exceptional if you are able to get a reservation there. Overall, just fell short of my expectations and I expect more for the kind of money Keio charges for rooms.

We booked here for a single night on our way home from a week in the snow, looking for a little luxury and access to the Shinjuku precinct.The hotel is about a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station in the underground walkway, so you are out of the elements until you pop up directly in front of the hotel. Although I wouldn't want to do this walk with kids and all the bags associated with a family.Walking outside the hotel you literally cross the street and are in the start of the Shinjuku shopping / eating district. Although a good walk from the eating at Piss Alley or bars of Golden Gai.This is an old school grand styled 4/5 star hotel. The rooms were what I would expect in size and amenity, Very clean, but definitely needing to be modernised, especially the bathroom.

Needing to find a hotel in Tokyo at short notice, the Keio Plaza offered great links to transport. The hotel is on one of the routes for the Airport Limousine Bus from Narita, and has easy access to Shinjuku Station West Exit, a few minutes walk away. My room was large, with two queen size beds, on the 25th floor of the South Tower, offering views to the east. The room itself was clean, warm, quiet, and very well maintained. The bathroom was large, and the towels were big and fluffy.The service, from check-in to check-out was first rate, taking only 5 minutes to have an iron and ironing board delivered.There are many eating places between the hotel and Shinjuku station, with a number open 24 hours a day. Cuisines included, naturally, Japanese, as well as Indian and Western establishments, along with numerous bars.For those wanting to go shopping Shinjuku station is underneath a number of department stores such as Keio, Odakyu, and Mylord. Further to the east is Isetan (with an amazing food hall) as well as a myriad of neon-glowing shops.If you're looking for a convenient, comfortable, well-maintained hotel that is easy to get to, with plenty of good places to eat nearby, and near shopping the Keio Plaz Hotel Shinjuku should be on the list.

Overall a pleasant stay at Keio Plaza, which is was good if not better than the international 5-Star hotel chains. Front office service staff were friendly and professional. With a long queue line for check in, the hotel had a staff to engage the guests in line, giving them an intro of the hotel, explaining what’s around the vicinity etc. Upon check-in, a porter brought our luggages to our room and explained to us how to operate the various switches and devices. Room is well appointed and of good size, in fact very spacious. It looks very modern and clean, seems like the hotel recently renovated their rooms. Housekeeping service however was just alright only — clean but they forgot to top up the bathing essentials and clear the trash. Can’t blame them since this hotel has over 1,000 rooms and at 7pm, the housekeepers were still at work! Check-out was just as smooth, and bellmen were very attentive and helpful.Location wise, can’t be better since it’s walking distance to Shinjuku station.

This was my first time in Tokyo. The hotel was nice, I think it was recently renovated (at least my room looked new). The employees were helpful and generally could speak English. The breakfast buffet offered traditional Eastern and Western options. The location was easy. Meaning that the Friendly Bus (bus shuttle to/from the airport) picks up and drops off in front of the hotel. The Government building was right next door, which allowed me to quickly go the the Observatory (45th floor) to get a panoramic view of Tokyo.Shopping and restaurants were also very close.

This is our Fourth stay at Kieo Plaza. We stayed in the main tower (20th floor). Checkin girl was not rude but maybe she was having a bad day. Our room was dated (I mean 80's). This room has not been updated since the hotel was built. The bed was old and I was too scared to look under the sheet in fear of bugs. I was itching all night !! The bathroom was smelly. Carpet needed a good clean. TV didn't work but seeing we are only staying two nights I won't bother calling reception. Location is great with a ten minute walk to Shinjinku station. At $400 AUD a night, think we may head back to the Hilton next time. I will take into account however that our previous stays at Krio Plaza have been great.

This is a very nice hotel. With great choices of restaurants in the building. All very delicious. It’s clean and great service. Easy check in. Also right next to the train station which makes it easy to get anywhere quick and fast.

One of the amenities I did not see until I looked around in the room is the free use of a smart phone (Android). Phone is located in the room and not hidden in some reception desk. You can make unlimited local calls but I didn’t ask if there was a charge. There is free WiFi on it and Google Map. I brought my iPhone but my Google Maps does not work without WiFi. I could stop by shops that provide free WiFi but that’s a hassle. I took it for a test drive in -7 degree centigrade weather. Phone will ask for a departure date and later tell you that it will erase all personal data after date. Everything was in English. Thought it would be in Japanese and I would have to poke around. I had a hard time trying to figure out Android’s Google Map in blizzard so I just relied on map’s layout instead of voice directions. Free use of a smart phone is definitely a plus.

Located a short undercover walk form Shinjinku Station this hotel is well placed.The Staff are friendly and the service good.I do object to paying 1,000Y for a VOD card to watch TV.That said I would stay here again.

Hotel to my pleasant surprise is nice and sizeable. The reception experience was quick and pleasant. The room is big for Japan hotel. They have almost all appropriate amenities subtract bath gel or salt(maybe taking Long baths are not encouraged). The hotel has several restaurants on the 2nd floor and a small convenient store which is good. However it’s about 10 to 15min walk to Shinjuku train station and in winter is not a pleasant walk as is too cold perhaps in sprin or autumn it is a nice walk. We had breakfast at the Jurin restaurant which is quiet compared to the glass cut. To us the food is good. Big plus is you can take the limousine bus either to Haneda or Narita airport. We will definitely stay here again in warmer Seasons!

We had an upgrade to the executive suite which worked out quite well for us since we had a toddler. We had a lovely view from our room and the bed was very comfortable. There was no baby crib, however bed guards were provided which still worked for us. The bed was quite comfortable, being 34 weeks pregnant having a good bed was a godsend. It was quite close to food, without being too close and hearing all the street noise. There is a complimentary bus to Disneyland and DisneySea which was convenient for us, just make sure to book the bus a day or two in advance. Overall, would definitely stay again.

Stayed here for a total of 3 nights in end Jan 2018 on a company trip. Nothing to complain about for this pretty decent hotel that is very well located. Rooms are clean and tidy. And in Japan, the toilet is always awesome with the heated seat cover and warm water biget. Pros:- must be the location! Right in Shinjuku! 5-10mins walk to Shinjuku shopping area as well as to the train station! - clean room with good view of the city.- a convenient store right at the basement of the hotel, need not go out into the cold at night should you need something.- staffs are friendly and helpful. They always greet with a smile and a bow. - the choice of breakfast is great, you can choose from 3 restaurant! Western, Jap or International, as I had diet constraint, I only tried international which is a buffet style where I can choose my food! - wi-Fi is strong fast, hot water readily pouring out. ;) - room well heated(since this is winter ... a very cold one).What can be better? :- ... there is no such thing as perfect, however I really find it hard to point out any serious short-coming for this hotel, probably on the expensive end but since I was on co trip that is not a big problem too, haha!Seriously this is a great place to stay! Well done!

This is an older style hotel 10 min walk from train station. The rooms are average and like most of Japan not cheap. The staff are friendly but not well trained and there English is sub rate. The breakfast is good buffet, ensure your rate includes breakfast. Wifi is fast and reliable BUT no movies on TV so no English content. There are more foreigner friendly hotels around, I suggest you investigate to compare. It’s equal to a 3.5 star hotel, the stay was nice but would find another hotel next trip. Ask for renovated room or your air conditioner will not be seperate !!!! You can only get the same heat as the whole hotel, very very stuffy.

Quiet, clean, comfortable, and spacious room. Also, they offer a very nice buffet breakfast. My only complaint is that the hotel is so large that it is a bit confusing to figure out where your tower is or how to get to your room or where to find breakfast rooms. And I could not find staff to help me figure out how to find the elevator. I know I sound like an idiot but it was very confusing. My absolute favorite part about this hotel was the view--I could see Mt Fuji from my room.
user_name:
Annie O
Lehi, Utah, United States

review_body: A really good managed large Hotel, which has been built many years ago, but all seen rooms or equipment well maintained.Very good and qualified Staff at the reception. My credit card was blocked by mistake and the staff called VISA during Check-In and solved the problem.3 different options for breakfast restaurants, Japanese and Western Food was available with great variety of dishes and a la minute eggs are offered too.An other positive point was the direct bus service from Narita Airport at reasonable rate. From the nearby rail/metro station well connected to all Tokyo districts.

We are a family of four and stayed in 2 rooms for 3 nights. As we had booked a twin room and a double room, they were on different floors. This was not a problem for us as our children are technically adults. The hotel rooms were relatively large for Tokyo. The bathrooms were similar to that in many Japan hotels (prefab moulded plastic) but clean and functional. We did have an issue at check-in when they put an extra $2200 onto our credit card. While this appeared on our credit card before we had even entered our hotel room, it took them more than 3 days to remove it despite a number of conversations about this. It is in a good location. A number of reviews have mentioned an onsite convenience store, however we could not find this. There are plenty of convenience stores nearby however. We would be happy to stay there again - so I have rated it 4/5, but it is not worthy of a 5/5 score.

If you want to check out at 12pm, this hotel will charge you 40 USD extra charge. Otherwise you would have to leave at 11am. Then it is another 40 USD if you wanted to check out at 1pm and then an addtional 80 (!) USD if you wanted to check out at 2pm.So for a late check out at 2pm, the total charge is 120 USD. This is quite simply theft and very poor service for a hotel that already charges pretty high prices and one would expect according service. Further there is not even a lobby where one could sit down and work while waiting for a flight leaving later in the day.As an additional bonus check in is strictly only at 2pm, whereas check out is at 11am. What happens with all these rooms from 11am to 2pm nobody knows (except of course the hotel trying to earn extra money with these ridiculous hourly charges).The gym is in fact just a few running machines, no showers or other facilities and the pool is closed completely in the winter. Otherwise the hotel is a standard business hotel, without any frills but also no major short comings unless of course you might not want to leave your room at 11am the day you are leaving.Also be prepared for a long queue of people when checking out at 11am.

First of all, this hotel was booked a day before my arrival. We had no expectations as it was a last minute decision to spend a few days in Tokyo. The hotel is just across the streets of shopping and food places. Super convenient! The shuttle service from airport took ya right at the hotel lobby, that was another plus point for us. If you’re considering a hotel for a first time visit to Tokyo just like my husband and I, I would say, ‘don’t hesitate to book!’.

I experienced the Keio Plaza tea ceremony in 2016, and I was so impressed that I took my brother in law and his wife on a subsequent visit to Tokyo. The first plus is teh location. The Keio Plaza is within walking distance of a number of Shinjuku hotels, and we were just ten minutes away. Moreover, once you arrive at the hotel the tea room is easy to find — no wandering half lost along narrow, winding streets, you just take the elevator to the 10th floor. Once there, you are instantly transported back to the Edo Period. The tea room, surrounded by a rock garden and water, is beautifully constructed, with tatami mats to sit on and a single vase of flowers for decoration. But the best part of the experience is how the tea master guides you through the ceremony, explaining the significance of each step and helping give you an insight into Japanese culture. I would recommend the Keio Plaza tea ceremony to any visitor to tokyo.

Tokyo is an awesomeness place, easy to get food, to shop , incredibly, it also got many fun things to do, if you like coffee, you can find a coffee shop since 1948, and have a cup of coffee there, if you like ramen, there are ramen shop every where. Just enjoy a wonderful time in Japan.

My family stayed at this hotel for five nights recently, and we enjoyed every moment in this hotel and Shinjuku. The location of this hotel is just 3 mins walk to Shinjuku Station, as well as to other cafes / shops / restaurants. There is airport bus shops at this hotel, so we did not worry about how to get to / from airport. The staff are friendly and helpful in every way. They clean the room and fix the bed sheets every day, rooms are spacious with great view outside (we were on 21st floor). The dinner buffet is good and price is reasonable, it is a great choice for families had a long day outside, and just want to stay in hotel and eat comfortable. And I went to the cafe on 45th floor, it has a great view of the city.

Only that my check in time spent me 35 minutes by a courteous staff through check, ask and check, finally got my booking found, room quality, quiet, was good with my choice of grandlux with compliment tea and drink all day on 34/F exclusive lounge. Compliment coach service to Disneyland, and airport shuttle to 2 airports. Comparing speaking, over 1400 rooms hotel in 2 blocks, the depth of choice of breakfast food and venue is not up to par.

Very nice hotel, close to Shinjuku station, which will get to anywhere you want to go in Tokyo.Good choices for breakfast and very friendly staff. The concierge was able to book a Michelin star restaurant for us and organised the booking on our behalf.Quick walk to Shinjuku station, plenty of restaurants close by, and two big department stores for any shopping needs.

This hotel is in a prime location with well appointed rooms and excellent service.I landed in the evening in Tokyo and took a very simple and easy bus ride directly to this hotel from Haneda airport and the only way to get into the city. The check in was completely Japanese (very gracious) and I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the room as I had heard all rooms in Tokyo were like broom closets.A quick drink and small appetizer plate in the bar at the top of the hotel with beautiful views and I was done for the evening. Straight to bed as I had a bicycle tour of Tokyo the next morning (see my review, it's a great way to introduce yourself to Tokyo).The greatest thing about this hotel is how centrally located it is as my bike tour started within a 5 minute walk of the hotel. The Shinjuku Rail Station is very close and a central hub for making connections to anywhere in Tokyo or Japan. It came in handy when I traveled to Kyoto as the station was 10 minutes from the hotel which made making connections easy.The staff always put my room back together nicely when I returned and even removed pizza boxes from a delicious little pizzeria I found at Shinjuku station.Keio Plaza Hotel makes a great landing pad for your first Tokyo visit. I would definitely stay again when I return.

Fair warning: Keio Plaza is one of Tokyo's largest and most modern hotels. Don't stay here if what you're after is the quaint experience of a little Japanese inn. If, on the other hand, you want world-class luxury and amenities without any of the cold ambivalence or outrageously high prices usually associated with such grand hotels, then look no further; you're coming to the right place!In a nutshell, they earn solid checks on these important factors:- Fantastic location in the heart of the Shinjuku district, within close walking distance to great shops, restaurants, and the JR Shinjuku train station.- Immaculately clean and well-maintained, including well-appointed comfortable rooms with spectacular city views.- Housekeeping is very attentive to special needs and requests.- Highly capable and friendly front-desk staff. On a previous trip, they even accommodated a break in the middle of my stay there by making special luggage arrangements and providing me an upgrade when the same exact room wasn't available on both stretches of the trip.- Great start to any day with intercontinental and Japanese breakfast options at the atmospheric "Glass Court" while peeking out over the denizens of Tokyo heading off to work.- Surprisingly great restaurants on the premises, including several Japanese options and the Italian/French "Duo Fourchettes," which tops most Italian restaurants in Rome itself.- Complimenatry Smartphone service.- Sky Pool (summertime only); perfect for a relaxing float on your back while staring up at the majesty of the Shinjuku skyline.You simply won't find a better haven amidst the modern hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Enjoy all that Keio Plaza has to offer!

we stay at this hotel for 3 nights. they service are very excellent. their front desk staff are very friendly and professional. I will choose keio plaza next time when I visit Japan again. last time I stay Prince hotel not too good compare with keio plaza.

We arrived at this hotel as the first place on our honeymoon trip. Very nice, very clean, comfortable rooms, and with a great view of the city. Excellent buffet restaurants. It is very well located in the Shinjuku neighborhood, there are several electronics stores nearby and also very accessible to other areas of the city. The staff and people of Japan are truly friendly, we were happy in our stay and we want to return.

This hotel takes the anonymous hotel room to its bland conclusion. There is nothing remarkable about the two triple rooms we filled our family with on the 16th floor of the south tower. Everything worked. The remote air was slightly claustrophobic and the windows didn’t open and it was clean and small with the three single beds but what we came away with was the feeling of beige otherworldly nothingness. There has to be more to life.

This hotel is one of the best in Tokyo because is very well located (at Shinjuku), very close to the subway station, the breakfast are terrific and the best of all: give you smartphone with free calls to the rooms and internet so you can use to walk around Tokyo!

The staff were very efficient and friendly, the room was a good size for a Japanese hotel, the breakfast was very good with a choice of eating either in the western or Japanese style restaurants. The location was excellent with a myriad of interesting little lane ways containing many small restaurants and bars in the area between the hotel and Shinjuku Station. It was our first trip to Japan and we used luggage forwarding from hotel to hotel which enabled us to travel by train with an overnight bag between us while our suitcases arrived at each hotel on the following day. It cost about $20AUD for each suitcase and the service is very reliable. The forwarding is arranged by each hotel.I recommend this hotel and would stay there again.

Great, quiet, clean luxury hotel with fabulous amenities. We enjoyed our stay immensely - especially the free flow happy hours in the lounge. Rooms are immaculately clean, and the attention to detail during daily cleanings was greatly appreciated. Rooms feature L'Occitanne Bergamot products, Nespresso coffee makers, and the comfiest Japanese pajamas (we hated to leave them behind). We would also like to extend a debt of gratitude to Konishi (at the Guest Services desk) who tirelessly worked to help us track down our tour guide (who we booked independently) who was MIA for 90 minutes. She did not stop until our problem was resolved. Thank you, Konishi.Only complaint: We had trouble controlling the climate in the room. Difficult to get the temperature cool enough for sleeping; and despite the complimentary humidifier, it was hard to keep enough moisture in the air.

The hotel has a great location, and very well staffed. We sent over luggages from kyoto , and the staff informed us promptly when the luggages arrived. The hotel room is comfortably sized, but it would have been better if the shower and the bath tub is seperated. The hotel has airport limousine to the airport too.

This is the 2nd time I've visited Japan but a first for Tokyo and during the Christmas holidays too. My previous stay was in Osaka and I was very impressed with Swissotel (see my review). Keio Plaza I would rank as equally impressive. This is a big hotel with multiple restaurants to choose from, though I only got to try the breakfast buffet at Jurin and the Glass Court. I would rate these as average for a hotel considering the price. You can also go to Starbucks accross the street or the other breakfast joints beside it. Check in / out was a breeze and hassle free given the multiple counters. Since I was with my family, we got a total of 4 rooms. My room was a twin standard with my two kids right next door. As we travelled during the holidays and only reserved two months before, the hotel was fully occuppied which resulted in our rooms being on the smoking floor and had no connecting door. I found the room to be large (for Japan Standards) and nicely decorated. It didn't seem dated nor dull. Beds were comfy and firm with the pillows being on the softer side. Bathroom was clean with good water pressure (hot water was readily available). Toiletries were complete but as with most hotels, expect body wash and no soap unless requested (same with lotion which you will need due to the cold dry weather). Internet was adequate but not entirely fast. The rooms had the usual flatscreen but it wasn't able to read my USB full of movies. I settled for the local channels (with very limited english channels) but since I didn't come to Japan to watch TV, I wouldn't call this an issue. Keio Plaza is right smack in the center of Shinjuku with a 5 to 10 min walk to the train station. The walk way is covered so no worries should it rain. It becomes only difficult during the winter as temperatures falls to 1° C which is a challenge to the unprepared. There are multiple places to shop and eat within the vicinity that make the hotel ideal. There is also a coin laundry 15mins away so bring a small suitcase with wheels if you're carrying a huge load. We took the airport limo service which makes its rounds around Shinjuku. Keio Plaza is its first stop so expect roughly two hours to get to Narita Airport.Overall, it was good nine days stay and I would definitely recommend Keio Plaza. Its pricey but well worth it. PS: Oh, I like the convinience store inside the hotel which was a life saver.

Hotel location is GREAT. Rooms are very clean and comfortable. Our room had great views out to Mt Fuji .. This is a great hotel if you follow their rules - the art of hospitality seems to have moved aside and business of running the business is key. EG: arrive before the official check-in time, and there is no way that you will get your room early. Ask for a late check-out, and US$50/30 minutes is the offer - we had 3 rooms booked, wanted to check-out 2 rooms at 9am and 1 rooms at 1pm - no possible without charge. It's transaction after transaction here .. .. Bathroom amenities (soap, shampoo) are not great, take your own .. but, check-in ontime, depart ontime - and you will have an easy / enjoyable stay.

This hotel is a gem in Shinjuku! We booked a triple room for 2 adults and a child and were given a high floor room. We were surprised by the view of Mt. Fuji. Everything in the room was beyond expectations. It was spacious and needless to say, in mint condition. The beds were super comfortable and room temperature is a great reprieve from the cold outside. The Loccitane toiletries and the bath sugar cubes were a blessing especially after a long day out. The hotel is a short walk (7 min) away from SHINJUKU STATION, and a metro subway station is also accessible by an underpass. This hotel is also a pick up point for certain tours and I especially like the fact that it also offers free shuttle coach service to Disney parks. I only wish that they would increase the frequency of this service as it tends to be fully-booked. For a hotel that is 50 years old, I would say that the upkeep of this hotel is par excellence.
