My family and I had our first out of the country trip and Japan was the first in mind.This hotel is very luxurious(compared to other hotels I’ve stayed in Japan).The hotel staff especially at the Bell Captain were very accomodating.I had encountered a problem with my shuttle reservation going to Disneyland and they really tried their best to help me.We also were in a hurry to have our breakfast on our 2nd day and asked the staff in the restaurant area where we can dine since there was a long line already.The gentleman gladly assisted us so we can catch our ride.It was definitely a worthwhile stay!

The only main concern is room size but otherwise everything is nice. Close to all the shopping and public transportation. I like the room that can fit 3 beds. Bed's size is quite small but this is normal for most hotel in Tokyo. Also many restaurants to chooses in the hotel's building.

Stay in Keio again. Been here in April 2015. Got allocated to the main wing. The room in contrast to my previous visit is a bit old and dated and smaller size. Overall still a good hotel to stay and location is great - in the better part of Shinjuku (5 min from station) and away from the red light district of Shinjuku. Glad to find out that my post in 2015 on the coin laundry facility near by still there. If you exit the back door of the main entrance, turn left towards Mitsui building and walk straight past Tokyo police station. Cross the road and walk into the lane way between the can do 100 Yen and Lawson. Walk straight and turn left in the first turning into a smaller lane way and you will find a super cheap 24 hours coin laundry. Make sure you change some 100 Yen coins before you come.

We are a family of 5 with 3 kids. I booked directly thru phone and the guy suggested we get 2 connecting rooms to fit us all. When we arrived in the room, it was so stuffy like there was not enough air to breathe. I turned on the air condition but only hot air was coming out. I complained and was told that during winter, our entire floor’s air condition is programmed as such, that is, only the heater is working, so even if you lower down the temp no cool air will come out, it was suffocating! They advised us to just turn off the switch! We were sweating so what they did was they brought electric fans into our rooms! Even if the staff was sincerely apologizing I am still so mad as this was not what I expected our hotel rooms to be. From all my travels this was the only time I experienced having electric fans brought into our hotel rooms ridiculous! I later learned that all the superior rooms have this kind of old air condition system and that the deluxe rooms have the new air condition system. So if you are planning to stay at this hotel be aware of this.The rooms are old outdated, the carpets are worn and dirty, I wore the slippers the entire time while in the room. I didn’t expect this since there are a lot of good reviews on this hotel. The size of the room was small, it was hard to fit 2 open luggages on the floor. The bed can fit one adult and one toddler. The toilet bathroom area was tight, very little space around the sink to put the toiletries. The ceiling was very low. There is a tub with detachable shower handle, water flow/pressure and temperature are good. The toilet is the typical Japanese one with different button functions. They included a mobile phone with internet that you can bring out, use google map and surf, I find the surfing part difficult as the phone was pre-programmed with their partnered merchants. Any calls made will have a separate charge, and you cannot use this mobile phone as a personal hotspot as they have blocked this feature. I ended up just leaving the phone in the hotel since it wasn’t user friendly and the phone kept heating up. I can’t help but compare this to the Marco Polo hotels in Hong Kong, where they give you a mobile phone and you can hotspot, call and text overseas free of charge.During check-out after paying, our luggages were still nowhere to be found. Our ride going to the airport was already waiting for us. We waited a long time and finally saw our luggages being pushed by 2 ladies who were taking their time walking and chitchatting, there was not any sense of urgency which should not be the case since the lobby was full of people waiting for their luggages and hurrying to leave.The ONLY positive about this hotel is the location. It is near Lawson, Lawson Natural, Yodobashi, Labi, a 24-hr sushi resto, and many restaurants. A 7 to 10 minute walk to McDonalds, KFC, Bic Camera and a further walk around 5-7 minutes more to reach Shinjuku West Station and Newoman mall, Takashimaya, Tokyu Hands.Overall, we are hugely disappointed with this hotel. We would definitely be looking for a different hotel when we go back to Tokyo. Would not recommend this hotel.

Booked 4nights,Hotel reception area is grand in terms of size with adequate seating area,check in/out process was smooth with cooperative staff(special thanks to Ms. Toda) ,Breakfast was great with many varieties,Room was v good in terms of size and lay-out with comfy bed and v good amenities tea/coffee,Toilet/Shower v good in terms of size and amenities and spotless/good house keeping service),Hotel has good dining facilities (KOREAN,Japanese,Italian And Chinese)plus bakery and small super market(open till 2:30 am),plus outlet shops and relax lounges.Location is 6-10 min walk to Shinjuku main station and near shopping malls and restaurant.Hotel at its premises also arranges limousine bus pick-up to both Narita/Haneda airportsI had a wonderful stay at this hotel,thanks Keio plaza hotel Tokyo

This is a very busy hotel, a lot of holiday makers, business men and tour groups in the reception foyer. There is 2 wings - Main and South. We booked the south superior twin room reading somewhere this wing has been renovated but the room while spacious (30msq) is quite outdated. The bathroom is also very old school, bath tub shower which I’m not a fan of. The 3 days we were in Tokyo (being the last leg of our Niseko ski trip), we had great sunny weather and woke up with full view of Mt. Fuji. We were on 25th floor. This hotel is on the west side of Shinjuku while not as crowded but still conveniently located, 2 mins to Shinjuku Station. There’s many eating places and convenience, drugstore around without going on the other side. The great plus for this hotel is there is a Airport Limousine Bus that comes direct to the hotel from either Haneda or Narita and vice versa. It’s the most expensive way to get to Narita but this beats lugging big luggages to Shinjuku Station. Overall, this was quite an expensive hotel which doesn’t match the value (maybe b’cos it’s peak period). There are better valued hotels in Shinjuku, only wished I didn’t do such a hasty research and ended up paying so much ~ A$400 per night.
We stayed on the club floor where the room, service and restaurant were excellent. It's a medium walk from Shinjuku station.However, the lobby area and general reception look a bit jaded.Good views.

Great hotel with good facilities. Free bus to Disneyland and disney sea make it a convenient hotel to there. Friendly and English speaking staff are available on the front desk only. The hotel rooms are clean and reasonably large. The only downside quite a long walk from subway station although underpass is available

We had 2 rooms with an early check in but unfortunately one of the rooms wasn’t ready when we arrived. While this was frustrating the staff were apologetic and did give us a temporary room while the other one was being cleaned. This is a huge hotel. A lot of people everywhere. We went to 2 of the restaurants, Jurin and Glass Court. Food was was good and staff were very friendly. This hotel is close to the Shinjuku train station and there are loads of restaurants and shops very close. We ate in a sushi train, the sushi was delicious and about $2 AUD a plate. Very cheap. When we checked out my son left his Appple AirPods in his room. We were on the train to Yudanaka and couldn’t go back to get them. The staff at Keio Plaza went above and beyond to find them and are sending them to our next location. Thank you so much, we are so grateful. I would recommend this hotel.

We liked the Keio Plaza hotel more than the Hilton because they offered a great happy hour. There is also a GPS in the room that you can use. We didn't use it, but we thought it was a nice touch. The location was great and the hotel staff was very nice

I was staying in the hotel from 23/12 to 27/12. I booked 4 rooms for 4 nights through Agoda very early in July. Somehow, I realised that I had put the incorrect number of guests (1 guest per room) during my bookings. When I contacted Agoda to update the number of guests to 2 guests per room, I was told that the Hotel charges based on number of pax staying in a room, not by room basis. So I was asked to make additional payment upon arriving on the hotel. After Agoda confirmed my booking and sent me a revised booking voucher, I also contacted the Hotel about the change to ensure that all rooms will be in order for our arrival because I know it is going to be the busiest period of the year. There were also issue when I booked for the Disneyland Shuttle Bus. Long story short, there were many email correspondences between myself and the hotel staff because they kept saying they could not confirm my bookings even though I had long revised my bookings with Agoda. Everything was however sorted just before my arrival but from the incident, it can be seen that the hotel is very prideful. They do not admit that they overlooked my bookings in any reply from them to me.We arrived early around 9am at the hotel but they did not allow check in. They were happy to keep our bags but check in had to be done at 2pm. When we went back to the hotel at around 3pm, there were long Q for check in. It took us almost an hour from getting into the line to arriving into our room. However, they have a system where a bellboy will take you straight to your room together with your luggageRight after your check in is completed. This is good because I did not have to wait for my luggage after I arrived in my room. The rooms were quite spacious by Japanese standard and they were clean and tidy. The hotel is located in a strategic location.As we need to leave very early the morning of check out to the airport, i did my check out the night before. There were not many people in line but I had to wait for 20 mins before my turn. And when I asked if I can book for a bellboy to my room the next morning with our luggage at 5.45am, the gentleman serving me said he will check and get back to me. He never did. I have to call for the bellboy in the morning and when we told them our room numbers, they said they have the details already. I was surprised because the gentleman had arranged the bellboy but never bothered to inform and update me.Overall, it is a strategically located hotel. However, they need to be more humble and improve their customer service.

We were personally assisted and checked into a high floor in the main tower with a good city view. The staff were extremely helpful and spoke very good English. We were even given printed details of travelling to Hakone by the quick train romance car. The rooms were spacious too.

During the stay, we found the floor had not been cleaned properly while we saw the dirt was still on the floor. The table was still dirty with some dust when we returned to room at night.Housekeeping was really bad compared with our stay few years ago. We believed the staff was just replacing the shampoo, body soap etc. Change the new towel and tidy up the bed and getting rid of rubblish only.The last thing they haven't improved is that they small refrigerator is still not cold to store drinks and food.Disney shuttle bus is very limited. Email response is very slow to answer client's queries.

Really loved the location of this hotel. Only eight minutes from JR Shinjuku Station. The location is around commercial area…quiet. There are some lovely restaurants ,shops and pubs only a few minutes away as well.Rooms were excellent, big enough but not huge, anyhow you don't go to Tokyo to sit in a hotel room.The staff, were excellent, always willing to help, and nothing was too much trouble.Special thanks to Go Komai of the room reservation.Super buffet breakfast at Glass Court restaurant was very good with plenty choice, and once again great service.Would definitely recommend staying in this hotel. I certainly will when next in Tokyo.

Although the location was good, was quite disappointed that being a Disneyland good neighbour hotel, the transportation provided to Disneyland was limited. Probably need to reserve way before you even check in....

Having stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel for 5 days 4 nights from 26/9 to 30/9, here comes both the good and the bad points.GOOD POINTS:1. Clean and tidy hotel room.2. Nicely decorated lobby.3. Quiet environment at Executive Lounge.4. Efficient check in and check out at Executive Counter.5. Convenient location.6. Courteous and helpful staff at Concierge.BAD POINTS:1. Can be quite noisy at the lobby area as there are always lots of people gathering near the entrances of the hotel. 2. Queue for buffet breakfast at Glass Cafe can be extremely long. It takes at least 10 to 15 minutes for us to get a table for 2 persons during breakfast time.

In the 70s this was Tokyos tallest building. So expect great views. Now somewhat dwarfed by the Municiple tower across the road. Fantastic they supplied handy phones which I have not encountered before for free in hotels. Rooms etc all fine. And clean. Being so large and very busy,they are not very flexible for late check outs, though charming in their refusal. Would stay again.

This hotel markets to international customers but yet offers these customers no value. After checking out near the end of November and checking our credit card statement, we discovered we were charged twice for room service. We called the hotel and gave them all details such as check in date, check out date, name and room number but yet they still have trouble looking up our transaction. A male hotel staff said that he will look into our issue and call us back in 10 minutes. After waiting for half an hour for him to call, I called the hotel again. A woman named Emiko answered asking for the same details that I gave the male hotel staff which I gave again but she still needed more info and asked me to e-mail the hotel. Your hotel should be able to look up all transactions with the details I gave to both the staff. Emiko still insisted on e-mail after I told her this and hung up. I can not recommend anyone to stay at this hotel after such rudeness and incompetence. I gave one star only because I needed to give something to post this review otherwise this hotel deserves no stars. For the amount of money this hotel charges for their rooms, it’s better to go to the Hilton or Hyatt where they actually value your stay and can speak English. Stay away from Keio Plaza Hotel.

Nice hotel close to most things you would like to visit. Rooms are spacious and clean, everything you expect is there. Staff very helpful and very nice. Will stay there again. Graet views from the room, the lounge and the bar on the 45th floor. Nice extra they have a mobile phone that you can use and take with you all the time you stay there :-) Really helpful. Would stay again.

Located about 5 min walk from Shinjunku JR station and 2 min walk from Tachome subway station. Very convenient to get around and it is also at the more quiet side of Shinjunku. Friendly and efficient service. Since it is a huge hotel, it was convenient to find help for your needs. The language abilities of the service staff varies. The more experienced staff seems to be able to communicate better and undertand and anticipate needs of the guests. We were not given the wifi ID and password upon check in and had to call the front desk for it. Unfortunately the one that was given over the phone didn't work. The bellboy/porter had to go down to the lobby to obtain the correct ID and password for us. Similarly the directions to Tachome, given by the guest relation officer, was not clear and we went the wrong direction, longer route. Beds are comfortable. Room size is good but the decor seems a bit old and outdated. Amenities provided were good but not high end for the price paid for the rooms.

Service overrated. Pillow covers were dirty and we had to ask for a change. Air conditioner in one room was bad and the service staff refused to our request for 2nd bottle of water ! Am surprised they say one guest will only get a bottle of water per day .

The Keio Plaza Hotel was an ideal place to stay! The staff was very accommodating in meeting our needs. The location was ideal, as it was near the train station and walking distance to many eateries and shops. The lobby’s Christmas tree was a perfect meeting place for many group activities. I would definitely come back to this hotel.

Spent 12 days in a luxe suite. Rooms were ok although a little dated. Room service was prompt and the breakfast was good. Very expensive for what you get and I would have expected a great deal more for the high price. I stayed in the south tower.Great location. 5 mins from Shinjuku centre and the train station. Nice views from the room.

Great location across the street from Japan government building. Close to the Shinjuku station west Tokyo. Easy access to the Shinjuku station.Several shops, restaurants around. Departments stores, etc.Limo bus form airport arrives to the hotel directly. Also departs from the hotel as well. Shinjuku Chuo Park is jsut down the street if you want to have a stroll or jog.Hotel is really nice, spacious lobby, with several nice restaurants stores within in the hotel as well as within walking distance. Rooms are spacious not huge. which is a little hard to fine in Japan. Little dated but well kept and maintained. Rooms were very cleaned.Breakfast was included we had two restaurants to choose from. One western style and one Japanese style. Always a line o get to breakfast so good idea to make some time for breakfast. Breakfast food quality was not extraordinary, but pretty decent to average for either Japanese or western breakfast.What really was a disappointment, was service. Do not get me wrong, All are friendly and polite, but I guess i felt little lack of attention to detail and genuine service you can only find in Japan. Like when they hold your card with both hands. Explain to you pointing things on ur receipt. I was left waiting by the concierge several times wihtout being acknowledge. I guess they had too many junior staff, but I was expecting better service. Overall good stay, but I think the hotel isoverated and not good value for the money. Just OK. I might stay again but there are other options in Tokyo for around the same money,

Breakfast and room service great Small but that is to be expected from Tokyo hotel. Staff were very lovely and very handy to have a convenience store in the hotel. Bed was very comfortable and had great nights sleep. Many different tours can be booked in the hotel tour office and tours leave from the lobby. Easy to get to via airport limousine and just a quick walk to Shinjuku station, shopping, cafes, parks etc. Will be staying here again!

The breakfast was very good. There was a good bathtub with an attached shower. The pillows were soft and we had a good sleep. The hotel had at a lot of restaurants that we could try and it was also beautiful.

It’s a popular venue for international conferences and they live up to the expectations. Staff very efficient and helpful. Room was superb. Hotel was close to Shinjuku Station and all the other shopping and tourist areas in Shinjuku. It’s just walking distance. Airport limousine bus can be used going to and from the airport so it’s very convenient.

I was very much pleased in my stay here. I enjoyed the nice ambiance of the room as well as the beautiful view outside. And i also loved the location, very accessible and near to restaurants and shopping centers. They also have free shuttle bus going to Tokyo Disneyland. And when I needed a money change, without any hustle, I had my dollar changed to JPY within a minute by using a money changer machine located at the ground floor. Truly a nice experience to tell.. I love going back...

Overall this was a pleasant hotel, perfectly situated in Shinjuku. The room was large with a great view. You could have breakfast in one of the three restaurants from 5h to 10.30h which was great. The big frustration was that we had to log in to the wi-fi every time we got to our room. The procedure for that was complicated and not flawless. With two IPhones and an iPad this was a daily agony.

Keio Plaza and myself did not have a good start: I had to wait almost 20min to get checked-in. Not only took it 10 min to get to the Counter but then also another 10min to get the Administration done. Too Long! With a bad first impression I was then possibly surprised by the room (Plaza Premier) which was spacious (though small bathroom), comfortable king size bed and nicely decorated and equipped. What turned me done unfortunately was the breakfast: there are three optional Restaurants which cater breakfast of which 2 with western style. The buffet was average in terms of selection and quality. In total therefore a mix of positive and negative experiences.

I stayed in the main tower and the room was very dated for the money. The best part was the location just around the corner from the subway and short walk to Shinjuku shopping. The main Shinjuku train station is incredibly large and busy so using the Subway station next door to the hotel is the way to go.

We had a superior double room and could see Mt Fuji from our window. Quite incredible.Very well located in Shinjuku within walking distance to the closest station and great for getting around all of Tokyo.Breakfast was really great, whilst we struggled with English to Japanese the staff were so overly helpful we felt so welcomed.Only drawback is that this is a huge beast of a hotel so you can get lost in it!

The hotel breakfast was great, the room was obviously really clean. The location of the hotel is great it has tunnel that is 1 min walk away from hotel and connect straights to the underground station. Would stay there if i go to tokyo again.

A tour group haven which is big, bland and smokey. The hotel is always way too full and gives smoking rooms on smoke filled corridors to non-smokers. At $30 a night you choke on that smoke, at $300 a night you start fuming yourself!

Very disappointed.Room was small and basic. Bathroom very small and l hate shower in tub set up. Some hotel staff were not very helpful which was a surprise.Breakfast was a bit of a wait as queues were always long, so hope your not in a hurry. Hotel lifts were also slow and waited a while to catch one.Great location was the only upside for me.Not a hotel on my return to list.

We chose this hotel mainly because it is near to the trains & they provide shuttle bus to Tokyo Disneyland. The hotel is conveniently located to the Main Shinjuku train station but we found a nearer 3 mins walk train station Tochomae.I've seen alot of mixed reviews on the attitude of front desk staffs but my taking was definitely on the good part. When we alighted from the airport limousine bus, we were greeted by the bellboy who was smiling and assisting us with our huge luggages. After tagging our bags, he explained that check in is usually after 3pm and then led us to the premier check in area as we had booked a hello kitty room for our 3 nights stay.The female front desk staff went on with the check-in routine and inform us that the rooms werent ready (as it was only 11am) and asked if we could go for lunch and a short walk and be back by 2pm.After lunch & some window shopping at Keio Departmental Store, we arrived back at the check-in counter slightly before 2pm as my son had slept halfway thru the shopping. The same female staff saw us and gestured us to take a seat at the sofa area while she assigned someone to bring us up to the room.Coincidentally, it was that same bellboy, who had helped us earlier, led us to the rooms. Along the way, he had explained to us in the best english he could mustered about the bakery & convenient store directions located within the hotel. When we reach the Hello Kitty Room, my wife was in awe and had quickly forgotten about our son whom i was still carrying. The bellboy also suggested that he'll help to take a photo of our family with the kitty background.Needless to say, our 3 nights stay at the hotel was very taken care of. From room service to small in-room requests to check out, every part was well communicated. Check out was super fast & no question asked~!I would have rate it 5 stars if not for the fact that they are not flexible in adding the breakfast option for the kitty room as they said that my booking was done thru booking.com and not through them directly.Anyways, still a very good job done and we had already booked for a return visit in April 2018. Lets see if they can match it up then.

To this hotel, a non-smoking room is just a request, not a booking. My wife and I are both allergic to smoke and no amount of air cleaning, etc. helps us. We had booked this hotel through a tour group who did nothing to help us. Staff would not give us a non-smoking room. Never stay here unless you are a smoker.

The Front Desk Staff from this Hotel need to be trained in handling customers. They are abrupt and failed to provide service recovery when mistakes were made. They can only say "sorry" and pretend nothing had happened. I guess this is their trick and being thought by the Management to get away with "MURDER" . Their lucky star is the location, for that, one has to fork out more $$$ to stay there and bear with the poor staff attitude. Checking in at the reception was an ordeal when I stayed there last week and also in my previous stay there. I always encountered issue with my reservation and got my dates mixed up which I ended up paying more for my room rate without breakfast. You cannot never lodge your complaint to the GM as the manager in charge told me blankly that the GM will not see this as a threat in their business. I wonder was that a directive by the Management to turn away guests as the Hotel sells by itself. This poor work attitude is going to bring the Hotel business down. I am certainly not going back there.

Location was good and a mere 5 Walk to Shinjuku station where you can connect to almost everywhere in Tokyo Hotel staff were all very polite and room was spacious enough for Tokyo standard Will definitely stay again if returning to Tokyo

We were very pleased here. Room was relatively spacious, well laid out, and very quiet. Excellent location for access to the Shinjuku train/metro station, and all of the action in the area. Food service was very good and convenient. Best of all was the hospitality from the minute we walked in the door. Excellent hospitality throughout, and exceptional service from the concierge providing information about what we wanted to see.

Our tour group was booked at Keio Plaza Hotel for 1 week. It was a long drive from Tokyo Narita, about 1 1/2 hours in the mid-afternoon. But I was quite impressed with the location, the room itself and the amenities. There was a nicely maintained fitness center (which I went to almost every day), a spa, loads of restaurants and a big, spacious lobby. It is in West Shinjuku, surrounded by nice office buildings and across the street from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. It is close (very walkable distance) to loads of shopping, restaurants and bars and to the Shinjuku Station. As part of the lodging cost, we received coupons for complimentary breakfast, which we could use at 3 different buffets---which were all extensive.

This hotel is situated in West Shinjuku opposite the Tokyo government building where you can get a great free view of the Tokyo skyline.The hotel is big and offers a range of dinning experiences although we preferred to walk 5/10 minutes into the centre of West Shinjuku to sample the many restaurants.You won't be disappointed with this hotel. It's also a short distance from the metro station which is surprisingly easy to navigate.

senior couple return after 30 years. booked a larger room. good amenities. easy walk around Shinjuku and to the station. Plenty of good department stores nearby. No problems in finding breakfast. plenty of great restaurants serving delicious food.

This is one of the very good hotel to stay around Shinjuku area with fairly large room with 10 mins walk to crowded area in Shinjuku. Staffs are friendly. Only questioning about too long waiting time for breakfast.

1st time travelling to Japan, and i decided to stay in Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku area.We were a family of 3 (2 adults + 1 13 year old youth) staying in the South Tower.Our hotel room has a nice view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. The room was spacious enough for the 3 of us, unlike the rest of the hotels that i have stayed in Kyoto and Osaka.I think the south tower building was recently upgraded and i was lucky to be assigned to the room.Location was easy to navigate as it took about 6 mins walk to Shinjuku station. There are lots of eateries around and 7/11, Lawson marts are just around the corner.The guest services staff are polite and can converse in english. The housekeeping staff did a good job everyday. ( we stayed for 4 nights), replenished the bottles of water everyday. There is also a mart in the level 2 which closed at 2.30am in the morning. The mart was big and has a section of souvenirs that i could purchased for a last minute shopping. Overall, my family has a fun and nice stay in Keio Plaza Hotel. Will come back again when i travel to Tokyo.

no AC in the room!! how is this possible?? the hotel said that since it is cold outside the rooms are centrally heated. well it's super hot inside and there is no ventilation. the windows don't even open. how can a hotel of 1,000+ rooms know the preference of all guests and have all rooms heated. this is unacceptable for the kind of money being spent on each night.

We checked into Keio plaza today (Nov 13) and got a room in the main tower. After settling in the room for a 10 mins, we realized the A/C and heater was turned off. We turned it on and set the temperature low hoping the room would cool and be less stuffy. After switching it on and waiting another 10 mins, we realized no air was blowing from the vents and the room got more stuffy. We called the hotel staff and they said the entire hotel (over 1,000 rooms) are being centrally heated!!!! Seriously?!?! Does the hotel know the preferences of all 1,000 rooms and that everyone wants it heated? The windows don’t even open so there was no way to get any air circulation in. Why are we paying such premium rates for such sub standard rooms?!??

The restaurant of the Keio Plaza hotel is in the basement and us called Glass court super buffet . This is a self service buffet with variety of foods , hot dishes , salads , meat , fish , sea food , sushi , soups , very good deserts And so on .

I have actually stayed in Keio Plaza Nov last year. It was our first visit to Tokyo and Staying in keio had been the right choice for us. First of all, the location was really great! It is like 10 to 15 mins away from the crowded Shinjuku and Takashimaya Times Square, Odakyu and Keio department store and it is only 3 to 4 mins away from a small station called Tochomae. There are lots of places that you can go from Tochomae station,without having to squeeze n get lost in Shinjuku central station. If you do your research you should know that Shinjuku station is the most crowded station in Tokyo, so really staying in Keio Plaza is like you are having the best of Shinjuku minus all the difficulties in navigating your way. Moreover on your way to Shinjuku central area, you will find lots of shops, convenience stores and small restaurants. Besides the location, I do think that they provide a great service, room is always clean, concierge was very helpful with our luggage though she is a female, and lastly i really love the free Disney shuttle service. You dont have to find your way through trains and stations if you want to visit Disneyland or Disneysea. Moreover some tour operator that operated mount fuji day trip also depart from their hotel and airport limousine also stop at their doorstep. So it is really convenient if you are a first timer to Tokyo.Room that we booked were actually quite big to fit 3 of us plus our 3 big luggages and there is still place for a dressing table. If there could be a downside of this hotel, is their checked in time. We had gone through a long haul night flight from the 0 coordinate and of course we cant really sleep on the airplane, yet we had to wait till 2pm in order to be checked in. Luckily checked in process is a breeze! Overall thank you Keio Plaza Hotel for your excellent service and great facilities that has made our visit a memorable one!

Beautiful views, excellent restaurants, unmatched pampering - all with incomparable Japanese courtesy from every level of employee. A stand-out amenity for us was a complementary smartphone in the room with free wifi for use with maps, accessing email, and local calling! No need for a local SIM or the wifi rental packages that abound (and confuse). What a relief to find that in the room when we checked in.Highly recommended!
user_name:
William T
Lake Lure, North Carolina

review_body: large comfortable room with nice amenities. the free smartphone was most helpful. good breakfast. excellent service. would highly recommend to anyone traveling to Tokyo. Location is very convenient for shopping and travel.

Keio Plaza hotel Tokyo is a very big hotel, too big. A lot of people running all over the place all day long. The rooms are very nice. All hotel services worked good. A few restaurants for breakfast (Western and Japanese). One of the services is a cellular phone in the room that you can use, while your stay, with internet for your day trips, for local calls and some international calls. Bottom line - we enjoyed our stay.

Stayed here for four nights with my mum and brother... The hotel is strategically located in the Shinjuku area. Room was beautiful with a great view of the city. Service is efficient and overall experience was really good. Definitely enjoyed my stay at this hotel.We also went to the Yamanami Teppan-yaki restaurant -- a bit pricey but that was kinda expected. It was a good experience though and the dining view was just spectacular.

This is a huge hotel, so there are groups of people constantly coming in and out of the lobby. However, the location is good - a few steps away from buzzing Shinjuku shops, restaurants and train station. Service is efficient, and the airport bus stops right at the hotel's driveway.

My wife and I stayed here for 7 nights, as part of our holiday in Japan. We paid extra for a bigger room of 33.5 square metres to have a more comfortable stay. The location of this Hotel is very convenient. The limousine Bus from the airport stops at the front door and also picks up for the return trip to the airport at the front door.The Shinjuku train station is within walking distance and there is an undercover pedestrian passage to the station.The included buffet breakfast was excellent with a large selection of food and drinks. We went early at 6 am to avoid the crowd.

We enjoyed two nights in this wonderful hotel. Hotel staff were very helpful and spoke reasonable English. The concierge personally helped us get our Wi-Fi connection working on our smartphone. The hotel has a nice minimart on the lower floor that is open late. The rooms was beautiful with a great view of the city from our window. The beds were just the right firmness and the room was smoke-free. Everything was spotlessly clean. The hotel is located directly beside the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building with its twin towers and observation decks. Walking a few short blocks through a very safe neighborhood gets you to a huge shopping area - Lumines - with an adjacent major train station. There are several subway entrances even closer to the hotel.

This hotel is more spacious than the previous hotels I’ve stayed in Japan. It’s in a wonderful location that’s near the subway and the train station. There’s a lot of small shops for dinner on the opposite side and it’s near the mall too. The hotel is clean, the staff are accommodating and you have 3 choices of restaurants for breakfast. Japanese, Western and one for both. The mixed one has the longest lines, especially after 7:30 when most of the guests come in. They have an excellent selection even if they serve the same food everyday. They have a nice convenience store downstairs too where it’s almost like a mini grocery.I would book the same hotel if I want to go back to Tokyo.

Location was great, 10 minute covered walk to the West gate of Shinjuku station. Odakyu and Takashimaya dept stores were connected to the station so lots of choices for places to eat. Even around the hotel, some office buildings had restaurant floors (NS bldg). Lots of tour groups so some restaurants in the hotel could be quite busy.An added bonus was a convience store in the basement of the hotel. I signed up for the Luxe lounge but didn't enjoyed it as much. Was open from 9-9 but happy hour was only from 5-7, same sppetizers every day.I would defitinely stay again because of the location.

Overall a satisfying 7 day stay. We did a family trip with my 70 something year old parents. Location is great but could be overwhelming if walking to Shinjiku train station and metro and you have elderly parents to travel with you. So we took taxi often with my parents, and it was always a 10 minute ride to major sites. Another good thing is there are many restaurants inside the hotel. We took advantage of it for the dining being so convenient. There is also a pastry shop and convenience store inside the hotel. We stayed at the South Tower. Both rooms had a great city view, especially one of the rooms was directly facing the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. We booked the deluxe package including breakfast. There were three breakfast restaurant choices and we always stuck with the Western/Eastern buffet called Glass Court. Staff were all friendly and the hotel is huge. We were happy with our stay. We were originally planning to stay at Hyatt Regency that is across the street from Keio Plaza. With my Japanese relative's recommendation, we chose Keio over Hyatt due to the great breakfast, a little closer to train/metro station, and many restaurants on site. Check in/Check out process was fast and efficient. Direct bus transportation to airport was available and well organized. Recommended.

The hotel is geneally ok. Location is really good and close to Shinjuku and to the metro/train station. View from 29th was good. Rooms are ok but seem dated. Considering the price I would have expected more/better.

Beautiful hotel with attached underground shopping. Close to the train station and subway. Bed was super comfortable and the staff and service was excellent and in English. Nice amenities in the rooms also.

If not for its location, Keio Plaza will not thrive in the business as the staff are killing the business slowly especially from the reception. Over the last 7 to 8 years, averagely, I travel to Tokyo about 3 times yearly and stayed at Keio due to its location. Sad to experience deteriorating service on each return visit, the last straw was just aweek ago and I decided not to return to Keio on my next trip in Mar. I had enough of their snobbish service. I had 2 reservations inclusive breakfast booked for the week, of which one was a returned visit. I reminded the reception staff toassign non smoking room for my return visit and to Ensure my request is spelt in my guest history for record. When I returned to check in for the second stay within the week during late evening, I was not given a non smoking room. Reason given by the male staff was no request being made and non smoking room is subject to availability. His Attitude was bad and he was very arrogant, unlike the Japanese culture, there were no apologies from him. I asked for the GM 's email but was told, he cannot divulge and claimed all matters will be channeled to the customer service officer. I then request to have a return call the following morning from the GM or the CSO to voice my frustration. I receive no call during my stay. For the interest of sustaining business in the Long run , the GM ought to take a serious view on all adverse reviews and make improvement on areas which are lacking, particularly the reception before it is too late as the staff are taking things in their own hands and sweeping rubbish below the carpet. Doubt they are ready to handle the Olympics groups if they don't buck up!

While I am not sure if I would stay here if I ever return to Japan, this was an excellent choice for first-time visitors to Tokyo. While the hotel may be a little dated, it is clean and the rooms are spacious. I stayed in a 3-person room and it was comfortable. The staff was personable. We did not eat breakfast at the hotel, but there was a Starbucks across the street, which was convenient if you are into that. There were a variety of decent food options within walking distance. I was surprised at the lack of TV channels for a hotel of this size. The proximity to the Shinjuku train stations was a plus, but please be warned that this is the busiest train station in the world and it is very overwhelming. We really enjoyed our stay here. Thank you.
user_name:
lalaearmuffs
New York City, New York

review_body: Keio plaza hotel is situated conveniently in buzzy Shinjuku. It's a stone throw from the train station, easily accessible within a 10 min walk through a tunnel directly to the hotel. It means you can travel from the Hotel to anywhere in Tokyo including the airport without hitting the streets and getting caught in bad weather!We stayed in one of the relatively new premier rooms that occupy floors 37 and up. Spectacular views. The premier floors mean you do not feel you are in such an enormous venue as breakfast is served on the 45 th floor adjacent to the wonderful lounge area. The room is very well appointed and the in room Nespresso machine is a wonderful fixture for a coffee addict. There are a variety of restaurants in the hotel but the streets surrounding the hotel are littered with hundreds of affordable restaurants to chose from. Great place to stay!!

This hotel is full of tourists that come by the busloads. Many of the guests here are from big tour groups. If you like crowds and noise, by all means, stay at this hotel. The hotel lobby is perpetually full of people talking at the top of their voices. You have to queue for a while just to check in. When I checked in at close to 5pm, I overheard the staff telling the person at the next counter that her room was not ready yet. Breakfast was a nightmare. Even though there are 3 breakfast restaurants in the hotel, you would have to queue to get a table if you arrive any later than 7.30am. The room is small and the walls are thin. From my room, I could hear people talking loudly in the room next to mine and along the corridor. I'll most likely never return to this hotel.

An stunning hotel in immaculate condition, right in the heart of Tokyo. The hotel has good selection of restaurants ow the lobby, with more choice available on the nearby streets of this incredible city.

The Keio Plaza is an excellent if slightly impersonal large hotel in Tokyo's Shinjuku district. The room was spacious and quiet despite the unseasonal typhoon that greeted us. The hotel is a good central location. It has a selection of restaurants and the food we had was excellent, especially the choice at the buffet breakfast.

Got the grand premier suites. Was pleasantly surprised with the premium service and the sky lounge. Room size wasnt too big but amenities were awesome. Best was the cell phone that we could use during our entire stay free with calls and data!! Once got our bearings right (Hotels huge), the location is very close to the main hub. English is also good among staff.

This is a huge hotel. It has around 47 floors and two towers. Location is in the Shinjuku area amongst all the highrise buildings - the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Offices is directly across the road from one of the entrances. The hotel seems to be always busy everywhere - as it has lots of things "happening" from several different restaurants, to free shuttle service (several times a day) to and from Disneyland. They will also arrange transport back to the airport, even if you have a pre-paid booking. The lobby area is massive and with the number of people staying at the hotel, you never feel hemmed in.The room itself is not that big, apparently quite typical of Tokyo. It has everything you need. The bed was a little on the hard side, however reasonably comfortable. The bathroom is very small & the toilet is located in front of the bathroom door so not very well designed. Everything is very clean here and there were good quality toiletries in the room. I bought a Japanese SIM card for use there, however a free Sharp mobile phone is provided in every room that you can use while staying there. It includes free international calls & google maps etc. and you can use it like your own. So the SIM card I bought before arriving here, was a waste of money, as the hotel phone was excellent. All history on the phone while there, will be automatically erased on check out day.Several restaurants here although very pricey - would not expect anything else from a classy hotel. Breakfast is provided in two restaurants (all you can eat buffet style) however I did not eat breakfast there as it was very expensive to eat there every day. I ate breakfast at a restaurant directly across the road and costs a fifth of what the hotel charges (menu items). Whenever I went past the breakfast restaurants there were always huge lines of people waiting to get in, so they were obviously very busy.There are also very wide light & airy underground tunnels just outside the side entrance of the hotel which leads directly into Shinjuku station - very handy. They even include a travelator in each tunnel.One reason I chose this hotel was that tour companies pick you up directly from the hotel. There are only a few hotels that have this happen. Other hotel guests need to find their way to specific locations for pickup.Wi-Fi was excellent - good coverage, and never had an issue with it at all even though I was on one of the upper floors.

I stayed at this hotel because it was the location of an international conference I was attending. Elite hotels are far better in Japan than anywhere else I've been, and this one did not disappoint. By Japanese standards, the room was enormous. The only reason I don't give this property the very top ranking is that, as good as it is, it's still not quite as impressive as the Prince Sakura Tower hotel across the city. But if I need to stay in Shinjuku again and my trip budget allows it, I'll return here. By the way, Shinjuku is THE place for camera shopping.

This is definitely not a boutique hotel if you are looking for one . It is a huge hotel , not very far from Shinjuku station.many room types. Lounge is lacking warm dishes in contrary to thers hotels this level in Japan.Room was clean with a reasonable size.We had a problem that was solved due to the the help of the front desk manager , Mr. Kento Tsutsui, that was very attentive and helpful.

Stayed at the 39th floor in a Grand premier room newly renovated, clean, relaxing feel, excellent amenities and toiletries. The room had all the convenience you can ask for. They thought of everything. Having a quiet breakfast at the 45th floor by the window was so nice. Breakfast came with the room. Concierge is attentive, patient and very helpful. Lots of choices of restaurants in the hotel. Location 5 mins walk to JR Shinjuku station via 2nd floor of hotel via walkway. Tip stay in newly renovated room. Enjoyed our stay. Will definitely return.

When we considered Keio we had heard and read a few things that did not fill us with confidence, however of the five hotels and ryokans we stayed in (all at same star level) throughout Japan which included ANA Crown, Keio was the best. We were pleasantly surprised. The staff were kind and helpful, rooms were clean and configurable. We would definitely stay here again.

Keio Plaza is located in convenient location in the Shinjuku area. Shinjuku station is around 5 minute walk and there is a wide selection of small restaurants and large department stores walking distance. Hotel itself is clean and functional but not memorable. It has a number of dining options on the premises. It is suitable for large groups and business travellers. Staff is friendly and courteous.

The hotel room is clean, variety of food in their glass buffet which I enjoyed eating with other foreign guest. A friendly hotel, most staff speak and understand English. Sanjuko bus terminal is near.

I used other hotel some time and returned to Keio now to compare. My next visit to Shinjuku will definitely be at Keio if rooms are available. This hotel has some Japanese touch and provides unique experience. It's clean, nice service and good location. It isn't cheap but to my experience nothing in Shinjuku is...I was able to check in early without extra cost and received my non smoking room as expected. I didn't use the roaming phone from the room although it's very nice concept saving your own bill and battery if you feel needing that...

Not a hotel for those with vertigo as rooms in the South Tower start on the 11th Floor but surrounding buildings go some way to counteract the sensation of height. The deluxe twin room was comfortable and well appointed. Breakfast is served in a choice of restaurants on the 2nd floor. After a poor experience on the first morning at the very popular Glass Court restaurant we opted for the nearby Jurin which served similar food to a better standard. The Keio Plaza is well located just 10 minutes walk from Shinjuko Station (where it is sign-posted) and round the corner from a subway station. A big thank you to the reservations staff who went out of their way to ensure that we were allocated the most suitable room throughout our stay.

The hotel situated in the hear of shunjuku. 10minutes walk to station. Just right behind of the hotel across the street. plenty of eatery places. Pleasant room decor with all the facilities needed is in there. Why do I say this? Even the plug converter is ready in drawer. Price: moderate.

Stayed at keio plaza for 1 night before leaving to travel to other states and returned to Tokyo for 2 nights before going home. Were pleasantly surprised on our return trip as we were upgraded to a bigger room. Spacious room by Japanese standards. Housekeeping was good. Room was clean. Hotel rooms are well insulated from traffic noise and from noise from the corridors. Check in and frontline staff were very friendly , efficient and helpful. Nicely located near eating outlets and shops, though not near the train station, nearest station was a 15 minute walk away. The hotel could arrange for a airport shuttle to bring you to the airport (chargeable ) so it's a plus point if you have many pieces of luggage.

Stayed for a business/leisure trip with a group of around 100. The hotel was organized enough to have all our check in information ready when we checked in. Stayed in the West tower on the 23rd floor. My view was the Goverment Building. It was not noisy. The room had a sitting area with a table and 2 chairs, two double beds, enough storage, kettle, coffee, tea, water, fridge, and a full size bathroom. There's also a handy smart phone with Internet that you could use free of charge. However, I also rented my own before I came to Japan and it was at the front desk when I arrived. The staff were fantastic. Friendly and always willing to assist when necessary. They helped me set up my mobile wifi device and sent it back for me. The location is close to the Shinjuku Train station, many restaurants, shopping, and pharmacies. There are a few vending machines as well not too far from the hotel. The only issue was the elevators being a little slow.

From check in to departure the staff friendly helpful and informed. Our room in the South tower 29 floor was spacious we equipped and tastefully decorated with an excellent view The “Handy” mobile phone which is available F.O.C. Including calls is a novel and helpful facility for guests from abroad. The hotel is located in the Shinjuko district which is a great location for shops ,restaurants and Shinjuko station which is reported to be the busiest in the world with train bus and Metro connections everywhere.Don’t miss breakfast in the Glass Court restaurant which mixes Western and Asian food .Delicious

I spent 4 nights at keio plaza as a lux premium guest which entitled me to some privileges including access to the Lux lounge which was a calm refuge from busy Tokyo. There was free coffee cake and snacks and a great view. Highlights of my stay were the sushi restaurant Karagi where the sushi chef prepares the sushi in front of you as well as Yamanani a Teppan Yaki restaurant where I dined on two occasions one dinner and one lunch. First occasion had Hida steak and the second Kobe steak. Both cooked as ordered medium rare, great service and food to accompany such as rice vegetables miso soup. Looking forward to anorpther visit to japan and keio plaza hotel soon

We stayed at this hotel mid-September in a Luxe Plaza King room.We flew into the Narita airport. There are bus's regularly operating from the airport to the hotel - cheap option. There is also a train service - going directly to the Tokyo main station - but if you caught this, you would then need to then catch a subway to Shinjuku station - which could be a hassle during peak periods - this is a cheaper option again. We caught a cab - which was around $250 AUD - not the best choose we have ever made - I would suggest the bus.The hotel itself is slightly impersonal - very large with 2 wings (Premier & South wing). Our accommodation was on the South wing.The room was spacious & well appointed. We had access to the club lounge on the top floor - which gave free drinks from 5pm to 7pm - always a nice way to start the evening! They did not provide breakfast with this service though? I have stayed in club rooms with many hotels - most have a continental breakfast available in the club lounge in the mornings - this was a slight disappointment. The hotel (in the Luxe rooms??) provide a free phone - which was a great advantage. We could take this phone out with us & we would always have internet access, maps & phone if required - this was an excellent touch.The location is what makes this hotel - close to the main subway (the system itself is easy to navigate & easy to use).The hotel is also close to the main districts of Shinjuku. Heaps of restaurants, bars & shopping is a short walk away. Please note, some of these bars & restaurants will not serve you unless you can speak some Japanese - I dont think this is meant to be offensive, but more that they will struggle communicating. Look or ask for English menus to get an idea of which restaurants are suitable.Be prepared for some serious hustle & bussel! Tokyo is extremely busy - it seems 24hrs per day! People everywhere - always! We caught a bullet train (Shinkansen) from Tokyo to Kyoto after our stay. So this was also convenient - we caught a train to Shinagawa station (all bullet trains stop here to / from Tokyo). You can then board a bullet train from there. This was certainly easier than going back into Tokyo main station & boarding there. Again the train service is Japan is easy to navigate & easy to use - but get a JR pass.Overall an excellent stay & I would return.Cheers

I tried to book this hotel and somewhere got switched to CTRIP?? I did not like the whole idea of being switched, but when I read that CTRIP was a mainland China company and that I really did not have a reservation with this hotel, I sort of went bonkers. Did not like the idea at all - my CC info of to a China company that I knew nothing about. I was relieved when I got a message later that my booking did not get confirmed - I hope I am done with with this experience. I am suprised that TripAdvisor allowed this to happen..

I have stayed at the Keio multiple times as well as the Hilton and the Sunroute. The Hilton is nice (big, impersonal, but nice) however, the Keio is closer to the subway station which is a definite plus especially in bad weather. It's quiet, comfortable, clean and convenient. The rooms are attractive--some with spectacular views--bathrooms small in the Japanese way, but don't feel squished. The Sunroute on the other side of the subway station is often less expensive, and is also an absolutely and totally fine place to stay, but the Keio is the more upscale of the two.

Convenient location. Close to subway system. Great accommodations. Excellent room service. Beautiful room. Excellent food. Loved the handy phone. Staff were kind and polite and extremely helpful. I would definitely stay again if I would ever be in Tokyo again.

Great location and views, Staff were friendly, the foyer impressive BUT that's where it ends. Beds were so hard we may as well have slept on the floor. There were no amenities as you would expect in a luxury hotel, only 2 bottles of water in the fridge that you had to pay for, no mini bar and if we needed the porter we had to go back down to the foyer because the phones didn't work. There were no bathroom amenities to speak of, and there was mold on all of the edges of the bath and tiles in the bathroom. The restaurant we ate in French/Italian was charging exorbitant prices for the wine. An ordinary bottle of Jacobs Creek Shiraz sells in Australia for around $10.00 but they were charging over $80.00 AUD. We had a coffee in the coffee lounge before we left and it cost us 1,300yen each, $14.83 AUD each, absolutely outrageous and it wasn't even great coffee. the vending machines sell better tasting coffee than that and it only costs a dollar.Very disappointing.

When planning a trip to Tokyo, I settled on staying in Shinjuku. There are so many choices of hotels in this area, but I finally narrowed it down to two, then selected Keio Plaza Hotel. The main reason I selected this hotel is the fact that we booked two different tours through Viator and one of the tour company's (JTB) bus pick up points was this hotel. The second reason is that the hotel was within walking distance to both a Subway Station (Tochomae) and a Japan Railway Station (Shinjuku Station).I booked two rooms here for 4 adults. 1 was for 7 nights the other for 6 nights as I arrived into Tokyo one day ahead of my family. The first was a room with two twin beds and the second was with one almost queen sized bed. Both rooms were pretty basic, clean and adequate for our needs. The mattress on my bed was on the firm side, I am not sure if they have any other types, I slept good every night. There was enough space for two adults in each room to be comfortable. The bathroom was also basic, shower with an extra deep tub, more so than any other hotel's standard bathtub that I have been to in the US, so if you like a good soak, you can do it here. They also have the toilet with the spray/bidet function on it. The hotel is in the middle of the city, so all views would be a city view and other tall buildings. Our rooms were facing the Metropolitan Government building which is across the street from the front side of the hotel.The room rate was comparable to any similar hotel with similar surroundings. I found it well worth it for the convenient location and the service we received. The hotel has great restaurants and excellent room service. Most of the restaurants were Japanese food, but they did have a Western style breakfast buffet, a Korean restaurant and a French/Italian restaurant. Also a nice bar/lounge. They do have some shops in the lobby and lower lobby including a convenience store and a bakery type shop. If you do not wish to eat in the hotel there are many restaurants within walking distance including a McDonalds and KFC. There is also a grocery store accessible through the Shinjuku Station.The staff at this hotel were outstanding. Very professional and friendly service. Most of the people we interacted with spoke and understood enough English to help us with our needs. I would definitely stay here again if I were to visit Tokyo and I would recommend this hotel to any one who would like to stay in the Shinjuku area.

this is my 2nd time staying in Keio plaza. my first time in the modern tower. the rooms are bigger than the main tower although the view wasnt that great. below is my review for the hotel. i love staying in ths area of shinjukufacilities 5/5: they is a conbini at the ground flour and they even provide a free iphone with which for internet. the staff's english were very goodroom 4/5: the standard room was very large. the furniture were modern and new. the bathroom is typical size for japan hotel. the bed was comfortable but could be better.Location 5/5: lots of restaurants nearby, a yodobashi only a 5 minutes walk, a peaceful park across the street for jogging, a subway across the street, a near shinjuku station. Plus being opposite City hall it is undoubtedly safe to walk at night.breakfast 5/5: there are two cafes for breakfast. the american style and Japanese style. the american style cafe is most modern has different set of menu (only western food). i prefer the Japanese style cafe which has both western n Japanese breakfasts.
user_name:
Abdulrahman92
Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan, Malaysia

review_body: The hotel is a short walk from the lively and beautiful streets of Senjuku District. The standard room is quite small and basic but comfortable. Breakfast is very good and offers a variety of choices. The buffet style was excellent too. Room service and cleanliness are perfect.

We were travelling as a family of three adults, so we were pleased to find that our room was spacious enough for us to avoid getting under each other's feet. The bathroom was a good size, with a laundry line over the bathtub if needed. We had a good view of the tall buildings of Shinjuku from our large window. The hotel provided everything we needed, from a mobile phone we could take out with us for the day, to a convenience store which sold late-evening snacks. The breakfast buffet was extremely adequate, with Western and Asian choices, and Mozart's music playing in the background. Twice we were seated at a table overlooking the garden next to the street, which was very pleasant. There is a long, covered walkway between the hotel and Shinjuku Station, with a travellator if you happen to be going in the right direction. We used the walkway a couple of times, but the really convenient station is Tochomae, an entrance to which is right under the hotel. The Keio Plaza Hotel was a great home-base for our exploration of Tokyo. We would certainly choose to stay there again.

Keio Plaza Hotel was our home base in Tokyo. I cannot say enough good things about this hotel. Rooms: The triple room actually has three beds unlike most of the other hotels which had twin beds and a roll out bed. The room was spacious by Tokyo standards. The shower had excellent water pressure which made it hard to get out of the shower every day. The water heated up quickly too. All the usual toiletries were provided including shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, hand wash soap, shower cap, cotton swabs, toothbrush etc. but they went the extra step and also provided things like hair ties (our whole group of ladies forget to bring any so we appreciated it), razor with shower cream and after shave, and even a room/linen freshener spray. There are pajama/robes and slippers too. The lighting was well thought out including a dim lamp that can be used as a nightlight. There are outlets at the bedside. Location: The closest station is Shinjuku which will take you to all over Tokyo and also the airport via the Narita Express. If you have tons of luggage, the walk from Shinjuku Station will feel endless but with your hands free it's an easy walk. Along the way there is a small convenience store for buying snacks and water. There is also a small convenience store on the 2nd floor of the hotel, which we didn't discover until the last night. About a 3 minute walk will take you to an area with tons of restaurants and 5 minutes will get you to a big mall. Service: Check-in both times was so smooth. There is never a line because as soon as you step up, there is a worker who will discreetly call someone on a walkie-talkie to come out to the desk to help you. They take your credit card info at check-in and charge you when you check out. The bell boys are really sweet and will explain everything to you in the room. Their English is so good, even better than the front desk crew. I was really impressed during our second check-in when my friend pulled out our baggage ticket and out of nowhere someone came running over to take it and go retrieve our luggage. The bell captain desk staff helped us google some things and gave cab drivers explicit instructions for where we wanted to go. Lastly, Sunrise Tours (booked through Japanican) has an office inside the hotel and pickup is inside Keio hotel, which saves an hour of having to be picked up from other hotels. There is also a complimentary Disney shuttle which is very convenient. It does fill up so reserve in advance. On the way back we wanted to come back on an earlier shuttle than what we had reserved. We just lined up at that shuttle time and since there was space, they let us board. My friend used the laundry service which was very expensive but punctual. We had a package delivered while we were away in Kyoto and the front desk held it for us until we came back. Last but not least, they provide you with a smartphone to use during the stay, which was incredibly helpful. We used it to navigate wherever we went and you can call to US for free. You can definitely find a cheaper hotel in Tokyo but I would absolutely stay here again. I loved our room, which felt like home and the location is so convenient. Plus the added bonuses of the Disney shuttle, tour location pick up, and the free smartphone made it worth the stay.

We stayed at Keio Plaza Shinjuku again after a few years gap. We stayed here about 7 years ago and have ventured into other Tokyo locations since then. But our revisit to Keio Plaza has pleasantly surprised us. 1st of all, the staff are professional, pleasant and friendly especially, the trainees who manned their front desk and concierge area. They are helpful and vibrant and full of energy . The senior duty managers are not as friendly as they should have (unfortunately). May be? they are 'managers' and they failed to point us to the appropriate restaurant. But all in all, their service is first class . 2nd of all, the location is perfectly and conveniently located. Less than 10 mins walk to the Shinjuku station (west gate) and there are tons of restaurants and shops along the road leading to the hotel. This is crucial for family with young children and family ( seniors) as it feels safe and has abundance to do along the short walk. Last but not least, they have more than 6 restaurants inside the hotel, their room service is also excellent and their convenience shop is just GREAT and opening hours is from 5 am to 2am ( can you actually believe that?) they have set a gold standard for 'hotel convenience shop'! The room size is great and one has sufficient spaces for many many pieces of Luggages! And the airport limousine service is perfect! Punctual and great service!I would recommend Keio Plaza to all visitors with family esp if one is looking for convenience, family friendliness and security. They may not be modernity designed and can have a more retro feel (70s design) but just love their marbles layered floors! Please enjoy he stay! It won't disappoint you!

Almost got a perfect score from me - great service, good attention to detail, my room was cleaned twice a day! Bed was comfortable, bathroom a tad small but it's Asia, great location near lots of quality restaurants and shops in Shinjuku. Will say food was "OK" but I was kinda spoiled with other amazing food in the area. Would certainly stay here again.

A very nice and big hotel. The location is not bad and it is walking far from center of shinjuku and not such a long ride to shibuya. The staff is very nice and welcoming, they helped us making our daily schedule pretty good. Taking the premium room is recommended because it gives you an access to the sky lounge which is open most of the day and offers drinks and good snacks. The staff there is very helpful. Additionally, breakfast is served in the premium lounge for those who reserve premium rooms.

The hotel is a convenient to Shinjuku station, a major transport hub. However, if you are pulling luggage, be prepared for a bit of a journey. If it's raining, probably best to take a taxi from the station. The area surrounding it is rather soulless government buildings, but directly between the hotel and station is a bustling area full of restaurants, shops and a few bars. The room size was good, for Tokyo.The staff spoke reasonable English and were efficient. We had arranged to have a mobile wifi and JR Railpass delivered there and all happened just fine.If you are having breakfast as part of your package, make sure you have it at the Japanese restaurant, not the Western 'super buffet'. The buffet is fine, but you could get it at 10,000 hotels. The Japanese bento box style breakfast was beautiful - a great experience.

Location is good which allows you to get connect with shopping, dinning and to the train station with walking distance.There is an airport bus service, that is one of the reasons I pick this hotel. The room is spacious, unlike other hotels in Tokyo, you can never open the luggage in the room.
user_name:
babadogcat
Hong Kong, null, Hong Kong

review_body: The hotel is great and offers a lot. It is huge and has many restaurants inside. The hotel is within a walking distance from the center of shinjuku. My family and I stayed for 5 days and we upgraded to the premium rooms. This was very comfortable because we could've entered to the lounge in the highest floor. This gave us the option to eat breakfast there with a little bit more privacy and also just stay there throughout the day and have a drink. The hotel is very big and the lobby is even bigger, It has 4 exits so make sure you know where you're going.

Keio Plaza is a great hotel. Staff are very helpful and courteous. Spoilt for choice of restaurants - Korean, Chinese, Italian and Japanese. Very easy to get around from here. Walking distance to train but also easy to get taxis. Loved the heated toilet seats!

The location was very good , It was a many storied, with a very spacious L shaped lobby, It seemed to be a very busy hotel , with many groups coming in & out of the lobby , but they were dealt with promptly & very courteously. We had a very comfortable standard room. The bathroom had all amenities with the famous Japanese robo toilet .The breakfast was amazing with three restaurants , a pure Japanese , a continental & a one which had a mixed type of breakfast . We stayed for three nights & found it to be very convenient & comfortable and would definitely stay there again. And of course there was a very good & free wifi .so you are always in touch with your family .

Just back from six days at Keio Plaza Hotel. Had a great stay. The room is large and very well fitted out with everything you need. We stayed on 25th floor of south tower. The hotel is near the shopping and restaurant area of Shinjuku and Shinjuku station. Staff are very helpful. All went like clockwork. We had the western breakfast buffet some mornings which was average but acceptable.

My partner and I stayed at the Keio Plaza for 5 nights as part of our Japan tour package. Our room, especially the bathroom was rather dated but functional and comfortable. This is a huge hotel that caters for tour groups and has many restaurant options all of which are pricey. Breakfast was over $30 AUD per head. Service was overall good.The best feature of the hotel is its location being in the heart of Shinjuku and close to the busy underground train station. There are plenty of shops and restaurants just a block away so you are spoilt for choice.

We stayed 3 nights at this hotel on a family holiday. Perfect & very central location in Shinjuku. Walking distance to underground & train stations, shopping centre & tons of restaurants. The hotel is quite dated but excellent service plus so organised. One of our rooms was a triple room - which had 3 proper beds rather then one rollaway one. Clean, comfortable & very efficient. Airport bus departs from our hotel & its a brilliant service to Haneda.Would highly recommend this hotel.

Our hotel room at the Keio Plaza was generically nice and comfortable - and not the shoebox I was expecting. The only notable elements were the extremely dedicated concierges who tried (and failed) to make us reservations at various Michelin star restaurants (we were already weeks too late) - and the small mechanical bull stationed in the gym. Maybe it’s for ab work-outs? It didn’t seem to be doing anything when I rode it for a bit.I also found the mattress to be weirdly hard -- like futon-style. Tip: Don’t flop onto your mattress face-first and expect to be met with cushy softness. The hotel is also connected to tons of shops and restaurants -- so you can comfortably get food and wander around when it's cold outside.

This is a lovely hotel close to shopping district of Shinjuku and the train station. It has 45 floors and great views on that level where there is a bar and restaurant. We had one expensive drink only but couldn't have afforded a "session". We had an executive suite on the 36th floor and had fantastic views. It's not cheap but I think Tokyo is probably pretty expensive generally anyway. There's local shops and cafes 5 minutes away out the back of the hotel and across the road. The concierge didn't tell us about this area though which was definitely patronised by locals , and directed us up the road 10 or 15 minutes instead. Possibly they were thinking we wanted western style restaurants although we had asked for "cheap and cheerful". Maybe that got lost in translation. We found the local area on our own and it was very interesting. There are some homeless people living in boxes etc under a bridge 7 minutes away but we didn't feel at all threatened. Staff at hotel were very polite and generally helpful- one customer service lady was especially good in helping us recover something left on a plane. One restaurant guy was surly at breakfast and also at one dinner we had there. The older checkout guy did his job but wasn't as friendly and pleasant as I would have expected as I paid my $2600 bill. But the checkin guy was great. Overall a very nice hotel.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza during the Tokyo Marathon Weekend, hotel was sold out and very busy, however were very accommodating and looking to assist where ever they could. The restaurants are fabulous on site and in the direct vicinity of the hotel itself. Location is close to lots of places for shopping with public transportation within walking distance to take you to the popular tourist attractions quite easily. No hotel shuttle from the airport so you need to take an airport limobus.

What a great hotel! We were here for business, and we had a great time. 5 minutes from the station, so this made it very easy to make our way around town and to the places that we needed to go. I enjoyed my time.

We stayed here for a week and the staff were wonderful. Our room was immaculately clean, linens of highest quality and bed very comfortable. We attended 3 different banquets/receptions and the food was beautifully presented, delicious, plentiful and suitable for both Eastern and Western tastes. The concierges were particularly helpful. They provided detailed explanations of how to get to the many destinations I had in mind and made some suggestions of their own.

The hotel is only 5 mins away from Shinjuku Station. There are also malls nearby the hotel but they open at 10am. Starbucks is only few steps away from the hotel. The hotel is very big with north wing and south wing. Plus, it has its own convenience store and boutique. The room is fine but not that big. It has mini bar, coffee and tea station and a television. Bathroom is also ok. The good thing is that you can also have your tour booked at the hotel but needs one day reservation. You can also have your breakfast at 3 restaurants: International Restaurant, Japanese Restaurant and I forgot the other restaurant. If i remember correctly? One breakfast buffet is 3,000 yen. The food is ok complete with tea and coffee.

Keio Plaza hotel is 5 mins walk from shinjuku station, it has more than 1000 rooms so the lobby is spacious.We have stayed in south tower, being upgraded to luxe double which is on 30th floor with complimentary lounge access. We have stayed for deluxe room before and found that luxe double has a lot of more warm settings, e.g. The shampoo shower gel are more premium (made in japan vs made in china), extra lady skincare set (4 packs), premium comb and even the sofa is in more sharp color!! Shower is very nice as the water pressure is strong enough for u to relax. Luxe double room is highly recommended!!! The lounge is on 34th floor with amazing views!! Lots of choices of juice and beer available! The most impressive is we stayed here for our anniversary and the hotel arranged a very sweet and lovely decoration for us!! We love it so much!! This made a good memory for our anniversary trip in Tokyo!!Highly recommend Keio Plaza Hotel!!

My wife and I stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel for four nights at the end of August. The hotel is in an excellent location - a comfortable distance to Shinjuku station with covered walkways the whole way. The room was spacious (read huge) and clean with modern enough furnishings and air con.Where five star hotels tend to stand out, and what justifies the price, is the level of service and amenities. Check in did not go smoothly, taking about 30 minutes with the clerk seeming to struggle with the reservation despite finding the booking straight away. I can excuse this as a one off, however everyone in our group experienced similar hassles. Once we got to the room the wifi didn't work, with the server being too busy. Again these things happen but advising to try again in ten minutes isn't great service when it's still not up 2 hours later. Better to admit you don't know when it will be back up!We had the buffet breakfast at Jurin each morning. The selection of food was great, however not all of the hot food was great (especially the scrambled eggs).
