The other disappointment was the exorbitant fee to use the pool, and the drink prices at the sky lounge - ¥1350 for a small tap beer is ridiculous.I don't usually whinge about hotels however this place really disappointed us and was not as enjoyable as other five star hotels. I definitely don't think it justified the price (better experiences at 3 star hotels), and I will be looking elsewhere on my next visit to Tokyo.

I stayed for 3 nights for business. I had a superior twin room with lots of space. Everything was fine. Clean and comfortable. The holes was built in the early 70s, apparently originally tallest structure in Tokyo for a couple of years. Notwithstanding its age it is pretty well maintained. A real positive was the free Handy Phones in the rooms . In effect a smart phone available calls navigation around the city etc at no extra charge. Not sure if this is std in Japan, but I found it incredibly useful.Other wise no issues,I agree with other comments that there are long lines for breakfast, it's not worth the wait, wonder down the street.Yes would stay here again. Regards J

We stayed 4 nights at the Keio Plaza Hotel and found out about their Japanese Tea Ceremony Experience from their web site. We made reservations for the tea ceremony for our family of four with the Concierge (the limit is four per group so this turned out to be a private event for us). We were warmly greeted and hosted by Teamaster Yano - she made the experience so educational, absorbing and serene. We opted for the traditional Japanese tea ceremony which took place in the tatami room. She presented each of us with wagashi then prepared thin-style matcha tea. We learned to appreciate the room's alcove, tatami mats, the tea bowls and so much else. Immense praise for Teamaster Yano.

I usually stayed at Hilton Tokyo and decided to change this time around to try Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo for 4 nights. It really lived up to my expectations as the hotel room had a beautiful view of the city and was also convenient to walk to Shinjuku station.

Brilliant place to stay with all the things you need. Only drawback is the smoking floor does smell heavily. Easy to get to and very polite staff.Room comes with a universal power adaptor for your needs. Restaurants and shops downstairs which I didn't use myself but convenient. Right accross the street from all the shops and underpass to trains. Being my first time in Japan definitely one of the best places all around and hotel location helped a lot.

This hotel is well located within easy walking distance to Shinjuku while far enough away to escape the noise. A very large hotel the rooms were reasonable size but still on the small side. Our check in staff were fantastic and gave us early access to our room after we had travelled all night to get there. This apparently is something they don't normally do so was much appreciated. Food and drink in the hotel was extremely expensive so I would suggest popping down the road which gave more options at a much more reasonable price Having said that we did eat at the all day fining restaurant one evening and the food was good and the service very good but for a more authentic Japanese meal you do need to leave the hotelWe enjoyed our stay here but it is such a large hotel it was not always easy to get around or in a lift Having said that it did the job for us for our four nights in Shinjuku

This was a great hotel to stay at in Shinjiku! The rooms were very spacious for Japan and super clean! We were also impressed with the amenities! We were also so close to everything and many entry points to the Shinjiku station.The gym was great to have but a bit small and limited. Staff was very friendly!

Really love this hotel!! Huge hotel with super nice staff, great location, clean room and last but not least amazing breakfast. Can choose 1 of 3 option and all is good so many food varieties. Just have to patient to get a seat because too many people waiting. The starting point bus to go to mount Fuji also form here so its very convenient.Perfect!!

I stayed about for days in this Hotel during a business trip to Japan, in two separate periods: location is awesome, in the center of Shinjuko, served by Limousine Bus (connecting Narita and Haneda airports at a very competitive prices, comparable/cheaper than trains) and 5 minutes walk away from Shinjuku station. The hotel is luxurious, offering many different level of rooms and services. I went at first for a premium room in the South Tower and then I choose an entry level room which was excellent as well. Personnel is extremely professional, helpful and friendly. The quality of the rooms and their cleanliness are exemplary. Unbeatable price to quality ratio. Definitely suggested!

My husband and I did a short getaway to Tokyo and could not believe we had waited so long to visit this city.We booked a room on one of the Plaza Lounge floors in the South Tower and we had a view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building and on clear days, Mt Fuji. We also had access to the Plaza Lounge. In the mornings this meant being able to have coffee and small cakes. In the evenings, it meant unlimited access (for a period of 2 hours) to alcohol such as sake and Japanese whisky (very dangerous) while enjoying the Tokyo sunset.The hotel was in an excellent location and we were able to find amazing restaurants within a short walking distance. The hotel staff were also very nice and helped us with reservations.

Very good hotel. God location, clean, ambience everything awesome! Upper floor window view fantastic. Good breakfast. The hotel may offer complementary swimming pool for guests. They charge Y 2000 from guest! Altogether, Great Stay @ Business Center of Tokyo.

Great location! Easy assess to shinjuku station and the shopping districts as well as food districts! The hotel also have a shuttle bus to disney land and disney sea it has everything you need near by like the convenient stalls and if u get hungry at night there is are restaurants near by which open 24hours .

We had a standard double room which was quite a good size and amenities were good. Location is great for exploring Shinjuku and not far from Shinjuku Station. Buffet breakfast had adequate selection in the two restaurants we went into. Small souvenier and grocery type shop. Reception staff efficient, but not overly friendly. View of city and on one fine day to Mt Fuji!

We found the staff exceptionally helpful and gracious. They were helpful in setting up tours and pointing out and directing us to local attractions. The entrances and exits are quite confusing and should be better marked but overall a good experience.
user_name:
cjm108
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is quite big and has many restaurant options as well a convenience store. It is a short walk to Shinjuku Station and the many eateries nearby. It's also just across the road from the Tokyo Metropolitan building which has free views of Tokyo. The room itself is very comfortable and provides great amenities to make your stay a pleasant one.

We stayed in the south tower on the 24th floor. The room was a decent size and clean.However, the overall levels of service left a lot to be desired. The English level of some of staff was variable (one enquiry on how to get to the National Museum was met with a look of puzzled bewilderment as if we had just asked about day trips to Pyongyang) and we had all sorts of trouble just sorting out an executive membership card and membership points. Although the staff are polite and bowed a lot, we found often they would say the first thing that occurred to them when dealing with an issue. This meant we had to make 4 separate visits to reception to get our membership card and then we had a further problem of getting the proper amount of points credited. This involved a further visit and emails that continued after we left. This is not the sort of service you expect from a 5 star hotel. In the course of this, we also learnt that if you spend enough to go to a higher membership level (as we comfortably did) then this will not be effective for 2 months and so you get no benefit from spending more money. Quite extraordinary.We guess that the main aim of this hotel is not to cater for individual travellers but large convention style groups (there were two such groups during our stay) with a corresponding emphasis on quantity not quality.There is a convenience store in the hotel but this (in our view) was overpriced. Less than 100 ms from the hotel is a Lawson convenience store (near to an area full of restaurants and next to the post office). This is a much better bet for buying everyday stuff.

There are endless entrances to this hotel, on different street levels. We entered at what we assumed to be the main entrance only to find later that this is Floor 3 of the hotel. We were quickly booked in and shown to our room by a delightful busboy (actually a female) the room was quite spacious with twin beds and en-suit. We were accommodated in the south tower. Staff were pleasant and helpful. Bags have been sent to Kyoto.

Its a great property at a great location in Tokyo. Walking distance from the Shinjuku station and lots of eateries around as well. The hotel has excellent restaurants and wonderful and smiling staff. It has a good convenience store for those midnight snacks. The rooms are very good sized as compared to most other hotels in Tokyo.

Incredibly friendly staff, most spoke English. Great on site restaurants. Several tours depart from this hotel, so can be busy in early morning. A couple of blocks from JR line, easy walk. Some nice areas to visit outside the hotel.

Business trip in August, summer time. Awful check in experience as lobby was crowded, queue was long to check in (30 minutes). I had time to observe the surrounding since the queue was long. Mismatched cheap looking furniture (chairs and random layout of tables for brochures and maps!), trolleys lined all over the place. Got assigned to South tower and queued for 20 minutes to reach the elevator, subsequently got squashed into the elevator as everyone tried to get in so they don't wait any longer. I learnt afterwards that the hotel has a teacher student convention of about 800 people, and part of the lifts was under maintenance. It's really bad to host something so big but yet be so unprepared for it. The wifi also drops alot - not good for business users. Had the option of 3 restaurants for breakfast so thank goodness while all the tourist crowd rushed for the 2 other international/american buffet , I had pleasant breakfast at the Japanese restaurant. I wished they offered different sides to their set breakfast though cos I had it for 3 days in a row. Nevertheless the quality was good at the breakfast. They could have serving staff that smiled more to make it a better experience. The Aurora(not sure if that's the name) lounge on the 54th floor was not bad, limited food choices for snacks with drinks. Good to have a convenience store to buy drinks / snacks on level 2. Expensive room service menu. Big comfortable room and bed and bathroom. Basic in-room facilities. As with most hotels, an underpowered hair dryer for me but that's just me. No ironing board in-room so quite inconvenient for business travellers with business shirts / suits . Conveniently located at Shinjuku station. And opposite this building called Mitsui Building with like 50 restaurants / cafes in it, cross the road, 1 minute and we can get to it. That's the best part since the hotel has limited affordable food options.

Staff are very friendly and efficient, and all speak good English. Rooms are all you could want and are maintained, restocked well. The only thing I found unusual was the abscence of coffee sachets. They only supply tea in the room category we booked. This was remedied by buying prepacked sets of coffee,sugar, milk from the store on a lower level. From this Hotel it is an easy walk to many, many resturants. There are great department stores with amazing food halls close by too. Overall a pleasant stay.

I stayed many times at Keio before, and this time I stayed at the newly renovated club floor and wanted to enjoy the new club lounge. Over the years I always stayed in Plaza Premier room with about 34 square meters. It is a spacious room by any Tokyo standard.This time I stayed at the Premier Grand room, a newly renovated room from Plaza Premier. The washroom is modernized. The new toilet is separated from the shower and bathtub. The new shower room has an electric curtain separating it from the beds, apart from the glass window. Toiletries are up scale L'occitane. New gadgets include a bluetooth speaker and an online tablet. The closet is reduced in size. What I liked most is that the new USB sockets and electric sockets are installed on the table top, making charging mobile phones much easier. The new control panel besides the bed makes switching lights easier. But unfortunately the dressing table is gone, too bad for the ladies.The club floor is located on the 45th floor, facing west. If I remember correctly there was no club facility before. The lounge has a relatively low usage. It occupied quite a big area and is well-appointed. Snacks are minimal though of high quality. The new Premier Grand room is about 25% more expensive than the original Plaza Premier room so one has to decide whether it is worth for the extra money.

From the lobby to the Guest room, Keio Plaza was a treat. Options of Restaurants, and the spread was impressive. Rooms were comfortable and spacious. Location was an added advantage as one could step out and be in the shopping hub in 10 minutes flat. Staff was very helpful and pleasing.

Great staff (concierge, registration, transportation), amazing breakfast buffets, amenities, proximity to shopping and train station. Hotel arranged for airport transfer and transpiration to and from Disney which were reliable and very punctual. Love the yukatas and bath products.Great room service.

Yes, the hotel is in a great location... convenient to the train station, shopping, restaurants & night life. However, what is unique is the excellent service prevalent throughout the whole staff. From checking in, to the bellhop, the cleaning staff, concierge, everyone is polite & eager to help. An added bonus is the free shuttle to both the Disney Sea & Disneyland. The buses are on schedule & cuts on transportation time & costs. We will continue to make this our one stop when visiting the Tokyo area.

Some institutions are always at the top because they just know how to please the customer. The Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku is a hallmark of great service, great choice and availability of restaurants on site and shopping in one of Tokyo's most popular areas. The rooms are functional with solid but not flashy amenities. There are great choices for breakfast including an American-style buffet or separate traditional Japanese breakfast. There are Greek, Teppan-yaki, Korea and Italian restaurants onsite as well as a well stocked convenience store and beauty parlor for your convenience. The hotel has a very attentive staff with multi-lingual capabilites and are committed to your enjoying everything about your stay and experience in Tokyo.

I chose this hotel for its location close to Shinjuku Station. It was an easy 10 minute walk. I was traveling solo and they upgraded me to a room on the 35th floor in one of their Premier Plaza rooms. Overall, I found my room to be very comfortable. It had two twin beds, which would be something to pay attention to when reserving. I was there alone and had booked a room with a single larger bed, but I wasn't bothered by this. The bathroom was really nice, though the rest of the furniture was worn around the edges. Still pleasant, though. The view was fantastic. I had views of the Cocoon and NTT Docomo skyscrapers. The sky lounge really has some nice views, and if you want a table by the window, I'd recommend reserving beforehand. I didn't eat at all in the hotel. Overall, I'd say this was about the room was about the standard of a nice midrange hotel in the U.S. with better and more attentive service and great views.

Keio has everything you could ask for. It has big rooms with well equipped bathrooms, and views of the city through large windows. There is an observation deck in the main tower on the 43rd (?) floor where you can get a view of Tokyo skyline for free.It is right in the heart of Shinjuku, and only a quick walk away from the train station. Really pleasant stay and would definitely come again.

We had a room on 29th floor. Largish room. Bathroom small and cheap fittings. Plastic tiles on wall and door. Must be a Japanese thing. Great breakfast and lovely restaurants on 7th floor. Must visit sky bar on 49th floor which is lovely. Little expensive there at £300 a night but we are in Tokyo. Wierdist thing was not allowed in the pool if you have tattoos! Also a charge of 2000 yen to use the hotel pool which is about £13

The hotel is nice and is very close to transit and shopping. Unfortunately staff would do nothing to help when we we mistakenly put into a smoking room, and the smell was absolutely terrible. Otherwise the room was comfortable. There is a variety of options for dining, and the hotel also has very good room service.

I enjoyed my four days at the Keio Plaza Hotel. Tokyo is such an awesome city!Location: The hotel is situated in Shinjuku, and it is very close to the subway station and restaurants. Hotel room: It was kind of small but comfortable. Some stains in the carpet. The bathroom was small though.Customer service: Staff was polite. No complaints.Because the hotel was big, there were a lot of people in the lobby, especially in the mornings.It is a very nice hotel. I would book it again!

This is my second stay at Keio Plaza Hotel. Rooms have been renovated and sport a refreshing decor. Hotel staff are knowledgeable, courteous and fluent in English. Very accessible to shops, department stores, subway stations and small restaurants. A very good hotel to stay at if you want to be in Shinjuku.

Keio Plaza Hotel has perfect location in Tokyo, across to Tokyo Metropolitan Government, near to Shinjuku metro station, shopping malls. Rooms are clean, Staff is so nice, goodhumored and one of the best thing is that you can find 3 breakfast type (international, American and Japanese).

We stayed at a high floor on the south tower. It was quiet and the room quality was good. They have all the standard proper items like kettle, cups and utensils, free bottled water, hair dryer, and an elaborate personal hygiene set. This hotel has very good restaurants. The Japanese breakfast set (not main breakfast buffet), the udon set (level 1 downstairs), the soba tempura, and the heavenly Kobe beef teppanyaki. It's a short walk to the main Shinjuku station so it's very convenient. Avoid traveling during weekday peak hours unless you want to experience being squeezed into an overcrowded train. Overall a very good hotel.

We stayed here recently for 3 nights after a cruise and thoroughly enjoyed our stay. I am a full-time wheelchair user and requested a universal room. This was very clean and well equipped and I asked for a view and was on the 30th floor which we enjoyed. The room had a double bed with a back raiser and a large single bed for my daughter. There was plenty of space to move around. The bathroom was not large nor did it have a roll in shower but there was so much extra equipment supplied that we managed well. The toileteries were plentiful and of good quality. The hotel was also totally accessible with very helpful and friendly staff who seemed to be able to provide written assistance no matter what the question. The hotel had a large number of restaurants serving various menus and these seemed very popular with none residents too. There was also a well stocked convenience store within the hotel selling food.The large Shinduku railway station was nearby and easy to use and also contained numerous and excellent food stalls. The department stalls near the station also had food courts in their basements supplying good and plentiful prepared and none prepared items. A great hotel and one that we look forward to returning to.

Stayed here for 2 nights and the location was a bit away from the main attractions with a nice 10 mins walk to the subway station, with several shops and restaurants on the way. The hotel was huge and the room was spacious as well as the bathroom. But don't expect any nice view as the hotel is surrounded by office towers. There were several restaurants that offered breakfast but one that offered both Western and Asian food was always crowded and needed to wait in line for ard 20 mins. The food there was quite good and has lot of choices.The staff was friendly and helpful. Airport express bus stopped right in front of the hotel that took about 70 mins to Narita airport.

My daughters and I stayed at this hotel in late June of this year(2017). First of all, the service of this hotel was outstanding. The first day we arrived, we wanted to eat at a shabu shabu restaurant that was not too far away, so I went down to the concierge to get some assistance. The gentleman who was at the desk started searching on his computer, came up with one and discovered that it was booked. He didn't give up though, he decided to call and ask. Guess what? They had a reservation that was perfect for us. He went above and beyond for us, which we greatly appreciated. It was raining one morning and we had no umbrellas. I asked the bell guy if he had any and he just coughed 3 over without asking any questions - just like that! The rooms were clean, nice and had a wonderful view. The only gripe I had with the room was that our room had 3 beds which was great, but they were either double or queens and that crowded the room a bit. Not a huge issue. I did love the vanity in the closet area. It allowed me to put on make up while my daughters got ready in the bathroom. One more issue I had with this hotel, which is quite big since I've traveled to a few places in the world and never had this arise, but in order to use their pool, you had to pay about $20.00 US. I really think they should change this policy. It's quite absurd. Needless to say, we didn't use their pool, although we really wanted to, but I couldn't justify paying $60.00 to use a pool. Overall, this hotel was pleasant and plush. I would recommend it most definitely!:)

Keio Plaza Hotel is a nice hotel and though our rooms were comfortable and clean, looked a bit worn. The location is close to Shinjuku Station if you don't mind walking about a mile. There are many restaurants near by and a coffee shop across the street. We purchased breakfast included for the convenience. It was a bit expensive to do so but the food was very good and you could choose between 3 restaurants to go to. There was a wide selection of dishes at two of the buffet restaurants and the Japanese breakfast restaurant was a visual and delicious treat. They offer afternoon high tea at the Sky Lounge but book ahead. We could not get in the day we went. This hotel has beautiful artwork on display, classes offered for a fee, a few stores to shop at, plenty of restaurants to go to without leaving the hotel, fitness center and other amenities.

Keio Plaza Tokyo is located across the road behind Kadoya hotel ie slightly further from Shinjuku station but still within 10min walking distance. It is not in the bustling center of shinjuku so environment is quiet. There are restaurants, shops & convenient stores between hotel & station. We stayed in the twin sharing room in the main tower and requested for newer (renovated) room at check in. Our room is spacious, clean & had the view of Tokyo metropolitan government building nearby. We are satisfied with the room though it's not the most comfortable bed I have slept in a hotel and it's not cheap. Will most probably stay in other hotels in my next trip.Note: we get 10% discount for breakfast buffet in the hotel, costs around 2800yen and we thought it was average in terms of varieties and taste.

I have stayed twice at this hotel. I love the shuttle bus is very convenience from Haneda international airport or from Haneda domestic airport ....they both have hotel shuttle bus that go directly to the hotel lobby. Saves me a lot of hassle as I'm traveling Solo.Room size is good and tradition japanese breakfast was so good. Location is the best ....it's just about 10-20mins to everything in Shinjuku!!!! Lots of eateries around !!! A Lawson And a pharmacy are just nearby . Keio plaza dept and other departments are just within walking distances. Highly recommended !!!!Will come back again in September with the hubby !!!!!
user_name:
GohPauline1200
Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei Darussalam

review_body: A tour and travel choosing this hotel for us during our Japan's tour last month and it is a nice and very big hotel which located at famous Shinjuku area (only a few minutes walk to Shinjuku shopping and restaurant area). there area 3 type of restaurant for breakfast (Glass court - serve Japanese and western, Jurin - Serve contenental, Kagari - serve Kagari set menu) and the most popular is Glass Court - it could be a long queue.

The hotel is way more expensive than its standard merits. Cheaper, better and more modern options are readily available in Shinjuku. Decided to stay at Keio as part of our honeymoon, and chose the hotel in part because of the pool. Except you need to pay 2000 yen/person/day (about $18) to access it, in addition to the room! Not OK.

Its a very grand hotel, very helpful courteous staff. The rooms were very comfortable with good quality linen and toiletries The hotel's location is very close the subway and also a stop for the airport express bus. Very highly recommended.

The hotel is conveniently located to Shinjuku shops and restaurants. The hotel staff is very helpful and polite. The hotel is rated as a 5-star hotel, but when compared to others in its class, Keio Plaza ranks 4 - 4.5-star at best.

Perfect location! Closed station(5mins walk),shopping heaven, many restaurants.Highly recommended if you would love to stay in the city!! Very clean and great buffet breakfasts! I stayed in rainy day, bellboy lend me an umbrella. Very appreciated!!!

This is a big and popular hotel. Check in was quick when I got there. Very helpful with our baggage. We stayed at the South tower, not too far from the lobby. The main tower lifts are right beside the lobby but I don't mind the extra walk to the South tower. Room is big considering Japan standards. Kept clean with lots of hotel amenities. We paid extra for the lounge access on the top floor. View was great, can see the Tokyo Sky Tree from there. Depending on the time, they served different snacks and drinks (5-7pm, they have beer!) Location wise is awesome! Close to the different subways, yummy restaurants and malls. All within walking distance.

We stayed at Keio Plaza for six nights from 26.6.17 - 2.7.17 (including 2 nights in Hello Kitty Princess Room) during our family holiday to Japan. We really loved the hotel, Rooms were very spacious, clean with great views. Staff were very friendly and helpful. Location is very convenient, as public transport and good restaurants are just around the corner. Hello Kitty Princess room was great surprise for our daughter and she loved it a lot! The complimentary Hello Kitty doll was a great gift for her. We would also like to specially mention about two female staff (unfortunately can't remember their names) who served us 'in room breakfast' on 1.7.17, they were extremely helpful and we were really touched by their hospitality.Would highly recommend this hotel and would love to stay there again in future

Stayed 5 nights for a family trip. The plaza twin room was very spacious and a plus in Tokyo. Hotel is within 8 minutes walk to JR Shinjuku station with lots of shops and restaurants along the way. There is a food stall along the road after 8:30pm too. The airport bus stops right in front of the hotel and great with luggage. Took about 35 minutes from Haneda airport terminals. Free shuttle to Disneyland and it would be great with kids.The only thing to criticise, if any, is that the bathroom entrance was a sloped steel plate. I almost slipped once with dry feet. The furnishings are old style hotels and not modern. But you get plenty of toiletries of the S brand. Rooms are clean. Breakfast can be chosen from 3 restaurants. Glass court with both western and Japanese buffet, Jurin with western buffet and a Japanese set breakfast. The Japanese breakfast also offers free flow coffee, tea and juices which is nice and not common. I would like the buffet food to come with more variety and change. Since the food are quite the same each day. Hotel staff are generally polite and helpful. I personally think Keio Plaza is a good hotel but I may not come to Tokyo for a trip due to the almost scary crowd. Good hotel and would be better if you plan to go to Disneyland.

This hotel was nicely situated in Shinjuku. However it is a very large convention style hotel with little warmth or ambiance. The hotel was clean and near Shinjuku station. The food in the restaurants was fair and not noteworthy and the the Concierge spoke little English and it was difficult to discuss possible places of interest outside the hotel. And, I got on the wrong elevator and did get lost as I was on the right floor but wrong tower ! Who knew!!

Fantastic location! Very near the metropolitan buildings which on a clear day give you spectacular views of the city. The location also provides you peace and quiet when you want to rest and relax but near enough to go to the wonderful shops and delicious restaurants around Shinjuku. The hotel is also near Shinjuku train station if you want to venture out. They are also very generous with their amenities and the free shuttle bus to either Disneyland or Disney Sea is a very big plus in my opinion as you can relax after a long fun filled day and not worry about the travel back to the hotel. If I get the chance to visit Tokyo again, will still definitely stay at this hotel.

Really love this hotel. Many options to choose from during breakfast. Room is clean n service is good. Location is really convenient near to Metro n food street. Will definitely stay here again. It is one of the drop off point for Limo bus n also there is a shuttle bus fron this to Disneyland Tokyo.

Stay for 8 nights in 1763 and 1765 south wing facing a giant Tokyo metropolitan office building. Overall good stay because this hotel location is very strategic and the housekeeping service is very good. Breakfast is okay in 3 restaurants. We admire Keio plaza because it is well maintained hotel with almost 30 years in business. This is a big hotel but they are trying to serve you well. Last day check out , we have to wait 15 minutes for elevator because they have so many guests. Finally the concierge staff coming and guide us take service elevator to lobby because we need to catch our train to Kyoto.

Keio Plaza Hotel is a large hotel, one of the first tall buildings built in Shinjuku. Despite this, the facilities are in perfect condition, probably fruit of competent maintenance actions. The hotel occupies an entire block and houses more than a thousand rooms. It is located five minutes walk from the largest train station in the world: Shinjuku Station. The rooms are very comfortable, and the complex has several restaurants, shops and even a mini-supermarket (convenience store). If you are lucky and the weather helps, you can see Mount Fuji from your room window.

Great location within walking distance of the Shinjuku station, modern and clean rooms and a breakfast with something for everyone with three different buffets. We had an amazing view of the Tokyo Metropolitan building.

We stayed for three nights at the beginning of our holiday, in the main tower - the hotel is big, the reception area reminded us of a posh railway station since it was always so busy with groups of people coming and going all the time, we saw wedding quests having photographs taken on one occasion.Our room was very modern and by Japanese standards a comfortable size - the bathroom was also modern, there was a large selection of guest amenities in the bathroom and of course those wonderful Toto toilets! Our rate included breakfast each morning which was served in a choice of restaurants on the floor below the hotel - we chose the restaurant called Jurin each day, there are full size windows looking outside. The restaurant is modern - you wait to be shown a table, the breakfast selection was immense, both western and traditional breakfast items, with a chef cooking fresh omelettes. We travelled with friends and each one of us had a different breakfast choice each day. The staff were always helpful and respectful.We chose the hotel due to it's close proximity to the main Shinjuku station - you can walk to the station, from the hotel, in what can only be described as an underground pavement for people, which is well lit, always busy, takes around 10 minutes with a case.The hotel is so large that there are a number of exits (front and back) to the hotel lobby area, there is also an exit by the Jurin restaurant on the floor below reception. If you take this exit, cross the road, and walk to the right, you will join the covered pavement \ walkway to the station. If you take the exit at the rear of the main lobby (ground floor), so the exit away from the reception, walk across the road, within a 5 minute walk you will enter an area that is neon lite with a vast selection of restaurants to cater for all tastes and pockets.

It's a hotel with a lot of activity and is usually full of people. There are quite a few restaurants and stores within the hotel, and there are many restaurants and stores outside within walking distance. The main train station is also walking distance. The only point is that you need to request a renovated room, or else you will get a small, old room. Of course, these older rooms are still very clean.

Lovely place to stay however, a bit annoyed that the pool wasn't open while we were there. It was incredibly hot and truth be told we booked this place because of the pool. Disappointed we couldn't cool off with a dip at the end of a long day sight seeing. Otherwise, staff were lovely and helpful, room was very comfortable and it is very conveniently located!

We are currently staying at the Keio plaza hotel as a family. We have one of the four bedded rooms in the main tower, which is great for space (for Tokyo), with a living space with a sofa and two arm chairs located in between the four beds. The suite also has two bathrooms. Great for a family of four (it could readily accommodate 5 or six if you have smaller kids who share beds but they don't allow it).On the negative side the beds are hard as rock.There are two different buffets for breakfast, one of which they call a "grand buffet". The grand buffet has a wider range of food, including a lot of Japanese food. It is much higher quality than the one with just western food. Price runs 30-35 dollars per adult, 15-20 per child, the grand buffet being the more expensive one respectively (but still being the greater value based on quality of what's included). Some room packages include breakfast I assume it's the standard buffet. There is also an a la carte Japanese breakfast available (which we did not try)The swimming pool is a bit of a joke. It's located in a lovely location outdoors on a seventh floor rooftop, but they have the audacity to charge hotel guests for entry (20$ per adult free for a child) and the pool is not even heated so on an overcast day it is freezing cold. The fee is hidden away in the terms and conditions click through in the pool description on their web site and is not mentioned at all on third party sellers of the hotel.Also a word of warning, they take the whole Japanese disdain for tattoos thing uber seriously at the pool. We were the only ones there on a grey overcast day. Our 8 year old daughter had a temporary tattoo of a T on her arm (ironically from a swim club tryout), and we were asked to leave because of it. Quite funny, would have been annoyed by it if we hadn't been able to use it to parlay a return of the pool fee.Location is convenient in terms of having a covered walkway access from Shinjuku JR station. No restaurants on the streets right around the hotel, but several if you walk 10-15 minutes. Hotel restaurants for dinner are overpriced but good.Not sure if we lucked out, but our room was extremely quiet, so it was great for sleeping.All in all a decent choice for a family stay, but not as good as hoped for due to the pool issues and lack of reasonably priced dining on site.

I usually stay at Keio Plaza for my business trip - I really like staying here coz very central and the rooms are big in Japanese standards. Staff gives exceptional service as well! It is easy to go here via Airport Limousine or if you want a faster alternative, train is another way. Lots of restaurants in the area as well!

I stayed for one week in the main tower in a double room. Two seperate and comfortable beds. Bathroom with tub and shower. Enough room for suitcases and hanging up clothes. Towels changed every day. Easy to get an iron/iron board or electric adapters - took maybe 30 seconds from the phone call.. My room had carpets on the floor.Several breakfast restaurants with different options. Breakfast starts 0500 in one of the restaurants! I don't know the price. Dinner is rather expencive - may cost 6000 yen or more. Had Sukuyaki in one of the restaurants one evening, really excellent! However, there are lots of restaurants with reasonable prices 100m from the door. The hotel is just across the road from Tokyo Metropolitan Building, with a great view (free) over the city. It is also walking distance to Shinjuku stations with many of the JR lines (including Yamanote-line that will take you "everywhere"), and the Narita express. There is also a buss shuttle to Narita from the hotel. The hotel i surrounded by other hotels and office buildings, but with the restaurant area in Shinjuku close by. If you want a comfortable place to stay, this is a good choise. It is a friendly and well mantained machine, but still a machine.

I love this place!! We stayed at the 37th floor, and everything was perfect!! I loved the view, the room was very spacious, the housekeeping was perfect, and the place is a great area for shopping, since malls are within walking distance. (Keio Department Store is maybe 2-3 blocks away, maybe a 10 min walk, when you're not distracted by the numbers of small drugstores and restaurants) I would recommend this place.

I stayed here in the Main Tower for 14 days and the room was super nice! All four of us had their own bed (double size beds) and even had 2 bathrooms in one room. Very modern looking room and bathroom. Staff is very nice and caring. This hotel also has its very own convenience store located on the 2nd floor on the South Tower side. If you ever stay here, go to the Luxe Lounge on the 34th floor in the South Tower and eat the strawberry cake. Its so good! Almost all the staff speaks good English so no need to worry if you don't know/speak Japanese. I would recommend this place.

This was our 15th or 16th stay at this hotel. I can honestly say we have never been disappointed here.We had two stays here during our trip. The first being before we left for Kyoto and the second being after we returned from Kyoto. We stayed in the Plaza Superior and the Plaza Deluxe rooms in the Main Tower. Both rooms were spacious, neat and clean. The Deluxe room being slightly larger than the Superior. There were a good selection of toiletries in the bathroom. We never once used our own shampoo, conditioner or body soap as theirs was just as good.The hotel itself is huge but not overwhelming. This hotel has plenty of restaurants to eat at if you so desire. We had breakfast at the Glass Court Buffet everyday during our first stay here. I have to say that I was and still am disappointed in this buffet. First off, it's expensive. Secondly, while they had many choices for a Japanese style breakfast, their choices for their American breakfasts were lacking. The bacon was half cooked and flabby. The made to order omelettes will be served runny on the inside unless you tell the cook otherwise and even then it was still slightly runny. The ham was really canadian bacon and the sausages were more like vienna sausages or cocktail franks. The saving grace for me was the toast and the small salad bar. During our second stay at the hotel, we had breakfast off site at Royal Host.The staff working at the hotel was just as professional and courteous as always. Over the years, we have gotten to know one staff member that used to work in reservations but now works in guest services. She is the nicest woman you'd ever want to meet. Thanks to her, our stays at the Keio have always been pleasant.Overall, I think the Keio is a great hotel. It's about a 6 - 7 minute walk to the Keio department store and Shinjuku station. The area has plenty of restaurants too if you know where to look.I will continue to come back to stay at the Keio.

We stayed here for 3 nights as part of a package tour that included breakfast. The buffet breakfasts were excellent and generous, offering western, Japanese and vegetarian food. Our room was spacious with huge windows and the well appointed bathroom had both tub and shower. (Toilets in Japan often provide a variety of ahem, intimate services which we tried to our great amusement) The staff at the Keio are endlessly polite and accommodating. Front desk speaks good English but room service staff and the bell captain desk may not speak English well, or at all. No matter what your request however they will try their utmost to help. Common areas in this large hotel are very pleasant and attractive.

Beware! Do not book a room here through a travel agent. I did. When I arrived I requested an upgrade and offered to pay the difference. I was told that it would cost $1,000 per night extra. I was told that the room I had paid for was, in their view, valueless because a travel agent had sold it to me. After 90 minutes of Egyptian rug Market negations, and at least 20 trips by the clerk through the wizard's curtain to speak to the manager, they agreed to upgrade for $400 extra per night.Once in, the room is very nice and the staff curteous. Food is ok. This is not worth $1,000 per night!

The hotel has a majestic location. Everything about it is top class. Amazing staff. I had an issue with my wifi dongle. The gentleman spoke to the service provider for almost half hour to resolve it. Just outstanding

Hotel is located in Shinjuku within 5-10 min walking distance to several Japanese and electronic stores and train station. The hotel itself is huge but didn't feel too busy. The rooms were a nice size, clean and comfortable. Staff friendly and helpful. Has several restaurants on the floor below the lobby.

The room was very old. Absolutely different from the photos on the hotel website. Beds were really hard and the air con was pretty weak.HOWEVER, the worst thing comes now. Our friend recommended us to try the Teppanyaki restaurant in the Hotel and therefore, we decided to email the hotel to make a book and to request for one and only table that has the prettiest view on a mini garden. The other reason of wanting this particular table is that it will have just fit all our guests of the meal, and thus, a greater sense of privacy. We made this booking 3 months before our visit day and we even attached a clear photo of the table we want in the email. Here comes the ABSOLUTE DISAPPOINTMENT. On that day, we went to the restaurant with our guests with a high expectation of the dinner. Yet, at the reception, the manager was already quite impolite to search for our booking. Later, he then led us to the table. WHATTTTTT. He brought us to the super end corner of a long table, full of other customers, with no garden view. We kindly explain our request (as mentioned in the email) to the manager and the manager showed an annoyed face while left us without saying anything. We then waited in our seat for around 10 mins without any reply. And we were quite pissed by then since this is NOT the service that we were expecting from a high end restaurant. We called out for the manager and he did not even put any effort to solve the problem. He said, "Nope, we do not have a record of your request". Be aware, still no apologises at this moment. I then told him to check the hotel's email account and he said he had a look at my email already and he said the hotel did not promise me anything and most importantly, I did not attach the photo of the table i want. HOLYYYYY !!!! I did not want to talk to this manager and requested for someone at a higher position than him. After a long wait, his supervisor came and I showed him the email on my phone. And they could not lie anymore, and they went out to sort things out.They came back and I was about to move to that table. However, they said that they had already given the table to another group of people and asked us to stay in our place for the dinner. We were shocked by their service and without the table we want, without the view, and most importantly, having been treated with such poor quality of service, we chose to leave the restaurant. A super unpleasant experience and a sense of discrimination was obvious!

Having stayed in Japanese hotels before, I knew what to expect. Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku is a very conveniently located hotel where guests will enjoy the perfect bit of distance from the crowds of Shinjuku while still being just a stone's throw away from the Shinjuku train hub. The hotel offers fair service, comfort and amenities. Service is above average but guests should not expect the over and beyond type of service expected of a hotel rated 5 stars by hotel booking sites. You will definitely receive what you have requested and paid the predetermined fair price for e.g. bedding arrangements for 3 in a room for 2, in line with the excellent standard of delivering expected in Japan. If you can manage your expectations that this hotel is a different type of 5 star offering in comparison to the more familiar western brands, then it will be indeed be an excellent 5 star choice in terms of location.

Enjoyed our stay there. Room was clean, single beds are wide! Stayed at the newly renovated South Tower. Close to restaurants and convenience stores. Not too near the Shinjuku train station tho. They provide free shuttle bus service to and from Disney Land. But book your seats when you check in. You can also book your bus tickets to the airport and they have a tour company within the building itself. So makes it easy to book your tours.

Putting Keio hotel tokyo against other comparable hotels, the following was found wanting...- check in was painfully slow: check in time was 2pm, but when we arrived at about 4+pm our rooms were still not ready!- wait time for lifts at the lift lobby was also rather long.- walls were relatively poorer in sound-proofing: we could hear the kids next door jumping and making noise.- although the staff appeared friendly, we found the more "junior-ranking" (for lack of a better term) staff e.g. bell service, concierge more warm and personal. A apparently senior-ranking staff from Guest Relations, looked tall and stoic but was not very helpful when asked for help (at least not the usual Japanese hospitality that one would expect).- this hotel does not have the IC reader for credit cards (only, which is quite surprising in Tokyo. Even small retail outlets have one!)- but most importantly, English proficiency is limited to a handful of staff; A hotel of this standing needs to have a lot more of its staff conversant in English (beyond the introductory few lines). All in all, it's ok in terms of its 'hardware', but the 'heartware' is found wanting.

I totally understand that i am a english speaking guest with no Japanese but my check in experience was not great. The receptionist was very blunt and too the point. I asked for two keys as i like to have two just incase one doesn't work and she told me no, 1 person in the room 1 key. I then got to the room and it wasn't good, nothing like the website. I went back to reception as said i wasn't happy with the room and i told her why and then she went on the website and said show me. As i said i guess things were lost in translation because of language but in hospitality you are generally hospitable.I then asked if there was a bar i could smoke in and she said no until i found out by accidents a little gem in the hotel, Brilliant Bar on the second floor. I have to Thank Baba who was my waiter every night and the rest of the team for looking after me so well. If you go there ask for Baba.The hotel is in a great location and the are a Disney good neighbour hotel so there is a free shuttle bus.All i am trying to say if you are a Japanese guest i am sure this is a great hotel but as a western guest the staff need to learn how to deal with western guests.

Rooms were decent and clean with nice views, but overall experience was let down by poor service from disinterested staff. Checkin stated for 2pm, turned up at 3pm and still had to wait. Staff didn't care at all about the inconvenience. Requested a late checkout on departure date, and were informed that a 2 hour extension would be 4000 yen. Had much better experiences at every other hotel we stayed at in Japan (many of which were much cheaper!). Wouldn't visit again.

I had a very dramatic experience.My room was in a top floor at the end of a hall I arrived at 8 pm.I was alone.Took a bath and wore a kimono.The bell rang ,went to the door.A naked man in his 20 with tatoos all over his body.I was terrified with the situation.I called the mananger and asked for help.He came half hour later.While I was scared waiting for someone to help the tatoo man appeard again. The hotel never apologized for the situation I went through.They just said it was a drunk Korean man.Which it wasnt by the way

The rooms are decent and location is good. But the staff have no basic hospitality and not helpful. Latest checkout is 1130, any later there is charge. My sisters family who travelled with us had an emergency with a sick child and requested simple assistance to contact dad in gym ( we were directed to call ourselves the gym phone which we later found out to be not working) and they declined to help still until we insisted.

its a very well and complete facilities in this hotel; very busy with lots of room guest from all over the world. breakfast was so good, superb fresh chilled juices, chef cooks eggs, buffet line was just great...having a real good breakfast will really start a enjoying my day for tour ...ha2!

Very convenient location and comfortable rooms. Shinjuku west side where department stores, electric stores, all kinds of restaurants, convenient stores and you name it, everything is around it. Right by Tokyo Metropolitan City Building. Easy access to everywhere as many public transportations are near by.

First of all, I have to admit that I pondered quite a lot if I should give four or five stars. I decided to go four just to give myself some space. I have nothing to complain about this hotel whatsoever. Service was helpful and staff spoke quite good english. Rooms were spacy and bed comfortable. Air condition was even great.There is several restaurant options within hotel. I ate breakfast in all three options and dined in two. Didn't get bad food. Needless to say, but kobe beef was extremely good.Some extrapoints for usb electric socket by bedside. That's the way to do it. There is adapters besides that in every room.So why not five stars? I dunno, there just was "something" missing, place just did not hit me. But it is definetely good option in this scale.

The location was a deal breaker for me. It was very convenient as I had to travel with luggages and what not and it easy to get public transportation. The room was also spacious with stunning view of the city at night.

Enjoy central location in a high-quality business hotel. Friendly service, transport to airport, delicious food and breakfast. I have been several times inTokyo. Keio Plaza is a classic choice. Hotel itself is not the newest but visitor can feel a flawless all-in-all quality.

I booked a Premier room on the 36th floor, with access to the Luxe lounge. The room was very spacious with a good city view, was well equipped, clean and well-maintained. The bathroom was a little small, but fine for one person; an outside vanity area with a mirror was good for storing bathroom items. Free wifi and a Nespresso machine with 2 capsules daily were appreciated. Walking distance to Shinjuku station and several department stores. Staff were pleasant and helpful; enough English for check-in and -out. The staff at the Guest Relations desk spoke excellent English. Huge foyer and general area but very limitede seating considering the vast number of people who were always present. Very strict about not being able to check-in early, so of you have a flight which arrives early morning, be prepared for a long wait. Late check-out available at approx. $25 per hour but excellent facility for luggage storage on hand.Lots of cafes and restaurants in the basement, but prices were very steep. Nowhere really just to sit and have a drink without actually going into one of them. Cappuccino $10 at the hotel but only $3-$4 at local cafes. A Convenience store in the basement was very handy for breakfast supplies and snacks. The Luxe Lounge was in the South Tower and open from 10.00 am daily. I have no idea what the breakfast would have been like as it was not available until 10.00 and by that time I was long gone from the hotel. I visited some afternoons for coffee and cake and a couple of times in he evening when a small range if alcohol and savouries was available from 5.00 to 7.00 pm. I thought the quantities and range on offer were very limited and less than generous; perhaps why the lounge was not busy.

First time I this hotel because we wanted to change district after staying always at Ana intercontental in Akusaka.And it takes a lot to get impressed after many stays in Ana.But Keio did not let us down in any way.Booked a big room and got upgraded to a even bigger with a view over the city and mountain in the distance.Big and clean room but with a wall to wall carpet that is a bit dated.Japanese bathroom with the nice toilet.Quitet room with good space ..more than 34 square meters.The hotell is very well maintained and staff is very serviceminded and location is perfect close to everything including subway bars and restaurants and shopping.Good price level to be in Tokyo.Did not try the breakfast because there is more than plenty of nice cheap local shops to eat just across the street.Will recomend and return to Keio.

✔️The staff are very accomodating. ✔️The hotel is close to the restaurants.✔️The room was spacious, clean and comfortable.✔️Bed was perfect!✔️Good food.✔️Perfect place to relax.✔️Near at Shopping Malls!✔️Security is good!

With my experiences to stay for several times at Keio Plaza Hotel, The first thing, the room and all facilities are comfortable. The second, the hotel located in nice area for shopping, dinning and night life. The last, the breakfast is good with a lot of continental, american and Japanese foods.

Travelled with friends at end of April. Great hotel with good location. Near the buzzling Shinjuku train station and near good restaurants and shopping possibilities. Hotel is huge, but everything worked with great efficiency. Would use it again.

Stayed for a week for business on one of the club level floors. You have a separate floor for check in which is nice. The room was awesome, bathroom was amazing. My first time traveling to Tokyo so I can't compare it. Also have free buffet breakfast with a chef. Service was exceptional.

The worst of service I've ever seen.Poor English staff at the reception that can't imagine it was four star hotel.Especially the primer counter staff.Me and my partner request about the policy of facility for primary member for three times and every time was different answer.Incredibly bad service and the oldest decor.Full of tourist groups in the lobby.And the sound-proof effect of the room is terrible. You can even heard the guest talking who's in next room.

We stayed for a total of 7 days. The check-in experience was really welcoming and the staff were very friendly. As we were settling in to our room, we noticed some spots that were less maintained. We notified housekeeping and they apologized for this mishap. The curtains did not provide enough coverage as light seeped through and woke us at 6AM. We notified the hotel for another cleanliness matter and they offered to switched us into a room in the South Tower. The new room was definitely cleaner but was kind of a downgrade. We decided to look past this since the hotel was in such a great location to get to the station and the nearby restaurants. Overall it was a decent experience but I would probably look for a newer hotel for the same price.

Before arrived Japan, we imaged our room should be small and compact in this busy town Shinjuku. Turned out this hotel has everything 5 stars hotel should have. High ceiling spacious welcome lobby, good size of room and great service from hotel staff. Only few blocks away can get to Shinjuku shopping area. 10 mins walk to Shinjuku subway station. Hotel has partnership with Disney and provide shuttle to both Disneyland and Sea. Very convenient and we love it.

My husband and I have stayed here many times over the past 20 years. I have noticed in the past decade that the prices have gone up quite a bit but compared to other hotels in it's class it seems to be the most affordable if you can get a deal. We usually take the Airport Limousine bus from Narita which drops you off right at the hotel. I appreciate that after being jetlagged from a long flight. It's a short walk to Shinjuku Gyoen and to the shopping area of Takashimaya department store. The bus terminal used to be very close by but it has relocated to a slightly farther location. Still walkable, though. On the lower level there is a convenience store that is well stocked so we often head there after checking in to pick up some snacks. Overall, I would stay here or at the Southern Century, whichever one offered the better rate.

We overnighter at the Keio Plaza, Tokyo on April 9, 2017. This was a post cruise stay as we were transferred to the MS Volendam the next day. Our rooms were so clean and the beds also very comfortable. The rooms supplied complimentary slippers, hair brushes and tiih brushes with toothpaste included. We took a trip around the hotel to see what restaurants and stores we could find. One place their convenience store on the second floor was a boon for tourists staying there. It had a great variety of take foods that you could heat up before leaving plus all the other conveniences you'd expect there. The many restaurants and buffets offered mainly Japanese cuisine which you'd expect but also a variety of Western food selections, the pricing was comparable with any 5 Star hoteksvyiyd find in Canada or the United States. The next morning some of our group had the breakfast buffet at the Jurin restaurant. They offered mostly western food selections for beverages as well as egg and potato selections. The cost was 3000 yen ( approx 36.00 Cdn) and was very good. The location of the hotel fir those staying longer than one night is very close to a train station as well as other local transportation. Many restaurant were close by also. If I had the opportunity to visit Tokyo the Keio Plaza would be my first choice to stay.

great locationexcellent roomexcellent dinner-specially Western/Japanese restaurant with huge buffetexcellent breakfast with huge buffet & variety food Western & Japanesebottom line- recommended 5* star hotel & not too expensive

Our room was located at the South Tower. Room size is not big, but well-appointed. Lighting is good, and outlets are thoughtfully located near the bedside which offer much convenience. Housekeeping did a fantastic job of replenishing toiletries daily. The hotel is not the closest there is to the busy Shinjuku station, but is still accessible by foot in approximately 10 mins. What I like about this property is that we could come home every day to a quiet, cozy neighborhood though not too far from the hustle-bustle of the city. Worth mentioning is the slew of restaurants tucked in side streets and convenience stores that are just a stroll away from the hotel. Keio Plaza is now our new address when in Tokyo.

Stayed for 4 nights and really cannot complain about anything. The hotel is large, but that didn't mean service standards suffered, with our room being spotlessly clean, modern and with good views over the city. The hotel is located in buzzing Shinjuku, which is an ideal place to base yourself in Tokyo, and about 5min walk from Shinjuku station. The walk to the station also takes you past lots of cool food places and shops. We didn't have breakfast at the hotel as we preferred to hunt out the different food options outside the hotel - including some very nice french patisseries (Japanese love french cuisine). Hotel also had a nice lounge on one of the highest floors which also afforded great views, whilst having a drink. Good to do before heading out for dinner, or at end of day.

There are two rows of tables (by the window or second row) but we asked to move when a table became empty (and of course went for a second cocktail). Expensive of course (around 1600/1700 Yen a cocktail) but you pay for the view. And it's stunning. They have some signature cocktails. Their Gin and Tonic had matcha infusion and flakes of gold ;-)

I stayed here for seven days before the start of Golden week. The staff were excellent, the room was bright, well decorated and had some fantastic details, not only the usual toiletries but shoe shining cloths, power adaptors and a supply of mineral water every day. I used the Italian/French restaurant, buffet breakfast and the 45th floor bar, the food was good and the service was top class! The only negative would be the cost, not a hotel for those on a strict budget!

We stayed in Keio for a few days back in October 2016. Nice hotel, big rooms just a tad bit old. Very nicely located in Shinjuku, across the street from the hotel is a street full of restaurants and convenience stores. If you were to follow that same street up ahead, it will lead you to the JR station which is about 10mins walk at the most. Hotel staff were very kind and welcoming. We were a big group of 10 people with children and all of us enjoyed our stay there. Will definitely come back and stay in Keio when we are back in Tokyo.

It's my 3rd night staying in Keio Plaza Hotel, location is good for dining & transportation, room is big, full cleaning set for both men & women is excellent, plus baby cot is really a bonus for my 1 yr old girl.

We stayed here in a twin room as part of a tour of Japan. Excellent hotel with several choices of breakfast options (excellent buffet) and a convenience store open until 2:30am. Several restaurants in the hotel but I cant comment on these as there were many options to eat in the local area.Very good location 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku station where you can access transport for all over Japan.Good size bedroom and bathroom with a large assortment of toiletries, combs, razors, toothbrushes etc.Sunrise Tours have a desk here and we took several day trips with them which we thoroughly enjoyed.I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel.

This large Japanese hotel houses many tour groups, so it is always busy! Within 5 minutes walking, you can find Hilton, Hyatt Regency, Grand Hyatt around the same area, but this one gives you the best value. The other ones might have familiar amenities and set up; but Keio is a very solid hotel, fairly large rooms for international standard. I have paid much more for much smaller rooms. Bed is comfortable, perhaps a bit "harder" for non-Japanese. Not much counter space in the bathroom. But overall it is comfortable with everything you need and more (free wi-fi, coffee makers...)! love the location, back entrance (L2) is steps away from the walking tunnel to Shinjuku station. airport bus stops here, all the taxi drivers know this hotel. Food choice from very cheap(conveyor belt sushi, ramen shop) to very chic; and the sushi restaurant in the hotel is regarded as one of the best (and very expensive) in the city.

Excellent hotel in Shinjuku, very well located.It is the typical hotel in downtown Tokyo, with hundreds of rooms, that are correct in size and very clean. Very good breakfast, but is recommended to go early if you want continental, otherwise you'll have a long, long line.

Located a few undred meters from Shinjuku station (the most important in Tokyo) with good shuttle connection to the airport, this hotel is a very good choice both for business and leisure. Good restaurants in the hotel and cheap in the area. Large rooms and helpful staff.

Stayed for 6 nights in the south tower in a plaza luxe queen bed room. Overall room size is great. It's the only hotel in Japan I stayed so far so have no comparison but I know usually rooms are smaller in Japan. Room was equipped with a safe, working desk and tv. Location is great. A few min walk from Shinjuku station and from many stores and restaurants. The luxe lounge is very basic. Some soft drinks and a small amount of food. It closes at 22:00For breakfast you can select from 3 different restaurants. Expect a wait of around 10 min. The hotel itself is huge and usually very crowded. Staff was helpful and kind. If you have any extra request try asking in advance as they are less flexible in real-time

Hotel is located in Shinjuku within 5-10 min walking distance to the subway. Rooms are decent sized and a bit dated, room rates are also higher. Asked for a non-smoking room but room still had lingering cigarette smell.There a lot of food outlets about 5 mins walk away across the road near the Shinjuku station. Limo bus drops off and picks up from the hotel.If this is your first time in Tokyo and claustrophobic... try the Keio Plaza.

This place is as basic as it gets, we were so disappointed. Really not worth the money!It's in a great location but there are many other places in great locations in tokyo.The room are small (which is normal for tokyo) and super outdated. The restaurants in the hotel are complete rip offs.... ridiculously expensive for nothing specialThe staff is a little bit condescending and don't really go out of their way to help you. We stayed 6 nights and asked to check out 2 hours later that the planned time and they asked us to pay for the two hours... i was in shockNot worth it... look somewhere else.Next time i'll probably Airbnb

I stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel with the group from Daikin Philippines for their Disneyland Company Outing. They booked the hotel for us, so I have no idea how much my double room costed. My stay was quite short, but Keio plaza proved to be a very very comfortable place to rest and relax after a long day touring Tokyo. It took a quiet 3 minute walk to find yourself local restaurants that cater very good food for as low as ¥750. And shops where you buy local merchandise, gadgets, and accessories. Food was ok, although I wasn't able to try the Japanese breakfast because it was always full. Staff are polite, friendly, and very attentive to your needs.

This is a big hotel and fairly close to the Shinjuku train station, and other cool areas. The hotel staff is very professional and friendly. The rooms themselves seem to. E a nice size. Not huge, but not small as I have read about most hotels in Tokyo.
user_name:
johndV2904ZO
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel advertises itself as an upscale hotel. It is far from it!Upon entry into the hotel, one recognizes the fact that it may once be a good hotel- with all the lightings, fixtures, high ceilings, and imposing lobby. Beyond these physical structures though, this hotel is really in bad shape!Even while checking in, one noticed the very distinctly in-Japanese way the front office staff deal with guests. Unlike most Japanese, they are not courteous or polite. They seem to be always on the edge and in a hurry to dispose of the guests checking in. This foreshadowed worse things to come.Having checked in at 845pm, our group wanted to have dinner outside the hotel and we approached the desk of a hotel staff with a marker that he is the duty manager. We asked him about places to eat. He dismissed us and told us that all restaurants would be close at around 9pm so we should just eat in the hotel! We told him that this is the Shinjuku area and, based on what we know, it should have many restaurants around the area. He angrily told us that he just said they will be closed and we should eat in the hotel!We refused to heed his discourteous reply. Instead, we asked for a map. He again showed his displeasure and angrily pulled a map from a stack of map, scattering all the other maps on the table and the floor! We were flabbergasted! He circled the hotel in the map and when we asked where the eating and shopping places are- he angrily pointed at an area right in front of the hotel and said stores are closed! Whew...We decided to walk to the area indicated and almost all the shops and restaurants were open! We had a wonderful dinner in a sushi place that night and in subsequent nights!If courtesy of duty managers and front office people is important to you, please avoid this hotel at all costs! The staff do not act like the courteous Japanese we all have come to know and appreciate.This hotel is really bad!

Stayed at KP for 4 nights. The hotel is huge, over 1200 rooms and feels like a shopping mall. Lobby area is massive. Hotel has several restaurants but all are mega expesive. Breakfast is good but no indian vegetarian options also expect at least 15mins queue to get a table even when tables appear free. I think this is down to size of hotel but you would expect KP to be managing this process as a 5 star hotel. The deluxe rooms are huge and fantastic city views. We were on 22nd floor and great room. Bathroom is decent size. Hotel is located near a metro station but Shinjuku station is huge so you need to ensure using the right exits etx. Hotel offers free shuttle to disneyland which is great. Overall a solid city hotel but for me it just misses the true class of 5 star hotel.

Fantastic buffet breakfast!! All the fixings for eastern or western tastes. Hotel was quiet, room was big. No coffee pot in room. AC worked. Location was very central - 300 yards from the WestGate exit of Shinjuku Station.

Let me start by saying that the staff at the front desk was incredibly helpful to a person. That being said, we had a problem as our reservation for two adjoining deluxe rooms for three nights was incorrectly logged as regular rooms. After 45 minutes, the issue was not resolved and we had an appointment to keep. They held on to our luggage and proceeded to try and resolve the problem. When we returned, they acknowledged the mistake was theirs and that they could only give us regular rooms the first night, but would switch our luggage for the second two nights. Not ideal. The regular rooms were average size mass-market rooms. Not a lot of room and we could only open our luggage by putting it in the space between the rooms, but the beds were comfortable. The next day, as promised, they moved our luggage into the bigger luxe rooms. These rooms were a bit bigger and less tired than the original rooms, but the bathrooms retained a certain cheap quality that I did not find in other large hotels. We could also hear our neighbor's small children. The hotel provided us with a lovely box of pastries as an apology, but more importantly, when we went to exchange our keys we realized that every single person at the front desk was aware of what had happened and apologized to us. A nice consolation. We had access to the lounge which is always an nice perk. In the evenings there was beer, liquor and snacks and a fabulous view. Biggest disappointment was breakfast. We were there over Easter weekend and the lines were astounding. We went to the smaller of the two restaurants and had a 10 minute wait the first day but a 40 minute wait the second day. Nothing compared to the larger restaurant that looked like it had a wait of over an hour both days (!). The spread was fine, with both western and Japanese options. This is an enormous hotel, so don't go there looking for an intimate, calm experience. That being said, the hotel grew on us over the course of the weekend. Location of the hotel is good, right near the train station, shopping and Shinjuko nightlife. Overall, a solid large-hotel choice.
user_name:
JAMBrooklyn
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is in a great location with easy access to Shinjuku station, shops and restaurants. The hotel itself is huge but didn't feel too busy. The rooms were a great size, clean and comfortable with an amazing view. I stayed in a deluxe room and then a lux plaza suite. The suite was no different than the deluxe room besides a higher floor and lux lounge access. There was a whole floor of restaurants if you wanted to stay within the hotel and a small/average room service menu. I would choose to stay here again mainly due to the quiet but convenient location.Great choice for exploring Tokyo!

Triple room that comes with 3 super single beds, so the rooms are large by Japanese standards. Breakfast is nothing to rave about- very limited variety and average taste. Hotel stands ouit mainly because of good location right in the smack of Shinjuku with access to rail stations and walking distance to majar restaurants nearby.

Larger than average rooms for a Japanese hotel. Clean comfortable but a little on the expensive side... but this is Tokyo! However lounge access is not really worth paying the extra for! Good location close to Shinjuku station.

Lovely sized room with good furnishings. Nice deep bath, Bidet.Great location. Lovely restaurants in building. Great little convenience store as well. Booked great prices on Qantas hotels with QFF points. Staff were friendly.

We visited as part of a tour with Titan Travel. This was one of the better hotels. It was in a good location and the hotel staff were very helpful. Food was lovely and the wifi worked fine. Pity that the pool wasn't open (it only opens in summer). Bedrooms were comfortable and had a safe.

Large luxury hotel in Shinjuku area very convenient for train station, shops, restaurants etc. Although hotel was busy we were surprised at how quiet our room was and we loved the views - we were on 25th floor. The Aurora lounge on top floor well worth a visit as night views are amazing also food in Japanese restaurant was excellent. Highly recommend.

Big hotel close to the train station, 5-10 minutes by walk. Room no to big but ok enough. Breakfast quality ok, sometimes there is queue to entry into but it is fast queue, just few minutes to wait. Free internet connection in the room is bad, most of the time no working. Nice staff and great position to visit Tokyo and to find local food restaurant to eat around it

The hotel is in walking disctance from a big subway station, is serviced by the Airport-bus. There are many restaurants, and shops in the area. Good size rooms and many restaurants make it ideal if you don't feel like going out.

Beautiful hotel in a nice quiet area. It's a nice big hotel with lots of shops and restaurant options. Easy access to train station as well via an underground walkway. The area is beautiful and very walking/running/exercise friendly. Rooms and beautiful and big (definitely bigger than most hotel rooms in Japan). Great customer service as well. Highly recommend as we had a great experience!

Fantastic Hotel with relay good service, Tokyo is a great place to visit, all the people are relay friendly and helpful would recommend anyone to go for a extremely good holiday and the culture,night life and shops are amazing.

Stayed here for 2 nights at their Plaza Luxe Twin Room two weeks ago.Pros and Cons as follows:-Pro - Good location, 5 minutes' walk to the heart of Shinjuku and JR station. Everything within easy reach be it restaurants, shops and train stations.Food and Beverage at Jurin All Day Dining Room - High quality food and presentation. Service good and friendly.Can take airport limousine (airport bus) direct to Narita/Haneda. Stops right at the hotel driveway. No hassle, but allow a good two hour to reach airport because it is the first hotel stop followed by a few other hotel pick-ups before heading onto the highway for airport.Room spacious and comfortable coz price-wise it is on the high side. Can use their lounge on the top floor free of charge for some small bites and soft drinks, coffee/tea. View magnificent.Cons:Very robotic staff at Front Desk i.e. Reception, Concierge, Bell and Guest Relations Male staff standing at reception area.Check in very slow despite all details filled in at time of reservation online. Had to rewrite same details again manually on check-in form!!!Staff at Reception unfriendly and no empathy. Rather cold and unwelcoming! Same for the whole team under Front Office, i.e. Concierge, Bell and Guest Relations.Perhaps they are too proud of themselves knowing that the location of the hotel is very convenient and has many facilities.One of the four lifts in the South Wing was under renovation. So, when coming down from the 33rd Floor at a peak time, it took 10 minutes!! Even with all four lifts operating, I doubt very much it is adequate for the number of rooms served. However, I understand this is a design fault which cannot be improved.This was the most expensive hotel out of all the hotels we stayed from Nagoya, to Toyama, to Tateyama, to Matsumoto. However, the service at the Keio Plaza's Front Office was the poorest!! We knew we had to pay for a good location hotel in Tokyo, but never knew that the service at Front Office could be so disappointing. The Bell staff was quick to show you to your room with your luggage, but never offered to help with putting them onto the luggage rack in the room and never explained anything about the room amenities. Quick to take the tip though. Very "unJapanese" for a change!!Apparently, was told by a friend she had experienced the same when she booked directly with the hotel. However, when she booked a second time (due to the convenient location) through a travel agency, it was like heaven and hell as compared with the first visit. She even got an upgrade to a better room for the price paid!!

We spent 4 nights in the South Tower on level 26. Very nice room. Service excellent by all staff. I had read in some reviews that getting breakfast at the lower level can be a scrum & if you go between 7 & 8 am, that may be true. However out of those hours it is a breeze. We got a window seat every morning. Coffee in Jurin breakfast very good. Would not hesitate to stay again.
