So you can tell my priorities! Seriously, this is a nice hotel in a great location and the staff are extremely helpful. But it is huge. I think there are 19 restaurants. We used the Japanese and American one which is in the basement almost at the end of the corridor. The food is expensive even by Japanese standards so check out the room service menu for clues. There is a reasonable convenience store in the basement floor where they sell fruit and sandwiches and also a department store close by if you want to go for an up market picnic in your room!

Our travel agent recommended this hotel. We were concerned with the "super busy" Tokyo environment. We found the hotel is in a beautiful district (Shinjuku,) where parks and other green space areas are within a short walking distance. Across the street is the Government Building, which is valued as an example of innovative architecture in the city. Under the building is a train station (subway, bullet and local), and at the top level of both towers is an observation level complete with a lovely restaurant, with some local specialty food shops. There is no charge. The hotel is perfectly located but it is large and very busy. When you first arrive, it can be intimidating. However, the service we received was personal, pleasant and excellent. There are other hotels which are smaller in the same area, but we were pleased with our choice.The room is well laid out, with quality amenities, great mattress and bedding. The lighting is excellent - for example, if you are going to the bathroom at night, as you walk to the bathroom, a soft night light comes on. The bathrooms contain the amazing Toto Japanese toilets which can spoil you for anything else. The restaurants were expensive but very nice. Breakfast was included in our cost. They have several breakfast venues - 1 for American style, 1 for Japanese and American style and 1 Japanese style. The food again is very good, the settings are lovely and the service is really good.Our time in Japan was marked by the lovely way we were welcomed and treated by fellow travers, guides, hotel staff, transportation officials etc. While we are considered older travelers, it was obvious that the hotel provided so much for children. For example, they were celebrating Beatrix Potters books and had displays of bunnies, garden patches and Easter eggs throughout the public areas. We were given access to the Club Lounge which served light tea and cocktail food and beverages. It also served as a quiet place to recoup after a busy day in the city. We would stay at the Keio again.

We stayed here for a few nights in February for the Tokyo marathon. From that point of view the location was perfect - the closest hotel to the start line. Given the hotel was the official marathon and super busy (I assume fully booked), our experience may have been impacted by this and does not reflect the normal standards of the hotel. We thought it was fine - it did the job. But nothing special. Service is friendly, but it was so busy that there was lots of queuing and waiting (even for a lift to your room). Definitely recommended if travelling for the Marathon.

Large spacious room with good wifi. Very comfortable bed with the room very clean. My first experience of Toto toilets - excellent. Very good shower and lots of extras in case one had forgotten something. Hotel had 3 breakfast rooms with large queues at the most popular. Didn't use this but instead took advice to use the other two where there was little queuing. Breakfast good selection of Japanese and western food. Lifts could be a problem at busy times in such a large hotel. As well as restaurants there were shops. However when dining in the hotel which I did one night or having a coffee I did find it rather expensive.

Very good room size with all the necessary accessories provided. Hotel is within easy walking distance to city hall and is free observatory. A 10-15 minute walk takes you to a nultitude of restaurants - some open 24 hrs. The hotel serves traditional Japanese breakfast, or you can choose a western/japanese combination buffet as an alternative.Service is very good, but the only reason I cannot give it five stars is because I was awakened by noise coming from either above, or from the next room early this morning.

Hotel has some fine details: safe with power plugs in side. Mirror in bathroom is heated so it will not fog from shower. The toilet seat is also heated--butt for different reasons. Flashlight in the night stand. Clothes brush and fabric freshener spray. Great Wi-Fi fast and had two lairs of security. The hotel staff is friendly and helpful. There is Shop on floor two with water, beer, sake, wine and snacks with relatively good prices. Plan a drink in the 45-floor sky-lounge in the main tower- good bar great view-note the thing that looks like table maker is your bill- take it to the cashier. Note: South tower elevators need to be included in your travel time calculations.

We stayed here for 7 nights in April 2017. Our room was on the 21st floor and on a clear day we could see Mount Fuji! The hotel is clearly signposted and easy to find, which is a massive bonus if you know Shinjuku station! Our room was spacious, clean with all the amenities you need. This is my second time in Tokyo and if I go again I would stay here. The staff are brilliant, as is the case for most of Japan.
user_name:
O4430PLamys
Nove Mesto nad Vahom, Slovakia

review_body: Big Hotel within min walk to Shinjuku JR Station. A Lot of Big Group patronized this hotel however the hotel generally do not allow Early check in thus if you arrive too early, they will only help you keep the luggage and you return around 2pm to check in.South Wing are newer, we book 2 room and dint relized that is of 2 different wing (Hello Kitty Room at South wing, the other on main building) However, Check in staff was kind enough to upgrade the other room to South Wing same block but different level, appreciated that.Hello Kitty Theme Room was awesome Kawaii especially if you are Big Fans of Kitty.Some of the items provided for the room could be taken home as souvenir and the hotel will give you a "Passport cover" where they indicate those items.However the in room service for Hello Kitty Breakfast was pretty costly and there was not much choice available and will not recommend that

Everything was perfect in this hotel, I enjoyed my staying here:Pros:- Location: 10 mints walk to Shinjuku station. And 5 mints to Shinjuku downtown district.- Rooms are in good condition, very clean and organized.- Friendly staff.Cons:- Toilet is too small.
user_name:
Khalaqi
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Amazing hotel with very friendly and efficient staff that taking care of you as sois as you're about to exit the taxi I got upgraded to a king room on the 26th floor! Fantastic view and very large room even by US standards! The room is equipped with all the amenities you can think of (even a Nespresso machine!) I would definitely stay there again 5 stars truly deserved! Great value for money! It's located in the quieter part of Shinjuku but within walking distance of all points of interests and subway! I STRONGLY recommend this place.

Location is good, staff is very friendly and helpful. Close to subway station and many restaurants and stores. Area is safe and it's important when you travel with kids. Only rooms need renovation, other then that good hotel.

As this is my second time to stay at this hotel and we are really like this hotel. Good location which just walking distance to the Subway and Shinjuku JR station. Nearby also have some shopping mall for you to explore.Besides that, we have tried the airport transfer service in this hotel. It cost us JPY 1230 per person from the hotel to Haneda Airport.There is 3 Breakfast option for you to choose: International Buffet, Japanese Set Menu Breakfast and Japanese Western Breakfast. We have tried the Japanese and International Buffet breakfast during our 2 nights stay at this hotel.

Nice large rooms and good location with plenty of places to eat under the hotel. Staff friendly and helpful. Easy walking to many shops and restaurants. We ate in the buffet restaurant for breakfast and plenty of choices either western or japanese.

one of the best hotels in Tokyo. rooms are big and clean,hotel staff is very attentive,location among hundreds of restaurants in the area.should find a solution to the queue to the breakfast restaurants maybe to serve coffee and croissant in the bar for those who does not want full breakfast.

This is a gigantic hotel, near the world's busiest railway station. Despite all of that, the atmosphere was calm. The room was fine and had the inevitable city view. Breakfast was fine, as long as you arrived by about 7am to miss the queues which built up over the next hour. The hotel has a good example of the qurky little shops which make Japan such fun to visit.

Nice location at the heart of Shinjuku.Large room space and awesome breakfast options.There are many restaurant options for dinner inside hotel basement,on of them is Italian restaurant.Room service menu is excellent and fast.Wifi connection is very fast.Staff are very kind and helpfull and they are always there for you whenever you need any help.

Ended our tour of Japan with 3 days at this hotel, it was the perfect hotel for us. We stayed on the 39th floor which gave us access to the 45th floor with all the amenities mentioned in other reviews. The concierge on that floor gave exceptional service in getting our boarding passes for our flights the next day and transportation at an early hour to Narita Airport. The view from our room was to the east and was spectacular especially at night. The breakfast was fine and the key to navigating the lengthy line was to schedule your visit to early or late times.All in all the rooms, the location and the staff were superb.

We stayed in the south tower where there were only 3 elevators for 40 + floors! The bell hop carrying the luggage cart had to use the same elevators. In the mornings around 8:30 - 9:30, we had to wait about half an hour and squeeze in anywhere possible! It's really ridiculous. The rooms were good size for Tokyo and very modern. There's a huge lobby but no where to sit!

Great location close to Shinjuku. The airport limousine bus stops at the hotel so that's a great way to get from Narita airport and only costs around Y3000.We had a Plaza Deluxe room which gave us access to the club room. The room was excellent, very spacious. Bed very comfortable.My only problem was the buffet breakfast, expensive at Y3000 and there was always a queue to get in, about 10min. Finally, the baggage forwarding service worked perfectly. If you're travelling with suitcases, it's a great idea and only costs about Y1500 per suitcase.

First time in Japan, but was pleased and impressed with everything about this hotel.From the moment that you arrive for checking in till the time you check out, my experience was a wonderful one and has no hesitation in staying here again.Room size was rather large with all amenities included. The shopping area is also a few minutes away.

We stayed for 4 nights and we were upgraded to a Premier Grand room on the 39th floor. This gave access to the lounge on the 45th floor which has free cocktails and snacks from 5-7 pm and a nice Western breakfast.The room itself was spacious and clean with high quality L'Occitane shampoo, lotions etc. The view was terrific and the location was close to the train station which can take you anywhere you want to go in Tokyo. There were plenty of places close by to eat and there are nice shopping areas - all within easy walking distance. We ate one night at Yamanami - the hotel's tepanyaki restaurant where we had the Kobe beef and spiny lobster. The meal was prepared by our own chef and it was delicious and beautifully presented. It's a bit pricey at around $200 each but if you want to splurge, this was a real treat! However don't eat at Jurin. 6 of us had dinner there. We all ordered different items and no one thought their food was good.You can listen to harp music in the lobby and you can take an ikebana flower arranging class if you want. They also had a kimono exhibit which you should see if it is still there. They were exquisite. I recommend exploring the hotel as well as the surrounding area as it has much to offer. We would have missed the kimono exhibit if we hadn't explored the hotel itself. They also had a Mt. Fuji photo exhibit with pictures of Mt. Fuji through all its seasons. A very nice experience!

We arrived in Tokyo after a long flight from the UK. This hotel is well situated in a good location for shops and the station. Very modern with all the technology one would expect in Japan. Fabulous large room and bathroom with facilities provided. We had dinner in the Chinese restaurant. Western breakfast is also available.in a separate restaurant. A room on the higher floors offers good view of Tokyo at night.
user_name:
tom d
Leighton Buzzard, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed a total of 8 days in Keio Plaza hotel in early April and it was great. The best part of the hotel was it's location. Right in the center of Shinjuku and if you are in Shinjuku, then you have entire Tokyo covered from a convenience perspective. There are 2 different exits for the hotels which lead to either Shinjuku Station or Tochamae Subway station covering the key metro and JR lines.The hotel in itself was brilliant as they have an option for a 3 person room, which is massive, I mean really huge from any perspective especially if you consider it's in Tokyo where space is such a premium. The room we had was in the south tower higher floor facing the Tokyo Metropolitan Building and on clear days we would wake up with a view of Fuji-san! The breakfast was not great, but not bad either. We ate in the Japanese restaurant on level 1 and that was quite good. The convenience store and travel desks are also very handy. Overall if you are planning a stay in Shinjuku Keio Plaza should be given a serious consideration.

When we first arrived at the hotel at 7am from a long overseas flight, our room was ready but we weren't allowed to go yet for some reason. The hotel staff were extremely nice about it all and took good care of our bags until we could check-in. I was surprised at how exceptionally the people speak English, even the doorman. The actual experience was pretty good as there was a wide variety of restaurants that where available just downstairs. The only flaw was the outrageous breakfast queue in the morning. Every restaurant was absolutely packed, but after waiting a while, the food was great. Overall, this hotel was a worth-wile visit and so close to the main streets.

best hotel i've stayed in tokyo! it's super convenient, near shinjuku station with lots of food and drugstores just 5< mins walk from the hotel! service is good and hotel room is big compared to other hotels in japan!

We stayed in this hotel for 5 nights and we were extremely satisfied. We stayed in a Premier Grande room, and it was fantastic. The room itself was large, very sleek and extremely comfortable. The bathroom was a technological marvel, with a separate toilet with sensors that automatically turned the light on when you approached it, and even opened the toilet seat! An English language newspaper was delivered each morning, which was appreciated. We had access to a club room, which offered extensive, tasty snacks and free alcohol from 5-7 each night. The lounge was available for soft drinks and juice all day. We availed ourselves of the breakfast in the lounge as well, which was very nice although not as extensive as what is offered in other locations in the hotel. Shopping and multiple restaurants are available for use in the hotel. Nearby were other shopping options and many restaurant offerings including western fast food, and numerous Japanese offerings. The hotel is very near the train station as well. I would definitely stay here again!

Large rooms and the most comfortable beds ever! Exceptionally clean and neat. Ate at the Buffet one night which , although pricey , was fabulous for the kids. The porters went way over what is expected of them - sooo helpful and worked out all our transport problems with a smile!

My second visit to this hotel in 18 months! I enjoy the location, restaurants near by and an excellent sundry store in the hotel. The traditional Japanese breakfast was amazing and service was taken seriously. Room comfortable in the Main tower floor 31 and higher very spacious compared to the cramped room my last visit. Love that they have luggage service in lobby to transfer suitcases to next hotel. They also have boxes of you do a lot of shopping.that Airport Limousine Service stops at this hotel and is comfortable and affordable. I will definitely be back even though I was a little scared that the front desk couldn't find my reservation for check in, but eventually found it with my name spelled incorrectly.Agent in training but all worked out thanks to my printed out confirmation.Overall, a nice comfortable hotel and I will return.

Room service very quick and efficient. Newspaper is delivered every morning. There are many restaurants in the hotel. I did not get the chance to sample all of them!The location of the hotel is fantastic within close proximity to Shinjuku station and to the shops and to two parks!There are many other facilities around the hotel too.Check in is slow but every thing else is quite efficient. I would certainly go back !The food is good. I particularly enjoyed the Chinese restaurant.I would say that the hotel may be considered to be too big, but it does run quit efficiently.

This hotel is very close to the Shinjuku satiation, shopping the food. You can walk to many different attractions close by. The lobby is very grand and impressive. The room is ok, nothing too special.
user_name:
Bonnie T
East Brunswick, New Jersey

review_body: Booked a Plaza Luxe Queen Club Floor room. Room was in the (I believe) south tower and was in need of a fresh-up. Elevator lines we ridiculously long. The Luxe lounge doesn't serve breakfast and the evening hors' d'oeurves were skimpy to say the least.Went to desk and said that we were unhappy with our arrangements. The woman we dealt with was fabulous. For about $100 (USD) per night we were given a Premier Grand room in the main building. The room was fantastic! Large, new, modern wood paneled room and one of the best shower shower arrangements I have ever seen. The Premier Lounge had great views, a friendly staff, and much more extensive food choices. And no elevator problems in this tower. The only negative thing I can say is that no sparkling was offered. We thought the upgrade was well worth the price. All in all, we were quite surprised to see rooms so different in the same hotel.

We've stayed here before and it's never let us down. The hotel is very close to Shinjuku station which is super convenient for heading out to places on the train. It's also linked to the station by a covered walkway which is very useful when it's raining and you have bags. The hotel itself is large and extremely well run. They have English speaking staff and can help you with all sorts of things like organising tickets to events etc. The room was very clean and large for Japan. Amenities were good, lots of TV channels. It's basically everything you need in a well located package. We've stayed in the Park Hyatt and would choose the Keio Plaza over it every time.

This was the luxury home base for my family of 5 during our stay in Tokyo. We had great service from check in until check out. We had help with reservations for hotel restaurants and karaoke, the bus to the airport, a taxi to an event, and an in room-massage. The teppanyaki dinner in the hotel restaurant was scrumptious and the chef that we had was exceptional. The view from the 45th floor was beautiful and we saw sunsets that were amazing. Keio Plaza made for a great home base for all of us after a day of sightseeing and/or shopping. (See Veroinca T's review for all of the places close to the hotel.)

We love Keio Plaza and this is the place we stay every time we visit Tokyo.This hotel is also a good neighbor hotel of Tokyo Disneyland and therefore it offers shuttle to Disneyland. You just need to reserve the shuttle via their website in advance, because they do get full easily.Location is the best, you can reach the hotel from the airport limousine bus from both NRT and HND, the limousine bus operating schedule is pretty sufficient as well. Walk to Shinjuku station is about 5-10 minutes depends on your speed, and there are lots of restaurants around. We stayed in the south tower with three beds on a high floor, which WE CAN SEE THE FUJI MT. in the morning! From bellboy to front desk to housekeeping, their service is great that I don't have anything to complain about. The convenience store downstairs is a bonus and was a great relief when we had our late night snack craving. On site laundry service is available but price is on the expensive side, traveling with two kids and staying for more than a week, we opt for a cheaper laundry option. Luckily, we managed to find a coin operated laundry nearby and solve our problem.

I have stayed in this hotel many times. The rooms are standard, but they are always clean and well equipped. Everything works. The hotel location is excellent. It is near train stations, many restaurants and entertainments.You do not expect luxury or personalised service in this hotel. But if you need a clean well equipped hotel room with an excellent location, this is the right hotel.Breakfast buffet is satisfactory. There are many restaurants inside the hotel itself, also a mini mart that sells everything you can expect from a Seven Eleven. There is a direct shuttle bus to Disney and the airport.I come to Tokyo very often and hardly stay in the room but to sleep. So this hotel works for me. But if you want luxury rooms or service, you won't find it here. This hotel is good value for money and has many repeat customers.

+ ROOM: spacious and clean.+ 2 buffet restaurants & 1 japanese restaurant to choose for breakfast. (enjoyed it)+ near Tochomae staion (Toei Oedo Line) take an exit at the restaurants and turn left.+ walking distance to Keio mall, Lumin 1 & 2 mall, Odakyu Mall, Takashimaya mall.+ walking distance to Shinjuku Staion for taking a bus and taxi. (this is where we took a bus to disneysea)+ walking to Kabukicho where there are plenty of restaurants.+ plenty of restaurants near the hotel, just a few minutes walk.- a little expensive, if on a budget.

This is my first time writing trip advisor comment and I have to do this because the service here is absolutely terrible. I would score zero if I can... I ask for a bottle water in my room (first time, first night checking in) and they said that I cannot because I can only have two per night. The front desk ppl are treating us like kindergarten students. No service at all...and the room is reasonably old for the price we paid. I would never recommend this to any of friends...

My husband and I stayed at this Hotel for 6 nights in March/April.Although in a great location there are inadequate systems in place to cope with the vast numbers of people staying there.Breakfast queues are unacceptably long and there are also long waits for lifts.The hotel needs to be modernised and provide more breakfast restaurants and lifts.The lobby area is very unwelcoming.We arrived at 9.30 am after a 12 hr flight from the UK and our room was not available until 2pm. We received a very cool reception. There were no easy chairs to relax in and the lobby was freezing cold-not a good start to our holiday.

We have just stayed at the keio plaza for our honeymoon and had an awful stay!Totally overpriced and terrible rooms (room 2014) so dated and falling apart.The pictures they show on their websites are not what their rooms really are. They appear to be showing off their new refurbished rooms which is falsely showing the real rooms in the main tower.I booked this special trip on the basis of the lovely pictures they showed and we were so disappointed and upset when it was not what we hoped. We feel totally robbed.Our room was tiny and the facilities were really poor. The shower scolded us on many occasions and the room had condensation issues. Breakfast was poor and we even had to queue up for 20 mins for it!! Ridiculous! I mentioned to them it was our honeymoon yet they didn't seem to care as there was no acknowledgement of this or any special welcome.I do not expect anything for free, but we just stayed at the hotel icon in Hong Kong prior, and for the same sort of price as the Keio they were so far up there in comparison. They went totally out of their way to make our honeymoon the most memorable stay possible, the keio didn't even say congratulations! We felt like they just wanted our money and to be done with us! Not really what you want for a special time in your life!Would never recommend them to anyone and would never stay again! Such a shame as Tokyo was such an amazing place to be in but this hotel did not reflect this!

Spent first 2 nights in Tokyo here at the start of an escorted tour of Japan. The standard room I was on 21st floor was very comfortable with all the usual facilities. There is an eating court on floor 2 , which is where breakfast is served in two of the restaurants, but get there early as long gueues form before 7am. The onsite super market supple a reasonable variety of food and wine

Stayed for 2 nights on arrival in TokyoVery very busy hotel and you have to wait ages for the lift down to breakfast and then have to wait 40 minutes in a queue for breakfast. All hot food is stone cold.Rooms however goodLocation excellent Near to the buzz of centre of town
user_name:
helenah110
Isle of Man, United Kingdom

review_body: I chose this hotel because it was one of the pickup locations for a day trip that we had planned, but it proved to be much more than just a convenient site. Situated within easy walking distance from the Shinjuku train and subway stations, this modern 4 star hotel had a wonderful staff who were incredibly welcoming. (The Bell Hop showed us around our room as if she were entertaining us in her own home!) There were several different restaurants within the hotel and we chose one to have a beautiful breakfast buffet one morning. The rooms were not huge but adequate (although the beds were a bit hard), and we had a beautiful view of the Tokyo City government building with its twin towers. We would definitely stay here again if we have another chance to visit Tokyo.

The Keio Plaza is a very good hotel, but it is not a great hotel, and it can be slightly confounding. There was nothing terrible about this hotel, in fact it excelled in cleanliness, customer service, and location. All very important factors. But it does have some negatives. First, it does feel like a bit of an 80's artifact. This is not terrible, but the place looks like it needs a facelift - some style. It does not feel sleek, or current in anyway. But perhaps the most confounding thing is the lobby. While more and more hotels worldwide are concentrating on making the lobby the centerpiece of the hotel, this one is oddly dull - like a greyhound station without anywhere to sit. Of course there are some really old catering style chairs put inexplicably along the wall behind check-in, but other than that there is not one stick of cozy furniture in the lobby. You could not come down here to work on a laptop or order a glass of wine or people watch. I tried to relax at the lobby bar but it is a smoker's paradise and you need an oxygen tank to sit there longer than 5 minutes. I ended up walking over to the Hilton to work from my laptop...Again, it is a great and reasonably priced hotel in other regards: the location is the best in Shinjuku and the room was cleaner than most rooms in the states...I just wish it had a sense of style. I have stayed at the Hilton down the street (which is just a bit too far from central Shinkjuku but a great hotel) and I found it to be a lot more modern and elegant. However, if you are just here to explore amazing Tokyo from morning to night, this is a great hotel. And the redone sky bar is phenomenal. Expensive but great.

This is a centrally located hotel at shinjuku- walking distance to yakitori alley and major shopping areas. Very busy lobby as many tourists staying and expect sometimes long check in time. Downstairs has a tour agency which I took for hakone day trip which is excellent as keio is one of the pick up points.

Hotel is easily reached from Shinjuku station and rooms offering wonderful view of Tokyo. Food and shopping is all close by but you need to go exploring first as hotel covers a large area. Beautiful fittings in rooms, quiet and comfy beds. Staff are happy to offer assistance with a good grasp of English.

Lovely spot to enjoy the view of Shinjuku and surrounding areas while sipping a cocktail or afternoon tea. Impeccable service, very serene atmosphere. A little on the pricey side but you pay for the view.

This is a huge hotel with around 13 restaurants, service was excellent and the food pricey but well prepared. We had 2 private tours in Tokyo and this Hotel is very conveniently located. They offer free coffee in thde room and have excellent room service. We really enjoyed the breakfast buffet.

This Hotel was just amazing. Staff were wonderful, so friendly and very helpful. We had a great room with a view of Mount Fuji. Small, but very comfortable and clean. Was easy to locate and very close to the train station.

The hotel is close to the train station good shopping facilities and public transportation. The hotel features multiple bars/restaurants, a small bakery and a mini mart. Very enjoyable stay and will consider coming back. I recommend asking for higher floors to capture the views of Tokyo. The hotel also has free shuttle to Disneyland/sea.

Visited with hubby as a group of 37 on a Titan tour of Japan. Stayed for 2 nights. Good location with plenty of bars and restaurants to try.Rooms good size, clean and comfy. Breakfasts in the Glass Court buffet style. Good variety of both Japanese and Western food to suit all tastes. Very busy and had to queue to get in each day! Restaurants for evening meals were a bit pricey so found other places to eat outside of the hotel.The hotel is split into South Tower, North Tower and Main Tower and I found it to be a bit of a maze and confusing to find my bearings!Staff helpful.Roof top swimming pool only open June to September.Good and would recommend.

As I am sure is evident from the title, I found the Keio Plaza to be an incredible disappointment - and I went in without particularly high expectations. Good things first - the location is convenient for Shinjuku station and the staff were polite. Ineffectual, but polite. Yep - I am afraid that's all of the good things covered. Now on to the bad. We stayed in a family room. Given the price (this evening is JPY75k, so approx GBP550 or nearly USD700) and the fact that its clearly not a five star hotel, I was expecting something spacious at least. Nope - four single beds lined up side by side with no other room to move. Basically the family room is a regular room which they have crammed 2 extra beds in to and doubled the price. Nowhere to relax and certainly nothing like the pictures on the website. Bathroom was functional but far from adequate, never mind luxurious. It was tiny and had a shallow bath (come on guys - this is the country of the deep bath!). Beds were creeky and uncomfortable and the room was so dusty that it triggered allergies pretty quickly. The Keio Plaza is a large hotel. That means expect to queue for everything (rather than expecting them to have provided enough of everything for a larger hotel). Lifts - 3 for 30 floors - so expect between a 5 and 15 minute wait to get in or out. Breakfast - you're looking at 30 mins to an hour. And the food quality when you get in is similar to the rooms - i.e. passable for a 3 star older run of the mill business hotel - but when you are paying as much as a Four Seasons, you will be expecting an awful lot more. Service was pretty checklist (especially at the restaurant) and when we complained we were met with a stoically stony face rather than any form of apology. Internet is slow and you are required to go through a lengthy login procedure each and every time you re-enter the room. In short, the place is fine if you know what to expect - which is what I would have expected from a 3 star hotel charging one third or less of the price. But at this price bracket, the quality of accommodations, food and service is frankly outrageous. I have stayed at many hotels in Tokyo at a much lower rate and have never encountered such issues (see reviews eg of Grand Hyatt, Palace and Andaz). I would never return to the Keio Plaza and suggest others look elsewhere too.

This hotel is conveniently located within walking distance in anything in Shinjuku and close to the subway. It is a very late hotel with lots of big tour groups. The lobby and front desk are crowded but the staff deals with the crowd efficiently and politely. Check in was pretty fast. The breakfast buffet that is included is very good. Many options for westerners with an omelet bar. The fresh fruit and veggies are safe to eat in Japan. They have a wonderful salad and as weird as that is I ate salad for breakfast every day.I have the hotel 3 stars simply because the room was so small and worn. Most Japanese hotels have small rooms but this was very small. The carpet, bedding and upholstery looks to be about 20 years old. Just worn through.Bathrooms are tiny with little counter space. Good water pressure and hit water. Comfortable bed. Great wifi.

We were here for a make a wish trip and this hotel was in a great location! It was nice and clean and the staff was very friendly. I love the water pressure in the shower lol. There is a restaurant right downstairs and it has a large variety of foods. Further down from here is a large variety of restaurants as well. Getting around was very easy with the staffs knowledge and if the didnt know, they definately found out and would give you maps and directions. I had no problems with language, as I only speak English and in the surrounding areas everyone definately did their best to help you out.

Stayed here for a couple of nights rooms well equipt and nit as small as I had expectedStaff were very efficient and service was good If you stay here you need to visit the sky lounge on the 45th floor of the northern tower I know it's expensive but it's worth it fir the views
user_name:
Henth1
Bury St. Edmunds, United Kingdom

review_body: Awesome location, walking distance to Shinjuku station, Keio Plaza/shopping & restaurants. The hotel itself is quite large, immaculately decorated & is very clean. The staff are polite and efficient and their understanding of English is quite good. They offer luggage forwarding and they also have a handy shuttle bus to and from Disneyland & Disney Sea; but these need to be booked in advance through the concierge or bell captain. The room and bathroom are fairly small/narrow but contained all the necessary amenities and plenty of toiletries. We were impressed with how quiet the room was and how we couldn't hear any street noise at all.The only complaints we had was that the hotel internet/wifi was hopeless; the queue for breakfast was often long and the pillows weren't hypoallergenic. We were definitely allergic to something in the pillows as 2 out of 3 of us were waking up in the morning with swollen & itchy faces/eyes. They might contain duck down or something similar. And we'd recommend lining up early for breakfast, especially in peak periods as the wait can be lengthy and your wait for the elevator back to your room can be even longer. If you have 8-9am tours planned, this can be frustrating. If you plan your time accordingly & invest in pocket wi-fi, you should have a great stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel and we would stay again.

Big international hotel with international standards. Staff was very friendly and the room was clean. Bathroom was a little small but sufficient. Breakfast was a disappointment. While the food was good and the hotel offers Western, American and Japanese Buffets, the wait before entering the Breakfast rooms was way too long. We had to wait 20 minutes only to get in every day. This is disturbing in a city were visitors want to see the fish market in the morning or have to leave for Disneyland early. So we ended having breakfast at Starbucks to safe time.

This is not your "romantic" hotel neither your "boutique" hotel... This is a large business hotel. It is well located just steps away from Shinjuku Station. It is clean with well trained staff. It caters to Japanese business people and large conventions. It does not have a lot of character but it is a sure value. It has several restaurants serving quality food. It also has hundreds of restaurants just blocks away.

Stayed here for two nights at start of Tour of Japan. Very impressive lobby with a large and wonderful cherry blossom display which had been set up in the last few days. Had a room in South Tower (1951) which was a very good size despite being a standard type room. Twin beds, two small chairs and table and plenty of room as well. Great for one and would be perfectly ok for two. Beds seem fairly firm as mentioned in other reviews. Free wifi seemed quite fast, accessed by using a code printed on key envelope. Lots of different restaurants in house to satisfy most tastes from Japanese to Western. However the main Shinjuku Railway Station is only a 5 to 10 minute walk and there is a wide selection of restaurants, fast food places and retail areas to satisfy most.

This vast hotel is very well located, in one of the main business and entertainment centers of Tokyo, near one of ghe main train stations. The rooms in the hotel are not renovated. The hotel is always crowded and the staff always busy, though doing their best to assist the guests. There's a long waiting time for Breakfast.

Standard room with very outdated bathroom. It should be more like a 3 star hotels according to American standard (Room is 3 stars and bathroom is 2 stars). Very large hotel facility, plenty of restaurants, and close proximity to JR Shinjuku.

There is nothing very wrong about Keio Plaza, although there are a couple of things that are a bit odd. This is a massive hotel with two towers, just a few minutes from Shinjuku station. The scale will come to dominate things. Firstly the lobby is a vast desert of marble, without very much in it (not even really nice places to sit). If you want a coffee, or just to sit down and wait for someone it feels a bit unwelcoming. The restaurants are also a bit strange. Not bad (in fact the Sushi restaurant is excellent), but oddly laid out. Note that most of them are on 2F, which is actually below the Lobby floor!The biggest problem is with breakfast. When the hotel is busy you will have to wait in line. It probably won't be for more than 10 minutes, and it's very efficient, but this isn't confined to peak times.As for the rooms, they seem fine. A reasonable size by Tokyo standards. They don't feel as hyper modern as some, but you won't feel let down.Positives+ LocationNegatives- Lobby- Breakfast queueing

Stayed here for 3 nights with my friends.Check in was very smooth and took only 10 minutes.Hotel Staff were very helpful.We have booked superior rooms and they were very spacious.Location of hotel is very central. Shinjuku staion is less than 10 minute walk which make travel around Tokyo very easy.I will highly recommend this hotel. .

The Keio Plaza near the Shinjuku station has access to many restaurants and shopping centres and bars. For us, access to the Fuchu racecourse was the key event.The buffet breakfast of Japanese and Western dishes was great. The room was clean and serviced as one would like.Staff were very helpful when I had WiFi problems. Just my age !!! Would recommend it

V Large modern hotel only a 5 minute walk from Shinjuku station. Limousine bus to/from the airports is very easy and fast (to Haneda) and comes right to the hotel door.Surprisingly for a hotel of this size and despite the advert in reception, there is no business centre.Breakfast at weekends can be a bit of a battle - I had to queue over 15 minutes to get in to one of the restaurants and the hotel restaurants are expensive when compared to the restaurants around Shinjuku but that's not that uncommon. Have stayed here twice and would definitely stay again.

I have a South Tower room, which is typical in size to an American chain hotel room. Not the largest but quite adequate. Took the queen bed option. Nice 40"+ flat panel TV with a few English channels and CNN cable news. Fast free Internet and well lighted room with lots of 110v outlets. Room also has small refrigerator and lots of hangers. Daily housekeeping with sheet change option after 3 days. Full bidet toilet, handheld shower, shower cap, hair dryer and toiletry. The only minor complaint is that you can hear people walking above you and the walls are thin enough to make out a faint conversation next door. However, you get use to these distractions quite fast. Overall 5 stars. Great location to train station/West bus terminal through covered passage way (about 1/4 mile long). Subway line outside front of hotel and 2 large department stores in train station at end of covered passage. Major subway lines go through train station as well as JR rail. Great places to eat! Wow!

Outstanding hotel experience in downtown Shinjuku. Just a short walk for the JR Railroad station and any store you might be looking for nearby. Two towers which both afford wonderful views of the city night or daytime. The breakfuas is an amazing experience with a choice of three different restaurants to choose from. A well stocked convenience store and many restaurants with the hotel building itself. The rooms are great, the beds comfortable, lots of closet space, drawers, a safe and small fridge in the room. The bathroom is very nice the shower work great and temperature setting is really nice. If you've never had or tried this you'll want it at home to go with the (wonderful) heated toiled seat. One of the better hotel chains in Japan!

Stayed 3 nights in the hotel. The location is perfect. Just 500 m from Shinjuku station and Shinjukus commercial area. In the hotel a restaurant, but very close are lots of food facilities, for every taste.The rooms are spacious and well equiped. Free wi-fi, lotes of amenities. Very rich breakfast in 2 different styles. American breakfast and Japanies/Western style.The rooms are in the main building and the Sothern tower. It can be a little confusing. because the southern tower is far from the main building.Hope to come again to that hotel.

I stayed for three nights a couple of weeks ago. Good hotel with a number of restaurants and a convenience store which was actually pretty useful for picking up a few gifts as my free time on this trip was very limited. I had breakfast in the Jurin restaurant and there was a good variety of food available in their buffet, it was a good start to every day. The public areas a impressive, the room was a little tired maybe but was clean and comfortable. The other people in my party were very happy with it. We used one of the meeting rooms on the 47 floor and the view was amazing. There was no iron in the room which surprised me a little but I had one within about 15 minutes of asking for one.

The hotel is very well positioned near the Shinjuku station. The rooms are small but apparently that's the standard in Tokyo. There are many amenities in the hotel such as bars and restaurants and also a 24 hour convenience store. The breakfast is fantastic with many options in 3 separate restaurants

A huge comfortable hotel that is about a 5 minute walk from the huge Shinjuku train station. Rooms are clean, comfortable and functional. No frills but everything you need works well - strong water flow, hot water, kettle and hair dryer. Amenities include everything (toothbrush, comb, razor, shampoo, conditioner, body wash etc) except body lotion.The breakfast buffet came with the room and was served in Level 2. It was average - Again sufficient but not special.

We stayed at this Hotel in Tokyo for a few nights. The Hotel is a luxury Hotel with all amenities and relevant services. We enjoyed our stay. one major problem we had is the air-conditioning in the room. Although it has been 3rd week of March the temperatures in the room have been too high, but since the cooling has been switched off, we had to bear with it - too warm. The standard rooms a small but comfortable. Also the Hotel is a bit overpriced

Wow amazing hotel, staff so helpful and friendly, lovely room with superb breakfast included. Choice of restaurants . We wanted to try sake so went to the sake bar, Nakamura and head chef were simply amazing people could not do enough for us, we tried three different sake's and chef taught my wife to use chop sticks.Food in the hotel very expensive but found some lovely places just outside from hotel. Can,t recommend this hotel enough and thanks to Japan travel centre for booking this for us.

This hotel is huge, constantly busy with uncaring staff and in desperate need of updating and customer service adjustment to yes we can.No matter what my request to the front desk was weather getting an additional key to my room or trying to upgrade my room it was a HUGE challenge.The lounge executive suite we got was large in size with very out dated well worn furniture. Granted the view is great if they could move a few building blocking it. Should be called a peek-a-view room.The bathroom is small and cheaply outfitted but is well stocked with amenities like lotions, disposable razors and toothbrushes etc.I am convinced the bed is made of bricks. It is ROCK hard with thin coverings and foam pillows which make for a uncomfortable nights sleep. The tv is far from bed and you will have to strain your eyes to see it.The lobby is like a railway station 24 hours a day. If not packed with tourists it has various functions going on. The desk manager almost sent us away as we asked for a concierge and told they did not have one till we figured out desk manager is concierge.The desk manager could barely understand English and could not help us. So we took a cab to our destination instead of a train.They have a flyer in room for an indoor massage for $89US. Try booking it, person on phone doesn't speak English. Go to South tower, arrive 15 later and give me a brochure that massage is $500USD!!! No complaining because it would be lost in translation. I guess this hotel does not have many English speaking guests.The train station is situated about 15 mins walk and I am sure it would be great and easy to use if we could just read Japanese. BecauseEven the machine dispensing tickets is only in Japanese. The train station is a complete underground jungle with so many pathways it is impossible not to get lost - again unless you speak Japanese which unfortunately we don't. Dont expect a help desk or conductor to set you on right train, it is every man for himself and it is overwhelmingly busy.Booking bus to Disneyland was pretty simple, you go to bellman desk and choose from 3 or 4 times that bus leaves to Disney and a return time. The bus is run by the Disney company and encourages people to go spend their money at Disneyland. Bring lots because it will be a very expensive day.Was a fun day but expect 2 hour long waiting times every ride, massive long lines for food and even for popcorn too.There is a convenience store in basement of hotel which carries a large section of anything you may need in a fix. It is expensive but easy to access if you can figure out how to get there.We went to the Japanese / Western breakfast ONCE during our five day stay at the Keio Plaza. It is 90% dinner food and the rest is made up of stale pastries and bread. You can try convince the chef to make you an omelette in sign language because he does not understand English.Breakfast itself was extremely poor and definitely do not recommend it at 3000 yen a person.The luxe lounge is located in the south tower. A 10 minute stroll through hotel and up another elevator. The view is expansive, the food selection is not. You lucky to find pretzels, dried peas and an Asian mixed dry goods. When I came the small dessert were out but replaced quickly but not worth the trip. Do not take drinks out of the lounge - it is forbidden.Overall we did not enjoy our 5 day stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel at all. This is not a luxury hotel. I actually feel bad for the reviews who think it is a luxury hotel as they obviously do not know what a luxury hotel is. This is a high volume tourist transit hotel - a far cry from anything you'd want to return to after a long day of sightseeing.

We stayed on the 29th floor at South Tower.The room is clean and of decent size but it does look dated. Some ceiling works need to be done as I can see cracks.Service at the bell desk is mediocre. The bell desk staff we approached on our first day did not inform me about making booking for the airport limousine bus service but simply directed me to pay at the vending machine. It was until the last day of our stay, a gentleman who came to help us with our luggage for the check-out informed us that we need to book our seats.For those who are visiting Disneyland, book your seats in advance.Location is good, you have good selection of restaurants just across the road. Isetan, Takashimaya, Lumine and Shinjuku station are just 5-10min walk.I may stay here again but maybe get a better room.

A few years ago I was in this hotel and I emailed the hotel a month before to arrange for a extra bed for my daughter. Everthing worked out great and I wrote a review with 5 stars. This time I did the same with an email for extra bed month ago and the reply is extra bed will be arranged but because I booked with airline so I won't get free breakfast...I feel little odd but I didn't react to it. When I check in at the front desk I ask if there are 3 beds and I was told "yes". Went up and found only 2 beds. Call front desk and was told house keeping will add the bed before we come back for dinner. when we came back still only 2 bed. Call again and finally got the extra bed. I mean not big deal but it has changed. The friendliness is gone so I will only give 4 stars and next trip I will be at other hotel most likely

Classy establishment. Large rooms for tokyo standards. Best aspect was the direct transport available to and from airport via bus (for a reasonable extra fee). very Central location. Close to three or four train stations (both JR and Tokyo metro), major shopping and restaurant district. Several eating and drinking options inside the hotel if you don't feel like going out. And also a convenience store right inside the hotel. Fast and efficient t check in and check out process. The bathroom was tiny and there were some signs of a little bit of mold. But most people would not notice. That was the only negative I would give this place. I've been to Tokyo 5 or 6 times and this was my favorite hotel so far.

I took a 12 day tour of Vietnam with World Spree and they offered a three night layover in Tokyo before heading home to Canada. There was no tour included here so my sister and I were on our own. I did research before arriving and discovered this hotel is very well located . It is about 2 blocks from the Shinjku metro station. We were able to use the metro with ease. There is also a limousine bus that you can get from the airport and it takes you right to the Keio Plaza. We also took a day tour to Mt. FUji and the bus for this tour also came right to the hotel. If you go out the front door of the hotel and walk right across the street, there is a pedestrian walkway all lit up that takes you to the metro. There is also a plethora of restaurants. The best thing though was the convenience store in the lower floor of the hotel. When we arrived it was late and we were tired and hungry. We asked about a grocery store in the area and they told us about the store. We were pleasantly surprised to see they sold wine. Sushi to go and all the other goodies you can find in any convenience store. We went to our hotel room had wine, sushi and a small bag of chips in our pj's. We were happy campers.We also found the hotel staff to be very helpful. The rooms were also very nice with great views. The breakfast included could be eaten at several different restaurants. They were all great places with an array of various foods.

This is a fairly anonymous, corporate hotel but it is well located, rooms are generous size, clean & comfortable; service is efficient & friendly. Restaurants are good, and offer a good choice of options. A good, safe choice.
user_name:
JonW68
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Visit Tokyo for 5D/4N and stayed in Deluxe Room Keio Plaza throughout. Room was quite spacious as compared to the normal size of hotel in Tokyo. Mattress and pillow are average but no complain (unless you are very particular - depend to individual) Subway (MRT) is conveniently next to the hotel and if you walk another 5 minutes opposite the hotel you can reach Shinjuku where cafe, restaurant, pharmacy and many other shops are easily available. Location is great ! Breakfast : 3 types of restaurants available for you to choose such as full western restaurant (Jurin), combination western and Japanese (Glass court) and full Japanese restaurant. Try every single one on a different day. You will love the varieties. Suggest to come early say before 7.30am for breakfast to avoid long queue (depending to the season or when do you come and visit Japan)

The rooms were very clean and comfortable. Quite doors. Good beds and bedding. Many food options (the Shabu Shabu downstairs was pretty delicious). Attentive and quick with requests and check-ins. Bus schedules ran like a clock each time. Open late convenience store downstairs. Just a very complete place. To add to the positive experience, I left a hundred dollars (in Yen) in my room and had it promptly returned.
user_name:
DCGuy3000
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Over hyped, this is not a 4 star hotel as claims more like 2 star with small rooms mediocre service, bad food especially in their Japanese tapanyaki restaurant on the 7 th floor rubbish food poor service, in all a sad experience unfortunately prepaid through an agent and non refundable for five days indeed a sad situation, the management completely uncaring.

Excellent location with very friendly staff members at the hotel. The buffet was average which its probably because I had a such high expectations but I guess its more for a business hotel rather than for leisure. The room was very clean and spacious for a standard room, I guess the deluxe room will just mean you get a better view of the city if you get the room facing the Shinjuku area, as the hotel is surrounded by a few tall buildings like the government, university etc.

Stayed here for a couple of nights at the end of a ski trip. Hotel is pretty centrally located, 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station (be warned: world's busiest station!). Rooms are small, but comfortable and well equipped (bath, shower, hair-drier, yakuta etc). The hotel bars and restaurants are very expensive: ¥1,200 (£9) for a small beer. Better off heading out of the hotel: there's loads of restaurants within 200m (a fact the hotel concierge is strangely reluctant to reveal!)

This hotel caters to large tourist groups and conventions. We stayed here as part of a post cruise experience with Holland America. It has no charm or sense of place and the rooms can be generously described as bland. The property is well located in town but do not stay here if you are traveling independently. You'll get run over by the mobs of conventioneers and bus loads of tourists.

This is an excellent hotel for several reasons. Excellent city centre location near Shinjiku district. Hotel rooms very good and the bed was super comfortable. Great shower pressure and incredible heated toilet seat. Lots of towels. Concierge will deliver iron to room. Breakfast was excellent with either Japanese or western options. For western options great omelettes or fried Bk available. There is a stunning rooftop bar with great views of the city especially at nighttime. Check out easy. I really enjoyed this hotel.

The hotel is consider quite near to the station and it has a shelter tunnel that links to it. Convenient to travel from airport to hotel. Arrived in Haneda Airport and took a bus which drops off directly at the hotel lobby. The main reason that i chose this hotel is because they have a free shuttle bus service to Tokyo Disney Resort. The hotel have great view and the room is neat and quiet. Bathroom is abit small but the bathtub is deep. They do have a tour agency at the lobby floor which can help you to book for day tour to Fuji Mountain. Overall it might be abit small but most hotels in Japan is about the same. Good part is that although it near Shinjuku station but its located in the west side which is some distance away from the more chaotic area of Shinjuku, so in the night if you are returning late it is still safe. However if you want to walk to there it just like a 15 min walk. Around the hotel they have 3 convenience store, Hooters, Subway, Starbucks, Sega UFO catcher store, one of their medicine store (which sells almost everything from cosmetic, snacks, facial mask to medcine and shampoo) and a few good local restaurant (One of the Udon shop is so nice).Overall i will choose this hotel if i visit Japan again, the guest service is attentive and respond fast to your needs.

Transportation from the airport is provided to this hotel which enabled us to choose this hotel for our stay in Tokyo. This hotel is conveniently located next to a train station which is walking distance. The staff were great and attentive. The bed sheets weren't comfortable but overall had a pleasant stay.

Probably the travel agent chose Keio Plaza since we came in a big group. Nothing's wrong with the hotel, but the distance to shopping is a bit far. The only complaint is our check-in process. Our group of four came earlier than the big group. The hotel refused to check us in even though they saw our names. The only reason is the travel agent didn't give them what kind of room. I know this is Japan, but at least why don't they put us in the low category room by only asked us if it's OK.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza for a total of 3 nights last week. Booked the first two nights via a global hotel booking website and the third by phone direct with the hotel hoping for a cheaper rate. Upon check in, discovered they had booked us in for the wrong night on our return visit. The problem with booking direct was that they did not send an email or text confirmation which would have highlighted the problem ahead. Anyway, they would not honour the quoted rate as they have 'dynamic pricing' and the rates had moved !! No amount of haggling would move them ...not even a room upgrade or offer of a free breakfast !!! the whole process was just robotic. The rules are set down and they will not budge.We encountered further difficulties upon checkout when they would not accept the Commonwealth Bank of Australia issued pre loaded Travel Money Card. The receptionist was well aware of the problem as it has happened many times before. A hotel of this size and stature is negligent in not fixing its payment systems nor advising potential guests of its inability to accept this type of payment. Overall a frustrating experience !!!!!!! Beyond that the hotel is in a fabulous location in Shinjuku, 5 min walk from the Shinjuku rail station, surrounded by thousands of restaurants and bars and the well known lights of the district. The airport limousine buses from Narita and Haneda Airports stop at the Keio Plaza Hotel which is a very convenient.

We were so glad we chose this hotel. The location was perfect for making the most of three days in Tokyo. Very close to the trains making it easy to get anywhere in the city. Our room was large by Tokyo standards, very clean and comfortable. We even had a distant view of Mt. Fuji.Don't pass up the free tickets to a tea ceremony. It was beautiful and informative.

I stayed in KEIO Plaza hotel Tokyo 4 to 6 March 2017, I left my La Praire foaming cleansing in my room 2368 south wing . After checked in Park Hotel Haneda( because on 7 March I must left Tokyo early flight) I called housekeeping and to my surprised they said they didn't see it. I am so dissapointed with this hotel. I don't think this is 5 stars, because I also found hair in the basket amenity and in plastic sandal, too. Be carefull when stay in this hotel.

We stayed in this hotel to try out their new Premier Grand Club Lounge located on the 45th floor. The new lounge was just opened on December 2016. Take note that you had to get a Premier GRAND Room in order to have access to this new lounge. There are also other Premier rooms (without the "GRAND") which have access to another lounge which is not the new one. The Premier Grand rooms are totally brand new and very very impressive and large. We enjoyed the 360 degree Tokyo views from the Premier Grand Lounge and did not bother to visit Tokyo Tower or the Tokyo Skytree. Check-in was via the Premier Counter at the lobby and we were immediately whisked to the 45th floor lounge and was checked-in by the very helpful and efficient concierge. We also bought our airport limousine tickets from the Premier Lounge concierge. Breakfast starts at 5:00 AM and you just have to request it from them if you have a very early flight.

Keio came highly recommended by friends, but the check in process put us off. A friend and I stayed here for a week and we were only given 1 keycard access for the room. When we requested for an additional card, we were flatly turned down due to "hotel's policy". However, we saw that there were other guests who were given more than 1 keycard (3, in fact!) and that just left a bitter aftertaste. The floor we were on was supposedly non-smoking, but the cigarette stench was so tangible! Room was big by Tokyo's standards, clean and came with the basic necessities, but I am not sure if I would return given that we paid premium only to get moderate treatment. Hotel's service was cold, not the usual Japanese standards, and I would have preferred it if they could speak some form of English given that this is an international hotel. Or maybe I am just unlucky to have met service staff who could not understand what I was trying to say. If you're looking for a good sized hotel and centrally located, this is a good choice. Other than that, don't expect any form of value add from the hotel.

Good check-in process. Like all of Japan, service staff have a high care factor. Good breakfast but hot cooked food not kept hot. In winter the room heating is set way too hot. You can turn it off but then no air turnover. No window to even partially open. No in room safe. Pillows are typical pretty = useless = way too thin.

The Keio Plaza is a very huge hotel with any restaurants. It is about 10 minutes walk to the nearest train station and to restaurants and shops. The hotel needs an upgrade. Everything is dated. The website and pictures is not true to the present condition. Will only stay here because of the price per night is lower than the rest we want and also it has a free shuttle to Tokyo Disneyland Resort.

This is a very pleasant hotel only reason I couldn't give them 5 stars is that the room was non smoking but carpets seemed old and still retained the smell. The lounge upstairs had amazing views of the city but was a bit pricey. Gym was small but had decent equipment

Easy to get to various train lines and easy walking to all areas of Shinjuku. Rooms are standard Japanese size which didn't bother us as we were out more than in. Hotel is also one of the few hotel stops for Limousine Bus from Narita. Easy option for first timers to Tokyo or if you're taking extra luggage back home.

downtown shinjuku, have a great stay, close to tourist spot areas, subway stations just at the base of hotel, could be very confusing for first timers like us, but good thing we have a friend in Japan to guide us.
user_name:
Hanie R
New York City, New York

review_body: For our first visit to Tokyo, the very centrally located Keio Plaza was our base for our six night stay.Firstly, the hotel is located very close to the maze that is the Shinjuku station, from there you can access more of less any kind of train travel (JR, Tokyo Metro). The areas itself also houses many bars and restaurants, we enjoyed some delicious meals in the area.Back to the hotel, it is huge, which makes it a little impersonal. As with most places in Japan, everybody you encounter is beyond polite and can't do enough to help you, but you probably won't encounter the same face more than once or twice.The room of the hotel was a very good size for Japan and is very comfortable, with plenty of storage space and a good, comfortable bed. Just be aware, despite being advertised as having 'air conditioning', this in fact only blows hot air, not cold. This was fine for our late February stay, but I'm not quite sure it would be as comfortable in the steamy summer months.Our room came with breakfast each day. There are three options for this, we tried the two western buffets, which were very well stocked with good quality food.Our primary reason for being in Tokyo was to run the Tokyo Marathon, and with the start line more or less out the front of the hotel, the Keio Plaza was a great base.As I mentioned earlier, the staff in the hotel were universally fantastic and for this reason, we'd definitely consider the Keio Plaza if we find ourselves back in Tokyo.

We stayed here for 2 nights at the end of our trip in Japan. The hotel is accessible from Shinjuku JR Station West exit via an undercover walkway to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building, it took us about 10 mins. It was easy to navigate between the station and the hotel, however we got very lost trying to find our way to the other side of the station to where the action is in Shinjuku. One night we gave up and got a cab! But if we had more time I'm sure we would have figured it out!Upon check-in we were given a free upgrade to a triple room, which was by far the largest room we experienced in Japan, and with a great view on the 31st floor! The bathroom was still quite compact and a bit dated but served its purpose. We enjoyed our yukatas and bed clothes. We experienced our first earthquake in our room 31 storeys up - all we felt was a few gentle sways!We enjoyed dinner at the Glass Court Super Buffet one night, it was the most expensive meal we had in Japan but I think we got our money's worth! The desserts were delicious! We also had a drink up at the Sky Lounge which was wonderful and a fabulous view of the city at night.We utilised the hotel's free shuttle to Disney. It was quoted to take 70mins which is a lot longer than it would take on the train but we wanted to get there before opening time to beat the crowds so we decided we'd prefer the convenience of a door-to-door bus. The bus took much less than 70mins and we had our tickets are were queued up with the locals in no time. We booked ourselves on the 1630 shuttle back to the hotel, assuming we would probably leave earlier and get the train home, but we had such a wonderful day we almost didn't make it to the bus in time! After a long day with not much sleep, we were again happy to have the convenience of the hotel shuttle.The staff at Keio Plaza were wonderful - from helping us book our Disney shuttle to assisting us buying some cold and flu medication at the pharmacy which is inside the building. We had a lovely stay, thank you!

We have stayed at Keio plaza many times over the past years and have been extremely disappointed this time...On checking in our room was upgraded which made us feel good , but arriving in our room there were stains all over our carpet and also on bed linen , management offered a replacement room 3 m2 smaller for a triple room which was wall to wall beds...therefore we decided to stay in our original room...We then connected to the internet through the hotels Wi Fi ... the signal was so inconsistent we could not maintain a constant connection ... managements advice was to reboot our phone near our room door, as the signal was strongest there...Ok the above issues you would expect at a3 star hotel , but Keio is rated 6 star and charges $450 / night...They could do a lot better....

We just spent four nights at this hotel which was recommended by our travel agent. 1) Great location close to transport, resturants, etc.2) Quality on site resturants3) Very clean and well maintained rooms and hotel in general4) Great service from all the Keio team5) Considering the quality very good value6) In our view the mark of a good hotel is that it is calming when you enter the Keio Plaza certainly is an oasis from the Tokyo hustle and bustle.Brod and Helen Australia

Took the advice of others here and requested a high floor, south tower, view to the west. Was rewarded with a lovely view of Mount Fuji as a crisp clear winter's morning broke on our first day in town. The hotel is about a 10 minute bag drag from the station - firstly across the main road, then through narrower alleyways of, mainly, assorted food places.The nicer, more upscale shops and restaurants are on the other side of Shinjuku station - easiest access is to walk across past the South Exit. That said, the eating places you'll pass on the way to the hotel are fine for a quick bite. Lawson and 7-11 convenience stores are in that same area on the hotel side of things.Hotel room itself was a good size for a triple. Bathroom good - the usual well-appointed Japanese set-up. General feel is that it's a little dated, but perfectly adequate.

The Keio Plaza is super clean, in a great location with a motivated and efficient staff.I have never seen such a fast and organized check in process. Everyone was hopping about to handle and look after you luggage. The desk agent had all the information at her fingertips and quickly dispatched us to our room. Wow, it was so easy. It was also nice to see people that really took their jobs seriously.Our room was clean and comfortable with American style electrical outlets-No need for adapters!!! Hot water was instant with excellent water pressure. Beds were comfortable with two pillows-one firm one soft. The lobby and common areas were large with a 5 star feel.Again, everything was so clean, neat, and orderly. The hotel also has several excellent restaurants. For me, this hotel has it all.

I visited Tokyo with family and stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel since members of my family were hotel members and had booked the exclusive member floor. Although I did not book the exclusive member floor, I still enjoyed my stay overall. The rooms were large by Japan standards and very clean. I didn't plan to stay in the room for long anyway so I had no issues with any amenities or details in the room. A few hiccups, however, did happen. One minor one was that even though I booked a non-smoking room, I was initially put in smoking room/floor anyway. They quickly switched me, which was no big issue at all. One annoyance, however, was the fact that the hotel members who do have their own breakfast lounge area required to pay an additional fee to eat at the breakfast buffet with the rest of the non-hotel guests. This was rather surprising to us since the hotel members' breakfast actually cost more if non-members wanted to eat there. We didn't quite understand the policy and had requested the executive lounge front desk to ask the supervisor. But was told that supervisor would've said the same thing anyway and gave no further explanation. She and her aloof attitude was the only wrinkle in our stay though. The rest of the staff, both regular front desk and premium lounge front desk, were great. Overall, great value for anyone's trip to Tokyo who is looking for convenience to Shinjuku station, shopping and being in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku.

It was my dream of my life , visit to Japan.My dream came true and stayed Keio Plaza Hotel .When you entered the hotel there was a huge flower arrangement, and fragrance amazing .There was a money exchange machine whatever you wantHotel stuff kindly, smiling like a dream that we seePlease go and stay

My heart goes to the hotel service above world class. They are so efficient and guest oriented. Special thank to Reception Kamata for doing right all the check in procedures. Good job guys ! Salute the japanese hospitality!

Very convenient since the hotel is located within the Shinjuku area and it only takes about a 10-15 minute walk to arrive at Shinjuku Station. Service is excellent; breakfast buffet is good. They also provide a free bus/shuttle service for guests who want to visit Tokyo Disneyland and Disneysea.

Very good location!. Just a few blocks to Shinjuku Station and shopping/entertainment/dining area. Have been using this hotel for over 20 years. The newly redecorated South Tower provides a good ambience. Staff very courteous and friendly. Will stay there every time we go to Tokyo.

Stayed here with a friend and we had a phenomenal time. Very central location in Shinjuku, many types of rooms to choose from (4 Bedded Rooms are great for a girlfriends’ getaway or family vacation; there are even Hello Kitty themed rooms!), and lots of dining options within the hotel. Apart from regular amenities like spa, pool, gym, lounges, and cocktail bars, there are so many activities to try be it the traditional tea ceremony (highly recommended) or the Japanese harp recitals. Exceptional customer service and express check-out available. Keio really isn’t just any hotel; it’s an experience on its own. Only tiny complaint I have is that the Wi-Fi password needs to be re-entered daily.

We stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel during the Christmas Holidays in Japan and I can say that Keio met my standards for a clean, spacious and complete room. What was not a pleasant experience though was the long wait to get our non-smoking room during our check-in. I cannot understand why we were given a smoking room when we had kids with us and we requested for a non-smoking room. Anyways, after we settled in our new room, everything was fine.

Every time I travel to Tokyo, I usually stay in Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo. This hotel near the Shinjuku Station, you can reach this hotel by NEX from Narita airport, or limousine bus directly from the Narita/Haneda airport, too. Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo have free shuttle bus to go to Disneyland, this service is very good! Their staffs are nice, polite and helpful! The room is clean and comfortable!

I have always stayed at Keio Plaza whenever my family are in Tokyo, which is at least once or twice a year, for holidays for so many years now. I have since also joined their EIC Membership as Prime Member (which is points based). Many accolades have been accorded to the Keio Plaza, Shinjuku and I have not been disappointed until my last stay from 28 Dec 16 to 4 Jan 17 (7 nights). I had booked online in mid-2016 and it which was an eagerly anticipated trip over the New Year. I had unwittingly booked my stay from Keio Plaza's official website but via iPrefer reservation which unknown to me, was a partner reservation system. As a result, when I checked in, I was denied my Prime Membership privileges which include breakfast vouchers, access to Member's Lounge and inability to chalk up membership points. Try as I will to explain to the Check-In Officer that I had booked directly through the hotel official website, he was adamant that nothing could be done, even after having consulted someone in the office that must be someone senior to him. I left it at that in frustration and total disbelief. I found time on my 2nd day (29th Dec) to feedback my unhappy check-in experience with the hotel. To my surprise, when I returned from my day trip to Karuizawa (shopping outlet and ski resort), an envelop had been slipped under my door with a note of apology along with with breakfast vouchers for the remaining days and access pass to the Member's Lounge. The cap in the feather was that the hotel had spontaneously changed my room rate to a preferential member's rate with a substantial difference in my favour! To me, that was a wonderful turnabout and Japanese hospitality at its best! My faith in Keio Plaza Shinjuku was completely restored.So why Keio Plaza Shinjuku? The airport limousine from Narita and Haneda brings one to its doorstep and there is a ticketing machine next to the concierge to buy your return airport limousine ticket (and do book a seat with the concierge 1st). It's a Disney Friendly hotel and provides free return bus trips from the hotel to Tokyo Disneyland and/or Disney Sea and back, but you need to make reservations with the concierge.It is conveniently located within walking distances to the major shopping centres in Shinjuku, restaurants and bars, electronic stores, entertainment and theatres and most importantly, Shinjuku Station with all the major lines that can bring you to Mt. Takao, Tsukiji Fish Market, Monja Street and almost anywhere else. If it rains, borrow an umbrella from the concierge or use the covered walkway to Shinjuku Station and the shopping centres. The hotel's restaurants and bars are also excellent.Finally, if you are hotel member, do not ever book through iPrefer!!

best place ever , near shinjuku station and great night life area with lots of great restaurants and bars .... you will not be disappointed ,,,, have fun ;)) we had a good view of the metropolitan side of Tokyo in our room , don't know about the other sides of the hotel ,

First of all it is a very big hotel. The key advantage is that the Airport Limousine bus comes directly to the front door from the Narita airport. The second main advantage is that main Tour company - Sunrise Tours starts the day tours from this hotel - so easy hotel pick up. Third is that it is very near the Shinjuku station which is a short walk away or a taxi ride away if carrying luggage.It is opposite the Tokyo municipal building which offers free viewing platform at the top of the tower. It is very impressive and would recommend it.Several restaurants - but always a queue in the morning when all the day tours starts around 8 am. This leaves a very small window for the guests to have breakfast and every one rushes in for breakfast around the same time. Should consider extending the opening hours to the morning so that there is a bit more flexibility.Food is good and the room was spacious - stayed for 4 nightsWould recommend

Stayed here a total of 7 nights recently, split into one stay of 2-nights and the other for 5-nights while on holiday recently. In between we were outside of Tokyo. All 7-nights were in a Plaza Superior Twin Room (Main Tower)Pros:(1) Rooms were cleanNo complaints here, room were kept clean throughout the duration of both stays.
