This being Japan, cleanliness is hardly a doubt(2) Convenient LocationIt is slightly less than a 10-minutes walk from the hotel to the Central West Entrance of Shinjuku Station. Needless to say, Shinjuku station is a main transport hub in Tokyo. And that also brings you to the endless food and shopping options of the Shinjuku Area. There is also a Lawson Convenience store about a block away from the hotel, if you exit from the South Tower entrance.(3) Excellent Service from StaffNo one in particular to mention, but the staff we interacted with were all very professional and helpful. First off, we emailed the Bell Captain team to make some restaurant reservations before we arrived. That was done promptly. The check-in on both instances was prompt and the bell-boys were also there promptly to send all the luggage up to the room. Very pleasant interactions with all the staff (4) Disney Partner HotelIt is a Disney Partner Hotel, and one of the biggest advantages of that is the shuttle bus it runs to and from the Disney Resort. Horribly convenient, even more so if travelling with kids, no need to squeeze in the subway and it brings you right to the doorsteps. However bookings have to be made via the hotel website to use this service and seats are limited. Though the 2nd time we used the service during our stay, there was a bit of a hiccup, but the service recovery was excellent and more in the section below(5) Stop on Airport Limousine Bus RouteThe hotel is amongst the hotels the Airport Limousine Bus stops at. Transport in Tokyo is horribly convenient, but the Airport Limousine Bus is an added convenience, brings you straight from Haneda / Narita Airport to your hotel door steps. A bit more pricey than the train, but worth the convenience. Saves you the hassle of pulling luggage through a crowded train station. Cons:(1) Non-Japanese TV ChannelsA problem that blights many Japanese hotel, the choice of non-Japanese channels, were essentially CNN,BBC, CCTV, another Chinese Channel, a movie channel and think was FOX Asia (for dramas), could really improve of the offerings(2) Internet Log-in ProcessA rather cumbersome process. You had to first key in a password to login to the Wifi then open your browser to key in a username and password. It is a two factorial system, a bit cumbersome. But guess is a good security featureSpecial Mention:We went to both Disney Sea and Disney Land. Both time we took the free Disney Shuttle. On the 2nd trip was to Disney Land on 20/01, there was a slight slip-up, the staff at the Bell Captain Desk forgot to load the luggage of some guest. The bus had to turn back and get those bags. A bell-boy did come on to the bus and apologize and explain the situation. Noticed at that moment several guests were taking video of the apology with their smart phones. Did not think anything of it. In all we were half an hour late arriving cause of the detour. That night upon getting off the Shuttle bus, was greeted by the Bell Captain Desk Duty Manager and apologized for the delay and in the room there was a note and box of chocolate from the hotel to apologize for the slip-up. Photo attached of note and choocolates. The Duty Manager explained they had gotten complaints on the delay from some guests.Was a good recovery response to a slip-up. Kudos to the hotel. Though personally wife and I felt was a small hiccup compared to other delays experienced else where and those times the apology and response was not even half as decent.Conclusion:Definitely will come back and stay here !!!! And I do recommend it to friends and relatives coming to Tokyo

Stayed in Keio Hotel for more than 5 times in the past few years, for vacation. The hotel is an established, huge and prestigious hotel in the area. It is connected by a underground walk way to the Shinjuku train station, so even it is rain or in winter, you could walk comfortably and directly to the station. The airport limousine stops at the Keio too, it makes it easy even if you have heavy luggage.Opposite to the hotel is West Shinjuku, where there are many small restaurants in the alleys, you can easily find all kind of Japanese cuisines there, breakfast beef rice, noodles, hot pots, grilled, sushi etc., apart from food, there are shops just and department stores just opposite to the hotel, Keio department store, BIC and even Mapcamera also has a branch there. It is just convenient.The service of the hotel is superb and of good Japanese tradition of hospitality, they have a good training to the staff who are very helpful and polite to the guests. This is pretty consistent, as I receive the same good services every time I stay there.This is not a brand new hotel, it is an old hotel. However, it is well managed and maintained, if I travel to Tokyo, I stay in this hotel unless it is fully booked. Once you come in, you know that things are taken care and you could just relax and focus on other activities in Japan!

Such a big hotel. The front desk people are efficient to the point of abrupt and not helpful. The floor manager in the foyer was less than helpful, and almost rude, and as we stood in the foyer with our luggage, he sent us on an excursion to find non existant seating in the foyer. It's a huge hotel, with many guests moving through, a massive foyer, and hardly anywhere to sit, talk, meet or plan.Room was good, but our room was quite noisy until about midnight, in south tower near lifts.The highlight: the lady who brought us room service was delightful. Thank you to her.Good location.

This is a good comfortable hotel in an excellent location that is convenient to many parts of Tokyo. We stayed 5 nights. It is very close to Shinjuku subway which makes it an easy place to get to many great parts of Tokyo. Overall a good hotel experience for us. However some quibbles: I was not impressed with the internet connection which was not straightforward and which caused all 3 of my devices an issue with 'server not trusted' type messages. Also the internet passwords (a double layer of passwords) had to be re-entered every day. Good, easy and secure internet connections are a must for travellers these days . Staff were always available to help, but the help was not always accurate or useful. For example, at the end of our stay, we asked the concierge for help to catch the subway to Haneda airport, surely not an unusual request (especially as the hotel's bus to the airport was completely booked out all morning). The instructions we were given were incorrect in that they suggested a long and complex route when a much easier one was available. These sort of things make a difference to a foreign traveller's experience.

If you are in Tokyo for short trip and intend to take the train or subway around the city, this is a good location that is very convenient. Stayed there in my last holiday in November 2016 and enjoyed my stay there with my family. Very comfortable bed and the room is spacious and very clean. Nearby many shops and F&B joints which is very convenient.Will stay in this hotel again when I am back for a short trip.

Stayed here for a week. I'd been abit apprehensive having read the mixed reviews but I needn't have worried. The hotel is well located and clean and comfortableWe had a room on the 28th floor and it was quite spacious - the bed was comfy and I slept well! The gym was much better than I had expected.The shop on the Lower ground was great and I used it everyday. I did think the restaurants were pricey but Tokyo is an expensive city. Make sure you go to the cafe/ bar restaurant on the 45(?) floor the views are amazing I hope to go backThank you To all the staff

The main rule of staying is Tokyo is to be near a train line that gets you around the vast city. This is a hotel that meets those needs as has an underground walkway to the main JR line.The hotel is a good 4 to 5 star hotel with clean rooms and good amenities. The breakfast options are good as well with a Western, Japanese and Mixed choices.For dinner there is a few restaurants in-house but would recommend walking a few minutes to find good quality local food

We stayed here for two nights recently. The rooms are quite small however given we were out all day, they were fine. The room was very clean when we arrived. The bed was far too hard for me, however everyone is different. The bathroom is getting a little tired but was fine. Housekeeping was very good and even folded the kids PJs which was a nice touch. The hotel is enormous and we were in the South wing. Check in was ok however not much information about the hotel was provided (in fact no information about the restaurants was given at all). We had room service one night which was excellent - probably some of the tastiest room service I have ever had. Only downside was the trolley will still outside our room the next morning which was a shame to see. The shuttle bus service to Disneyland and DisneySea is a great service - but book early to avoid disappointment. I would stay here again if returning to Tokyo.

We were told that the hotel had a great location, but we didn't realize how centrally located it was until we got there. The Shinjuku train station - the busiest in Japan, is maybe 10minute or less away. Various eateries - all wonderful and interesting - are within 5 to 10 minutes away in the Kabukicho area. There are 2 big gardens near the hotel - within 5 minutes to a central park of sorts behind the Municipal building, and about 15 minutes to the Imperial garden. The shopping is also great, with perhaps my best shopping experience being at Isetann (15 minutes away). Nearer are Takashimaya, Lumine, Odakia, and Keio department stores. As to the hotel itself, it is old but well maintained. It has all the basic amenities, although a bit small as most hotel rooms in Tokyo are small.

We stayed in a basic, non-smoking room with a king bed. The room was fine. The bed, although a little hard, was comfortable. The place is huge with many restaurants. Although we enjoyed the Teppanyaki restaurant (very yummy) we tended to venture out to eat for two reasons: 1. It’s good to explore a new city and 2. The restaurants in the hotel were very expensive. One morning we tried breakfast (not included in our booking) and had a latte which amounted to $13 AUD. Be warned.The location is about a 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku Station and although not terribly close to all the action, well-placed with plenty of cheap restaurants and shops in a small shopping hub (??) two minutes away. We found it to be a good place to get the station for our adventures in other parts of Tokyo. A long, underground tunnel takes you to the train station so you barely need to even step outside.The huge downside for us was the internet. As foreigners, you rely quite heavily on hotel wifi to plan your daily adventure. and the wifi at Keio Plaza was the worst we’d come across in almost 20 years of travel. I would assume some rooms would have good internet, but despite complaining about this numerous times to the staff, the problem was never resolved and we weren’t offered a different room. Oftentimes we would go 24-48 hours without any internet at all. We found this to be very difficult for us so if you choose this hotel, perhaps buy a phone plan that has a good amount of wifi, or hire a portable wifi device.

Located about 10 minutes walk from the Shinjuku JR Central West exit this is a very comfortable hotel with a pastry shop, convenience store and a selection of restaurants on the second floor. The roof top pool is open in summer

We have just checked in and we are so disappointed. I had read all the reviews and were expecting a five star hotel. Maybe from the 1980s. The bathroom is pink. The beds are hard and bedding looks tired. The carpet is stained and smells of smoke despite being on a non smoking floor. It's a great location and staff have been great, but compared to other places I've stayed in Japan, it's overpriced for the quality. We are really disappointed for our final hotel in Japan it's so tired and depressing looking.

Nice Hotel and good services. and they provide shuttle bus to disneyland and disney seaRoom is quite big. enough for Two adults and two young children.There is a connecting way to Shinjuku Train Station just outside the back of the hotel.

We booked 3 "superior" rooms here for 3 nights for our adult family. The hotel is in a great area, Shinjuku has many good restaurants, shops & tourist sites. The hotel is a short walk to Shinjuku station (from the rear exit) which is very convenient too. Lots of great local restaurant meant we didn't actually eat at the hotel. The rooms were decent size and very clean, bathrooms in good condition too. They placed us all on the same floor within 2 doors of each other in the south wing. adjustable air con in room. Kettle & tea but no food. Travel time by bus from Haneda airport 1 hour, from Narita 1.5 -2 hours, approx cost pp 1500 yen. A bit inconvenient to do by train as both require a change of station so bus is best option unless you are travelling light. Top floor bar with excellent view worth a visit, small but interesting menu.

Stayed here for for couple of nights and will love to comeback someday! Nice location near lots of stores and eatery, very close to train station. Room is spacious and clean, excellent amenities. Great breakfast selection and lots of options. Very recommended!!

For a first timer to Tokyo (Japan for that matter!) this hotel was beautiful, central to the trains, food, nightlife, shopping etc... would defiantly stay here again! Our room was clean and spacious with a view of the city and on a clear day Mt Fuji!

Travelled to Tokyo for the first time with my family last april 2016 and stayed at keio plaza. The hotel is very strategically located as there were a lot of restaurants just outside the hotel. Hooters is just around the block. The rooms are very clean and quite large. We were 5 in our family and easily fit in the room. Our view from our room even showed mount fuji from afar. I would recommend this hotel because of its location and cleaneliness.

We stayed here a few years ago and it is a very big hotel. We booked a tour this year and the meeting place was on the second floor of the hotel. It was a bit difficult to find but the hotel staff directed us to the proper area.Be sure to explore the walkway connecting the hotel to the Shinjuku Station. It is a life saver during the winter!

Location is quite convenient as it is near eateries and the train station. Room is spacious even with 3 beds placed in the room. Service from the front desk is average, however, the staff from housekeeping were friendly and warm.

I stayed with my family (wife, 8yo and 4yo) over XMAS 2016 for 4 nights. As you would have read, the location of this hotel is excellent. Once you have your bearings it is a quick walk to Shinjuku station and many different restaurant and bar areas. Its excellent for that. The rooms are sizable and are well maintained. Yes, as per other reviews, they may be slightly dated in some areas, and the bathroom styling is probably not going to cut it on the latest season of "the Block", but if you want clean and sanitary, you aint gonna get any better.Bar fridge content is frugal - so if you want to tie one on in the room, go down to the 7 eleven style convenience store on the very bottom floor near the restaurants and pick up booze at really good prices - like $3 a beer. TV is in Japanese nearly exclusively, but there is a button on the remote that you can press that changes many of the dubbed channels back to English. The name of the button is in Japanese, so a little trial and error is needed here (you also have to push it twice - handy hint!!) Whats important to note is that this really is a Japanese focused, not western focused hotel. A mate of mine booked a little earlier than I did and he got a Japanese style room - that means tatami floors and roll out futons. If that isn't your scene, make sure you let the team there know that you need a western style room. This will ensure you have a comfortable night. (mind you if you have a crook back, the futon can be amazing) Finally, the check in - check out routine is nearly totally inflexible (and frustrating). I arrived in Tokyo at 6am with two tired kids and turned up to hotel and tried to get an earlier check in than 2pm. After an hour of negotiations, I managed to get 130pm. However, EVERYONE in at 2pm, so when i got there at 115pm there was already a line of 50-60 people, so we actually checked in about 230pm.The staff were extremely polite and indeed delightful though, so the frustrations eased a little.Overall, I would recommend this place quite highly. Just remember that they have rules that dont get broken, so you have to deal with a little inflexibility. Other than that, enjoy the location and enjoy the great city of Tokyo

When I walked into Keio Plaza, it instantly felt the hotel 'was a bit big for its boots.'The line to check in was lengthy and the process to check in was long. They insisted in escorting all visitors to their room which is not necessary. However eventually I got to my room. As it was the New Years, it is a major holiday and people were very busy and there was a lot of people at the hotel. The hotel also charges a premium around this time. When I entered the room, it has been refitted probably several years ago, but still hold certain things that suggest its heritage from the 70s or 80s. In some ways, it felt the room was updated but not upgraded, leaving some finishings rather rough. However overall, it was pleasant. Service wise is generally OK but not exceptional. This may be due to the busy time of the year. They also have strange frequent flyer/miles rules that means you may not get your points. The difference that this hotel feels to other 4 or 5 star hotels is that while the room is OK, it's comparing it as a chain supermarket to a boutique store. It just feels it wants to churn as many people through as possible. I am making judgement based on comparison with other 4 and 5 star hotels I have stayed in and the price I was charged for my stay. I am happy to pay premium prices for what I feel value but this time around I simply didn't feel I had it. It wasn't bad per se but it wasn't good either, hence the rating.

Fantastic hotel! Great customer service. Great location especially if going on a Mount Fuji tour as the tours depart from here. The subway station and train station are within walking distance. Plenty of eateries in the stations and a number of restaurants in the hotel. Would definitely stay here again.

Pros: Big spacious Rooms. (Of course with a high price )Location. Cons: Very busy hotel. Doesn't feel like 5 stars. Service very mechanical Cannot make ANY request. The way it is, is the way it's going to be. Very abrupt and almost rude staff. Very unhelpful staff.

Stayed for three nights with two teens. Easy to find from Shinjuku station (there are signs in English), we walked there with the assistance of "moving walks" to make it easier with bags (although they were closed on way back).We were checked in a little earlier than expected and were provided with a free upgrade to a slightly larger room free of charge.The "triple" room had three good size single beds (something I had been worried about as booking the room didn't really indicate this) the beds are standardly firm and the pillows were kind of larger cushions. But after a day of walking/exploring they were pretty comfy.Room had all the usual features (temperature control, mini fridge & tv) and had USB charger plugs, so if you forget your conversion adapter it won't matter.The view was of some other buildings and some of the city outskirts.The bathroom was nice, shower over bath, clothes line, amenities including toothbrushes & hairbrushes, and the "electric" toilet/bidet.Outside the bathroom was a "make up/powder" area that had a sink, which was our favourite part of the room (two teens).The staff were fantastic, the majority of those we spoke to could speak English well enough to not have any problems. They have a shuttle bus for Disneyland drop offs/pickups & a convenience store. Starbucks across the road. Only downside was with the elevators trying to checkout, took quite a while as they were always full and we ended up having to fit in separately, and I ended up going up to come back down. Definitely would go back!

The set up of the room is a Japanese house tea, peaceful, warm and tranquility, made me felt welcome and relaxed. Yano tea master explained in details and the meaning of every part of the items, position and movements. The quality of the tea was good, its powder not leaf. Yano was awesome. I recommend this place for the tea very convenient location, if, you plan to go to the Robot show and shopping is walking distance. Thank you to Yano made my trip closed with double thumb up.

The Keio Plaza was very close to shopping, entertainment and eating areas. A short walk to Shinjuku and the subway was a big plus. The triple room was plenty big enough and tastefully decorated. The decor modern and a view of Mount Fuji a real plus - see photo. The staff were very helpful.

I had been highly recommended to this hotel by a friend. I had understood that it had been extensively refurbished and therefore I was expecting a modern, updated room, especially because I had booked a Club Room. I stayed in a Club Room in the South Tower on the 29th floor. The room certainly was dated, with marks on the walls, old highly used furniture, thin towels and a dated bathroom. However, the rooms were quite large which was a good plus.Staying in a Club Room gave us lounge access on the top floor of the South Tower. The lounge is open from 10am-5.30pm for refreshments and then up until 9.30pm for the bar. However, I wouldn't particularly recommend paying extra for the lounge. The food and drink is nothing special and the lounge became very crowded at certain times of the day. In the gym, the equipment was quite dated. In the South tower, there was a mini-mart conveniently located in the basement which was even better than any Lawson's you could go to outside. It has a wide range of pre-prepared foods (Japanese, Chinese, Western etc.) which the attendant can even microwave for you. There is also a selection of restaurants in the hotel. The location of this hotel is superb. It is extremely convenient to walk to Shinjuku station, numerous restaurants, shops and department stores, and the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum Observatory behind the hotel. Overall, we were happy with our stay. The staff were polite and helpful and the location can't be beat.

We stayed at the Keio plaza hotel for one night on the way back out of Tokyo. Family of five we got a triple and twin room. Triple was good size with single beds. Twin had two singles in a pretty small room. Don't jump in bathroom if over 6 ft. restaurants on level 2 were varied. Super buffet was fantastic with huge choice and quality. Even fussy young kids went back multiple times. Located in what seemed to be electronics shopping district. Several stores up to 9 floors filled with gadgets. Amazing selection available. Only two stops away from harajuku on JR line. Great clothes shopping with some amazing people watching. Would stay again.

Very nice hotel. Good location- although train station within walking distance, hotel is on the other size of the busy Shinjuku city center. Room service was prompt, house keeping good. They have airport (both Narita and Haneda) shuttle service that stops right in front of hotel, very convenient. Also free shuttle service to Disney. But make sure you book the shuttle buses early as they get fully booked quick! The only negative comment is they didnt let us check- in early although room was available.. and rooms were quite pricey.Otherwise a pleasant stay..

Keio Plaza Hotel is a really nice hotel for tourists as it is very accessible in terms of stop-overs for the airport limousine bus, Tokyo Disneyland/ Disney Sea, and Tour group pick-ups. The Shinjuku Station West Exit is just beside the hotel. Many small, quaint but good restaurants are also just 2 blocks away or a 5minute-walk. The rooms are bigger and the toilet has the modern japanese toilet seat which is really nice during cold weather because of the heated seat. There is only one bad thing that I can say and this is the bad smell emanating from the toilet everytime we enter our room at night after our tour even after it has been made up during the day. This happened only twice in our 4 night stay so I guess it has something to do with housekeeping or the person making up the room. Spraying the room & Toilet with a frest scent after cleaning would have been really nice.

Being 2 adults and 2 kids travelling around Japan, it can be tricky finding accomodation to fit the 4 of us. The Keio Plaza hotel ticked all the boxes. Basically our room was 2 normal sized rooms, with the wall between them removed. There were 2 bathrooms (albeit, both quite small) and a lounge and 2 lounge chairs. The beds are short, so the adult feet do tend to stick out!!!! The beds are also closer to the ground than a Westerner might expect. The hotel is in a good location. It is quiet for Tokyo standards and just minutes from lots of shops, department stores and restaurants. We would definitely consider staying here again

2 nights. We received a free upgrade when we checked in to a premium room. Location: Short walk from the station. Location to me is excellent as it is away from crazy crowds yet so easily accessible. There is a F&B area on the way to the train station that offers many dining options.Common Areas: Well maintained. It is a big hotel and the lobby area is big. Basement houses quite a few restaurants.Rooms: The same room as what we got last time we stayed here. It is spacious and comfortable. Wish the toilet was slightly bigger though.Service. Excellent service. Helpful and attentive staff members ready to go the extra mile to assist guests.Overall: Highly recommended. It is truly one of the best locations to stay when in shinjuku.

The hotel is big- which means a queue to check in. But it moved quickly. It's very convenient as the Airport Limousine stops at the hotel. It is also about 8 mins walk from the Shinjuku train station - west gate. The hotel is clean - nothing fancy, rooms are pretty big compared to others like Sunroute and JR Blossom which I've stayed in. But it's also pricier. What I like about this hotel is the amount of food places just a stone's throw away. My only gripe would be that it didn't have a coin-operated laundry room!

The hotel's location (stone's throw from the Toei subway; ~5-mins walk to the JR Shinjuku station, and close proximity to Haneda airport), clean and comfortable rooms, and the sumptuous Japanese buffet breakfast. We stayed on the 26th floor (main tower, non-smoking room), so had a good view, too! Staff from the airport bus company were particularly helpful (and flexible) in accommodating an extra child passenger, even though the seats were fully reserved. My main gripe would be the busloads of tour groups, although it's to be expected of large chain hotels. Long queues at breakfast time because of that. That said, would certainly stay in the same property if I were to return to Tokyo!

If you have no budget concern, Keio Plaza hotel would one of the best choice of your city trip. 5-8 mins walk to station, bus station and department stores. Always can find a good place to eat something: Ramen, BBQ and anything you want.

Stayed here for a holiday trip to Tokyo. Check inn line took FOREVER and I felt like a faceless number to the hotel. I am not sure if they can pack any more people in that place. The location is excellent, food choices are abundant and the tours the hotel facilitates are good. One thing I really hated was the inability to control climate in the room. If its a warm day in the winter you are stuck sweating in the room. You cant even turn on the fan for white noise. The room are large for Japan but a bit pricey. This place is a solid 3.

I like this place because of its spacious room that can accomodate 3 adult and 2 children in one room with reasonable and affordable price despite its old / simple interior design of the inside building and room but it is clean.... also the staff are quite helpful. At first i was not so sure of this hotel, but after seeing the room, i am happy. And not far from the hotel there are lots of food places that you can go. And most of all it is near the train station.

Newly refurbished premiere rooms had super comfortable beds, excellent use of space, top quality furnishingsAccess to the spanking new huge Club Floor on the 45th floor with all the amenities from breakfast to happy hour Service was excellent and efficient.

Expensive , had to pay more when we arrived and the staff on the front desk were surly and unfriendly. There was a mistake with our booking and the front desk were argumentative and when I asked for the manager was told I would get the same outcome and would have to wait at least 10 minutes so staff said I may as well give up . I didn't and was met with a slightly nicer manager who offered a compromise with the surly response that that was all he was willing to do . I would have been fine if they were not so rude . First contact with the hotel at the desk was not welcoming and the rooms were tired . Position was amazing and restaurant staff made up for the lack of manners of the front desk .

Keio was the perfect way to end our family holiday. A short distance from the Orchard Road of Tokyo, even missing our flight on what was supposed to be our first day could not bring our mood down. Our room didn't really have the best view but it was close to the lift, spacious and comfortable with four beds and just enough power outlets for everyone to have their phones charged. There are many food options nearby as there's a mall as well. A short distance away, there's a Halal-certified BBQ place. Definitely coming back soon, but please Tokyo, be slightly warmer.

This hotel is like a small city with its numerous restaurants and shops. It's also connected underground to subway stations and shopping centers. The rooms are large with great views. The staff was friendly and very helpful. No tipping is permitted.

Nice hotel in a great location for exploring. It's very big so check in can be busy. But efficient enough and reasonable English. Rooms are fine but can be pokey so get the biggest one you can afford. Some have been done up recently try and ask for them. Otherwise rooms are good standard, clean with comfy (if firm) beds. Bathrooms a little tight but fine. Breakfast was tasty but good sized queue at peak times. Close to train station and the shopping centre there has good stores and a great food mart in the basement with lots of take away type food. Overall a pleasant stay and would go back.

Beautiful hotel with very large rooms, also a good number of floors. Lots to see during nightly thunderstorms with plenty lightening. Very helpful+friendly staff, would definately go back. Plenty sights during day to visit, eg Mount Fuji, so would recommend coach trip. The guides a great help, can't help you enough. Would go back tomorrow!

Following a cruise from Vancouver to Alaska to Yokohama stayed here. Giant tourist hotel with two towers and usual very small rooms. Advantage is that many tours leave directly from this hotel as well as airport transportation. Lots of restaurants, but cheapest breakfast coffee was $7.50/cup. Near Shinjuku Station.

Nice hotel situation at the west side of shinjuku station. With underground link to the station about 10 mins away. Hotel has several categories and I had made my booking via expedia, but expedia booked me in the unrenovated superior room. I had to pay extra at the front desk to upgrade to a deluxe renovated in the main building which was totally worth it. Don't be fool by the pictures on the website, these are unrenovated rooms. Please check properly the type of rooms you are paying cos usually it's the cheaper unrenovated low floors. The deluxe renovated room on the high floor was totally worth it. It's very very big with a personal vainity corner beside the toilet. Plenty of space to walk around even with 4 big luggages open and a roll away bed. House keep is very well done. Everything will be perfect if the front desk service staff and the bell counter aren't so hostile and unfriendly. The working staffs are the friendly and helpful ones, however, the supervisors and managers are the one showing the attitude. It's a great business hotel minus the service. I won't be back for sure regardless of the room size.

We booked our king bed room at the premium South Tower with two breakfasts for one week stays there. Hotel has four different breakfast restaurants for us to choose and they are all very fine dinning. Room size is moderate considering Tokyo tiny size standard. This hotel located within 5-8 minutes walking distance to Shinjiku station. Hotel have airport limo bus at front and it is about 100 minutes to Narita airport if traffic is smooth.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza for the first time, for a week. Location is good, 10 minutes away from subway and JR station. Convenient.Lots of restaurants around, convenient stores, pharmacies, and large department stores. Hotel room superior twin, about 200 sq ft. Bedding was okay. Washroom old style and ventilation inside the washroom must be improved.Around Christmas time, so cannot avoid paying high prices. In normal non high season would probably be cheaper If you are looking for a more modern hotel, then Keio would not be your choice.

The hotel is very well located, a few minutes walk from the busy Shinjuku center and station. Restaurants are close by , within the hotel or in the small streets nearby. But this is a big hotel and the front desk staff are always busy and rather impersonal. Same for the main restaurant staff . We were travelling with children and were given 2 rooms at different ends of the corridor in spite of having requested for adjacent rooms in our booking and again via email prior to our arrival. The in room dining menu is also very limited after 11pm. Our flight was long and we were hungry after checking in at 11:30pm. The standard rooms are on the small side ( when used as a triple room, there's hardly any space left) , carpet Looks old and worn but all basic amenities are provided in the room. The wifi was also not reliable, most often we could not get connection to the hotel wifi. On the good side, the breakfast buffet is good and because of jet lag , some of us missed breakfast the first two days but fortunately we could use our vouchers for lunch as well . We also had a very enjoyable dinner in the Japanese teppanyaki restaurant on the 7th floor - expensive but very good. The concierge was very helpful as we asked for directions to various tourist sites.On the whole, we had an enjoyable stay - location wise , we could come in and go out easily with our children , for sight seeing during the day , a rest In the afternoon and out for a stroll or dinner in the evening.

We came for 4 nights, with a group to explore Tokyo This hotel is huge with many restaurants and food options. At the lobby level you can find an automatic machine to change money. Short distance to the main attractions

Stayed for business and was given a Luxe room at the South Tower. I requested for a room at the Main Tower and was told that it's full. The staff informed me that the South Tower is recently renovated but the room looks a little dated. Room size is huge by Tokyo standards and there's a huge variety of bathroom amenities provided, like the full sized hairbrush! My room faces the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building and Mount Fuji showed itself on the third day, which was a nice surprise! The hotel is next to the Tochomae Station exit and once you go down the stairs of the station, it takes about 5 minutes to reach the station gates. From the South Tower, go towards the reception on the lobby floor (which is level 3) and turn right to walk to Shinjuku. There are several convenience stores on the way to Shinjuku and the hotel also has an in-house convenience store located on Level 2. The one in the hotel opens till 2.30am so that is helpful for those who needs a late snack. Breakfast is available at the restaurants on Level 2 and Jurin is the only one which has breakfast until 11am. The international buffet at Jurin stops at 10.30am and from 10.30am to 11am, a breakfast set is served. Glass Court, opposite Jurin, always sports a long Q because it serves both Japanese and International fare. Glass Court has the onsen egg which Jurin does not but I feel that the difference is not that great. Food served at both restaurants are largely the same. For pokemon players, my room at the south tower does not sit on a pokestop and the main tower would have 2 pokestops available. However, I had farfetch'd appearing in my room one night!

The rooms are extremely worn. The room looks nothing like the photos and we asked to move and the new room was no better. We were told if we wanted to move again it would be to the unrenovated part of the hotel. I can't belive this is the renovated part. The carpets are dirty and you can see where they have tried to hand repair it. The bathroom is from the 1970s and when you flush the toilet you wait for 7 minutes for the horrendous piping sounds to calm down. Their is mould in the bathroom. The beds are spring based and uneven. The air conditioning doesn't work. This is the worst hotel I have stayed in and we have three more nights to go.

B/F : everyday crowded and needed to wait at least 15 minutes for a table. Same choices everyday.Room : We were given a high floor but only can have a 1/4 glimpse of mt Fuji as its been blocked by the tall building infront.Location is ideal. Being first time to Tokyo, we are actually quite pleased with our choice although the room rate is really expensive compare to hotels nearby.

Location is near the restaurants and shopping areas. There are many restaurants in the hotel . The check in & out queue are too long . The pillows are too soft. Tried calling the front desk, housekeeping & guest service desk for extra pillows and no one answered. The housekeeping should have eye for details, missing items after cleaning the room. The room was not done properly . Made reservation for coaches to Disney but reservation was not found ! We are very impressed with the bellman service , very attentive and briefed on emergency exit.

Stayed for two nights in early December 2016 for company event. It was my second stay in this hotel. I stayed in main tower building, a newly renovated part of the hotel, which is smaller than the room size I stayed two years ago, but a lot cleaner and modern. The hotel is very huge for Tokyo standard.I didn't experience the check-in process since I went with a large group and we had our tour leaders prepared all the required stuffs. Stayed in a twin-bed room, the room was average in size. I didn't have any problems with my room, everything was standard and pretty much okay. Had western breakfast, food quality was good, but the restaurant was very full in the morning, we had to wait in line to be assigned seats.The best thing of this hotel is absolutely the location. Easy access to Shinjuku station with several entrance points to the station. Shinjuku station is also very large, you can find a lot of food stalls, restaurants, shops and bakery alongside. Besides the station, the hotel is within walking distance to Shinjuku area, a lot of restaurants and shops nearby. I always ate at a Standing Sushi, small restaurant around 5 mins walk from the hotel.

Probably the worse check in experience. Had to pay more than stipulated when reserved through booking.com, no flexibility in checking out at 12pm (once collect payment, said check out at 11am), paid for room with breakfast and ended up without breakfast for my children... terrible terrible terrible Avoid this hotel if you expect service and the link with booking.com is so detached it's like dealing with a separate country, supposing to compliment each other.

I expected more of Keio based upon other reviews and room rates. If I return to Tokyo any time soon I will look elsewhere. Compared to other Tokyo hotels it is lacking Japanese hospitality and calmness. Facilities could use a solid cleaning and updating. Breakfast not great either.

Nice little hotel close to the station and so close to all the city sights, once we negotiated our way round the Tokyo subway, it was in a great location with tons of cheap eats and so culturally different loved Tokyo.

pros: central location, lots of restaurants inside the hotel, food is decent. free shuttle bus to disneyland.cons: service was lacking in many areas. front desk staff especially had alot of attitude.tips: beware of hidden tax charges if you book directly on their website. i would book through a third party site such as expedia instead. there were three separate tax charges tacked on to my final bill.

This is a conveniently located hotel in Shinjuku that I stayed at on two separate occasions over the course of a week (we started in Tokyo, went to Kyoto then back to Tokyo). If possible, I'd recommend trying to stay in the main tower as I think the rooms are nicer in the main tower as opposed to the South Tower. I loved the location, and the hotel staff were very friendly. I didn't try any of the on-site restaurants though.
user_name:
mdc5027
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is near shopping locations. From here it is just a short walk to the various train lines that can take you to all of Tokyo. Staff is very polite and there is also a shuttle service to the airport.

+ everybody is trying their best to accomodate the guests+ very strategic location nearby shinjuku area+ suitable for business hotel+ everything is very well maintained considering it is a very old and historical hotel+ very professional to give solution in every situation+ very nice breakfastminus sides:- very busy hotel even for check in or breakfast- the bed is quite stiff for me and the blanket is quite small and thin so it easily goes everywhere during the sleep- it may not suitable for kids, this hotel is more like business hotel

We booked directly and well in advance to take advantage of advance booking discount. We stayed in a Plaza Luxe queen for 4 nights which was comfortable and a reasonable size. This also gave us access to the Luxe Lounge, which was great to come back to in the evening after sightseeing and have a tea/coffee and cakes ( if early) or soft drink/beer or wine in the evening. We had no problems with crowds as we did not have to come/go at peak times. We ate breakfast at Jurin - no waiting ( we noted lines at one of the other breakfast restaurants) Location was good. Short walk to the station ( above ground or mostly underground) and near Government Building for free observatory ( day and night).Yes, it was a little expansive - so was everything else we looked at when trying to find a place. The lifts were a little odd ( call buttons on each side not linked) but again we could avoid the peak times.Only regret was perhaps not exploring the hotel a little more and trying some other other eating places within. Room service was super efficient - well it is Japan.

We stayed in Keio Plaza 30 years ago and this is our second time here. Everything on location and amenities are good as based on reviews by others and the usual Japanese culture. Hotel bell boy offers directions and even an umbrella when he saw us without one on a raining night.You can take limousine bus from both Narita airports with all your luggage directly to Keio Plaza, and vice versa.

I stayed 6 nights in the hotel on my recent business trip. I won't stay here next time. First the good stuff. The location is great. The service, although not personal, is amazingly good for a hotel this size. Everything else is mediocre at best. The rooms are dated. The breakfast buffet is average---unless you like canned fruit cocktail. The elevators in the South Tower have the craziest arrangement. There are two different call systems. Each across from the other. One elevator bank doesn't work at all. So each time you are in the lobby you need to push buttons on both sides. That's not so inconvenient when you figure this out. But the real nonsense happens when during busy times. If you are get into the elevator in the morning, be prepared to stop at every floor. Most of them empty as the riders got picked up by the elevator on the other side. Also get used to lines at this hotel. Lines to check in. Lines to check out. Lines to talk to the concierge. Lines to get into the breakfast room. Finally my pet peeve. I am a gym guy. I try to get exercise every day when I am traveling. The gym at the Keio Plaza is the absolute worst gym I have seen in a hotel of this caliber. In fact, I have seen better gyms in budget hotels in rural America. I admit I am a little picky about this subject, but a hotel with thousands of rooms needs to do better than 3 treadmills, 2 ellipticals and 1 stationary bike. Oh, there is also a pad to to push ups, and two exercise machines that make no sense whatsoever in terms of why they are there. The whole thing is a joke. So, unless you get an incredible deal and don't care a wit about working out I would avoid this place. I recommend the Hilton nearby.

Location of the hotel was ideal for being my first time in Tokyo. I will most likely stay here again given the ideal location. Located not more than 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku station, the station has boasted being the busiest subway/train station in the Tokyo area (even busier than Tokyo station) can take you anywhere in Tokyo. Buying a day pass for the subway allows you unlimited rides to anywhere in the city for just 1000 yen ($10 USD).Rooms were quite larger than I expected and well appointed. Free bottle water per day, heated toilet seats, in room safe etc. Toiletries were very well stocked including toothbrush etc.For dining and food, the hotel itself have about 11 different restaurants. They western style cuisine to traditional Japanese food, to Teppanyaki, Sushi or even tempura. I personally ate at two of the restaurants.. Yamani - Teppanyaki restaurant was phenomenal ! .. and western breakfast at Jurin. A bit pricey but very convenient and the service was nothing less than excellent! If dining at the hotel isn't your thing, Near the Shinjuku station (a mere 10 min walk), there are literally hundreds of places to dine. You can even go up to a couple of large Malls near the station.. Keio Department store Mall or Odakyu Dept. Store and there are food courts (all kinds of different food you would want) to dine in. Sight seeing - If going on your own using the subway/train for site seeing isn't your thing and would like something more organized (with transportation and guide), the hotel is actually a pickup hub for one of the largest tour companies in Tokyo. The tour company (which as an office within the hotel itself) can offer your tours that pickup directly from the hotel ranging from half day tours, night tours, all-day Tokyo tours and even tours to Mt. Fuji all within the convenience of your hotel. The hotel also offers a shuttle bus to Disney if you like (check with the Bell Station for pickup and drop off times).The hotel is pricey in a US perspective but then again, Tokyo is pricey it itself. For being the first time in Tokyo, I think my wife and I choice wisely with Keio Plaza. Definitely will stay here again.Site Seeing Tip:Best View of the City for free? Instead of going to Tokyo Tower where you are charged to go up to the top, try going to the Tokyo Government building across the street from the hotel. It's FREE and the view is better than the Tokyo Tower.

The hotel is located on the western side of Shinjuki, so more on the business side of the area. The hotel is quite large with two towers. Because there are so many floors and rooms and one of the elevators was under maintenance, that meant for long wait times for elevators. Unfortunately, the hotel is dated, the rooms are the typical small Japanese size rooms, the beds are quite firm (if you like a very firm bed), the ceilings are low (particularly standing in the shower/bathtub), the linens and towels are thin and rough, but the shower/bathtub's water pressure was surprisingly strong. It is, however, conveniently located near the Shinjuki train station. There are several hotel restaurants to choose from, we only dined at the Glass Court Japanese and western breakfast buffet where the selection was large and food quality was good. We'll probably try another hotel the next time we're in Tokyo for those rates at the Keio Plaza.

Close to Shinjinku station (5 min walk). This hotel is huge but they sure have got it right. I find it hard to fault. It has everything you need. Great for business or pleasure. Big rooms with great views of Tokyo.

Recommendable. Advantages: great location, close to metro station, only 30-35 min from the airport by taxi, high standard - clean, spacious rooms, many restaurants with various offers (including Japanese one), two bars (be careful - smoking allowed!!), shop etc. Friendly and swift staff. I will definitely choose it again.

excellent location, walked to wonderful inexpensive restaurants. Easy walk to trains.Rooms clean, comfortable, maid refreshed bottled water and all bathroom products so plenty all of the time. We had a superb view if mt fuji from our room. Would definately recommend staying here.

Recently in Shinjuku (arrived on the 24th Nov 2016 and it decides to snow after leaving home with a previous temp of 34C). Checked in my luggage as we got there at 8.00am, staff were great and spoke excellent english. Stayed for 4 nights. Staff as with all japanese people very friendly and had great communication skills. Great selection of restaurants on B1 and a well priced souvenir shop as well. Rooms are clean and well maintained, just need to search the TV for some programs in English. Very central to to the main train station with a 8 minute walk but quicker if you navigate the underground walkways which are amazing with great places to eat and a variety of small shops.Can highly recommend staying here and will be back,

This hotel is close to shopping and has restaurants on the lower floor. Access to shinjuku station is a brisk 5 minute walk via a tunnel if you don't want to be exposed to the weather. It is 2 stops away from the busy Tokyo station and easy access to the shopping district. The hotel has large rooms available for families. The rooms are modern and have all the necessities. It's modern but not plush or luxurious. Buffet breakfast is available at 2 separate restaurant and there is a wide selection of western and Japanese cuisine. Communication in English remained a challenge from reception check in to all other services at the hotel. Taxis were frequent if you were not using the train. However tourist rail passes are the cheapest means of travel and easy if not travelling with young children.

Rooms are smoke free. Clean. Staff are efficient but aseptic at times. When breakfast is going to be heavily booked, we got a note in our room which was a nice touch to help spread the crowd out. No coffee in the room and the fridge was sparse - a little disappointed for the price paid. Overall good but can be much better, really.

I spend 6 days in this hotel and definitly would not come back. The room is ok and clean, the bathroom is really old (plastic curtains in the shower) and the customer threatment is not good at all. They have denied my late check out (i explained that my wife is pregnant and my flight is very late night) and the concierge is horrible! The hotel puts a german lady with a poor japanese to make reservations, when we arrived at the attraction our reservation was not there we we couldn't go in. Anyway, i am glad to leave this hotel today

Convenient, well run hotel in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo. The rooms are comfortable and the hotel service is good. Since it is next to the Skinjuku rail station and several metro lines, it's very easy get around Tokyo using this hotel as a base. The breakfast buffet is excellent. If I were to visit Tokyo again, I would stay at this hotel.

Very conveniently located,only a few minutes walk to the Shinjuku station. Wi-Fi service reliable ,room is of reasonable size, and housekeeping is well done. Buffet breakfast nice variety & good quality. Overall a very pleasant experience & will certainly come again.

Location: Convenient - is around a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku station. And another 10 mins to the Golden Gai area. Yet is still in quieter part of Shinjuku so one can relax once away from all the bars/restaurants/shops just minutes away.Room: Was in the south tower. Room was spacious with all the necessities. Clean and well kept.Food: plenty of restaurants within the hotel. Though only had the breakfast buffet - the usual mix of western and local. They did have 4 restaurants where one could use the breakfast coupon so helps getting bored of the ambience if you are there for a few days.Staff: polite and helpful all through. Though don't expect a personal touch.Gym: a basic gym. Did have a quite a few machines for cardio, however not much of an option if you looking to do any weights (guess 10k was the max dumbbell they had, and just a chest press and leg extension machine)

Big hotel with service minded staff. Easy to find from Shinjuku station, sparkling clean rooms with comfy beds. No smoke odour but I think I stayed in the refurbished tower.Make sure to book a seat in the airport transfer when you arrive, otherwise it might be fully booked, we forgot this and had to take the Narita Express instead.

I just arrived this morning. I talked to the lady at the check and told her that I had zero sleep on the flight and am happy to pay for an extra nights stay to have my room early. Despite rooms being available the lady took pleasure in denying my request.Behind the check in the key boxes have red lights if occupied and green lights if vacatant. At least 100 were vacant!!I waited in the reception for 3hrs, watching over 50+ guests check out. Not once did the lady offer a room. After talking to three receptionists and almost losing my cool I finally got a room. I asked the original lady why she did not offer this to me when I arrived. She ignored me and talked to the other staff instead, which is just plain rude.A seriously bad first impression.The staff here do not care about their guests.

Spend 5 nights in the hotel with two kids. We had a Big, clean room with two bathrooms and a magnificant view from 33 floor! Very friendly service in reception. Only reason why I give 4 and not 5 Stars is the fact that breakfast was not included in the Price of the room and it was very expensive.

Clean room, good location, older facilityA highlight of the stay was sushi at Kyubey -- a branch from the Ginza restaurantAmazing food and great experience.There are three breakfast options but The Glass Court was vastly superior to the so-called American buffet (Jurin) which didn't have a machine for espresso-based drinks.

Good sized rooms great service and wonderful restaurants. Also great location with underground tunnel connecting you to Shinjuku station. Would definitely be happy to go back. Wouldn't bother with club lounge though doesn't offer much at all!

Stayed at Keio Plaza from 3 November till 13 November - 10 nights. The stay was overall pleasant. Housekeeping was excellent. The decor seemed a bit dated so did the colour scheme in the plaza luxe room. The other downside was we could hear the thumping of foot steps from the room above at night which was quite annoying as we were trying to wind down. The size of the room was generous, easy enough for two people to walk around however the bathroom was quite small and difficult to maneuver around. We did enjoy the luxe lounge during our stay and the staff there were really friendly. The hotel location is very convenient to the JR lines and subways including shinjuku station (which is the busiest transportation hub in the world). The hotel restaurants were on the pricey side, so we decided to venture out for lunch and dinner which was much more affordable. The convenience store located in the hotel was extremely helpful. Location overall was good, easy to walk to restaurants and shopping spots. Will definitely stay here again.

Child friendly hotel. Very convenient for shopping and free access to Disneyland! Buffet breakfast is good because of several resto choices. Tip: we stayed at the south wing which is newly renovated. Will definitely consider staying again when in Tokyo :)

We were really looking forward to our stay here but left feeling rather disappointed by our experience. Upon check-in, there was a very long queue which took 20min to eventually get to the front. I had booked a non-smoking room however when we got to our room, it stank of cigarettes. I asked the bell service staff to move us to a non-smoking room as we don't smoke. She kindly offered to help us and rang reception 3 times from our room to request the change but no answer! So we were asked to wait in the room while she went downstairs to speak to reception. We started getting rather annoyed at this point as the room smelt so bad and after waiting almost 30min we eventually got a call to the room and asked to come back to reception as they had found another room for us. By this point we had headaches from the horrible smelling room! When we reached reception, I explained our situation to one of the staff and he asked us to join the back of the queue again which would have taken another 20min! Unbelievable, we were almost ready to cancel everything. He asked us twice to join the queue and only when I told him this was terrible service as we had already spent almost an hour trying to check in, he went to get his manager. The manager explained that there was no non-smoking room for us available right now and we would have to wait. However, because they had made us wait for so long already, we were running late for our dinner plans and there wasn't anywhere for me to get changed. When I explained this to them, they magically found a room and kindly upgraded us to a larger room. We were thankful and appreciative but there was no apology for making us wait for so long and we felt like the manager was cold and not sincere. Felt like everything was a battle just to check in! The staff need to communicate better between themselves to deliver more attentive service you would expect from a 5 star hotel. I have stayed in cheaper hotels which have much better service!

We stayed there for 3 nights, a group of 30 executives of an international group.This is an unpersonal hotel, no atmosphere or soul.You want to have a breakfast? Wait and queue for 15mn for an average western breafast.Rooms are small,old but clean.Restaurants are average and over priced.Staff is not able to speak a minimum of english.Service is far away for Japanese standard.An example : a group of 7 of us wantdd to have a last drink at the bar called Brilliant.We waited several minutes untill beying saod that the bar was full.. while we were able to see that it was half empty. We went to see the duty manager to make some complaint . Not able to speak an average english. It took him 10 mn to bring us a paper to write a complaint.. idiot , we are at the digital era... Spent 10 mn on the phone to say us , with difficulties, that it was impossible to have a drink coz ghe bar was full... did not propose any alternative solution.... where was ghe legendary customer service in Japan? Certainly not in Keio Plaza... save your money... better to choose a simple, low cost business hotel, you will finally get the same level of service

Keio plaza is a decent Japanese hotel that offers all the basics including a good sized room and a decent breakfast. Staff are courteous but not overly friendly. There's wifi. Not sure about a gym (bono time to even look for one...). Short walk from the Shinjuku station and lots of restaurants nearby.

We had some trepidation over our first visit to Tokyo because of its size and well-publicized expense.The Keio Plaza Hotel proved to be an excellent experience. Other reviewers have mentioned these factors, but they really made for a comfortable and hassle-free stay in Tokyo.1) The Narita airport bus stops right at the hotel - no walks with luggage, or additional taxi rides needed.2) Tour bus companies (Gray Line and Sunrise) pickup right at the hotel. 3) The hotel has an entire level of restaurants: two Japanese, one French-Italian, one Chinese, and one, more casual, Continental. We ate at the medium-priced Japanese and the French-Italian restaurant. We thought the food was excellent and the service, gracious. Hotel guests received a discount. The prices were equivalent to a mid-level restaurant in our own large American city. We thought they were a good value. There are more casual eateries (plus Starbucks and McDonald's) on the streets between the hotel and the Shinjuku rail station, but after days of touring we wanted relaxed sit-down dinners.4) There is a convenience store on the restaurant level which has inexpensive take-out food -sandwiches, sushi/sashimi, yogurt, beverages, and snacks.5) Shinjuku rail station is a ten minute walk away - there is a covered passageway at ground level on the north side of the hotel (which also serves commuters to the office towers in the area). The Tochomae subway station is even closer - one block from the hotel. This line gave us direct service to the Edo-Tokyo museum and one-transfer service to Ueno Park and the Tokyo Station area.6) Kabukicho, the neon-lit, nightlife and red-light district at the northeast end of Shinjuku station is a fifteen minute walk. We were interested in seeing it, but also glad to get back to the more corporate environs of the Keio Plaza. The Tokyo Government Center (with its free observatory) is a two block walk in the opposite direction. Finally, the rooms and service exceeded our expectations. The rooms were equivalent to, or larger than, standard contemporary, city hotel rooms in the US (see picture). Check-in and check-out were very fast - also unexpected in a large and busy hotel. Lobby staff spoke excellent English, with a level of politeness which we already miss here at home.
user_name:
IDLnyc
New York City, New York

review_body: Summary of my stay:Friendly staff Room was cleanGreat location (near to restaurants, shops, bus station and train station)There are money exchange machines and mini market (mini market open till late) Beds was not badPillows were little bit hard (not too comfortable) Room size was little bit below average, but is was OKOverall, I recommend to stay in this hotel.

What a joy to stay in this hotel, from the moment I step into this hotel, I got treated comfortably and feels like home. This trip purpose was watching motogp in Motegi which is 1.5hr shinkansen from Tokyo. We are delighted that we got upgraded to siperior non-smoking room in the south tower which is my first time to stay in south tower, I just got multiple stay experience in the main tower. The room was clean and tidy, it is obvious that it has been renovated recently as all furniture are really new and trendy! As usual, I will enjoy my breakfast in the nice restaurant which is located on the B1/F, since thsre are varoius choices, mainly Japanese and western style for buffet settings.Definitely will come back as excellent service and great location in the west side of Shinjuku, recommend to you all!

Hotel is located 5 mins walk away from buzzing Shinjuku station west exit, Shinjuku Express Bus Terminal, shopping, entertainment and same direction from hotel 3 mins walk for food, opposite of hotel is Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building where you can go up to level 75 observation deck for free to view Tokyo day or night view.2nd level there is convenience store and restaurants, big lobby and also provide complimentary shuttle bus for hotel guest to Disneyland and DisneySea*advanced reservation required as 1st come 1st serve. Good to reserve the complimentary shuttle bus service when hotel booking is confirm.Keio Plaza Hotel is also one of the stop for airport limousine bus, book prefer time slot for return at the small office located beside bell boy counter at least one day before departure but subject to available and the demand, good to block early if they allow, if the airport limousine bus office closed for the day, blocking of the time slot can be done with the bell boy counter. If your flight is in the late afternoon as room check-out time is 11am, leave your luggages with the bell boy counter, inform them that you are taking airport limousine bus and they will give you number tag to each luggage, the luggages will line up outside when the time is near and we will only need to go out, point our luggages for them to load into the bus. Is so convenient.Room is very comfortable, clean and look newly renovated. Stayed at 33 level, nice night view with large window.Pleasant stay.

We stayed in 2 superior rooms in the South Tower in November 2016.Bell service was friendly and welcoming, check-in was smooth. Rooms are very spacious, compared to the average in Tokyo. Beds were super comfy and large. Noticed security guards patrolling the floors late at night which made us feel safe.Breakfast at the Glass Court Restaurant was amazing, food was delicious and with variety. *The croissants are amazing, Location was superb, one of the exits ( the one outside the glass court restaurant ) connects with a covered walkway leading to Shinjuku Station, which makes everything convenient. On top of that, it's a rather peaceful around, with the majestic Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building standing in front of the hotel. We got lucky because our room had a great view, with Mt. Fuji in the background. Price is a little high, but you get 5-star comfort and service.Will return here when in Tokyo.

We stayed here prior to our Asian cruise. This was our first stay in Tokyo and it was intimidating, but easier to navigate than we expected. The airport is not close to the city and after looking at our options, decided to take the train to the Shinjuku station. It was fast and a short walk to the hotel. That being said, we found out at check in that the hotel has a bus that will pick you up at the airport. Didn't think to contact the hotel about that option.The hotel is very nice and employees were all helpful and very friendly. We ate at several of the restaurants in the hotel and really enjoyed them. The concierge gave us a map and directions to tour the city. She also made reservations and gave us a discount coupon for dinner at the Robot Restaurant. All in all an amazing start to our cruise.

The longest queues to even check in. We got told we got an upgrade, however upon entering our room, we realise that our 'upgrade' was a smoking room, with two beds, instead of one. My partner is asthmatic, and has hay fever. Just from minutes being in the room, my throat was burning. It absolutely stunk, and the bathroom had the foulest odour. I called guest services, and told them to take back their upgrade, I want my other room. He told me that I could not get the other room until tomorrow, and even then, we would not get a double bed. I let them know about the medical conditions, and that I did not care about the bedding arrangement at this point, I needed a non smoking room. He blatantly refused, and told me to give my key to reception tomorrow if I still wanted the other room - this being the hotel manager. I asked to speak higher, and spoke to two people in guest reservations, who transferred us to another room, which was smoking but the smell wasn't as strong. On top of that, it is November, so the temperatures are cold here. We tried putting on the heater, and it wouldn't work. When we asked the hotel reception why, they explained that they have one system, and they choose when we can and can't use the heater or cooler, and right now it's only cooler season. The blankets aren't actually blankets, they're sheets. If I could give anyone anymore of a recommendation, it would be to not even consider this hotel. Disgusting.

When you check this hotel by Google map,Maybe you would feel anxious so far from Shinjuku station. BUT Don't worry about it! because This Hotel can access within the Shinjuku station yard out-of-rain!you had better try video search first maned as “Keio Plaza hotel From Accessway within the Shinjuku station yard.”Shinjuku Station is the biggest one in the world, linked any famous hotel and shop.One of them is this Keio Plaza hotel as easy access way.

This hotel is quite nice and all staff members were extremely helpful. Upon check-in, we were escorted to the room, and the bellhop pointed out heating, robes, slippers, and anything else that he deemed important. The room was comfortable and clean. We enjoyed the breakfast although it was somewhat expensive.

I have used the hotel for about 30 years and it is still my favorite hotel in Tokyo. The neighborhood has changed but the hotel still has the same good service and feeling. Over the years the rooms have been renovated so they keep good standard and have everything a business traveller needs.

Keio Plaza Hotel is near the west gate of the Shinjuku Station which is one of the busiest in the Japan if not in the world. there is a tunnel that connects Keio Plaza to the west gate, very convenient. The area is almost exclusively office buildings, therefore only busy during rush hours. The hotel has many dinning options although a little expensive. Walk a few minutes towards Shinjuku station and there are plenty of lower cost options.It is hard not to get good services in Japan. The rooms in Keio Plaza are pretty standard for western style hotels in Japan. Wifi is good and 1080P HD TV in the room.

We stayed a night at the Keio Plaza hotel the night before we flew back to the US. The hotel is in a relatively good location near the Shinjuku JR train station, with plenty of restaurants and bars nearby.

Very stylish and upmarket hotel. In the Government building area and well appointed. Plenty of staff and has a taxi rank for those who don't want to walk. They offer free shuttle bus to DisneyLand which is some way out of Tokyo. The room was very large and the furnishings great. Bathroom was excellent with plenty of quality toiletries. Cable TV and a settee and plenty of Tea & Coffee to enjoy in the room. Good quality bed and very comfy. Hotel is lovely and recommended by Trailfinders. Airport shuttle bus available at 3100 yen each. Takes about 1 hour 20 to the airport and lets you see plenty of the outlying area of Tokyo. Allow for 4 hours before departure to get from the hotel to the airport

This hotel is really comfortable, clean and close to everything you need, its about a 5 minute walk to Shinjuku Station with the JR Lines and Shinkansen. The local Subway is under the hotel aswell. Local restaurants are terrific and there are literally hundreds and there is a convenience store across the road. We arrived at Narita Airport and organised the Limousine Bus to take us to the hotel, which was around 2 hours to Shinjuku but they are clean and comfortable and right outside the airport so you don't have to worry about navigating the train system on the first day you arrive as its rather overwhelming when you first ride the trains in Tokyo especially with children. After a few times we were confident and could find our way around but you never get over the sheer volume of people rushing about at the stations, its simply mind blowing!

Pros - great location near shops and restaurants, subway stations, Shinjuku station; larger than average rooms for Tokyo; pick-up point for many tours and the airport limousine bus; friendly and enthusiastic staffCons - rooms the main tower a little tired-looking, some towels almost threadbare, totally unexpected for a 4-4.5 star hotel. The manager was not too helpful. When asked for directions to a pharmacy where my wife could fill in her insulin prescription, he scribbled a straight line on the map, not bothering to explain that the pharmacy was inside a building which had Japanese characters on it. The least he could have done was write down the address in Japanese and ask us to take a taxi. Of course we got lost! What saved the day for us was our awesome tour guide Kenji-san from Tours by Locals who braved the afternoon rains for us to look for that pharmacy.

This place is well worth a visit. Although food and drink is quite expensive here the rest of the hotel is fantastic. We arrived at about 23.00hrs and as you can imagine at that time we sailed through check in. I wold strongly advise travellers to ask for a Mt fuji view in the south tower. If you get lucky with the weather you won't regret this. The rooms are cleaned between 10 and 3 each day and ours was always done to a high standard. We found all the staff to be polite and helpful and had no language problems. The hotel is ideally situated for exploring shinjuku and the surrounding areas. I would without doubt stay at this hotel again if we revisit tokyo

The hotel is near the trains stations and around 15 to 20 mins walk to the shopping area as well as the bus station going to Gotemba☺,( if you plan to shop) There are lots of restaurants to choose from around the area and convenient stores. The room is quite big enough and they granted my request for our rooms to be beside each other. They have a post box in the hotel just case you wanted to drop the rented pocket wifi. The best of all is that the airport shuttle stops in front of the hotel. You can buy the bus tickets at the hotel as well.

This hotel offers variety of breakfast choices, quick service from friendly staff. I did not expect that the hotel rooms are big though bathroom is quite small at the Main Tower where we stayed. For a wonderful experience and fantastic place to stay in Shinjuku, go to this hotel.

Nice Hotel and good location. The room is consider as big in Japan. Many shops and restaurants around within walking distance. Free shuttle to Disney Land. Located at West Exit of Shinjuku Station. There is a Hello Kitty theme room available but not sure what is the rate though.

Stayed 5 nights at this amazing hotel. Booked the Plaza Luxe Corner King with complementary Luxe Lounge access on level 30 - Amazing spacious room, large bathroom, coffee facilities, desk, and spectacular views. Comfortable bed. Very quiet and extremely clean. Hotel has an great array of restaurants from a la carte to buffet and also has a convenient store located within the hotel.Checked in late without any hassles. Reception staff are attentive to details and very friendly. Hotel is very central to a lot of locations, walking distance to shopping centres, restaurants and also to shinjuku train station. Plenty to see and do around this location. Staff are more then happy to assist you with your travel needs. Also has the benefit of transfers to and from both airports via the airport limousine coach that stops at this hotel.Would definitely recommend this hotel and will definitely stay again soon.

I like how quiet the location of the hotel and contrast to it, the back exit of the property leads you to a lot of small & big shops, restaurants, malls, coffee shops & the central train station. Just cross the street from the back door and it's a long stretch of shopping place. I also find it very convenient that the limousine bus to and from Haneda airport stops at the property. The staff were all polite, friendly & efficient to their guests. It's so nice to see people so dedicated to their without expecting tips. (I admire the Japanese for that, lovely culture.) my room is the plaza superior in the south tower which is the newly renovated bldg. it was so easy taking the train from the airport to Keio plaza but if you will do lots of shopping, I suggest taking the limousine bus to the airport. It's quite an effort to carry your luggages up the stairs.

This is a great hotel in a good area . Rooms are large and room is very comfortable . Food good .right near railway station ,lovely park over the road .its in easy reach to lots of good resturants and shopping areas. You can visit quite a few attractions from here Mt Fugi is within an easy distance . The hotel has coffee and tea making in the rooms . It is a very large hotel but very friendly ,The breakfast is self service but has a great choice of good food in a nice inviroment .

Ive stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel many times. That hotel is normally very crowded during holiday seasons, business conventions & weddings. Many Japanese choose to stay here.I've stayed at 2 room types.The Plaza Luxe room in the south wing has only a queen sized bed and is smaller than other rooms but very tastefully renovated. ***Read below to see what i wrote for the breakfast that was included.The Plaza Premier King room in the main wing is huge. There is alot of space for me to open 2 98L Rimowa Topas luggages and still have lots of space to walk around and even 'throw shopping around'. It is very clean, modern japanese design and there is a dressing table outside the toilet which is a plus!This hotel is a Good Neighbour Disney Hotel, there is a shuttle bus to Tokyo Disney Resort. If you're going, book your bus tickets at the reception/concierge or email the hotel in advance. They'll give you a bus confirmation when you arrive if you did the latter.The airport limousine also stops at this hotel, it is very convenient.The gym is a little bit old and limited however its good enough to get a workout. (Not 24hrs)Keio Plaza has lots of good restaurants. Hotel guests have 10% discount!Kyubey has awesome sushi (not michelin, but still really good as some michelin places tend to overdo the vinegar to rice ratio).Yamanami has great teppanyaki! Amazing melt-in-your-mouth beef.Glass court has a great breakfast buffet. ***If you stay at the Plaza Luxe room, they will give you breakfast at the Lounge (near the check in area) which has a very limited variety (western). The hotel is about a 8-10minute walk to Shinjuku station. There is a tunnel you can walk through from the back of the hotel (Basement level) directly to the JR lines & metro. You can also walk from the back door (cloak room direction) through the office building and row of shops and you'll reach Shinjuku station.The hotel is near lots of things.Just needs a bit of walking. But so convenient. - standing sushi bar (3-5mins walk)- 24hrs sushi joint (3-5mins walk)- tax free drugstore/beauty store (3-5mins walk)Those below are on the other side of shinjuku, but still walkable.- Kabukicho- Ichiran- BAKE hokkaido cheese tart (shinjuku station, near kabuki-cho exit)- BIC Camera- Uniqlo, BICQLO - Adidas, Nike, Sports Lab by ATMOS- NeWoman, Blue Bottle (Famous for coffee)- & so much more!! I only listed my faves.

We love this hotel; location was super about 7 mins to shinjuku station which is also the highway bus station that we hopped on to Gotemba Premium outlets. Hotel provides complimentary transport to and fro Disney Resort which is super convenient for the early bird and the tired individual after a long day in the park.
