Just 2 mins walk and you can find eateries and 2 convenient stores. The hotel takes care of every detail - even provide facial Wash and moisturiser specially for lady.

Nice and comfortable hotel, high standing, at 5 min walking form Shinjuku station, very convenient for Yamanote line, Toei line, all JR lines and metro.Walking area with access to department stores, sops and galleries. Marge rooms, very comfortable bed, classical japanese style bathroom. Breakfast european/US style.Start for tours to Fujisan, Hakone etc.

The hotel is ideally situated near the train station and bus station. Walking distance to shopping areas and various restaurants. Hotel is clean with superb amenities. Spacious rooms. Staff are friendly and helpful.

Our tour group stayed at this hotel just recently. The rooms were very comfortable, clean and spacious. There are plenty of plugs to charge our phones and cameras. The bathrooms were well stocked with toiletries. There are quite a few places for breakfasts and dinners. We only had breakfast at 2 of the restaurants. Both were buffets. One is mainly western style and the Super Buffet had both western and Japanese style breakfasts. We enjoyed both but the Super Buffet had more varieties. I recommend getting there when they first open to avoid waiting in lines. We were lucky that we are early birds so we ate before the lines began. The hotel is very close to many restaurants, all are within 5 - 10 minutes walk. It is also very close to the Shinjuku station so you can go shopping using the local transportation.One perk from this hotel is that the guests can ride the "free" shuttles to/from the Tokyo Disneyland and Disney Sea Parks, but you will need to make reservations. Prior to leaving for Tokyo, we made arrangements/reservations with the hotel for the free shuttles to and from the hotel and Tokyo Disneyland, which was so very convenient. We also purchased Disneyland park tickets on-line ahead of time to make things easier. The shuttles are very punctual, so be at the bus stop ahead of time so you won't miss the bus. The hotel customer service is excellent, everyone is very polite. I would stay at this hotel again the next time we visit Tokyo.

We had a beautiful room at Keio Plaza, with many amenities. The staff was well versed in English, and were incredibly helpful with mapping our routes out and finding places and things to do. The complimentary breakfast passes offered generous breakfast buffets with both Japanese and American favorites. The selection of restaurants and bars in the hotel means that you don't have to venture out if you haven't recovered from jet lag.

The hotel is very well located as it is walk distance away from Shinjuko station. The rooms are spacious and modern. The hotel offers a variety of choices for your meals by accessing the many restaurants that are hosted in the building. A bus/shuttle service connect you to Tokyo Narita Airport. All in all, the Keio Plaza is an excellent choice to visit Tokyo!

Can't fault any thing. Everything was spot on. Beds comfortable. Long queues at breakfast but it moved really quickly and everything was fresh. Location is excellent. Very short walk ro Shinjuku station, restaurants, shops etc. You can also book the airport bus, both Haneda and Narita.

We stayed at Keio Plaza for one night pre-cruise and two nights post-cruise. We had requested a handicap accessible room. Arrangements were made by email with several sent and always promptly returned in excellent English. The room had two twin beds and two easy chairs. No queen or king beds available in the handicap rooms. One bed and one chair had electronic controls to raise and lower the height and head of bed. There were several electrical outlets although somewhat difficult to reach. We always travel with a multi outlet extension and a local adaptor for our multiple items, but I crawled under a table to plug it in. The room was nice, but nothing fancy. The bathroom had an accessible toilet but was too small and had a large tub that was very difficult to navigate. We knew that before we arrived, but it is difficult to find a room without a tub in Japan where baths are part of the culture. Complimentary water and a mini refrigerator and hot pot. Our rooms were on the 30th floor but at the end of the hall. Decent views and quiet. Multiple elevators going to different levels but easily located. We had breakfast and three dinners at the hotel. All were extra. Breakfast was an ok buffet. Watch your time as they tear down and set up for lunch a little early. A little expensive, but typical for a large hotel. Also ate at the Italian and the Hibachi style restaurant. Both had reasonable options on the menu. We particularly enjoyed the hibachi restaurant. Everything cooked at the table. Excellent service and very clean. Respectful of my husband's crustacean allergy. Dinners were $175 and $135 for two with no alcohol. Ok for the hibachi but probably overpriced for the Italian. Service was very good and abundant. English speakers were available and could handle simple exchanges. Beyond that they may need someone else to help with your problem. The best buy were magnum bars in the lower level sundry shop for less than $2. We had one every day. There are money exchange machines off of the lobby that are reasonable and easy to use. Shopping is available in the hotel. Fair number of kids because of the proximity to Tokyo Disney. They were no problem. Very nice hotel close to the transportation system. We stayed at the hotel and did our sightseeing to and from and on a separate day tour. Would use again. Would not work for several days because of inaccessible tub/shower.

We decided to try Keio Plaza Hotel upon the recommendation of a friend who has a travel agency. She told us she always stays here whenever she comes to Japan.The rooms were spacious and clean. Can accomodate three twin beds. All accomodations come with breakfast (which is not the case for other hotels) but the breakfast has the same choices for the last five days. Overall this is a very accomodating place to stay. Very near restaurants and shopping area of shinjuku.

High rise hotel in Shinjuku. We stayed on the 24th floor but there are many floors above that! The rooms are reasonable size (not huge) with nice bathroom and good selection of free toiletry items in case you forgot anything. The lobby is huge and beautifully decorated with an ikebana display.Breakfast offers a choice of western or Japanese, or you can try a bit of both. It's busy but well stocked and good choice available. I cannot comment on the dinner menu because we ate out all of the evenings we were in Tokyo. The hotel is very well placed for this, there are several streets full of small restaurants just behind the hotel and Shinjuku station less than 5 minutes walk if you want to venture out further. There s also good shopper no very close to the hotel with Dacia department store just across the road ( the basement food floor for s well worth seeing) and a new Tokyu Hands store just opened beneath the hotel.

Clean room Excellent location just a short stroll to Shinjuku station. Many staff members spoke English and were happy to assist in any way. View from window was amazing!! Beds were quite hard and pillows not the best. Otherwise fantastic!

Kieo Plaza Hotel proved to be a good value for our short visit to Tokyo. Modern, large comfortable room. Staff very courteous, egar to assist, usually adequate English speaking. Several restaurant choices available on lower floor, most various asian options, good quality. Cafe provides quick service for both western and asian choices. Shinjuku Station provides metro service within an easy 10 minute walk. Would not hesitate to use again on future visit.

This is a very large hotel. It is well located only a few minutes walk from Shinjuku station and close to the Metropolitan government building where you can go up the towers for a panoramic view of the city at no charge. The rooms are modern and pleasant but the main downside is the queue at breakfast. We waited nearly 20 minutes to get in which you need to bear in mind if time is critical. There are plenty of places to eat outside the hotel for dinner which we used as eating in the hotel is expensive ( a cup of coffee is almost £10)

I dont normaly talk bad about hotels but this one was a huge disappointment. Keio plaza is a very expensive hotel but It deserves maximum a 3 star. I am right now staying here, today It is my 6th day in this hotel. When we arrived we had to change the room twice because of the smell of cigarette ( we order a non smoking room and these rooms were supposed to be for non smokers). they are not cleaning the rooms properly, they just change the towels make the beds and thats It. The rest they leave the way It was, like old newspapers, shopping bags and If something is on the floor It stays there too etc. We did some tests to see if they are doing the job right but they arent. I never saw they using a vaccum cleaner while cleaning the rooms. The bathroom is made of plastic, like in a budget hotel. If you see on the pics you will think its marmor but its plastic. The walls are paper thin, you hear everything. There is a gap between the door and the floor and the noise comes through it (see picture) We had problems with the air conditioning in the room during two days. The carpets are very old and smelly, the rooms need urgently an upgrade. The minibar came with just these 2 bottles of water and these 2 beers and thats It. There is also a huge line to make the check in, you have to wait a bit to get to make yours. We tried to go to another hotel but the city is full, unfortunatly. The only good thing I see is the location. Near shinjuku station (about 3 blocks) and many restaurants around. This hotel is never a 4 star nor even a 5 star hotel. Stay away.

Keio Plaza is a very nice hotel in the perfect area of shinjuku ( next to metro and JR station).We had a very warm reception experience, the room was big and comfortable as for the bathroom.Yet a little bit conventional if you're looking for something more fancy.In any case, thumbs up!

This hotel in a convenient setting is too huge for a guest to feel any warmth. Its size is baffling and its dinning services cannot take in the 7-9 am pressure, with waits on both Western and Japanese dinning rooms that may take 20 and even 30 minutes (I heard the "American" breakfast is less crowded with good reason but have not tried it myself). Staff were helpful to a degree but could not take the time, with the amount of work needed, to actually show us, for instance, were the automatic change machines were, and we ended wandering the halls for 20 minutes asking several staff members about them. The rooms are smallish but this IS Tokyo so no surprise there. Fitness center also too crowded to be any good in the early hours. all in all a good bed and shower but have enjoyed hotels elsewhere in Japan, even big ones, much more.

Stayed 4 nights on a conference, clean and ok rooms (plaza deluxe room, refurbished tower), impersonal restaurants and difficult attitude in conference services. This is massive hotel, long queues for check in, breakfast waiting lines up to 30 minutes. Construction or some other noise throughout the nights from above floors. Essentially this is a group tour hotel. Not suitable for business travelers.

Stayed at this hotel for two nights as part of a tour package. The hotel is modern and located well close to all amenities. Plenty of eateries around. Service is good. Bottled water provided daily and choice of western and Japanese breakfast provided.We tried the Japanese breakfast which was most enjoyable. Highly recommended.

Very convenient location to food and shopping. We walked 3 min to the Shinjuku station. Room is quite spacious for 3 people with 3 twin beds. Housekeeping didn't clean out our teacups second night. Room is quite dated but clean. Visit the free observatory in the government building right across the street.

Fairly solid clean and safe feeling 3 star hotel. Nice without being luxury. It's a huge property so you feel safe and taken care of with all those resources around you but since it's so big it feels a little unfriendly; but the people who helped us all seemed just fine. I wouldn't call them overly friendly but they were pleasant and helpful. Best part was convenient location in Shinjuku. This isn't a hotel that makes you want to hang out for more than the time you need to rest, sleep, change, and then move along your journey.  PROPERTY- huge hotel with great location in Shinjuku- two major towers of rooms and tons of restaurants; I didn't eat at any so I cannot comment on it- they serve breakfast but it was fairly expensive so we opted out of it- lobby is on the 3rd floor- multiple doors to access hotel depending on what direction you approach fromROOM- moderate size with 2 twin beds, sitting chair and table and long desk. bathroom had a big tub, heated toilet, and sink. small bathroom counter tops. fairly large for a Tokyo hotel.- the non-smoking room smelled like smoke and even with the ionizer and air freshener, the room smelled awful and you cannot open windows- outdated design, tired carpet- basic amenities- safe and refrigerator in roomLOCATION- steps from the Tochomae subway stop and within ~10 minutes walking from Shinjuku Station. Use the underground passageways if you are walking to Shinkjuku station; it is much easier than trying to find out how to cross that huge Shinkjuku station thoroughfare- across of the Tokyo Metro Government building (our room had a great view of it), which offers free access to the 45th floor observation decks (North and South Buildings)OTHER- the Airport Limousine bus stops here to Narita and Haneda; you can make a reservation at the Bell Desk and pay on your room charge- on top of my hotels.com payment I think they charged a 600 yen hotel tax for a 3-night stay. Cash or credit card accepted- the guest services desk helped book reservations at restaurants - super helpful if you just ask!- depending on the price you pay, I think it's a fair hotel. I don't think it's worth luxury hotel prices.

Checkin in at 15.30.. they said room aren't ready yet.. need another hour.. i made a scene asking to see someone in charge, the lady then came out and said 1 room is ready, the other one will be ready in an hour. I said okay (I'm bringing my baby and he needs his nap time)..I think she's just trying to delay me.. I'm writing this review still standing at the front desk, as the lady looking through our passports and typing stuff on her computer..My second time here.. and I'm MAJORLY disappointed..

Big and bustling, lots of dining options but not so impressed by the giant bar/lounge. Selection on menu limited. Location is quiet in midst of the skyscraper area, but only a moderate walk to the very busy Shinjuku area. Views are a bit obstructed and unfortunately the 24th floor bar was under construction when we were there. Probably needed as the rooms and common areas are dated. Perfectly comfortable place to stay and good staff, but there are ample alternatives in Tokyo.

A large and impersonal hotel situated 2 mins from Tochomae underground on Oedo line and 10 mins level walk to Shinjuku Station. Rooms are good quality but small with a clean bathroom and warm toilet seat. Good American buffet breakfast although hotel needs larger breakfast rooms to cope with peak sittings when a wait of up to 30 minutes can occur. Good quality a la carte food in evening at reasonable prices except for wine running at £80/bottle. Beer is reasonable price and hotel has a convenience stooe where wine can be purchased at UK prices. There are a number of restaurants in the area at more reasonable prices. 5 minutes walk to government building which has a free observation deck, highly recommended

The room was very spacious compared with normal hotels in Tokyo. My room got a very nice Shinjuku city view. The location is convenient with plenty stores and restaurant within walkable distance. The airport shuttle also stops at this hotel. Just that the metro station is a bit further than expected.

Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo is one of the busiest hotels I've stayed at in Shinjuku. A lot of your groups from Europe, China and other countries. This makes for long lines at check-in, restaurants and elevators. However, that is the only negative thing I can say... the staff are friendly, helpful and a pleasure to work with. My room was excellent and above average size for a Japanese hotel room. I would definitely stay here again!

I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku because I wanted a good location with a well spaced hotel room for my very tall teenager & hubby and of course, the nearby train station as we wanted to catch the train to Yokohama for a day trip. We arrived Tokyo almost midnight - the hotel has a B2 mini mart that opens till 2.30 am and sells bento sets/sandwiches. We also went around the Shinjuku district -- you need to exit at hotel level B2 West Exit & cross the road to the opposite direction, pass Starbucks at the corner and ahead another small road ... there you will see bright lights with Pachinko parlors, small and niche ramen/drinking outlets. I bought my iphone 7 plus cover and iphone 6 battery pack and found the prices cheaper than Singapore -- from a . shop that sells all electronic gadgets and the name is Labi Shinjuku, opposite Hamakatsu restaurant. Don't throw away the receipt as it has a 20% rebate so that you can use the amount to deduct it off your next purchase. Must buy umbrellas in Tokyo as they are so much more cheaper at Yen 700 to 1200 for a 99% UV protection. Shinjuku is vibrant & Keo Plaza is the best!

This hotel did not look anything like the marketing images. It was dated, dirty, and looked like it belonged in the 80s. Totally misleading. A long walk from the station. In an area away from all the best parts of Shinjuku. Very long check ins and mix up at check in with room type. Would not recommend.

I was here with colleagues for a conference. The place is really luxurious, everything is top class, very clean, just like every place here in Japan. This is an amazing place for you to visit.(1) Don't go to Roppongi ! ! !(2) Go to Shibuya !

very good service and communications by email.Yamato sent luggage delivered to check-in counter within few minutes of arrival .Line for buffet breakfast but not Japanese breakfast,your choice.Executive lounge free with membership(free on application)

I have stayed there with my family almost every time we went to Tokyo! very good location which take about 10-15 minutes walk to the JR line. The room is quite big and comfortable. Staffs were friendly but some staffs had problem with communicating in English. But anyway, we are going to choose here for our next trip!!

When I was preparing for upcoming Tokyo travel, I reviewed a number of Hotels. I chose the Keio Plaza Hotel based on the Trip Adviser reviews. It was important for me that it close to the metro station and Viator tour companies makes pickups from this hotel. This was a good choice. The hotel is located in nice area with easy few minutes walk to metro. The room was spacious even by the USA standards. The hotel has stores, restaurants and even a convenience store. Few restaurants serve breakfast. We used one offering Western and Asian buffet. We really enjoyed our stay at Keio Plaza Hotel.

Enjoyed one night stay on the Luxe floor and the lounge was a pleasant break from the busy surroundings. Good sized room and bathroom, large comfortable bed and efficient staff. Well located to Shinjuku station and lots of options for dining.

Keio Plaza is a very comfortable and solid 4-star hotel nicely located near Shinjuku station.It is not exactly stylish, hip, or exciting, but the rooms are large and clean and breakfast options plentiful. Service is also impeccable and the price is rather reasonable for Tokyo.Keio Plaza is an excellent choice if you are looking for a good price/quality ratio in this part of Tokyo.

I stayed four times in Keio Plaza because of the location and room size is quite standard. It is big hotel in TokyoTen minutes walk to Keio Department Store and major shopping area. They also provide hotel shuttle bus which is convenient when you bought a lot. I concern their service is really cannot reach a standard, no smile, no greeting and poor English. I decided this is the last time to stay in this hotel, I will never come back.

We had a lovely stay. The room had everything you could possibly need. The staff were thoroughly professional , very friendly and helpful. Couldn't ask for more.Would definitely recommend this hotel and use other hotels in this chain in the future.
user_name:
John and Kerry R
Sydney, Australia

review_body: Normally I stay at the Hilton in Tokyo and I have found them great. But I also like to mix things up, so I thought I would try the Keio Plaza. I have always found Japanese people to be friendly and considerate, so I was shocked when I told them that I was feeling unwell and they refused to check me in early, even when I offered to pay for the pervious night. If this was the Hilton this would not have been a problem. They would have had a room cleaned quickly and found a way to help a valued guest. Keio Plaza do not care and I suggest you sleep on a park bench before you book a room here. Safe travels.

we recently stayed at keio Plaza Hotel, although the location was pretty close to Shinjuku station, but if you took the wrong exit, you can easily get lost in finding the hotel. also we were a little disappointed for the internet connection, when brought up to the front desk, they could do anything, and when we asked about using the business center, they said there would be charges for using it. this is not a 4star hotel services...

The hotel is very well located in the district of Shinjuku. The rooms are quite big and from ours we could see Mount Fuji, which was a great surprise. We did not get the breakfast option, however they have a konbini inside the hotel, what made things very easy for us.
user_name:
teramotopaula
Sao Jose Dos Campos, SP

review_body: Large hotel , but very quiet and comfortableOnly a 1 night stopover but we felt very welcomed and at home Good choices of food , central to eating places and a beautiful park is nearbyClean area We walked to nearby dept stores and down small streets and tried the local cuisine . Was great.Railway station nearby - a quick walk , very central

This place is great. Although our rooms was somewhat small, which is probably normal in Tokyo, everything else is perfectly taken care of. It's clean, über hygienic, well maintained, everything you need is there in the room (bathroom supplies etc...). The staff is friendly and speaks well enough English. The hotel is nicely situated in the Shinjuku district. Only a two minutes walk there's a cosy and busy area with a ton of restaurants and oddly enough a great number of electronics stores. 15 minutes walk and you are in the hart of an extremely lively part of the city, famous for it's night scene, the hotel surroundings though are really quiet. The hotel has a sky lounge which was unfortunately closed for renovations, it's supposed to have great panoramic views over Tokyo. Instead we went to the neighbouring Park Hyatt for a drink with a view from the 52 floor, in the bar used in Lost in Translation. Very nice place as well, too bad one can smoke in Japanese bars...

I had been to this hotel for at least 6 times, the main reason I chose to stay there was because of its location, convenient , about 10 mins walk to the train station. It also provides Airport bus to both Haneda and Narita. The rooms are spacious too.However, do not expect any kind of Japanese hospitality or ""omotenashi"". It doesn't matter if one chose to speak in Japanese or English to them. (By the way, the staffs at Front Desk only speak simple English) Whenever you asked for help, they would conveniently refer to you another department. No one was keen to take ownershipRooms are not sound proof and most of the time, you could hear your neighbors.They were always fully booked with huge convention groups thus do expect to queue for breakfast daily and it took a while to take the lift during peak hour.It is about time I consider looking for another alternative.

Very nice hotel. Good location. Great service. Nice large room, nice bathrooms. Quiet. Lot is different restaurant inside he hotel, has also a pastry shop, convenience store. Walking distance from major subway station.

Hotel is huge, long queues for everything, from check in to breakfast (in the case of breakfast, it may take you 35 minutes to get a table!).No coffe shop in the hotel before 9.00 am.Room carpets are extremely dirty.Bathroom is very small, only tub with a curtain...Crazy prices (250 euros) for an hotel which is in the end a 3 stars hotel, not more. Believe me.I will never come back.

- We arrived late at night, so we did not experience a long waiting time to check-in. The procedure was straight forward but the luggage boy did not bring our suitcases to the bedroom, we had to do it by ourself. Not up to standards for this kind of hotel.- Despite our request, the room we got (non smoking Standard room in Main Tower) was not renewed, we went back to the reception and faced a robotic staff who did not even try to look for our reservation details. We finally were told to wait for the manager call in the morning regarding our request. By 10 am, we got a call from Mr Tsutsui, the manager on duty who apologized and told us that we were upgraded to the South Tower, in a renovated Plaza Superior room on the 21st floor.- Regarding the non smoking room, I also want to insist on the fact that the "non smoking" labels on each room door are magnets that can be removed easily, I'm afraid these rooms may become "smoking' rooms according to booking volumes. Despite that, we did not notice any tobacco smell during our stay. - The second room was much bigger. As we stayed 6 nights, we appreciate the comfort and the amenities. We also were lucky enough to see twice Mount Fuji, on the left of the Tokyo government building, from our bedroom.- Daily room cleaning was efficient and spotless. All amenities items were replenished daily. Be aware that cleaning service ends at 3pm.- Daily Japanese newspaper in English language dropped at our door. We don't know if it's the only option the hotel provides. We would appreciate an option linked to our nationalities.- We appreciate the coffee filter set available for free in the bedroom, it's very easy to use and the coffee quality is fine.- We did not experience any food and beverage outlet within the hotel as many food options are available just crossing the street.- Price is high, even for standard room.

The Keio Hotel is a nice Hotel with a very good service. We spent her fife days and we are happy with the Hotel and the staff. All Staff a very friendly and helpful. I recommend the breakfast in the Japanese Restaurant in the Level No 2. It is very good, even it was not my taste. But compare with that what I got on the countryside it was very good.

Building is huge, different towers connected through different entrances, I was staying in South tower 14th floor, room is spacious, amenities among the best I have ever seen, but the major problem I have faced was the queue for breakfast in the morning, there are 3 restaurants to choose from but either one requires 30 min before being seated, insane, they should definitely consider additional restaurants to accommodate the number of residents during full occupancy.

Hotel is ok. Very well-located and close the metro and several electronic shops.Beds are comfortable and rooms are decently sized for Tokyo.Value for money is not great as it is very expensive for what it offers.Breakfast good but crowded.

This hotel is well located and the room we stayed in was functional. However, we booked a four night stay for the price of three and when we came to check out, they charged us for the additional night. When we queried this, we were told the additional amount was a "consumption" tax. He refused to acknowledge he was wrong. Eventually a manager came and admitted the bill was wrong although it was a battle. The consumption tax was obviously a lie. We also asked to keep the room for an extra hour but was told the hotel was fully booked and we could not although if we paid 5400 Yen, we could keep it an extra hour. They could not have been more unhelpful if they tried!

The hotel was close to the Shinjuku station but a little farther away from all the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku. The room we stayed in was not very comfortable because it's very noisy at night and we constantly hear either construction or ambulance noises - not too sure what the sirens were. The sheets were not comfortable, very rough and makes a lot of noise. Overall the room was ok, but the location was good.

4 days in Tokyo. My friend booked it and liked the location. Reasonably close to the JR train station and what could be termed restaurant street.However, the room itself needs major improvement.Bed was lumpy, sheets were rough. However, it was the ventilation system that was disgusting. I thought it was just the fan speed that was inadequate until I looked closely at the air intake system. Pictures attached.

Location of the hotel is perfect..it's located next to Shinjiku metro station and well connected to main areas in Tokyo. Rooms are spacious with cool furnitures. I could not get time to explore this hotel however i would say its one of the biggest hotel in Tokyo. Def visit this place in future!!!

I booked the Keio Plaza on the basis that I had a very pleasant stay there before. This time I wasn't as impressed as I was on my previous visit. The staff were not as friendly as before. It is also a lot more expensive than on my previous trip. Some aspects of the room are getting very tired - the bathroom could do with being brought out into the modern age.The location of the hotel is great. It is two blocks away from Shinjuku station (on the quiet side). I will look at other options for my next trip to Tokyo.

The Keio Plaza is an excellent hotel with all the amenities one would desire. The room was large by Japanese standards and larger than most US hotels. The staff was always attentive; they all speak English. There are several restaurants within the hotel. There's also several coffee shops within a few minutes walking distance. There's also a "pocket of Japanese restaurants" in a alley two blocks from the hotel. For the adventurous, its a great place. We ate at a restaurant on the fifth floor. Absolutely outstanding and reasonably priced. There's an underground passage to the Shinjuku subway station but the walk is rather long. I love this hotel!

What service! From the moment we entered , luggage to the room , getting taxis , breakfast ,wow , we could not fault it. The view from the 27 Th floor was skyscraper cliff city. What an incredibly professional hotel .

Stayed here during September with a group and found the Hotel to be massive. Hardly saw any of our other group members because they were distributed all over the Hotel and many many lifts in the Foyer take them all to different wings of the Hotel. Got lost trying to find rooms many times. Lifts are super fast when they do arrive however expect to wait a little as there are many many floors here. We were about 50- 60 people from all over the world and in the past we have attended fantastic receptions here at this venue. The rooms vary in size. Ours was compact as usual but still very comfortable. Twin rooms were much bigger. The loo is always fantastic with the washer so we have now purchased these for our home as well. The restaurants on the basement level are super. We had a dinner there with our host and the food was amazing.. We also attended another hosted dinner upstairs on the high floor whereby our hosts and the other guests partook of a very traditional Japanese meal in the Japanese style sitting on cushions and feet in the cut out area below the table. Over-all this is a classy hotel and is an icon in Shinjuku. Access from the West Exit (Nishi Guchi) from Shinjuku station and walk straight ahead slowly looking for signs above. Keio Plaza is written there. Ahead you will see a roundabout type situation...with cars parked at times. There is a small steeple in the middle of the roundabout. Keep to your LEFT on the path as you walk around the roundabout under cover. There is usually a taxi stand here if you cannot manage your luggage. The Hotel is a 2 min drive from here, or a 10 min walk straight ahead past marble pillars and little shops on the left further down. After walking 7 - 8 mins - all under cover- look to your left consistently and you will see the Keio Plaza Hotel on your left . Walk up the stairs or take the path up if you will wheel the bags. If taking the train from Narita to Tokyo Station catch the CHUO Line to Shinjuku. and follow directions above.

This place is amazing, not only that we got here spring but the location itself is the best. I love how big this place is and the center piece they have is so ravishing :D like fresh flowers every other day. Accommodating people and the check in counter is always in full service. We checked out really fast :)THE BREAKFAST BUFFET IS SUPERB :)I would like to stay here again :)

I used to be a big fan of the Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku since 15 years ago, staying there two to three times a year but judging from the last two of my stays, service level has definitely gone downhill.1. there's obvious room for improvement regarding the english level of frontline staff, do not attempt to relay complicated ideas to them in English .....2. Our recent stay in Sep revealed even more flaws in their customer service. Check-in time was 1400 hr and knowing that Keio Plaza is getting more and more crowded these days, we don't expect an early check-in and was there only at 1400 hr. Our room wasn't ready and was asked to return in an hour......Our room wasn't ready after that long hour, and was asked to check in first with the room key to be followed. By 1700 hr, our room still wasn't ready, and we were told to line up in the long queue for check-in again .................Let's just say the check-in wasn't pleasant and the frontline staff wasn't apologetic at all ...... we were given only 6 breakfast coupons when we should have 8 ..... the staff obviously wasn't happy when I pointed her mistake .......3. The hotel is crowded, the price is expensive, service level is declining. I would suggest staying at the Century Southern Tower nearby. With the endless JR station construction work completed, Century Southern Tower offers a much better option in Shinjuku.

we stayed here for 3 nights. our room were on the 26the floor. view was good. AC was good. Cleanliness was good, not great. its a big hotel with underground access to Shinjuku station ...*a long walk*yet it's lacking the warmth feeling compare the other similar hotel level. The staff is a bit "cold" .. yes, they smile but you got a feeling that they do that because they have to not because they want to do that. the wifi keep going on & off even when you stayed inside the room. the wall was a bit thin so you can hear your neighbor from time to time. nonetheless, its a nice hotel but it's lacking that hospitality i expected it would have

It is not a cheap hotel but cheaper compared to other on same standards. Location good ( check to Tochomae station as well, closer than Shinkuju station). Try hotel restaurants for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Quite a lot of options with great taste. Good free wifi.

Absolutely massive hotel, loads of shops and restaurants including a convenience store.Rooms were large as was the bathroom.Beds were comfortable.The breakfast offerings were amazing (we visited two separate restaurants) and the service everywhere was terrific.Great location, walking distance to stations, shopping, restaurants etcI would stay here again in a heartbeat

I could have graded the hotel as a 4 because there is no spa facility and the lounge was not well-stocked. The reason for a grade 5 is the fantastic service offered by all staff, from the bell boy to the concierge and breakfast staff. We had a luxe room that was not very large but had all the conveniences, including a large safe and a wonderful Japanese toilet with heated seat, shower etcetera. I would love one of those at home! There are three breakfast restaurants, of which one serves Japanese breakfast, the second Western and the third both Japanese and Western breakfast. The overall feeling of the hotel is high class and that you get what you pay for. It's a traditional hotel, without any ethnic flavour or special style. The location is good, almost on top of the Tochomae metro station and a few minutes from the Shinjuku station.

The location is superb, the hotel restaurants and facilities are excellent. The staff were very good and the concierge staff can speak some English, and are very good at organising things to do. Our room was small and a little tired but all things considered I can recommend this hotel as a good base for a stay in Tokyo

Stayed there for 2 nights on 24th floor. Large and comfortable rooms with easy to adjust climate control system and a view. Perfect firm bed. Rooms are clean and bathroom is amazing. Service great and invisible. Dining options are plentiful yet somewhat pricey. Easy to find and all information is tastefully presented inside of multiple elevators. One of my best hotel experiences. On par with Sofitel.

We spent two nights here before starting a cruise and it was great. The hotel is centrally located with easy access to subway and trains. Many restaurants and great shopping are within a few blocks as well. The rooms, although not large, are well planned out, comfortable, quiet, and spotless. The hotel staff was very friendly and helpful. Would definitely stay here again if back in Tokyo.

Good hotel, excellent location with many Shinjuku highlights within walking distance. Very close to Shinjuku Station--there is an underground walkway. Breakfast buffet at "Glass Door" restaurant was mediocre but omelettes were good. There can be quite a wait for the buffet after 8:00 am, so best to eat early. At the time of our stay, one elevator for the south tower was under renovation, so you could wait a while for an elevator, or it might stop at most floors. Allow yourself extra time.

Keio Plaza looked good from their website and since it is one of my corporate preferred hotels I decided to try it. I arrived before the 2pm checkin time off a long flight and was told I needed to wait to checkin because no rooms were ready. Every time I went back to check if a room was available they said no without even checking, I know that there are rules but there needs to be some use of discretion. The rooms are out of date and dirty. I happened to have a black light with me which shows bodily fluids and was astonished at how filthy the room was especially the shower curtain and carpet throughout the room and even the walls. I have attached some pictures. There really is no excuse!

Large hotel, with inside restaurants and banquet rooms. Large rooms, good (attentive) service, closeness to many yakitori places. No problems. The hotel food (i.e. drinks, dining) is pricy and there are better options in the neighborhood. A bit too impersonal for me.
user_name:
Kai C
Half Moon Bay, California

review_body: We stayed here on 2 occasions just for the practicality of being close to the station. The hotel is clean although the front of house when checking in are not very flexible. On our second stay we have been given a room that although it is clean it is literally like stepping into 1970. This is located in the main tower. The South tower seems to be a more modern so maybe ask for a room in that tower.

This is a classy hotel. There are many cheaper options but I booked this for a comfortable stay after a few nights on Futons in another city. This was our end of holiday spoil. It was clean, roomy and very convenient to Shinjuku station (west). Plenty of restaurants, shops and nightlife very close. Would definitely stay here again. Its has many fancy restaurants within the hotel but we chose to eat at the local restaurants instead.

Rooms are a good size, nice interior, and very clean. The staff is very friendly and helpful. Very close to the station. It is a 5 minute walk from a nice area with multiple restaurants, bars, and arcades if choosing to experience some of the nightlife. Stayed in a regular room the first night and booked one of the Hello Kitty rooms the second night as a surprise to my wife. Hello kitty room was full of hello kitty, a little overwhelming for me, but my wife loved it.

Stayed at this hotel for 3 nights in Sep. The hotel is located a short walk from Shinjuku train station, which is ideal to travel around Tokyo. The hotel has 4 breakfast restaurants, which caters to different cuisines, and a couple of dinner restaurants - which are good. The rooms are decent size for Tokyo, while beds are slightly hard but give a decent sleep. There are alot of restaurants in the area, if you do not eat at the hotel.

Was there with my family. Booked a twin bed room with an extra bed. It was nice. The room was bigger than other similar grade hotel with a nice tube in the room. The location is good, ~10 min walk from the metro station to there and you would pass through an area with lot of shopping stores and great food - the area that helped me to spend few nights (after my kid was slept).But 1 comment on the swimming pool.. it looks good.. but it charge really a lot, about USD25 per adult.. for most of the similar grade hotels, their pools are free for hotel guests to access, at most, few dollar for towel / locker usage.. I really don't understand why they charge so high. Other than that, I've no complaint at all.(Note: from other reviewers comments, there are 2 areas - renovated floors / original floors. I've requested for the renovated floors - you may ask so as well)

Stayed for 4 nights at this hotel and could not fault it. Nice rooms, friendly staff. Close to the station but at the same time reasonably quiet. We had use of the lounge up on the 34th floor which was included in our package which was nice as we had before and after dinner drinks and snacks.A very enjoyable stay

Location, restaurants and service fantastic. Friendly and helpful staff. Felt very welcomed. Use of gym complimentary however had to pay to use pool. Would recommend hotel and be happy to return and stay again.

Rooms are very clean (GIven Tokyo mentality, I doubt if there's a really bad room in Tokyo)The 7 or 8 restaurants downstairs are without doubt excellent, but there are plenty of very good eating places within 3-5 minutes walking distance toward the train station at a fraction of the price.

We recently had a 12 night stay in this hotel which is a short walk from Shinjuku Railway Station. Our check in was without incident and we were taken to our room. It was 'compact' compared to other hotels we have stayed in but it had all the comforts of home.Our stay was pretty much noneventful until we wanted to have more than one cup of tea per day. these were replenished each day (except when they forgot). It was a daily occurrence for me to call room service to ask for more - very annoying. Initially, we were provided with a coffee machine and 4 pods. these were to be replenished each day. We had been there for 3 or 4 days and not used any. On this particular day, we had 2 visitors come to our room and proceeded to make coffee. I called room service and asked for a few more pods and was told that I had reached my daily allowance and would need to buy additional pods. The service manager eventually came to our room to explain in more detail and brought more pods. We were not charged for the additional pods as I explained we had not used any prior. We didn't ask for any more pods again. We decided to go for a swim one day but were told that we had to pay 2000 yen each to enter the pool area. That's about A$25.00 each. Needless to say, we didn't swim. on the first day in the hotel, we notice black hairs on the ceiling of the bathroom (it was quite low). During our stay, these remained. It wouldn't surprise me if they are still there.

The hotel is some 40+ years old. I can imagine its good old days, but right now it needs some upgrade with its hardware. Anyway, I'd consider the room as clean and neat. This was not the first time we visited Tokyo, and we were fully aware that many Japanese did not feel comfortable speaking in English. However, we were a bit disappointed (and frustrated) to find, in this 4.5stars hotel, that some staffs of the check-in counter (and even of the concierge) were not able to communicate in simple English. Location-wise, the hotel is on the west side of Shinjuku (with Shinjuku Station as reference). It took us 10mins to walk to Shinjuku station; 15-20mins to walk to the east side, where most department stores are located. We found it more convenient when we stayed in another hotel right above the Shinjuku Station during our previous visit.

I wanted to rave about Keio Plaza Hotel but I just couldn't. The hotel excels when it comes to accessibility and location. It is a very short walk from the biggest subway station in the world, Shinjuku. And you have another metro like (Toei's Oedo line) literally steps away from the hotel. This means if you are checking in here only to sleep, all of Tokyo is very accessible. The hotel is also accessible via the Airport Limo Bus as they are an official stop. If availing of that feature, head for the bell desk. Rooms are small as expected for Japanese size but somehow comfortable. BUT (and here's the big gripe), the hotel does not pay heed to requests you make at reservation -- meaning if you wanted a double room or a non-smoking room, you may still end up with a smoking room with a single bed. If you try and ask for the room you requested at check-in, they will tell you to pay double. My other travel mates also received a note in the middle of their stay that the hotel was hiking up their room rates due to occupancy levels. Wow. You'd wonder if this hotel was operated by the Yakuza. Certainly not Japanese hospitality or "Omotenashi" as I didn't observe or feel whole-hearted customer service. It is ludicrous even in Western standards. Given there are many other hotels in the area that are of similar distances to the station, I will definitely stay away from Keio Plaza when I return to Tokyo.

We stayed here at the end of our holiday in Japan - the location was conveniently located near the train station, staff were lovely and accomodating, beds were comfortable and nice pillows! Many tours also offer pick ups from this location so makes it easier if you are booking day tours etc.

I stayed here for two nights to get some sight-seeing in after a week of business travel to Hino. The first great thing was that they transferred my bag from the Keio Plaza in Hachioji to this one in Shinjuku. This allowed me to just go to work in the morning, get on the train after work, and arrive here for the weekend without dragging luggage around. This next day, I took a Hato bus tour, which picks up right from the lobby. Finally, an express bus to Narita also leaves from the hotel. All of this made sightseeing and travel back to the airport extremely simple and convenient. This is a big hotel, with multiple restaurants. It also has a pretty good convenience store - making it easy to buy a simple breakfast of yogurt, juice, and other things the night before rather than have to go to a restaurant for breakfast. All of the staff I encountered were friendly and helpful. The room was well-appointed and very comfortable, with a decent sized desk and a task light.

We visit Tokyo group of 60+ people. Location is closed to Shinjuku as one of best shopping places in Tokyo. Room is big enough with full amenities in bathroom.Breakfast was long Q in waiting line due to many tourists in this hotel.There is Lawson Convenience Store near hotel by 5-min walk.

A short walk from the station, and we arrived at the Keio Plaza. Coming via the covered walkway from the station, I was underwhelmed when I saw the entrance to the hotel. Little did I realise how large the hotel was, and this was the smallest of three entrances. Hence, exiting the hotel was made easy with all the other 'larger' entrances available. In essence, the hotel was well kept, clean and the staff were all happy to go out of their way to assist. The concierge team were most helpful in so many ways and on so many days and it was such a pleasure to deal with them. Whilst we were there, one experiences was not so favourable. There was a large conference on at the time and this impacted the utilisation of the lifts. At one stage, we had to wait half an hour because all the attendees were going to dinner at the same time. This was annoying. Also, if you plan to use the pool, be prepared to part with money. I am used to having that facility available as a paying guest and it was not a cheap additional charge. Upon querying this, to be told that the other hotels do it, so we do as well, did not justify a valid reason to me.

We stayed here three days at the beginning of a nine-day Japan vacation. Picked this place based on reviews and its proximity to Shinjuku station. The walk from the station to the hotel ended up being about 10 minutes. The hotel boasts free wifi, but at least in our room on the 14th floor the connection was inconsistent.On the surface the hotel has an aura of a luxury establishment, but beyond the ritzy lobby the hotel is actually mid-tier and somewhat dated. This in and of itself is not bad, but Keio Plaza is no luxury hotel. Our stay went without a hitch and I'd stay there again but wouldn't go out of my way to do so.
user_name:
AndyBrown79
New York City, New York

review_body: For a first timer this hotel is the perfect jump-off from your travel. Yes I agree its a bit pricey compared to others, its large and busy hotel but its also very convenient. As you arrive in Tokyo you just take an airport bus and the hotel is included in its drop point. Also another selling point for me is that tours also originate from this hotel and extra perks if you're staying at the hotel, they have free shuttle service going to Disney. Then when you go out its a few minutes away from shops and restaurants. I traveled with my 2 kids so the room they gave is perfect for us, three double size beds and for breakfast you won't get bored with the food since you have 3 restaurants to choose from. It was recommended to me and I will definitely recommend it to friends.

I stayed here for four nights for business meetings. The room was ok. Bed was comfortable and the room was very big. None the less the feel was impersonal. The room had full amenities including iron and complementary water The location was perfect for meetings with government. Despite being clean and well operated I wouldn't like to stay here again.

We used to love this hotel because of its central location very close to Shinjuku station, relatively small but decent room and reasonable rates so we had been staying here in the past. Recently, however, we found Keio's rates too pricey for its class, despite keener competition in hotel industry.

I stayed here for a conference in the middle of summer. The hotel is very large and the staff are efficient. The room (a twin) was on the smaller side but the bathroom was well appointed. The location is great if you want to be close to Shinjuku and Shinjuku Station. There is a charge to use the pool - 2000yen or approx $20usd. The gym is small and crowded if more than 3-4 people are working out at the same time. There were times where there was a long (10-15min) wait for the elevator due to so many people wanting to use it at the same time. My overall experience was fine but for the price you would not expect to have to pay for the pool.

I would say that this hotel is “Central to everywhere” Shinjuku Station is in the middle city surrounded by shopping center. So close to the train station and airport limousine stop is at the hotel. The hotel has a free shuttle bus to Disneyland and Disney sea (reservation required!) I have stayed here for 7 nights.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel when I was visiting Tokyo for a conference. The hotel is in an excellent location, offers free wifi, hotel staff make every effort to help despite the language barrier.I found the hotel had excellent facilities. Rooms were spacious and had all the amenities. Breakfast was included in yhe price. They have a couple of western style breakfast restaurants (opens at 0500 till 2200). Also, there are plenty of restaurants within walking distance (3-5mins). Shinjuku train station is about 5-7mins away and is easy to get everywhere in tokyo.A little on the pricier side but well worth it if you don't mind the money!

The hotel is always full of acivity from the lobby, to the restaurants, to the areas around the hotel. This is great for us as this shows we're in the middle of everything. Department stores, restaurants, and shopping is nearby. The rooms are very clean and with complete amenities you would expect from a 5-star hotel. Restaurants offer great food and very good service. Definitely looking forward to our next stay.

After a long flight from the UK we were transferred to the Keio Plaza hotel where we attempted to check in. We were told no one could check in until 2pm. This was adhered to to the second. We were very tired and jet lagged due to the time difference we were told to wait in the lobby until check in time which was some 4 hours away. Surely a room must have been available before then. Not a good start to our holidays. The room we did get was basic and a comfy bed. Food was just too expensive to even consider. Free Wifi was available in the room. A charge was made if you wished to use the pool.

After being in Sapporo we were overwhelmed when we arrived at Hotel. We had seen maybe half a dozen Westerners in our 4 days at Sapporo and the peaceful quiet experience dissolved instantly we stepped into the foyer and loud western tourists!!There are a lot of tourist groups but having been on a couple of these it does make it easy being picked up from your Hotel.The staff are really helpful and friendly and the Luxe rooms are beautifully appointed with extras.

Big and luxurious rooms! I loved the view and being close to the train station is a big plus. Breakfast was really good and again the view was great. It is also very close to a government building where you can go to the viewing floors free of charge! This is a great hotel for a stay in Tokyo. Im going back this year!

Suinjuku district is my favourite. Any time I go to Tokyo, This is the place I want to stay. It's very well connected to go everywhere thanks to its huge Railways Stations and Bus Terminal. Keio Plaza Hotel is also my favourite hotel here. Very good service, nice people, beautiful rooms with nice view. Hotel can be expensive in certain period of the year, try to book it in advance. Hotel is located 500 meters from Shinjuku station and also by Airport Limousine Bus from both Narita and Haneda Airport. If you go to Tokyo, suggest to fly to Haneda Airport which is the nearest one to Town. Keio Plaza has various restaurants which can result expensive, but just a few meters from the Hotel you can find a good choice of Yummy Restaurant at all prices.

The hotel is first class well maintained , staff are well mannered and helpful , the room was a good size and very comfortable . For Uk visitors Tv channels very limited, bathroom immaculate includes electric heated toilet seat which has a douche wash .  The hotel is in a really good location for the station , shops and centre of city .  We found everything very expensive in Tokyo compared to UK and were really surprised that out and about few people speak English and few bi lingual signage , ordering food was a fun experience , most places have plastic copies of the food on offer so as long as you can point you can get by . Amazed that Japanese favourite food is Itallian !

If Hotels with no atmosphere are your thing then this is the place.I have stayed here before and it gets worse. the breakfast queues are a disgrace and due to the lack of common sense by the staff or freedom from the management will never improve and you just have to accept it.However i always book a double room non smoking. For the second time to this hotel i get the same reply " Sorry sir single smoking only available" this time i didn't take it. You have to be very assured in your comments, so that you get what you have booked and i did come close to being very rude. Again because the staff act like robots with no personality and freedom to deal with problems.I will try not to stay here again and will opt for the Hyatt opposite in future.Also you would think that from my booking they would know i have stayed with them 4 times in the last 12 months, and that should interest them in giving good service. This is not the case as they mainly cater for large tour parties. You the know the type of customer that stays for 1 visit and never returns again. Honestly if you want service, for an expensive hotel stay somewhere else. The Blossom is good as is the Hyatt opposite all about the same money.

Very good location base for easy access to all areas of Tokyo and beyond due to being very close to Shinjuku Station. Easy to navigate underground & overground trains (Japanese not required). Close to Golden Gai, Kabukicho & Harajuku. We were even lucky enough to get a (very distant) view of Mount Fuji from our room on the 23rd floor.We went during cherry blossom time making it very busy but still managed everything we wanted to. We even did alot of walking with no problems. We did hire a MiFi (portable hot spot) so we always had internet (google maps) which was alot cheaper than roaming data.We stayed on the club level which gave us all day access to a lounge with snacks & drinks.

Very central location, easy walking distance to Shinjuku Station and to department stores and shops. Airport bus stops right in front! Convenience store right in the building which is open till the early hours of the morning is a big bonus, as it also has an ATM. The specialty restaurants in the hotel are a bit expensive, but there is no shortage of other eating places within walking distance from the hotel. The hotel even gives out a map dedicated to ramen houses, which we found really handy. Our room was impeccably clean, the staff extremely polite and professional. Worth every single cent!

The location is in the middle of (almost) everything in Tokyo. Near Shinjuku train station and airport coach stops here, this is an easy access for our elderly travelers.Hotel lobby had so people going around. TOO many people waiting for their pick-up for some tour destinations.Room is big enough to accommodate the family.Very expensive but RECOMMENDABLE!

It may not be the flashiest or most luxuriest hotel in Tokyo, but this is still my favourite. The location is great for business in the Shinjuku area with access to the subway and bus station within minutes.The Rooms are comfortable and very quiet, with good amenities, great views from the upper floors (from some you can see Mt Fuji on a clear day), and nice bathrooms. The staff are very very helpful, the front desk speak fluent English as well as everyone in the shops and restaurants. In typical Japanese style, the staff are so polite and respectful. Once when I came with my wife she took ill with food poisoning on the BA flight, and the hotel staff took us to the hospital in a taxi and spoke to the doctors. It was something I shall never forget.The restaurants are excellent with several for breakfast (Japanese or Western). I would highly recommend the tempura and teppanyaki restaurants. Also there is a great little shop on the basement which does boxed lunches, snacks, drinks and other essentials.If you are traveling around Japan I would highly recommend you use the Takuhaibin luggage delivery service which you can ask for at the bell boy stand. Your luggage can be magically delivered to your next destination instead of lugging it around. Trains in Japan have very little storage space.I can't recommend this hotel highly enough.

Me & my husband wanted to do tea ceremony for years & we had a chance to experience it during our honeymoon. Many thanks to Michiko Yano for fitting us in the last minute and she is wonderful. She explained everything clearly in english and made us feel very comfortable. The tea room was so beautiful and traditional, more than we ever expected. It will be one of our fondest memory that we had in Japan, on our holiday.

This hotel is very nice and has a perfect location in Shinjuku. The lobby is very large and spacious. Also, our room was large, clean and very well-maintained. Our room had a nice view of the impressive Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building located directly across the street. My only criticism was the very long wait for an elevator to our room (in the South Tower). Due to construction, an elevator was temporarily closed and caused long lines for the elevators during peak times. We spoke with a concierge at the hotel to arrange a city tour. She was very pleasant and helpful. I recommend this hotel.

East meets west breakfast- excellent!Usual American breakfast, bacon, sausage ,eggs, omelette station, bread, pancake etc. in addition there are rice , rice soup, fried chicken chunks-boneless , tofu , other side dishes to eat with rice. Miso soup and some Japanese favorite , naato- it is fermented soy bean and supposed to be good for you. However it is slimy and have a smell that needs to get used to. Over all , excellent breakfast with all breakfast beverages , juices, pastries, salad and open kitchen set up. Good experience.

The airport limousine stops at this hotel. The rooms in the new wing - the South Tower - are quite spacious by Japanese standard. Being close to the Shinjuku station, it makes Travelling around very easy. There are lots of good food even until late in the evening. This is a great location for shopping & eating. They also have shuttle bus going to & from Disney land. Would definitely recommend this to anyone who is looking for a place easily accessible from airport & Sunway stations.

Keio is an upscale hotel at periphery of shinjuku. A lot of tour group pick up and drop off from this hotel. Airport limousine bus also drop off and pick up from here. Making it a very convenient hotel. It is still three long blocks to got to shinjuku station. Or one can take tomache station and transfer at shinjuku station. Basement convenient store is excellent. Sells all sort of snacks and handy foods late into night. Their peach jello is so good my kids was asking if we can go back just for that. My room was spacious with 3 single size beds. I was very appreciative of having a bed on my own. Room was clean and renovated. The bathroom however needed a facelift. It looks like come output from the he the 80s with the salmon plastic tub and Corian sink top. Staff was helpful. Overall a good stay at a price. Would recommend it for families with good numbers of people.

I stayed with my wife an son in a big triple room where we had space enough to feel very comfortable. Three big beds and a gorgeous bathroom. The hotel has many food options, from traditional Japanese food to international buffet. Staff is really helpful and kindIt is a four stars hotel that feels like a five stars. I would definitely recommend it.

The hotel itself isn't too shabby. Our rooms were at the South tower on the 33rd floor. The rooms were quite spacious and clean. Breakfast was boring. But the one thing that took us by surprise was the use of the pool. I'm not sure if this applies to all or most hotels in Tokyo, but we had to pay 2000 yen per person to use the pool! I've never stayed in a hotel with a pool that charges their hotel guests! It's not a cheap hotel to begin with! Apart from that, the location is fantastic. 5 mins walk through the underground passage to Shinjuku station ( from the hotel lobby, go to B1 exit 2, underpass is on the right) I probably wouldn't stay here again, might as well stay in a boutique hotel without a pool for the same price, if not cheaper probably

Before I go to there, I thought it would be old and not very clean, but in fact it looks new and very very clean. This really surprised me. It is close to Shinkuku rail station, five minutes walking from the back gate of the hotel, and a lot of restaurants and bars and stores for everyone.There is Limousine Bus can arrive directly from the airport.Very much facilities.

When I was checked in the counter women was not kind, that is unusual experience at the hotel front.Second day, when I came back to hotel, bathroom was not clean. Maid didn't clean bathtub. Sampoo,conditioner and shower gel cap still opened. It was awful

Was there for only 1 night (thru a cruise line) and was extremely impressed. Rooms were excellent, as were staff and service. I ordered room service the next morning for breakfast and coffee. The scrambled eggs were the best I have ever eaten. I used Japanese Yen and was amazed at how great the charges were compared to here in the USA. The service was beyond excellent. The hotel staff can't do enough for you. They have shops that are beautiful. Also a "convenience store" which has about everything you need. Only draw back for English speaking guests....TV only has CNN and BBC. Walking distance to many great shopping and restaurants.

Keio Plaza Hotel is a great place to stay in Tokyo. It is a short walk from the subway and train stations. It is right across the street from the Tokyo Metro Building. Also, it is a short walk down the street to the Park Hyatt. All those places are a great starting point for experiencing the city. We had a room on the 31st floor that had a wonderful view of the city. The hotel has a very modern feeling and a choice of breakfast buffets. The staff is very helpful with anything that you would like to do in Tokyo. They made us a reservation at the Park Hyatt for drinks and dinner. I would recommend this hotel!

Great location but elevators are very slow !!!Lots of restaurants to try !!!Buffets are super delicious!!!!I give 5 stars to the curry dishes ...Trip advisor app are no good at all !!!!!!!!! On iPhone :)I waste lots of time to get this ThruI want to rate this app 1 star if I can !!!

The hotel is in a perfect location only a few minuets walk from Shinjuku Station and plenty of entertainment! Shinjuku truly is a wonderful part of Tokyo! The hotel is modern and has everything you would expect to find in the rooms. The beds were comfortable, the view was great, and the facilities make it possible to live out of the hotel if you were so inclined to do so!

Big hotel very crowded and not impressive first feeling but overall very efficient. The lobby is very essential and it might be difficult to find seats. Rooms are big, comfortable, and clean and well maintained with a lot of space. Good desk for working, plenty of power socket for any kind of device and also for any plugs (EU, USA). Power sockets at the night table on both sides. Restaurant generally very good and Kagari (the Japanese one) excellent with a lot of local costumers and at a very reasonable price. Congress side impressive capacity good level of organization. Concierge efficient and helpful, often crowded.

We stayed in this hotel for 2 nights Well appointed rooms with everything you need.plenty of bars and restaurants in the building. Our breakfast wasn't included but you have a few choices all which are fantastic. Great location to train station restaurants and bars to explore 2 minutes away. Would recommend to stay here.

The Hotel location is great ( close to Shinjuku Station ) The service and the rooms are excellent. The only thing that i don`t like is the line that you need to do everyday for breakfast in the Restaurants.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo for one night on August 11, 2016. I was traveling with my 15 year old daughter and 12 year old son. We stayed in the Hello Kitty room (Hello Kitty City, triple bed room). It was as great as the photos on their website show! The hotel was expensive and so we only stayed here for one night, but it was worth it for me (the Hello Kitty fan). The room was very spacious and everything was Hello Kitty! The front desk staff was busy when we were checking in, but attentive and communicated very well. Our bellboy was wonderful – showed us all the Hello Kitty points of interest as well as the amenities, which were many. The hotel provided everything we could want and even allowed me to take home many of the Hello Kitty items (they provide a list upon check in of everything you can take :). The hotel is beautiful and very large. The room amenities (coffee/tea/hot water) and beds were very generous and comfortable and the bathroom was also well appointed (complete with a pink tub). If I were not staying in the Hello Kitty room, I would not have paid the very expensive room charge. But it was totally worth it for me for the one night and I would recommend the Hello Kitty Room to any Hello Kitty fan!

Whenever in Tokyo, I stay at Keio Plaza. It is a very convenient place to start touring the city or use Shinjuku station for day trips. A lot of restaurants and facilites are already inside the hotel, with more options outside. For easy access to Shinjuku station, use a short cut by going to the lowest floor (below the lobby). Step outside and enter the tunnel to the station.The rooms are very spacious and the personnel is very friendly. There are great views from the higher floors, as the windows are large.

My wife is in a education program that wanted to visit Tokyo, Japan as a school trip. The school has their own travel agent that they use for this trip and of course i just joined in last later additional participant which paid and coordinated by myself, not using the travel agency that the school uses. Long story short, of course we didn't know that Japan uses occupancy instead of pay for room like any hotel in USA does. Therefore I have to pay extra in order to stay in the same room with my wife which is just a small fee which i paid without complaint.But when i ask for extra breakfast voucher, i was rejected flat out by the manager and to make matter worse, he has the audicous to say your wife already have the voucher, you just an addition guest that has to pay for breakfast?? At this point, i felt that he insulted me without being direct insulting, and i felt a bit offended by the way the manager said to me.I thought Japan has great customer service because I end up staying another hotel (Sheraton Miyako) for the last 3 nights, they even took my wife and my luggage up to our room which Keio didn't do that.Keio standard room is much smaller compare to Sheraton Myiako standard room. Keio's wifi is unstable because i kept get disconnect while Sheraton wifi is strong, fast and stable.House keeping comes in the afternoon for Keio that's first for me, while Sheraton is in the morning which it should be.Sheraton only consider their hotel a 4 star rating, but they offer excellent service. Sure i didn't get breakfast voucher because they already stated when you book that they don't provide free breakfast but i didn't ask so that's on me. Keio, i asked and i get not only rejected and they insulted me on my intelligent. So if i ever come back to Tokyo again in the future which i will in very soon, I would NOT stay at Keio, there are many hotel choices in Shinjuku that offer 5 star service without being actual 5 star rating.

Marc, 2016 Hina-matsuri (Girls' doll festival) its show Japanese tradition. If you visit here in another month you can see different exhibition for each month. Keio Plaza to be located center (i think :D) you can walk around Shinjuku from here and beautiful decoration, view and yummy breakfast.

The hotel is not far from the station. You can walk with your luggage to get to the hotel. The room is very spacious. I got the room with a very good view (Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building), I got sick during the stay. The room is very comfy. I had real good sleep to help me get through the trip.Breakfast is sooooo great. There are various kinds of japan to try.There is also a small mini mart in the hotel. Everything is very convenient.Please also check whether your booking is eligible for the club lounge. I have missed that.
user_name:
Check R
Bangkok, Krung Thep, Thailand

review_body: The hotel was well maintained, the rooms quite airy and well kept. The good location was very convenient and made our shopping and tours so much more easier. Service was very good and they even assisted in making a special event even more special. I will certainly place this as the hotel I will stay during my next trip to Tokyo.

The only negative thing I could say in regards to the hotel is that it was not initially clear on how to store my luggage till the check in time of 1400, however the staff member I asked directed me to the right location.While the hotel room was expensive (approx $400AUD), it didn't feel like a rip off. Some of the reasons why were smooth elevators, RFID door keys instead of useless magnetic strips, 2 bottles of complementary water, overlapping curtain rails, a kettle you could easily refill and plugin, the adapters for non Japanese plugs and included wifi that was easy to set up.Transport options are excellent from here. It is less then 10 minutes to walk to shinjuku station complex. The hotel has a desk associated with booking air port transfers (via Airport Limousine) and booking the Tokyo Disneyland bus. The hotel also has a JTB Sunrise office and meeting spot for supporting tour pickups. The restaurants provide excellent food and service. However they can be expensive eg 3000 yen - 10% guest discount, for the breakfast buffet. They are also popular places for non guests as well.

Keio Plaza Hotel is a truly excellent hotel, and wonderful value for money. Even before i arrived at the hotel, i had several packages sent to them and they kept them for me. The hotel's guest relations department also helped with restaurant reservations. At time of my arrival, the check in was fast and efficient. And i was showed to my room personally. The room was extremely clean and big. It was extra spacious as i had chosen the Luxe room, which was really comfortable. The bed and duvet was comfortable too. For the rest of my stay, i had to trouble the guest relations with more restaurant reservations which they obliged every time. Their service was efficient and great.I also enjoyed access to the lounge, which was really nice - good beer and snacks and a great view of Tokyo city! Amd the location of the hotel was amazing. It was right smack in Shinjuku (which was super convenient and central) but it was tucked away at a quieter corner. So, guests can enjoy being in the centre of the city but with some peace.My only grouse is with the lifts which don't show how long it'd take to arrive at my level or where they are at. I later realised that this seems to be the same situation for many lifts in Tokyo. Just a tiny blemish on an otherwise perfect stay.

This hotel is prestigious, accessible and very luxurious.We did not understand that our booking included the Club Lounge.Staff were very helpful at all times. Tokyo is apparently notorious for the bad wi-fi and I don't like to spend travelling time on the internet anyway.Thank you for a lovely stay!

Real clean, good food, unfortunally few english Speaking person. Easy to' walk, near jr station.People very Clever, sympatic and efficient . Good location for business, family and Friends. Good for services and turist accomodation.

This is a business hotel but with a strong focus on client satisfaction. Japan is not the cheapest location to visit, so we were happy that breakfast was included. We are at two of the restaurants for authentic Japanese and teppanyaki experience and were not disappointed, even though they were the most expensive meals of our trip so far.
user_name:
Satpal D
Leamington Spa, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed for 8 days. Room and breakfasts were great. We paid extra to have use of the pool and club lounge. Don't even bother going up to the pool if you want to swim laps as it's impossible. Regarding the lounge probably the worst we have ever been to. Only beer and wine Sat and Sunday. However scotch Mon- Friday. Go figure?? The canapés if you can call them that were boring and the same 8 nights in a row. The staff in the club lounge were also very unfriendly and don't seem to like cleaning up after people.

After paying so much for a room per night they have the audacity to charge you the equivalent of SGD20 per person to swim in the pool as a staying guest! This is just greed. My husband and I took our toddler excitedly down for swim only to find out we had to pay equivalent to SGD40. When I complained to the manager as it is not stated when booking or upon checking in, he could not have cared any less. For the price you can do much better, stay somewhere else please!!!!

The hotel is a busy standard hotel, a bit outdated in its style. Rooms are comfortable although small as always in Tokyo. But a basic amenity like WiFi kept breaking down on 17th AND 33rd floors. I and my kids needed to re-log all the time. and if you choose this hotel for the swimming pool, note that it is NOT free of charge. No less than 2000 yens, even for teenagers. so 10000 yens for a family of 5, non negotiable ;-(

I should start with the positives. Keio Plaza is ideally located in Shinjuku with great access to shops, restaurants, rail stations and the entertainment options Shinjuku is famous for, including the Golden Gai bars. The quality of the rooms are good, the staff are generally very helpful and they did a wonderful job of checking in a group of 29 of us quickly and painlessly.There were a number of other things that missed the mark.The foyer and reception area lacks any welcoming feel with very limited seating and no clear meeting point for guests. It has a very small gymnasium which is surprising for a hotel of this size and you have to pay extra to use the pool.While some of the above are possibly difficult to change, it was things that should have been done better that were the greatest concerns. Level 45 is where they have a well known bar and restaurant facilities and this was closed for renovation. Fair enough. The problem was there was no real attempt to provide good alternatives and one of the hotel staff on the first night actually directed us to level 45 for a drink.In the cocktail and tea bar off the lobby, the only real alternative it was very nicely set up but frustrating that so many of the staff were slow to attend to taking orders.A large group conference came to the hotel while we were there and this caused serious problems which should have been much better handled and communicated. For some reason it was felt necessary to have them in the South Tower which already had a lift out of service and then another one dedicated to the conference at peak times of the day.
