A grand hotel set in the Japanese tradition of grandness.New and old wings connected at a large lobby. Reception is also large with many people checking in. Members' check in area on the right.Since last visit, the rooms have been renovated. And given the short walk through a narrow street to Shinjuku eki, there are numerous bars and stand up joints to try. Most notably the standup 100Yen sushi place.

Location wise it is better than the Hyatt Regency which is still 2 blocks further away from Shinjuku Station. There is a covered walkway from the rear entrance of the hotel below the lobby directly to the Station (Shinjuku West). East is where all the action is but no good family hotels there. If you are travelling with kids, make sure you book the Disney Shuttle on the day you arrive since they go full days in advance. We booked the Premier room for 3 Adults which had 3 large twin beds perfect for 2adults, our 11 year old and our 5 year old. Their convenience store is very well stocked and same prices as 7 eleven. Make sure you carry a pocket Wifi everywhere. Getting around on your own can be difficult. Tons of breakfast options outside the hotel near Kogaikun university. 2 mins walk. Our personal fav was Pronto.

Check-in is fast and efficient. The staff are all extremely polite, friendly and always smiling. I felt very welcome the moment I walked in.The hotel's location is quite good and within walking distance to train station and shopping malls. Popular departmental stores and brands like Daimaru, Uniqlo, Muji, BiC Cameras, Daiso are very accessible. If you know how to walk correctly for 8 mins, you are 90% sheltered even if it rains.Rooms in the hotels are spacious but very warm. Not sure why but my parents room next door are also the same. Not sure whether they centralise the air con temperature because it's still warm even when you set the temperature to 18 degrees. This made me a bit disappointed.The shampoo, conditioner and body soap are from Pola and smells nice. Rooms are very clean and we like the dressing corner where there is a separate hair dryer and a mirror. Good design.Power points are adequate and I do appreciate the multi charger that they provided by the bedside. Wifi signal is extremely strong and stable at the lobby using the guest password, that's awesome!!! Unfortunately I don't get the same experience in the guest rooms. All rooms have their own username and password and you have to manually log in again every day which is very troublesome. Speed is also not as fast.Breakfast is above average. Have tried better so nothing to shout about. Massage can also be arranged in the room at 7100yen for an hour. My wife tried and she says her middle aged female therapist is very good. As the room key cards are personalized and printed with your room numbers, please do not lose it as a 1000yen penalty charge will be imposed for lost key cards. I'm pretty sure other hotels will be unlikely to make you pay for it, In the hotel there is a 7 eleven just opposite and a Family Mart just next door. There is also cigarette and drinks vending machine, ice maker, money changer machine, post box so it's really convenient!All in all I enjoyed my stay and would look forward to coming back. At certain peak periods of the year, the room rates are very high and will not be worth staying. It's always good to book early as I think this hotel is very popular even dates for Dec 2016 is mostly full.

It certainly looks like a grand old hotel; plenty of bling on show and staff standing around, but what it gains in appearances it lacks in customer service / personalised service. Our room on the club floor was bigger and the Club facilities OK, but had far better and more on offer in other 4-5 star hotels. Staff were often a little standoffish and didn't exude a 'welcoming' air.It felt imposing, cold and anonymous all at the same time.

Sometimes it is difficult to find a non-smoking restaurant. I find it sickening to eat food while inhaling second hand smoke. The Keio hotel has a morning buffet that is reasonably priced at 3000 yen per person. The service and quality of food are very good.

Location is very tourist friendly. From Haneda or Narita, it a drop off point to the airport bus limousine which is an economical way to go to your hotel. The hotel is also less than a kilometer walk from the Shijuku station thru a road filled with shops and restaurants. Also a pick up point for several Tokyo tour. You'll need an entire day just to shop and eat around the hotel

The Keio Plaza Hotel was wonderful! We stayed for three nights and could not have asked for better service or amenities. The staff were all very gracious and helpful. We fly standby and had to check out a day early... We did not make our plane and called them at 12:30 am to see if we could check back in. They let come back and gave us the same room. No questions asked!!! I am fairly well traveled and the service in this hotel is top notch. It is also conveniently located to train station. I will stay here again and will recommend to friends.

The overall experience was good especially for my 3 year old who had sufficient space to run about within the room. We stayed on the 31st floor newly renovated superior room. The hotel staff even offered the bed guard for my kid when I expressed concern that she may fall from the bed.The perks were that the hotel location was one of the drop off points for the airport limousine bus and the hotel also provided free shuttle service to disneyland. Everything was hassle free and hotel concierge even helped to keep our luggage and courier to the airport even after we have checked out of the hotel(note: we were moving off to another area before flying).The only con was that the mattresses were quite thin and gave me back ache.

Already the second (or third) time stayed in this hotel. Stayed 6 nightsLocation, Room size, surroundings all above average.The house keeping varies by day, on "good days" the room is neat and tidy but on "bad days" you can have unclean cups, toothbrush just directly placed on counter (I'm a pretentious clean freak, I usually will reuse the toothbrush and put them inside the cup). "Unidentify dirt" on a supposedly new/clean bed sheets. The one thing I am not too happy about this stay is when I checked-in, they have me waited for 40 mins+ before I can get my room (it was around 4p.m. already, not that I arrive early). But their super straight regulation decline my request to check out at 11:30 (check out time is 11:00).

My overall experience in the Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo was very positive. The rooms were comfortable and the staff were extremely helpful and professional. The food in the hotel restaurants and the breakfast buffet was also superb. The biggest problem I had with the hotel is the Wi-Fi connection. I honestly have never experienced a worse connection. I am unsure whether this was due to the location of our room (near the top floor), but the internet would cut out every 20 seconds or so. Over a period of 8 days at the Keio Plaza Hotel, I never had a stable connection lasting more than 15 minutes, which was extremely disappointing and something I was not expecting from any hotel in Tokyo. However, overall it was an extremely positive experience. I would definitely return as the quality and standard of the service was exceptional. Location is great, with Shinjuku Station (one of Tokyo's main stations) in walking distance (ca. 10 mins).

Had a fabulous 3 nights at the Keio Plaza. The hotel is well located within easy walking distance of three metro stations and a short walk to a bustling night-life area with stacks of restaurant. Eating in the hotel is expensive so I'd suggest going out (except for breakfast - the included brekky is great, and 3 to choose from). The room was spacious, bed comfortable and scrupulously clean. I had, what I assume was, a 'standard' room, but it was spacious and had everything you could possibly need, and a magic view to the Tokyo Metropolitan building across the way. Room was properly serviced daily with fresh towels, complimentary water and consumables. If I was to be really picky, it would have been nice to have a better choice of TV channels. Service was impeccable and individual staff members super helpful. Could not fault it.

Be warned, if you arrive at Shinjuku station, this is not the easiest place to find. Not because of the hotel location, but because of the station. Just keep following the signs either for the hotel of the Government Offices Building and you will find it. And what a delight when you do. This is a very grand place with an enormous foyer in marble. There were plenty of staff on reception so the wait to book in, even at opening time of three in the afternoon, was not too long. As you learn to expect from the Japanese, they are polite and efficient. The room we had was enormous with floor to ceiling windows out onto the Tokyo skyline. The two double beds were slightly hard, but made with crisp sheeting, the bathroom also large with every thing you could ever need (and their toiletries are very very good),your yukata is supplied along with a fluffy bath robe. There are various eatieries (all a bit pricey) but breakfast is plentiful and varied (scrambled eggs to die for), but also try to find the mini supermarket there for extra supplies (in the basement). A totally delightful way to start a holiday in Japan.

This hotel has everything including several types of restaurants, a convenience store, function rooms and an inviting breakfast buffet. It is better to allow a little extra time for breakfast on weekdays if you are on a schedule as it gets quite busy as business people depart. There is also an omelette station. The rooms are comfortable with complimentary toiletries and good pressure on the hot water. There is a fridge in the room and the hotel is walking distance to local restaurants and convenience stores as well as the subway. It is, however, a fair way out of Tokyo city.

The hotel is well located and staff are excellent.Everything a tourist needs such as facilities, restaurants, close to public transport and shops and tours organised efficiently in a huge lobby area.Buffet breakfast was 10 out of 10The only complaint is we booked non smoking rooms but were put in smoking rooms.The girl at reception firstly told us we had made no request which was incorrect and after showing our booking confirmation for non smoking rooms she told us it was only a request.The room didn't smell all that bad I must say but the floor corridors and lift area smelt strongly of smoke.If this is a big issue for anyone when travelling my suggestion is book elsewhere as we didn't get what we booked, confirmed and paid for.Apart from this I would highly recommend this hotel as a place to stay if visiting Tokyo on holidays

We stayed there in June 2013 after our visit from Tokyo Disney. The hotel provided free shuttle bus to and from Disney. It was an big old classic hotel. The room was large and expensive in Shinjuku area. If you walk 300m from the hotel back which lead you to JR Shinjuku station, you will find nice alleys which full of small nice restaurants and shops. Ramens and sushi were nice with reasonable prices. I bought my camera there which was much cheaper than ones sold at big electronic stores closed by. There were also shops selling used cameras.

My husband and I, as well as my parents, stayed here on our first trip to Tokyo. My parents had booked a cheaper room than ours, but I thought that theirs was nicer and more modern. Our room was high up in the main tower, had an impressive view, and was spacious and more than adequate, but I didn't care for the decor at all, nor did I think that the beds were all that comfortable.We had breakfast at the buffet every morning, and I will go back for that food even if I don't stay there again. The variety was fantastic and everything was amazing.Of course, the other high point of this hotel is the location, just a few blocks from Shinjuku station and the Keio Mall, and it's only a couple more blocks to the Shinjuku Garden.I don't think you can really go wrong with this hotel, but there are probably some perfectly nice alternatives that aren't quite as pricey.

Both the hotel itself and room size are quite big by Japan standards. Nice to have that extra space in the room, especially if one has kids, as opposed to most other cramped hotel rooms in Japan. Agree with many reviewers here that the lobby is almost always very busy, and moreso the reception area. Very nice to have a convenience store in the basement that has mostly everything you need, and at regular prices as well. One of the most talked about aspects of Keio is the breakfast. If you have a breakfast coupon, you can choose from among 3 restaurants - Jurin, Glass Court and Kagari. Jurin is mainly continental with a bit of local viands and rice/miso, good selection and longer hours. Glass Court is called the "super buffet" since it has a huge selection even for breakfast (chicken, salmon, veggies, pancakes, waffles, congee, rice, bacon, eggs, etc etc), but the lines are always long at the entrance after 7am. Kagari offers a Japanese set menu for breakfast, and the ambience is a bit gloomy, hard to start the day that way.Location wise, the hotel is average. Getting from your room to any of the hotel entrances/exits will take a bit of time already because the hotel is big, then getting to the main Shinjuku station is another 10-15mins depending on your pace. And the Shinjuku station itself is big so after a long day of walking, all those steps add up. There's Tochomae station just 5 mins away from the hotel entrance but the lines there are much more limited than the Shinjuku station where JR and subway are all converged. Lots of food choices though just steps away from all entrances of the hotel, best bet is to explore and choose. For shoppers, the bulk of Shinjuku shopping is approximately 15 minutes away on foot, but once you get there, there are so many options to choose from.Hotel staff were generally friendly and helpful and cheerful, and that is a big plus especially knowing that they do not accept tips and do their service willingly. Free internet, no handling fees for packages in or out as well.Overall, above average hotel considering all factors.

We stayed in this hotel during our first trip in Japan. Location is good, since it is located in Shinjuku, hence we had an easy access to the train station. Several tours offered by different agencies designates this hotel as a meet-up point, so its really convenient if you'll just have to go down to the lobby to meet them. They also have free shuttle service to Disneyland. What I didn't like about the hotel: Although it is near the Shinjuku station, there's nothing much to do around here, especially at night. Unlike in Asakusa or Ueno area where you can just walk around and find a couple of restaurants/foodshops should you need a grub in the middle of the night.

Dinner included as part of a tour. Presentation excellent and we were spoilt for choice. Massive selection of Japanese dishes as you would expect but we enjoyed roast beef and gravy!,roast potatoes and a delicious selection of vegetables. There was also cheese and home made breads. A welcome change for a Japanese tired palat. This restaurant served a good selection of wine and compared to other places we had visited more reasonably priced although still expensive.

This was our first time in Japan and the location does not get any better than this. The views were great but Tokyo is also a very expensive city for the location you pay premium price and rooms are a lot smaller than what one may be used to. But most trains come to the area so moving around Tokyo from this location was a breeze and there is a lot going on around the area. Service was average nothing special par say, food super pricey in hotel, definitely go out to eat as there are many choices and for the western traveler, quite a few Starbucks. For the location and considering the city I would say the price was fair.

Since this is our first time to visit Japan, my husband and I wanted to stay at a hotel where we can easily go around the area, have decent choices of restaurants, easy access to/from the airport and a place where we can join local tours with ease. Keio Plaza Hotel did not disappoint. From the time we arrived at the airport in Haneda, we took the Airport Limousine Bus and it dropped us off at the actual hotel. No need to walk and haul your suitcase to another destination. Then check in was a breeze, got escorted to our room. The staff showed us all the amenities of the room. I liked the part when she showed us the fire exit next door before even entering the room. Found this information worth knowing after experiencing a magnitude 5.6 earthquake on our 2nd night. The hotel is just 5 minutes away from the Shinjuku station. If you are a Starbucks fan, you will pass by one store on your way to the station. We had breakfast at the hotel every morning,were given 3 options as to which restaurant to have breakfast. We picked the Glass Door as the food is more pleasing to the eyes. I think there's more selection than Jurin. And the staff at the Glass Door is more attentive to clear your plates. The room itself is a good size, the bed comfortable. There is a Nespresso machine in our room, the water has a good pressure and easy to get hot water on the shower. Closet size is big for both of us. We got a room that has a fabulous view of the Metropolitan Government building and Mt. Fuji (if she decides to show up). All in all, we are happy with our 5D/4N stay in this hotel. Will definitely choose this hotel again when we;re back in Tokyo.

We stayed for four nights at the start of May. The hotel staff were very polite and the room was more spacious than anticipated. Had a stunning view on 27th floor - only downside for us was the smell of smoke in the room. Location of hotel is the bestselling point as you can get everywhere from Shinjuku train station which is only a few minutes from the hotel. Free wifi was also included.Great hotel to stay for a few nights to get to know the city, will stay again but ask for no smoking room.

Arrived on an early morning flight to be greeted with the news that check-in was 14:00 (understandable), there were however no changing or shower facilities - after a 12 hour flight waiting from 08:00 to 14:00 when you are jet lagged is hard work when there are no facilities and the staff are hugely polite but hugely unhelpful and do not seem minded to support in any way.Hotel is functional, clean but trapped in the 80's - perfect if you just need to use a hotel as a crash pad without any other expectation.

Located in the Shinjuku business district, but just next to the interesting small streets selling cheap goods and offering great local food, and just a few minutes walk from the main Shinjuku train station, this is an interesting place to stay. The hotel has very few public meetings areas, just a few couches in the open lobby area, but the Excelsior cafe across the road does great coffees!Rooms look a bit old fashioned but are comfortable and well equipped (but no body lotion). there is a kettle and small cups with green tea provided. So take a mug and some instant coffee if you want to keep your caffeine levels up. There is a good fridge and 2 bottles of complimentary water per day. The air conditioning works well and it's very quiet. There are great views over the city, particularly from the meeting floors and bars on the 45th floor. Breakfast was a bit of scramble as we were at conference with everyone eating at the same time and it wasn't that good a selection for a western buffet. We ate at the sushi restaurant, which was completely amazing. Personal chef prepared eight pieces for us. Wonderful attention to detail and managing different dietary preferences (no wasabi for me!). The hotel also has a Little Kitty floor, but none of us explored that!

The staff was just wonderful. Very friendly, helpful and accommodating. The location is very close to restaurants, shopping, and transportation. The rooms were a lot more spacious than I expected. Very neat and clean. The coffee in the room was very good! Great breakfast buffet in the Glass Court . We would definitely stay here again.

This hotel provides what you need and more. Rooms include: toothbrushes and paste, hairbrush, cotton pads, hairband, slippers, razor, shampoo, conditioner and cotton buds. This is all especially handy if you are a short stay or it's at the end of your holiday.The shop downstairs sells lots of essentials at normal shop prices. Breakfast is varied and plentiful and will keep you going during the day. The pool is only open in peak summer.

Stay: May 19-22, 2016This was my 2nd time in Tokyo. Our last hotel (Century Southern Tower hotel) was better overall, but the main advantage of staying in Keio Plaza was the location & ease of access. Easily accessible to train stations and around 5 minutes away to Shinjuku station, the hotel's location made it extremely easy to get around. Besides that, the hotel is surrounded by restaurants, convenience stores, and little shops that are always interesting to explore. A few minutes of walking will also take you to the huge Keio department store, Odakyu, the Takashimaya area, Tokyu hands, etc. ROOM: +The room itself was quite large, although we were able to stay on the luxe lounge floor. I don't know what the rooms on the other floors were like, but I think most are fairly spacious (based on feedback from others in our group). We also had a large window overlooking part of the city. +Had free wifi and basic amenities +Quiet; we couldn't hear any traffic or noise (though we were on the 34th floor)-Not very clean. The tablecloth (which they did not replace during our stay) had some stains on them, and the carpet felt dusty (which is what you would normally expect from hotels that have been around for quite a while). -Cleaning service was not very clean; they tended to leave used cups and other things even after they had been in. -Lighting a bit dark; everything tended to look quite gloomy in the room, especially at night. FOOD: +lots of variety for breakfast, lunch, and dinner within the hotel as well as areas in the vicinity -limited seating; absurdly long lines to get into the Japanese restaurant for breakfast.Since we were often in a rush we ended up eating Western breakfasts for most of our stay since there was no line getting in most days. OVERALL SERVICE: +Those at the front desk were very kind and helpful, and they had a lot of maps available that were definitely helpful. +Easy arrangements with transportation to and from the airport -Check in was too late (4 PM), and check-out too early in my opinion (11 PM)Overall, for me it was an average place to stay in; perhaps good for short business stays due to location and access to things like internet, etc. For family/leisure stays, it could be better.https://www.tripadvisor.com.ph/ShowUserReviews-g1066457-d304305-r375654815-Keio_Plaza_Hotel_Tokyo-Shinjuku_Tokyo_Tokyo_Prefecture_Kanto.html#

We stayed here for 5 days and it was a wonderful stay.It was well situated and there is a free bus service to and from the train station which runs regularly.The rooms were lovely and very clean and the staff very helpful.We would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
Jacqui C
Kurrajong, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Food excellent at RestaurantsRooms Good Service good but by the book. No exceptionsLate checkouts are chargeable.Breakfast always the same menu no variations throughout my stay of 7 days.Checkin by always a queueCheckout also always a long queue.Improvement needed in service standards

great buffet selections during breakfast, there is korean, chinese, japanese food available in this hotel, and nearby mitsui also has lots of restaurantsbreakfast buffet is highly recommended in 3 restaurants, jurin, glasscourtfree wifi in this hotel, room needs better cleaning thoughtoilet has a ramp and faucet sink is a little tough to use

We experienced a wonderful tea ceremony at the Keio Plaza Hotel - our tea master was Michiko Yano. It was a highlight of our trip to Tokyo. The tea room has a traditional tatami room and another version with chairs for those that can't sit comfortably on the floor. Michiko guided us through the ritual, from the washing of our hands, through the drinking of the tea and the clearing of the utensils with a rare grace and beauty. The calm, yet precise way that she moved was like a living work of art. Yet she made us comfortable, smiling and letting us know it as ok to relax and enjoy the experience. I would highly recommend the tea ceremony at the Keio with Michiko to anyone. It was a stillness of time I'll never forget.

Our family stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel in middle of April. The staff were polite and helpful. The hotel is located quite close to the JR line and subway lines. This was convenient as we were travelling with 2 children aged 9 and 5. The hotel also has a gym which was in good condition and weights and various cardio machines. The hotel was also located close to restaurants. There is a shuttle service from the hotel to Disneyland. Though one needs to book this well in advance. The hotel is also located across the street from a government building that has free access to the top floors for sightseeing. Overall I would recommend this hotel for families.

The first night they tried to put us in an old, smoking room. I refused and was given an ok room that was non smoking. We left for two days to go to Disney and they assured us we would have a better room when we returned. Sunday night when we returned we were put in a room that was so old and nasty that I could not believe it. Maybe rated a 2 on the scale. Next morning I tried to find another hotel but they were all booked. I decided to give it one more try. I told the desk that the carpet was so worn out the thread was showing the mattress had to be 20 years old, spots all over carpet and walls where dirty. I just could not take it as we were staying 10 days. I was finally give a refurbished room in the south tower that was quite nice and would be rated a 4. I think Tripadvisor needs to check out all rooms before giving a rating of 4. Not a great start but nice people that work here.

Spent four lovely nights at this hotel as part of a group of about 50. The hotel is a quality facility, across from City Hall, and a short walk from a shopping area. A little longer walk takes you to Shinjuku station, with a broader array of shops (Yuzawaya and Tokyu Hands) and one of the main subway terminals.Some of the elevators were down when we were there, so I pulled back a star for that. The restaurant buffet was good, and the staff throughout the hotel were very helpful.The wifi is free, but you have to sign in every day.This hotel has a Hello Kitty suite, and I was able to catch the bus to my Viator tour to Mt. Fuji right in the main hotel lobby!

Very large, crowded and old hotel. Rooms need to be refurbished. Staff are very friendly and extremely helpful. Location is good and 5minutes walking distance to Shinjiku station. Breakfast was good. Wifi is very week and not available in many areas. Many guests were complaining about the week wifi!

Keio Plaza is well located near Shinjuku Station, just a short 5 mins walk. If you are coming in from either Haneda or Narita airport, the airport bus stops in front of the hotel, very convenient. For Japan standard, the rooms are well appointed and comfortable sized. Our children slept in their 3 bedded room in the South wing, their room was large and can accommodate 3 persons comfortably. Keio Plaza is not a cheap hotel, but given their location and well appointed rooms and facilities, it's highly recommended .

I only chose this hotel because my in-laws who are flying in to Tokyo to meet our 8 month old son for the first time heard great things about this hotel from their neighbor. Obviously that person didn't stay where we are staying, which is a standard twin room. I usually do extensive research before I choose a hotel, especially now with a baby, but since my in-laws already decided that this is where they want to stay, I booked it reading only a handful reviews (all say clean, comfortable, spacious, great location or something along that line).Clean ? I found a pubic hair on a foot towel and trash underneath the bed. Enough said.Spacious ? Not if you book a ‘standard’ room.Comfortable ? Not if you are a non-smoker with an 8 month old baby and they put you in a smoking room.Location ? I guess so.After booking, I found out that this is like a buffet of a hotel – it is gigantic and has hello kitty rooms to fully renovated rooms and not so renovated rooms like the one we are staying right now (yes, I’m here right now as I type this review).Long story short, I knew we would be staying a smaller/outdated room. I knew that plenty from my research. A pubic hair on a foot towel or trash underneath the bed don’t really upset me (okay, maybe the pubic hair). I’m upset because they put me in a smoking room, knowing that I’ve asked for a crib or a bed guard for my baby. They asked if I asked for a non-smoking room. I don’t know what the procedure is but I also didn’t ask for a smoking room but what I did ask was a crib…A BABY CRIB. They say they will try to switch our room today as the hotel is 108%(?) fully occupied. Also earlier party asked to switch their room for the same baby reason so they didn’t have any more non-smoking room. So I’m not the only crazy one who wants a non-smoking room for a baby.The room and the entire floor reeks!!!!! I can’t wait to get out!

This is a very nice hotel with comfortable rooms and the service is what you would expect from Japan. Well worth the visit but bring lots of money as the food and room cost is expensive. Room service is very high and the amount of food for a westerner is way too little. The lounge is also not up to par with only nuts and drinks being served. In most other hotels of this caliber usually an attempt is made at a light hot meal for those who are tired of heading out to the usual restaurant experience. If you don't mind leaving the hotel for something to eat this hotel is nice. A reasonable room will run you around $300 us per night.

Stayed here as part of a business trip and the room was spotlessly clean. Received an upgrade to a deluxe room and I think it was perhaps bigger than the regular room with a dressing area and sort of a 'mini lobby entrance' which gives some privacy to the 'bedroom'. Breakfast which was included was not great but I'm unsure whether we were given some 'special breakfast' area which was perhaps for business people which was quieter but not much selections beyond some cooked bits. On the last day I realised where everyone else was having breakfast (in the basement) and it looked much bigger with probably a greater choice of western and eastern breakfast. This was disappointing.

Centrally located in Shinjuku near the station. Many things in the area within a 5-7 minute walk. A good Lawson is across the street to get drinks & snacks if needed. Hotel is slightly above average but the location makes up for it. I've stayed at Hilton & Hyatt, those hotels are nicer but the location of Keio Plaza is superior.

Hotel is large, has two towers, some walking distance inside the hotel building (for example, restaurants are in one build while room in another tower).The hotel and room are clean. Staff are courteous. Hotel is well located by the main train station and by the shopping center. One thing though, during the dinner time, the lobby is crowed - too many tour groups try to congregate to go out for dinner.

I have spent part of my honeymoon here. This hotel is in a great location, next to Shinjuku station. All the staff is very helpful, and there is an excellent breakfast.However, the small downpoint is that the rooms a bit worn and outdated, even if with a great view!The place is good, but very expensive! Maybe too much for what it offers, as it does not have a great charme

We prefer a much smaller hotel, this hotel is like a small city. But somehow it worked.We had a wonderful room, the staff was always helpful, the restaurant, though expensive had a nice range of choices.Our room was spotless.The location was excellent for transportation and for the neighborhood.

Short walk from Shinjuku station. So about 90 minutes from Narita if you take the NEX train. Tall high-rise. Nicely decorated. Rooms are plain but clean. Good service but staff seems to have limited English speaking capabilities. Have stayed there twice.

Many people especially tourist in the morning. Not enough seats for guests to wait because of the tourists - noisy as wellBreakfast - American - nice quiet place to eat and discuss ROom -love it and the bed. TV cable- not too many shows to select. this hotelShould improve this Im stuck to CNN english. cater to your english speaking friends tooBAthroom - great and very cleanELevator - long waiting Location - good- 3 to 5 min walk to the center

Stayed here for 4 nights with wife and 4 year old daughter .LOCATIONThe location of this hotel is 6 on 5 . located very close to shinjuku metro station and only 200 metres from tochomae metro station (1 stop before shinjuku metro station ) . Behind the hotel there are so many eating joints , cafe , bars etc etc and you can easily walk to the main shinjuku central area .the airport limousine offers direct transfer to the keio plaza hotel and takes about 2 hours from narita international airport .HOTEL OFFERS FREE DISNEYLAND /DISNEY SEA TRANSFERS DEPARTING 4-5 TIMES A DAY .basement of hotel has lots of restaurants and even a convenience store to buy general stuff ( alcohol , cigarettes , snacks etc ) at regular price .No need to pay for the in room mini bar :-)Staff is very attentive and cheerful . they will help you as much as they can .PLAZA LUXE DOUBLE ROOMafter paying almost 400 usd , this room was the biggest disappointment . small and the queen bed was too too small for a tall person like me , also we were 2 + 1 and i asked hotel if they could provide and extra bed even with charges , they said they cant as its a club room and no provisions for an extra bed . so imagine 3 ppl trying to sleep on a small bed for four nights . even the bath room was quite small and shower area/bath tub congested .club room comes with free club lounge use and you can have evening drinks etc but for such a massive hotel i found the lounge to be very small and even the snacks offered there were not good .stale cakes /patties and very little variety . please try some other room category . no point in booking this expensive club room .

We stayed in the main tower of this hotel (also has a south tower) for 3 nights as part of a Nexus group tour. Room was very clean and tidy with comfortable firm beds, good air conditioning, Wi-Fi, TV channel selections. The bathroom was a good size with very good water pressure for both hot & cold from the shower. Quality toiletries were provided. Buffet breakfast in the Jurin restaurant provided a very good selection of food. There are 11 restaurants in the hotel including French/Korean/Chinese as well as 7 bar/lounge areas. The hotel is a short walk from Shinjuku railway station and Post Office. The streets near the hotel have shops selling electronic goods, cameras etc., restaurants and entertainment venues like karaoke and come alive at night with plenty of people. There are also 2 large department stores near the railway station. All staff encountered during our stay were very friendly and polite. A special thank to the staff at the guest relations desk who assisted me in trying to locate a hobby store that had stock of the Hot Wheels Japan Classic series of die cast cars.

The last of three hotels we stayed at in Japan and the best of the trip. We had a lovely refurbished room on one of the higher levels with great view. Immaculately clean and a very sizable room, could not fault the service, staff or room. Would stay again for sure!

We booked this hotel at a discounted rate. One of the largest room we have stayed in Japan after over 15 visits to the country. Comfortable, large room, clean, and location is excellent just 5 mins walk to the station. Airport shuttle is vey convenient. The service is excellent. Bell service is 10/10, very well trained. They insist to take luggages for us up to our room even if we wanted to take it ourselves. Bell capital Mikiko Inahashi is extremely helpful in helping us to send and receive commercial parcels for our business, and voluntarily track down a missing parcel for us even it has nothing to do with the hotel. He chased it and make sure it arrives before we depart to airport. He did all these behind he scene without bordering us at all and with hundred and thousands of first everyday, they remember our faces. Helped us when we need it and did not take a single tips for the work he did for us. I cannot thank him enough. The world is a better place with man like him, worth recognition. For the housekeeping, excellent service, remember our requests, and kept the room tidy for us. Excellent! They have also helped to track down and find a headphone that we left under the bed and managed to send it back to us. Excellent service! How can anyone complain?? I really appreciate the service we received and the renovated tower is very comfortable. Will certainly return! Your hotel should be very proud!

this high rising hotel is superbly located in shinjuku, very close to multi transportation options shinjuku station, and walking distance from kabukicho entertainment quarter. many restaurants to choose from, very good and efficient service.

After reading reviews, I found this hotel quite surprising actually. Bell boys were very attentive in noticing you coming through and offering to help with your luggages. The front desk staff took a little longer in checking us in but that could have been attributed to the language barrier. Rooms were very clean and tidy, albeit a little small. Sufficient room to hold your luggages but not much room for anything else. The beds, I found, were quite hard and made it a little frustrating to sleep on but that's just preference. The washrooms have the toilets that have the Japanese options of flushing and bidet washing - quite cool for first timers. Washroom was also quite small but manageable. The view in the room was also pretty nice, gave a really good view of the sunrise. Location was spot on - very close to shinjuku station. Around the hotel's area are lots of restaurants and shopping malls that were very convenient to get to. The only disappointing thing was that there were no amenities (ex/ pool, gym, etc.) - perhaps it's a Japanese thing?

Travelling on business, stayed in a standard room, which was on a smoking floor in the main building - as soon as you get out of the elevator the cigarette smell follows you everywhere, even the pillows are soaked in smoke. For a gigantic hotel like this one I was told they had no free non-smoking rooms to move me to. One night decided to try the room service - poor selection, but what you get is the worst part - be prepared for very small portions despite the high prices. There are some pictures in the menu - totally misleading! There were two options of beef steak at the same price but with different type of sauce. I ordered the one that was not on the picture and what I got was literally two pieces the size of a small meatball each, no fries and some decoration made of pumpkin I think. I had to return it, I am not charging my company for a joke of a main course!

Can't check in before 2PM even if room is ready. Rooms in South Towers are nicer but amenities are better in main tower (Occitane products, in-room coffee machine). I do not know why they use different products. Reception desk is useless. I will not come back to this hotel.

Stayed for 1 week in the south tower which has been recently renovated. Spacious rooms by any standard (even moreso for Tokyo).Busy lobby but very friendly and helpful staff.Conveniently located near shinjuku station for your travel needs. Plenty of local restaurants and shops if you don't want to venture far. You can stay on shinjuku west for a nice dinner or venture to the east side for late night bars and clubs. Offers free shuttle service to Disney resort which is a plus. Also fairly priced door to door shuttle service to haneda and narita airports.If it's in your price range, i would recommend staying at keio plaza for a comfortable Holiday in Tokyo

Main Tower with good view；Friendly staff with smiles and swift services；Easy for shopping and eating nearby；Comfortable room with hot and powerful water supply for bathing together with safe provided indoor.

Found the entrance impressive, but long lines by the check in counter.Room was priced as 5 star, but was really a 3 star at the most.Outdated and nothing including the in-room coffee maker didn.'t'work as it should be.Housekeeping staff tried to be helpful, but didn;t understand a word we said.

I was told that portions of the Keio Plaza were built in the 1970's, and was one of the first of the big hotels in Shinjuku. We stayed in the newer tower on one of the upper floors. This gave us breakfast privileges in the Crystal dining room (nice) and a few other minor perks. The whole hotel has apparently been recently updated and is an active place, well staffed and user friendly. It's location is good, being close to the Keio rail station which, after you figure it out, can take you anywhere. (It took us about 3 days of use to do that!)Our room was large by Japanese standard, well equipped with various gizmos, quiet and spit spot clean. A good choice for your Tokyo visit.

The hotel is really impressive from when you first enter the lobby with stunning crystal chandeliers. The rooms are excellent with the very best complimentary toiletries (L'Occitane) really good power shower and everything spotless. Breakfast buffet is amazing - I am still slightly puzzled by the food other nationalities will eat at an early hour! Really good choice and impeccable service.

Keio hotel has very nice location near the train stations, restaurants, convenience stores, and some shops. They also has free shuttle to and from tokyo disneyland and tokyo disney sea. Straight shuttle to and from narita or haneda airport. The room is clean but very small.

Lobbed in to Tokyo for five nights. Great hotel about ten minutes walk from Shinjuku station. Everything you need, helpful staff and great breakfast buffet. Runs a shuttle to Disney for free if you want that. Rooms were of a great size. They had a free afternoon tea time with drinks and nibbles also. Highly recommend!

Have just spent 3 nights in this fabulous hotel. Room was spacious, comfortable, clean. Staff very helpful, extremely polite, always there to assist no matter what your enquiry. Breakfast venue and restaurants were excellent with staff there to meet your every request and need, service at dinner restaurants were "the best". A huge congratulations to all staff members from laundry right through to 45th floor. This Hotel is so central, easy to find your way around Tokyo district. Highly recommend and would definitely return.

Was given a free upgrade and had a choice to choose smoking or non smoking room despite Agoda booking seem to have difference with prices for smoking or non smoking room. They are extra considerate as we travelling with two young kids.. Room is spacious and comfortable.. Locations is superb and its walking distance to Shinjyuku JR Line and Tochomae Oedo Line. Lotsa shopping around and i am in love of the street stall right across the hotel. Will come back again.

We stayed at this hotel for 4 days last month and were very impressed . The location to Shinjuku station is very convenient , the staff are polite and helpful , the rooms are tastefully furnished , the breakfasts are to die for and all the hotel facilities are first class . We found it simply the best value for money accommodation in central Tokyo .

Our first visit to Japan. We stayed at the Keio Plaza in Shinjukufor 5 days after a 2 week cruise on the Diamond Princess. The hotel was superb. Our room was very comfortable and surprisingly spacious, despite friends' warning that Tokyo's rooms are usually tiny. The free wi-fi was very useful and fast. The hotel is adjacent to the Oedo subway line and the Shinjuku train station. Even as "newbies" to Tokyo we had no problem in using the trains and subways unescorted. Lots of friendly English speaking railway staff happy to help and point us in the right direction. However do avoid the morning rush hour, but evening rush hour was a lot less crowded. The hotel has a very useful convenience store on site. There are a variety of international restaurants, our favourite was the Korean offering. We thought that the restaurants were a bit on the expensive side though but there are a good number of more affordable restaurants in the building across the street from the hotel's rear entrance. We didn't take breakfast in the hotel as we thought 3000 Yen was a bit too expensive for us. Try and get a package that includes breakfast as these are available. Overall we had a very enjoyable stay with great service from the very friendly and helpful staff.

Very spacious rooms even by Japanese standards. Everything needed was in the room. Cleaned exceptionally well every day. Restaurant choices and standards were excellent. WiFi always worked well. Great location just across the road from the exciting Shinjuku shopping/restaurant precinct and a short walk to Shinjuku station.

Stayed at Keio Plaza for four nights during April, Sakura/Cherry Blossom season with my husband and two adult children, in two rooms, one queen, one twin, (non-smoking) in the south tower. These rooms are renovated and we were happy with their fit out. Check in was painless and staff were helpful. Location is great! We traveled from Narita Airport on the Airport Limousine Bus directly to the hotel's front entrance. Very handy! A few minutes walk out the front of the hotel is the undercover walkway to Shinjuku train station. This station has several million people use it daily, so it's very large! Whilst we walk a lot when travelling, it was a pleasant surprise to find within a 5 min walk, plenty of restaurants to chose from! One of our best meals of our two week trip was found here for under $10 AUD which included, fresh grilled fish, miso soup, pickles/condiments etc. Simply delicious! On a big downside...after arranging check out the night before to save time in the morning as we were travelling from Shinjuku train station, with luggage in peak hour (interesting!!!) to Kyoto, we spent 20 minutes waiting for a lift that wasn't at full capacity! One lift was out of service and two just did not open in all that time! We had to split up to squash ourselves in, with force, after waiting this long and then it stopped at every floor from ours, the 23 floor to the ground! We felt waiting this long was simply unacceptable. Thankfully we had allocated an extra hour for incidental issues and made our transfer connection! Otherwise, a good hotel with a small convenience store downstairs, in a good location.

Excellent stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku. We like to get out and visit neighborhoods, so the location both within Shinjuku and proximity to Shinjuku Station was great. Hotel room and amenities very good, staff highly professional and cordial -- it's an incredibly busy place but the front desk staff remembered us by name. Would stay again without a doubt.
user_name:
Lehualani
Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Hawaii

review_body: When booking ask for a room in the main tower as these rooms have been renovated. Our triple room on level 33 was very comfortable and had ample space for 3 adults and their luggage. Good location close to Shinjuku train station. Ideally situated for restaurants and shops. So many to choose from. We only discovered on our last day that there was a underground walkway linking the hotel to the station. My only negative is the beds were very firm and pillows were either too hard or too soft.

When looking for a hotel in Tokyo you need to look out for a couple of things, 1. The size of the room 2. Do they keep the air conditioning system on during the winter months and spring months. The Keio Plaza has upgraded rooms and non-upgraded rooms, if you're booking on Expedia for example, make sure you pay attention to the type of room you are booking, as well as the tower you're booking in, there is a very big difference in comfort between the two types of rooms. The Keio Plaza does turn off their AC during the cold months and the rooms can get a little stuffy but they will provide a fan if requested. The only hotels in Tokyo that keep their AC on are the western hotels like the Hyatt, Hilton, Marriott, etc. The hotel itself is very nice, all the rooms are very clean and well maintained. Keio Plaza is one of my favorite hotels in Tokyo because of where it is located. It's a 5 minute walk to Shinjuku Station, there are also tons of restaurants located on both sides of the station, all different types of cuisines. The Airport Limousine Bus, picks up and drops off at the Keio Plaza as well, it makes getting to and from either Narita or Haneda very easy.

The very first impression was that this place is too big to be true but it is so efficient and conveniently postioned right in the Shinjuku area so ideal for public transport and once one leaves the vast lobby the size is relative so it can be recommended. We had a room on the 35th floor with access to the luxe lounge on the 34th floor with a spectacular view over the city, free drinks and yummy nibbles. The L'Occitaine toiletries were also much appreciated in the bathroom. The room was absolutely spotless and there was even an ironing board and iron in the large cupboard. So all in all we were more than satisfied and would come here again

The Hotel is perfectly located, near to restaurants shops and Tokyo's busiest Rail Station Shinjuku There is plenty of space in the rooms and have all the amenities Has a direct shuttle bus to Disneyland should that be one of the items on your travel itinerary

Having lived in Japan previously, and travelled to Tokyo numerous times throughout my line of work, I had always been told about Keio Plaza from so many people that I decided to stay here last year on a business/leisure trip.This hotel isn't the cheapest nor expensive option in the central Shinjuku area, however the perks are many. There is a Limousine Bus that connects Narita and Haneda airports with the hotel directly, and if you are travelling light, you could also opt for the JR NE'X Express Service which will get you as far as JR Shinjuku Station.From here head towards the West Exit and follow the corridor all the way through and you'll find Keio Plaza easily.The theme in the lobby is definitely grandeur, however the decor throughout the hotel is light and understated, making for a pleasant stay regardless of your room category.From the onsite convenience store, pool, fitness centre and endless dining choices in the vicinity, the hotel provides all you need, whether you're travelling for business or leisure.The front desk staff are helpful, efficient and can provide maps, transport advice and dinner suggestions for when you'd like to explore your surrounds.Thoroughly enjoyed my stay here and would recommend to anyone trying to make the most of a fleeting visit to Tokyo.

The hotel has two large towers and is close to the Shinjuku rail/subway station. I had a queen room in the south tower and on a clear day could see Mount Fuji. The bed and pillows were comfy, room clean, fast free internet, safe, fridge, tea set, desk for working and plenty of outlets to charge the electronics. There are plenty of great places to eat in the hotel, but if you want a cheaper option, walk out the back door and go a few blocks. Lots of good restaurants nearby.

This hotel is situated about a 15 mins walk from the main train station, and is away from the bustle of the train station at Shinjuku, in a very quiet area close to a park. It has many restaurants, from a cafe to Korean, Chinese, Japanese, and French and Italian. The evening buffet is very good with a range in choices from salad, t Japanese food, and even a steam fish.The room we had on the 26th floor was small by US standards, but very clean and adequate, and has all the amenities such as plugs, wifi, and a very good shower, and a king size bed. The service was very good, and the check out time was 3 pm which is convenient if you have a late flight. One can take or the airport bus back to the airport about a 2 hour run right from your front door for about $32 US. One could go from the train station all over Tokyo by riding the subway.

The room was adequate and clean. The bed was a little firm for my taste, but not terrible. The wi-fi was decent. All of the staff were polite and helpful. The location is amazing for exploring Tokyo. I would definitely stay here again.

The location was great. It was a walking distance-like literally across the street- to the malls, restaurants and even an arcade (which was open until 1 or 2am) but don't worry, the noise does not even reach the hotel. The room we stayed in was very clean and spacious and it had a great view of the city below. The staff is very polite and very efficient. The hotel also has 3 (I think) restaurants to choose from and the food is also very good. My family and relatives really had a nice time and we had a very comfortable stay at Keio.

Stayed here for one night on a stop over. The staff were polite and courteous, but our room was less than impressive. The carpet was stained in spots and looked like it had seen better days. Overall our room was clean, the displays in the lobby were very enjoyable, but I felt that I had over paid for what we got.

This is a lovely luxurious hotel. Variety of restaurants and useful shopping facilities. Rooms are very good providing everything you need. Restaurants are expensive but there are nearby much cheaper eating facilities. Is situated very near to central shopping and to 'Electric City'.

Typical Japanese hotel rooms runs small, so don't be surprised. Overall, hotel was clean, breakfast was alright however it is located in a very prime location, only 500m away from Shinjuku Station, lots of food just minutes away, close to possibly every shopping spot in Tokyo. This hotel also provides shuttle services to Disneyland and DisneySEA. It also has a direct airport shuttle (back and forth). Would stay again because of the convenient location and friendly price. The hotel has a very strict policy on check in time (which is 2 pm) so if you were on a long haul flight and arrive in tokyo sleepless early in the morning i suggest you come prepared.

It was quite a walk with our rollerbags from Shinjuku Station - that's because I didn't realize there was a moving walkway at the extreme right side which finally emerges into the open and Keio Plaza Hotel was right there on the left side! Very convenient!The reception was pleasant & efficient but the best was our bell captain who helped us with our bags (too exhausted to carry on) and he was at his best when he stepped past us in the room and with a grand flourish he opened the curtains and said "Mt Fuji"! We had an excellent of Mt Fuji in the distance but a bit hazy and we didn't get a glimpse of it again over the next 3 days due to haziness and bad weather! It was a real treat for us at that one moment!There are many cafes and restaurants to choose from but just outside the hotel on the street level towards Shinjuku Station - there are even more eateries to entice you.Very good location in Shinjuku - just lots of walking - but that's Tokyo!The hotel room was excellent for a triple share - nice big comfy beds and very spacious by Japanese standards. Big plus for Disneyland fans - there is a free shuttle daily to Disneyland/DisneySea.

The hotel is near Shinjuko station but until you find your bearings it is hard to find. Excellent amenities and staff. Small room and a smaller bed size is typical for Japan. Very clean and comfortable. Location is a highlight with the old style alleyways around the corner with every choice of Japanese food at good prices. As a first stop for us it was central and easy to walk or catch a train to numerous locations. The distinctive buildings nearby were great for finding our bearings when out walking.

We stayed here in April with our 2 children aged 2 and 4 in a deluxe twin room. This room has been recently renovated, but still feels quite dated. The beds were very uncomfortable and the decor is very basic and underwhelming. Upon arrival the reception staff were not very helpful. We arrived at 8am and our room wasn't ready until 3pm (which was fine) however the staff made it seem like it was a big inconvenience to leave our bags there until our room was ready. At no point during our 3 night stay did I feel like any staff we came in contact with went out of their way to be helpful or friendly.The location of the hotel was great to walk to shops and restaurants, but that is the only positive thing about this overpriced hotel.We had dinner at the Japanese restaurant on level 1 which was outstanding.

We stayed 3 nights at the start of our Japan tour and couldn't fault the hotel apart from finding its bars & restaurants very expensive (but pretty normal for all the hotels we stayed in). The location is terrific in the heart of the Shinjuku district, just 10-15 minutes walk from Tokyo's busiest station, 20 minutes from the beautiful Shinjuku Gyoen National Gardens (entrance just 200 yen) and directly opposite the municipal buildings with its (free to the public) viewing floors providing excellent panoramic views of the city. The hotel has so many facilities and restaurants, it's like a small town! We chose to eat all our included breakfasts in the main buffet restaurant and these were the best in our whole trip with masses of choice but we could have eaten in several of the other restaurants. We ate no other meals as we found so many local restaurants nearby which were vastly cheaper, though we did have a cocktail one night in the bar. We regularly used the convenience store in the hotel which sold bento boxes etc & drinks at street prices (including wine at under £5 a bottle compared with at least £35/40 in the hotel proper). Our room was a good size, well equipped and spotless. Our only problem was that we couldn't use the internet even though we seemed to be connected but we found internet very hit & miss across the whole country. TIP - to escape the crowds and general mania of central Tokyo, we took the JR Yamanote line from Shinjuku station to Hamanatsucho and from there walked half a mile or so to Hinode pier where we caught the regular ferry under the Rainbow bridge to Obaida Seaside Park - a haven of peace away from the crowds and with an amusing miniature Statue of Liberty. We returned to Shinjuku via the fascinating Harajuku district with its tiny streets full of boutiques and cafes crammed with local fashion-conscious young Japanese.

We stayed for 5 days and we are in awe at how grand and large this hotel is. Despite the size and the seemingly large number of occupants, this hotel is efficient, systematic, clean, comfortable and offers great customer service. From the Haneda Airport, it takes about 45minutes via the airport limousine bus. The location of the hotel is near Shinjuku Station. Easy to move around and explore Tokyo on your own. Just cross the street and you are either walking towards the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building or the restaurants and the camera city (Yodobashi). Convenience stores abound near the hotel. Our room on the 39th floor is spacious and comfortable. Housekeeping service is excellent. Expect a clean room and replenished bottled water if the room is Plaza Premiere. Toiletries are complete! Breakfast options are from Japanese buffet to American buffet. You have three restaurants to choose from for your breakfast. Worth a try.Will definitely go back to Keio Plaza Hotel (a little pricey but worth it) when we visit Tokyo again.

Room very clean and tidy, excellent distribution and amenities. All expected from a 4 star is there - and a couple of things from a 5 star even.Breakfast options are bit odd, but overall many good options for dinner in the hotel for days you burned your energy during the day. The hotel has connection to Shinjuku station, but its quiet side, so you have to get the right direction to see a lot to explore in a very short walkway. Have to say it was a bit pricy, but have to say it is an excellent option for those searching for a 4 star hotel

Keio Plaza Hotel is very convenient hotel. If you are a family with kids, this hotel is recommended. It has limousine bus from airport dropping us at the hotel costs 3000 yen for one way and 4500 yen for round trip and kid over 5 years old at half price. There are many choices of breakfast to choose. There are tour service picking us for one day trip program. There is free shuttle bus service to Disneyland. There is convenient store opening til 2 am. The cost of hotel is bit high but worth to pay.

This kid one of the nicest hotel we have stayed. Plenty of Bottled Water in the Room. Room was more than comfortable with space for both of our luggages. We had access to the 13th Floor For Refreshments. Meals were all excellent. We would love to return there.

The attention to detail is second to none. Located in Shinjuku, close to the subway system that will get you anywhere in Tokyo. Service, friendliness and in house restaurants will fit everyone's taste buds. The 36th floor had a great view of the city and mere minutes to the Hyatt (great restaurant on the 52nd floor) and, if so inclined, a short walk to the Karaoke bar.

We stayed in Keio Plaza 3 days (April 5, 6 & &). Very convenient for tours. Buses come to the hotel. Lot of restaurants in working distance. Rail station is close to the hotel. Breakfast buffet was very good (It was included in our room reservation). Will stay again.

A large and busy establishment. Many tourists use this hotel so English speakers are easily found.It has every amenity and is superbly located. We were there during the Girl’s Doll Festival and there were several stunning exhibits of hanging ornaments made of silk and embroidery throughout the hotel. These are intended as charms to bring happiness to girls. A boy’s festival is held in May.We stayed 5 nights and ate at nearby restaurants or in the restaurants of the department stores. The fine dining options within the hotel building did not meet our budget. Our room on the 22nd floor was spacious and comfortable and a real contrast to many of the Tokyo hotel rooms we have used in the past.

Booked by travel agent as part of a group tour. Excellent room, wi fi , breakfast choices. Excellent location, helpful staff . One of the lifts was being repaired and this created a bit of a queue at times. No other issues. Recommend it.

Stayed three nights in this Mega Hotel in a very convenient location in Shinjuku. Very near the train station/Subway and many Department stores and shopping restaurant areas. The hotel itself has at least 7 restaurants although all overpriced considering the many options nearby. There are two breakfast buffet places (one Western, one Asian) and they are as bustling as a train station. The Western one is a very nice renovated bright spot with good selection and immaculate serving areas. Just expect to wait to be seated. The triple room was comfortable and not overcrowded. nice amenities in the bathroom as well. This was a reasonable room rate for such space and location. It just did not have much atmosphere in lobby due to huge crowds and groups checking in, circulating and meeting in lobby. It does try with a lovely display of soft art sculpture celebrating Girls but it would be hard to make this hotel feel cozy and charming.
user_name:
Mathilde S
New York City, New York

review_body: It's our first time in Japan and we are lucky that our travel agency booked us in this great hotel. Room is just fine though we only stay there to sleep or rest. Bathroom amenities were complete with Shiseido facial wash. It was easy checking in and out. Front Desk and Lobby personnel are so accommodating and could understand English. They have lots of restaurant to choose to eat your breakfast. Food are okay though price are a bit expensive. Place is accessible to shopping malls, Japanese restaurants and train station. They have also a 24/7 small grocery. Hope we could return to this place again.

+ Good Location near Shinjuku Station+ Multiple restaurants + Good service quality+ Supermarket in hotel+ Clean and comfortable rooms+ Friend's room had a view of Mt. Fuji on a clear day- Long waits for breakfast due to large crowds

This hotel is in a great location! It's close to many eateries and the train station. ALL the staff are very polite and very helpful. The room itself has many great features, especially a plug board with multiple international adapters, USB port chargers at the side of the beds (brilliant), cable TV, spacious bathroom, vanity table, the list goes on! A great hotel to stay in, and if you get a chance, try the specialty bakery on the lower level!

Great location, easy walk to Shinjuku Station, restaurants and luxury shopping. Takashimaya, Lumin etc very close by.Rooms were really nice and large except for the bathroom which was cruise ship small! Definately a good place to stay. Breakfast was good.

Beautiful and organized structure. Very courteous staff. Cleaning at the top. Placed near a busy area full of restaurants and shops. Fantastic holiday. Thank you. I hope to come back. From the upper floors you can enjoy a wonderful view. A++

I have stayed at this hotel a number of times for the large room, convenience and the value. It is a huge hotel with most Japanese patrons and tour groups; just try to have breakfast in the morning, you get it! Not 1 or 2 but 3 or 4 restaurants are all serving breakfast of all kinds if you have a breakfast coupon. the western/ buffet always has a long line, the food is average by American standard.Location is good with lots of shopping and restaurants nearby, and the subway is about 10 minutes walking. This hotel is actually very close to both Park Hyatt and Hyatt Regency hotels. Rooms are a bit dated, but fairly large by Japanese standard. It is simple, but very clean. All the staff are always courteous.

This hotel is like any large business-focused hotel, with everything you would expect (including expensive restaurants). It was well located near the Tokyo Tourist Office (which is in the Tokyo Metropolitan Building), and within easy walking distance of several subway stations. We got a room on an upper floor, so had a view (not much to see other than a big city). We were on the "club" floor, so we had access to the club lounge---which offered drinks throughout the day (the snacks served were very limited). We heard from another guest that other parts of the hotel were not as nice as the club floor—guess that area has been renovated. The hotel worked for us, but there isn't anything unique about it.

Fantastic Location , Awesome Service and the Automated Money Changing ATMs and the basement super market are a real treat!!!!! If I go to Tokyo again it has to be at the Keio! Access to Shinjuku Station was soo easy .....

The Keio Plaza Hotel is conveniently located in the Shinjuku (Western Part of Tokyo) and it is a 5 minute walk to the Sinjuku Rail and Subway Stations and the Odakyu and Keio Department Stores, and myriad restaurants are also within walking distance. The ambiance of the hotel is outstanding and the rooms by Tokyo standards are large and well appointed. Free Wi-Fi and reasonably priced to very expensive (typical Japanese hotels) restaurants and shops. Food was great. This hotel may not be the best for people not familiar with Tokyo, but from our standpoint it was and is perfect. I have stayed there many times in the past and it is still in great shape and feels newly renovated.

Great location close to Shinjuku Station allowing access to attractions. Hotel staff friendly and very helpful. Our room was spacious and extremely comfortable. Many eating places both within the hotel and nearby areas as well as a handy convenience store downstairs. Would definitely stay again!

For the second year in a row, we have tried to check in AM at the hotel. On this occasion, we attended reception three times trying to get an early check in. Having flown on an overnight flight from Australia with my 81 year old mother, she was keen to secure our room and some sleep. But typically, reception stuck to the tired old routine about rooms not being available until after 2:00pm as they needed to be cleaned. Rubbish. The hotel has hundreds of rooms and there were surely some that were clean. Equally, we stayed two nights in a standard room as we had paid for, then upgraded to a deluxe room for the remaining two nights which was part of our group package. Why didn't the hotel put us in the executive room for the whole four nights so we didn't have to move rooms which is quite disruptive. We won't be staying at Keio Plaza again. The improvement opportunity is to get a more flexible check in with your front desk team. On this occasion, extremely poor.

We arrived in the early morning on 11th April. Check in was only from 1400hr onwards. Went walking around Shinjuku till closed to 1300hr. As the family was dead tired because we were not able to get any rest on the night flight here, I approach the front desk and requested if it would be possible to check in slightly earlier. The front desk staff was very helpful and told me to wait for at least half an hour as the room was prepared for us. It was less than 10 mins before he called to inform me the room was ready.Extremely happy with the service provided. Hotel is in a good location. Walking from the west side of Shinjuku station to the hotel took less than 10 mins. Along the way - plenty to see and eat. We are a family of three and the room we had on the 28th floor was large by Japanese standard. We had two super single beds and a single bed.Will definitely choose this hotel again on my next trip to Tokyo.

Great location in Shinjuku area, and great for shopping. Staffs were just ok and not impressive. (I might have too high expectations from Japanese standards though). Breakfast was ok, offering both local and western choices.

Excellent location in Shinjuku, although still a fair walk from the station, especially with luggage, although it's underground and sheltered for most of the way. The rooms are huge for a Japanese hotel, and there are a number of restaurants which make breakfast easy if you're lazy to go out.
It located in front of tokyo public office and very near from shinjuku stationRestrant for breakfast are also good. They have 3. I recommend class gardenRoom is bigger than other hotel in tokyo.

Keio plaza hotel is an old Japanese style hotel, well located at 5' of Shinjuku train station. The all is quite old, and you can feel it in a very strong way. Service is very good as everywhere in Japan. Breakfast is desapointing, as the all experience when you are travelling for business.

I ended up in this hotel since I was at a conference.The views are amazing. It looks like it is tradition to stock these hotel rooms with lots of toilet treats in Japan. The hotel has a lot of traffic. It is extremely busy. Lots of people circulating in the lobby from cruise ships and excursions. I remember being very tired and not finding a place to seat. The room layout was not for a 4.5 star hotel. These are some of the smallest rooms that I have seen. The staff is very distant and I found the restaurant staff snobbish. I would say that this hotel lacked personal touch.

Well positioned for access to restaurants, amenity and a central rail station (ie multiple rail companies and train lines), and department stores.The hotel's sheer size makes it impersonal. Staff cannot cope with anything out of the ordinary or offer meaningful solutions easily or quickly. Interactions take a very long time eg: 45-60 mins.Hotel and room cleaning could be better.Main Building reception and foyer is far superior to the dark and dreary equivalent in the South Tower.A LOT of tour groups come to the hotel, so you are often navigating around large groups.It is not unusual to wait 20+ minutes to be seated at breakfast, so plan for this wait time if eating before 9.30am.To us Japanese beds are great because they're very firm. This is our 3rd stay in 10 years at this hotel. Whilst they've renovated, its to an average standard only. Overall disappointing; we will not be coming back to stay here again.

Keio Plaza Hotel. Shinjuku (TOKYO) JapanWe stayed at this hotel last week for four nights and it was perfect. A very rare 10 out of 10 score from me.I will start with check-in. Very efficient and courteous and we scored a room upgrade. Room was on floor 24 and was spacious and spotlessly clean. Daily maid service was 100% correct. Lighting was good and the air-conditioning worked all the time. One stand-out was the lift service that never kept you waiting. This is a big busy hotel and the lifts were great unlike most other big hotels where you wait ages for lifts.Our schedule did not allow us to really investigate the full suite of offerings but everything we interacted with was perfect. We enjoyed Breakfast each morning and it was a very well-oiled machine. Dinner one night in one of the Restaurants (which is rare for us to do in-house) and it was excellent.This is a very, very busy hotel but still ran well under constant pressure. Hotels, even 5 star ones with a great pedigree rarely operate at this level of guest satisfaction.

We had a very enjoyable stay at the Keio. The staff provided great service and it was very convenient to have many of the tours start from the hotel. The hotel was not as close to the station as I thought but was very manageable. We also stayed in the Princess Kitty room and loved it. What a fairyland for a child. Everything had been considered in terms of decorations and continuing the theme with the breakfast.

4.5 stars....very nice rooms in new tower, smaller but OK rooms in south tower, great location near Shinjuku stationgood selection of restaurants, usually better value than other hotels in area (Hyatt, Hiltion)2 stars ....Pet peeve - the fitness center access is NOT available 24hrs per day. When I arrive from overseas flight, due to jetlag, I like to use fitness center ~ midnight, however the hotel staff do not give you access. The Hilton and most hotels of this class offer 24hrs access to fitness center. No reason why Keio Plaza cannot do same.

This hotel is near the Metropolitan Government Building. It is within easy walking distance of the South Exit of Shinjuku Railway Station. The rooms are very comfortable and there are good amenities. Within walking distance are very good restaurants of varying prices and shopping. My husband and I didn't have breakfast in the hotel but we found a very good Excelsior Cafe which had excellent breakfast and coffee just across the road on ground floor of office block (just across the road from the hotel). The hotel is within a building housing restaurants and shops so if it's a more intimate hotel you want this may not be the place for you. I would recommend this hotel for is location.

We stayed at Keio Plaza in Shinjuku and we were pleasantly surprised by the size of our room! The hotel upgraded us and we had a room that was approximately 175 sq. ft. The hotel is a bit far from places (about 15 minutes walk to the nearest mall / subway station) but it was manageable for us. There is a Starbucks right across the street for anyone who needs it! One downside is that there is no security in the elevator so anyone can go to any level within the hotel without an access key.

Very nice hotel friendly helpful staff everything well organised nice rooms with comfortable beds shops nearby for snacks and drinks cheaper than using mini bar we visited Tokyo to watch my son in law run in the marathon which started right outside the hotel. The hotel was situated within walking distance of the metro and train stations which we used a lot to get around Tokyo quite early to use.

i spent four nights at the Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo as part of a tour of Japan. Despite being a huge hotel, it is well organised and well managed. Rooms are of a quite reasonable size considering Japanese standards and there is sufficient space for two big suitcases, while still being able to move. Rooms are confortable with all amenities and a bottle of water per person is complementary each day.Breakfast is good and rich, with a wide selection of western and Japanese food. The problem is, however, that, as there are so many people, it is often necessary to queue before being admitted to the restaurant. This is the case even if there are a couple of options for the breakfast. It is a problem as queues could last for 20-30 minutes at peak hours.

Enjoyed the hotel, great location and had all the amenities you need. .The location is perfect.The staff is wonderfully patient and Helpful.They have a good international buffet breakfast..We so enjoyed our stay there and i hope to return

Just returned from 5 nights at the giant Keio plaza hotel, located some 10 minutes walk from the Odakyu/Keio Plaza dept store side of Shinjuku West station. We booked a 4 bed family room, no 3136, which is effectively a double twin room, with the partition wall knocked out. There is ample room for 4 small twin beds, a small 3 seat sofa, and 2 armchairs, as well as the benefits of having 2 bathrooms. This was in the main wing, and the furniture and fittings, though a little dated, were always kept clean. the large flat screen TV even showed a dozen English shows, which is unusual in Japan. Free wi-fi for as many devices as you want, where you had to relog in every day was a bit painful but ok.The let down is in the service, not from the want of trying to serve, but from the dated processes in place. They start check in at 2pm, and not a minute before. Given that check in takes 20 minutes, and despite 10 plus receptionists, a long queue develops. Wrtitten forms are still being filled out, breakfast coupons manually collated, and the recptionist are still doing paperwork 5 minutes after a guest departs with their key. Looking at their check in software, looks like something circa 1985, with computer screens to match. They need to invest here, and set themselves up with the latest electronic point of sales hard/software. This inefficiency then transfers itself, to all the other service areas. Long queues at bell desk, duty manager, concierge. Though there are many restaurants, and a 10% discount for guests the dinner deals, JPY10k plus for teppanyaki, tempura, sushi etc don't come cheap. The lunch deals JPY3-6k are far more reasonable, though quality is good, its nothiing so extraordinary to make you want to pay double for dinner.This hotel with the right management could be so much more, but is stuck in a bit of a time warp.

After traveling to so many countries in my career, finally I landed in the country of a rising sun.
