In this work trip, I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel located in the centre of Tokyo.Guests are to expect a large hotel consist of two towers. The location is excellent. JR Shinjuku station is a 10 minute walk, and there is also a subway station right next to the hotel entrance. Shinjuku mall, department stores are all with reachable distance. It is an extremely busy hotel, its lobby perennially congregated with large number of tour groups. So if you are after more discrete stay, the hotel probably is not a good candidate. I stayed in a two different type of rooms, the renovated plaza luxe room in the south tower and the standard room in the main tower. They are distinctively different in size and condition as you can see from the attached photos. The plaza luxe one also entitle guests to access to the club floor, servers tea and coffer during the date and happy hours in the evening, but do not expect a full happy hour experience. The drinks served in the evening are very minimal and food items are nearly non-existent. I noticed that a bottle of locally produced whisky was consumed by guests in the first few days of my stay but was not replaced, well at least not during my 9 nights stay. There is a very small gym; again if exercising is important during your trip, you would be very disappointed. If you book the business package, you will have breakfast in the smaller restaurant which is designated exclusively for business people while there is always a long queue outside the main restaurant. It is a good idea to book the business package, although the breakfast is basic but adequate.Service is the highlight. In fact, it is the highlight of Japan. You will never know what top customer service is until you travel in Japan.

I stayed at Keio Plaza because of its very convenient location and the efficient shuttle bus service provided between the airport and hotel which runs every 40 mins. It's a huge tourist / business hotel with 2 towers and the south tower has been renovated with better modern facilities.Rooms are relatively small (typical Japanese hotel standards) despite I stayed in the Plaza Lux which is only 30 square metres. Tried to book the Plaza Premier room which is a bit larger but not available. Asked for an upgrade at a fee but still not available at checking in. The Plaza Lux is about 30 sq metres with no separate shower cabin in the bathroom. I was finally upgraded for free to a Plaza Lux corner room the last day, which is a bit bigger, bigger room with real King size bed and a separate shower cabin. The benefit of staying in the Plaza floor is that there is a separate check-in counter where you can avoid the long queue of tourists, bearing in mind it's a big hotel and there is always a queue for checking in and out. Guests staying on the Plaza floor get the use of the Lounge at the top floor free; where they offer coffee, tea and soft drink and snacks for free.It's an average hotel located within walking distance to almost everything; the frequent shuttle bus service between the hotel and airport is a great selling point. Shuttle airport bus service to other hotel runs less frequently and thus if you have a lot of luggage, it's a plus..... carrying heavy suit cases up and down the stairs to catch the JR to the airport could be demanding.

Read that Japanese hotel rooms are small, but not the case in the Keio Plaza, lovely big room, well appointed, very comfortable. If you get breakfast vouchers that allow you to choose your restaurant, the American buffet style one is good, but the other (think it's called the Glass Court) is much better, darker, calmer, better food. There can be queues if you go at the popular time. Location is excellent, lots of amenities around the area. There is a great convenience store on a lower floor, they have lots of food things, even the baked goods/pizza style stuff which they will microwave for you. Really enjoyed our stay here.

We spent 4 nights at Keio Plaza last week, and loved it. The room was renovated, very large and comfortable with excellent bathroom and a small sitting area. We were on the 30th floor and had wonderful views across Tokyo. The airport bus will drop you at the hotel, there is a shuttle bus to Disney (book early, we phoned to book right after booking our room online) the included breakfast was fantastic and our breakfast coupons could instead be used for lunch if we wanted (extra payment may be required depending on what you order) We also had a Washoku dinner included in our stay and it was delicious. The hotel was huge and busy, but we never had to wait long for the lift, restaurants, to check in or to get advice from the concierge desk. The hotel is in a great location, 5 minutes easy walk to Shinjuku Station, and many restaurants and shops nearby. It is also an easy walk to the beautiful Shinjuku Gyoen Park. Our only real issue was that the bed was a bit firmer than we would like, but we still slept well after busy days! We would definitely stay at Keio Plaza again in the future!

Great breakfast, although it's 3000 Yen, it's worth the money if you are hungry!Rooms very well maintained for such a massive hotel! Attentive helpful staff.Convenient for Shinjuku and the JR Yamanote line (free on the JR pass).Follow the signs for the Government building from the station.

We were not expecting a luxury hotel, but were pleasantly surprised at the Keio. The location was excellent. Close to Shinjuku Station and Takahashi Station. It was even straight across the road from the Government Building and easy to access their observation towers. The room was comfortable. What it lacked in size it made up for in amenities. We found a lot of extra comforts that helped our stay. The shower was incredibly hot and the water pressure was high. They included a power adapter for our use as well as free bottled water everyday. It was a very busy hotel so check-in/out took some time, but it the lined moved quite well. There was also free internet and it worked well enough for us to FaceTime with our kids. That was a major bonus.We ate breakfast downstairs one morning and really liked the convenience of starting our day with a good breakfast before heading out for touring activities. Overall I thought it was a great hotel even though I considered it a value hotel (at $160/night) and was pleasantly surprised at comfort.
user_name:
Lindsey M
Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, United States

review_body: The last time we stayed here was 2 years ago and we always stay at Keio whenever we are in Tokyo because of its location and value stays. On this trip we stayed for 4 nights.However, accommodation prices in Japan have risen sharply over the last few years due to the increase in tourists volume from North Asian countries.The hotel lobby gets very busy and crowded between 2-5pm because the masses (tour groups) all start to check in. This also explains the long breakfast lines if u go after 8am. We did not take the breakfast package but saw the long lines each morning we depart for the subway.We were upgraded to a bigger room on the main building 29 floor (2909), from the standard queen booking. The room were clean, quiet and very spacious.The hotel concierge were very helpful in our restaurants reservations when I communicated to them by email. The hotel has many restaurants as well as a convenience store for your needs. The subway/metro Oedo line serves the hotel. The station to alight is Tochomae and it about 100m walk to the hotel.Overall I highly recommend Keio plaza for its convenience to shopping, gardens, restaurants and transport. I prefer the airport limousine bus though it takes a longer journey but the door to door service from airport to hotel makes up for the longer time, vs taking the train to Tokyo or Shinjuku station and carrying your luggages across buildings to hotel. For those taking the train into shinjuku station, a short taxi ride to the hotel cost about 730y only.

A short walk to the train station, malls, GREAT FOOD and shops, Keio Plaza is a convenient place to stay! You can even see Mt. Fuji from your room on a clear day! Rooms are always clean and they have the essential Japanese 'luxury' of electronic toilets that have seats that heat up, adjustable temperatures and water pressure for the bidet and music to avoid what some think to be the awkward sound of using the toilet, haha! Breakfast came with our stay and they have 3 breakfast buffet options. I loved how they had Japanese style cuisine and International as well with a selection of bread, breakfast meats, etc. Definitely fuss free when I went with my family!
user_name:
Margaret G
Moraga, California, United States

review_body: Great location in Shinjuku. 5 minutes walk from the Shinjuku subway/train station. Surrounded by places to eat, stores for shopping, convenience stores and places of attraction etc. Special thanks to Higashi-san of client relations for arranging the adjoining rooms for my family. Can't say the same for the lady at the premium check-in counter who insisted my 3 young children stay on a different floor in a different tower (Keio Plaza has 2 towers - main & south towers) despite my request in my booking 6 months ago to have adjoining rooms.Our appreciation to Katoh-san (from concierge) who tried to help us arrange for the adjoining rooms when he found out that my children were in the different tower.The rooms were clean and spacious. Only downside was a rather small fitness room with 2 treadmills and an exercise bike with no weights machine. Swimming pool was closed too. Overall an enjoyable stay in the hotel.

As a hotel in Tokyo city center, you can never ask for a big room. However, even if the standard room is not big, Keio still makes room for two comfy sofas for guests to have a chat or see the night view from the window. Very chilled and well-designed. The breakfast is fantastic. We had breakfast every morning. Even though the dishes are almost the same, there are two many choices you hardly get the same thing. Overall it tastes fab! Love this hotel and would love to come back next time.

This hotel is situated in the business area of Tokyo. Theres an airport limousine to and from Hanida and Narita airports that drops and collects at the door. In fact a lot of tours collect from this hotel as well.The hotel is huge, and as a previous reviewer said there could be ques for breakfast. We were alway down early so didnt find this a problem. The food we had in the restaurant was good - there are 6 restaurants- and 2 are open for breakfast. The staff were also extremely helpful. I suppose the downside to such a large place was ques if you needed to speak to someone. The rooms we had before and after our trip were spacious and clean.The hotel is also a short walk from Shinjuko station where there are shops and resaurants if one doesnt feel like eating in the hotel.It is also next door to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government buliding which has twin towers with obersvation decks on the 45th floor free! We tried both towers. So beautiful views of Tokyo and Mt Fuji on a clear day. Then a short walk past that building is Shinjuko Gyoen National Park which is a haven of peace in a busy place. We were there end of March so the spring flowers and blossom were out.Would certainly go back to this hotel again

We booked one night at Keio Plaza to spend our last night in Tokyo in comfort before flying out of Narita the following afternoon. I'm glad we chose Keio Plaza. We were upgraded to a Premier room on the 35th floor with fantastic sweeping views of Tokyo. The room had top notch amenities and was huge by Tokyo standards. Everything you could need was in the room already and we were shown how to use the blinds, air conditioner, etc. as the bell staff brought our bags up.We also had the buffet dinner in the hotel and it was very, very good with solid choices for both Japanese and western fare. Overall, could not be happier with the Keio Plaza Hotel. It's a short walk from Shinjuku station which makes it a perfect spot for easy access to the Narita Express train and connections to anywhere in Tokyo or to catch the Shinkansen to anywhere in Japan.

Arrived at Keio plaza via airport limousine from Narita airport Tokyo. Dropped off at front door! Staff extremely attentive and check in was a breeze. Upgraded to a bigger room. Spacious room with powder room. Tea and coffee making facilities and sitting area. Location of hotel is great.....short walk to Shinjuku station. Amazing hotel and would highly recommend. Love this place!!

Perfect location for exploring Shinjuku and Tokyo. Station can be reached directly from the hotel. Views from the hotel rooms are great! Only downer are the long queues for breakfast, better come before 6.30am or after 8pm when the groups have left.

I stayed in Keio for total 5 nights last week. For the 1st 4 nights, I experienced wonderful Japanese hospitality. I checked out and went to Kawaguchiko for one night and came back to Keio. To my horror, my triple sharing was not registered with the hotel. On top of that, when I checked out, I was told to pay Japan hotel tax even though my first 4 nights stay had no such tax when I checked out. The front desk were unapologetic and kept asking me to understand their situation! The hotel is conveniently located and had the airport limousine right at the hotel. If you are going to Disneyland, there is also a free shuttle bus but make sure you booked early. The rooms by Japanese standards are spacious and has sufficient space for luggages. The triple sharing is also good because they give you a real bed instead of a foldable sofa bed. In my first room 1230, I found falsies on the carpet. This says something about housekeeping!

Went there last year Dec'15 and decided to revisit again in Mar'16. A great place to stay in! Has convenience store, bakery shop and restaurants located in the hotel and free disneyland shuttle bus. Walking distance to Shinjuku JR line and has lots of restaurants and pharmacies located around the hotel area. There is also an underway link at the Mitsui building next to it that links to Odakyu mall just in case there is rain. Has discount when purchasing at Keio mall too. The staff there are all friendly, helpful and able to converse in English. My family loved it a lot and will always revisit when we go Tokyo.

Stayed 6 nights at Keio. Had a renovated standard room which was very spacious for 3 people. Had a good view of Shinjuku from 22th floor. Fast wifi provided. Easy access to Shinjuku bus terminal and train stations, and the airport limousine stops directly outside the hotel. The hotel is very big and lobby is always busy. Check-in queue could be long but the queue moved quite fast. There are cheap eateries nearby for those who don't have breakfast option in the hotel .

Family trip in the end of March. The hotel is located close to Shinjuku station, perfect when you travel with JR rail pass with access both to Narita Express and JR Yamanote line. The room was big enough for 3 adults, the beds were big and a bit on the hard side for westerners. There are plenty of shops and restaurants in the neighbourhood. The only negative is the price for breakfast and food in general on the hotel, but there are plenty of alternatives in the area.

Travelled as young family, kids 2.5 and 4.5 years, one of the few hotels that would accept 4 per room. The location was perfect, walking distance to the restaurants and bars of Shinjuku and an easy walk to the metro. The hotel had plenty of food options, which we really only used to feed the kids before venturing out, but all looked good. Only downside is just how busy it is, I have never seen anything like it, if your looking for something boutique and intimate then this is not the place for you, but it's clean, perfectly located, and by Tokyo standards, good value for money - would return. (Also the shuttle bus is direct to/from airport to hotel, which huge plus considering the amount of luggage we had with us).

I chose this hotel primarily, hotel shuttle bus stop RIGHT INFRONT of lobby! With heavy luggageS and expensive taxi fees in Japan, this seems good logical choice! At the airport, buy airport shuttle bus ticket. Counter speaks good English and will direct you to right elevator and bus area. There is a indoor waiting area, with seating for old/young ( and can shield from cold wind). Must collect luggage ticket inorder to collect at end of bus ride. There is no need to download your own luggage from bus as porter do their jobs diligently with pride. Tips not needed.The main tower is nearest to Main Lobby. B2 Floor consists of whole stretch of restaurants including convenience shop which closes 2am. (where endless variety of cup noodles, Japanese mini toiletries & snacks, even "Hello Kitty" souvenirs! which shop gladly allow tax refund for 5000yen purchases)Hotel Back door - 5mins walk to Shinjuku station. Along your walk, you will pass by Lawson, family mart - similar 7/11 chain. Where sushi, bento set (rice set), sandwiches, cakes/pastries are cheap and delicious! Airport shuttle bus TO airport, buy early at concierge vending machine! Only one bus per hour interval, so seats are limited for hotel guests. If hotel pre-allocated seats taken up, you can try your luck at next bus stop - Shinjuku station (but open air bus stand, no seating and queue! Be prepared to face the chill wind! ) Our flight was 12.30pm, but we only got 7.30am seats the night before! Both 8am and 9am timing were full! There is also Disney free shuttle. But book online (via hotel website) for guarantee morning timing. Cuz most family guests who stayed Keio are going Disney!TIP:Rent Wifi portable gadget at airport. 1st day pickup rental is not counted. 3D2N (including return day) cost 3000yen. Useful as not all places in Tokyo are wifi. take note: battery last 8-10hours, be sure to charge at night.

This is a very very busy hotel and caters for very large groups and conferences. As such, the foyer and lines can be quite long and busy. The rooms itself are adequate, clean and relatively spacious.The selling point however is that it's centrally located and a very convenient base to explore Tokyo.

This hotel was the first on our trip to Japan and what a start !! The Keio is a very large hotel but the staff are very attentive, polite and efficient. Although check in was busy they soon cleared the queue and we found it quick and easy..The location is a short walk from Shinjuku Station by a travelling walkway quite good with luggage.We had a room in the South Tower which was quite large especially after what I was expecting in Japan ! The room was on the 30th Floor was very clean, good size bathroom, with the heated toilet seat !! And very quiet.Breakfast was included in our rate and there was a great choice of restaurants with a fantastic choice of food on offer. Great start to a day before sightseeing.In the evening you have a good selection of Restaurants, Noodle Bars, Sushi Bars etc etc all within a 5 min walk or you can go into the Centre of Shinjuku where you have even more choice.My husband had been working in Japan before I joined him for this trip so we had quite a lot of luggage which we didn't want to transport through on our trip and as we were coming back to this hotel for our last night they allowed us to leave a couple of large bags in storage which was a great help.I would highly recommend this hotel as a base to visit around the Tokyo / Shinjuku area.

Had an opportunity to stay in Keio Plaza Hotel last week, it was my first time in a Shinjuku hotel, not too shabby. My room had a wonderful view of Shinjuku (in front of TMG). Rooms were clean, toilet wasnt too small... however, I thought their elevator system was slightly confusing. From the lobby going up to the rooms or meeting rooms, it was fine, but from mid floor (rooms) to other floors, there werent a lot of signs on which elevator went where... so that was confusing!I loved how the staff could all speak english!

Wonderful Hotel and despite its size it doesn't feel impersonal or big like you'd expect. Convenient location, comfortable, quiet, GREAT dining options, nicely appointed Rooms and the best Staff. Ice or extra pillows in a flash, ditto on laundry pickup or special requests and at a surprisingly reasonable rate.

This was my husband and my first trip to Japan. We wanted to stay somewhere that was well-located and clean. The Keio was great! We stayed in the South Tower for 5 nights. Apparently we were given a complimentary upgrade which was very nice. The room was much bigger than we expected! I had heard that hotel rooms in Japan were often small but this room was as big or bigger than many I've stayed in in the US. The staff were very nice. The room was clean and comfortable. And, the location was great. Made for a great base for exploring Tokyo. If/when we come back to Tokyo, I would not hesitate to stay at the Keio again!

I've stayed at this hotel many times in the past and its always been a good experience overall. Staff are mostly very polite and the hotel is always clean.I stayed in the South Tower on the 24th floor and was told that it has been newly renovated. No complaints here. Everything looked solid. Bed was comfy too.Housekeeping was very polite every morning and did a very good job keeping the rooms clean while leaving personal belongings untouched. I had forgotten to put away my diamond-studded earring and left it on the drawer. Came back later in the day to find it still there. I wouldn't recommend doing anything like this but I'd like to credit their housekeeping staff.The wifi is decently fast but usually disconnects you after a while, forcing you to have to reconnect and log in to their website again, which is a little troublesome.The only issue I had with the hotel was on the last day. My wife had purchased tickets for the bus to the airport and had made it clear 2 times that we would get on the 7:20am bus on the following day. When we were standing in front of the bus, we found that our names were not on the list and the staff member at the hotel was quite rude before finally going back into the hotel to check for us. 2 minutes later he returns and says that our names aren't on the list so we can't get on. At this point we were kind of pissed off and my wife then explained to him the situation. He quickly went back into the hotel to check again and came back after another 2 minutes apologizing and saying that it was a mistake on their end. We ended up getting on the bus and leaving, although holding everybody up for 10 minutes.Overall I still had a good experience here and would return again.

I realise Tokyo is an expensive place to stay especially if you want to be central. Keii plaza was quiet expensive to my thinking ( anything over $450 Au per night is expensive). For this money I had hoped for a room that was not so dated. It was however, roomy and clean. The main facilities are good and well kept. It is not a stand out hotel except for its location and helpful staff. The floor staff were able to help with restaurant bookings and other information. The buffet breakfast was plentiful but very busy. If you arrived after 7.30am be prepared to wait about ten min to be seated. The location is a quick walk to Shinjuku station which is the hub to go anywhere in Tokyo. To me this was its redeeming feature. Plus the coach from the airport stops right at the door of the hotel which makes your first night in Tokyo much easier. ( no dragging bags everywhere).

Everything you would expect from a luxury Tokyo skyscraper hotel. South tower is 30 floors while the main tower is over 40. Rooms are spacious and comfortable. The location is great, in Nishi-Shinkjuku between the train station and the municipal government building. Easy walk to JR Shinjuku station. Lots of restaurants in the hotel to choose from. Shuttle bus to airports for a fee. Haneda is more convenient. Excellent service. Expensive, but sometime good deals can be had.

This is a big sparkly modern hotel with all the amenities that you'd expect and really handy for plunging into the centre of Tokyo.The rooms and beds were comfortable and the bathrooms well equipped and spotlessly clean. There are plenty of in-house restaurants to choose from to dine in (although you may not need to with Tokyo calling just outside) and the breakfast buffet caters for just about every breakfast whim known to man (or woman!) kind. Enjoy
user_name:
Tigris15
Royal Tunbridge Wells, United Kingdom

review_body: Came to a trip in japan, started at tokyo.Starting the trip in keio Plaza tokyo is a very soft landing to a new country, specially Japan, where the language is a big problem to a visitor. Room facilities are in a high level, food is tasty, location is near to a metro station. If I come visit again I'll stay there.

We arrived at 12.20 after an overnight flight and told we could not check in until 14.00. I got the impression even if our room was ready we would not be allowed to check in. We arrived back at reception at 13.50 to find a long queue. The check in staff seemed very slow and inefficient.Our room in the south tower was very new with modern decor. The bathroom was small.
user_name:
Caf92
Henley in Arden, United Kingdom

review_body: Keio is an old luxury hotel in Shinjuku. We booked two plaza premier room including lounge access. So my room review is toward the premier room. We did not include breakfast as there are tons of restaurants walking distance, even a 24hr sushi place.Hotel location is quite good, relatively close to Shinjuku station. It is one of the Disney friends hotel that offers free shuttle to Disneyland. There is nothing to complain about the rooms. All perfect, with Loccitane amenities, 50" large screen tv, in room expresso maker.....What i didnt enjoy was the lounge access. The lounge is small and mostly full of people. We wanted a quiet evening but it was quite the opposite. There were no food, just some snacks selection. Drinks were standard. And it is located in the south tower... our rooms were in main tower :(The only complaint I have in Japan (all hotels i stayed in) is the lack of english program on tv. The only english channels are ccn, bbc news, nhk world and one more channel. They even try to translate to japanese via a voice over the news, so its quite annoying.Last but not least.... Japan is amazing!!!!

We stopped here for 6 nights at the start of a tour of Japan and really enjoyed our stay at this hotel.The level of service was excellent with all staff going out of their way to help you.We stopped in a newly renovated room in the South tower which was very well decorated and had everything you needed to make your stay very easy.The location is also excellent as it is only a short walk from Shinjuki Station and in close proximity to the restaurants and parks in the Shinjuki area.Also it is served by a number of restaurants housed in the hotel complex itself.Another plus was it was across the road from the Observatory Towers of the Government building and so we were able to visit both during the day and the night where you get excellent views of the Tokyo skyline.If you visiting Tokyo I would recommend you stay at this hotel.

The location of the hotel is very good. The area has plenty of restaurants within walking distance and the train station is very close. The hotel is always bustling with people in the lobby and restaurants. The only downside is that because it is so busy, you don't really receive warm service upon check in. Everything is very fast and efficient.

Beautiful hotel. Would definitely stay there again. No smoking rooms was great and plenty of restaurants so no need to go out into the cold weather. Very helpful staff. If you want to get their bus to Disneyland book as far in advance as possible.

We stayed for 5 days at Keio Hotel Lobby: Many tourist fell in line at the concierge but staff was very fast at checking in. We requested for renovated rooms and gladly thats what we got. Rooms: Rooms were very nice and also the view, We got a twin bed room so we can get a bigger space of the room, beds and pillows were okay not the usual soft beds you can get in a 5 star hotel. Bathroom:Bathroom was small, toilets were equipped with heaters and and the tub was also fine Not modern style but its fine coz its clean Environment: The location of the hotel was very safe and nice, just a few walks from the hotel you can be at the JR station, and lots of food stalls and convenient stores restaurants and shopping malls For a mid budget tourist this hotel is recommended

Cool hotel, located in the middle of Shinshuku, friendly staff, excellent rooms, great food, plenty of bars at walking distance, next train station at 5 min walking distance, a bit expensive though, but Tokyo IS expensive...

Excellent location in embassy neighborhood. Good breakfast and service. Nice restaurants around and into hotel. I will back for sure. The room is spacious and has a nice decoration. The bathroom has a toto toilet and this is funny and usefull.

We stayed here for 2 nights in a Renewed Superior Twin, Non Smoking (Main Tower), then we went to a ski resort for 7 nights then returned to Keio again but stayed in the Tatami suite for 6 nights. The renewed superior twin - did not look renewed at all - so not sure if the extra we paid was worth it or not. The room was ok, but I would not have called it 4.5 star. The Tatami suite was beautiful - we paid ALOT more for it - but was worth every cent. Had 2 large rooms (1 for the futons and the other had a small table and TV ) and the bathroom was spacious. We were on level 10 - so still had great views of Shinjuku skyline. I think there was a communication problem as they didn't make the futons for us at the time specified, but eventually we told them just to make the futons and leave them out. We rented a pram online - the owner at the ryokan from the ski resort - did it online for us as it was all in japanese. It was fantastic - delivered on time to Keio and was seamless, was half expecting it not to turn up - and they pick the pram up from the hotel as well once we were done with it. The buffet breakfast which was included in our Tatami suite - was good for the 1st few days, but the menu DID NOT change at all - the same thing every single day - the variety not as good as other hotels we have stayed at e.g.. Shangri-la Hotels - so if they had a different dish every 2nd day or something, it would of made it better. The hotel was very large had about 7 + restaurants of which to dine from (only 3 of them can be used for the breakfast) - expensive compared to what you can get at the shops. As the hotel was so large I felt that I was just another customer, the staff were polite, but I wouldn't say warm, friendly or welcoming. The place we stayed at the ski resort - the service was impeccable and the staff were so nice and warm. At Keio they were just there to do there job. Every time we stay at the Shangri-la hotels (in Singapore, Malaysia) the staff are so nice and friendly and chat to you, ask you questions etc.. But this also could be a language/culture thing? anyway, I would probably try another hotel if I was to return to Shinjuku - it was great, but not AWESOME.. Our stay at Nozawa Onsen was AWESOME! The upside - they offered free shuttle bus to Disneyland and Disneysea - book in early though as they fill up real quick - and i would recommend the 630am time slot. Also they have a paid bus to and from Haneda airport.

The best thing about this premise is its central location, within walking distance to the heart of Shinjuku. Shopping and dining options are plentiful around the station area. Venture into the small alleys for excellent though often small ramen restaurants.With about 1,400 rooms, this hotel is often busy and crowded with large tour groups from China. So do not expect quiet or personal service. But I do have to mention the excellent service provided by the concierge desk. Helpful and patient despite the often challenging situations with less travelled patrons.The rooms are quite large by Tokyo standards and spotless.Another plus is the free shuttle bus to and from Disneyland Tokyo, do book in advance as they tend to fill up quickly.

Three couples stayed for 3 nights on our way to ski at Hakuba. We took a taxi from the airport to the hotel door as it worked out a similar price to the train. This review may be biased as we had booked the executive level with access to the club lounge. Our rooms on level 38 were large - king bed with lots of room either side, a couch at the end, a desk across one wall and a couple of comfy chairs. The bathroom was also large with a deep bath with shower over - big fluffy towels. Large cupboards with drawers, also an iron and board provided. A pod coffee maker plus tea making facilities. Everything was spotlessly clean. Checkin and checkout was quick with staff always polite and welcoming. We breakfasted in the buffet (Asian/Western) once and in the Western buffet twice. The choices were excellent and always fresh. We had one meal in a hotel restaurant - Chinese style food which was good quality and tasty but reasonably priced. Access to Shinjuku railway station was a 10 minute walk either through interesting streets or through an underground walkway. The surrounding area between the hotel and the station is a maze of good eateries and small street style shops. The hotel was a good choice for our brief stay.

You could not ask for a better location to stay in Tokyo than this hotel. 2 minutes walk to Shinjuku station, and the rest of Tokyo available from there. We stayed here for the Tokyo Marathon, and couldn't have asked for a better location. The service was amazing. I hurt my ankle several days before hand, and needed ice constantly. It was to our room almost before we had hung up the phone! We stayed in both towers, and the south tower, while a little older, is still nice, and the rooms a bit larger and include a couch. Could not find anything to fault!

Stayed at Keio Plaza for my first trip to Japan! Staff are generally friendly except for a couple grumpy faces which were definitely not a good representation of polite and friendly Japanese pple. I booked this hotel over Sunroute due to their gym. After I checked in, I realised the gym is located at main wing, which was quite a hassle coz I stayed in the south wing. End up I only visited the gym a couple times thru out my 8 days stay. Gym facilities are neat but not fantastic. Breakfast was really not worth it, think u can get better ones outside.

It was our first time staying at keio plaza and we were very impressed with their service. Upon arrival, the bellboy was quick to react and helped us with our luggages. He even made small talk with us and made us felt welcome. It's a pity I didn't get hold of his name then as I did not manage to see him on shift again. Another bellboy was nice and gifted us with a paper ball with bell for us to entertain our baby who's crying. They offered free cot for infants if you are traveling with babies. It's a walking distance from the shinjuku station but it's convenient enough for us as we need not climb any fleet of steps to get to the hotel. You may take the NEX airport transfer directly from Narita to the hotel. Keio plaza also offers bus transfer directly to the airport upon check out. Will definitely go back and stay at keio plaza again for our next trip to Tokyo.

Great trip travelling with friends for the Tokyo Marathon. The Marathon starts a stone's throw from the front of the hotel so is really a perfect place to stay if you are tackling the challenge. There are shuttle buses between the hotel and both Narita and Haneda hotels. Also a shuttle bus to Tokyo Disneyland. A good selection of in-hotel restaurants and a good view across from the bars. There is a special Hello Kitty themed room if that's your thing... The breakfast buffet is excellent.

We had a very nice room with a breathtaking view over Tokyo, everything was tidy and clean, as we espected from a place like this. Staff is very kind and helpful, they speak a very good english too.The choice of restaurants is good, both western cuisine or japanese, and all are at least very good if not excellent. Breakfast buffet is one of the biggest I ever saw.The only thing tah was disapponting was the vip luonge on top. We had the ionvitation ticket but coudn't try it because it closed too early in the evening (between 9 and 11 pm).

We stayed in this hotel as a good location for being picked up for some day tours we had organised. The hotel itself is well situated in the Shinjuku area, close to the train station and shops. It is quite a large hotel with many speciality restaurants that mean not having to walk too far to get a feed. Our room (a standard room) was a little on the smallish side but serviceable. Basic supplies and room services. Staff were eager to please, however we found the language barrier a bit of a problem for us. Very few staff speak or understand English which meant ordering drinks or meals required a bit of patience before our needs were understood. And this in our experience is not uncommon in many hotels of Tokyo, or indeed shops in general.Would we stay there again? Maybe the Ginza area would be better?

First visit in Japan and I like it so much! People are so clean and friendly. + close to subway. Less than 2 minute walk+ free shuttle bus to Disneyland and Disney sea+ friendy personnelTips:- bad weather is a big no-no. Check the weather before you go- go for a higher level in the hotel. View is amazing. If not, observation deck is open till 11pm- tips to personnel is not appreciated

The hotel is just 5 minutes by a walk from Shinjuku Station @west exit , and 2 minutes from Tochomae @Exit A2.We took the Limusine shuttle bus from Narita Airport about 3000 Yen per Person.( Discount 20% if use JCB credit card), so no need to carry our luggages. We stayed at the Deluxe room 2 nights, room is big and comfortable. We chose this hotel because it is close to "Highway bus station ( Bus for going to Kawaguchiko Mt.fuji). Only 5 mintues for a walk. There was a some malls and many restaurants surrouding the hotel. The most that we love this hotel is "The convenient store on 2nd floor where open until 2 a.m." i heard from my japanese friends that the cakes and restaurants in this hotel are famous. But i had no time to try it. Must try next time. The staffs are well trained,speak english very well,willing to help. They also offer the service from YAMATO transport. Sending luggage from hotel to hotel,or hotel to airport. One luggage is only about 1200 yen. So you no need to take your bug luggage with you if you wanna go to travel another city of japan... Btw, Love this hotel. Worth my money.

This place is very large and very busy. The hotel is made up of two accommodation sectors with one having more modern rooms than the other sector. The rooms are big and feel like you are getting what you pay for, (if your a large person get an upgraded room). i was disappointed by the bed which is too small (certainly by western standards). The food in the restaurant was of a poor standard and way too pricey. I would not stay here againTraveling around by train is easy from the local Shinjuku station.

We picked this hotel mainly because it was close to Shinjuku transport hub (Narita Express trains stop there and it is also part of the massive Tokyo train network. The room was clean and comfortable, the staff were helpful and friendly (nothing unusual about that in Japan), but the choice of food options, while extensive and of a high standard, was quite expensive for what was on offer. Still, a good hotel, especially if someone else is paying.

There are many things to like about this hotel, but it is not relaxing and it is not at all personal. With 1,400 rooms and numerous group tours from China it is busy and the first floor feels more like a train station than a hotel. The convenient location is an easy walk to the west exit of Shinjuku station. And the tower provides a good view of Tokyo and the surrounding office buildings and city hall. The 12 restaurants cover all the bases, although they are pricey compared to places a block or two away and some are hard to get into, with lines out the door. The standard rooms are not bad and a reasonable value.

This hotel was great. I stayed in a premier plaza room, which was a great size compared to other options. The shower had impressive water pressure, a nice change of pace from some of the other places I've stayed recently. The bed was a bit too hard for my taste but my fiance loved it. The hotel had plenty of restaurants to choose from, and tons of restaurants within walking distance if you're looking for a bigger selection. There's also a good size convenience store in the hotel for anything else. Breakfast was included with our stay, and was a good american style buffet that can't be overvalued. The staff was very helpful for any questions that we had. Overall, we had a great time and would definitely stay here again.

Good place to stay with very good rooms. Just spent 1 night at this place before heading back to Europe. Offers everything what is needed and main Tokyo spots are easy accessible by cab. Hotel staff is friendly and very supportive.

This is my third time to stay in keio plaza hotel and I chose the premier plaza level as I travel with my family and we want to have a much more enjoyable stay to forget the daily work and tight schedule temporary. We did quick check in at the plaza premier counter next to front desk and we were assigned to 39/f which is the top level of the premier plaza rooms as I request upper level floor during my reservation. But actually same view as my last stay in this hotel and the accomodation was almost the same as the renovated room, the main different should be much more safe staying in premier plaza rooms as we needa use the room keys to access to our level. The lounge was a little bit small but there are variety of choices for snacks and drinks, the stunning view of the lounge was also nice as we could see the tokyo tower from the lounge.Definitely will come back for my next stay in Tokyo, no matter with friends or my family!

This was my first time to Tokyo so it is a bit hard to make a comparison however I can say this was a good stay and no complaints. Lovely hotel, lives up to its luxury category. We had a standard room, it was spacious, a view of Mt Fuji, clean, and well appointed.Some Japanese oddities we had to get used to. Rules, you must obey them, for example, check-in is after 2pm so don't even contemplate lining up or trying earlier. You will be told to go away. Room cleaning, put your 'Make up my room' sign out. It's a very well ordered society so get used it, you will then enjoy Tokyo. Nice thing about this hotel is it's a safe haven for a Westerner but at the same time giving you the Japanese experience. The hotel has a number of restaurants so plenty of options to choose from. Two bars on the 48th floor which give wonderful views of Tokyo without outrageous drink prices. Location wise it's a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station which gives you access to the Metro and thus all of Tokyo for touring the day. Shinjuku has great shopping, restaurants, and quirky back streets to explore. I would go back to this hotel

All are good in Keio Plaza. The room is not too much bigger but quite comfortable with a king size bed. Restaurants are very amazing, different ways to eat Japanese food. The hotel in general is clean and the staff is very educated and polite. I will back in the future with family.

Beware when you book this hotel! This was my experience 5 minutes ago. I am in Tokyo with a group of friends celebrating a birthday. My friend booked a luxe premier room as she had favourable experiences when she stayed here a few years ago. On checking in, there is a special premier counter. The lady checking us in looked grumpy and service was not pleasant. On entering the room, my friend was a little shocked with the size of the room. She had booked it at ¥45,000 and another friend booked a regular room for ¥20,000. We compared the rooms and found them to be identical!!! I am truly dismayed that in these times that such dishonest practice can still surface! Lets see if we can sort this out!!

This hotel has been my favourite stay in Tokyo lately. Location is good, room is spacious, staff are super friendly and the food here in buffet breakfast is good.I have stayed here for a week and got upgraded. So I had the Japanese breakfast set instead of buffet which was also very good.My room was a bit noisy because of the wind (according to the staff) which kept me awake for 1 night but apart from that it was a very pleasant stay with extreme comfort.

The Keio Plaza is an enormous hotel with over 1,000 rooms so it's really busy all of the time, however despite reviews to the contrary, we found the check in procedure to be fast, efficient and friendly. You're also really conveniently located just outside of Shinjuku station - it's a 10 minute walk from the station through the underground shopping plaza in the direction of Tokyo Government Building which is right across the road (and has a great FREE observatory with fabulous views over Tokyo). The important thing to note about the Keio Plaza is that the rooms are refurbished to different standards, so you need to be aware of this when you book. You want a refurbished room in the south tower as these are really recently refurbished and are therefore much, much nicer. If there's a small/reasonable price difference, then it's worth paying it. The website is excellent though, and does tell you which rooms are in the main versus south tower, so read through the different room types carefully before you book. We were originally in a "renovated" room in the main tower but weren't really happy with it so we spoke to one of the managers who moved us first to another room in the main tower and then to a room in the south tower. I'm going to give the Keio Plaza 5/5 for customer service because this gentleman was extremely proactive in finding a solution to keep us - the customer - happy. He even sent a box of chocolates to our room which was a lovely gesture. You don't often find customer service like this anymore, especially not in such a big hotel. He really did go above and beyond. The room we ended up in was PERFECT - spotlessly clean and modern, enormous with twin beds and a chaise lounge to relax on, in-room wifi, a modern bathroom and powder room. It was everything we had hoped for, and more. So for the convenient location, outstanding customer service and fabulous room in the south tower, the Keio Plaza gets 5/5 from me.

Keio Plaza Hotel is a 4-star hotel that is conveniently located to 2 train stations (Shinjuku Station- 10 mins walk and Tochomae Station -right in front of the back entrance). I chose this hotel because I have heard of good reviews of this hotel from people who have stayed at this hotel and also because it was the only hotel in Tokyo that could fit in a triple-share room (according to my travel agent). The hotel has a large, spacious lobby with some sofa and chairs. We received a free upgrade to a bigger room that has a dresser, which was cool. The hotel staff were polite and helpful though not entirely fluent in English. Guest room was new, clean, odourless, and very comfortable. Housekeepers were very helpful although they were less conversant in English than the front desk staff. I managed to communicate with them through gesturing and used my basic Japanese language proficiency. Our travel package came with breakfast in the hotel, so we visited all three restaurants for breakfast. It was quite shocking to see that at 8.30am, the queues for all restaurants were very long! I have never seen guests queuing up to such an extent for breakfast before in other hotels (in other countries and my own country). Usually, the breakfast queue is short, with about 2-3 families queuing and they are often offered a table each in about 2-5mins. But for these 3 restaurants in Keio Plaza Hotel, the wait can be up to 20mins to get in! It was ok for us because we were not in a mighty big rush but having to queue for so long for breakfast was perturbing. The hotel stationed some staff to try to ease the queues by asking guests in the queue if they would like to head to a shorter queue of another restaurant but no one moved. The longest queue observed for all four mornings that I was there was the Glass Court's Super Buffet. I think this is overly hyped up because it is still a breakfast buffet but it is probably marketed as a 'super' buffet because it has porridge (Jurin only serves rice), Japanese roasted tea, Japanese natto, and a couple of variety of cakes. Otherwise, I would think that Jurin would suffice for breakfast because it also serves a sumptuous buffet spread. Both Glass Court and Jurin have egg stations so you can ask the chef to fry scrambled eggs, omelettes (you get to choose the ingredients inside) or sunny side-ups. Onsen eggs are available in the buffet spread. For those who have not tried a genuinely Japanese breakfast before, be sure to head to Kagari, the Japanese restaurant that serves Japanese breakfast by individual sets. You will be asked if you would like rice or porridge and then you wait to be served. Japanese breakfast sets are very intricate because they have small side dishes all neatly stored in colourful porcelain ware. These make the dining experience very exciting and intriguing because you get to taste different types of small side dishes such as candied walnuts with anchovies and preserved vegetables. For drinks, you can get them from an open area which serves juices, coffee/tea, and water. This hotel has a very good marketing strategy. I was given a membership card when I checked in. This is enticing. Well, also, I have stayed in another hotel in Tokyo before so I really appreciate Keio Plaza for being larger, cleaner, more spacious and and more Japanese. A positive mention of the hotel's bell desk. They are highly organised and neat. Guests who arrived at the hotel earlier than the check in time could leave their luggage with the bell desk. Staff at the bell desk will tag each piece of luggage and wheel them into a secured area that looks something like a warehouse, to store them. We passed them our luggage when we checked out at 545am and headed for breakfast at 6am. When we returned to the lobby to wait for our bus limousine, the staff had already helped us wheel the luggage out and placed them neatly together. These staff are not men only; there are young ladies who have a lot of strength to carry, hoist and push many suitcases at a go too! This was impressive. I hardly see females working at the bell desk because suitcases and luggage may be too daunting for them but for the Japanese bell desk staff, they are superb!

Excellent hotel with great staff and full amenities. Location is excellent for business and for tourism. About one hour to Shinjuku area from Narita (90 minutes if traffic is heavy) and half that time from Haneda - use the Friendly Buss as easiest way. You have to just slow down and be patient with staff in restaurants - no one rushes

We stayed in this hotel for about 5D/4N as given the convenience of the subway just under the hotel and had free daily shuttle bus to/from Disneyland. There is also a convenient mini-mart downstairs for last minute needs or snacks. We had a beautiful view of Mt Fuji on a clear day.The rooms are very spacious and the warm toilet seats are a great novelty. Only thing was the mattresses were too firm for my husband and he complained of a backache end of the day else it would have been perfect.Staff are friendly and helpful. Location is great is very central to all areas in Shinjuku like the major train and railway stops.

Been staying here twice during my business trip, both are good experience.One time, i got placed in a dated room, very outdated style without view. Room are big and tidy tho.Another time, i was place in a huge room, with nice view and abit modern type facing the swimming pool. I enjoyed both of my stay. As for Tokyo standard, for the price, it is quite valuable for what we paid, especially the size of rooms.

Stayed 2 separate nights in Feb 2016. Spoilt on the first night with an upgraded room (from "standard") in the South Tower with views towards Mt Fuji- good mattress, thick blanket, higher-end toiletries, renovated bathroom, coffee & coffee cups, etc.Came second night in a "standard" room in North Tower and was surprised to find mattress that has seen better days; blanket that is old & thin and not even of the Vinnies' standard; toiletries that any Japanese country town hotel would beat hands down; bathroom that belongs in the eighties; no coffee or coffee cups. Come on- this is not a hotel in Tokyo outskirts.To be fair, the room size is of 5* standard. it's clean & quiet. Hotel staff very conversant in English, friendly & obliging.Was going to give 5*+ for the review if not the experience of the second night.

My stay was generally good except for:- being charged ¥6,000 for 2nd occupant in a queen room. I travel alot, but have never been charged for 2nd occupant.- language barrier during check in. Staff didn't understand I was looking for convenient store outside of hotel. - breakfast wasn't worth the money. Basic English buffet breakfast. I would of recommend this hotel only if cost is a consideration.

Book name brand hotel like IHG, Hiton, Marriott. My room looked like it was last renovated in the 80s with big stain on the floor that made me feel uncomfortable walking barefoot on floor. Do yourself a favor and stay away from this place

I was there for three days on a travel trip through Japan.The service was very good, and the facilities grandios.It had many restaurants with many propositions and it has some shops in it.The rooms are extra big, with big beds. It offered 1l water every day, and the bathroom supplies were very nice.It had every supply in the room it needed and you could ask what you wanted.It was also very clean and tidy

We stayed in Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo couple month ago, the hotel very good, the location was great. The hotel was large, clean and welcoming staff. Everything going well and we would recommended Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo to everyone.

A superb high quality hotel …. most japan hotel rooms are rather small but the room i have is large, clean and super comfortable … the only setback is the long wait at the check-in counter as it is always very crowded with guests checking in even though the hotel have many staff handling the guests at the check-in counters … this is a very big hotel and they r doing their best to make their guests as comfortable as possible ...the location is also good as it is situated in Shinjuku area and a 5-8 mins walk to the station .. Shinjuku Station is a hub and it is always very crowded with locals as well as tourists … though it is crowded with ppl in the station, you will never feel intimated and japanese are always very friendly and courteous … the airport limousine bus stop right at the hotel thus going to and fro to the airport is very convenient …lots of shopping and eateries in shinjuku area and u can never feel bored …

Stayed here for a couple of nights in January 2016. This is a HUGE hotel - absolutely massive - can mean that there are long queues are reception but they move people through with polite and efficient Japanese courtesy.Rooms are a very good size for a Tokyo hotel and there is a large range of restaurants and bars to chose from. There is also a bakery and convenience store in the basement level.Really handy to the main Shinjuku stations, and lots of dining options all around you.Couldn't fault the place - good value, good sized rooms, good location, and good amenities within the hotel itself. Would definitely stay here again.
user_name:
dbtripper
Mount Barney National Park, Australia

review_body: The hotel was large and clean upon a very late arrival. We were greeted by friendly staff who seemed to be plentiful no matter the time of day. We booked two rooms despite not being on the same floor we were in the same building which was easier. The rooms are quaint with enough room to be comfortable for the small amount of time spent there per day. The bathrooms are a bit small and could use a renovation. The breakfast buffet was relatively good for the price and had a selection of western and Japanese food. The location is fantastic with only a 5-10 minute walk to the Shinjuku Station and less than 5 min walk to the free Tokyo Government Metropolitan Building for stunning panoramic city views. The night life near the hotel is somewhat lacking and a solid walk out of the electronic shopping district will take you to the parts of Shinjuku with more food options. In all the hotel was great and would definitely stay there again.

And don't book through your travel agent who booked us into a premier room that we didn't need. With taxes the room was close to $400 USD a night. Book this yourself on trip advisor or some such. The rates we paid are more than double the asking price. That said, the staff was helpful when we came in on a red eye...early in the AM...you should know that rooms are not available until 2 pm. They managed to get us a room at noon and sent us to their premier lounge to wait for two hours. Our room was clean and comfortable and beautifully appointed. But I'd bet a room below the premier floors are just as nice. Also, no one warned us that a cab from Narita to hotel would be over $200 in a metered taxi. Tokyo is clean and beautiful but price wise it's even worse than NY.
user_name:
Joanne o
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel lives up to its 4-star status easily. Staff are very friendly and helpful, the hotel is immaculately clean and is very close to Shinjuku station - about 10 minutes walk (under cover) when you learn the layout. Allow at least 20 -30 minutes the first time around! Shinjuku is BIG. Staff are all able to communicate adequately in English, or are able to refer to someone who has the ability for more complex questions.There are several restaurants "in-house" offering a variety of food styles - tepanyaki, korean, italian, casual etc. - and there are many other eating places close by. The hotel food prices are rather steep, but in line with expectations for this level of accommodation, ranging from Y2500 to Y10,000. The breakfast buffet is highly recommended.There is a small convenience store on Level 1 in the South Tower which is well stocked with food and drink items and toiletries, and reasonably priced.My only negative comment is that, like all shops and hotels that i visited in Japan, the heating was rather too high in the public areas (in winter). Room air conditioning was adjustable and very adequate.On the other side, elevators are quick and quiet, and the free wi-fi is very fast.We were holidaying in Japan for 3 weeks and stayed here for 3 nights each arriving and departing. I will stay there again on my next visit.

If you're staying in the Shinjuku area, and want easy no brainer travel from the hotel to Haneda airport, this is one hotel you can consider. The airport has bus routes which stop at this hotel. Of course, this isn't the only hotel covered, but this hotel is closest walk to the maze called Shinjuku station.  A 10 minute partial covered walk will take you the the large crazy maze. However, there are ample shopping and eating places in the area, so no worries for boredom!However, the hotel is large, filled with tourists, and unfortunately they can get a bit loud. The old wing has walls that don't particularly block the sound, so a late night mother daughter argument was very well articulated. Most are staying here for the same reason I was, - easy access. So if luxury, discreet and a more calm atmosphere is what you want.. look elsewhere.Breakfast options were divided into many areas, but for Western fare, pick 'super buffet'. More variety, except that it doesn't change. Room service was prompt and rooms were cleaned spotlessly daily. Size was pretty decent (twin room). Toilet and bath are large for hotel standards. Quite a few plugs to handle the ipad, iphones, camera chargers and whatnot. Wifi was a bit spotty, so get a SIM data card to avoid frustration.The bar at the top floor had great views of the Tokyo skyline & the Metropolitan Govt building, but the drinks were not cheap. Seek alternatives.Tip: from Haneda airport consider buying the hotel airport + 3 day tokyo metro pass (does not include JR) if you plan to seriously trek around and shopTip2: Reserve your bus seat back to Haneda airport once you checked in. Don't leave it for the last minute.

It is a clean and quiet 5 star hotel. Walking distance to subway and supermarket. The staff are very kind. The rooms are big. The Western breakfast finishes at 9:30 but the Japanese breakfast continues until 10:30 and it is excellent. WiFi is extremely fast and free. I would stay there again.

Classy hotel in centre of Shinjuku.Perfect for sightseeing,shopping etc.Easy to get around for meals,excellent transport links etc Luxurious,spacious clean room.Bathroom of high standard with great linen..

Checked in and realised our request for non-smoking floor was not forwarded by booking website. However the staff was very helpful and transfer us to the non-smoking rooms the next day. Best of all we just have to pack our bags and leave in the rooms while we went out to enjoy ourselves. When we came back our bags including some items we forgot to pack were in the new rooms. Fantastic!

Starting with the many positives:- location. Central, 5 mins to Shinjuku and on top of a subway station, surrounded by restaurants and shops. Can't be beaten for convenience. Airport bus drops you at the hotel. - breakfast. Choice of 3 restaurants, we always ate at Jurin. Great choice, and we never queued. - convenience shop and cake shop in the basement; great for buying milk for our baby and midnight snacks!!- fantastic nursing room on the lobby floor, with microwave you can use for sterilising etc. Also a nursery on 30th floor; we didn't use it but nice to at least have a room for kids to run about in. And a few major downsides:- they point blank refused to accommodate our 1 year old baby. In advance I e-mailed the hotel to ask if they could provide a travel cot. They told me no as not enough space. So I said ok, please could you provide a mattress on the floor. They again said no. So I said ok no problem, we will bring our own. They AGAIN said no, saying it was against their policy!! They would only provide a bed rail so that our wriggly 1 year old could share the small double bed with me (pregnant) and my husband. When we arrived our room was very large and had a space of at least 6x4m next to the bed, so I was pleased we had ignored their e-mails and brought our own solution. But I am staggered they would refuse to provide any type of bedding for a baby (even if they charged it would be OK). We have travelled to a huge variety of countries and hotels almost monthly since my son was born and this is the first time I have ever experienced anything like this. - cleanliness. The room was very dated and needed renovation; carpets were grubby, walls heavily marked, furniture old. It had clearly been cleaned before we arrived but it is too old really. And they left a dirty cup in the room for 2 days; not a big deal but I don't think cleanliness is high on their list. Bathroom was a bit better. - staff variable. Some were lovely and very helpful, others acted like they couldn't wait to be rid of you. All were polite, just some were friendlier than others.

stayed in the plaza luxe king room, renovated south tower. room was excellent, clean and spacious bathroom with separate shower. recently refurbished. good size for family of 2 adults and 2 kids under 6. service all round is good. access to Luxe lounge came with the room. but the selection of light snacks was extremely limited, one of the smallest selection i've seen in a hotel private lounge. i've seen better stocked office pantries. Had dinner at the Italian restaurant (Duo Fourchettes) - we had one of the best pizzas (4 cheeses...mmm... yummy!) in our life there. pricey, but worth every penny. perfect thin crust with a slight chewiness. generous portion of cheese without being overwhelming. served with a side of honey. excellent harmony of flavours, kudos to the chef. There's only thing that fell short of our expectations: when we called housekeeping to request for more bottled water for the room, we were told there was a limit of 2 bottles per room per day. Seriously?? i'm knocking 1 star off the rating for this. no skin off my back to go downstairs to buy some water from the convenience store on the ground floor. its a really small detail, but i expected more from Keio Plaza; this isn't Sunroute Plaza or Washington Shinjuku. neutral point - late checkout was denied. checkout at 11am. not a big issue as we could leave our bags with the concierge. overall the staff, room and restaurant were great. but hotel management needs to look into their policy on bottled water. and maybe better selection of snacks for the luxe lounge. tips: 1.if you're too lazy to walk to shinjuku station, take the train from Tochomae station (Oedo line) which is just outside the hotel. its one stop to shinjuku. great if you have kids who are always moaning "I'm so tired, i don't want to walk..."2. there's a FANTASTIC playground at Shinjuku park, great for kids from 2-12. ask the staff for directions. its a short walk, about 500m from the hotel. no moaning from the kids when walking to the playground.

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights and had a great time. When we walked into the hotel with our luggage we didn't have anyone to help us,we were not greeted which was a bit disappointing but then we were seen after a good 10mins . I think it's because they had a lot going on. It's in a great location with a nice Chinese restaurent! Staff are attentive and lovely. And our room was spacious and clean. I'll definitely be back! Thank you Keio Plaza

Medium size rooms that need a make-over. Rooms service was great.Restaurants are over-priced.Bar is dark, singly and tacky.The hotel is huge and it feels like you're walking through Central station most of the time.The convenience store downstairs is great for cheap alcohol and snacks.If you want a warm, friendly hotel, I don't recommend this hotel.

We cued at check in, at breakfast, at the gym and at check out. It's like a huge factory with rather unprofessional service. Location was great but that was about it. On arrival they could not find the reservation...etc

Having stayed at the Keio many times it is always a please to return.Being a big hotel it does have a cozy, small hotel feeling.Location is tops and a very short walk to Shinjuku Station.Kudos to the staff. Very service oriented and always with a smile.

The size of the hotel room in comparison to what you would normally get in Tokyo is what drew me to this hotel. That and it's location.However, I won't be back in a hurry.We stayed in the Plaza Premier in the main tower and whilst it's suppose to be a premium room, the experience was far from. Bathroom is extremely dated, didn't feel all that clean, smelt like sewerage after flushing and sheets were 'crunchy' ie. I could hear myself turn in the night because my flat sheet cracked and creaked!

This is my second stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel (first time was in 2008). This visit was excellent and did not disappoint, just like my first visit. My husband and I stayed for 6 nights and booked the “Business Plaza King” package (came with king bed, wi-fi and breakfast every morning). Below are some of my many reasons why we love the Keio Plaza: - Our room, with a king size bed was spacious, clean and quiet. Came with nice amenities and the bathroom was large with a nice pressurized shower head. The room was very comfortable. - The hotel staff was always courteous and helpful. - Conveniently located right by Shinjuku station that will pretty much get you anywhere you need to go. (We bought a Passmo and basically took the JR and subway all over town.) - Food and shopping available right across the street. - Easy to get to and from Narita with the Airport Limousine Bus dropping us right off at the front door.- Keio offers a free round-trip shuttle bus to and from the Disneyland resort (which we took advantage of). You just need to reserve your seats in advance. - We also took a day-trip tour to Mt. Fuji and surrounding areas where the guide picked us (and others) up right at the hotel. We would definitely stay here in the future again.

My brother and I stayed at Keio Plaza hotel for a total of 4 nights. The hotel staff was lovely, especially at the reception and concierge. However, we went to one of the Japanese breakfast place on level 2 and thought the food could be improved. The food was evidently cooked the night before and been stored in the fridge. The fish and tamagoyaki I had was cold. I think you are better off going to glass court with their buffet breakfast even if it means waiting in the line. Also the walls are very thin so on our last night we could hear the room either next or above us making loud noises and didn't sleep very well at all. Overall I was satisfied with the service and the cleanliness of the hotel. Also note that if you exit from Shinjuku station make sure to exit via the west exit, there are signs that will tell you and if you can't see any, follow the sign towards the Tokyo metropolitan government building, the hotel is right before that.

The hotel is very central to shinjuku, with the train station being only about a 7 minute walk away. The concierge is very helpful and staff very polite. Quite a choice in hotel restaurants. There is a small convenience store on the ground floor which makes picking up food or toiletries when not bothered to leave the hotel very easy. The rooms are very nice, and the view from one side of the building is stunning - Mt Fuji is lovely to wake up to. Would definitely recommend !

Great place to stay ib city center. the rooms are just great. the breakfast and diner where out standing.The service was exelent. we loved to stay in this hotel very much and will stay there on our next trip/

Great rates for a triple bedroom which had enough room for three adults to maneuver suitcases and stay relatively comfortable. We didn't eat at the hotel, but we should have- heard that the sushi restaurant was one of the best in town. It's an enormous hotel, popular with tour groups. They're very efficient with check in and out and were able to check us in at 1 pm.

We stayed in two rooms (two adults and two teenage children) on the 26th floor of the Main Tower. We requested renovated rooms and I think the rooms were renovated, but the bathrooms seemed quite dated although it was all impeccably clean. We also requested non smoking rooms, which we got, and a view of Mt Fuji, which we didn't get. The rooms, beds and bathrooms are Western style. There is wifi, a TV, kettle, Japanese green tea bags and coffee and a bar fridge. We arrived at about 8pm and our check in was quick, as was our check out at about 9am a week later. We experienced none of the queues that other reviews mention. We purchased a variety of items from the handy convenience store in the basement of the South Tower and had breakfast at the Super Buffet Glass Court. The buffet was quite good value with a huge array of food,Western and Asian, at 3000yen per person. I am coeliac and brought my own bread to eat at breakfast as, when I phoned the hotel in advance to ask,they told me that their gluten free bread contained wheat! I don't think they have an understanding of what gluten free is. The location of the hotel is superb. Just outside the back entrance to the hotel is a tunnel through which a five minute walk will take you to the West Gate Underground Plaza part of the very convenient Shinjuku station, from where you can go to just about anywhere in Tokyo. Behind the hotel is the Tokyo Metropolitan Goverrnment building, you can go up for free to observation decks in each of the two towers to see stunning views. This is better, in my opinion, than going up Tokyo Tower or Skytree as you can see both of these attractions rather than being in them. We could even see Mt. Fuji on the day we went. Shinjuku post office is 200 metres from the hotel and you can use international cards at the ATMs there. There are many restaurants near the hotel, and even a pachinko place, although we often ate in the restaurants in the department stores at Shinjuku station. We used the laundry service, a week's worth of washing for the four of us was 140,000 yen. Everything was returned in impeccable condition, individually folded with tissue paper and then wrapped in plastic. While the hotel is enormous and, as a result, quite impersonal, the wonderful location makes this a great choice.

Keio Plaza has clean, comfortable and spacious premier rooms. Airport bus limousine stops at this hotel. Their staff can speak in English. It is a great hotel in Shinjuku area. Note that hotel location is about 8 minutes walk to the JR Yamanote line and major shops.

We stayed here with our one year old in January 2016. They were very helpful with arranging a cot, and the nursing room downstairs was second to none with everything you might need. The hotel room was clean and average sized, impressive for Tokyo standards. Walking distance to restaurants and bars. Good free wifi as well.

The hotel is in. Good location, about a 5 minute walk from the station via tunnel which is handy when it is snowing. Staff were very helpful and answered all of our questions. Our room had 4 single beds and an ensuite with separate vanity room. It was enough for our family of 4, but we didn't spend much time in the room.Generally a pretty good choice for someone looking to explore from a central location, in a western style of accommodation. Shinjuku is a great place to wander around and shop. There are great department stores and lots of options for food.

We found ourselves in Tokyo earlier than expected and we booked this at the last minute. This is a great location right near the Shinjuku station although it's about a 10 minute from the West exit. The rooms are modern and I don't think the rooms were that small. Two people can manage comfortably with carry-ons. They have a beat selection of restaurants. There breakfast buffet can satisfy many different tastes both Western and Asian.

Stayed here for 3 nights, we slept in the Kitty Princess & Kitty Town Room. Few breakfast restaurant choice, we opt for Kitty breakfast, Japanese and American Buffet during our stay. Enjoyed our stay in this hotel, strategically located in the Shinjuku district. My favorite room is the Kitty Town room, even though my travel partner is the Hello Kitty fanatic.

We stayed for 3 days over New Year and enjoyed it very much. It's everything you need, done to an excellent standard: room size, view (we were on the 24th floor towards the wonderful Tokyo Government building and with clear view of a snow-capped Fuji - don't expect the latter outside of clear winter days), service, quiet, cleanliness. Breakfast comprised an excellent, large and very varied buffet with both western and Japanese dishes on offer (we didn't eat in any of the restaurants as there are other many others a short walk away). In short, everything you'd want for a high-standard business . It's by no means horrid aesthetically but don't expect the exquisite - this is downtown Tokyo. It's vast, and designed very well to cope with large numbers of people. It is clearly very well managed. Staff were mainly Japanese speaking but so nice I doubt there would be communication problems as long as you are polite in turn. The hotel's location near Shinjuku station is outstanding for travelling both within Tokyo and beyond, and that was a major reason we chose it (besides its very good reputation which my wife already knew from working in Tokyo). Views are from our hotel room and of and from the top floor restaurant in the Main Tower.

We spent 4 days in Tokyo and stayed at Keio Place. We are a family of four and because we could get a family room, even though we booked 4 months in advance we had two interconnecting rooms. As you would expect the rooms are very small in Toky hotels, but the lobby's restaurants are huge. As you come into the Lobby the Hotel makes a great impression. However our rooms were very dated in terms of the fittings and appliances (radio, kettle, tv etc.). However, the rooms were very very clean which is probably more important. Staff were exceptionally helpful and went out of their way to help whenever they could. The location is about 6 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station (major hub). Renowned for great restaurants and shops. I would probably stay in this district again, but would investigate other hotels for value for money and amenities. The beds are very hard and the pillows are not great, so I didnt sleep particularly well here, but thats all personal preference.

We stayed here on our last night in Tokyo before flying home so decided not to splurge. Given the price we probably got a fair value but I likely wouldn't stay here again. Lobby area was nice enough. The room itself was a bit small and felt pretty old and needed to be updated. I had seen pictures of other rooms that looked more modern so perhaps it was just the luck of the draw - we stayed in the main tower. One positive was that we had a pretty nice view. We've previously stayed at the Hilton and the Hyatt in Tokyo and I would say that while the Keio Plaza's location is better, the rooms themselves leave something to be desired.I think next time I'll make a point to stay at an American hotel chain - I've noticed that those tend to be more spacious, both the room itself and especially the bathroom.

A great hotel close to Shinjuku station. Great buffet breakfast and a range of restaurants within hotel. Rooms very clean and spacious bathroom. Would definitely recommend this hotel! Some good restaurants within walking distance from the hotel. We took the limosino bus from Narita airport, which takes you to the hotel doorstep- very easy! Approx $30aud pp

There are two towers as part of this hotel - the main tower and the south tower. We booked a superior room and was given a room in the south tower. Note that there is a huge disparity in the quality of the two towers - the elevator to the south tower looks like a service elevator (the rooms are equally outdated). Also, as of Jan. 2016, there were renovations ongoing in the south tower (at least on our floor), and it was very noisy from 10 am - 4 pm. They said they were fully booked and could not move us to another floor. The staff also do not speak adequate English, so communicating with them on simple questions (e.g. wake up call, airport shuttle) was difficult. This was not a pleasant experience for us, and we will not stay here again. On a positive note, however, the food at the breakfast buffet was excellent. They have both western and japanese food options at breakfast.

It's a great hotel for business people because the hotel provides a lot business services for them. By the way, Kieo Plaza Hotel has a nice location.
