Airport shuttle bus could be easily taken in Kieo Plaza Hotel. It's near to the JR and subway station. There're some convenience store, pharmacy, electrical store and various food shops nearby. Those shops close in the mid-night. Therefore, you can still enjoy your dinner when you shop in the late night. However, the air-conditioning system in the room was not performed very well. It was cold sometimes and hot sometimes, even nothing have been changed. All in all, Fuji Mountain could be seen surprisingly in the room.

If you like to sleep in a nice cool room with Airconditioning then avoid this hotel . If you want to lose weight then come here and sweat it out in your room . The hotel is set at a temperature of 26 degrees Celsius and there is nothing less than that. In addition if you like to keep fit on your holidays . The gym here is 2 running machines and a bike and the pool is closed. This is. 4 and half star hotel . I really do not understand why??? Satisfaction here is poor.

Hotel is nice, has good facilities and is centrally located for Shinjuku Station and surrounding area.Service was prompt and friendly and room was very comfortable and clean with great views (we could clearly see Mt Fuji from our room in the South Tower). Wifi was lightening quick!Beds and pillows are hard was our only complaint but that is just personal preference.I would definitely stay here again for the price.

We are presently 2 nights into a 3 night stay at this hotel. It is extremely well located to access Shinjuku but just far enough out of the really busy area to be really relaxing. It is about a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku station. The hotel is recently renovated, clean and well appointed. Staff are very friendly and helpful, and cannot do enough to assist guests. We are loving our stay. We would also strongly recommend this hotel to all travellers.

Great location, short walk to the train lines. Staff understands English and communicates well. Clean and comfortable hotel. They have quite a lot of restaurants you can choose from. Personally tried both the teppanyaki restaurant and the Italian restaurant, both were good but I'd recommend the teppanyaki one although a tad more expensive. A great convenience store below the lobby as well which has some pretty decent bento boxes that you can ask them to heat up for you if you wish.

Stayed here as a family of 6 - children aged 13, 11, 9 & 8. Although a bit soulless, our rooms were spacious, comfortable and clean. We had superior twin rooms w a sofa bed made up in each. The sofa bed was less comfortable than the usual hotel roll-in bed. The location was fantastic to use as a base for exploring Tokyo. This was very important to us. The hotel offers free shuttles to Tokyo Disney and a charged airport limousine service that transports you to Narita (2 hours) & Haneda (1 hour). We had the buffet breakfast (which opens at 0500) and the spread put on was generous. I didn't have the booking or check-in issues others have mentioned. However I usually email book my reservations as I find that most hotel websites are unable to cope with family bookings. Our check-in was smooth and prompt despite it being quite busy.

We stayed here for one night as a pre cruise hotel recommended by Celebrity Cruises.The hotel was fine although perhaps would not rate it as four star. We arrived late morning but were kept waiting for at least 3 or 4 hours by the hotel staff before being allowed to check in. The hotel location is fine for walking into the local shopping area and the overall experience was fine.

We really regretted choosing this hotel especially after an excellent and highly- recommended stay at Hilton Tokyo.Problem began upon check-in, the room we had booked via the hotel's own websites can NOT accommodate 2 adults and 1 child 11 years old. The lady at the reception told me that children are only for kids under 5 years of age. Therefore she said instead, i should have chosen 3 adults in the option. What the heck?? She did apologize profusely that the hotel's reservation website does not state so.Second, despite booking a bigger room called plaza premier, the room can not accommodate 3 'adults' but funny enough, the smaller superior twin can. Thus, need to cancel my plaza premier reservation and change to superior twin...BIG surprise.. The receptionist couldn't cancel it for me directly from the hotel's system. Solution: i need to go online and cancel it hence she can rebook me in the renovated superior twin from the hotel's system. Okay...Third, i found out that the rate she quoted me was higher rate than hotel's own website. Told her that and she said she could not match the online rate. So guess what? Despite being right in front of the check-in counter, i need to go online again to reserve same room with lower rate.Fourth, after check-in, we asked for 2 additional bottle of water, and the answer is flat NO. 1 bottle per person per stay. I have never encountered this ridiculous problem before in all the hotels we ever stayed. So draw your own conclusion whether it is worth to spend your money to stay here. The only thing this hotel has is its location, 5 minute walk to Shinjuku station. The room is bare and average, dated bathroom, thin paper towels; i really wonder why it commands such a high rating in TA.
user_name:
NateyDot
New York City, New York

review_body: Japanese hotels are typically pretty small but this room had plenty of space and was conveniently located, with plenty of things to see and do (and most importantly, EAT) in the immediate area, plus public transport options.

Well...i read some reviews on this site before making my reservation. My first impression when i walked into the lobby was...WOW such a big hotel!This hotel has North and south wing and i was in the south wing. I dont find the room impressive, quite a run down hotel, perhaps i came from Sapporo hotel and in comparison, it look average to me.It 5min walks to dinning places and further down you reach Shinjuku Station, which have lots of shopping.Personally, i don't think is a good location for family with Kids (teenage). Is more of a commercial area, if i am here for business, I would rate it as a great hotel.

Keio plaza hotel Great hotel , loved our stay here . I read other reviews and was a little scared but it was a fantastic stay . Rooms were clean and spacious . The room service very expensive and not really willing to go out of their way for anything. Go downstairs to the restaurants . They were a bit pricey to but included breakfast was amazing a highlight to the start of the day. We stayed 5 days and check in and out was quick efficient and friendly .

We chose this hotel because it was a Good Neighbour hotel to Disney and provided a free shuttle to the Disney resorts, yet wanted to a downtown Tokyo location. It's nearer to Shinjuku station than the Hilton where I stayed the last time, though not as cozy. The staff were unfailingly helpful and polite though.

Right in the middle of shinjuku area, this hotel is one huge facility. Lots of dining places at the lobby which boasts of different cuisines. Check-in was smooth, despite coming in on a bust time, it took them less than 15 mins to check us in. Front desk are well spoken and efficient. The rooms, despite being small (normal in japan) was spectaculary clean and cozy. Expect typical japanese ingenuity when using the toilet. The area itself is perfect, you can go out and explore shinjuku . Did i mention we had the best view? Looking over shinjuku skyline and park, its like seeing central park from outside our window. Dining and SHopping haven at its best. We enjoyed it so much we planned to stay here again when visiting tokyo.

We booked two superior rooms as we had 5 people ( 2 adults, 3 children). The rooms were spacious by Japanese standards and very modern. The hotel was HUGE - there are two towers with different lifts. We didn't eat at any restaurants and chose to get food from the convenient store on the back of the lobby as it was cheaper and had a lot of choice. The only issue was the lack of seating in any of the lobby area. The location of this hotel was particularly appealing as it was close to Shinjuku station and various other tourist locations. By warned about the bars - they are very smokey, so if you're a non-smoker this isn't very pleasant ( Japanese have differnt smoking laws to Australia)

We had a Christmas dinner buffet at the restaurant of KEIO PLAZA HOTEL.Today's special were the 'foie gras' and 'slice of roast beef',nice and beautiful.But, others were so terrible. Boiled crabs were dried, appetizers were just salty, cakes were... just piece of cakes.The price was 8300 yen/person.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is a nice hotel and a good place to stay. It's close to Shinjuku Station, department stores and restaurants. The hotel is clean and the layout of the rooms is pretty similar to what you would get at a hotel like the Hilton. If you're wanting a more traditional experience, it probably isn't the place for you, but if you don't mind it looking like every other fancy hotel in every other capital city, then this place is perfect.

We arrived in Tokyo a day after our family checked in. Got in at 1230PM and was politely informed by concierge that check in time was still at 2PM, which was totally ok with us. Though I did try at the front desk and and I mentioned that we had family already checked in, the receptionist did not hesitate in finding us a room right away. Nice location if you like to walk a bit (which we do), about 10 minutes walk from downtown Shinjuku. Free wifi was great!

Family of 4 including two late teenagers. We do enjoy this hotel. Spacious, clean rooms. Unfortunately, there is a new, tall building opposite so we were only able to see HALF of Mt. Fuji this time:(. However, excellent location within an easy walk from Shinjuku station... even with suitcases as there are lifts at the station. Staff were attentive as ever, spoke good English and the breakfast was very vast and tasty too. There are only 3 choices, but we ate in Golden Court - serving both Japanese and Western breakfasts. It does get busy, however, so try to get there early :) Overall, good value and, again, a great location. Only pity is that their swimming pool is outdoors and so closed for Winter. A great shame.Also, we were here after skiing in Nagano prefecture. We bought JR East Flexible 5-Day Pass beforehand (Yen 22,000 each) and we were able to use them to get around Tokyo including Shinjuku, Shibuya, Akihabara, Ikebukuro and Yoyogi Park... so did not need to buy a separate ticket for the Subway system.

This is the second time which we stayed at Keio, first being about 3 years ago. We were pleasantly surprised when we checked in at the hotel on 27 Dec - we had a free upgrade to the room with a king sized bed! Room was in the south tower. High floor, very spacious room and looks new. Suspect that this is the newly upgraded/refurbished tower given that my impression of the rooms was one which was older and a little outdated. But this room was definitely new! Location wise was alright - about 5 to 7 mins walk from the Shinjuku main station. Also conveniently located near all the restaurants in shinjuku area, very very convenient. Would recommend this to all!

We stayed here as our base in Tokyo for four nights and enjoyed its location a lot, with easy walk to Shinjuku station and therefore trains anywhere.The beds and pillows were hard (welcome to Japan!) but everything was as you'd expect in a hotel like this. Our views from the 29th floor were particularly spectacular.The breakfasts were fine, and the Ramen we had one night was really good. Hotel was always busy; queues for check-in and check-out seem to be the norm.

This is not the first time I had stayed in this hotel. I chose this mainly because of location, as it is within Shinjuku, with a reasonably walkable distance from the Shinjuku JR station. We were allocated hotel rooms on the 17th floor in the South tower, and we stayed for 3 nights. The rooms were rather dated and badly in need of renovation. We were allocated better rooms in the previous two stays, where the rooms were renovated.During check-in, I was given the Executive Card, which provided some benefits for its members, including an access to the Luxe Lounge. However, when I tried accessing the Luxe Lounge, the entry was refused, and as I tried to enquire further about the terms and conditions, the staff did not want to explain and referred me to speak to the front desk instead. The attitude was not what I was expecting from a Japanese hotel. This time the overall experience was rather a put-off. Comparing this hotel with the other two hotels within walking distance from Keio Plaza, I would rather choose the other two, at least for the service of the staff. Given the experience, I might have to think twice or thrice coming back to this hotel for my next trip.

We had a very pleasant stay at Keio. The staff were so courteous. We were left by the Disney shuttle and they can't stop apologizing for it. The lady in-charge even sent us a gift for the inconvenience it brought us. The concierge are very helpful with directions on where you want to go or what you want to see.

I have stayed here many times and found this hotel quite large, well managed and have good standard. However, the size of hotel brings lots of guests so very crowded. The breakfast rooms has line but serve good food. Location is a bit walk to Shinjuku JR station. Standard room is quite tight but ok considering Japanese standard. I prefer to stay at JR Blossom. It's newer, and calmer.

Stay at this hotel for 3 nights . Big hotel with big lobby but breakfast was average. Room quite spacious. Bed was hard. TV channel most are japanese. Location was good near department store and shinjuku station. Good hotel if you looking for crowded surrounding and lively nightlife

The hotel and room was amazing, except for the very small bathrooms which made the stay less comfortable than any of the other hotels we stayed in Japan. The breakfast buffet was quite good and had many options. The polestar sky bar is the best bar I have ever been too - a must see.

Got very good room on 28th floor facing metropolitan building. I have stayed there for 10days. Only issue was hotel has fixed English breakfast menu, just imagine having same breakfast for 10days...!!!

Stayed here twice over the course of our holiday. Lovely hotel with large comfortable rooms. The staff were friendly and attentive with good English, despite being extremely busy over the new year. Breakfast was of a high standard with lots to choose from. Highlights being the luxe lounge, with complimentary snacks and drinks and great views.We would certainly book and stay here again.

We only stayed for one night and our check in time was actually delayed because the room was not ready so they compensated us by upgrading our room to a 4 bed suite with 2 toilets (there were only 3 of us). Thus very satisfied with the way they handled the situation. Very good breakfast buffet. 4 restaurants to choose from.

This is the fifth time we have stay in Keio plaza hotel in last 2 years We spent 3 nights at keio plaza, That is a very beautiful moment for our family The staff is very nice and very good service mind . Thanks again , we will be back.

Stayed here on a family holiday, 3 of us in the room. Three King single size beds and plenty of room for 3 suitcases and extra bags. Bathroom had heated toilet seat (a must in Japan), good range of toiletries, good size wash basin and room to put all our toiletries. Shower over bath. Great view of city from room. Breakfast in either top floor bar/restaurant area,with views over city or in restaurant on ground floor which had better variety. Western and Japanese style food. Los of restaurants in hotel, only tried the pizza/pasta one. Staff couldn't have been friendlier or more helpful and spoke good English. Can walk underground all the way to Shinjuku station or above ground. Five minute easy walk. Would not hesitate to stay here again. Wouldn't even bother looking elsewhere.

Booked 2 rooms for renovated deluxe rooms main tower n check in on 18th dec 2015 n was given room 2803 & 2804. Was pleased that they tried to accomate side by side for my family of 5.The views was pleasant and this hotel got free shuttle bus to disneyland n disneysea but remember to book early in advance.Their toiletries was well stock in the bathroom and each room have a shisedo facial wash.The breakfast is good n got 3 selection restaurant to choose from but my family prefer Glass Court the best. Remember to join their membership which is foc and you will save more than half of the room rates.

centrally located at Shinjuku, lots of convenient store and restaurant within 5-8 minutes walk, best bell boy services and the hotel also provides free shuttle bus services to Disneyland and Disneysea Tokyo, make sure you pre-book upon arrival.

Second stay at this hotel. We had a twin room with extra bed in the main building . It is a bit small and the bathroom is small too. The Bed and room temperature Is ok. This hotel is full of Asians .. Chinese and hongkongers. Recommended to book the hotel restaurants on the 7th floor in advance. Always fully booked. Relatively convenient.

I've stayed at this hotel several times over the past 10 years. The location of this hotel is very convenient. The free shuttle to Disney is great! And the rooms are very large, compared to most hotels in Japan. The rooms are also well-appointed with amenities and are kept very clean by the house-keeping staff. There are several excellent restaurants and a convenience store in the basement of the hotel. The views from the upper floors can be fantastic as well. Also, the wi-fi is very good, throughout the building.Unfortunately, the check-in time can be very slow, and if the hotel is full, the wait to go either up or down in the lifts can be long. The last time I was there, I waited around 10 minutes for an empty elevator each time I wanted to go up or down to my room. That is completely unacceptable. And there is no option to use the stairs or service elevator. Also, in July/Aug the pool is open, but the hours are not good. You cannot go for an early morning swim, out of the extremely hot sun in the summer, since the pool doesn't open until 9:00am, and then the pool closes early in the evening. And the fitness centre is too small, considering the size of this hotel. It's a decent hotel, which I would recommend for it's cleanliness and location, but don't expect any flash or 'wow'-factor. Don't pay too much!

My family and I stayed in this hotel for a couple of nights in early November 2015. This was one of the best hotels we stayed at- in terms of location and service. Staff were very polite, helpful, non discriminatory, and very accommodating. Rooms were huge considering it was in Central Tokyo. Location was excellent, it was near the train( shinjuku) station, parks, shops, and the metropolitan government building. This hotel accommodates the bus, always a plus if you need transport to and from the airport as an alternative of the Narita express train. The concierge will help you book and assist in the payment for the bus fare. There was a bus going directly to Tokyo Disneyland. As I have mentioned above, the rooms were huge, kept clean by the efficient staff from housekeeping. The bathroom was well maintained. There was a supply of toiletries even a complementary comb/brush. The toilet seat was heated. There was even a vanity area or a dresser separate from the writing table. An excellent place to stay in Japan. Would definitely stay there again if planning to stay in Shinjuku area.

I struggled to find a nice hotel near a metro station, Keio Plaza turned out to be an excellent choice, we enjoyed the neighborhood, relatively quiet, but felt still close to the action. Not many attractions within walking distance, but conveniently located just a 5min walk from Shinjuku stations (train, metro), which is how you move in Tokyo anyway. Expect a huge place, tall towers, buses of people arriving, but they were quite efficient, and our rooms were impeccably clean. Breakfast buffet was awesome, not particularly cheap, but worth every penny, especially the professional cooks preparing omelettes to perfection in induction pans, watch out as the included breakfast can be the small buffet version, still pretty good, but not as great and vast as the main one. You can get also amazing views of the nearby skyscrapers.

We got a twin bedder room in the main tower on the 33rd floor for 8 nights. The room was spacious, renovated, clean and classic. The bathroom looked abit dated but it was clean enough, and was well stocked with toiletries daily. We had hoped for a room in the south tower which was recently renovated but was happy and comfortable in the room we got. My 7year old slept very well indeed!The lobby looked abit dated and retro but a Christmas tree with the decorations did make it look abit more cheery.Kudos to the housekeeping team which cleaned up the room beautifully each day.The location was great too! Just a short walk (3mins) to many eateries(2 streets of food!) and convenience stores. The subway was also very near(5min walk) and it was at a major shopping area Shinjuku, which had large malls nearby.....keio,takashimaya,isetan,etc.It was also a partner hotel of Disneyland and we enjoyed the free shuttle to and fro from disneysea.The airport limousine also stops and picks up at this hotel's doorstep and it was super convenient.We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here and highly recommend this hotel. Would love to stay here if we ever visit Tokyo again and to have a chance to stay in their hello kitty themed room! Thank you Keio plaza hotel!

This is a big hotel, not a personalised inviting place. The hotel is functional and suits it's purpose of being in a great location. Staff don't do English very well (I wasn't expecting them to) but they do try hard. We had a terrific time there and for the shinjiku area this is great.We chose a 4 star hotel and this is exactly what we got, no surprises either way.

My family and i (6 persons) stayed a combined total of 8 nights .Service effeciency and delivery was like clockwork. Max marks, almost nothing was left behind and everything as expected. 5 stars.Area of concern - waiting area for checkin (1400). Very makeshift, almost an afterthoughtLocation. Very good , in Shinjuku.Restaurants and outlets anongst the best

I recently returned from my 3rd trip to Tokyo, Japan & my 1st stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo for 3 nights. It is centrally located in the heart of Shinjuku. The daily Breakfast Buffet at Glass Court Restaurant, offered imaginative Western & Japanese dishes. English copies of The Japan Times & The International NY Times, were left outside our door every morning in a clear bag. Our room was large, clean & comfortable, had robes, slippers, a teapot, green tea bags, a refrigerator & toiletries. On a clear morning, I was able to photograph Mt Fuji from our room window # 1863. Shinjuku is the home of the world's busiest Train Station & Tokyo's largest complexes, skyscrapers, hotels & entertainment spots, a true "City of Lights". There is an Underground Passage Way at Shinjuku Station, always filled with thousands of pedestrians. It is an absolute pleasure & delight to watch incoming passengers walking on the left & outgoing passengers walking on the right. No one bumps into each other, pushes or shoves. There is a great cohesiveness amongst the Japanese, their culture & methods are incredibly orchestrated, sweet like sugar and everything nice. Trains, stations, buses, pavements & streets seemed buffed & blow dried, escalators & elevators worked at all times, and are ultra punctual. Koishikawa Korakuen Gardens - Lidabashi Station. Met a Bride & Groom dressed in traditional Japanese Wedding Clothes with their Photography Crew. We asked if we could take photographs of them, they agreed and asked if they could take photographs with us. It was a lot of fun in a beautiful setting with a full moon bridge.Kagurazaka Alley - Lidabashi Station. Tokyo's old Geisha District (Kagai) consists of over 20 members. The Geisha Legacy consists of charmingly, narrow, winding back lanes, elegant black exteriors and cobblestone streets with names like "Kakurembo Yokocho", "Hide-and-Seek Alley" have been lovingly preserved. The neighborhood has gained a new appellation as "Petit Paris". Kagurazaka houses the largest concentration of French expatriates in Japan.Kazurazaka Temple - Lidabashi Station. A Shinto Shrine on Kagurazaka Dori's Main Shopping Street.Amasake Yokocho (Alley) - Ningyocho Station. Amazake "Sweet Sake", is a fermented rice drink, it is alcohol free and has been around for centuries. It helps digestion and is also a very good hang-over cure. In the Edo Period, it was commonly drunk to ward off the dreaded "Natsu-Bate" - Summer heat fatigue. The vitamin B & glucose provides an immediate jolt of energy, I drank a lot of it, before & after my pregnancy. Takashimaya Times Square - Shinjuku Station. A culinary exploration of the basement floor, you will experience their diverse,elegant showcase of Japanese food known as a Depachika. I filled up on Japanese pickles & matcha, a green tea powder traditionally used for Japanese Tea Ceremonies plus numerous bottles of chilled Amasake. Tokyo Metropolitan Edo-Tokyo Museum (Hakubutsukan) - Ryogoku Station. A very impressive Museum, you enter by walking over a replica of Nihombashi Bridge, the starting point for all roads leading out of Old Edo. Exhibits covering the Edo Period, portray the lives of the shoguns, merchants, craftsmen and townspeople.Kagari Japanese Restaurant - This divine food temple served a testing menu of 20 delicious items on colorful, unique shaped dishes at the Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo.

This is a huge hotel with 40 floors and gets very busy at times. It has convention/banquet facilities, which also adds to the human traffic in the lobby area whenever there is an event. The location is fantastic - near to the subway/train stations, the airport limo bus stops and picks up at the lobby of the hotel, walking distance to Takashimaya and Isetan, numerous eating/drinking options 5 minutes walk away ... The hotel itself offers plenty of dining options, and in the basement you can find a well stocked convenience store. The room size was decent, they even had a powder area with mirror and dressing table just outside the bathroom.

Keio Plaza has one the best rooms I've ever experienced! Spacious, modern (with hi-tech gadgets), and an immaculately clean room kettle (no rust or scum)! The view on the 31st floor was also amazing! The service staff are conversant with English, and are attentive to your needs.Keio Plaza hotel is a 10mins walk from the main JR Shinjuku station, with Eng/Jap language signs to guide you along the way as you navigate through the under passes. It also has a shuttle bus service for hotel guests going to Disneyland/DisneySea, which requires reservation that can be done via email, or at the front desk when you check in.I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at Keio Plaza, and they are worth every dollar and yen spent. The only regret I have was that I couldn't stay too long, as their price was a little out of my budget for this trip. :P

Location: 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station (West exit). The west side mainly is business district while retail shops and restaurants are more centrally located on the east side of Shinjuku station. Given Shinjuku is one of the main stations with different metro and JR lines, staying in this area minimize the connecting trains when taking public transportation. Transportation: limousine bus available from NRT airport to/from the hotel. For those who have returning flight before 10am, this is one of the very few hotels in Shinjuku that has the first bus leaves at 5:50am. Narita Express (NEX) is another option, it's faster than limousine bus but you will arrive or depart at Shinjuku station instead of hotel's front entrance. Hotel: Few reviews mentioned check in line was long. It could be that we checked in at around 7pm, there was no line. As some reviews mentioned that the rooms are dated, that's why we paid a higher rate for renovated rooms and the rooms look the same as what's in the pictures on their website. Spacious for Japanese standard and clean. We accidentally got a queen size bed instead of two twin beds but it works out well because we had our 4 year old slept on the couch with it pushed next to the bed as a bed extension. It ends up with more space in the room. We booked this hotel for a few reasons - location, limousine bus drop off/pick up right at the hotel, early pick up for limousine bus for morning flight, free shuttle to Disney, and convenience store/restaurants inside the hotel. Tips: - If you are traveling with kids and/or with lots of luggage like us, take the limousine bus. NEX requires a good 10 minute walk (assuming you don't get lost) or you will need to flag a taxi from the station to hotel. Be aware that it will take over 1.5 hrs during rush hours if you go with the bus option. - Train station exit to the hotel is West Exit. Just follow west exit sign and as you get closer. you can find Keio Plaza Hotel on the signs for which direction to go. - Free Disney shuttle requires reservation. You can request it through their website. - You can include breakfast as one of the booking options. There are 3 restaurants to choose from: western buffet, western and Japanese buffet, or Japanese set breakfast. All of them are 3000 yen per person and you get 10% off for hotel guest if you pay it at the restaurant. If you are looking to have breakfast at the hotel, it is cheaper if you book the rooms with breakfast options but do your math as some days you might not be able to make it if you have early morning itineraries.- We booked a day tour for Mt. Fuji through viator (local tour company called sunrise tour) in advance. You can also book it at the hotel for pretty much the same price. We would definitely be staying at this hotel again. Little things that the hotel offers here and there make your life easier or less headache if you are like us traveling with a 4 year old and a 20 months old. This hotel is a bit pricy but you pay for what you get.

stay here for 3 nights. love the room with a fantastic view of the city and the garden. room was clean and not quite reasonable size. they come with a bath tub and luxury shampoo/toiletries. also serve halal meal for our contingent at that time. location wise, very strategically located and walking away to many places

Conveniently located with fantastic views of Shinjuku, we had a nice enough stay at the Keio Plaza for our first Tokyo holiday. The staff were polite and the rooms were clean. However, from photos on tripadvisor, the hotel website and & a friend's visit last year, we were expecting a bit more. I now understand that there are two towers, with the South Tower as the most recently renovated, which we didn't stay in. Our room was a bit on the ordinary side and not what I was expecting given all the photos I had seen. Another let down was the Wifi - which only seemed to work outside the hotel. We had a very frustrating morning, waiting for friends to contact us but with no Wifi, we were stuck. The staff were very helpful, lending us the use of an iPad at the front desk, but this did not resolve the ongoing Wifi drop outs. The two bars on the top floor were great, particularity the Polestar Bar, with dazzling night time views of the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. Overall, our stay leaned more towards average than anything higher. Could not fault the staff, but there was certainly no WOW factor to our stay here. We had booked the Hilton for the last 4 days of our trip and they certainly delivered WOW.

Overall not bad. The airport bus from Narita direct to the hotel door was very convenient especially after a long flight. Check in took some time, the staff member took our passports & disappeared for some 15 minutes, I felt concern about that but once she returned I noticed a trainee badge. Just would have been good if she could communicate that she was going to photocopy them etc not just walk off. The hotel room was dated & worn, with bumps & dents in the furniture not really what you'd hope for paying over $350. I wanted to book this as a birthday treat so I guess paying that amount I expected a little more. The room was of a reasonable size for Japan. Our room smelt so badly of smoke, I couldn't breathe or sleep. My eyes were all red, even our clothes started to take on that horrible dirty smoke smell. The next day I asked to please be moved to a non smoking room, I was told the hotel didn't have any. They gave us an air defuser to use & after a day or 2 it started to be a lot better. The staff were always kind & polite & willing to help. I found the location really great & in a quieter area. The other handy thing was the Disney shuttle direct pick up & the hotel was a meeting point for one of our tours. So for those sort of reasons it's a good choice. We stayed for 7 nights. Personally i would stay at the hotel gracery instead. For me it was cheaper & more modern.

The room is good size compare to other hotels room rate. other Hotel area is spacious and staff is very friendly and helpful.The Buffet breakfast on 1st floor is really good in value. Consider AUD 30 for full buffet breakfast.

This is a large hotel in a great spot. Reception is very busy all the time but is helpful and friendly. Not keen on early check ins though! The wifi was very good. The rooms are pretty dated but at least clean and comfortable - just not worth the high price.

This is a very large hotel with a lot of rooms. We were lucky to receive an upgrade and our room was very spacious and clean. The location was great, and worked perfect for us and our two night stay in Tokyo. The staff were polite, but concierge seemed fairly uninterested every time we spoke with them. Fortunately we were able to sort everything out on our own.My only note is to be aware when booking on third party sites. Make sure you have the correct amount of guests listed. We were surprised to pay $150 more because I didn't note it was double occupancy (1 bed).

We stayed here for 6days and our stay was truly amazing! The location was okay. Walking distance to the mall and convenience store. Their foor was tasty and delicious. Their staff was very friendly, helpful and accommodating. We will definitely go back here! Cheers!

Whilst checking in there was quite a substantial queue which was handled rather poorly by the staff. However after some waiting time I was called forward and attributed a room in the south tower. The surprise was big as I entered a room. It resembled rather a room you would expect in the 1970ies. After having checked my reservation and reviews of other travelers it came up that my room was a so-called non renovated room.I filed a complaint at the front desk which was handled poorly. I learned that the hotel at least internally distinguished between these two types of rooms which by no means was clear upon booking. The only thing I was offered was an upgrade to a new room which would trigger in total almost 470 USD on top on the 900 USD I already paid for a five nights stay. All in all too much money for this properly since the overall rating in the relevant hotel review fora is hardly comprehensible.

Stayed for 8 nights at the executive room with Luxe Lounge access. There is really nothing we can compliant about. There is a dedicated room for reception, thus avoiding any crowds during checkin. The rooms are spacious, clean. Rooms come with a view of Mt Fuji on most day of our stay! Luxe lounge is rather small, but it is ok since we needed them mostly at night after our long day out. We did day trips, Some trips depart right at the Hotel lobby at level 3. This ave us time! Plenty of good foods around the hotel area too. Location is really a plus.

Stayed in the south tower. View was fantastic. Food at JURIN was terrific. Staff at the front desk and concierge was knowledgeable and very helpful. The room was quiet and the shower and bath area was terrific. There was a small like 7-11 in the building that had drinks and sandwiches and toiletries that was very helpful.

I have been staying at this hotel at least once a year since 2009 so I think I am pretty qualified to review it. The biggest draws of this hotel are availability, convenience and the fact that it is a Disney-friendly hotel. They usually have rooms even if you make bookings close to your travel dates, it's conveniently located near Shinjuku station with lots of shopping and restaurants. And if you are traveling with kids, they have free shuttle buses to and fro Disneyland resorts. Airport limousine stops here. Most of those remain and you can continue rely on them. Some other things have changed though. The room was HOT when I checked in. Curtains were left open and the sun had heated up the room. The AC didn't work because the system had been changed to heating for winter. Toilet was not clean (You won't want details on this, trust me). There were leftover pop corns under the bedside table. I asked to extend my check out time by one hour and was rejected. Not that I expected the request to be granted. But the rejection was rather curt. Imagine getting that kind of rejection in a culture that has difficulty saying no. I waited close to 5 minutes to get help to reserve a seat on airport limousine bus while bell boys ignored us. Treat this as an average city hotel for its convenience, but don't expect more. With the emergence of competitive Airbnb options, I think this might be my last encounter with Keio Plaza. It was great and I hope they can get that standard back.

The only complaint the mainland China group. Very loud, rude, no manners.Other wise a quality hotel with very good location in Shinjuku. On the quite side of that busy area.Very clean, spacious despite in Tokyo.

A big city hotel with more than 1400 rooms. An old hotel with 45-year history. Although renovated, oldness is recognizable by bathroom and cracks on a crossbar. Breakfast has limited variety and quality is below average for city hotels. Breads dry out. Direct limousine bus from Narita Airport is available but they are infrequent. Better to use more frequent limousines to other city hotels nearby. But you need to take a taxi to Keio Plaza because many steps around the hotel entrance. Hard to get in with heavy luggage. Needs improvement.

We stayed for 2 nights. This is an excellent hotel to stay in Shinjuku, it is just a few minutes walk to the shopping and eating areas. The breakfast's choice and the food quality were really good too. We stayed with our 2 year old son so this hotel is perfect for a family with young children as the location is very convenient.The only complaint we have is that we find it difficult to connect to the the free wifi when we were in in the room. This is especially so for new phone models (I 'm using Samsung 6S edge, our older phone however didnt have a problem connecting). You need to go down at the common area to connect first then only you can access it in the room. But once connected, the wifi works perfectly fine.

Stayed here for 7 nights in December 2015.This hotel was highly recommended by many people and seemed to have good reviews.The room was very big for Tokyo standards but it was disappointingly old and the carpets had gross stains everywhere.Maybe we got the older rooms but was quite disappointed anyhow.Location wise it was very good..was across the street from many restaurants.and it was also very near to the subway and shopping centers.The breakfast buffet was nothing to shout about too..don't bother wasting money if it's not included in ur room package.

Amazing Hotel with several restaurant choices within, serving western, Japanese and oriental food. Luxurious bedrooms with all amenities including dressing gown and slippers. Bathroom with multi functional toilet and heated seat

For my family of 4 kids requiring a stroller. The airport Limousine Bus transfer direct to the hotel and Disneyland free coach rides sealed the deal despite the relatively expensive price. However, the price was probably expected due to the Shinjuku location. During our stay, it became clear the location was excellent with Tochomae station below the hotel and Shinjuku station connected by a well used sheltered underground walkway. The walkway was a 15min stroll with spinner luggage when we took the Hakone Romance car line from Shinjuku. The Tochomae line also gave us options to avoid the JR line rush crowd. It is difficult to squeeze a folded stroller onto JR rush hour train. Remember to check Hyperdia options for both Tochomae and Shinjuku stations when planning your subway route. Can make a difference of a few train transfers but may increase the train fare.

clean room overlooking the back lawn and the city. there were 8 restaurants. Mostly Asian food. One with American breakfast. Lobby personal were very helpful. The "M" train has a station right near the hotel

Checked-in for a 4 night stay in Keio plaza. Checking-in was a breeze. Was assigned the newly renovated superior room on the 32nd floor in the main tower. The three super-single beds were comfy, room size just right. Room was replenished with mineral water daily and you can request to change bedsheets daily. Particularly like the 2 sofa and round table near the entrance of the room. Just a mere 3-minute walk away, we found a place filled with restaurants all priced reasonably. There is even an underpass to get to the Shinjuku Station. ( exit from one floor below the lobby area to get to the underpass which is on the right side of the property ) Though hotel price is on the high side, the overall convenience and the newly renovated rooms made it all worthwhile. Great choice for families with children.

This is the 2nd Keio Plaza brand hotel that I have stayed in. The room standard is consistent and well-maintained. There is also a variety of breakfast selection with a few restaurants to choose from. Located a short 3 mins walk from a busy street of restaurants and shops, the hotel is also 10 mins walk away from the Shinjuku JR station making it accessible from the Airport Express Trains departing from Narita airport. Alternatively, you can also take a limousine bus service direct from Narita airport which drops you at the hotel doorstep for a slightly higher price than the train service. Tourist can purchase a 2-way ticket for 4500 yen when you produce your identification at the bus counter. The hotel also offers free shuttle bus service to Disneyland/sea at designated timings. Limited seats available, offered on a first-come-first-serve basis. Hope this helps :)

This hotel is located right near the buzzing area of Shinjuku - you can walk to the main shopping area in around 5 minutes. The hotel is nice, although the rooms are quite small. There are lots of restaurants in the hotel, they are all pretty good. It was not the best value for what you get (this is not really at the 5 star standard) but then Tokyo is a very expensive city. There is a decent gym but no swimming pool. The limousine bus from HND and NRT stops at the hotel.

My family and I were in Tokyo in November 2015 for a short holiday. We traveled from Osaka, Kyoto then Tokyo. Because our stay was short, we wanted to stay in a hotel that is strategically located...near the train station so mobility was easy and near the shopping area. Keio Hotel provided our needs. Upon check-in, the front desk staff was very helpful and readily gave us an upgraded accommodation when he learned that it was our first time in the hotel. The three buffet restaurants offered a wide array of choices. Our room which was on the 27th floor offered a nice view and was very clean. All the staff from the front desk to the bell captain were very accommodating. It's now our preferred hotel when visiting Tokyo.
user_name:
Tonette A
Quezon City, Quezon City, Philippines

review_body: Stayed here one night on business. The rooms were large. The beds were hard but comfortable. Lot's of restaurants in the hotel. A large convenience store in the hotel. Service was excellent and within walking distance of Shijuku train station. Would stay here again in a minute!

The hotel is really nice and HUGE. Our room was very big and spacious, even by US standards. The staff are very friendly and helpful and the location is also ideal for exploring the city. The breakfast buffet is pricey but tasty and the free wifi was very convenient. Getting from and to the airport is also a breeze. Overall, great choice, I would book again.

Keio Plaza Hotel Shinjuku is centrally located in the heart of the Shinjuku area. The hotel is within short walking distance to an array of great dining, shopping and entertainment. The Shinjuku train station and shopping complex is about four blocks away so you there is no shortage of things to do and places to visit. Location is everything...Keio Plaza Hotel got that part right, but they lack in room cleanliness.Our party stayed in two standard twin rooms for three nights on the 25th floor at approximately $238.11 USD per night. The rooms were simple and adequate in size, however we had company throughout our stay...there was black mold on the window silicone as well as in the bathroom tiles silicone. That explains the allergy symptoms I was experiencing throughout the three night stay. Paying over $200.00 USD per night is on the high side. At that room rate, the very least any guest should expect is a clean spotless room free of black mold.The best service in the world does not matter if the room has mold in it. Keio Plaza obviously failed in inspecting the rooms to ensure it is fit and safe for guests. How could they not see black mold on white silicone. Its like missing an ambulance with its sirens and horns blaring. Complacency kills. Keio Plaza must revisit their housekeeping standards and make immediate improvements.I will consider staying at Keio Plaza Hotel Shinjuku again, but will require a guarantee from hotel management that the black mold has been completely eradicated.

Spent 6 nights in total at this lovely hotel, which is quite convenient if you fly out to/from Tokyo airports (either Narita or Haneda).Deco was a bit old but facility is all there, good shower and room size. Didn't try the breakfast, there is an convenient shop which gives you plenty of option to choose from.Walkable distance to Shinjuku station (by 10-15mins). If weather was nice, I don't mind actually.One highlight is the sushi dinner we had at Kyubey! absolutely fantastic, highly recommend!

We selected this hotel because of its great location and were hopeful that the reviews were not overstated. Although the hotel is located approximately 10 minutes from Shinjuku station (assuming that you take the west exit at Shinjuku station) I suggest taking a taxi if carrying luggage otherwise it's a pleasant walk.The hotel was everything we expected and a bit more. Our room was spacious, clean and comfortable. The hotel and restaurant staff were excellent and made us feel comfortable and welcome.The restaurants available within the hotel offer a wide range of cuisines are a welcome option after a day of touringWe highly recommend this hotel

Wifi is free but slow and sometimes hard to connect. Room is clean and fairly sized. Not exactly cheap - I paid about USD 260 per night. Although location is in Shinjuku, it is still 5 - 10 mins walk away from Shinjuku station. If you have shopped for the whole day, it can be a pain walking back. Airport limousine operates straight at the hotel - very convenient. Breakfast at glass court is best among all the 4 breakfast choices. Lots of food choices within 5 mins walk from hotel.

I found the Keio to tick all the boxes. Comfortable rooms but the facilities were 5 star. We stayed there twice in our trip and managed to eat at most of the restaurants. All were excellent. The convenience store was very reasonably priced and again the food available was fantastic. The pool deck is fantastic and the whole hotel has a wonderful feel, where your kids are quite capable of freely walking down to the convenience store. Also the close proximity to the train station and fabulous restaurants and shopping is again the draw card for Tokyo being one of the world leaders in sophistication .

We stayed in a premier plaza room which was spacious and a great view of the city. The room has well stocked with all kinds of toiletries, robes (western and Japanese), and slippers. The bathroom was remodeled but they used faux marble counters and shower surround which detracted from the overall quality of the room. There were a few stains on the carpet, but the room was clean. Beds are super firm and it had electronic shades. The plaza lounge is in the south tower and the premier plaza rooms are in the main tower. It is a relaxing venue, with an assortment of beverages and snacks. Some of the guests were chowing down on the canapés, but it wasn't enough for a meal substitute. The buffet breakfast at Jurin was very nice, large selection mostly western and some Japanese dishes. The selection of western and asian choices improves in the Glass Court buffet. We ate early, around 6am, so never had to wait in line. The location is superb, close to Shinjuku station, the busiest in Japan, and large department stores that have a food court on the upper floor with many restaurants, and a huge selection of take out food in the basement. There are many restaurants within walking distance between the hotel and the train station. We stayed here because it was part of the package offered through JTB Sunrise tours which offers a wide range of hotel choices and Keio Plaza was supposed to be a 4 star quality if upgraded to premier plaza. The staff were helpful and courteous, and refused tips. Overall, a good choice for Tokyo.

It was with trepidation that I booked the hotel for our October visit as we were hard pressed to find something suitable to our travel styles, with most hotel being booked. The reviews I had read had some negatives that bothered me: unfriendliness of check in staff, long line ups at breakfast to name the most concerning.It is a behemoth of a hotel with some thousand rooms, but surprisingly it works with great efficiency so typical of Japan. We never experienced any waits for breakfast which was surprisingly very good. Great coffee and solicitous service. Rooms were clean. Toto Toilets are the best in the world. Love the abundance of amenities: Terry Robes, Yukata and Pajamas for each guest. Front desk service was excellent and gave us a generous 3 PM check out which we didn't really need. A good choice of restaurants with the minor complain that their last calls were a bit too early for travellers with a late check-in. All in all a wonderful experience.

Great location and very nice hotel. Minutes to Shinjuku station. Rooms are nice and spacious. Good breakfast buffet and you can choose from three different restaurants. The airport transfer from Haneda to the hotel back to the airport is superb. Enjoyed every minute of it.

The hotel was very good and the premier plaza room was extremely comfortable!The lounge had import bear and a few snacks and provided a good opportunity to relax. However there were negatives. One was breakfast, since it was a very big hotel with guests from all over the world and there were 2 restaurants for breakfast (providing slightly different menus), both of them had long queues (especially the restaurant we wanted to go to) and while we had a 1 year toddler who was hungry, this was not really ideal. The second was the distance from the lounge from the premier plaza room - it was located in another tower (this may only be a problem since I was lazy and didn't want to walk)

Pricey hotel but had its benefits of being a short walk away from the Shinjuku station and in close proximity with the Takashimaya mall. The room itself is on the smaller size given the price but its a big property overall with a western touch. Pro tip: There's a special hotel exit that connects into the shinjuku station tunnel so its even faster to walk that route versus what googlemaps will direct you towards.

This hotel is very nice and in a good location close to Shinjuku train station- when getting off the train you need to leave via the West Entrance - it's about a 10 min walk from the station - not super close but the train station is huge. There is a big department store just above it and a short walk to Shinjuku centre with a whole heap of shops and restaurants.We stayed in a twin room and the size was good - it hard to fit 2 large suitcases as there is only 1 "place" for bags but you can put another one on the floor. The bathroom was larger than I expected and nice deep bath and they provide amenities which smell nice. The WIFI was good and free and there is an English radio station next to the bed which was nice. The room was well maintained.The hotel itself is impressive with nice views and a big hotel feel - the lobby was always filled with people.We got the bus to Narita airport which cost 3000 Yen. They also have a free bus to Disney land.There are a whole heap of restaurants in the complex - the buffet breakfast is very good. For dinner I would get out into the city as the restaurants are pricey.Overall this was a nice hotel and a very safe feel in a great location. I would stay here again.

The room at the renovated main building is large with twin big beds (a bed can accommodate two asian-sized adults if needed), huge bathroom, closet and desk. It is very clean, look and smell like new. Amenities include bath robe, pajamas, slippers in addition to the usual amenities. You have to ask for body lotion though if you want it!With out asking, they provide you daily with Japan Times and New York Times..The hotel provides many convenient services: Airport bus services to/from the airport direct to the hotel; free shuttle bus services to/from Disney Resort bus-shuttle (it should have more trips instead of just three a day); free wifi; has many quality restaurants - Japanese, Korean, International; The hotel staff are very helpful and customer service oriented, not to mention that they are very polite and respectful.Its location is very convenient. It is near- walking distance -to the shopping areas and restaurants.The hotel is a highly recommended place to stay for business or for a vacation.

Have been reading about this hotel and decided to stay here from Nov. 15-20, 2015. The hotel is actually located in the heart of Shinjuku, but it is still a good 10-15 minute walk to the area where the restaurants are, the shopping area, the main shopping street, etc.. The housekeeping is so so, some do their jobs well while some do not really see what needs to be cleaned, leaving a lot of garbage on the tables and desks. We checked in close to midnight and the receptionist we met, a certain Kawai could use a lesson or two in English, we could not seem to understand each other when in fact, a fours star hotel should have qualified and fluent front desk personnel, or maybe I was just unlucky since the guy I spoke to after her was very kind and accommodating. The hotel is definitely not Conrad in standard and service, but is could really be near if it wanted to, the hotel is decent, the teppanyaki restaurant on the second floor is very very good, and so is the Chinese restaurant on the basement (2nd floor as what they term the basement), there is a convenience store at the basement of the building, open till 230am, the food in the three places for breakfast is ok, the lunch buffet at the glass court is very reasonable and the food is quite good, there is a big advantage at this hotel since there is a daily shuttle bus to Tokyo Disneyland, and the Airport limousine bus literally stops in the hotel. Would I stay again at this hotel? Well the rooms are decent, the beds are comfortable, but as mentioned before, it is still along walk to the dining and shopping area. To the hotel management, pls improve on some of the front desk personnel, the one I met was very "challenging" I would rate the hotel on a scale of 1-10, around 6-7

My first visit to this hotel in Shinjuku, and found it to be very good. Location is ideal for shopping and entertainment areas in Shinjuku, being only 5 mins walk to the main areas. In the hotel itself there are a range of places to eat, though I would recommend exploring the local small restaurants down by Shinjuku station which are good value and the food is excellent.

After the debacle of the desk staff losing our credit card on arrival the rest of the stay was awesome. We stayed in the renovated tower and it was by far the best accommo of our trip. A welcome level of comfort after a heap of snowboarding. The location is excellent, only a five minute walk from the Shinjuku train station that we used as our hub. The hotel is on the 'technology' side of the train station with a wealth of camera stores etc. Fashion hunters and crate diggers may be better off staying on the eastern side of the station. The beds were really comfortable and the bathroom facilities were also really good. Our views were extraordinary too. Definitely worth getting a higher floor for impressive views at night. The bar at the top of the building is worth a look to although a beer doesn't come cheap. We'd definitely recommend staying here. The staff were really helpful (after the card issue) and the location is excellent.

1. Check in process took me 30 minutes2. Room is very clean and neat3. Shampoo , soap, towel, etc are provided well 4. Overall a good hotel5. Near the goverment building and hilton hotel6. Located near train station. So, make us an easy access to reach everywhere

As for Japan it's very good hotel. Rooms very big, also the bathroom. Very clean, european style. You can choose the menu - european or japaneese. Inside there are ATM and automatic currency exchange ATM. It's near Shinjuku where you can go for a beer to very very old and small bars with japaneese climate.

This is a very large hotel but VERY well organised and offers shops and restaurants without having to walk outside. I had a Plaza Luxe room which was spacious and overlooked the monolithic Tokyo Government buildings (which has a great observatory free of charge - not to be missed). Good choice of food and the Western breakfast room offered everything you could wish for. The day before I left the most wonderful enormous Ikebana decoration had been 'built' in the giant foyer - a sight to behold. Stepping out of the back of the hotel you are a few minutes walk to Shinkuku Station and the fantastic Keio Department Store.

We loved the hotel which was within a 5-8 mins walk to Shinjuku station via covered walkway, and had a free shuttle to tokyo disneyland! Booked the lowest fare "Run of the House" rate for 2 legs of our trip, and ended up first with a nice double queen room and upon our return for the 2nd leg, upgraded to a japanese styled suite which could fit 4 futons across! Great value of money! No lack of food options within premises

Had a room on the 38th floor with a great view of the City Hall. Bed was firm and comfy. Room was spacious. Internet service was great and included. Staff very pleasant throughout my stay. On-site breakfast was pricey but there are less expensive options off-site nearby. 5 minutes walk from the Narita Express train stop. Direct train from Narita to Shinjuku but takes 80-90 minutes.

Japan is always mythical, even a hotel which is not under a western hemisphere brandname for us is a risky business, well this hotel is a very nice place, located within Shinjuku area and price&location relation is hard to beat, in my fare breakfast was included and was a good one.
user_name:
Mauricio G
San Jose, Costa Rica

review_body: This is a big hotel. I would say it is ideal for business travelers, but could also be a good option for vacationers. My wife and I stayed there on vacation and it was a very pleasant stay. The hotel has several different restaurant and buffets, what is good if you want to stay in for the night. The surroundings have many options of restaurants and electronic related stores. It is a short walk from the Shinjuku train station, that connects with the whole city via JR trains. The rooms need some renovation (I leave here a suggestion for management) but are of a very good size for Japanese standards. The check in starts at 2 PM and you cannot enter in the room 1 minute before that. Lines form at the counter at this time so it might be better to get a little after 2 PM to check in.

Perfect location close to Shinjoku station in safe area, next to Government building and streets of restaurants. The breakfast is huge-try the American Japanese restaurant for plenty of variety in a more upscale setting. American breakfast restaurant is also great and is bigger and no lines. The variety of food is unbelievable-think cruise line cuisine rather than Holiday Inn breakfast. Staff are very helpful, but this is a big hotel so not the sort of place they get to know you, or you them. The rooms are comfortable enough, but just not updated-think pink Miami 1970's! All in all, I wouldn't be averse to coming here again as it was more budget friendly than some other choices, but there is a lot of hotel choices, so weigh up if location and food quality versus a visually appealing decor is more important to you.

I travelled to Tokyo for business and i found this hotel perfect. Located in the middle of the skyscaper city, this hotel was very close to my office. Shinjuku station is right infront (200 mts) while GOvt metropolitan building is behind. Breakfast buffet spread was awesome and the staff was helpful and polite. Rooms were big and had al necessary amentities. Would recommend this hotel above, hyatt or hilton in the same area.

The location is in CBD of Tokyo (Shinjiku area), easy access to transport, restaurant, and night life. The room is cosy and clean. They provide shuttle bus for the guest to go to Disneyland and return.

My husband and I stayed for three nights in this hugely busy hotel. They must have at least 6 bell staff working at any one time - it's a huge operation and the berooms are spread between two towers with 34 floors. This is also a conference, seminar and wedding venue and has shops where you can buy a variety of goods.The bedrooms are spotlessly clean and are incredibly spacious and the toilets have heated seat with in built bidets and warm air dryers hehehe. An experience in itself, if you haven't visited Tokyo before. You will find that these type of toilets are common in Tokyo.There are multiple themed restaurants in the hotel where you can take breakfast or dinner so there is no need to worry that you will have to wait a long time for a table.I lost a diamond ring the bedroom and the housekeeping staff took the bedroom apart almost and sure enough they found it for me - they were amazing and I couldn't thank them enough. I cannot imagine any other hotel helping in that way. Great great service.The gym is tiny - very tiny, with only about 6 pieces of equipment.There is a hospitality room, one for males and one for females - for re packing cases or getting changed - and excellent idea.One thing to be aware of, this hotel WILL NOT let you check in before 2pm under any circumstances. If you have had a long flight like us and arrive at the hotel at 07:30 hrs, you have not choice other than to sit around in the hotel public areas or walk around Tokyo. When check in opens at 14:00 hrs, there can be up 100 people waiting, if not more, just waiting to check in. I would suggest that this is something they could improve upon by releasing bedrooms as soon as they have been cleaned an cleared by housekeeping.

This hotel is large and I stayed in the main tower on the 19th floor. The room was quite large for Tokyo and it had a sofa in addition to what you usually expect. There was also a separate dressing room with a very large wardrobe and a desk which was handy. The room was not super models but was in very good condition and very well serviced each day.The location is great - it's about a 10 minute walk to Shinjuku station - exit the hotel by the back entrance and walk strait ahead to get there. On the way to the station, you can deviate into the side streets which are full of shops and restaurants. The station is huge and you can go anywhere from there - just make sure you remember which exit you need to come back from.The hotel has several restaurants - I only had breakfast there a few times but the food was really good and the service efficient, the do both buffet and cook omelettes etc. on the spot if requested. If you go for breakfast, it gets really busy towards 8AM so try to rise in time for an earlier start if you don't like lining up.Generally a great hotel - I would stay there again for the convenience and the service and room.

I usually stay at Hotel Sunroute ShinJuku. But it's full at that time. My Singapore friend recommended this hotel to me. It's more expensive but better.After reading many review, I booked Main tower- very good.There are 3 breakfast room1) Western buffet 2) Western and Japanese buffet 3)Japanese set meal. I try No.2 and 3. They were very good and reasonable price (Japan standard :), 3000 yen with 10% discount for hotel guest).There is one convenient store in the hotel as well.For location, it's only 5-10 min walk from Shinjuku station and many restaurants around. One minor problem, It took 25-30 mins for check-in due to longgggg Q.I had to leave hotel early morning. Therefore, I had my check out in the evening- one day before.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel during a recent 12 day visit to Tokyo. The hotel is super convenient and is located literally within a 2 minute walk from a subway station and a 5 minute walk from Shinjuku station. Getting to the hotel from Narita Airport is really easy using the Narita Express that stop at Shinjuku station. If you head towards the 'West Exit' of Shinjuku station you will literally walk into the hotel. The hotel is clean and very tidy and has got a lot going on. The ground floor of the hotel has got a few restaurants and a convenience store which is not only available to hotel guests but it's also available to the general public. We stayed in a Plaza Premier room which was located on the 38th floor with amazing views of Tokyo. The room was a very decent size with plenty of space for two people. The hotel staff was amazing - really helpful and nothing was too much to ask or to do. Because it's one of the area's oldest hotels, some of the interiors look a little dated but it's by no means ugly or awful in any way. I think as a landmark of Shinjuku and being so central to everything, Keio Plaza was the perfect choice for us. Service was good and the room was really comfy. They were really helpful and even helped me plan our days out. I will definitely stay here when I go back to Tokyo, without a doubt!

We're a couple from Israel arriving at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo on 22-10-2015.We enjoyed very much our stay at the hotel, but the special event was when my wife loosed her pers bag in a store in Tokyo.We re ported that imediately to the Chief Bell Captain, Lobby Service, Mr. Nobuyuki Kaneko , who immediately actioned and detect the bag at the store we visited and personaly go with me, Harry Gershony to the storewhere we received back the lost bag.Regarding the hotel, room was very nice, very good breakfast and excellent gourmet dinner buffet, we realy enjoyed the stay at this hotel

For a hotel in Shinjuku, the price was very reasonable. I was upgraded to a nice room with a view. Window shades were even motorized. Great amenities throughout. Would consider this for vacation later with my family. Checkin/out was pretty efficient. Breakfast service was attentive. Access from Narita was simple via the bus.

Super convenient hotel near Shinjuku station. Staff was really nice and very helpful in finding local restaurants. Room was immaculate with a killer view. We got the room with 4 beds which let the whole family get a great night's sleep. The room had two bathrooms as well! Sushi restaurant in the hotel is the best in the city, but super pricey. However, would eat there again for the experience and best meal in Tokyo.

TL;DR: Premier room: excellent bed, brilliant soundproofing, comfy room, bathroom so-so, great views and location.We stayed in a 'Premier' room and got a nice discount by booking online in advance for 5 days. The room itself, on the 36th floor of the main tower was excellent: a decent size by any standards with a king-sized bed "by Simmons" - I have to say one of the best hotel beds I've slept in; really steady even if your jet-lagged partner bounces around. The layout of the room allowed both a pleasant sofa and a convenient seat for reading with a little table by the side of both in addition to a functional desk for working, without feeling crammed at all. My wife was also very pleased with a little makeup desk that rounded the offering. Stowage was a little more limited.Sound proofing was absolutely superb, again one of the best experienced in any hotel. The view from the room was very nice too, overlooking the Tokyo metropolitan government building, with a strip of windows running the full length of the room that let in plenty of daylight. All in all a very comfortable room that it felt good coming back to in the evening.The only letdown was the bathroom; bizarrely this was some sort of prefab plastic thing with a low ceiling (< 2m) and very dim lighting, which made shaving very difficult. Not really a match for a 5 stars hotel "Premier room"...The Premier room comes with access to the "Luxe" lounge, which provides complimentary drinks until 10 I believe, but is situated at the top of the hotel's other tower so a good 5+ minutes distance depending on luck with the lifts. The meagre snacks selection didn't make that stroll particularly worthwhile; beers were more generous.Location of the hotel is great as others have said, for both travel links out of the massive Shinjuku station which is perhaps 5 mins away, and for dining and entertainment. We tried one of the hotel's restaurants one evening but the service was overwhelmed with the number of guests so we left after 10 mins as no one managed to even provide a menu. That said this was no issue at all given the wealth of excellent restaurants that can be enjoyed within a 500m radius; and for those feeling more adventurous there are even more choices on the other side of Shinjuku station, perhaps 10 mins away. We would certainly be happy to come back...

We stayed here for three nights on arriving in Tokyo. It really well located, close to a number of tube stations and a huge railway station. We were able to travel around the city easily from this central point. The room was big; clean, tidy, and had lots of toiletries! We had an amazing view of Mount Fuji for the window and were lucky enough to have several clear days to admire it.Clean towels were provided on a regular basis, as well as fresh bottled water. There were a number of restaurants on the ground floor, but one of the highlights is the sky lounge at the top of one of the towers. Definitely worth stopping in for a cocktail. The only downside was the queues for breakfast. There were several options, but the queues were awful at all of them. This is a busy hotel so getting there early or late is recommended!

We stayed in the renovated South Tower in deluxe room. Rooms were nice, beds very comfortable and couch/desk in room. Service was slow at front desk due to what appears to be a very long winded booking system, and there can be a slight language barrier in understanding requests, although all staff speak English. The front desk was always staffed by Trainees during our stay resulting in things taking longer. Be sure to book a non smoking room and check this when you check in. We stayed for a couple of nights ahead of a work trip, unfortunately my work colleagues were all allocated to smoking rooms as it wasn't specified at time of booking. We were as well, and it took us 45mins speaking to reception to be moved to a non smoking room. Hotel was full so they couldn't reallocate my colleagues when they later arrived resulting in Hotel staff spraying room with air fresher to mask the smell. Good selection of Japanese and Western Breakfast options. Whilst there are a number of restaurants you can choose from for Buffet Breakfast, you can expect to queue up if you go to breakfast after 7.30 if they are busy. We queued for almost 30 mins one morning at 7.20am. When we finally got into the restaurant, there were a number of empty tables. We raised this with one of the restaurant staff and they just laughed. We raised a compliant at reception which took 45 mins to get a resolution and 3 staff including the duty manager. It was an extremely frustrating process. Check out also took 30 mins as there was an issue with our bill. We stayed at another 5* Hotel the night before moving across to the Keio Plaza Hotel, and their service levels far exceeded the Keio Plaza. There are a number of restaurant choices in the hotel and it is very close to Shinjuku station. There is airport bus to/from hotel for $1250Yen or you can catch the subway. Be sure to visit the bar on Level 45 for great views. My colleagues used the gym and said it was quite small for the size of the hotel and pool is outside so only open during summer. We had a great stay in Tokyo and hotel was very central to everything. Meals were all very good in hotel. If you show your room key you get 10% discount off your restaurant meals for lunch/dinner.

Many choices for breakfast trditional Japanese through to continental can be a bit busy but if you pick your time no problem. Guest relations staff incredibly helpful and will go out of their way to assist. We used the baggage forwarding service - it worked like a charm and saved us struggling on bullet train with bags

First, I want to commend the Service at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo. Like most good Japanese hotels, they do a good job. And the location is convenient if you have work to do near Shinjuku. But I have to say I think the hotel is very average. My room was nothing at all interesting and my bed was uncomfortable. I used the exercise room daily for a week, but it's small and uninspiring. The breakfast buffet is solid but - except for the omelets and French toast - nothing close to exceptional. The Keio Plaza Hotel obviously does a good business, but if you want a great hotel experience, consider other options.

To spoil myself I switched from my usual budget hotel in Shinjuku to its upmarket neighbour, the Keio Plaza. As it turned out it was worth every cent of the extra money. My room was spacious beyond belief, the bed was extra comfortable, the service top rate and the buffet breakfast delicious. My every need was catered for right down to the borrowed umbrella when the heavens unexpectedly opened up to the corkscrew needed when I discovered that a bottle of wine purchased at a nearby department store was not a screw top. It arrived placed on a serviette atop a tray within five minutes of making a call to room service. The room was as quiet as a tomb and the TV with its many channels was easily to negotiate once you pressed the 'English' button. It was an easy five minute walk to the Keio department store, just a little longer to the south exit of Shinjuku station and even more conveniently, was a pick-up stop for Sunrise Tours. Every facet of its operations seems to have been expertly planned and brilliantly executed. I took breakfast early (between 6 and 7) and encountered no queues as some people have complained. I'll certainl stay there again.

Good business hotel, but its big really big, so therefore prepare to Q for breakfast. There are lots of restaurants with a bar you can smoke in. The lift system is good and needs to be as there are many floors to navigate. Good location for Shinjuku shops and train station. I am going back in November so that says it all really.

Keio plaza, has 2 entrances, in front of a Goverment building, and back access to Tochomae subway station and shinjuku station in 3-4 min walking. this is very convenient. High standing, large space in the rooms, all funcitonal items available, TV, Wifi, internet, frig, ... large bed, nice bath room. High quality service (reception room service, breakfast). Shops and restaurants available, but close at 10 pm. If need for food later go to shinjuku station area, all restaurants still open.

The hotel is in a great location n the heart of Shinjuku, just five minutes walk to the train station and also a stop on the friendly limousine transfer routes from both Haneda and Narita. The hotel is huge, with a well presented lobby area. The staff were very friendly and could not do enough to help. The issue I have with the hotel is that the rooms were average. Marketed as 4.5 star and at a cost of USD200 per night plus I thought the rooms were dated and required a large update. I had one of the standard rooms, perhaps the higher grades are better. So great location, great staff, let down by what I consider 3 star rooms.

There are three choices for breakfast, we tried all three. The best is the Japanese one. I strongly recommend it. There is a mall across from the street. This makes it very convenient to find a reasonable place for dinner. We ate in one of them (forgot the name) - the food was good, the price was reasonable, and the service was good. If you do not want to go out, the Jurin restaurant is very reasonable (price, quality, and service). We ate there for dinner once and were very happy with it.

Worst hotel experience of my life. I didn't bother to read the reviews before checking in (it's a big name hotel in Japan -- what could go wrong) and was put in a smoking room. When I complained they said that even though I had requested a non-smoking room I wasn't guaranteed one even though what it actually says in my reservation is "Non Smoking Room basis" and that smoking room can be requested when check in which in now way implies that there is a chance you will be put in a smoking room. I explained that I have asthma and that if they couldn't change the room I would like to cancel and find another hotel and they said I would still be charged for the room. I then went to talk to the manager (in Japanese) and finally after showing her all of the negative reviews and asking her if no one cared what damage they were doing to their brand she said she would allow me to cancel without charge.I've been traveling to Japan for 20 years and have never had a bad experience at a Japanese hotel -- Keio Plaza is just terrible, you are much better off staying somewhere like the Hotel Century Southern Tower.

Within walking distance to Shinjuku train station which will lead you to everywhere you want to go easily. There are also lots of small food outlets in the Shinjuku area. We found great Jap food like Ichiran ramen and the standing sushi bar there.

Really enjoy staying at this hotel. Besides the great location, the friendly hotel staff and renovated rooms are definitely a plus. Hotel room sizes are nice for Tokyo as many hotel rooms are the size of shoe boxes in this city.
