All the subways you need are 5 mins away, there's shuttle buses direct to and from both airports plus free transport to Disneyland. Lots of food and shopping right around the corner. Recommended for both business trips and vacations!

I stayed in this hotel more than three times.When I was still single, the area is very convenient for me, Food places and shopping malls are all around. After I have kid, travelling with my mom, my 2-yr old girl and my hubby, this hotel is a perfect choice as well, Airport bus directly send/pickup you to/from hotel is so convenient(well, of course you will need to buy the ticket.), especially you travelling with someone too young/or too old... :PRoom size is bigger than average in the area. (I usually picked the 35 square m/or bigger) Only One thing- The bathroom is a little too small, and the bathtub is a little dangerous for kids and elder people.(Must be really careful) It also has a nice Nursery room just next to lobby, convenient store just inside the hotel, Shuttle bus to/from Tokyo Disney resort, less than 5 mins walk to subway station. I would come back here and def. recommend this hotel if you're staying in the area, no matter what's your age, you're single, married or with kids.

I can't remember last time I stayed at this hotel but it's probably 15 years ago. At that time it was very old and all worn down, thus never considered this since. Has to come to Tokyo this week and all hotels were full when I checked earlier, so reluctantly I booked my stay at Keio Plaza.To my surprise, it's actually much better than what I experienced 15 years ago. All the rooms are refurbished (I assume all rooms, at least mine was nice and the furniture and fixtures are all in good conditions). And more importantly, the aircon in the room is working like a charm (very rare in Japan, most aircon in hotel rooms doesn't really work, no matter how you adjust the temperature or fan speed it stayed constant at around 28 deg C). The thermostat actually works here in my roomConveniently located, good restaurant for breakfast, very close to the shopping area and the Shinjuku park for a morning run.The only thing that's disappointing is the gym, it has basically nothing except a few treadmill.Now I have one more option when I come to Tokyo

I had stayed at this hotel for one week during school holiday. It is very good hotel, good location, close shopping, big room, very clean, very good service. During we stay, there was raining one day, hotel provide the umbrella for free. You go to hotel from airport, if you have JR pass, take JR train to get there, better than taking the bus. But only one thing you need to put on mind, they are check in time is 2pm. If you arrive there in the morning, you have to wait. I will go back there if I go to Tokyo next time.

I checked in to Keio Plaza betw 4th to 8th October. Upon my check in, I was asked to pay Y800 for hotel tax. I was not informed about this when I booked the hotel with Expedia. But since it is not a big sum, I obliged. On the 8th when I checked out. The reception asked me to pay Y800 again. I told him I had paid when I checked in but he said there was no record. I clearly remembered I did as I track my expenses and the balance tallied with me paying the Y800 upon my checked in. I did not persist as it was a small amount but I wonder how this could happen. Otherwise the hotel is well located. 5mins to Shinjuku Station is about right.

This is a good hotel for business trips. It has the usual amazing service you will find everywhere in Japan.Location is great! 5 mins walk to Shinjuku station, lots of great food options. Easy airport express options as well.Breakfast options are good, however I did not try any restaurants for dinner due to the walking distance to the shopping mall and streets full of different restaurants.Room was clean and had everything I needed for my business trip, wifi was good speed as well.

This hotel is huge, huge lobby and crowed. Rooms comfortable, well designed, nice views on most of them. I'd experience earthquake and hotel is well designed to support it. Walk distance to main tube station. Close to a shopping district and large electronic shop.

We were there in Oct'15 but dont have a good memory as our boy was sick and the hotel refer us to an expensive medical clinic about 15-20 minutes by taxi from the hotel. The clinic name is Sendagaya International Clinic. Seems like the clinic is for mostly tourist/expatriate and we feel that we were being rip off as the total bill came at close to 30000 yen. The hotel never informed us about the possibility of such huge medical bill and when we complained to the guest relationship manager, they just said that the the clinic was actually cheaper than other alternative. Our room was in the south tower and it was small and dusty. Breakfast was ok. Location is ok because not far from the hotel there are train/bus station, dept store and restaurants/shop. This was our first time to Tokyo but i think next time is better to stay at Shibuya/Ginza area where you have more attraction than Shinjuku area.

We stayed here for five nights in total, splitting in two and three night blocks. Our first stay was in the main tower in a superior room. It quite large and very functional without having stylish decor. There was a separate dressing area outside the bathroom and the king size bed was good quality. Bathroom was decently sized with nice and well stocked toiletries and towels. They provided a cot but not much more baby amenities.The second stay was in a smaller room in the southern tower, which is accessed by a very short walk from the lobby. The room was still clean but amenities were different as well because the class of room wasn't as good as the first stay but decent though. The same goes for the toiletries in the bathroom.There is a small gym that has modern machines and weights that I used, and an outdoor pool that is only open in the summer so did not get to use it.There is a free shuttle bus to Disney that needs to be booked in advance and it's a very convenient service.Staff are friendly as always in Japan, with a decent command of English, relatively speaking.No breakfast was included in the rate we got but it is available and they have a range of restaurants at the bottom level of the building, along with a convenience store.We had an enjoyable stay here and would think about staying again. The proximity to the Shinjuku station, shops and restaurants are its main selling point. Plus, if you have a west facing room you may be able to see Mount Fuji on a clear day, which we did.

We stayed in this hotel for 1 night before a cruise. Lovely clean hotel in a good location near shops, restaurants. Views from the restaurant where we had breakfast offer you views over Tokyo. Everything we needed was within walking distance.

Keio Plaza Hotel is located in the heart of Shinjuku, so it's very convenient. We have easy access to shopping malls, restaurants, convenient stores & all transportations. The room is big, clean & comfy with reasonable price. The staff are helpful. The hotel also provides many day tours such as to Disneyland, Yokohama & so on (not free but convenient) for their guests. If you have no idea how to visit any place, you can contact hotel information center.

So tasteful for buffet breakfast provided in the morning with 3 restaurants that you desire International, American and also Japanese open from 05 a.m. to 10.00 a.m.The clean room with full amenities, morning newspaper, cable T.V. (almost in Japanese)

We are staying here for 7 nights at the beginning of our Japan holiday. We have a King Size room on the 25th floor. Corner room opposite the Government Building. Great sized room with more than adequate bathroom. Great shower with lots of hot water.The bed is a bit firm and the pillows a little on the soft side but still sleeping well.Room is cleaned every day and excellent housekeeping standards.Limited English speaking channels available on TV but.....we're not really here to watch TV.Standard of room service food average and quite expensive.Also....local ATMs in building DONT accept overseas credit cards if you want to withdraw cash...you need to find a nearby Seven Eleven Store or Citibank ATM. Both about 15/20 minutes walk away. Staff very friendly and helpful. Excellent onsite restaurants. We would definitely stay here again if we came back to Tokyo.

We stayed here for 11 nights, following a 3 night stay in Nagoya for the Susuka F1. The hotel is lovely, we couldn't fault it. The location is fantastic .Free wifi worked great. The view from the bar on the 45th floor was also fantastic - although the drinks a little pricey - but worth it for the view. All in all i would highly recommend this hotel and when i get the chance to return to Tokyo i shall certainly book this hotel again :-)

The airport bus stops right in front of the hotel and there's a free shuttle bus to Disney land and Disney Sea. There are many shops and small restaurants near by, it is approx. 8 mins walk to JR station west exit.The rooms are clean and large compared to other hotels in Japan, the price is reasonable. The main tower undergone renovation so it still looks very new. They even offer Hello Kitty room nowadays. The hotel also have some nice restaurants but expensive in the evenings. The staff are very friendly and process good English so very easy to communicate with them. There is a large convenience store on the bottom floor of the hotel opened till 2am with a large selection of goods and small gifts. My only concern is their slow wifi connection.

The Keio Plaza is an old hotel but it is well maintained. We chose this hotel as we were intending to visit Disneyland and also needed a room for three.The Disneyland shuttles, airport transfers, location and room size are the major plus for Keio Plaza. It is a lot more convenient to take the Disney Shuttle as it takes roughly 20-30 minutes by coach from the hotel and gets you directly to the main entrance of the theme park. The hotel is also about a 7 minutes walk from the JR Shinjuku West exit. There is a Yodabashi and many food options along the way from the station to the hotel, so it is very convenient to get food. There are also a couple of convenience stores in the surrounding area.The room is big, clean but nothing too fancy. It serves its purpose well - if the price is right. The only downside is that the hotel gets crowded (so check-in takes a while and you probably won't have a ready room early) and that the price point is rather high. I would choose to stay in other hotels if I am not visiting Disneyland or need a bigger room. Oh, about wifi - the connection is not stable and drops easily - good to get a portable wifi instead of relying on the hotel's.

We spent three nights here in early December, 2014. The beds were big enough for my tall Texan husband to have a good sleep. The Sizzler's across the hotel was a great easy place to get a big dinner after a day of sightseeing when we were too tired to read Japanese menu.Our view is the monstrous Tokyo city building. The incredible night view made our Tokyo visit so memorable for my family.

We generally try to stay away from large hotels and the Keio Plaza has 1400 rooms. However, this hotel really works. The staff were all friendly and helpful. The rooms were not large, but we're certainly fine, particularly if one wants to spend most of ones time in Tokyo and not in the hotel. The facilities are extensive and the hotel is only a few steps away from a multitude of Shinjuku restaurants. We vote for the Keio as a really good place to stay in Tokyo.

Less then 10min walk from Shinjuku station, remember to take the West exit at the basement level. If you exit from the train station on ground level, it is more difficult to locate the hotel. Had difficulty in connecting to the Wifi in the room, the operator on the phone is totally of no use as she claimed that it is our HP problem.Went to the reception counter and managed to connect and signed in successfully. Tip - Try to sign in and get connected at the Reception before you head to the room.

A great hotel for first time visitors to Tokyo as the location is very accessible. It is pricey (but all Tokyo hotels seem to be) and the onsite food is ridiculously expensive ($10 for a cup of coffee anyone?), however, it has great accessibility to a number of subway stations and exploring Shinjuku which is absolutely alive at night.The only comment with respect to the service is the painfully long check-in lines. Nothing is more frustrating (for N. Americans) than waiting in line while there are only two check-in agents yet another 15 people behind the desk. I'm sure there is a good reason but if you've taken a red eye flight, it's frustrating!The concierge is very helpful - be sure to ask them for directions on where you are going and they will help you navigate the metro. Once you use the metro once, you'll see how super simple it is. Don't be afraid!

We stayed in the hello kitty town room and absolutely loved it!! Check in was easy once we had found the desk (it is a big place!) bags taken up to the room for us. Room was big, comfy and so much fun!!! The decor was amazing and complete with a giant kitty and a little one to keep as a monento!! All toilettries, pjs and slippers were provided which was super helpful as our luggage did not arrive! Reception also provided items such as phone charger that we needed. There were a few options for brealfast and the japanese set breakfast was beautiful. The location was great, short walk to shinjuku station and could get anywhere from there. When leaving check out was at 1100 which was no problem as we needed to be on our way, the hotel also courried our luggage to our hotel in kyoto for us for equivalent of £8 per bag so we didnt have to worry about them while scaling Fuji!! Would stay there again and would definetly recommend the kitty town room!! A great fun start to our round japan trip.

A lovely roomy spacious hotel in a convenient area of Tokyo . Staff very pleasant and welcoming , rooms spacious with nice bathroom and air conditioning . Selection of restaurants within the hotel area that are nice but expensive . We had breakfast included that had a great selection to pick from

Friendly staff, easy check in / out, great amenities, clean room, free safe deposit box, safe in room, convenience store in the basement, terrific breakfast bar, breath taking views. This hotel is conveniently located within 5 minutes of the Shinjuku station and post office. There are also a ton of terrific spot to eat within a short walk also.The service was fantastic from everyone at the hotel, I couldn't have asked for more. This is my go to hotel from now on when I visit Japan!

This is a huge efficient hotel. Modern and clean and convenient to public transport especially the metro station next door on the Oeno line. A highlight was the buffet dinner meal in the restaurant with a fantastic menu range and excellent cuisine. Next door in a very high government office block with even more magnificent views of the city at night.

We stayed in two renovated rooms as a family of 6 and found this hotel to be excellent. Roomy, great service at the restaurant and bars and excellent location for the Shinjuku Station. A few friends were staying nearby at the Hilton but commented that the Keio was nicer. Highly recommend.

We were visiting Tokyo for the first time and this was a great choice. The coach from the airport is efficient - just remember to book a slot back in plenty of time as they were full when we tried (the same morning) so we had to leave on an earlier one. Great location with lots of shops and restaurants nearby and easy to get to the metro. Staff were very helpful. Only downside was we didn't get to use the pool as they don't let tattooed guests in but apparently this is the case in many Japanese hotels.

We stayed in premier room at main tower, room is big and clean with Nespresso machine, facing metropolitan building, perfect. We booked the leisure package, which it says including breakfast. But apparently not the full breakfast, just a small one in the cocktail lounge. The choice is really sad, fruits, jogurt, cereals and pastries, not like a 5 star hotel breakfast. The pastries are bad, like it was made the day before. We asked if we can go to the main breakfast restaurant, they said no. So leisure package is not good.We also got voucher to go to Luxe Lounge in the south tower. Lounge is ok, nice view with some snacks and beverages, but they close at 22.00.The hotel location is very good, just a step away from Oedo line metro and Shinjuku station.We were told that to check out we can go to premier counter, but when we went there, no one was at the desk. After waiting for some time, we moved to main counter.

Lovely rooms & perfect location. Has a lovely lounge with views over the city serving drinks and snacks. Only a short walk to Shinjuku station but even shorter walk to a different subway stop from the back of the hotel. Only downside is that there was nowhere to sit outside to relax after a long day of sightseeing (the pool area was already closed)

The Gumbys are staying at this fine hotel. So far day 2 but I thought I'd relate a salutary experience so others might benefit from what happened to Mr Gumby.The hotel room has an e-toilet and by that I mean one with a panel full of buttons next to it to ease the experience of evacuating one's bowels or bladder. Of course Mr Gumby could not resist these buttons for what is a button for if not for pressing? So Mr Gumby is enthroned having done what was needed and decided to press the button which looked like it might send a gentle spray up to the nether regions and was rewarded with a continuous jet of water hitting the area it was presumably designed to hit. After about 20 seconds Mr Gumby had had enough and decided to turn it off. So he pressed the button again, to no avail. Thinking that there was perhaps a delay Mr Gumby waited , but no, the stream of water continued its relentless journey upwards into Mr Gumby's bottom. Now slightly panicking Mr Gumby hit the button again, but nothing. Then Mr Gumby saw an on/off button which he hit straight away. All that did was to turn of the very pleasant toilet seat heater off. Now mild panic started to set in and worst case scenarios flashed through Mr Gumby's mind. What if it couldn't turn off? A flooded floor, building collapse due to water damaged concrete? Even worse the indignity of having to leap off the toilet, force the lid down whilst the relentless geyser of water tried to escape the pan and then having to shout to Mrs Gumby to call the hotel engineers to fix the problem. That particular vision had the indignity of the engineers arriving in the room to be greeted with the vision of a pink and very clean posterior bent over the toilet trying to keep the lid closed. Finally Mr Gumby espied an orange button with the word OFF on it and hit it as fast as he could. The jet of water stopped! Mr Gumby declares and avows that, at this moment in time, he has the cleanest backside in Japan if not the world and henceforth will always look for an 'off' button before pressing an 'on' button.

Beautiful grand hotel, extremely functional for conferences but also great for travelling whether as yourself a couple or a family.Exceptionally clean - green tea available in rooms.Fantastic location in central Shinjuku.Great hotel breakfast and world class staff - so helpful and accomedating!Pretty expensive but worth it. 10/10 would stay again. : )

We came here for our honeymoon, I understand that Tokyo is not yuor usual honeymoon destination but we love this city. We booked the business suite which is located on the 25th floor and overlooks the Tokyo metropolitan building - which is quite an impressive building! The hotel is in a prime location, right in the heart of Shinjuku in between the station and the central park. The hotel is huge and spralling with restaurants and tourists from all over the world. Considering this fact, we were checked in quite quickly and the service we were provided with throughout our stay was impecable. The only downside I could pass comment on was the pillows - not fluffy and did very little to support my neck as the filling seemed to part in the middle and sink. Saying that, after exploring Tokyo all day, I still slept very well!

Room is nice location is good though you need to walk a bit for train station which is not advisable going to the airport especially if you are carrying a lot of stuff. But of course bus stops right at the door step of the hotel . service is also good (though we are not allowed to extend for an hour without pay they said that's it's full but if you are going to pay its okay) except for the internet you need to log up in everyday which is a hustle . The sushi resto there is excellent but it's very expensive.

We stayed 5 nights in a Premier Twin room. Extremely clean. Good size room; very comfortable. Really enjoyed our stay. Staff helpful. Chose a room in the MAIN tower, not the south tower. South tower has older rooms in need of renovation.

Stayed there twice: in 2012 and in 2015. Both times in a Plaza Premier room, but first time without breakfast and lounge, second time - with both. The Premier rooms are large and the view is great on both sides of the hotel. "Luxe Lounge" is not worth the money, no food, only drinks, pretty disappointing compared to other hotels. Breakfast: food and choice are very good, but poorly organized - virtually always one has to stand in a line for 10-15 minutes before seated. Location is great. A convenience store in basement. Swimming pool is not free even if you pay the top rate for a Plaza Premier room with club benefits - very disappointing. Limousine bus to pretty much everywhere. Great place to stay in Tokyo, just do not waste money on extras.

This place is huge, nice and beautiful. The Service is great. Room is nice. Various restaurants and shopping opportunities on site. Linked to the Shinjuku subway station via a tunnel. Just 5 min walk. I had a great view from my room of the Tokyo Metropolitan building on the 28th floor and received access to the club lounge that was surprisingly small when everything else in that hotel is huge. The limobus frequently stops there whether you commute to/from Haneda or Narita airport.Beware the buffet breakfast on the 2nd floor Western and Japanese is by far much better than the Western buffet at the lobby level on 3rd. Usually, you will be politely ask to consider the Western buffet breakfast at the lobby level if you do not look Asian. Better wait to get a seat on the 2nd floor.

Firstly, thank you Belova Ksenia on the desk at Guest Relations. I would have been lost without you translating and writing places we were going in Japanese. The Keio Plaza is big and very busy. Our room was a great size and with little extras like hair brushes, and the option of booking the Hello Kitty room if you had a little girl, make it special. The restaurant, Kagari, was exceptional and a highlight for us on our first night. A few minor issues.... as there are not enough chairs or lounges in the foyer, my husband and son sat down, out of the way, to wait until check in. He was told to stand up. We couldn't use the bar unless we purchased a drink, and we had just travelled for hours from Australia. They need more chairs. We just wanted to rest while waiting for our room.Also, keep the internet/wifi password with you at all times as it drops out constantly. I asked for milk to use to make a cup of tea in our room and was charged $8 AU. Usually, a little fresh milk is placed in mini bars in good hotels. Go to the family mart downstairs and buy your milk (they have great sushi too).Bring your own pillow if you're fussy. Japanese pillows are really bad.We would stay again and LOVED Tokyo.

friendly big rooms clean and comfortable. Nothing to much trouble. Great service and food stayed two night close bus and train services easy to get around in town people very helpful free wi fi serviced rooms

I am the usual guest of the Keio Plaza at Shinjuku as it is a very convenient location with good services. We booked the renovated Superior room and upgraded to the spacious Deluxe room. Good hospitality with English speaking staff.

We needed a hotel in Tokyo for one night and having stayed in Shibuya two weeks earlier selected the Keio for access to Shinjuku and also for comfort. It is an older hotel, so some of the interior decor is a bit dated, but we had picked renovated rooms and we were very happy with the space and layout.Check-in, check-out were fine, we stored luggage as well, which was handled without fuss. A late lunch also went very well at one of the restaurants in the hotel where they delivered the food quickly and also provided a gluten free option with no notice.The view from the room (28th floor) was also pretty good.

This hotel is very much in the center of all things Shinjuku; we've also stayed at the Hilton nearby and find the Keio plaza to be more convenient to the trains, restaurants and arcades that we love. I was very impressed by this hotel overall; as some have mentioned it's definitely an institution. When we checked in they gave us a complimentary upgrade to a Plaza Luxe Corner King. I believe they did this because they were running out of twin beds and we were a couple who had booked twin beds... It was a large, clean, and lovely room with a desk and a lounge area. The view from the 33rd floor looked out over the city and government buildings to the mountains and was utterly gorgeous!! The toilet had a big glass standing shower and a bath with a shower, and the ubiquitous Toto Washlet which we adore :) The air conditioning worked flawlessly and housekeeping was surprisingly impeccable: the minute we left our room, they'd have it clean within an hour. This hotel contains one of our favorite sushi restaurants in Tokyo, Kyubei. I'd recommend the omakase; the chefs do speak some English and are happy to educate you. When I didn't know what one fish was, the chef actually brought out a book with translations. There's also some great Japanese whiskey (Taketsuru 21) in the bar on the 2nd floor (I think) across from the convenience store.One caveat: the gym is a dreadful, hospital room-sized facility with bright fluorescents, but it is well-maintained.

The hotel was in walking distance of stores, shops, restaurants and parks. It was a beautiful hotel, very clean and the staff were very friendly and helpful. The only down side for us was that it was a very expensive hotel and yet you had to pay extra to use the pool and it would have been nice if breakfast had been included. It was also a long distance from the airport (Narita), but there were shuttles. Wifi was free. No ice machines on the floors, but the staff brought us ice when we requested it - at no cost - and they refused all tips.

It is an absolutely great hotel, having a couple of (themed) restaurants of which we checked out 2 for breakfast with great delight.The hotel is located near to the junction of quite a bit of public transportation, so quite easy to reach (although it takes a couple of minutes to walk from the underground to the hotel which may be strenous after a multi hour flight...).The hotel also has a nice pool that looks good but we never visited due to the suspiction that the big line of people were waiting to gain access to the pool.The biggest issue with the hotel is the apparantly low elevator capacity without (recognized) possibility to use stairs instead (the stairs we found had indicators on the doors that alarms will sound if opened...). In conjunction with a congress apparantly happening in the hotel that led to warning signs of elevated waiting times at times of high usage (and we had to wait in que some 10 minutes to get access to the elevator once).

Very nice hotel next to busiest tube station in Tokyo. Handy location with plenty of shops and restaurants. We didn't have breakfast included, so first time there, we bought a sandwich from the convenience store in the basement as we couldn't find any suitable western type food. The next day we ordered room service, which was better and not too expensive. We had dinner 2 nights up on the 45th floor. Basic meal but reasonable. There are plenty of restaurants in the hotel but most were a bit more expensive and as we had had big lunches we didn't want to eat too much or spend too much.We recommend this hotel as it was very efficient, clean and very well located.

Our room was very spacious, had wonderful views, very clean and modern. Bed very comfortable, staff were very friendly and helpful. A number of tours leave from this hotel which we found to be important as we did not wish to find our own way to other hotels to commence tours.

Nice, comfortable hotel. They had EVERYTHING you could need right down to hair ties in the bathroom and a charger in the safe! We also didn't need adaptors. Good sized rooms. Restaurants in the hotel were very good too.

Overall I was disappointed with the hotel from start to finish. I arrived at 11am to check in however was informed that I could not check in until 14:00. The staff were unfriendly and when I asked if any room would be available early it seemed an inconvenience.When I did finally check in the room was nothing like in the pictures. We were in the older part of the hotel and therefore the rooms looked like something out of the 1950s. The carpet was stained and there was dirt everywhere especially underneath any of the furniture. We were also near the elevators which shook our room every couple of minutes giving me a sea sick feeling.Eventually we complained at reception and was moved rooms, again it seemed like an inconvenience. This room was a little cleaner but still not great and my bedding had stains on it. The only bonus to the hotel was the location as there is a selection of restaurants nearby and it was very close to Shinjuku train station. We did not try the food at the hotel as it was very expensive compared to the restaurants outside.For our finally night we upgraded to the Hello Kitty two rooms. These were brilliant but for the cost of nearly £280 a night I would expect it. They are decorated very well and we are glad we ended our holiday on a high point in the two rooms.The hotel did agree to store our luggage while we travelled to Kyoto however even that caused issues as although I informed them that several bags had fragile items, they still chucked my heavy bags on top of them.Overall I would not return to this hotel as it was the worst hotel I stayed in during my holiday in Japan. I heave been informed that the renovated rooms are apparently better and what is pictured on the booking websites, however they should include pictures of the older rooms so people know what they are getting themselves in for. My advise is to book one of these rooms or the Hello Kitty rooms.

Every time I will try to reserve a room with access to the Executive Lounge, where the service is convenient for tourists who like to return to the hotel for a rest on and off while shopping around in Tokyo. Even after check-out, the lounge will allow access and you have a cozy place to relax before leaving for the airport if you do not wish to rush for a last minute shopping.

check out time is 11:00h which is very unusual. we had to leave for the airport at around 17:00h. we deposited our luggage with the bell captain and asked for an area where we could sit and evtl. have access to electricity for our phones. answer ... we do not have. only a few normal chairs in front if the reception or in total 8 (eight) armchairs (already packed with 10 asian guests) !!! after asking the manager of the guest relations whether they expect us to sit on those chairs now for 5 hours .... we earnd inly a smile but no answer. unbelievable for a 4 star hotel with more than 1.200 rooms.

LOVE - Luxe floor room (clean, stylish, comfortable) with Luxe lounge access (free and simple refreshment from 10am to 10pm). It's definitely worth the extra dollar to book Luxe room; HATE - Air-con malfunction with quarky noise on our 1st night, which wake you up at 3am! Love - Nearly all staff have a gd / reasonable standard to communicate in English. Good courtesy as always in most of Jap. hotel.HATE - Some customer service training is needed to handle crisis. E.g. Becoz' of the air-con noise in our rm at 1st night, we request to change room for our rest of 4 nights. The frontdesk staff told us there are no same room type available room that we could change and we had to wait for the coming day. Seriously? do you think that is the best you can do when your hotel has over 1000 rooms! ALSO, when we were placed in another room later, we were asked to CONFIRM if the air-con in that new room had no problem. We, who stayed one night in that room, could only tell you the air-con had no problem last night, but how could you expect your guest to CONFIRM your room's air-con would have no problem the rest of the nights. RIDICULOUS.LOVE - Breakfast is great, lots of restaurant choices considering you have so many guests in the hotel; waiting time for a table is less than 10 mins.LOVE - Great shuttle access from Haneda / Narita. Save ALOT of hassle with luggage.LOVE - Lots of restaurants choices around.HATE - Location a bit far from Central Shinjuku / stations in a hot / humid summer days. Will only come back again to Luxe rm with lounge access.

Very good service and answer every question you have for them. Train station is just 1min away (below the hotel) .. Food streets is just across the road. Limousine bus service to airport, premium outlet, Disney etc are available. Will definitely come back if I visit Tokyo again!

panoramic view of tokyo, a place to stay to visit the city.The near station with several lines help you to go for a trip in every place.If you have tired a ryokan in kyoto or other smaller town you can take this hotel.

As my subject title suggests, the only good thing about this hotel is that it has a great location to the main area of Shinjuku. We stayed at the Premiere lounge and upon checking in, the service received at the Premiere lounge (presumably more exclusive) was not exactly great. My friend made a genuine mistake in her reservation for the hotel stay, but the duty manager was very impatient and almost condescending. Despite hearing our explanation of our booing, they shifted most of the blame to Agoda - which my friend made the reservation on. No attempt was made to help explain the matter further, the duty manager was banging angrily at the keyboards while trying to retrieve our reservations - not to mention that my friend has stayed more than 4 times at the Premiere rooms in this hotel. This is something we least expect from what is well known to be Japanese hospitality.

Airport transfer via Limo Bus was a breeze. Brings you directly to the hotel lobby. Check in was a breeze with many counters and typical Japanese hospitality. The English communication could be better. Its a smoking hotel so choose your rooms wisely. Adequate lifts for a big hotel. Waiting time was minimal for the lifts. Rooms were spacious, modern and clean (Plaza Premier Room). Bathroom space and layout though were somewhat disappointing. Views facing office buildings (Tokyo metropolitan). Location: Just outside of Shinjuku. Underground Walkway to Shinjuku JR station was useful especially if it rains. Above ground can be complicated but is roughly a straight path in an alley towards the JR station - along the way you can buy drinks and snacks from the convenient stores, check out the latest trends in the pharmacy, stop by Standing Sushi bar for a snack and shop at Yodobashi mega electronic stall. It is also convenient if you are taking the local buses to other areas outside Tokyo as the major Bus terminus is there. The Odakyu romancecar station to Hakone is also located just across from the bus terminus. The department store is located above the train station and food/supermarket at the basement. Its s bit more complicated if you wish to walk to Isetan side of Shinjuku as you will have to locate and underpass hidden in an alley way. Did not dine at the hotel but noted there were large restaurants with buffet options for international cuisine and Japanese as well. One plus point is the free shuttle bus to Disney Sea and Disney Land stop at the hotel with specified timings. Do make a booking with the Bell Hop the day before to book your seat on the shuttle bus. There is also a return shuttle from Disney to the hotel - do take note of the departure timings and be punctual! Overall a good hotel option for both business and pleasure if you wish to stay in Shinjuku and near the train or bus terminus.

My husband and I stayed 4 nights from 28 August 2015 at Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku and it was exactly as I expected after reading the reviews - a centrally located, large and efficient hotel. The room and bathroom were clean, bathroom amenities were generously replaced when used, Wi-Fi worked fine in the room, very easy transport between the hotel and Narita/Haneda via the Airport Limousine Bus. We had use of the Luxe Lounge which opened from 10am to 9:30 pm. After a day of walking it was great to relax with a glass of wine in the lounge before heading out for dinner. The lounge serves free wine and beer after 5 pm and tea/coffee soft drinks and a few pastries at other times. The lounge is not as well stocked as other hotel lounges but we found it good enough.We had dinner at Kyubey and it was excellent. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys good sushi. We also had a teppanyaki dinner at Yamanani which my husband raved about - that would be his recommendation.The negatives - the bathroom is small. It also took me a while to find where to plug in my charger and the socket for the kettle did not work so I had to make tea at the desk. i also think that Luxe Lounge should offer simple breakfast items (bread, butter and jam would do) in the mornings.This hotel is not for travellers who enjoy the more personalised service of boutique hotels but it is perfect for those who want an efficient, easy to get to centrally located hotel to use as a base for their visit.

This hotel is huge. With two separate towers. Popular and mostly catering for large tour groups. The rooms are large by tokyo standards. With western beds and facilities. All the restaurants are expensive so don't bother dinning in unless you don't care about price. It's about 3 blocks walking distance from Shinjuku station. It is a good position to be based in Tokyo. I probably wouldn't stay here again though, but good for a first time visit to Tokyo. Next time I would probably stay in a smaller hotel in shibuya area closer to shopping and restaurants.

Well located, wide rooms. Staff are efficient. There are several restaurants, bakery and convenience stores. Shinjuku area is worth a visit. Subway some minutes walk! Restaurants at breakfast time can be very busy, you can choose places at the station or just crossing to Shinjuku district! There are several dept stores in the area too!

We had a lovely few days in Tokyo staying here. The rooms are large and have tea/coffee making facilities, hair dryers and everything you would expect in a well appointed hotel.There is no or little WiFi available in the rooms which took us a day or two to work out and was quite frustrating. It is available in the foyer but the foyer is always crowded with few seating options.It is really well located and I would definitely stay again, more so if the WiFi issue was sorted out

For a pleasant and comfortable stay in the city, Keio Plaza Hotel always delivers. Situated just across the street from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building, Keio Plaza Hotel is at the hub of a remarkable city district adjacent to the Shinjuku Train Station. The rooms are spacious and very clean with a full set of guest amenities (love the Shiseido face wash, wish they sold it in the convenience store!). The staff are very professional, helpful and accommodating. The hotel restaurants leave no traveler hungry, and offer everything from casual to fine dining. The Glass Court's breakfast buffet is amazing with its huge variety of Japanese and Western selections. For a casual dining experience, Jurin is a great choice. Even the hotel's convenience store, located on the South Tower's 2nd floor, offers a nice selection of snacks, candy, as well as sandwiches, salads, fruits, cold noodles; souvenirs and travel necessities. The Luxe Lounge, the hotel's best kept secret, is housed on the 34th floor of the South Tower and offers spectacular views of the city, comfy seating zones, free wi-fi, and a small, private meeting room (fee-based). It is a very comfortable place to unwind and relax. During the day the lounge offers tea, coffee, soft drinks, snacks and mini pastries and cakes. Beer, wine and hors d'oeuvres are served in the evening. All are in a self-service environment, and there is a host on duty at all times to answer any questions and offer assistance. Note: The Luxe Lounge is exclusively available for free usage by designated Executive International Club members and designated Plaza Luxe/Plaza Premier guests only. Dining, shopping and transportation are in close proximity, with department stores Keio, Odakyu, Takashimaya and Tokyo Hands just minutes away by foot. There are also at least three Uniqlo stores nearby, as well as a host of fun shops and restaurants. Sekaido is a nice, little stationery shop. Bic Camera and Yodobashi Camera are perfect places to get your electronics fix.

Spent a couple of nights so it's not going to be an in depth but still a heads up review is better than nothing. The hotel is quite big so get to know it. There was an executive lounge but didn't have the chance to use it. We were on the 27th floor in the south tower. The bed was spacious (king size double) and the mattress was as comfortable as the pillows (i'll give it 7 out of 10) . The room's been renovatad in the last 5-6yrs so everything was in a pretty good condition. In general in japan spaces are small (for our western standards) and this hotel makes no exception especially the bathroom which was made for 5th graders. It was ultra clean like most of the hotels in japan , the room service was on the spot along with the house keeping and the breakfast was good.

I've been in this hotel for 3 nights, we got a new room and it was nice but the other ones, old ones are very bad, old fascinated and with a terrible smell of smoke. Good location and breakfast. Not suggested for honeymoon.

My family stayed in a Premier Room. We occupied 2 rooms. Wifi speed is fast. Place is Clean and Tidy. Since my friend occupied a regular twin sharing room, they said that the room is small not good enough for a taller person, they can touch the ceiling in the bathroom. :-) But overall, they were satisfied because of it neatness. The lobby is sooo spacious. You have three choices for your breakfast. We will surely stayed again to this hotel should we decided to go back again in Shinjuku.

I got the renovated room and it was beyond comfortable. Room size is pretty big compared to other hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo(30 sqm). Since it's newly renovated everything looked pretty new and the bed was very comfortable. the staff were very polite. location wasnt the best since i have to walk quite a bit to the shopping malls and train station.

The hotel was huge but easy to find your way around the two towers and only 300 metres from the busiest rail station in Tokyo, Shinjuku. Well worth a look and non smoking...... Our room was huge and the bathroom area was a great size with a powder mirror outside the actual bathroom. Pick up for tours is easy and the Japanese restaurants on site were divine.

4 nights in a "plaza premier king". Reception is great as we we arrived early, the room was not ready but we were offered the option to wait in a private lounge with beverages and cakes. The room got a beautiful view 37th floor. We have chosen a smoking room. Decoration is classic but fair. Bathroom ok only a point : if you are tall the shower is not so comfortable. Bed is comfortable. To be noticed and important for travellers facing jet lag in the basement of the hotel on top of numerous restaurants you have a shop which open at 5 am and get everything you need to eat or you wish to drink. Laundry is perfect and not so expensive The location is really great and convenient. WIFI is working but no high-speed in the room only in the lobby/ bar.

This hotel was chosen for our visit to Tokyo and turned out to be an inspired choice.The facilities were all as hoped for and more.The staff were so good and coul;d not be helpful enough, we were made to feel like VIP's I would recommend this hotel to anyone thinking of staying in Tokyo.Thank you Keio Plaza ...

Stayed here a few nights, after trying for some time in vain to find a hotel in Shinjuku with a twin room that was non-smoking. (Harder than it should be to do that in Tokyo.) more expensive than planned, but alternatives were undesirable. Hotel is very well located, a couple of minutes walk from both the train station and the Tokyo Government Metropolitan Building, which has excellent lookout towers.Hotel checkin was friendly and efficient. All staff we encountered were both friendly and helpful, despite the massive sure if this hotel. Room was a good size, with typical facilities and interesting view of Shinjuku skyscrapers. Free wifi was not as fast as we would have preferred but it did work.Breakfast was the highlight, however. We chose the Japanese breakfast, which was very tasty, spectacularly served and located in a very pleasant and small restaurant. We have normally chosen the (western) buffet, and pleased to have made a different choice this time.

....when it comes to providing information about a laundromat near the hotel. I am currently staying here for a month, and when I asked the Premier Reception a laundromat nearby, the staff instantly said that there is nothing nearby, and the nearest one being a 30 mins walk! No doubt the hotel is trying to get people to use their overpriced (like every hotel) in-house laundry service. That is not the type of service a hotel should provide its customers. My company uses this hotel all the time for our staff. I will be having a word about this to them.

I was fortunate enough to get a room at the premier plaza and the room was more spacious compared to the main building and well-renovated. The service staffs were very helpful in giving directions and will be greeted with genuine smile when approached by us. There is a free shuttle service to/fro disneyland/sea at stipulated timing but we will have to reserve our seating at the concierge at least a day before going and they will issue you some form of receipt for you to board the shuttle bus. I In-room service wise, I called for a shiatsu massage one of the night as I was feeling tired after a long day of shopping. I opted for 1hr 30mins massage thinking that the japanese will be better in shiatsu than if I were to do balinese/thai massage (in japan, right?). To my disappointment, the massage by the therapist was substandard and it was more like a mere implied pressure on my body than the legit way of finger pressure massage. I would not recommend doing shiatsu massage in house. Location wise was a short walk to Odaiku and other major departmental stores like Isetan and Takashimaya. All in all, I would recommend this hotel for its location (if you intend on shinjuku that is) and it's price. It is quite a distance away from asakusa and ginza area but in tokyo, taking the metro is the most convenient way of getting around. So that isn't much of an issue!

As expected the service was top-notch. Better still the food was amazing, especially the breakfast options. I chose Jurin for its ceiling-high windows which overlook a lovely garden. The table facing the window is wonderful for a pleasant start for the day. The breakfast selection and quality is unsurpassed.

From the 30th floor, our room had a magnificent view of Tokyo and the government towers opposite. It was spacious, immaculate and had absolutely everything (and more than I could imagine) to make our stay extremely comfortable.

I stayed couple nights last time visited Tokyo I just wanna comment on couple stuffs. First Keio Plaza is located 7 mins away from Shinjuku station which means tons of shopping and tons of restuarants nearby. This hotels offers Good size room comparing other hotels in tokyo. However this hotel is expensive and plus they charge everything that you use. I guess I had to pay extra yen for location!!!

Close to the Shinjuku station with plenty to eat around the hotel. Paid shuttle bus is also available directly to the hotel from Narita airport. Spacious and very clean. Near to the observatory at the government building just across the road.

Super good location just a short walk to Shinjuku Station and various shops/restaurants. Suitable for families wanting to visit Disneyland with the free shuttle service. Plaza Luxe Rooms are highly recommended for a better standard room

We stayed in the renovated area of the hotel, the room is spacious, we really thought it would be small because of the Japanese standards, even the bathroom is nice. You walk for a minute and the train is there, walk a few more and there are array of shopping stalls. In the heart of shinjuku, the bus from the airport even stops at the front of the hotel. Will stay here def again.

I have lost my magnetic card in the city- the charged me 500Y. I have paid my room approximately 25000 . Can't they offer a plastic card seriously? I also went to see the swimming pool. This one is not sunny at all (hidden by the tower), you have to pay to enter, and it is allowed to public. Also it is quite the usine downstairs. I queued 20mn to check-in and still struggle to find the reception or breakfast restaurant among all the souvenirs shops. Even though the rooms are nice , I am very disappointed and will not choose this hotel again.

Stayed for a couple of nights at the end of our 3 week tour of Japan. To put this into context, had stayed in some lovely hotels in various cities, and had started off in the Hilton in Tokyo.Sadly, the Keio Plaza was not a memorable end to our trip.The issue was the hotel is so huge that you end up queuing for everything - check in, restaurant access for breakfast, to speak to the concierge, etc. etc. Also, everything is a bit dated and tired.Good points though, rooms are good size, with good amount of wardrobe space for fitting your cases into. Bed was comfortable, and bathroom was good size with nice amenities.Downside, odd step into the bathroom, not ideal in the middle of the night in the dark! Wifi was very poor, kept cutting out and even when connected was slow.Found all the staff helpful which was great.Sadly, we would probably not return.

Large well-known hotel c. 10 min walking distance from the Shinjuku station in Tokyo. Overall the hotel is quite busy as hosts a number of conferences / events and there are quite a few people next to the lobby. The check-in was quite slow as there were only two check-in desks open. Stayed in a plaza luxe double - very spacious for Tokyo, scenic views, high floor. The lounge access is a plus however doesn't offer much apart from a nice view and a few soft drinks during the day.

Good Location and connected to the underground. Very close to the shopping area of Shinjuku and only 15 min ride on the underground to the Tsukiji market. We took the bus straight from Narita which was very convenient for us. Bigger room than expected.

Very well located, spacious and many and usefull services. Direct bus to and from Narita airport. Underground station at 5 minutes. Prices according to Tokio standards!Very close to a busy night area with plenty of shops.

For a family,The four bedded room with two bathrooms is a luxurious oasis in busy Tokyo. There are not many of these rooms available in the hotel so Americans can book them through the KEIO Plaza office in Los Angeles.Breakfast in the glass court is well worth the expense and hotel guests receive a ten percent discountI recommend this hotel highly.

Stayed for 2 nights beginning of August - perfectly placed hotel. Admittedly the rooms were are a little frayed around the corners but well catered for. Staff friendly enough and reception has a good command of English - not that we anglophiles should expect this everywhere we go. Bathroom very clean.As it is in Shinjuku, you can shop until you drop and have very affordable eateries on your doorstep.

We stayed here for five nights as part of a family vacation. The hotel is very close to shin juku station (centrally located) and huge. We stayed on the upper level floors which were very clean, quiet and comfortable.Amazing attention to detail in this hotel. As an example, there is a square of mirror in the bathroom that does not get foggy with condensation (how do they do this??). Excellent service in general, everyone employed by hotel was unfailingly polite. Very clean. Comfortable bedding. Very good help by concierge, Tokyo is just huge and this lady (Bella? From Russia) was very patient and provided very good help (and maps!). Upper floors (top 2?) grant guests access to guest lounge with amazing views of the city, beverages and (classy) snacks like profiteroles and spiced nuts.

It is a great hotel with restaurants and train station nearby. The room was comfortable with everything we need. The hotel offered three breakfast options, Japanese style, breakfast buffet, and one with mixture of western and Japanese cuisines. We stayed there for five days, and it was fun to decide what to have for breakfast!

We stayed here for 5 nights as part of our honeymoon in a superior king room. It was big and airy with a fantastic view of the city. The bed was very comfortable and the air conditioning was bliss given the heat in Tokyo in July! A benefit of the superior room was access to the Luxe Lounge which had wonderful views and complimentary drinks and snacks.The bathroom was clean and very well supplied with toiletries. The shower had excellent water pressure and the toilet was very modern, with buttons for a heated seat and so on.The service was very polite and friendly and we found all staff spoke very good English. They were very helpful and gave good advice on travelling around the city. We were very close to Shinjuku station, which made travelling very simple. There were some restaurants and cafes close to the hotel and there were also a high number of restaurants in the hotel, which gave a lot of choice.We really enjoyed our stay and would definitely recommend it to others.

We stayed in the hotel with our family. Very satisfied. Great location, nearby train station, shops and dining areas. Great breakfast; choices of Western and Japanese. The rooms are spacious, something that is valuable in Japan. Prices are reasonable.

The hotel is too big. When you arrive by yourself the first time you have to find out where the front desk is located.Once they, very kindly receive you, you might not see no one again until your checkout.Be warned: Traditional restaurants are always full, and close early. You will have to make reservations if you are willing to try them.Hard to find anyone to help for directions; everyone seems to be very busy always. Specially young people at the concierge are not cooperative when you ask for information about the airport limousine.Hotel in well located area in Shinjuku, the best thing is that it is nearby the keio restaurant zone, with many options, and 15 minutes walk from the kabukicho zone.The views are not so great. From one side there´s the twin tower building blocking, and from the other side you can´t see any of the two Tokyo towers.

We stayed here for 4 nights whilst we explored Tokyo and surrounding areas. The hotel is a great base for Shinjuku and other areas. It's only walking distance from the madness, but far enough away not to hear it and get a good nights sleep. The rooms are very large and clean. Good value for money and I'd definitely stay here again

Unfriendly staff, poor concierge, "don't ask me anything" operator. Old posh hotel but managed a crew who don't give a damn if their client were happy or not. Do not recommend, there are better hotel. Walking from Shinjuku Station was a pain as there are not much exit with lift.

Hotel is big and rooms were spacious but old and scruffy. Room was only every three days!!! When I asked why only my towels had been changed they answered that they had an "eco-policy" whatever that meant nothing to do with eco friendliness. Even though we left cards for sheets to be changed they were not. Then wanted to charge me extra for asking for a new card when I left my key inside and then said it was against hotel policy to order any more for security reasons. After some arguing got my card...not enough service had to wait 10 mins to get our bags from storage, then 10 more for taxi. Must be better value for price somewhere else. Best thing was buffet breakfast.

We stayed in this hotel last week as a family of four and it was lovely. This is a very large hotel and is very busy but we never felt that this was in anyway compromising our enjoyment there. The hotel staff are efficient and friendly. We had Premier rooms which were well appointed and large. They even accommodated our request to have two rooms near one another and we were placed at the end of a corridor (nice and quiet) with rooms opposite each other. Any requests were dealt with quickly and politely. We only ate in the breakfast buffet restaurant because the hotel restaurants were expensive, but judging by the excellent standard of food at breakfast I am sure they would be good quality restaurants - just beyond our budget. There are plenty of places to eat nearby. The hotel is next to an underground walkway that takes you straight to the trains - which in summer was perfect. We stayed at this hotel - went for a few days to Kyoto and then back to Keio Plaza - when we returned our rooms weren't ready so we were compensated by reducing the cost of the late check out we had requested. Staff on the customer service desk were helpful and booked a tour for us too. Overall, I would thoroughly recommend this hotel - great location, lovely staff, comfortable rooms, value for the money we paid.

This hotel is fantastic. Staff very helpful and everyone's English was really good. Our room was really nice and in a perfect location, it was walking distances from everywhere we wanted to go. We were early for check in so the booking staff allowed us to use their luxury lounge to hang out in while we waited. Would recommend and visit again. Plus it was also the meeting point for a few of our organised tours so very convenient.

We were so tired from all of out adventuresome touring that when we checked into the hotel, it was like coming home. We didn't have to wonder if the bathroom would be "Western" or not. We didn't have to ask how things worked. We could take a wonderful shower. We were very pleased with the location. In just a few minutes we had walked across the street and gone up the 40-whatever floors to see the spectacular views from the the government building next door. All in all, we'd stay there again in a heartbeat.

Very very large hotel in Shinjuku area of Tokyo , centrally located on government building side (as opposed to shopping and entertainment precinct) of district . Easy walk to major transport interchange etc large range of restaurants catering for all tastes. Within the hotel and good size shop providing a range of travellers needs including food snacks meals and souvenirs. Hotel advertises free bus to Disneyland, however during our 6 day stay this was fully booked so you should not rely on using it. There is no ATM at hotel but the post office which is open for 23 hrs a day is just a short walk down the road. There is also a useful business centre with printer available. I booked a triple room which was a double room plus an addition single bed which did not leave much room for luggage or space to move around . Staff friendly and helpful. Room service on our last day was not done properly . Enjoyed our stay but the hotel size made it seem a bit impersonal there is only limited seating available when waiting for airport bus service.

We stayed at this hotel a while back. Shinjuku is one of the biggest hubs in Tokyo with plenty of shopping and eating to be had. For me personally, it's within walking distance to YODOBASHI camera shinjuku, one of the greatest electronics store I've seen anywhere.Within 50 meters to a convenience store. Only 2 stations away from Meiji shrine and harajuku.All in all, if you like shopping and dining, it's a very convenient place to stay.Tokyo is very large so if you stay in Shinjuku it takes a while to travel to the eastern part of Tokyo (asakusa, tokyo sky tree, etc). The places (suburbs?) you are likely to visit in Shinjuku (for us anyway) are harajuku, shibuya, omotesando, ebisu. Although in saying that you could spend a week alone shopping and dining in Shinjuku.

This is a very busy hotel with both foreign and local guests. Elevators are always crowded with many Chinese & Southeast Asian guests chatting like there's no tomorrow. Very noisy corridors. Rooms are bigger than the average hotels in Tokyo. Bed is comfortable and overall very clean. This a very old hotel and aircontioning system justifies the age of the hotel.. winter or summer, always warm ! Bathroom the usual Japanese standard, small but lovely ! Customer Relations staffs are very professional and helpful. And, restaurants in this hotel are great and oishi !!!

I spent the first night of a week long business trip in this hotel, as my preferred hotel didn't have a vacancy for the first night of my stay. The service was fantastic, but the place is a worn 4 star business hotel... Nothing more, nothing less. The price was very fair for the experience provided. My room had a good view. 4/5. Adequate for the price.

We stay here inshinjuku and this hotel nearby the station and walking for 15 minutes to the shopping area. This is big hotel with two tower, quite place to stay but not too far from crowded area, shinjuku shopping area, where you can find a lot of merchandise : souvenir, electronic, new and second hand bags and watches from luxury branded , cinemas, bar, restaurant etc you could also find kabuki thratre here.

I went there with my daughter and her friend on 07May-15May15, Keio Plaza is the hotel i stay each time i visit Japan, it never let me down, once you arrival the airport either at Haneda or Narita Airport there's Limousine bus that take you right in front of the hotel. fare for adult 3.100JPY and child 1.550 JPY from Narita (1hour 20mints) and 1230JPY child 620JPY from Haneda airport (50-75 mints)This is my 7 times staying at Keio Plaza, The service from conceirge, front desk , room services, housekeeping and tour desk is excellent. Staff are very friendly and helpfull. the hotel at the south wing are newer and cleaner , i stay 5nights at the south wing and 3nite at the main. The main side is a bit old and even thou i request non smoking room, you can still smell the smoke this is the only complaint i have. Keio plaza is right in the heart of city, is in shinjuku area and walking distance to the bust station, the train station and lots of shops and restaurant near by. they have free shuttle to disneyland ,you hv to reserve seat in advance at the concierge counter. If you need to visit places n not sure about it just go to the tour desk they will give out map to show you how to get there with option route there. There's also vending currency exchange machine at the lobby. very convenient to get around for first timer to Tokyo is just 2 station to Harajuku and a station from Shibuya by JR. The hotel have around 11 restaurant, you should try the breakfast at the hotel they have a few option for you to choose .I'm going again on Nov , for sure Keio is my only option

We stayed for seven days.Rooms were small but adequate, toilets/bathroom were good.Keio Plaza Hotel has a very good location.Close to Shinjuku station, where stops airport trains.Very comfortable hotel.

I visited Japan in July 2015 with my pregnant wife and 2 yo daughter and stayed at 3 different hotels - Conrad near Ginza, a service apartment in Osaka and Keio Plaza. Experience was great until we stayed in Keio. Please bear in mind that this is the Plaza Premier (Pretty much an executive room) room we are referring to.1) location - great with 10 min walk to Shinjuku station. 2) Check in - chaotic lobby with no porter on hand to send our luggage up.3) Room - decent space but this is once again the plaza Premier room. Toiletries are branded.4) service - Firstly, the hotel is so busy that no one ( bell captain/ front desk/ concierge ) picks up the phone. Secondly, as we booked 2 rooms and had a flight at 4pm. We asked to check out late for 1 of the 2 rooms at 1.30pm which is pretty much just an hour and a half longer than the regular timing. The Premier front desk lady (Fukuda), who was extremely polite, said it was hotel policy and she could not do anything about our request unless we paid for an extension. We reiterated that we had a 2 yo and a pregnant traveler but she could do nothing because it is "hotel policy". So much for the family hotel brand they try to portray. Thirdly, we asked for a recycled carton box to pack some of our excess purchases for our flight but once again, the hotel wanted to charge for a new box. Ironically, the hotel room has a sign that states that we need to help the hotel save the environment. This was the last straw that resulted in this post.I hope this does not come across as too negative but we hope that future travellers take heed of our experience and decide for themselves if this is for them.

The conceirge staff has been efficient and helpful in helping us reserve dinner tables before our arrival. The location of the hotel is convenient, five minute walk to Shinjuku Station or the long distance bus station.Lots of restaurant choices, though we have not really tried that out this time.Convenient shuttle to airport and Disneyland.

Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo is located next to Shinjuku Station. It's very convenience to get to departament stores , restaurants and JR line from its back door. The hotel staffes are very friendly and can provide all information that you need. If you want to book the bus to NRT or HND. You can ask they to book it for you then buy the bus ticket in the vending machine of the hotel. The Limousine bus just stop of Keio Hotel. Only onething is need to improve : There is no wifi at gym. Its wifi is really good in the room or lobby after you login. But can't get wifi at gym. We have to get out of gym to double check email when we exercise there. It's really inconvenience.

Had a lovely staff here, in the heart of everything. Has shops in the hotel and the staff were very friendly and happy to help with any questions. It is rather expensive (dining options) and I was surprised to see they charge an additional amount to use the hotel's swimming pool, sure include it in the overall price (if you have to) but do not charge people additional to use it. Young daughter was very disappointed you had to pay extra (not an insignificant amount) and didn't want to go for a swim after she heard about the cost.

We stayed for three days as part of a Trafalgar tour. Hotel staff were very efficient and despite our atrocious Japanese, looked after us very well. Rooms were small but adequate, toilets/bathroom (as almost every one in Japan) were great, particularly the electronic toilets with multiple buttons and controls. There is a huge range of restaurants and breakfast meals had a great selection and freshly cooked food. Locations is good, with a short walk to the party/restaurant part of town. A very good stay and would recommend to others, as well as be happy to return.

This was my first time visited Tokyo and stayed in this hotel. The service was good and I loved the view. There were many restaurants to choose. I didn't know the Japanese foods are so good like that. I really enjoyed it.

Beautiful hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. Shinjuku has so much to offer you could spend a week exploring that neighborhood alone! The Shinjuku station is mere minutes away, you can see your hotel from the station and vice versa. That station is where you can catch the shinkansen to different areas of Japan. And if you have a Japan Rail Pass, the Yagamote line is included and will take you to most (if not all) Tokyo hotspot neighborhoods. But back to the hotel...It is clean, classy, and comfortable. The rooms aren't huge but very comfortable. The staff will gladly help you make dinner reservations around town. There is a rooftop pool, but they charge for it, and it isn't super cheap either. I believe it was 1200 yen a day.Feel comfortable booking this hotel, you won't be sorry.

Stayed here for 3 nights. From the entry to the service everything is first class. With 10 restaurants to choose from there is little need to go hunting outside. The Chinese restaurant was particularly good. Also the breakfast menu with a fusion of Asian and European options. Only slight negative was hard which seems to be the norm in Japan and despite asking for a double room we received two twin rooms for us and our two children. Overall thoroughly recommend.

Stayed for 7 nights.Superior rooms are outdated and not renovated rooms. I specifically asked that the rooms not have stale cigarett smell as it is a non smoking room but it had a stale cigarette smell. The carpet was dirty, had dust under the bed, corners of furtniture and around the edges where the wall met the carpet. I would say the condition of the room is 2 stars. The cleaning/house keeping was poorly done. There was always hair left in the bathroom. On one of the days there was still hair in the bathtub drainage. OMG. The cups I used to drink tea was not replaced but just wiped as one day when I had drunk milk out it and left it, when I came back in the afternoon, the cup still had dried milk stein with just some bits wiped off. So wash everything everyday. You dont know what they are using to wipe those cups. Tea bags were not always replenished. The only plus about this hotel was the location to Shinjuku station and the convient store down stairs. Staff - senior looking ones are not friendly at all, but the junior staff are very helpful.

A very good hotel .travel six in a group.we book two room.they gave us two big room .three beds a room.very clean.and staffs very helpful.upgrade to the new rooms.recomended.to travellers .ni far from shinjuku jr station and very near tokyo metropolitan building.(free entrance)we used the courier service to osaka and luggage arrived as stated.

Great hotel with 1438 rooms in 2 high rise towers right opposite the Tokyo Metropolitan Government complex in Shinjuku. In walking distance to Shinjuku train station and shopping, dining and entertainment areas.We arrived conveniently and fast with the Green Tomato shared shuttle service from Narita airport, booked through Viator's website in advance from home, but one also could have taken the Airport Limousine Bus directly to the hotel or the Narita Express train to Shinjuku station for much less money.Check-in at the hotel was slow but well organized due to many groups arriving. The staff at the front desk and throughout was friendly and helpful. We had reserved a superior non-smoking room and received a renovated room in the South Tower on the 21st floor with full view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building and Mt Fuji in the very far distance. The room was spacious with a king-size bed, a seating area and a small writing desk. Plenty of floor space to not bump into our opened 2 suitcases on the floor. A flat-screen TV with international stations, a small built-in refrigerator and quite large safe and a 2-drawer cabinet completed the furniture. Ample closet space for clothes. Bathroom with a Toto toilet/bide, bathtub with powerful shower, one-sink vanity. Separate make-up counter with small sink and hair dryer. Plenty of free toiletries and amenity items.Room was very quiet with good A/C. No problems with free Wi-Fi.Breakfast was not included in our room rate. Hotel has a variety of restaurants and bars with rather high prices. There is, however, a small convenience store on the second floor-2F where one can buy snacks, sandwiches, drinks and bottled alcohol at a decent rate.There is a multitude of small restaurants and shops in the near neighborhood. For example, walk out the back hotel entrance to the Shinjuku First West Building across the street and have a sandwich and coffee at the Excelsior Café Shop in the lobby for just 500 Yen, half the price of the Starbucks down the road.To sum it up, the Keio Plaza Hotel is a great and large hotel in a good location in this confusing but very well functioning Megalopolis.

This is my second stay in Tokyo, I still choose Keio plaza hotel because I acknowledged that the hotel has renovated recently. We choose renovated triple room and it's excellent since the room size was really comfortable for three persons as all of us are shoppaholic, we bought so many stuffs but we wouldn't feel crowdy in the room as many friends told us that the hotel room size in tokyo was really small. Obviously, we chose the right one for our stay. As usual, this hotel have free shuttle bus to tokyo disney resort and it's one of my reason to choose this hotel. The breakfast was really good and I especially recommend the coffee in this hotel. Will come back definitely for my next trip in Tokyo!

I had booked two rooms at Kieo Plaza hotel for 7 nights. Hotel has nice location. Check in time is 2.00 PM and we came at 11.00 am, hotel couldn't provide rooms even at extra cost. They made us wait for 3 hours.Hotel is clean and service is good.we had a major wi fi issue in room number 2005. This room is in corner and wi fi signal was very week. Even after complaining few times hotel could not resolve the issue.Otherwise satisfactory stay, will stay again.
user_location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
user_name:
o_viren
National Capital Territory of Delhi, India

review_body: I wasn't sure how it was going to pan out considering I was traveling alone, but turns out this is a fantastic location, great buffet breakfast and other restaurants, practically in the heart of Shinjuku and walking distance to the JR. The location is quiet yet highly alive a few blocks away. The room I had was super clean, bathroom beautiful, comfortable bed, all the western amenities we are used to. The sheets were very white and soft mattress and pillows, TV with local channels and some from China, Korea and America (then again I wasn't here to watch tv so only did so briefly). This hotel has separate wings and I was in the south one. Many gift stores lobby area and the food court was on the second floor. Their convenience store inside the hotel is opened until 2:30 am so plan wisely if you want snacks in the middle of the night.I had an upgrade when I came in so I had the view of the street from the 20th floor. The staff is very helpful and always smiling. Pick this place, you won't regret it!
user_name:
soloraven
New York City, New York

review_body: Pretty much nothing to fault the hotel for, whether it be for its location, the service levels and the cleanliness of the rooms. We booked the club room package and were given complimentary access to the lounge which serves snacks and drinks till 1030pm. This was great given that we only arrived from Tateyama at 930pm and were too exhausted to go out for dinner. There's a subway station just at the side entrance of the hotel which took us only 15 minutes to get to Tsukiji. All in all, Keio is a great place for a relaxing stay in Tokyo amid all the hustle and bustle. It may not be the cheapest hotel out there but they do promise service levels for the price we paid.

2 nights in a standard room.Positives: Location is great. Conveniently located within a short walking distance to the train station and restaurants.Negative: Its pretty expensive for the standard of rooms their providing. This is a BIG hotel so there's aloooooot of guests. Be sure to check out early because we experienced bus loads of other guests trying to check out in the morning and the front desk could not cope with the volume.Overall: Rather disappointed because I have heard good things about the hotel. The rooms are comfortable but the toilets are rather tiny, expected more for the price we were paying. There's a pretty good buffet restaurant in the basement that served great food. Worth a visit if you want to dine within the hotel.

I booked 2 rooms for my family of 5. I requested additional bed for my 3 kids to stay in 1 room. It was a good surprise to find the hotel put a proper bed in the room instead of a sofa bed. Both rooms were nice, clean and spacious. The hotel has a very close proximity to the Shinjiku station which is very convenient to travel around.

The location fantastic. What you get for your price is not that great. Breakfast was nice but had to queue for over 30 minutes to get in. Service was in general not very good. Even had one person hang up on me when I called reception to ask a question.

The first night of my arrival I was in the south tower and my room was newer and nicely appointed but for some unknown reason, I was asked to move the second night to the main tower and found the room smaller, old and in need of refurbishing. The hotel is very large and for a traveler who is not dependent on a per diem the variety of restaurants within the hotel would be very convenient. On the amount our company gave us, the restaurants within the hotel were too expensive and we needed to eat outside of the hotel for every meal but breakfast. The breakfast which was included in the price of my room was very nice with a large variety of items to choose from. I was with a team and we found it frustrating that there were no gathering places within the very large lobby and other areas in the hotel. There was on couch and two chairs in a hotel with hundreds of rooms. We had no place to sit and talk.

Standard rooms are just ok, rather small and old - needs refurbishing, location is excellent, breakfast is very good, a little miscommunication between the reception and JTB staff when handing luggage that has to be sent to Kyoto from Tokyo by truck.

This hotel is situated west of Shinjuku station, the business side of the district. An easy 7 min stroll to the station and bus terminal through streets filled with cafes, restaurants and shops. The area is quieter and not the neon lit Shinjuku portrayed in travel brochures. But that means it's lovely and quiet in your hotel room. Our 27 th floor room in the renovated south tower was spacious and comfortable. No street noise at all. Very clean. Air con worked really well as did the free hotel WiFi. We had a triple room which incredibly had 3 double beds. The showers worked well. Toiletries were great. I enjoyed brewing the organic coffee in my room each morning.
