We didn't pay for the hotel buffet. Why would you when food is cheap and plentiful outside? Lawsons is a mini market 20 metres outside the hotel. You can buy sushi, hot and cold fresh food, drinks including wine and beer to have a feast in your room for breakfast or an evening snack. We had views of the city to the Tokyo Skytree. Staff at the tour desk, reception and guest relations were all very polite and helpful. We booked a tour through the hotel -Dynamic Tokyo which was fantastic.This hotel is close to the bus terminal for Mt Fuji. We booked a trip to Fuji Q, a theme park at the base of Mt Fuji. Incredible views and world's best roller coasters! For those who hanker for the bright neon lights of Shinjuku, just stroll towards the station and walk to the underpass near Uniqlo. On the other side, east of Shinjuku station, you will find the shops, neon signs, red light district etc. The airport limousine bus drops you in front of the hotel or the Narita Express takes you straight to Shinjuku station. Couldn't ask for more. Brilliant location, comfy hotel, great service. Will definitely stay at the Keio Plaza if i return to Tokyo.

Tokyo is so big that our goal in selecting a hotel was to find one that 1) was good for families 2) had a range of meal choices 3) easy access to public transportation and 4) places we wanted to visit near by. Keio Plaza Hotel met all of these needs and more. Despite being a large hotel, we never felt overwhelmed by people. The hotel offered multiple restaurant choices as well as some well stocked stores for various amenities. The staff was very helpful in identifying restaurants and places to visit. They are well connected with JTB which helps with accommodating various day trips. The rooms were very spacious and well appointed. We ate in several of the restaurants in the hotel, and were very pleased by the quality of the food. Shinjuku station is a terrific hub given all the rail and subway lines that run through. Finally, the price was quite reasonable given the quality, location etc. We would definitely stay there again.

I've been here for serval times because the good location and reasonable price. Actually, the front desk staff are efficiency and helpful. The rooms are clean, tidy and spacious.Everything is nice. But, this time I had a bit disappointing as when i approached the concierge to seek help for using the limousine ticket vendor machine, the staff just point at the instruction. And the other day I called for a cartoon box, they ask me to pick at the concierge by myself. I understand that maybe they have a heavy workload. I hope that they will improve in this area.

Rooms are nicely appointed and very clean. With 3 adults in a standard room it was crowded and hard to walk around the roll away, but had large bathroom and closet space.Location is excellent, the subway station is a couple blocks walk, there's shopping,and food close by.Difficult to communicate with front desk people and took 20-30 minutes to check in.

It is 2 small blocks from Shinjuku station and for that reason, it earns a nod. We stayed in Tokyo for five nights and felt that we needed to be close to a transportation hub to make it easier to get around. Tokyo was the first leg of our Japanese vacation, so we didn't need to cap it off with 5 star hotel. It was good, clean, pleasant; I would stay there again. I gave it 3 stars because we have come to expect good, courteous and pleasant from the Japanese people in general; am I getting jaded? But seriously, the Japanese did certainly pleasantly surprise us in their friendliness, helpfulness, and the cleanliness of the city.

Lovely hotel close to shinjuku station & really close to everything. Great bars & restaurants within walking distance. Also shopping centres & department stores nearby, check out the cakes at Odakyu they are amazing

The hotel is very accessible to everything in shinjuku...mrt, shopping, japanese food, bus stops. It is just across the metropolitan tower, one of the talllest buildings in shinjuku area. The staff are polite and courteous, fast check in and check out. There is free shuttle to disneyland or disneysea. The lobby is a spacious, though not that elegant The rooms and bathrooms are 4 stars quality, spacious and well maintained.

We choose this hotel because it offered four in a room and have a central location. Travelled here with two children almost 4 and 5 1/2 years old. Five nights. Had a room with good view. Room had enough space for us, it had two bathrooms. Service was fair enough. Good English.Used the breakfast buffet restaurants, these had good selection of food. Also used two of the dinner restaurant. But that was not value for money. Recommend eating at better and much cheaper alternatives in short distance from the hotel.

I was staying with my 2 teenager daughters.. The room was quite spacious, we had 3 beds. They had a shuttle bus to disneyland and disney sea which was very convenient for us. The service is good. I liked the location since it was near restaurant and shinjuku station.

All staff from porter to check-in and lounge staff spoke English and were very helpful and friendly. Got a Plaza Luxe room on the 30th floor which was very spacious and clean. Didn't quite like the shower facility though as there was no separate shower cubicle apart from the bathtub. Not too sure if the bed was really a Simmons as it felt very mediocre in my opinion.Unlike other hotel lounge accesses, this one did not come with any breakfast. Only tea and bar services are provided. However, the hotel does take an effort to change the snack variety on a daily basis.For those who would be using the subway, just take note that there is a station named Tochomae station which is very very near the hotel, and a direct stop away from the Shinjuku station. Location is not too bad as it is about a slow 10 minutes stroll to the heart of Shinjuku where plenty of eateries and shopping are available (near the Odakyu dept store, where it also happens to be the boarding point for buses going to Gotemba premium outlet).Do take note that if you want to take the airport limo bus departing from the hotel, you have to make a reservation beforehand with the hotel staff to secure a seat. This is in addition to making a payment at the automatic vending machine at the hotel, where you will be issued a bus ticket.Wifi speed was acceptable.Would definitely consider going back to this hotel but will not pay extra for the Plaza Luxe with lounge access.

Very sad how this hotel take care the guest so advise stay away. I took this hotel because want swimmingpool rest before mount fujii. First they want 25 usd extra for small pool after they refuse u because have very small tatoo on my arm. They dont like u to much, Lobby five stars the room 1 star cheap and dull, small . could have better for less half price. Advise not go her i lost my money on this worst hotel been

We stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel in Shinjuku area. The hotel is about 3 blocks from the train station. We stayed in room 3126. It was a family suite that had 4 beds and 2 bathrooms. We were a family of 2 parents/ 2 teenagers. The breakfast buffet is wonderful serving both japanese and western style. I really loved this hotel and it was perfect for our family of 4 adults. Lots of restaurants and stores close by and you can walk to the underground subway and train stations. The beds were very hard but it seems like all the beds in Japan seem to be very hard.

Had a room on the executive level 39. Large room but a very firm bed (I like firm beds). Everything is electronic, from the electronic blinds, to the electronic toilet to the heated bathroom mirror that doesn't fog up. Great location within easy walking distance of Shinjuku and its shops and train station. The breakfast included as part of the executive package was great - in a separate executive lounge on the ground floor. Impeccable service. Would stay again.

Arrived late at night with young child , no porters to carry luggage , then taken to a old depressing room that smelt like an ash tray , room looked nothing like brochure so we asked if there were any others available to be told there was but we would be charged another $280 , we took the room as the other was totally hideous , next day spoke to the front desk manager to complain totally arrogant , bad attitude asked to speak to general manager and was told no I asked again with another arrogant no , Shame the rest of the hotel and staff seem very nice will never return plenty of better hotels in Tokyo !!!!!!

I was bit apprehensive before but when i reached the hotel my comfort level was at optimum level.Right from smooth check in to upgrade to new refurbished room everything was great.Kieo plaza is huge hotel ,well connected shopping areas n transport at walking distance.Staff is polite n communication in English was not a issue.Our included buffet breakfast in any of the 3 resteraunts was amazing spread ,so we had the opportunity to have Japanese breakfast.Rooms r spacious with all mentioned amenities.Bathrooms also roomy.best was anti fog coating on bathroom mirror.View from my 20th floor room was great opposite Government Metropolitan building.Direct airport limo bus service from hotel.Checkout also very smooth.If ever going again to Tokyo i 'll definite stay here again.

Fantastic hotel, got greeted with an upgrade when we arrived, staff were happy to give directions and help with what trains we needed to catch for our trip. Room was quite big especially for Japan, very clean, very efficient, very friendly. So close to Shinjuku station so great location, very close to restaurants as well. The wifi was great and fast in the room, my only negative would be the beds and pillows slightly hard but thats just my preference. Would highly recomend staying here and would definately stay here again.

Hotel at centre city,very nice,room very clean and staff so friendly,breakfast so yummy,service so fast and very good,wifi good signal,local people very good,near go to market,i will recommend to friends
Great hotel, great experience.Rooms are amazing and large. Bathrooms are good sized.Breakfast is awesome. Staff is good.Location is perfect.You can't go wrong here.Be sure you'll have a good time.
user_name:
Leo D
Rio de Janeiro, RJ

review_body: A stunning room overlooking Tokyo, what more could you want!! Great service, great breakfast, pleasant friendly people, we used the safety deposit box by reception as there wasn't one in the room but that want an issue. A fantastic location, really pleased with our stay!!!

I stayed here in June where the weather is warm and overcast with rain. We were a party of four people and booked a room with 4 beds and 2 bathrooms. The Limousine Bus offers rides to and from both Narita and Haneda airports (there is a nominal fee) to the Hotel. Check in went very smoothly. The hotel front desk clerk was very friendly, efficient, and able to converse in English. The Keio Plaza Hotel is a Tokyo Disney Partner Hotel which offers a free shuttle to and from Tokyo Disneyland with advanced reservations. The room was clean and had everything we needed to be very comfortable. The beds were very firm and the size of a small full size bed enough to fit only one person. It was very convenient to have two full bathrooms. Also included in the room was a refrigerator, hot pot to heat water for coffee/tea, robes, house slippers, a safe, and bathroom supplies which included shower caps, toothbrushes, hair brush, soap, razor, and hair dryer. There is no coined laundry in the hotel. The location of the hotel is wonderful! It is a 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku Station. The concierge is also an excellent and friendly resource to provide information about the Japan Rail system and cost. They also have a map of Shinjuku. There are also many places to shop and eat all within walking distance. The hotel is also a primary pick up site for day tours or half-day tours if you would like to see more of Japan. The bell hop provided excellent service as well. Our flight did not leave until midnight but they held our baggage for us after we checked out and got our luggage onto the limousine bus when it arrived. The location of the hotel is convenient but the excellent service, friendliness of the staff, and cleanliness of the hotel is what will bring me back again.

Stayed here for 1 week during sakura season. Place is in a nice location, 10 min walk to shinjuku main train station.Food is good, try eating the japanese breakfast to experience the local cuisine.Wifi is very slow, sometimes connection is intermittent.Room is very spacious.

I stay at Keio Plaza Shinjuku almost every time when I am in Tokyo. The location is really convenient if you need to travel around Tokyo. JR and underground station is nearby with 5 mins walk. Staff speaks good English and very polite. This time I feel a bit disappointed. The room is spacious comparing to some other hotels.But the room really needs renovation. Wall paper are tearing off and there is stains at the toilet bowl. The Wifi is really slow and cannot access to the network often.

My family loved this hotel with many nice restaurants, when I was a kid. Then, I used this hotel many times for business, when I grew up and moved from Tokyo. This is a huge hotel with many nice rooms and restaurants in a very convenient location. This hotel has a convenience store, a bar with nice view, and even Karaoke ! A superior standard hotel for business and for family in Tokyo for more than 30 years. Can recommend to everyone !

Its proximity to Shinjuku and train stations is one of its best qualities not to mention the spacious rooms with 2 queen beds and a sofa bed for the nanny. The staff is also very friendly and helpful. The free ride to Disneyland and Disneysea is an added bonus. So many quality restaurants in the hotel. Our family was very satisfied with this hotel.

We stayed here twice during a recent trip to Japan onThe recommendation of a friend. The hotel is huge, occupying two towers in Shinjuku, but it didn't feel overwhelming of anything. The staff were very welcoming and efficient. Our rooms on both stays were excellent with great views (we had a city view one stay and the opposite side the other - city view is best). The rooms are spacious - particularly by Japanese standards. The hotel has various restaurants and bars, with some on the 46th floor with views to match. There is s shopping centre in the basement. Location-wise, the hotel is perfect. A 5 min walk to Shinjuku station (one of the stops on the Narita Express from the airport), and there is a covered walkway from one of the hotel's exits straight into the station (ask if you cannot find it!). Tochamae subway station is close by. Good restaurants and bars nearby, and the hotel is on the tour bus pickup circuit. Would definitely stay here again.

The hotel is very nice, especially the front desk. The guest services desk was good, but not outstanding. My Plaza Luxe Room was very nice and extremely clean. My biggest complaint was the gym as the dumbbells were too limited. Great cardio, but that was about it. Can't beat the hotel location.

This was our first trip to Tokyo ever! A colleague recommended Keio Plaza, as we had no clue where to stay in Tokyo. She had stayed at the hotel when she ran Tokyo Marathon in 2014. Before even getting there we liked the fact it is situated within walking distance to Shinjuku Station, where the train from Natrita Airport arrives/departs. We got an early bird price in the Plaza Queen Building which was very good deal in European measures at approx 150€ per night for a luxury hotel. Extremely good value in other words!We loved everything about our room om the 25th floor! Newly renovated, fantastic view over Shinjuku, fancy toilet with lots of buttons :-) , complimentary water/coffee/newspaper. Also, the bars with sky view were excellent as well as the nice pool area. Top class experience all over! We would also recommend Shinjuku as a good starting point for your Tokyo visit. Lots of good shopping, restaurants, bars etc. The Yamanote line as well as the tube runs everywhere. Harajuku/Shibuya is within walking distance as well.

Location is superb, just a few minutes walk from Shinjuku station and Shinjuku post office. Restaurants and pubs are just roughly 5 minutes walk from the hotel. Service was fast and efficient. Wi-Fi is very fast as well!For the room type, we got Deluxe the Main room which was very very spacious for 3 people. Each bed could even fit 2 people. Overall, it was a comfortable and convenient stay.

A really very good comfortable clean hotel.We upgraded to give us access to the club lounge (34th floor) which also gave us breakfast in the very quiet and peaceful cocktail lounge each morning (truly far from the madding crowd!!).All staff we talked to or had any dealings with were at all times very pleasant, courteous and helpful.Only a 10 minute walk to the very busy but well connected Shinjuku station, we found this an ideal spot from which to start our wanderings around this great city. I'm sure others may find locations more suited to them but I would always recommend this hotel - it is truly an oasis. It's big and has a number of restaurants, bars and shops of its own - and generally busy with tour groups.It is also one of the hotels on the direct airport bus route (certainly from Haneda).

The location of the hotel is excellent, very near to shinjuku station, malls, restaurants. hotel is also cloe to Shinjuku Gyoen national park where you can view cherry blossom.Breakfast buffet is very good. Love the pastries! Good size room for Japan i guess.

Operated by well known Japanese conglomerate, not the fancy chic type but practical, located very close to shopping areas. Foodie within walking distance and opened till late. Our travel package include brekkie and you can choose from a few restaurants. We stayed at main building, room size is decent but seems to be the older wing as compared to south tower. There is airport bus stop right in front of the hotel and there is also direct shuttle to Tokyo Disney. Convenient store and bakery are available at the basement of the hotel. Staff are helpful and polite. We are pleased with their services and will come back.

Enjoyed our stay at this hotel. Room size is good for even triple sharing. Everyone working at the hotel were very polite and courteous. Free Wifi in rooms. Location was close to Shinjuku station. Would stay here again.

This is a massive hotel! We spent 2 nights here and it was enjoyable for a short stay in Tokyo. We had a room on a high floor with a stunning view of a snow covered Mt Fuji in the distance. The rooms are large and comfortable. It is minutes walk to Shinjuku Station, so getting anywhere in Tokyo was a breeze. Shopping nearby. Some good eating in the area, but check with concierge for recommendations and bookings. The staff were a delight to deal with and extremely courteous. Despite the large numbers of people checking in and out it ran very smoothly. Our room had club access which is at the top of the hotel and provides some lovely views.. The club is ok, but nothing special. There are a number of restaurants in the hotel, but they are fairly expensive. The breakfast buffet is a good choice as there is not a lot of local breakfast outlets available, especially during holiday seasons. Good, fast and free WiFi in your room. Overall a very comfortable and pleasant hotel to stay in.

Stayed in Plaza Premier room for 5 days. Excellent service and very quiet. Love the City view, French bath amenities and the cute ironing machine. Early check in and late check out were granted. Short walkable distance from the shopping malls and train station.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza for five nights. We were very pleased with our choice of this hotel. It is less than 10 minutes walking to the Shinjuku Station which was one of the main reasons we chose this hotel. As seems to be the case in Tokyo, there are plenty of restaurants nearby. There is also a shopping mall near the train station and many other large stores nearby. Right next to the hotel is the government building where tourists can go (for free!) to the 45th floor to get a 360 view of Tokyo (and Mt. Fuji). There's also a pretty nice park next to the government buildings (and a 15 minute walk to a large Japanese garden on the other side of the train station). The hotel itself is a nice hotel with nice sized rooms. We opted for the two single beds and had a pretty large room with two chairs and a table as well (a Renewed Superior room). The bathroom was of average size with good counter space. There was a fog-less mirror and one of those toilets with the flush/bidet options that are common in Japan. There are many restaurants and bars in this hotel, as well as a bakery and convenience store. We opted for the buffet breakfast with our room and it was a modest buffet (but with good quality food). One of the people we were traveling with was disappointed that our only option was a Western buffet and that the Japanese breakfast was an additional charge. Everyone who worked at the hotel was very polite and room service was very fast to bring ice to the room when we needed it. Also, we had no difficulty with English at the hotel and they were very accommodating of my husband's dairy allergy (having soy milk ready for him every morning at the buffet). There was also free wifi included with the room. Maybe one negative (although I didn't find it to be a problem) was that it is a popular hotel (i.e., there are always a lot of people in the lobby and elevators).

Shinjuku is the best place to stay for first timers in Tokyo. Lots of restaurants walking distance behind the Keio Plaza hotel where we stayed. Some restaurants were open 24 hours! There are a couple of convenience stores and pharmacies around the area for immediate needs. Big department stores are few blocks away. We were five in this trip so we got two rooms. Our room for two was comfortable with strong wifi signal. I do not recommend triple sharing because i found our other triple sharing room quite pricey, considering the third bed was just a sofa bed, and the size of the room was exactly the same as the double sharing room so there's not much space to move for triple occupancy. But our overall experience was great! I don't mind going back and stay in this hotel again next time.

Very convenient : direct limousine bus service from Narita AirportSmooth Check in procedure although could not meet our request of the newly renovated room. Very impressed with the decent size of the room, in fact, a lot bigger than the 'others' in 'Tokyo standard'. The room was fully equipped, to my expectation. It is even better equipped than some 5-star hotels in Las Vegas !!!Will stay here again, hope they will put us in the renovated rooms next time !

We have stayed here three times now and keep returning because it it is a great place to stay. Modern rooms, free wifi, plenty of restaurants and in a very convenient location close to major transport. Friendly staff. The convenience store on Level 2 provides an economical source of snacks and drinks.

The best hotel I visited in Tokyo, excellent rooms and a great choice of restaurant in it. We stayed here 3 days and we try different service, and obviously 3 kind of restaurant at the base of the hotel.

The service staffs tried all their best by providing extra miles of their services. Bus service available to Disneyland, and airport limousine is just at the doorstep. Imagine u don't even need to carry your luggage at all, best hotel in Tokyo I ever stayed so far.I stayed two different types of room due to the non availability of the type I wanted to book.First night at the south tower of the hotel which I don't remember the name of the type of room.Advisable to pay a little bit more by choosing the Premier Room at the main tower. With better view and better selection of the amenities.Overall, the best hotel in Shinjuku

Location is great, walking distance to shinjuku main shopping area, even though quite a walk to Takashimaya. Reception and bell captain are great, well english spoken, helpful, efficient. they helped us to get a dinner reservation which we tried the night before but the restaurant staff who doesnt speak good english said it was full. Tips : if you need any restaurant reservation, please ask someone who can speak Japanese, or else its difficult to get one.Hotel is big, crowded, a bit confusing as they have main tower and south tower. And hotel lobby is meeting point for some tours, making it even more crowded in the morning.Room is quite big, but outdated, carpet look old. That is a corner room which we got upgraded to. Got airport shuttle which is a big convenience, and we tell the bell captain we will took the shuttle at which hour (booking far in advance is needed, or else seat are fully booked), and our luggage are ready and tag outside when we arrive back to hotel. Have convenience store downstair but price are too steep. better go to Lawson station or 7 eleven nearby. Got free wifi.

Our day tour of Tokyo finished at Tokyo Railway Station @ 5pm right on rush hour. With directions from the tour guide how to navigate the rail, we managed to work the ticket machine in English, find the correct platform, exit at Shinjuku station which has. 3.1 million commuters a day & follow the directions clearly on the walls & arrive at our hotel in under 30 minutes.

I had stayed in this hotel for two times which is the first high-rise hotel in Japan. Even though there is a 3 year gap between my accommodations, the quality stayed the same if not better. First of all, the location is very central and its walking distance to the Shinjuku station. If you dont want to bother with the metro on your way from the airport (which can be very crowded at certain times) you can always hop on to the "friendly bus limousine" service at the airport and it will take you directly to the hotel. The rooms are always clean and the staff is very friendly. Communication was not a problem with me because I found that there are staff members who speaks good english. When it comes to pricing I think the amount is fair considering the quality of the hotel. It is said to be 4 star hotel but during my stays I felt like its more like 4 and a half star. During my research I was looking at the 3 star hotels around the area and the rooms they had were too smal for a family visit. I dont think it would be confortable if you are 2 or more people. And the pricing of the 5 stars were really high for my taste. So this hotel with its quality/price and wider selection of rooms stood out for me.If its your first time in japan I would definitely recommend this hotel. The only thing you should chek before booking is the breakfast. There are different restaurants in the hotel and the prices differ. If you decide to buy the breakfast during your stay I dont think you ll be dissappointed because it was very rich, but if you decide not to buy it you can always walk across the street and get something for the road from the shops.So overall I was very happy with my visit and definitely would like to stay here again

Situated in an ideal location close to Shinjuku station it would be difficult to find a hotel that is better than this one on all accounts. It is so well organised, everything runs like clockwork , the staff are great, food is excellent and the facilities are really good

Nice hotel, but no bargains there...Old hotel, but well maintained.Rooms are large, but old, (at least at the south tower, where I have stayed).Many good restaurants at the hotel, not cheap, but very good.If you lose your plastic key-card, they will charge you 500 yen, which is a rip-off, considering that is is less then $1 to produce those.Good location, 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku JR station.

Excellent hotel and easily assessable via Shinjuku station there is also an airport shuttle from the hotel to Haneda and Narita aiport and vice versa. We stayed at room 3061 and 3062 which provides great view of Tokyo city centre . I will definitely recommend this hotel to anyone. Food and shopping is barely 5 mins walk from this gorgeous hotel.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo for one week in mid May. I travelled with my husband and 2 year old. We chose the hotel because of the relatively attractive price, its location and the good reviews we had read on Tripadvisor. We were not disappointed.We had a room in the new wing and the room was of a generous size by hotel standards worldwide (not to mention Tokyo). There was space for an arm chair, a little chaise lounge and a dressing table. The bed was comfortable, the sheets clean and the towels white and fluffy. The bathroom amenities comprising of L'Occitane products and a Shiseido Face wash was also a real treat. There is both a hot water kettle and a Nespresso machine in the room which was perfect for us.From the airport, we would recommend taking the Airport Limousine Bus. The ride is comfortable and the fare is fixed. With peak hour traffic, the taxis can prove to be pretty expensive from the airport, especially Narita. The Airport Limousine Bus drops you right at the doorstep of the Keio Plaza Hotel. Do the same for your return trip to the airport.It was also very convenient moving around from the Keio Plaza Hotel. On the ground floor (below the main lobby entrance), when you exit from the new wing, to the right of the hotel is the path to the Shinkjuku train station (approximately the length of 4 full-length travellators) and to the left, barely 100 m away is the Tochomae station. Once you get to the Shinjuku station area, you will also be in area where the department stores are such as Odakyu and Lumine. There are also lots of eateries in the area and some of which have good reviews written up by bloggers.What we thought was a real value add was the fact that the hotel provided free transport to and from Disneyland. There are 3 pick up times to Disneyland and another 3 return times. This is really convenient and you should book early because it does fill up. Many other tours also do pick ups from the Keio Plaza Hotel which is very convenient.The room rates we paid for the hotel did not include breakfast. But in Tokyo, this really doesn't matter given that there are so many eateries in the area. This gave us the opportunity to try different restaurants, all walking distance from the hotel. There was an awesome dipping ramen place which we tried as well as an Udon joint where udon noodles were served with a whole buffet of tempura items. If you don't want to venture too far for breakfast, there is a bakery in the hotel itself as well as a supermarket/convenience store which stays open till really late. If buying bottled water, buy it from here rather than the Family Marts nearby as the price difference is quite negligible.We had a very good stay in Tokyo and staying at the Keio Plaza Hotel certainly added significantly to the enjoyment of the holiday.

Bit of a trek from the train station and actually in direct vacinity not much around. Rooms are clean and spacious for Tokyo but are dated. In saying that everything is in order and the place has plenty of facilities. Shame the pool isn't open year round. Wish I'd known before. Viewing Tower next door that you can head up for free which was nice. Has everything.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza for 8 days and found it to have comfortable spacious rooms. It was extremely quiet. The traffic noise was barely noticeable, and I don't think I ever heard anyone in the hall or in adjacent rooms. The information card said the rooms had been specially sound proofed, and I'd say that was true. We were on the 35th floor of the north tower and overlooked the government building. The city view was very nice. The staff was very helpful when we checked in late at night. We had reserved seats on the courtesy bus to Disney Sea, and they had all the paperwork ready for us. I had also signed up for their club and they had my membership card waiting for me. The lobby can be a zoo during the mornings, since there are many tour groups who stay there. It's all handled I'm a very orderly fashion. The people and bags are kept to one zone, so it's easy to avoid them. I'm not a breakfast eater, so we didn't visit the Japanese or Western buffets. I was happy that there was a Starbucks just across the street where I could pick up coffee and a scone. Just go down to level 2 (below the lobby level) and go out the doors by Poppins, which is h hotel's bakery shop, and cross the street. Starbucks is on the lower level of the plaza. Poppins also has good scones, rolls and pastries, but no coffee. There is a coffee maker and tea supplies in the hotel room, but it was nice to have a larger size cup. The hotel location is a quick (5 to 10 mins), covered walk to Shinjuku station. Go out the same doors as mentioned above and go to the right once you get to the sidewalk. You'll see the tunnel. There's also a subway station if you turn left from the hotel. It's not even half a block to the entrance. Between that subway station and the subways/trains at Shinjuku, you can get pretty much anywhere. There are a lot of places to eat just steps away from the hotel. You can find pretty much any quisine you want, at varying price points. Unlike the area of Shinjuku on the other side of the JR station, the local neighborhood is relatively quiet at night. You can wander around the small streets full of eateries without feeling like you're in a seedy area. That's not so true on the other side of the station. It's a lot more lively and you'll find people trading wares/services you may not want to buy. I would definitely stay at the Keio again, should I get back to Tokyo.

My friend and I booked this hotel last minute for an impromptu Tokyo trip. We read good reviews but never expected it to be as nice as it was. The property is beautiful. There are many banquet halls that hosts weddings there. Upon our arrival, the bell hops stowed our luggage while we checked in and proceeded to take them up to our rooms for us after we completed checkin. Check-in was super quick. The lady who helped us was an English speaker which was great! Our room was very spacious. The view of the city was nice. It had all the amenities needed. There was even complimentary toothbrush kits, brushes, hair ties, and other toiletries, which was a pleasant surprise. The front desk helped us book an afternoon tour of the city for the next day which was very helpful and it was super convenient. There are a lot of restaurants on property. We went to Jurin, it was pretty good and reasonably priced. You get a discount at all the restaurants if you are staying as a guest. Be sure to show your room key when it's time to pay the bill. The staff was friendly and helpful. The hotel was very nice. I am not quite sure what the actual hotel class is, but, my opinion it was comparable to a four or five star hotel in the United States and I highly recommend it.

Great location, its near the Shinjuku station and there is an underground pass to the station as well (in case its raining/too cold to walk outside). The room is spacious and well maintained. The staff are very well mannered and helpful. There is a free shuttle bus to the Tokyo Disneyland/Disneysea but you have to book them in advanced (still a great service and reduce the hassle of having to arrange your own transport). The airport limousine also stops at this hotel. I found this a better way to travel to the airport as we had a lot of luggage.

Large hotel quite well located, with large atrium. When we were there, it was nicely decorated with colourful displays of dolls. All the staff were courteous and friendly, but the hotel felt dated and a bit impersonal. Our bedroom, a standard room, had two 4ft beds. Small rooms and beds seemed a feature on our trip to Japan and you need to be clear in what you want. Perhaps they do not expect couples to sleep together! We found this in other hotels. Shower was old fashioned, with a hose that stopped the water supply when it was bent. Several restaurants in the complex, for different nationalities. Both American and Japanese breakfast was available. For a westerner, you would need coffee and cake an hour or so after the very interesting Japanese breakfast.Wifi was available but not always reliable.

Huge hotel and very busy with coach parties. Despite this staff were efficient, friendly and very helpful. The room was comfortable and of a good size. Minor criticism that only coffee supplied in the room. I would have liked tea. The hotel is practically next door to Shinjuki railway station and has plenty of eating places close by. The hotel itself has over 10 restaurants and bars and my favourite was the Korean restaurant. These restaurant, and the various shops within the hotel, were on the expensive side, as one would expect in this standard of hotel. My only other criticism was that the swimming pool was not available as it does not open until June. I visited in May and the weather was hot so I would have liked a swim. Overall I enjoyed my stay and would definitely return.

Don't forget to dine at Glass Court while you are staying at Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo.The dinner buffet is a good deal among hotels in Shinjuku. It is very reasonable and lots of selections which make a good choice restaurant for a large group. Everyone can find something to eat. We were eight of us. Everybody was happy at the end. Foie gras was the best. Because their wine list was a little dull I brought a bottle of California wine I like and paid 3000 Yen corkage.Don't forget to make a reservation. They are usually fully booked.

If you have to be in the Shinjuku business district then this has to be one of your options. Enormous towers of hi-tech but somewhat impersonal so not for everyone. Rooms well equipped and views of Tokyo from the higher floor levels are stunning.

Keio Plaza is very well located within 5-10 minute walk to Shinjuku station. Shinjuku is a must go neighborhood for tourism and its station is well connected with other important sightseeing places. There are nice places to have lunch/dinner within walking distance from the hotel. The wifi was included in the daily rate and worked very well. Rooms are quite large for all standards and bed/bathroom are very comfortable. On the cons: hotel is big, with no personal touch (eg: check-out extension for 1-2h was denied) and any additionals were very expensive (eg: breakfast, dinner).

Keio Plaza's location is excellent. It's very accessible to the Shinjuku station (a few minutes walk) and right next to the Tokyo Metropolitan Gov't Office.The hotel staff of Keio Plaza is excellent. They speak good English, and provide excellent service.Our experience at Keio Plaza was one of th best. I would definitely go back to Keio Plaza

The location is great, very close to the Shinjuku station, which is one of the largest stations in the world. Approximately 5 minute walk. It's very close to Lawson's/711 and a bunch of ramen restaraunts. The rooms are reasonably sized but ask for a non smoking room. The wifi connection isn't so great, many times it disconnected or would continuously prompt to login. The staff is very nice and accommodating. The Japanese culture is very nice!

The hotel covers an entire block: two 40 storey towers, tens of restaurants on two floors, lobby as large as a cathedral etc...If you like cosy places, pass your way !The Standardroom I had (room 1959 South-Wing) was very spacious and calm, but the decoration ages out and would benefit from a serious refresh: wall-paper discolored, stained and flaking off. No power socket on the desk to plug my laptop, etc..I had an brilliant afternoon-tea at noon (on Saturday May 16th) in the Art Lounge Duet

We chose Keio Plaza Hotel for this trip as we knew that it was the meeting point for our Tour which we got from Japanican.com. It was very convenient. The airport Limousine bus stops at this hotel too. You can buy your Airport Limo bus ticket at the airport. Then from the hotel, going to the airport, you can also reserve (with the help of the Concierge) and buy the airport limo bus ticket from the vendo machine. There were 2 Lawson convenience stores nearby, Doutor Coffee shop, Subway, C & C curry and some other restaurants nearby. There was also a cosmetic, pharmacy shop nearby. The subway station is also near. But just to warn you, this is a busy hotel with lots of tour groups every day that we were there. We were there during the Golden Week April 29- May 6, 2015. We requested for a non-smoking room but when we went to our room, it smelled of cigarette. We requested for a change of room and the bell boy quickly helped us by calling the reception for us. They gave us a non-smoking room. Love the Toiletries, Nespresso Machine. The South Tower room of our kids were a disappointment though. So better make sure you get the renovated rooms. But overall experience was good. Will go back to this hotel.
user_name:
Mary Jane G
Metro Manila, Philippines

review_body: I've been to Japan for business and for pleasure more than 80 times, and let me tell you, the Keio Plaza Hotel is your worst nightmare. Checked into my room which reeked of cigarettes. Nothing else available. I can hear the elevators rushing around all the time (I'm still trapped here 'cause they have my CC number and I don't have time to fight them. Can't WAIT to leave.) Japanese service is exemplary, but there is a bubble of indifference around this place. Phone calls completely ineffective. Hordes of big tour groups in the lobby. Breakfast mediocre at best. DO NOT STAY HERE.

The hotel is at a convenient location from the Shinkuju railway station - 5-8 minute walk in a straight line from the eastern side of the hotel. There is also a covered walkway with a few pedestrian travelators from the railway station to the northern side of the hotel. As mentioned by others the Friendly Limousine Bus (yes, that's what it is called) from the airport stops right at the hotel front door (western side). The is also a counter in the hotel which you can book a return trip back to the airport, if required. We spent 7 nights there and could not find any fault with it. The staff were friendly when help was asked for. Our room was in the south tower (as compared to the main tower). I guess the main tower could have been a bit more busy that the room in the south tower. The hotel lobby was big enough so that one did not feel cramped with all the tour groups there. Our room was of a good size, comparable to western standards. Our travel agent recommended getting a room with twin beds as they generally are of a bigger area that one with a double/queen size bed. (Maybe someone would like to comment about it.) As this was our first time in Japan and our first hotel experience in the country we were extremely pleased with the level of accommodation.

Quick service, accommodating staff. We were upgraded to a large room in the south tower and couldn't have been happier. Very clean, patchy wifi in our room. Lifts were speedy, location fabulous. Peaceful although close to Shinjuku station, with many restaurants and bars on the way to the station. Recommend it highly.

Stayed 4 nights in the Plaza BIZ Plus room and am duly impressed with the cleanliness and efficiency of this hotel. The limousine bus from the airport stops at the hotel lobby making the transit from airport seamless. Check-in was quick and most staff had a reasonable command of English. Staff were friendly, always quick to greet you and helpful. The room was clean and comfortable with an excellent bed and choice of hard and soft pillows. I am a very picky sleeper and I had no problems falling asleep at this hotel. The hotel is a short 8mins walk from Shinjuku Station and less than 5mins walk from Tochomae Station. A little quiet off from the main bustle of Shinjuku, there are still many drug stores, restaurants and convenience stores within 5mins walking. Overall an excellent hotel.

We stayed here for 4 nights, the staff are very friendly and really helpful. We ate in the hotels restaurants, Chinese Nan-En, Jurin for breakfast and Glass Court (they have seniors discount if you are over 65) while they may seem expensive compared to Sydney restaurant price I thought they were reasonable and the quality and service was great. The convenient shop had a good range and the prices were actually cheaper than say 7/11 shop. The hotel is a cross the road from the Goverment Office, Observatory, great view and it's free. We did the Mount Fuji-Hakone 1 day tour coach there and back that actually leaves from the Keio Plaza and doesn't do the round of the other hotels which is a bonus plus it's a bit cheaper so would recommend it.

This was our first time in Japan and were a little overwhelmed by the cultural and language differences. However, we were impressed by this hotel and found the staff so friendly and helpful we didn't want to leave. The room was excellent as were the restaurants and the location, so close to Shinjuki station and shopping centre, outstanding. We would certainly come here again! A wonderful experience.

Hotel is perfectly located in walking distance to Shinjuku station. Staff is very friendly, rooms are convenient. Great view over Tokyo having a drink in the lounge on 25th floor. Sometimes the hotel seems to be very crowded due to big tourist groups...

Stayed 4 nights in June 2014, got a good rate by booking in advance. the room was large compared to 2 other hotels of similar quality we stayed at. Decor a bit out of date but we understood some rooms had not been renovated yet, but it was still high quality comfortable and clean. It was good to have free WiFi and the staff helped with power plug adapters. (don't take the US type with the earth pin, all the sockets we encountered are 2 pin only) Bed was comfortable. Best thing is it is so close to a huge array of local restaurants, train station, shops shops and more shops. Loved it.

We stayed in the Plaza Premier room for 10 nights in April 2015. It's a very luxurious room and we were lucky enough to get the 39th floor. The hotel was by far the most expensive place we stayed at, but we got a fantastic room with great views. Breakfast was included on the bottom floor and was lovely every time. We dined at most of the restaurants at the hotel and were always very happy. The creme brule at the Italian restaurant was the best we'd had. If you show them your room key they take an extra 10% off the total bill.The hotel's location is great and placed near the government building which is a good landmark when trying to find your way back to the hotel. It is right next to a subway tunnel which makes for easy access to Shinjuku Station.The hotel was nice enough to hold on to our bags for 4 nights after we checked out and went to Hakone, then forwarded them to our location in Kyoto for a small fee.My experience may have differed if we had opted for a cheaper room, so if you have the extra money to spend I would highly recommend the Plaza Premier rooms.

There's no getting away from it, this is a big hotel! The Keio Plaza is part of a wider company that also has interests in transport (train and bus), so not surprising you can get a bus direct from Haneda Airport to the door. Tickets are available at an airport counter, you get a ticket for your luggage as you board which you exchange at your destination - all very efficient. Oh, and about two thirds of the bus journey is underground.We arrived at 8 am and couldn't check in until 2 pm but it was very full because we hit the cherry blossom season - we actually took our room at 1:30 pm. We were able to use the time to briefly wander around the small shopping arcade and check out the restaurants in the basement. We went out into Shinjuku and found a choice of very reasonable noodle bars and curry shops. In many you pay at a machine which has a menu, take the ticket and a seat and hand it over, that simple. We used the Polestar Bar three times. Check out the whole drinks list, we found the beer expensive but the Champagne reasonable by comparison to bar prices at home (the UK), and it leant an air of celebration to the spectacular view over Tokyo. One thing to be mindful of, in Japan it is still permitted to smoke in bars and restaurants so remember to ask for non-smoking...or smoking!Our Plaza Premier King was all that we expected, plenty of room, very quiet and well serviced. The room was fresh and contemporary which was at odds with a bathroom from a different era - a chic room with a granny bathroom (no offence granny). However, very functional, loo with more features that you thought you'd ever need, so not a problem unless you spend the majority of your stay in the bathroom.There's a really good convenience store where you can pick up a few breakfast things to get you up and out of a morning without breaking the bank with the hotel breakfast.Lots to do nearby, Shinjuku Station, Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden is a must do. and have lunch at the Yurinoki Restaurant, the food is great and the (older) ladies who work there are a treat.

We chose to pay a little extra for a large room as we needed a cot for our 3 month old daughter. The room we got was really reasonable size, even with the cot. The hotel itself is very pleasant and the staff are all super polite and efficient. I'm sure that the facilities available (gym, restaurants, etc) are all superb although we didn't test any of it out - first travels with a new baby didn't mean much time for fine dining or workouts! The hotel is very convenient for transport access but is far enough away from the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku station to allow for decent rest. Would certainly recommend the hotel for any visitors to Tokyo.

Well located, with great city views from its rooms, Keio Plaza is a must stay for travelers willing to spend some extra bucks. Staff has excellent English skills, and most of them are friendly and willing to help you anytime. WiFi is a bit slow and crashes a bit often. Also the bathroom is not as modern as you might expect. Other than that this hotel is fantastic!

Perfectly located. 5 min walk to Government building and free observation decks, IT hub, Shinjuku Railway Station, Bus Terminal, restaurants. Friendly helpful staff. Free wifi. Room with great view. Quiet. Very large room.

Took the Narita Express to Shinjuku Station. Look out for the West Exit 西出口 and exit via there. Keep left after exit and there's a tunnel with a travelator. Walk till the end of the tunnel and the hotel is there. Took around 10mins to reach. Staff was quick in doing check-in and even notify us of next day complimentary shuttle to Disney (to prebook before arrival). Even pass us our wifi router upon check in. Room is clean and spacious. Easy access to Shinjuku Station and nearby shopping district.

This hotel is the place to stay at if you wanna visit Shinjuku, Japan. It very convenient to the Train and Bus Station. The whole staff speaks english which is a very big plus. The are very helpful if you are not familiar with the place they will tell you how to get there. It is a bit pricey but its all worth it.My family and i are very happy that we stayed in this hotel.

Pleasantly surprised when we entered the room on 31st floor of main building, as there was a great view of the city. Spacious room size exceeded our expectations. We had thought it would be much smaller given the reputation of Tokyo hotel rooms. Room very clean and well maintained. Next to sheltered walkway that is linked to Shinjuku station. About 15 mins walk, but I was with my elderly parents who were strolling while the office workers hurried past them. So it should be less than 15 mins with average walking speed.Great location, lots of food choices nearby and shopping too. Some restaurants stay open till 2am so you won't have to worry about going hungry. Airport limousine bus stops at Keio Plaza Hotel. Free shuttle bus from hotel to Disneyland but seats limited. Great place to stay. Expensive, but we saved money by taking the family package where 2nd room was at 50% off.

This is a big and very busy hotel due to its excellent location with walking distance to the Shinjuku station which is very convenient. There are major electronic and camera stores nearby. Hotel rooms are big however it does show its age in the furniture but the room is clean and big. Staff is very helpful and no problem communicating in English. Hotel seems to be used by lots of tour groups. We enjoyed our stay in this hotel and will definitely return next time we come to Tokyo.

It is a big hotel but has a lot of tour groups coming through. A very good location in Tokyo . However if you are not going with a tour, you may have difficulties finding good food or help because not too many locals speak English . Be prepare to bring changes for fast Japanese express restaurant . You pick food items from a machine and pay that machine first before people will cook your food from the back. Don't expect a cashier.Beds were firm and clean. We stayed on 41st floor. View was good. Reception front was nice and polite even they had long line of tour groups . They are more cater to Asian tourist than westerners because it was hard to communicate at times.I will return to this hotel if I go Tokyo again.

We had only one night stay in this hotel. It locates in a quiet corner of Shinjuku, surrounded by office buildings. It was interesting to see Japanese hard working at Friday night through your window. It was about 10 minutes walk to JR line, and not close to the shopping (noisy) centre (15-20 minutes by walk). And, there aren't many casual dining places around (there are some about 5-10 minutes by walk), the restaurants are business style. We had an early flight the next day, but we couldn't book the shuttle (to Narita airport) at the hotel as all the shuttles were fully booked for the morning. We walked to Shinjuku station (west gate) and booked the shuttle bus finally.The room was also business style. Excellent space and comfortable bed, extremly clean. I would prefer this hotel if I was on business trip other than travelling.

Located across the street from Toyko Metro office building and afew walking blocks from the JR Shinjuku station. This is a 4 star tourist hotel housing many tour groups. Our guest room was clean but small (compared to US standards). The hotel, room, and bathroom is dated but very well maintained. Looking at hotel photos, some rooms are renovated but we did not get one. This hotel is convenient to transportation, shopping, Kubukicho, Piss Alley, Robot Restaurant and Maids Cafe. Good choice for a hotel.

Checked-in late on a Monday evening and requested a high-floor room after reading the reviews on this site. Was travelling with a Japanese friend and despite the booking being prepaid on my credit card and in my name, the check-in staff only communicated in Japanese with my friend. Check-in staff member then asked if smoking room was okay (in English) I confirmed it was fine, only for the check-in staff member to ask my friend in Japanese if that was okay! Anyway...allocated room on 17th floor. It stank, had stains on the walls and hairs in the bathtub from (I assume) the previous guest. Lovely!Check-out is a ridiculously early 11 a.m. and they try to make you pay 3000 yen extra if you want to check-out at 1 p.m. and an extortionate 8000 yen for a 3 p.m. check-out! For the same price we could have stayed at the Hilton, which in my experience is far superior concerning price, service, decor, etc. I wouldn't recommend it at all. Location...yeah fine, but there are loads of other places nearby which are just as convenient and at least modern.

With two tall towers in the heart of Shinjuku, right on the edge of the skyscraper sector, Keio Plaza is a fantastic central location.The rooms are comfortable, many with great views over Tokyo. The hotel has a range of restaurants and cafes, a convenience store, a range of gift shops, childcare, karaoke rooms, bar all in house.The service is attentive and polite.A recommended stay. I'd stay again :-)

We were frantically looking around for a hotel in Shinjuku within walking distance from the subway as many hotels were fully booked. In the end, a friend recommended Keio to us and we manged to book a room.The hotel is around 10-minute walk to the Shinjuku subway station, which we found it to be very convenient. It is also closed to many eateries, including a sushi restaurant that I went back 3 times in a few days to satisfy my cravings for sushi.One area that the hotel needs to improve on is the staff service. Probably because some of them are not well versed in English, I got mixed level of staff service.The bell boy who helped to bring my luggage to my room was excellent as he answered my questions on where to find good food and convenience stores. He even drew on a map on where they are located.

This Hotel plaza is in a very very good location, a block away from Shinjuku, and Shinjuku station, three stops away and you are in Shibuya so, the reason of my 5 stars is location. Rooms are standard and also depends a lot on what floor you get, we were given floor 12th so there wasn't much of a view, the room was clean though. Breakfast is good, they have both western and Japanese style.

The experience you get from this hotel is like lottery. Either good or very bad depending on which room the allocate you in.We had a great stay in 2014 when we stayed in their renovated room.Knowing that not all their room is renovated, from entries in Tripadvisor. We requested to for a renovated room when we made our reservation 4 months ahead.Response from them was robotic and seem like they agreed.However when we checked in, it was the 1960s themes room. The room is horrible and has a mouldy smell.We called the front desk and the guy has no product knowledge, insist the room we are in is a renovated room. ( Renovated in 1960?)We went to the front desk and he escalated to his supervisor which escalated to her supervisor the front manager who insist there is no other room available.After 1 hour or negotiation he offer us a renovated room in the main tower but has we have to pay the different. We asked him for his GM contact but he refused to give us.Maybe there is no such person? If you look at their website and tripadvisor replies it all from a generics email.Super cold and robotic service from Keio.Never will stay here again.

Spacious rooms especially by Japanese standards. Very functional and comfortable as well as convenient to all points of interest in the area. Buffet breakfast which was included was excellent with a wide selection. Recommended

Pros:Within 10mins walking distance from Shinjuku station.Staff very helpful.Decent size rooms for Tokyo/all essential toiletries provided.Free WFI.Cons:Earliest check in time is 14:00 so don't turn up too early.Breakfast/food very expensive however there are plenty of eating options by Shinjuku train station.

2nd stay in this hotel Pros1)Its location and accessibility from the airport and to Disney. 2) A variety of breakfast to choose from3) Good room size4) Nice food at the Teppanyaki restaurant and the best service rendered by the staff there. They should be at the front desk.Cons1) Staffs are polite for Japanese standard but that is all we can expect from them. Do not expect friendly or personalised service especially from the front desk staff. 2) Staff at the Executive check in area do not even bother to help me to check in and immediately direct me to the front desk reception area eventhough I am EIC member3) Strict check in timing at 3pm. Eventhough, we arrived early in the hotel with a tired toddler but the hotel do not even allow us to check in 15 mins earlier than the 3pm check in time. Despite telling them our situation and if it is possible to expediate the room cleaning. 4) Despite having at least 3 restaurants that we can have our breakfast, the front desk staff just failed to inform us about it and just informed us about the breakfast area for EIC member

this well located hotel is huge! the rooms are very comfortable, and whilst not huge, are large by Japanese standards. we had a room that gave access to the sky lounge - from where we had fantastic views as we enjoyed (free) pre-dinner cocktails

Stayed here with family for a few days, upon the recommendation of friends. It did not disappoint: clean and very comfortable rooms; courteous and helpful staff; great location, near the Shinjuku station, even had an underpassage connection, which could connect you to any part of the city and even the subarbs via the Shinkansen (bullet train). Also just across Tokyo Metropolitan Gov't Authority Office which offers a fantastic city view on the 45th floor for free! A short walk to Kabukicho, on the other and more lively side of Shinjuku with big branches of Don Quijote, Uniqlo etc. Hotel itself had a convenience store and many restaurant outlets at the lower level but we were not able to try them as there were other convenience stores, restaurants around as well.

Stayed last week of March. Friendly staff. Lots of choices for breakfast you have three restaurants to choose from. Clean, adequately sized and comfortable room. Wifi was fast too. Shinjuku station and shopping area is just walking distance from the hotel. There were also lots of restaurants nearby serving authentic Japanese food.

Stayed here many times and never fails to disappoint! Many restaurants, great Sky Lounge and great location! Rooms are large and very comfortable! Great views of the city and Mt. Fuji on a clear day! I highly recommend the Keio Plaza! All tours also depart from here.

There are two towers at Keio Plaza. Make sure you pick the newly renovated room. Service was only OK, but only a 5-min walk to Shinjuku Station (west entrance). Service at the front desk is sub-par by Japanese standard, and when we requested porters to carry luggage from our rooms down to the main lobby, they sent two ladies and I felt bad for them. The room we stayed was slightly larger than average hotel room size in Tokyo, but the room felt a bit tired and you can tell the hotel has been around for quite some time. They need to renovate the whole building. Wi-Fi was OK, can't complain.

I agree with what everyone has mentioned about its great location. We love the eateries nearby the hotel, the Shinjuku Gyoen is only 15 mins away, the shops, the convenient store and drug stores nearby provide the best value for money. They have shuttle bus to and from the airport, as well as the free shuttle to Disney, although you have to book the seat way in advance.BUT , we found that the service of the hotel is NOT CONSISTENT AND NOT UP TO 4 STAR HOTEL STANDARD. There were eight of us in our group, 6 ladies and 2 gents. We stayed at Keio for 2 nights, everything was fine and went to Kawaguchi for an overnight stay. We then return to Keio for another night. On this second visit, we arrived late at night, with lots of luggage and tired bodies. Surprisingly, unlike on our first visit when we had good impression of the hotel and services, this time the concierge refuse to bring our luggage to our rooms and told us to bring them ourselves. If the hotel was very busy at that time, we might have understood, but they were not busy and a few bell boys appear to be available. Only when we asked to speak to the manager on duty, when the concierge finally agreed to send our luggage to the room. Its not a pleasant experience at all and completely ruin the good impression we had initially. I dont know if the hotel has this inconsistency in service throughout or if the specific 'bell boy' had a long tiring night and thus the bad attitude, and to make it worse, the manager on duty actually sat just a few meters away and must have heard our irritated conversation with the bell boy and just simply ignored us and not even trying to solve matter. Thank God we moved from the hotel the next day.Although Shinjuku will still be my preferred area to stay in Tokyo,I don't think I'll be coming back to this hotel again.
user_name:
Yenny C
Jakarta, Jakarta Raya, Indonesia

review_body: We stayed here for a total of 9 days at the Plaza Luxe room at the 33rd floor. The hotel is very big as well as the room itself (vs normal Japanese rooms) and is easily located a couple of hundred meters from the Shinjuku station. It is also near several convenience stores as well as many restaurants. Service was great. We even used the premier lounge for checking in and out. However, the housekeeping was not very satisfactory. Whenever we arrived back at our room, the room did not feel spic and span and one time, there was a rag left in the tub.We were very busy and did not complain except for a few times like I had the bathrobe replaced by hanging it over the tub and only one was replaced, the other was missing. One time we also did not get any water bottle refill although when we called, it was immediately replaced. I hope the management would take note of these inconsistencies in service because the front desk was good but the cleaning team was not.

A little background here: Used to stay here often on business trips but due to numerous complaints (rude staff, terrible internet connection, dirty rooms, etc.) from coworkers and myself, my company terminated our contract with Keio Plaza and switched back to Hilton instead (good move). Fast forward to present: While planning our anniversary/vacation trip to Tokyo with my girlfriend, my trusted travel agent told me that Keio Plaza's rep has been bugging her about how they've improved their services and the hotel has been renovated recently, etc. so I decided to give it a second chance (bad move):- Upon check-in, front desk staff wanted to charge us more because I have a +1. After some explaining, I was able to convince them to waive the fee but all these for a +1, REALLY? I chalked this up as my oversight so let's move on... (30 mins wasted)- WIFI connection is slow and intermittent. Front desk was notified and they acknowledged that there might be a coverage issue (28th floor, main tower) and their solution for my problem is... I kid you not and I quote, "Sir, why don't you use your devices in the corridor or next to the front door?" I was speechless and hung up... (1 hr wasted)- Keio Plaza's ISP (NEC I believe) called the next morning trying to help but they (NEC) admitted that they can only help me with logging on WIFI, not staying on WIFI. (Another hour wasted)^ all these issues happened in less than 24 hours Other info/rant:- While booking the reservation, my trusted travel agent told Keio Plaza's rep to give us "VIP treatment"... That sure didn't happen.- Apparently not all rooms have been updated/renovated. We got the smoke-stained "70's theme" room by default, not by choice.- Our room smells like chimney even though we reserved a non-smoking room.- Their laundry staff can't count so make sure you count with them to prevent being overcharged. Bottom line: I will never stay here and I will not recommend renewing our corporate contract with them.

Everything everyone said about this hotel is accurate, it is situated near to the train station, eateries and light shopping. I will only mention some of the things that I have tried and love. Cozy room and comfy beds, clean toilet, nice view from 20+ floor above ground. Breakfast was okay. Nearby a lot of bars, Japanese men will gather and drink right after work. If you are into tasting real Japanese alcohol with some snack at a Japanese style bar, here is a good place to stay, you can drink a lot and still find your way back to the hotel by just walking for a short 5 minutes. If you are hungry for some sushi, there's a 24 hour sushi house nearby. There's also drug store selling cosmetics. All these are within walking distance from the hotel, no more boring nightlife in Japan.

nice place to stay in japan. near to station only 350m away.friendly staff. have privet bus that take you to DisneyLand. near to shopping mall and places. I've enjoy stay at the hotel when i was tokyo. and think of booking again if i may come to tokyo again.

Type of Room: Plaza Luxe- South TowerPros: Great Location (plenty of restaurants nearby, close to MRT and Department stores and Airport Limousine/ bus stops here), Newly renovated room (I did not feel old), complimentary breakfast was good (with this type of room you have the options to have breakfast at 3 different location: at the more exclusive and quiter breakfast lounge near the reception or the bigger restaurants at on the lower floor), lounge access was a nice touch especially at the fairly reasonable room rate they charged during the sakura seasonCons: The variety of food provided in the lounge was quite little, nevertheless, it is a good place to relax.

We stayed at this hotel with our five year old and had a great experience. The room was very nice and had an incredible view and the bathroom was nice as well with great amenities. The staff was efficient and friendly. Please note that this hotel does not allow early check in and the line was very long when they opened for check in. We had the breakfast buffet once and it was very good and a wonderful variety. There is a park with a playground near the hotel, which was wonderful for our five year old. The hotel is located close to a subway station and also many restaurants. We would stay here again.

We made our first trip to Japan and stayed in this hotel for 8 nights. We had the Plaza Luxe room in the south tower. We thought this was a good value for money, getting a room from 29th floor with great views over Tokyo. Being jetlagged one morning enabled us to see an amazing sun rise from the room! Additionally with that room type you get to have a better breakfast near lobby and an access to lounge on top of the south tower.We found the service in the hotel to be first class all the way. The way every one from the staff took care of us was marvelous. The location is very good, excellent connections were very close. The hotel also offered a free transportation to Disneyland, a nice addition to a wide range of services.Even though the hotel is huge in terms of amount of rooms, it doesn't really feel that huge. No long queues or anything. Was a lovely visit, and if possible we will go there again in the future.

This hotel exceeded my expectation. It has very good location next to Shinjuku train station, shops, eateries and Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (which provides free access to its two observatories at level 45).The room was impeccable - spacious, with king-size bed, long wooden desk, impressive Japan-standard toilet seat, branded toiletries and yukata. Among the toiletries were the non-standard items like bath cloth, hairbands and L'occitane effervescent revitalizing sugar cube.It's our first time enjoying Japanese standard in a hotel, and we were truly impressed. We were attended by 2 bellboys who carried our luggage, showed us to our rooms and explained to us the various things in the room. All this happened although the hotel was quite crowded at the time when we arrived. Both check-in and check-out process were smooth.

Great Hotel, centre location, easy to walk and shop nearby.We are happy the hotel have Wifi and Baby Coat for us.We walk from the hotel to nearby train station, and the location is great for us to travel with kids, so safe

My husband and I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel as part of a tour group that was running the Tokyo Marathon. I can highly recommend it to other travelers.A hotel's location doesn't get much better than this. The Keio Plaza Hotel is situated very close to the Shinjuku Station - which is the busiest transport hub in the world. We found it quite confusing and difficult to navigate around this station so would often use an alternate station located just a couple of minutes walk from the hotel. It was quick and easy to get anywhere in Tokyo from here.Our room was very comfortable and we were delighted when we woke up, on one of the few clear days, to discover that we could see Mount Fuji from our hotel room. Having a warm toilet seat was also a great experience!There are so many amazing restaurants in this hotel that you are really spoilt for choice. We ate in a variety of these restaurants and always had a great meal. Our breakfast was included and there was even a great variety of restaurants to choose from for breakfast. There is a pastry boutique in the hotel and some of the pastries are beautiful works of art - and delicious too.If I have to find a negative about this hotel then it would be that they were very regimental when it came to the check in time. We arrived on an early morning flight from Australia and we could not check in any earlier than check in time. Although we realized that we were far to early to check in when we arrived it would have been appreciated if they let us check in earlier, as soon as a room was available. Apart from this we had a great experience and I can highly recommend this hotel.

Great hotel to stay in... Near a lot of places. Near the subway. Near lots of nearby restaurants. Staff courteous. They thought of all amenities in the roo, even a fabric freshener. Would definitely go back!!

This is a luxury hotel in the business district. One block to restaurants, drug stores and pachinko parlors. Terrain is flat and streets have cutouts.We stayed in room 3006, which was somewhat accessible. Door is 36 in., Bath door is 30 in., Toilet height is 17 in., Tub height is 21 in., Ramp into bathroom has a 2 in. rise, bathroom floor space is 30 in. x 59.5 in., bed height is 17.5 in. Room is carpeted. Bed is firm.

The Hotel is in a great location. Walking distance to the shopping, restaurants and the train station. Its a big and busy hotel, however we found the service to be excellent. Breakfast was included with a variety of dining options. Our rooms were great and we had the privilege to wake up to the sight of Mt Fuji from our windows. Highly recommend this hotel for your stay in Japan

Nice location, near everything without the congestion. Sufficient infrastructure, enough elevators. Breakfast at the glass court was good with efficient staff who are capable of speaking English. Courteous and friendly personnel. Would recommend this hotel to others.

Stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel for 5 nights - 2 rooms with 3 kids. Excellent location. At the safe and better side of Shinjuku. 5 min walk from Shinjuku station and if you are lost just walk towards west Shinjuku and use the high rise building as a mark. The only issue I have is the staff are less than helpful when I asked them about nearby coin laundry. They insist that they is none near by and the nearest is next station or too far to walk. When I search the net, am surprised how many people are having same issues. Managed to find 2 within 5 min walk from the hotel. Link is below http://maps.apple.com/?q=35.694947,139.695111&sll=35.694947,139.695111Other than that, the lobby is extremely busy all the time. Probably reflect that it's a popular hotel for tourist.Will stay there again for its location, cleanliness and good size room.

Located at Shinjuku, close to the busiest station in Japan & walking distance to major shopping districts e.g. Keio/ Odakyu/ Lumine/ taka/ Isetan. Look out for the landmark of Post office. Food outlets and electronic supply shop just right across the hotel. Reception level has the concierge counter for shuttle services such as Airport Limousine (prebook) to Haneda & Narita airports & disneyland. Luggage can be stored for the convenient of exploring the ground before check in (2pm) & check out (11am). Free Wifi can be access in the hotel, password given upon checking in. We have a triple room & were pleasantly suprise to see 3 different colour toothbrushs. Thats thoughful. 10% discount is given to hotel guests for all the restaurants and cafes in the hotel.

The room was very spacious on par with the best of U.S. hotels. The bathroom was adequate but there was not very much space to store our personal grooming equipment which was common to all of the rooms we stayed in Japan (and a lot of other hotels). The Toto toilet seat was very refreshing and we're thinking of getting one when we remodel our bathroom. The staff were so friendly and helpful. Our agent arranged breakfast as part of our stay and we tried the Jurian which offered a great choice and quality of Western and Japanese food. The Japanese breakfast was exceptional. The other buffet restaurant was good but its Western food was not as good as the Jurian. We would definitely stay here again when we visit Japan once again. The other reviewers correctly noted how close the hotel is to Shinjuku Station and to other restaurants and shops.

Second stay at this hotel and its still an excellent choice. The location is 5 minute walk from shinjuku station. Ask for a room in the upper half of the towers and you will also have an amazing view from the room. The hotel is not for people ona tight budget but also not too expensive considering what you get. Sure the rooms are starting to show some signs of wear but they are big(for Tokyo standard) and still have a very good standard. The hotel got 7 excellent restaurants for dinner and lunch. 3 of them also got breakfast option where you can have continental, japanese or all you can eat buffet. I will certainly stay at this hotel next time im visiting as well.

A stone throw away from the famous shinjuku station ( 5 min walk ). A rather grand hotel with many entrances.. Across the road is the Metropolitan Government Office. Friendly Airport Limousine ( coach ) that cost mere ¥1,230 ( Haneda Airport to hotel ). On your departure date you can buy your bus ticket next to the concierge counter. Free shuttle to Tokyo Disney on schedule time. If retail therapy is not screaming your name or the Japanese friendliness & culture is not tempting you to take the day tours..the hotel has great facilities, from gym, pool to numberous f&b outlet right up to money changer machine...The standard rooms are average in size, well equips. Crazily but cool they even have Princess Kitty Room. Yes...u got it right..for the Hello Kitty fans.

Stayed for 7 nights. The hotel gave us great options for our breakfast and the rooms were clean and comfortable. The staff were very accommodating and friendly. The hotel was located in a nice part of Shinjuku so going to the stations was easy (there's a new, fast access to Shinjuku station and Tochomae station was right outside) as well as good shopping (Odakyu, ABC Mart, convenience stores, electronics and watch shops, Uniqlo, Don Quijote, etc) and food options (everything we tried was good!) in the area. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office was right across too.

Located near the busiest train station in Tokyo - Shinjuku. With many restaurants and cafes nearby, you are spoiled for choices. The hotel room comes with high speed wifi connection and cable TV. Thumbs up to the housekeeping team for the cleanliness of the room! Speaking of convenience, you can take a airport limousine bus directly to and fro from the hotel lobby. The hotel also provides free shuttle service to Tokyo Disneyland.

Was a little worried about the old rooms when I saw the pictures from other reviews so I booked for the renewed nonsmoking room in the south tower for our 4 nights stay.
