Upon check in, we were happy to say that we made the right decision. The room is new and clean and we can see Mont Fuji from our 22th floor. For ppl planning to book, south tower is still undergoing renovation. 20th floor and above were completed but not the lower floors and the south tower lobby. Location is convenient with minutes to transit and restaurants and shopping.

love the hotel, we stayed there for a few days, and its a walking distance to many shopping areas and attractions, it also has an easy access to the train station. the staff are friendly and helpful too.

Stayed a total of 4 nights. Booked a plaza premier for 3 nights and a princess kitty room for 1 night.Hotel is a straight walk from Shinjuku station. You can choose to walk thru shinjuku vibrant streets or a covered walkway with travelator so there is no complain about walking distant.The plaza premier room is big, clean with excellent amenities and big window with great view.The princess kitty room is to satisfy my wife constant obsession with everything Hello Kitty. Room is cute and spacious, although personally I'm favouring the plaza premier room.Keio Plaza is a big hotel with high volume of guest, but they manage the crowd extremely well by allocating different restaurant to guest during breakfast. Transfer to airports is also convenient from the hotel.Staff response is excellent. I really appreciate their assistance for my wife who fall sick and need a doctor consultation. And yes they have a clinic on the 30th floor. 5 full star is deservingly earned.

Great hotel, spacious rooms, close to Shinjuku station for transport links and also walking distance to many attractions (Meiji shrine, Yoyogi park, Harajuku Street, Shibuya Crossing and the Robot Resturant.)

We stayed here for 5 nights recently. My wife had a conference at this hotel and so our stay was based more on the conference location than a strong sense that this was a great hotel. However, it ended surpassing our expectations. Great service (as with virtually all things Japanese). Lovely lobby. The room was surprisingly large for Japan and very clean, with nice amenities and style. We made sure to get the renovated rooms (I think it was South tower). We normally stayed in more luxurious types of hotels (e.g., Four Seasons, Ritz Carltons, etc.), and this one held up just fine -- and the price also was very reasonable.

This review is very overdue - stayed in February 2014 for the Tokyo marathon. Hotel is in an excellent location for the marathon start (short walk) as well as great location for walking around the Shinjuku area and close to the Shinjuku station and large malls. The hotel is huge and caters to large groups. Definitely recommend a room in the renovated tower, we changed rooms on arrival as our first room was not the room type we had reserved, the room we changed to was excellent, on a very high floor with great views over Shinjuku. Daily breakfast ok but long queue each morning to be seated. Excellent Sky Lounge on the 45 floor highly recommended as well as the Italian/French restaurant Duo Fourchettes. We had lunch at one of the sushi restaurants in the hotel which we do not recommend, very ordinary food and ridiculously priced.The hotel staff were very friendly, polite and helpful throughout our stay. We definitely recommend this hotel, choose a renovated room option and be prepared for a very busy hotel.

We booked a twin room at this hotel for 4 nights and were upgraded on arrival. The hotel is quite pricy but we were late booking and wanted to stay near Shinjuku station. It is very clean with extremely courteous staff and our room had 2 king singles, a small table, chair and a two seater couch. The only thing that I wouldn't worry about again is the breakfast. For the price you would do better at a bakery or Starbucks. On level 2 there are restaurants and a grocery store. The hotel also provides free secure WiFi connection.Beware mattresses are rock hard but I suffer from back problems and slept well so I can't complain.You could not miss the station from the hotel, dead ahead, but to return you have to pick the right exit. Central West and South were good although we still managed to come out the wrong stairs on occasions. It was always a surprise but just remember that if you can see the Lumine store which is on top you'll get there. I wanted Shinjuku as I thought the Shinkansen left from there, but it doesn't and so we had to travel in peak hour to another station with luggage which is an experience to avoid if possible. The hotel is more in business end and East exit more lively area.

Stayed at Keio Plaza for 5 nights in March 2015.The room was very clean, the bed comfortable and the bathroom was a good size as well.Stayed with my girlfriend and we had lots of room for luggage, clothes and personal space etc. (Not always the case in Japan!)We stayed room only, and went and got our own breakfast every morning which was nice. The thing that set the room apart from all our other hotels during our stay in Japan was the views. We were on the 19th floor, and the room window runs from floor to ceiling so we would sit and eat breakfast at the table and chairs provided and look out on the city. You can see the landscape for miles and the city skyscraper line as well. It was something special.The customer service desk are also great. They have ready printed instruction sheets should you ask to go to anywhere in the city which is a massive help!The location is also great, you are only a few mins away from Shinjuku station so once you have sussed out the JR lines and the subway then the city is your oyster!Would 100% stay here again if returning to Tokyo.

I stayed here as my normal hotel in Shinjuku was full. It was a nice change, although one night I walked straight passed as I thought it was an office block! It was apparently the first large building in Shinjuku some decades ago however it still retains it's glamour!My only advice is to either be early at one of the many restaurants for breakfast or better still wander out to one of the many "cafes' that have not appeared nearby - especially near the station. With so many rooms (there are two towers) the queues can be quite long.The hotel is close by the heart of Shinjuku, so lots of activity, offices, shops etc and the station has the most throughput of people per day of any station in the world!

This hotel has very nice room and good service. Breakfast has great view (45 floors) they have many restaurants on the second floor. I would give this hotel 5 star if they didn't have such a bad wifi. You will need 2 set of wifi user and password. Each room have different password and the signal is very weak. You will get disconnected even 2 minutes.

Firstly let me start by saying the hotel staff were lovely and friendly at keio plaza. The hotel is huge and and well maintained. The bed was such a disappointment, it honestly hurt my back because it was so hard and uncomfortable, we stayed in the south tower and didn't really have a good view of the city at all, but the room was clean and tidy. We went to attend breakfast one morning and were greatly disappointed as the food was cold and I don't believe they did a good western breakfast, but we are in Japan after all. i personally wouldn't stay here again just because of the bedding and I would rather pay extra for comfort and perhaps a nice view. Will be staying in another hotel in Shinjuku on the way back from our trip so will be interesting to see how they compare, fingers crossed for comftable bedding!

Service is still great. Prices are fair. Great location. Still like everything about this hotel, except....the WiFi here is terrible. Gets disconnected every minute or so. Surprised I'm even able to write this review right now.

We were fortunate enough to stay at Keio Plaza from March 22 - 28. We booked through JTB and got a very good rate for this excellent property right in the heart of Tokyo. The service is 5-star - everyone from front desk to room service to bellhop was warm, polite, and kind. The room is large and comfortable and we had a lovely view of Mt Fuji between the skyscrapers. Access to the hotel from the Shinkuku Station west exit couldn't be simpler. The Airport Limousine Bus also stops here and is a very convenient way of getting to/from the airport. I highly recommend Keio Plaza for anyone new (or returning) to this awesome city.

We stayed four nights in this very large hotel in Shinjuku, chosen for us by our travel agent- with good reason. It has many eating options; we mostly chose the excellent Jurin Buffet for breakfasts and one dinner. Our two tours started from here and the Shinjuku station is a short walk away with Tokyo barely 20 minutes away by the quick Chuo Line.Our room in the South Tower was clean, quiet, well equipped and comfortable, but a bit tired. The staff are efficient and professional.

The Keio Plaza was in a great location and we had a very enjoyable stay. We stayed on the 32nd floor in the south wing and the room was spacious, very clean and appeared to be recently refurbished. Check-in was smooth and they were able to give us access to our room prior to official check-in time. Bell staff were very obliging and helpful. We arrived into Shinjuku by train and were able to walk from the station with our luggage; the airport transfer back to Narita direct from the hotel was easy. Would highly recommend staying at the Keio Plaza.

We stayed in the Luxe Suites for 7 nights. These are our thoughts from our one week stay:The refurbished 'luxury' suites in the South Tower are supposed to be better than the regular Main Tower rooms. The Luxe suites merely update the South Tower rooms to a contemporary look in keeping with present styles. The dark faux-wood panelling is muted and tastefully stylish. The suite itself was average sized, no better or worse than many others we've stayed in and posed no restrictions when wanting to spread out and make ourselves at home. My favourite aspect of the room were the shower taps; in true reliable Japanese style these taps and shower head were precise in a way I've not experienced in other international hotels and allowed me to shower in perfect temperature comfort. No other features or aspects of the room stood out for better or worse, so we would say the suite was average in a satisfactory way.The hotel complex is massive. It is foremost a convention/conference hotel. Expect to share public space in the hotel with hordes of package tourists. Do not stay here expecting personal service; the place is geared to churn guests in and out of their rooms and service is merely courteous, efficient but perfunctory. I was surprised the hotel was established in 1971 - there is no trace of its early 70's decor anywhere which would've mitigated the hotel's 'datedness' and explained its faded charm. I could only discern an 80's vibe from the public areas and shops - that must've been the time of its last extension. Only the bars/restaurants and Luxe suites in the South Wing offer evidence of modern-day decor. The rest of the place is stuck in 1982.Our package included breakfast in the Cocktail Lounge located next to the check-in. We rate it passable but below average with a very limited hot selection. There are other breakfast options in the hotel with more extensive buffet selections but our package did not include that option. I politely requested to exchange my breakfast coupon one morning for the Japanese breakfast coupon and that offered an interesting if equally limited diversion from the same-same of powdered scrambled eggs and bacon.Our Luxe suite package included 'lounge' access on the 34th floor. Treat it as a nice quiet sanctuary to escape the Tokyo bustle, the loud crowds in the lobby and to rest your weary feet. Don't expect a selection of high-tea treats and all-day snacks as found in better hotel 'club lounge' offerings. The food selection was extremely poor (pretzels, nuts and tired cake-bites - NOTHING ELSE). Raid the fridge for beers, wine, sodas or coffee but don't expect the food to appeal or recharge you after sightseeing.Both breakfast and lounge access use outdated paper 'coupons' and passes for entry. It is a rinky, outmoded system emblematic of the hotel's old-era operations. Check-in systems remain heavily paper based but it obviously works for them. The hotel is well located within minutes of Shinjuku railway station and the nearby nightlife. Overall, we rate the Keio Plaza Hotel 7/10. The Luxe suites were good but the rest of the place isn't compelling enough for a repeat stay. Once is enough.

This hotel for local people is a medium quality hotel that's been around for ages. I stay here every three months or so for entertaining customers at the Chinese restaurant. These days, this hotel accepts too many package holiday tours and recently bus loads from China. This creates a long queue at check in and out. For those that have this concern might want to book the club room that has a separate and helpful priority check in counter located beside the front desk and has a small room. No queues here. Food quality is as expected, quite good at all restaurants.

After reading many good reviews about the hotel i decided to stay at the keio plaza hotel however i am greatly disappointed with the quality of service and communication skills your staff lacked. On 22-28 i stayed at your hotel for 6 nights and as I mentioned to your receptionist at the time, the accommodation was unsatisfactory in the following ways. Firstly the room was not equipped with a room heater, making the room extremely cold during the nights. Secondly it was very difficult to communicate our needs to your staff as they cant speak English very well hence they could hardly provide us with the things we need. Furthermore we encountered a staff who was very impatient as he could barely understand our request for red tea instead of green tea.Overall i am satisfied with the cleanliness of the hotel and the space was reasonably big for a japan hotel however i expected better service from this type and price of hotel.

Overall the experience here was very good. The check in process was a little bit slow, but that was typical of a large hotel.I did use the club room facility one day, which allowed me to do some work and have a meeting in comfort.The room was actually really big. Typical Japanese hotel rooms can be quite small, but this was a very pleasant surprise.The hotel location is walkable distance to the train station and I also caught the Narita Limo Bus to the airport, as it leaves from this hotel, so getting in and out of the hotel was very good.I would recommend this hotel to fellow business travellers and I would stay here again next time.

You don't feel like you're one of a thousand guests at this hotel. Every staff member treated us as if we were the only person there. The front desk staff was fantastic, professional and helpful. We took a twin bed room because we wanted to escape another hotel. Turned out the "twin' beds are two full-size, so my wife and I did not have to sleep like Laura and Rob Petrie. The room was huge and very comfortable.The Keio is in the center of exciting Shinjuku, which is a good neighborhood to stay in Tokyo. There is lots to do just in that area. Great shopping, food and excellent transit connections.The Keio Plaza is a great destination hotel.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is full delight: beautiful great hall, kind welcome, spacious rooms, amazing view over Fuji-san and crazy breakfast make it a must-stay ;)Our only (small) disappointment has to do with the swimming pool, for which there is a charge.

Keio Plaza is a huge tour group hotel very conveniently located near Shinjuku Station. Renovated rooms are really nice and large by Tokyo standards. The wifi is fast and if you get a premium room, you can get cute lounge access. Beware however - guests booking through online channels (like booking.com) are given an inferior breakfast with *super* limited hours at the "crystal room" on the ground floor. This breakfast has half the hours of the regular breakfast, and 20% of the total offerings (and is continuously out of stock). The tables in this room are also not normal tables, so you will be stooping over your food. Just don't buy a breakfast inclusive rate and pay the 3000 JPY for the real buffet breakfast onsite - or fight the hotel for a full voucher. You'll be glad you did.The hotel knows that it's trying to pull a fast one on direct-booked guests, as was evident from multiple conversations I had with the staff - eventually resulting in a full breakfast voucher being given by the GM. But then, in a follow up with booking.com the hotel's Sales Director lied in an email about the breakfast setup, reinforcing my opinion that they are trying to cheat. So here's the thing - it's a very good hotel for the price, just DON'T give them prepaid breakfast money. It's not worth it, unless they guarantee you the full deal. Also note - check in and check out were a mess when at peak times. Plaza Luxe rooms include priority check in and might be worthwhile for that reason alone.

Went there jan of this year. Temp was like 1 to 5c. Perfect weather for walking around shinjuku. Lots of restos and electronic stores along the way going to the subway station. Isetan is not far away. Breakfast was good too. Nice room with heated toilet seats. Ask a room in the new tower tho. The old tower has smaller rooms.

The location near Shinjuku station is perfect for all the seightseeing spots in Tokyo. Though the station is a little confusing at first. Our first night in a hotel in Japan and we where a little surprised how helpful and friendly the staff was. Check in and check out went very smoothly, and the staff was very helpful in all. The room was large and you could find everything you could expect from a hotel like this. One could see that the room had been used, a little worn down but nothing that bothered us. One of the beds was adjustable so you could raise it up for reading position. On the downside would be that the beds where quite hard, woke up in the night with a sore hipbone and had to change position All in all a good stay.

This was my first visit to Japan. We landed at Haneda Airport at about 2230 hrs, and by the time we had our passport stamped, it was already 2310 hrs. Managed to take the last limousine bus that took us straight to Shinjuku station which is just 5 mins walk to Keio Plaza Hotel, never expected it to be so convenient. Although we reached the hotel at a little past 12 midnight, checking in was no hassle at all. In less that 5 mins, we are already in our room. The room is adequately large for a family of three, very clean, and very quiet. Beds are very comfortable and they provide many variants of pillows ranging from hard to soft, so you will never miss your pillows at home. Bathroom was very clean with all the amenities of a 5 star hotel, and the best part was the safe in the room which is really big, so big that my wife could lock her handbag in it. Travelling about in Tokyo was no trouble at all because the hotel is linked by a tunnel to the Shinjuku subway station. From this station, you can travel to almost any town or city. There are lots of restaurants and sushi bars within walking distance from the hotel and a few big shopping malls are also located nearby. This hotel also provide free shuttle bus to and from Tokyo Disneyland and Disneysea but you have to make early reservation first as it is almost everyday full. But the best part was, you can purchase limousine bus ticket at a ticket vending machine located in the hotel itself and the bus picks you up to the airport from the hotel itself. Keio Plaza Hotel is really a marvelously convenient hotel. I have no qualms recommending this hotel to all visitors to Tokyo.

Great hotel!Very clean, great amenities, and in a generally great area in Shinjuku. We used two rooms for 6 persons, and we were fairly amused to find out that the extra bed in the room wasn't like a typical folding extra bed. In fact the extra bed came under under one of the beds, and it's mattress was a full sized, and felt exactly like the other twin beds. Clean shower, which came with all amenities, and of course a fancy toilet seat (the type you'd expect all over Tokyo). The hotel also has a convenience store, restaurants (on the pricey side though), a business center (three computers and a printer), and an excellent guest relations desk - the type that can assist in getting you a bus to Disney, has bus tours, can assist in getting you tickets for the limousine bus back to the airport. Overall, a great location and a great hotel which gave us a good experience for our first stay in Tokyo.The reason I only gave a 4/5: 1) no direct hotel transfers (we had to take the limousine bus - and at least limousine bus has pick up/drop off directly at Keio Plaza Hotel lobby)2) 10 min walk from nearest train station (sometimes hard with older people in a family vacation)3) not the cheapest hotel available (sometimes I prefer cheaper hotels because I wouldn't want to be in the hotel for long - I'd rather be out exploring)

Wer travelled as group and were located in the south annex. The rooms are very quiet, the beds are very comfortable, and the cleaning service is very good. The rooms however could do with a refurb. The view was very good. breakfast in the glass court, while very busy was very efficient in its service. All the normal things available for breakfast, including omelette, fried eggs, an expresso coffee machine. We ate in the glass court the first night. Excellent buffet with first class food, cost 6,600 yen. Wine is expensive at 1300 yen for a small glass. Receptionists are good and the lobby is impressive. While there is a kettle and tea in the room, there is no coffee. Thr shop in the restaurant floor does however sell small jars. A good central location

This is by far the best hotel I've stayed in a long time.Smooth reservation process on line. Bus limousine from Narita very well organised, comfortable and reasonably priced at ¥31000 pp.Hotel is enormous, more than 1400 rooms, 45 floors up and a couple of towers.Reception and check-in was straight forward and a 20 minute wait.Elevators and equipment are efficient and silent.Breakfast was included in our rate with option of 3 restaurants: Japanese, western and a mix of both. We tried them all. Service is outstanding with a wait of less than 15 minutes, even when they had 6 conferences going simultaneously. Great variety of food: cereals, fruits vegetables, breads , fish, juices, make your own yoghurt with mix of fruit sauces. Tea, coffee, cappuccino maker .We've got a room on the 25th floor with city and mountains view . Room is ample, very clean, capsule coffee machine, tea, bar fridge and nice amenities including Shiseido face soap. Air conditioner temperature is not a problem at all. The safe is enormous , situated in a drawer and includes a charger for your laptop. I found this very convenient as you can see inside and there is no need to be in awkward positions inside the wardrobe, where usually safes are located.Bed is very comfortable and they have included robes and slippers.Highly recommended.

Love Love Love the location of this hotel and the employees are all super professional and extremely helpful. The check in went super fast and we were walked to our hotel room on check in. We originally booked a two bed room but were given a three bed room when the receptionist saw we were two adults and my son they gave us a room with three beds. My only complaints about the hotel is one the beds are super hard not comfortable at all and I wish the hotel pool and spa were usable. The hotel gym could use some weights also. But other then those small complaints I am super happy with the hotel.

This was our second trip to the Keio Plaza in Feb 2015. Firstly we had issues on check in - we were given a twin room and not a double as requested, after a bit of time this was changed and we moved to another room. Due to room availability when we booked we had to split our booking, 3 nights in the Deluxe room and 1 (or 2 ?) in the premier room. What was the difference between the 2 rooms?? well the deluxe was actually bigger, the only other things that the premier (more expensive) offered were.....better towels, robes, and toiletries...that's it. Otherwise the deluxe was a far better room. A lot of the rooms have been renovated I think, but the condition is still a little worn - marks on walls, stains on carpets. We had paid for a full buffet breakfast and were given the vouchers for the make shift dining room to the right of the reception area...this is a lovely room predominantly I would say for people wanting to eat and check out fast, business people, it is also very uncomfortable to eat at the tables, which are small low coffee tables. This was not the restaurant that serves the full buffet breakfast, and the breakfast was very limited, and not good at all! and definitely not what we paid for. We have stayed here before and had the buffet breakfast in the main restaurant located on the below floor and it was very good. I explained to the reception that we had been given the wrong breakfast vouchers, but their attitude was basically "bad luck" and we were stuck with what we were given - NOT IMPRESSED. We had the buffet dinner which was very good also. All in all I actually do like this hotel, but it isn't cheap and they really need to work on their customer service, and what they offer you for the price you pay. Oh and no indoor poor - outside pool closed in winter. The location is OK but there are closer hotels to the centre.

We stayed here on 20-27 dec 2014. Xmas time in Japan. Keio is a big old hotel and have some renovated side. We stay at the premier floor so not much complaint on the clean modern room. The hotel really full of tourist from china and Indonesia. Even on the last day of our stay there's sale from Isetan on their ballroom. A very busy hotel. My biggest cons on their service maybe on their concierge department, it is together with the receptionist so seldom staff standby there so you have to wait and wait if you want to ask something. Nevertheless they try their best in communicating in proper English. It is my first in Tokyo and I would say this hotel is a very Japanese style hotel like Rihga Royal hotel. The pros of cos on the location in prime Shinjuku, shopping and eat at the very best !

In the past six years I've visited about 20 countries, both for work and leisure, and this is the absolute best hotel I stayed at in Japan, and possibly in all of my travels. When I arrived, the staff upgraded my room as a complimentary service, placing me on the 30th floor of the South Tower. I'm very sensitive to atmospheric noise, and am acutely aware of my surroundings in hotels. I didn't hear a single peep from anyone during my stay at the Keio.The bedding is amazingly comfortable and soft. Even by US standards, the room was large--by Tokyo standards, enormous. It's the only hotel in Japan where I could stand fully upright and touch my head without bumping against the ceiling (I'm 6'8"). The amenities were plentiful, and the hotel boasted a ton of restaurants (none of which I ate at--shinjuku is a 5 minute walk away). As for location, it's a short walk from Shinjuku JR station, and about a 10 minute walk from the heart of Shinjuku's neon, somewhat seedy underbelly (avoid the big guys trying to pull you into their bars.).Definitely stay here--when I return to Japan next year, I fully intend to.
user_name:
JzeroT1937
New York City, New York

review_body: Keio Plaza is truly a grand dame of Sinjuku hotels in a huge complex offering myriad room offers catering to diverse budgets. The negative reviews are probably aimed at the cheaper rooms in the old block. We stayed at a Premier suite and were truly impressed by the size, comfort, huge amenities range and traditional Japanese hospitality. Comfortable yukatas for adults and kids were standard issue with even kids amenities provided. We enjoyed many meals in the superb selection of F&B outlets and were really impressed by the excellent culinary offerings and impeccable service. Keio Plaza is connected to the Main Shinjuku Station via busy sheltered walkway and is just 5-10 min stroll right in the heart of Shinjuku. Across the back entrance of the hotel are streets of eateries, discount electronic Supermkt like BIC and pharmacies to stick up on Japanese beauty products. No-brained hotel for families because the Airport Limo bus stops here and most importantly it's a Disney hotel which offers direct complimentary shuttle to and from both Disneys! So no need to worry about rushing for public transport and you can stay till the parks closed and yet do some more shopping before catching the last shuttle back.Will probably return again for its superb location.

I am giving this huge, rather outdated hotel a "very good" rating because of the following reasons:1. The rooms are bigger than average and while definitely old, are quite clean (the carpets need changing though and the bed has seen better days)2. Well suited for foreign travellers as seen by the masses of tour groups staying at the hotel (however this also means that the lobby and common areas and the restaurants are crowded and the decibel levels are high).3. Short walk to Shinjuku Station, close to shopping and many izakayas and small restaurants around the area.4. Even if staff seemed impersonal and harried at times due to the great number of guests, they were always invariably polite and courteous.5. Lots of restaurants in the basement, good breakfast buffet and even better Japanese set breakfast. The bar on the 45th floor gave a good view and the drinks were reasonably priced.

Massive! Superb location, good bed, stylish room - had a deluxe one, which gave us access to the lounge on the 36th floor. That was really welcome and civilised. Shame the canapés kept disappearing and weren't topped up with the required frequency.The staff were efficient and helpful, and nothing was too much trouble. Good English spoken everywhere.Good selection of in-house restaurants, some a bit pricey but you can sometimes get a deal if you're a hotel guest.That said, I get what the other reviewee said about being like a train station. We were lucky and waited less than 3 mins to check in and out but observed large groups waiting for ages when we passed by.Some may consider it very brash and impersonal, others may see it as Japanese efficiency on a large scale.Loved it here. Great choice and would go back tomorrow if I could!

When you have to wait 40 minutes in a queue to check in its never a good sign. Even though we had the executive floor none of the numerous staff assisting cared to advise us to go to the cordoned off red carpet check in - which we noticed later. Then it took another 20 minutes to merely give us our room. No wonder we noticed every day an absurdly long check in at Reception.The rooms are ok - clean, 1980s and business like. But the lobby and common areas are like a train station or airport - always a hive of activity. Further, the concierge and staff treat you like a passing commuter in a train station as there is always a queue for everything i.e. Hallo, goodbye, next, ….The breakfast was minimal with minimum variety and adequate. The executive lounge had a nice view with free coffee, tiny chocolates and inedible tiny canapés. Every time we arrived at the Executive lounge we had to yet again show our Coupons as if we entering the "forbidden zone" - well it was more like the "cone of silence" in the twilight zone.If you like being treated like a commuter in a clean train station this is the hotel for you.

We traveled on march. A group of 8 adults and 2 kids. Its expensive when booked thru Agoda/ expedia. I booked directly to ther website and got our 4th night Free! if you used Mastercard/ american express. That's a huge discount! from Php 5,500/night down to Php 3,900/night per person The Pros: 1. the best location. walkin distance to subway, great food, malls and convinience store. 2. Convinient: Free shuttle to disneyland (please book early and email them early like 2 weeks before for disney shuttle) Japan's subway is crazy, if you have kids with you. You don't want that loong walk and uncertainty while looking for the right train. The tour for Mt. Fuji (sunrise tours) has also a pick up point to keio hotel. - savings + convinience Narita Limousine bus has direct drop off to this hotel. 3. helpful staffWe woke up late for breakfast. Their manager lead us to another restaurant that could accomodate us. He evan walked with us! 4. big rooms for japan standard.we booked newly renovated superior room.- comfy soft bed- no noisy aircon- rooms complete with everything you wish a hotel have - blower, bathtub, hot and cold shower, warm toilet seats, toiletries they even have pony tails ready =) cons: a little expensive: if you are into backpacking this is not for you.Japan accomodation can go as low as 800/night.

Probably one of Tokyo's biggest hotel with 2 wings and decent size rooms. Located about 15 minutes walk from Shinjuku station. Surrounded by lots of nice restaurants and shopping centres. We stayed in deluxe triple rooms. The room was far the most generous in comparison to other hotels in Tokyo. The bed was a bit hard but bearable. The hotel offer shuttle buses to both Disneyland and Disneysea. Which is convenient but unfortunately the schedule is a bit early. Do book in advance as they tend to get full early. If you book for daily tour in Tokyo from JTB, this hotel is one of the pick up point. For family travellers this hotel would be the best option due to it decent room size and shuttle bus services to theme parks. Airport limousine to both Narita and Haneda are also available near the concierge where you can purchase the ticket via the vending machine. In conclusion I will be back for sure.

We booked a triple sharing room with breakfast and found the room spacious for Japanese hotel standards. The hotel is centrally located with plenty of meal options, on one side you have mall type shops and restaurants and towards the Shinjuku station you have traditional Japanese stalls and restaurants. The hotel is just a 5-10 minute walk to the Shinjuku Metro station and also walking distance to various attractions such as the Government Metropolitan Building which allows viewing on its 45th floor from 9:30 am to 11 pm for free, Shinjuku Gyoen Garden is 20 minute walk, Yoyogi park is 30 minute walk, etc. This hotel is also a point of gathering for tours and station for a bus ride to the airport; very convenient. The hotel breakfast with the room is Continental Buffet and we liked the ambiance and the food selection (fruits and vegetables). We stayed for 7 nights and the hotel staff were all helpful, cheerful and efficient.

This is my third stay in Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo and am still impressed with it. The premier plaza is upgraded and a very outstanding feature, to me, is that there are card senors at the four corners of each lift (elevators to the Americans) for you to tap on to access the floor of your stay.The staff is ever helpful and in my case I had to leave on the morning of the Tokyo Marathon and they advised me well so that I would not be caught in any jam.This hotel is always my choice of stay in Tokyo as the airport bus stops right at its door step and its location is very convenient for food and shopping.

Have stayed two nights at the hotel as it was tight in with the flight package. We had arrived very early in the morning and just as expected, the hotel can only allow us to deposit our luggages with them till our room is ready. Luckily we were prepared for that and gone ahead to visit Yushima Tenmangu Shrine for their plum flowers blossoms festival. Most places were still too early to catch the blossoms till late Mar, but sure glad we made it to see the full blossoms at the shrine.Upon returned to the hotel around noon, surprisingly the front desk informed that our room was ready for check-in. The room is clean, spacious and bright with two queen size beds and a small round table with arm chairs. Only problem was the weather was still considered late winter, only heating was available in the room. So the room was a bit warm even when we lowered the room temperature to lowest at 15 degree. The staff advised us to off it totally so that the room can be cooler by itself but ended up too stuffy due to lack of ventilation. Luckily the housekeeping staff was able to get us a portable fan upon request, thus that ended up well for us :) Surprisingly no mineral water nor tea/coffee bags provided, otherwise, location and service of the hotel are really ideal for exploring Tokyo and even to Hakone since the Odakyu express train service centre is near to Shinjuku Station too.Lots of shopping malls and restaurants nearby. If you have a lot of luggages, may take the airport limousine bus at ¥3100/pax/way, the bus will drop you off directly at the hotel from Narita Airport.

Situated in the middle of Shinjuku, and easy walking distance to the subway station, it's a great location. Fantastic shopping nearby, and plenty of eating options reasonably priced.I left my ipad behind, and the staff were very helpful and managed to courier it back to me before I left Japan. Recommended, I'd happily stay there again.
user_name:
Ian R
Wellington, Wellington, New Zealand

review_body: The location is great and staffs are nice, helpful and efficiency. I stayed in plaza premier floor, the view is good and room design is modern and comfortable. Further, the room size is biggest enough for two persons. The room package included the free access to the club lounge and free wifi. Highly recommend to stay there.

I stayed at this property with my partner for over a week in September 2014.The location is fantastic as it is within 10mins walking distance of the Shinjuku JR rail station.While the rooms are not much to look at, they are extremely clean and tidy. The views you get from staying in the tower are fantastic.There is a really good selection of restaurants in the lower floors - but a suggestion if you are having breakfast at the hotel is to get there early (06:00am) if you don't want to have to line up to get at table.What really makes this a great hotel is the staff - they are amazing. For example, we were travelling to Kyoto for a week and I didn't want to have to lug around two suitcases. The concierge stored by second suitcase for the time we were in Kyoto and then organised airport transfers for us for when we returned to Tokyo to collect our bags and return to the airport.

If you looking for a smaller intimate hotel then this is not it. As per previous reviews this hotel has loads of group tours staying here so there are often loads of suitcases and guests in the lobby. If you want a hotel that has spacious, clean modern rooms, with staff that are efficient and situated near Shinjuku station then this is it. It is an easy limousine bus drive from the airport and a few minutes walk from Shinjuku station. I had breakfast in the club lounge which had a good variety served buffet. It's a gorgeous room with a view outside. I stayed in the main tower in a renovated room. No wifi in Lobby. Only room.I would definitely return.

Stayed here before the Tokyo Marathon which made my experience 0% hassle, as the starting line is just across the street at the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (which by the way is a great place to check out for free to view the skyline of Tokyo by day or night!)Hotel staff is very kind and helpful, and transportation is easy from this hotel. Taxis are waiting at the front, and the Airport Limousine Bus also drops and picks up directly from the hotel. If you venture a short walk, you can also find the subway station pretty easily if that is more your style.Rooms are comfortable enough. The hotel itself has about 7 different restaurants to choose from. I was satisfied with all of them during my stay. TRY the sushi on the 7th floor! It was a fun and tasty experience I will never forget.Which also reminds me...hotel also has a fitness room on 7th floor as well.Also, convenience store and souvenir shops below lobby.All of these things made for a very relaxed and easy stay in one of my first times visiting a foreign country.

After looking at the hotel website, I thought it was going to me more than it actually was. The best service is from the doorman... from there it goes down hill pretty quickly. There are literally dozens of chairs lined up in the reservation lobby for people to sit in while waiting to get registered into the hotel. (Advise to the hotel: get rid of the chairs and get more people to register guests... people want to get in their room, not wait in your lobby.) As for the rest of the hotel lobby, there are only a couple of couches. The room itself was clean but worn. Being a frequent flier to Tokyo, I have come to expect more from a Japanese hotel, particularly one in this price range. The shining star of this hotel is the restaurants. Suggest you try the shabby-shabu restaurant which is pricy but well worth it with excellent food and service.

We stayed 4 nights for a group of 14 pax. What I liked about this was the location, it's on the "quieter" side of shinjuku, but easily accessible on street level or through the series of connected walkways. Room size was ok and views on the higher floors are good. The landlord is that it is opposite the metropolitan government building so if you get lost, just lookout for the signposts!Not sure if I would stay here again as I'd like to review other hotels in the area. Plus point is that is has an airport limo that stops here. Downside is that this is a really HUGE and busy hotel. I suspect it's very popular with tour group tourists/westerners/south East Asians as I rarely saw local visitors staying here.

Myself and 3 friends stayed at this hotel on our first ever visit to Japan. I really think we struck it lucky with staying here, the location is the best thing about this behemoth of a hotel, it was absolutely perfect, it was almost like living on top of Shinjuku but without the noise of the trains! The views we had were incredible, the rooms were spotless and the toilets comfortable(and western!) All we knew when going to Japan was that we needed to be near the Yamonte loop, Shinjuku station though (the busiest train station in the world) is connected to everything so being so close made the holiday so much easier. There's even a delightful bakery we would stop by every morning. Stay here, you'll have no problems and the location will be great, hopefully you'll get a more than reasonable price like we did :)

Keio Plaza was a positive experience. Very friendly staff, good restaurants and spacy lobby areas. The scenery is huge from the high-up rooms and the top floor restaurants. The room was cosy and neat. Good pillows. The location is very good in the middle of Shinjuku ja very close to the metro and Shijuku railway station. A lot of small restaurants of all kind nearby.

the second time stay. Very convenient location, close to Shinjuku station west exit, though it would be better if there were courtesy bus service to the station. Convenient to Nishi-shinjuku area restaurants most of which are very reasonable. Breakfast buffet in the hotel is good. The hotel is nearly 50yrs old, but well refurbished. Good room service and house keeping.

Many good hotels in Tokyo but the Keio has been my " home away from home" for many years.The staff is great and the restaurants and bars are superior.Shinjuku is a bustling place and the hotel is smack in the middle.Shinjuku train station is within walking distance.

I lived in Japan in the late 80's, early 90's - at that time the Keio Plaza was one of the premier hotels in Tokyo. Today it is still a quality hotel, but in terms of style and service it is a bit old-school. We stayed here for several nights in November of 2014. In the past couple years (I know this by looking at their website and by information from my agent) they have updated the lobby VIP breakfast lounge, many of the rooms and the VIP guest lounge where you can enjoy a drink at the end of the day. The main lobby however, is still very dated and while the service is very good, it is a bit formal - no one is very quick to smile (quite different from the other places we stayed on this trip). The service was much warmer at the VIP Breakfast area and VIP Cocktail Lounge. We were fortunate that our agent had arranged for us to be checked in at the premier service desk, which allowed us to avoid the long lines of tourist groups checking in/out at the main desk. The location is very convenient - one of the first stops on the limousine bus shuttle from the airport and very convenient to Shinjuku Station - Just a couple blocks. Overall our stay here was fine.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza Premium Suite for business the other week and was blown away by the quality of the room and service. I would come back here to enjoy the great ambiance and great food in the restaurants.

We have been here in the beginning and at the end of our Hokkaido photography trip at the end of December 2014. This big Hotel is very conveniently placed close to Shinjuku Station with many shops and restaurant, just in a short walk. The Hotel is huge with many restaurant. If you can afford the highest floor, there is a beautiful panorama of the city. Staff people are very kind and helpful (well, you are in Japan!) and everything is clean and in good order.

The hotel is a bit outdated though it was one of the best in the 80s and the room is smaller than expected ; it is also a bit far from Shinjuku Station. Service is ok but is a very busy hotel. There are more new hotels near the station. As they are so busy the bell boy forgot what we requested him to do while busy handling others. Also when we depart and need to buy the shuttle bus tickets, he forgets to issue tickets to us but collected our bus fares with a receipt only... We only realised we need the tickets when the driver asked for it . Overall this is an ok hotel but seems can't upkeep with the latest new development. Also for the breakfast buffet ; the choices of food is also limited.

Having stayed at the Keio Plaza for many times, we had no hesitation in coming back. The airport limousine bus stops at the hotel so there is no problem accessing the airport. Close to Shinjuku station and there are no shortage of shops and restaurants to choose from.Only thing is over the years it seems like the rooms are getting quite tired and even though we stayed at one of the renovated "Luxe" rooms, it really didn't feel very luxurious at all. Although the room is very big for a Japanese hotel and cleanliness is top notch.

My husband and I stayed at the Keio Plaza for 4 nights. We booked the Premiere Plaza Room which is definitely worth spending a few extra dollars on. The room was very nice and big (comparable to a 4 star hotel). It was clean, looked like the photos, and had a beautiful view. It had black out shades so you could easily sleep in, great room amenities (2 complimentary water bottles each night, complimentary tooth brushes, razors, etc.) and a bath tub. It was also great because it came with access to their Lux Lounge which has complimentary drinks and light appetizers. We loved this! The hotel staff was very friendly. We don't like doing tours and prefer exploring cities on our own and the hotel staff gave us very easy to follow directions. It is very simple to get around, as the train and subway station is within walking distance. The trains and subways are much cleaner than you see in other cities. We went to Harajuku, Shibuya, and Asakusa all very easily from our hotel location. The hotel does have several dining options, but I would recommend eating outside the hotel. We did the breakfast buffet here one day and then did the breakfast buffet the Park Hyatt another, and I thought the Park Hyatt's breakfast was much better. However, my husband did like the Japanese food selections at the buffet at Keio Plaza. There are so many great dining options near by and I recommend looking on tripadvisor to see good options in the area (we ate amazing sushi at a local spot that was walking distance).. The hotel lobby was happening, which I found to be a plus. The Park Hyatt hotel, which we also visited, while beautiful and more luxurious, was too quiet for my taste and I thought it was weird that there weren't many people in the lobby area. I also think the location of Keio Plaza is better. One negative I want to mention - our flight home was later in the day and the front desk was not willing to give a late checkout without paying extra money. Normal check out was 11am. It wasn't that they didn't have the availability, but the agent said it wasn't their policy to give late checkout without you paying. Not even 30 minutes or an hour! It wasn't a big deal, but they should consider changing this. I would recommend this hotel to anyone as long as you book the Premiere Plaza rooms. I would come back and recommend it to friends.

Excellent hotel .Great central location .Hotel is a 5 Star rating in my eyes .I am currently staying Premier Plaza Room 37 th Floor .Fantastic views very large room .Staff are of a high standard including the room cleaners who are so polite and helpful .Can not fault this hotel in anyway .I have read reviews of being dated .? They must be staying at some other hotel or they are use to a brand new hotel .It is not dated in my eyes .I defenatly will be returning to Tokyo and to this Hotel again ..

Huge hotel. Old but very well maintained.My room looked as if I was the first one to stay there. Spotless. Cleanest hotel I have ever stayed. Period.The room was quite big compared to other Japanese hotels.The rates, like many big hotels in Japan are super pricey but I was on business, luckily...Will not pay for this hotel if I am traveling for holiday.No breakfast in my stay. Cannot comment.I am just impressed by the cleanliness.Of course, great automatic heated toilet seats and I liked the Shiseido face cleanser in the toilet.Can easily walk to the busy Shinjuku shopping area. Lots of food available. Plenty of 24 hr convenience stores.If you go down to the basement level, you can "escape" through the back into a subway walk all the way to the Shinjuku train station. Good to know this if it rains.Most staff can understand English. Courteous and polite.No issues at all.If I am here on business, no hesitation to stay here again but I may not want to fork out my own money to stay here !

No shortage of Japanese courtesy and the large variety of in house dining options available make the Keio Plaza good for the business traveller. But it is starting to look and feel a little dated, despite some of the rooms having had a makeover in the last couple of years (I've been staying there for over ten now) and better value for the tourist is available elsewhere.
user_location: Henley on Thames, null, United Kingdom
user_name:
TimboNagasaki
Henley on Thames, null, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed here for 3 nights whilst on a business trip to Tokyo and booked a Plaza BIZ Plus Room. The room was a good size and the bathroom was too, with a decent selection of toiletries available. The internet access was good. The one downside was the lack of English speaking TV channels. The staff are all very polite, helpful and keen to please you. The majority of staff speak and understand English. The Hotel is huge (You can easily get lost!) and very impersonal, but it's in good condition. There are a variety of different restaurants to choose from, although they are all quite expensive. The breakfast offered at the Hotel is average. There are choices - eggs/bacon, fruit, cereal, cheese/meat and breads - but these are limited compared to other Hotels I've stayed at in the region and the quality is just ok.

From the start the hotel has people at every step performing services the hotel thinks are important to make they upscale. But they are not. My reservation included entrance to a executive lounge. Not much but bad wine, beer and pretzels .The bathroom was small and hard to get around in even for one. The room itself was nothing to write home about. The food was overpriced for what you got. For example, a $20 dollar burger look as if it came from Mac Donalds.

Huge hotel with very busy atmosphere, lots of tourist groups. Location is quite good not far from the shinjuku station. Lots of nice restaurants around. Room was clean, nice and comfortable. .. And very beautiful view to Mount Fuji. Breakfast restaurant were very busy around 9 but before 6am there were not much rush.

We stayed here with our three teenage boys. It is a well presented hotel where the people are pleasant and professional. It is located above the massive Shinjuku station so is very central. All you need is within easy walking distance. Has free shuttle to Disney resorts.

in Japan, good and caring service manner is not anything special. Keio Plaza has been very experience in serving foreign tourist and established efficient logistic while maintaining the good service. When we stepped in the hotel, there is a long queue for check in. The staff immediately pick up your cases, and give you a number tag when queuing. There are quite a number of check-in counters that you need not to wait long. They speaks good English. After check-in, they will call the staff and pass them your luggage tag and you will be escorted to your room. Bad thing is it is so popular that many mainland China visitors choose to stay there also.The room size is good also and we get a room with Mt. Fuji view.So bad we arrive late and leave early in the morning for a local tour.The breakfast is good as well.

We stayed there 9 days in January. Adjoining rooms were excellent ie. good size (better than other hotels in Tokyo we have tried); there is wifi etc. The only problem (a minor one) I feel is that perhaps because of the large size of the hotel they were slow to respond to some issues raised eg. initially there was difficulty getting into their wifi system. When informed the response we got was "Stand in the corridor..the reception is stronger there"(?!). When one of the toilets appeared to come with an unpleasant odor, their solution was to send someone up with a spray of fragrance. However if all goes well with your room then this hotel is very good because of its location in Shinjuku. Do use the dedicated hotel bus service from Haneda airport both to and fro the Keio Plaza Hotel. I cannot recommend enough the hotel staff service regards this bus service to Haneda. They take over completely from you ...wonderful!

Brilliant hotel in a great spot so close to the station. Rooms are very spacious (unusual for Tokyo) and the staff could not be any better. We are a family of 5 so we had 2 rooms next to one another. There is undercover access to the Shinjuku station which is fantastic. If you are travelling to Hakuba there is a direct train (limited express) from Shinjuku to Hakuba station that does not require any changes that leaves during the ski season at 7.30 am daily. This is perfect with kids and luggage also very scenic!

Excellent hotel for both business and leasure trips.The plus: It's within walking distance from the Shinjuku station, from where you can take a direct express train to Narita, hence avoiding traffic with the bus.

Stayed for a week in mid Jan with my wife and three children. We had 2 adjoining rooms in the south tower and although most things went smoothly and we had plenty of room, we were a little disappointed with the "dated" nature of the furnishings in the room and our bed was one of the most uncomfortable I have ever slept on. Restaurants and bars in the hotel are nice but way over the top expensive. Head across the road or up toward the station for some more options.Staff were helpful when it came to airport transfers and theres a free bus to Disneyland.

Stayed at that the hotel last Dec again. Every year in Dec when I visit Tokyo, I will book to stay at there, but I can feel the service at the check in counter is very lacking. Staff were not friendly and is very unlike the Japanese service which I had experienced in hotels located in other parts of a Japan. The concierge almost book me on a wrong time for my departure limousine to the airport.Luckily, I was quick to realize the fault, otherwise, I would have taken a wrong route to Haneda instead of Narita. I must say the rooms are big and location is indeed a plus factor which makes me choose the hotel.

I loved the hotel, the view was really amazing (got the chance to see Fuji mountain from my room), rooms are comfortable and clean, WiFi is available. I liked the variety of options in breakfast, and the service was really nice. I also liked the great consideration of the guest culture & religion as they indicated Qibla direction in our room without having to ask about that!
user_location: Emirate of Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
user_name:
Raghas127
Emirate of Sharjah, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Stayed in December with family in the renovated Superior rm, free wi-fi. Room was very clean and I was allergic to dust. I was given to a room on 33 floor with good city view and part Mt Fuji view (white cone top) on a clear morning ! Hotel is big, check out is quite fast .Limousine service to airport is fast but it is our own responsibility to check own flight and bus timing as the staff may be clueless if you have a tight time allowance to catch a plane.walk to ShinjukuJR is not really near - about 13 to 14min . But lots of eating houses around the area, a good 7-11 at a corner too. Generally a clean and comfy stay, just a but pricey - but this is TOKYO !

Great home away from home. All services were performed as you would expect. Room was cleaned daily. Not one negative thing to say. Plenty of food, drink, and entertainment options nearby, plus walking around is safe. The plaza and the park behind were a great way to stretch the legs instead of sitting inside.

I have spent 4 weeks at Keio Plaza now. The hotel has a great location in Shunjuku, is well connected via the subway and buses. There is a direct bus from Narita and Haneda to the hotel (Airport Limousine). The staff speaks decent english and communication has never been a problem so far. Great room service and quick check-in/check-out. Hotel has some restaurants but there is only one vegetarian sandwich option at Jurin (one of their 24-hr restaurants).

Great location - walking distance to the alleyway bars + restaurants of Shinjuku. Directly opposite the Tokyo Metropolitan Governent Buildings. Walking about 5 minutes in underground arcade to Shinjuku station, with lots of food and cute shops. Cool retro bar on the top floor with happy hour drinks. Lovely spacious rooms, free newspaper, quiet, nice toiletries.

I accompanied my wife for her business trip to see wonderful Tokyo. The staff was perfect and kind as Japanese people are.The location was not city center, but there was a very big metro and train station next to the hotel, you can go anywhere using it. And was this spectacular view over Tokyo, whether you are on Main Tower or South Tower you will see Tokyo city or Fuji mountain. So if room size matters for you. The rooms are so big, about 30 square meters, which is like 5 times a French hotel room.And wifi, the wifi was every where and very fast.Definitely worth the trip and the price.Thank you again to all Keio staff.

Rooms were clean but quite dated. I wouldn't stay there again if i ever went back to Tokyo but location is central and transport links were very good and punctual.Didn't eat at the hotel as nice as it looked it was pricey compared to other places

My family and I have stayed in Keio Plaza for the third times. The first and second time we came with the tourist agency, so we have to stay at the deluxe room. In the third time, we traveled ourselves and came for the Plaza Premiere room in the main tower. We found that the room is quite nice and new. All room amenities are complete and comfortable. My parent stayed in the king bedroom which is spacious and comfortable.The location is superb. I can walk to Shinjuku with around 5-10 minutes distance. Have convenient store and small shop around the corner.Breakfast is nice. Have around 3-4 choices of restaurants. We love Kagari which is the Japanese one. The food is quite nice and traditional Japanese. However, we found that the choice of breakfast at Jurin (the western one) is few and not as good as Kagari or the Chinese one. Look forward to go back to Keio Plaza again!

Our first impression is that the room was a little outdated (kind of a 70's hotel room). Once we got used to it we got comfortable and even thought it had its charm. It was super clean. The hotel is close to Shinjuku station and Tochomae station you can take virtually any train line (JR, Keio etc)Our only complaint is that with with our jet lag we would get VERY hungry at weird times and ordered room service a coupe of times. It is definitely expensive and food is average. (I guess it gets expensive as there are a bunch of taxes and service charges they have to squeeze in, plus its a huge hotel).Anyway, At the end of our stay we discovered a convenient western breakfast spot "Royal Host" it's cheap and a few blocks away. Also if you go into the Keio little mall theres a food court with great reasonably priced cheap eats. Overall the hotel was convenient and the staff is nice and we had really good service. Would recommend to stay here.
user_name:
Paulina S
New York City, New York

review_body: My Husband and I were on our honeymoon in Tokyo and unfortunately our travel agent mixed up our room request and we were put in the old tower. When we told the front desk of the mix up - although it was not the fault of Keio Plaza, they upgraded us to the premier suites. (We did pay a charge, understandably, which we hope and are in the process of working out with Flight Centre).The Premier suite was spacious, modern and well-equipped. There are many great restaurants in Keio Plaza to enjoy. The location is central and Shinjuku Station is a hub so it's easy to zip around Tokyo on the train.

Heart of the city easy access to any part. Rooms are clean and I imagine they all have nice views. Lots of restaurants to choose from. Good for Americans I recommend this location. Got a deal with Amex one night free. The place is big and there are little shops inside. The buffet is good and modest for Tokyo standards.

Stopped here for 3 nights as part of a cruise & stay hotel.Service and check in was slick, as you'd expect from this class of hotel.Room was spacious, nicely appointed. All you could need in the bathroom. All spotlessly clean.Tea and bottled water provided daily, good wifi signal.Breakfast had a good range of food, both European and oriental, but there were long queues to get into the restaurants if you are later than 7am. There's a Starbucks 5 mins walk away if you only want coffee and a bun.The main shopping and electronics area of Shinjuku is only 10 mins walk away.

My family and I stayed in Tokyo for 3 days. We stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel for 2 nights and 3 days before making our way to Kyoto. I had a print out of the map to get to the hotel and still we got lost. The directions on the hotel website are unclear for foreigners. It simply said head west to Keio plaza hotel from Shinjuku station. At the guard gate, a friendly Japanese man approached us and offered to take us to the hotel. Without help from locals or the aid of google maps we wouldn't be able to locate the hotel. Besides the obstacle of getting to the hotel in the first place, the overall stay in the hotel was lovely.

This is the worst hotel I have ever stayed. I was on a 3-day trip with my family. At 2pm, they didn't have the room ready, the front said it will be ready in an hour, but they never did. When I confronted them about the room, it was so obvious that they DID NOT PREPARE THE ROOM AT ALL. We had to wait there for another hour for the "manager" Mr. Imai do all the paperwork. If they had the room cleaned and ready, at least they can send us up first, but NO. We had to be there wait for almost another hour. The front desk girl was also be unhelpful, except for the fake smile that they always put on.The front desk is the most inefficient, rude (especially when they say they will help, but they don't), and please stop put on fake smiles. It only makes the services seems much worse. Typical Japanese robotic service. Smiles and apologies, but obviously there were NO HEART and NO ACTION to help out the guests. Worst hotel ever!

We booked a Plaza BIZ Plus room at the main tower and was pleasantly upgraded to a Plaza Premier Double room on 39 floor. The room was nice, spacious and very comfortable. The king size bed was very comfortable. The room had a good view. The bathroom was comfortable and spacious by Tokyo standards and had nice Occitane toiletries. The room had all the nice mod cons: Nespresso machine, a great couch in front of bed, choice of yukata and buttoned down bathrobes, a nice make up table outside the bathroom. Guests enjoyed a good 10% for meals at the hotel restaurants. The hotel is a short walk from Shinjuku station. Airport limousine buses do a pick up from the hotel to Narita or Haneda. Overall we had a great and comfortable stay.

My husband and I booked a Luxe Queen room (grantee non-smoking), our room was on the 30th floor in the south tower, window facing the Government building. The deco is modern and cozy, they even have air purifier/humidifier in the room. Bed and Linens are both very comfortable. Wifi is fast and reliable. Two complimentary bottles of water everyday and organic coffee and a variety of tea. (Hot water Kettle in the room) Check-in was a breeze, the bell boy guided us up to our room, he was really pleasant and made us feel very welcomed. We took advantage of the pre-fix meal offered by their restaurant for the customers staying at the hotel only. We went to Kagari (Japanese restaurant) and Jurin (western), both were very nice and the waiter/waitress speak English very well too. We liked the location very much, easy access to everything. It takes about 5 mins walk to the Shinjuku station if you walk fast, normal pace will be around 8 mins tops! The housekeeping does a superb job! Its so nice to come back to the hotel neat and clean everyday! There is a convenience store inside the hotel too, but if you want big bottle of waters, outside convenience stores are still slight cheaper. All in all, highly recommended. Thank you Keio Plaza for contributing such goodness to our wonderful Tokyo trip.

Location: Near Shinjuku shopping area but still have to walk a distance (1km) to the main shopping area.Note: This hotel catered more to BIG tourist groups.Check in: Was a nightmare. Perhaps due to peak season. It's like Las Vegas type of check in with long queues. When we arrived some rooms are not ready yet.Room: We booked a triple sharing (2 adult + 1 child). Was big enough to be comfortable for 3 persons. Room is outdated but equipped with necessary ammenities like toothbrush, soap, shampoo and slippers. Shower pressure is not good! Cleanliness not too good. Once I found a dirty towel hanging behind the bath door!!Free WIFI.Breakfast: Nightmare as well! Have to get up early to QUEUE (for 30 minutes!!).Pros: There's convenient store below and free disney shuttle bus which one has to book in advance.Check out: Was fast.

Over rated and very expense not worth the price. We paid for a superior room $400.00, not a very friendly hotel by the Japanese standards. I will not recommend this hotel, there are other hotels in the area that has better service.

We are family of 5 and booked through booking.com. We arrived early morning and the hotel happily stored our luggage. Our requests for 2 superior rooms (main tower) on the same floor was fulfilled (although not adjacent we used the internal phone to communicate.) The rooms were spacious - especially the double, clean, and had all the nice touches.We only requested assistance with travel info a few times & the staff were helpful. The location, Shinjuku was convenient- to airport, tokyo sightseeing & Disneyland. We had breakfast at surrounding coffee shops. There is a number to choose from. I'd recommend & return again to Keio plaza.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is about equivalent to a 4 star hotel in Australia. It cost us abut $400 p/n for a superior room (no breakfast) in the South Tower over the New Year period. We were on the 19th floor and had a view of Mt Fuji from our room. The room was of a normal size, therefore spacious by Japanese standards. We booked directly via emails with the hotel, which required no deposit. Mastercard authorisation was taken on arrival at hotel.It is clean and quiet, staff are professional and it is well located for sightseeing and shopping in Tokyo. Meals in the hotel are prohibitively expensive, but there is no shortage of cheap ramen and yakitori places in the surrounding streets or restaurants in Shinjuku in general. It has it's own convenience store in the basement.It is connected to Shinjuku train station by an underground passage (catch a NEX from Narita right to Shinjuku station), and has a metro stop right at the back door too. If you have done some research and decided that you want to stay in Shinjuku, then the Keio Plaza makes an excellent home base.

I've stayed in Keio Plaza Hotel in December 2014. I made reservation for the renovated rooms as I have stayed in the non renovated room before and I would like to experience different room. When I arrived there, I was given the non renovated room. I went to the front desk and I told them that my room was not the renovated room and I had booking for the renovated rooms. The front desk replied to me that this was the room that I had paid for. I tried to explain to them again that I had made reservation for the renovated room and paid more for the upgrade. They then replied to me that my room was slightly renovated room. The funny thing is that the hotel website displayed the room photographs and they were clearly labeled. The room that I'd gotten was not the renovated room and they did not have the slightly renovated room photo put on the website.I was surprised that hotel would use the word slightly renovated room. When the hotel website put on a photo of the renovated room and they accepted reservation for the renovated room, the guest would expect the renovated room and not the slightly renovated room. This experience made me wonder how many type of rooms does Keio has for the Superior Rooms? The renovated, slightly renovated, not renovated only or more? That would certainly confuses the hotel guests.

Although our stay at this hotel was very pleasant, as it was clean and run efficiently, it was nothing special. Everything ran like clockwork, but it was all very mechanical and robotic. There was nothing about our stay at The Kieo Plaza that would make us go "Wow! That was great!". One of the annoying things about the hotel is that it was extremely crowded, and every food outlet would be full at all times, so we couldn't spontaneously go to one of the outlets for a meal or coffee. They were full even outside of meal times, so it was impossible to even just to go for a cup of coffee to one of the cafes on the lobby level. It seems to be a very popular hotel for locals as well as tourists. So although breakfast was included in our stay, every single outlet that served breakfast would be full from very early, and we would have to queue up every morning. On the first morning we were there, we didn't expect this, so ended up rushing through breakfast when we finally got our table, so that we could be at our meetings on time. So from the next morning, we knew to go down 45 minutes earlier than we normally would. Everything is very clean, efficient and runs like clockwork, The staff are efficient. But the hotel lacks character, and is just too crowded. I'd probably try somewhere else next time, but still, it's definitely not a bad hotel, and we had no bad experiences there.

I have been again at Keio Plaza after several years and I have found the same efficency and cortesy of my last visit. It is perfectly located near the Shinjuku station from where you can reach every place in Tokyo. Good stay and if the opportunity I will be back again there

My family stayed in 2 Plaza Premier Rooms. We were only here a week ago but couldn't remember anything much nice to say.Memory 1: Very busy hotel with a daily crowded lobby which felt like we were in a middle of a conference meeting coffee break... where everybody gathers outside to chat and have their drinks & snacks.Memory 2: Had one breakfast inside the restaurant beside the front desk lobby. Food was poor and very limited for the price I paid for the premier rooms. It was further ruined when I barely sat down at 9:20am when Mr. Satoh approached to inform me that last order is 9:30am. I replied that it's a buffet so everything should be there and I don't need to order anything. He returned 20 minutes later to tell me that they will clean up soon. That was when I raised my voice and told him that I understood him the first time and to stop bothering me during my meal! My wife with a few other hotel guests walked in that time and they were also reminded that breakfast is almost over. How can this person be so inconsiderate and unwelcoming?!Memory 3: We were probably given renovated rooms because they were clean and nice. With regards to location, we always had to take the taxi to go to the major shopping areas. It was just too far and cold to walk.Overall, I will not return to this hotel.

I traveled with my mum, so we booked a twin room in this hotel. The room was very clean with a decent size. The location was great, with multiple metro stations and shops near by. In the hotel itself, there are lots of restaurants and a convenient store. The service was also great. Free speedy WiFi in your room and very friendly staff. Really enjoyed our stay and will definitely recommend it to others.

The size of the rooms were nice. I wasn't expecting that it was going to be bigger than expected. Service was excellent, they have maps of all kinds for you to be able to go around. They even have a map for church and schedules. Near shinjuku station so it's so easy to get around. Fitness gym was nice too. Clean and organized, towels and water dispenser is ready for guests. Will recommend this to all. :)

We booked this hotel on a recent family holiday, largely based on location. Shinjuku is a great area to stay. Lots of shops and restaurants around. Restaurants from the very cheap to the very expensive. But lots and lots of choices. The hotel is less than 10 minutes walk from the train station which is very handy. When we first arrived in the hotel, we were surprised at how upmarket it looked compared to the price we paid, and the prices of other high end hotels in Tokyo. We honestly didn't expect something so nice.We stayed in the south tower. The rooms were a little dated, but clean and comfortable. We loved the bathrooms with the usual heated toilets - a special treat in winter.Overall very happy with the hotel.

Picked this hotel mainly because of the good reviews and the proximity to the Shinjuku JR station. I would stay there again. Spacious rooms and the beds were wonderful! We were in the Main tower on the 34th floor. Fitness center on the 7th. Free WiFi in your room. Friendly staff and beautiful hotel. This was my first stop on this trip to Toyko and I didn't want a hassle getting to the hotel from Narita. There were 2 options to get there - one by bus which stopped a little nearer the hotel and the other was the Narita Express which is still very close but getting in and out of a station can be difficult. I chose the JR to Shinjuku station because it was 1500 Yen and less time to get there vs the bus which drops you off a bit closer, but 3000 Yen. Be sure to take the West exit of Shinjuku if you choose the train.

I traveled with my wife, spent 4 days in this Hotel. The location near Shinjuku station, you can walk around 200 m from Shinjuku station to reach this hotel. Very strategic location.The staff is friendly and helpful. The room is OK, comfortable enough.For breakfast only have western menu, I wish they provide Japanese food :). There was always same menu for 4 days.Overall I feel K, comfortable with this hotel.

Spent 10 days at this Hotel. Was there alone for 2 days in the Main tower, then 8 in the South Tower. Rooms were fine and the staff was accommodating. Breakfast time is very busy. Found a nice restaurant (Royal Host) just north of the Hotel. Inexpensive and good breakfast. Don't waste your time or money on the hotel breakfast buffet.All in all, I would recommend this hotel.

I travelled in a group of 15 (three families) and recommended to stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel (to the other families that travelled with me), as I had stayed there with my family during my last trip in 2008. With any review there are positives and negatives and our stay was mostly positives and I would stay at Keio Plaza Hotel again but would do a little research on the rooms before booking.This time our stay was for 7 nights, we booked a total of 5 rooms. We were able to have two double beds with a roller-away in four of the rooms, so we were able to accommodate 3 persons and even 4 in one of the rooms. The hotel rooms are been updated at the moment, so ensure you request for a recently renovated room. One family flew in earlier from Sydney, booked separately at the hotel and was given a room on the Main tower on floor 36 (they were happy with their room and had done their research to request for the Main tower and floor 36 above). The rest of the family (11) flew in later that evening and was given the South wing on floor 15. The rooms on our first night on South, floor 15 had not been updated and we were quite disappointed, the rooms felt like we were back in 2008, aircon did not even operate, so we requested better rooms which the hotel staff provided for on South, floor 23 for the remaining 6 nights. Would certainly ask for upgraded rooms whether Main or South Tower. Upgraded rooms were alot better, but tv was small surprisingly for a country known for electronics, phone and amenities were also what you would expect of a lower rated hotel. Beds and pillows firm.Never-the less, staff was very helpful from room cleaning, to concierge, bell captain to organising airport transfers. We experienced a Japanese tea ceremony at the Hotel, which was lovely, and believe the Hotel is looking at introducing more cultural events for hotel guest.Can't beat location, central to many shops, restaurants, buses and train lines, which we found easy to get around the city of Tokyo.The Hotel is a few minutes walk to convenience stores and many restaurants that opened late, so this was handy although the hotel had many restaurants to choose from.The limousine Bus drops off in front of hotel and picks up from hotel from/to Narita as well as to/from Haneda, You can also organise a direct bus to Disney Land. You can't beat that for convenience right to Hotel, without organising extra transport to pickup/drop off point.Definitely do your research, ask for the upgraded rooms. But Keio Plaza Hotel is ideally located.
