user_location: Port Moresby, National Capital, Papua New Guinea
user_name:
558BrianC
Port Moresby, National Capital, Papua New Guinea

review_body: Rooms are spacious and comfortable. Beds definitely on the firm side. Hotel is large but runs very efficiently. Staff friendly and helpful. Good location a few minutes walk from Shinjuku station and next to subway.

Stayed 2 nights in a 4-bedded renovated room in South Tower. Room is spacious with view of Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building and glimpse of Mt Fuji in the background. Generally clean and bed was very comfortable with firm mattress.There was a queue during check-in, took a while but staff are professional. It is a huge hotel with many business and large group guests so the lobby has high human traffic. In-room Wifi connection was ok although had to re-login at times. About 5 mins walk along covered link to Shinjuku JR station.Overall a top quality hotel in a good location.

Hotel Keio Plaza is a great 4.5 star hotel with over 22 restaurants and bars. It is close to Shinjuku Japan Rail subway. The rooms are well appointed with bath and shower over the bath, sleeping accommodation is excellent, beds are comfortable and the rooms well presented and maintained.For breakfast on our first morning, we chose to visit the restaurant on 24th level. Fantastic 270 degree view of the city and good service from the staff. The range of food, however is eclipsed by the much larger restaurant on level 2. It is called The Grand Buffet, and it's range and choices of food is spectacular! If your choice of menu cannot be found amid the 22+ restaurants, there is a further extensive range of traditional Japanese and other Eastern and Western restaurants, including McDonalds and Subway, and a wonderful Udon Noodle Bar. The food is good, and the prices, inexpensive! If you have never tried Japanese Udon noodle, go and be pleasantly surprised!Our stay at the Keiko Plaza was very enjoyable and a Gold Star to a young Russian trainee, who was always around when we were seeking assistance. Brian Richardson, Adelaide, Australia,

What a view. South tower 27th floor and My Fuji is so clear. Great large spacious room with clean linen and well appointed amenities. Shisedo products and everything in the bathroom you could want. Staff friendly and helpful. We'll located next to Shinjuku train station. Ask for south tower facing west as rooms are newly renovated.

Hotel is very conveniently located , the JR & Tokyo Metro ( Shinjuku Station) are just 5 min by walk. The hotel rooms are quite good. Hotel staff is very helpful & patient. We did most of our sight seeing using our JR pass & location of the hotel was ideal for travel by JR or Tokyo metro. The most famous Robot restaurant is 10-15 min walk from the hotel. Actually they are connected by a subway. We had left our bag at Robot restaurant after the show & realized it only after we got back to the hotel, so we asked the Manager in charge to help us & they were so helpful in calling the robot restaurant & finding our bag. I think generally speaking the people of Japan are very nice & helpful. A wonderful experience. Great value for money too. We had opted for no breakfast & we did not have problem as there are many convenience stores close by & the hotel has its bakery !

First time this hotel, try 2 different before.We used to take rail to Shinuku, but this time we took coach which can stopped at the front of the hotel. Save a lot energy if you have heavy luggage. You may not heavy at the beginning but sure after few days of shopping :) This is rated 5 Star Hotel and it really worth the title and good value for money. My package included breakfast which have 4 choices, 2 for buffet and 1 American and 1 Japanese style. Trust me, go for "Glass Court" and you will understand what I mean...The bed is very comfort, good heating system, first time we have in-house coffee machine for us to paly for while. We decided to buy one for that model as well.Very strong Wi-Fi, over 30Mbps and free of course. But only available in room. you have to pay for other area.For everyone travelled Japan should fancy their toilet which have funny button to play with, not mention that heating seat...We stayed for 7 nights and really 200% happy with this hotel.

Lovely hotel in a great spot. Right next to all the shopping in shinjuku. And about 5 min walk from the train station. Would stay again for its location and if your going to the disney parks they have a free shuttle bus that leaves 3 times a day very convenient but need to book ahead to get the popular times. Only falt I have was we wanted to get an early checkin as this is somthing we didn't think about before arriving and was unable to. Could only get the standard 2pm which was a little inconvenient as we where catching a tour at 12:30 and just got off an overnight flight.

Stayed 4 nights with husband - large room, 2 single beds (not a problem, though others may dislike this), small bathroom with bidet/toilet/heated seat which was odd but fun to use, room amenities restocked daily, and a daily newspaper. Breakfast was included in the package, and was a choice of 4 restaurants. Tried the Japanese set breakfast (very tasty, though confronting if you're not used to that food so early in the mornign), but ended up preferring the mixed Western/Japanese buffet for a wider choice. Be prepared to queue at some times in the morning for a seat though.Tried the tearoom - overpriced for what it was, especially as the hotel is surrounded by shops that sell better for less. I wouldn't recommend this, but I can't fault the rest of the hotel.The hotel has multiple exits, which can sometimes be confusing and disorientating until you get used to navigating in Shinjuku. Right next to the train station, again confusing until you work out how to navigate by platform number and line.Some great shopping nearby, easy train ride to Shibuya for Tokyu Hands and the nightlife. Lots of great, cheap, eating places in the railway station and around the hotel to try.

This hotel needs renovating. Big and usually very expensive but is becoming more peripheral to the attractions of Shinjuku and seems to be struggling to remain top class. Prices seem to vary enormously so shop around. Buses stop here from Haneda and Narita.About 10 mins trek to Shinjuku station
user_location: Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom
user_name:
7Wanderlust123
Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom

review_body: I had stayed at this hotel before about 4 years ago, and booked 8 nights in this hotel for 2 rooms on the Keio Plaza Hotel website. I booked a room with King bed, and another room for twin beds. My booking was made about 3 months before my stay. I received an email confirming my stay, and I had no idea of the unpleasantness that would ensue at check-in.When I arrived, I was informed that my King bed booking was only a "Request", not a confirmation, and that I had been assigned 2 twin rooms. This was even though the rooms were held under a credit-card confirmation. Having flown 6-and a half hours, and travelling from the airport to the hotel, I would spend the next 1 hour at the front desk to get the staff there to recognise their error. I had to speak to the duty manager who was very hesitant to assign me a room of my booking. They wanted me to pay an extra fee for an "upgrade" room, which I refused. Finally they relented and gave me the room with the King bed. More was to come.The next day, I made (what I thought) was a simple request for an extra room key, so that my children on the other floor could easily reach my room, as the elevators are coded for the floor. Despite reasoning with them and numerous pleas, the front desk again refused. Despite speaking with the duty manager (a different one this time), he flatly refused. I have no idea, nor could they properly explain the reason why this simple request could not be fulfilled. I reasoned with them that there was no potential for a security breach, as my teenage son would be the one with the extra keycard, there was no extra cost to them as we would be returning all the keycards at checkout but they refused to budge. I cannot for the life of me understand why there is so much inflexibility here. It cost them nothing to please a guest and all they can do is say these are the rules. I requested to be provided with a feedback channel to the GM of the hotel, but the staff refused to give it to me. I am not sure if this hotel is interested in learning about its deficiencies.This will be the last time I book at the Keio Plaza Hotel Shinjuku.

Found the south terrace room we stayed in to be very tired. Beds really hard. Pillows really hard. Face cloths and towels thin and crusty. No adjoining room for our children , however I do believe they are available, as we stayed here once before, in 2011. Maybe in other terrace. The staff at the restaurants are wonderful. We did not complain to reception about the beds, a mistake I think. Our fault.

with all the amenities and friendly staff. I have been staying at this hotel off and on since 1986. It just gets better with age. No matter what you need, the staff can provide it. I use it as a home base for exploration of the city since there is easy access to the Tokyo subway and Shinjuku station via an underground passage. Plenty of shopping nearby too.

I greatly enjoyed my 4-night stay at this hotel. The airport bus drips right off at the hotel, which is convenient. A bell hop waited with our bags, while we checked in. We had a spacious room on one of the upper floors. This room would be spacious even by North American standards. The view was fabulous.The bed was large and comfortable. On one side were controls for all the room lights. Each side had a "foot light" that illuminated the under side of the night table. This was convenient for getting up at night without waking your partner.We ate breakfast in the dining room with western and Japanese buffet. When we arrived early, we had no wait. At certain times, we had a brief wait. Food was excellent. Chefs made fresh eggs - one frying eggs and the other making custom omelets. There was a large selection of both Japanese and western food.One evening we tried the sushi restaurant. The food was pricey, but comparable to another top-rated Tokyo sushi restaurant that I had been considering. This was the best sushi I ever had. The quality and presentation were superb. The abalone and chrysanthemum blossom was so unusual.The hotel is a short walk from Shinjuku station - just a few blocks. Between Shinjuku and the hotel are many inexpensive restaurants. To the south of the hotel is the Metropolitan Tokyo building, which has a free observation deck for a fabulous view of the city.

Been staying here for years and the recent room upgrades have brought them up to date. A good range of food is available from the many outlets in the hotel but breakfast can be busy at peak times. The hotel is easy to reach from airports with bus services right to the door, or try the NEX from Narita.

We stayed 5 nights at the Keio.The hotel is well situated on the east side of Shinjuku station in the pleasant skyscraper district. There are restaurants on the east side and shopping outlets at the west side. And there is the lively area around the station. The Yoyogi park and the Meji shrine are close by. In addition to all the busy trains and subway lines in Shinyuku station there is also the convenient station Tochomae on the Oedo almost next to the hotel.Sunrise tours uses the hotel as a collection point for their tours which was practical. What made the hotel pleasant was their wide range of restaurants and their relaxing eatery and bar on the top floor. And the tiny store in the basement made it possible to buy rolls, cheese or cuts, and drinks when one was fed up of restaurant eating.It is not a cosy boutique hotel but one that is well situated and offers a variety of options in house and outside to relax after an exhausting day of visits. The rooms are ok, the staff professional.We booked the hotel as part of a package, Sunrise must use very good rates when I compare with the internet prices of just the hotel.

A 3 minute walk away from 24-hour restaurants, boutique bars, and convenience stores. Less than a 10-minute walk away from the train station and the happening Shinjuku East district. Rooms are spacious, clean and value for money. However, staff are not very friendly and helpful when it comes to requests and directions, breakfast is normal. Overall, a good accommodation for those who are looking for a strategic location in the Shinjuku district.

This hotel is very well located, scrupulously clean, the concierge staff are very helpful and there is an excellent choice of breakfasts. In addition they run a limo coach to Narita which saves money and trouble. The rooms are a good size for Tokyo. OK, it's a bit impersonal, but what do you want in central Tokyo? I've stayed there and chosen to return.

Rooms are big by Tokyo standard and renovated since the last time we visited years ago.Experience marred only by one staff who checked us in the the Premier Executive special check-in who was not too polite. Other staff were extremely helpful and the bellgirl even declined a tip for hauling our luggages. When we came some year ago the Bell Boy took our tip!

Rude staff. Nasty, noisy room. Good location. Did not want to be there if I didn't have too. Too bad. When I asked to have my room changed to a renovated one, they said no, it wasn't what I paid for ( it was part of a tour) Maybe they could have offered an upgrade at a price... Very disappointing

Stayed here during a family vacation in September 2014. Paid a premium price for the hotel and expected better than what I received. The staff is nice and is willing to accommodate, but we were placed in the non-refurbished room in the South tower. Upon entering, I felt a massive sense of disappointment in what I saw. The rooms in the South tower were very old, dingy, and mattresses that felt old and dirty. It was dark and the lighting was terrible. After a couple of minutes, I got quite furious and went to speak to the receptionist. I asked nicely for the same priced room in the Main tower. They spoke a lot of Japanese so I took out my Ipad to show her the room I actually reserved, cause I believed she had no idea what I was asking for. I tried to explain to her that the room I reserved did NOT look like the room I received. After she mumbled something to me, she switched me over to the main tower. The room I received in the Main tower was bigger, brighter, and nicer, even though it was not refurbished. The rooms are clean. Beds are still not that comfortable, but that is okay. Aside from that, the location of this hotel is awesome. It is very close to the Shinjuku station, which is like the Grand Central of NY. Lots of great restaurants and shopping within walking distance. Even though the room aren't great, the location makes up for it.
user_name:
miz_element
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed at this hotel late October 2014 for four nights, pre-cruise. I chose it mainly for its proximity to Shinjuku station and for the variety of restaurants available in the hotel itself. The room was spacious, well maintained and with views of the city. We tried the Grass Court buffet but then switched to the Jurin Restaurant on the 45th floor for the remainder of our stay mainly because of the Western food on the menu and of course, for the fantastic view of Tokyo! Another favourite in the hotel for us was the Delicatessen where you could buy pastries and pure fruit juices etc.We walked to Shinjuku station in approximately 10 minutes; eateries and coffee shops are within close proximity to the hotel. A fantastic place to stay; would stay there again.

I didnt take the advices of ppl from trip advisor and took the unrenovated room in the south wing. Terrible. The air conditioning is centralised and as it's winter now, they put the heater on. However, with 3adults in the room, it's pretty stuffy in the room despite weather being 18degree C outside. We couldnt chg our room as hotel was fully booked (apparently...) so we could only suck it up. 10mins after, the bell boy who showed us to our room came back again and said he could bring up a fan for us!! (Yes, it does help GREATLY with a fan!!) I was pleasantly surprise and honestly, touched, by this really small, thoughtful and personalised service from a big hotel like this!!! Thus, for service, it would definitely deserve a 5 star! !!Location-wise, indeed, it has many lines at shinjuku station. However, it's not as convenient as i thot.. (i rely heavily on trip advisor for reviews on hotel) it's a 5mins walk from JR shinjuku (the nearest line) however, it's a goos 10-15mins from other lines by tokyo metro. So, unless planned to shop only at the departmental stores at shinjuku and taking ONLY JR lines, this is perfect. but with the morning and evening rush hour, it is a orderly madness!! I personally very much prefer shibuya area..Room-wise, i cant comment much since I'm given a not renovated room.. however, i dont think it's that bad except the air conditioning part. So perhaps, like wat everyone else say - choose and insist on the renovated room.

I stay in this hotel last month (Nov 2014) for 6 days. Was told that it is very near to Shinjuku station, but actual fact it is about a 15 min walk from the station. Rather far and although it is within walking distance but yet seem far. So my advice to you, is that you need to be prepare to walk.The hotel basically is grand, expensive restaurant, expensive breakfast.I manage to stay at the 29th floor and the view is simple beautiful. I stay at the main building side and wasn't able to view the Mt Fuji, but view is still great. This should be the refurbished room.My only complaint was that the room was dusty, although they clean up daily. This is really not acceptable for a 5 stars hotel. I hope they improve on the cleanliness.Last but not least, there's a clinic on the 30th floor. Overall I will choose another hotel if I visit Japan again.

I booked a Premier room at this hotel for my the last 4 nights of my honeymoon in Japan and wasn't disappointed. Check-in was very busy (we arrived on a Sunday afternoon and it seems to be a very popular hotel), but well organised and we were quickly allocated a spacious room on the 39th floor, which had great views and seemed to have been recently refurbished. I found the staff very helpful and the hotel even supplied my wife and I umbrellas, when we had to brave typhoon Vongfong for an evening. The location is ideal, as it is situated 5 minutes from Shinjuku train station, if you want to explore Tokyo and on either side of the station (and indeed, inside!) there are a multitude of places to eat, drink and shop.We didn't sample the food at the hotel, as there are so many places to eat nearby, but did have free access to the Luxe lounge, which was a nice perk. In addition, we finished most evenings at the Polestar bar on the 45th floor, which possesses amazing views across Tokyo and a fabulous selection of drinks! I would thoroughly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for somewhere to stay in the Shinjuku/Shibuya area

It's all you'd expect from this type of hotel. Very big and shiny inside! Lots of conventions going on, so the huge lobby almost resembles Grand Central station at times. 47 high floors, but the elevators was the most efficient I've ever come across. Clean! Great A/C! Very friendly staff! Highly recommended indeed. And the value is quite good too!

We went to Japan for the first time, and had booked Keio Plaza. Lonely Planet recommends this hotel as an upper end hotel to stay. We took 2 rooms and both were extremely clean. The restaurants attached to this hotel were steeply priced, and we only ended up having breakfast at Jurin - the all day diner. The breakfast spread was fantastic.Location wise this place is fantastic, as Shinjuku JR rail is barely 200 meters away, and so is the Shinjuku market, post office and a host of other tourist attractions. We strongly recommend this place, however, you won't really get a flavour of real Tokyo since this is located more in the heart of the Business District

We decided to break our flight home at Tokyo,after 5 weeks in Europe.We landed at Nagrita and arranged for a limousine pick up,which I would seriously recommend you do.It is about an hour to the Keio in the limousine service(under 100 aus)Initial impressions are quite spectacular.The foyer is the size of several marble coated football fields.We stayed in 4 and 5 star hotels in Europe and they came no where near the Keio, for first impressions.(one Hilton foyer woud have fitted a few thousand times into this foyer)The restaurants are of a high standard,although I prefer to eat in the local Shinjuku precinct where you are spoiled for choice and diversity and fascinated by the neon side show.It is also substantially cheaper.You are met at the entrance by a concierge and your bags delivered to reception where they are given to an attendant who will show you to your room and who will explain all the ins and outs whilst in your room.The English at reception was reasonable but the courtesy and politeness of the staff was outstanding.The first thing you need to be aware of is, that Japan is still a very much smoking society.Our room had not been booked as non smoking,hence we were to be given a smokers room.We were however offered an upgrade to a larger suite which was non smoking for 3000 yen(30 aus dollars) per night,which we agreed to, which turned out to be a great decision.The room was in the main tower just opposite reception on the 33rd floor and was outstanding.It was large, well designed and the view over Tokyo was to die for.The only small criticism was that the bathroom ,whilst luxurious 5 or so years ago and scrupuously clean,was looking a tad dated,I also question the use of laminated flooring in lieu of timber in a small area,but that is nit picking.The only issue we had with the Keio is that when checking our banking on the internet(which was free)I found the Keio had frozen a 1000 aus dollars as a guarantee for 3 nights.We had prepaid and after a few discussions this gurantee was reduced.I know why they do it ,but hotels,not just Keio,need to standardise this practice.I think travel agents are as much to blame as hotels, as the Keio, and they need to stand up and be upfront.I do not want my assets frozen for a week at the whim of the industry...it needs to be reasonable.In the end the Keio agreed it was unreasonable and made sure the security was released on departure.I suggest you check your accounts...I do.

Stayed in November 2014 for 5 nights in a Plaza Luxe Queen Room (South Tower) at a cost of around £140 GBP per night (lucky to have good exchange rates right now!) This was a refurbished room so very comfortable and also had access to the Luxe Lounge on the 34th floor. The lounge is open from 10am to 9:30pm and offers a quiet space to work with free soft drinks/snacks all day and alcoholic drinks after 5pm. I was staying on a business trip and it was really helpful to have access to the lounge at various points during my stay to catch up on e-mails in a quiet and calm environment. I would highly recommend booking a Plaza Luxe room in order to get access to the lounge. The location is excellent - in the heart of Shinjuku with a huge array of transport connections. This is a great place to stay if you are on a business trip to Tokyo.Service was efficient and courteous throughout. I didn't eat at the hotel but there are a wide range of different restaurants which are reasonably priced for lunch but overpriced for dinner (would recommend even just walking into Shinjuku station where there are plenty of reasonably priced restaurants). WiFi is available in the rooms and the Luxe Lounge but not in the public/banquet areas of the hotel so may be worth buying a visitor data SIM card to access the internet elsewhere (try B-mobile Japan). Getting to the hotel from Shinjuku station is easy. If arriving on the Narita Express, follow signs for the "West Exit". As soon as you go through the JR ticket barrier, you should follow signs to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government and then you will begin to see signs for the Keio Plaza Hotel. Once you exit the station underpass, the hotel entrance is to the left. If you have luggage, it is around a 10-15 minute walk from the train platform to the hotel reception. A one-way Narita Express ticket is only 1500 JPY from Narita Airport to Shinjuku (half the price of the hotel shuttle), is the quickest way to get to the hotel and I didn't have any problems with luggage (there are lifts/escalators in Shinjuku station).There seem to be a lot of TripAdvisor reviews bemoaning hotel policies like not being able to check-in early or "inflexibility" or not being able to change rooms if you don't like yours. All I can say is that this rules are rules and the reason why things are so efficient and work so well in Japan is because everything runs by the book. What makes you so special that the hotel should let you check-in early or change your room if you don't like it?!Do your homework before arriving and you will be fine. You can't check-in before 2pm so if your flight arrives early into Narita, book into the Nine Hours capsule hotel for a few hours to recover before getting the Narita Express to Shinjuku (see my other review on this for details). If you don't want an old room then book a refurbished Plaza Luxe Room (they are excellent). If you need internet access outside your room then get a visitor data SIM card. Plan in advance and you will have a great stay!

We stayed in the South Tower and even though we requested a non smoking room, unfortunately the room had a very stale smell of cigarette smoke. The room is small in comparison to other hotels we stayed in, through out Japan. The furniture looked circa 1970's, which is the era of the hotel and it was so worn and chipped. The carpets were aged and would have been impossible to clean because of their worn state. They looked very dusty. The bathroom was very small and tired.The shower was over the bath. The attachment for the overhead shower were comprised of cheapplastic. The toilet had this awful black scum which was a permanent feature even though the rooms were serviced daily. A bottle of water was not provided in the bathroom per person and as I used a bottle of water from the minibar, I was charged on checkout! The only redeeming points were the convenience of its location to the train station and the view of Mt Fuji, however I would have cheerfully compromised on those advantages to have a room of a better standard.

We spent 10 days in Japan and I am glad this hotel is the ONLY place in Japan we run into rude service. We stay 6 nights in their premium double room, first day after late check-in, we found a dodgy stain in the provided towel, I was already partially undress and ready for a hot shower but instead I have to put on my cloths again to wait for the replacement towel, annoying.On our last day stay, we booked the hotel airport shuttle bus from the bill captain counter in very early morning and he ask for our room number and gave us a print out of reservation confirmation with total cost of 6200¥, after we returned from our day trip in the evening we decided to settle our bill to avoid rushing in next morning (the airport shuttle bus depart at 5:50), the front desk employee for some reason look grumpy and piss off when we arrived in front of him, neither smile nor greeting was offer, after I signed and paid the bill, I realize the bus fare was not included so I ask him if I should pay the bus fare now or tomorrow morning? he ask if I have the bus ticket, unaware and confuse why I needs to purchase a bus ticket for "Hotel airport shuttle bus" (the bill captain failed to mention anything about bus ticket and turn out the bus is not from the hotel, it is run by third party company) I ask him if he is referring to the A4 print out I received from bill captain this morning, he now look really piss, he raised his voice and ask: "DO you have the bus ticket? YES or NO?" I ask if he is alright? why he look unhappy? He just replied "I am OK, just drop your room key to that box when you leave tomorrow morning", he then turn away to look at some piece of paper while I was still standing in front of him!I went straight to speak with the duty manager, before I finish telling him what is happening he apologies "robotically", I look at him and realize I am wasting my time. We really enjoy our trip in Japan and certainly will visit Japan again in the future, I suggest anyone looking for a four star hotel to stay away from this one, after all who want to pay 200000¥ for rude service?

I love this hotel because:-- the room is clean and big (comparing to a lot of mini hotel rooms in urban Tokyo). The amenities and furniture were excellent. - the location is great. Only 5 minutes walk (all covered) from the Shinjuku metro station. Very easy for travelling around.- in-room free Wifi. connection is pretty strong too.- the staff are efficient and courteous. They speak English too. - 24hr convenient right inside the hotel- great value - only about USD200 / nightanything bad regarding this hotel? I can't think of any.

If you're looking for a hotel that is well located in the lively district of Shinjuku, then this hotel is a good option. Rooms are well sized, bathroom's on the smaller size. We used this hotel for it's location to Shinjuku station, which is a city in itself (pay attention to the Exit Signs and info boards to find your way around). Hotel offers a Disney shuttle bus and is a stop for the limousine airport bus which is convenient. Dining options are varied, though pricey, but overall the hotel is comfortable and we received reasonable rates as we booked in advance. I'm sure there are cheaper options around Shinjuku, but you'll receive great service, good facilities and a good location by booking here.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza for the second time in October this year, as before on our last two days back in Tokyo after a 3 week tour of Japan. Lovely staff, 24 service check-in and check-out and the airport bus picks you up from then main entrance. The Decor is slightly dated in the south tower, however the views compensate for that and more. Our room looked over the Tokyo Metropolitan Building and we could even see the jaw dropping Mt Fuji in the background.I will definitely stay again when I'm back.

This was our 1st stop on our travels from the states to Japan for 3 nights on a Business group trip. The rooms were very clean and attractive with all the Amenities. The Hotel had several options for restaurants both Japanese & Western style. Was close to shopping and Train Station. Great Views. Would surely recommend.

Decent size room, albeit non-renovated South tower, great & working amenities. Japan top cleanliness, warm room temp during autumn.Breakfast with three choices of restaurant, each with their own specialities. Brilliant bar open until early wee hours with excellent service, in house umeshu choya on rocks thumbs up.Walking distance to either shopping district, major train station, subway station and plenty of taxis available.Its a great hotel for either business or leisure......enjoy!!!

Great location with excellent staff who will try to solve all of your problems. Traditional Japanese breakfast on 2F had little variations from day to day, but definite worth a try. The best way to get to/from airport is via airport bus, which drop you at the doorsteps. Convenient and cost-effective.

We stayed three nights in a superior twin room in the south wing (38th floor). The room was a decent size and generally well-equipped with fantastic views across the city, although Tokyo isn't that great to look at. Breakfast buffet in Jurin was terrific, varied and we didn't have to wait for a table. The Polestar bar is spectacular and it's well worth stumping up for one or two expensive but expertly-prepared drinks to enjoy the view / atmosphere. The airport limousine bus from Haneda is cheap and goes right to the door, but it's less convenient for onward Shinkansen travel from Tokyo station (either a tricky subway journey with cases or 3,000 Yen for a taxi). Nearby Shinjuku restaurants and bars are lively but not so much that you can't escape the madness by stepping back into the hotel - ask for a high floor to guard against road / reveller noise to make sure.

This huge hotel is in a great location next to the very busy Shinjuku train station, the shops restaurants and business centre. The hotel has several restaurants with great choices of Western and Japanese food for breakfast lunch and dinner and excellent conference facilities. My room was in the South Tower and the decor was a bit jaded with poor views compared to the rooms I seen in the North Tower. Also the room was a smoking room which was a bit unpleasant and would recommend specifically requesting non smoking (if required) The concierge and reception staff were always helpful. All in all a good 4 star hotel in a great area.

This hotel had friendly, helpful & polite front desk service staff.Their Wifi was alittle complicated for me; As you would need to access a certain webpage on your iphone/android device, a webpage already provided by the hotel. From that website on you type in the username and password, thus, doing so; you'll be able to access the hotel's internet. Aside from an afternoon of those complications I enjoyed my night in Keio Plaza Hotel, so as the Disneyland Shuttle bus ride. Hotel's buffet breakfast is at the top most floor. Variety of food is little though. Try to be there early to avoid long queue.

Truly disappointed with the staff and room in this hotel. Definitely a one time only stay.On checking into the hotel I requested a late check out by 2 hours and was informed I would have to pay extra. The following morning I went to the Duty Manager and made the same request and explained the reason for the late check out was the fact that friends were taking us to lunch in the hotel for our convenience. The Duty Manger showed no flexibility and repeated the party line that any additional time was chargeable. Considering their inflexible nature I could only assume their arrogance and inflexibility carries on to other issues we might have at their hotel.As far as the room is concerned it is old and tired looking. Scratched up furniture and a bed that reminds you of sleeping on the ground. The whole room needs a facelift. Finally should someone be talking outside the door of your room it sounds like they are in the room with you. The door has no noise reduction insulation. All in all a stay to remember and not to repeat.

My husband and I stayed there for 6 nights in October. Upon arrival we were met with some lovely hotel staff to help with our bags and the check-in process.Our room was large and clean with a nice view of the City. The location of the hotel is on the quieter side of Shinjuku but also not too far away from all the city buzz... 10-15 minutes walk to Shinjuku station and Kabuki-cho shops and restaurants. There is a little convenient store (amongst many restaurants they have at the hotel) within the hotel where we were able to buy some late night snacks or breakfast for the mornings when we had to get up very early for tours.One thing that definitely stood out during our stay was the service. To be exact, it was during post-stay. I left my medicine in the bar fridge after we checked out... only realised it when we got to the airport. I called the hotel, got to speak to a gentleman by the name of Hida in Housekeeping, he kindly offered to post the medicine back to my next destination and as he sent it by express mail, the medicine was already there waiting for me when I arrived at the next destination. I offered to pay for the postage which he declined as it was just 'part of their service'.Will definitely stay at this hotel again when we go back to Tokyo.

Stayed here for 4 nights with my family.....it is an enjoyable stay throughout....the staffs of the hotel, front desk, bell hop and even the security are all very friendly....they serve guests with grace.....nearby shinjuku have lots of eateries, mini shrine to visit, shopping centre and neatby mrt to visit other parts of japan.....they do serve breakfast and we have three restaurant choices to choose from and they have varieties to choose from.....overall the stay was good.....will definitely stay here again....

Had the pleasure of staying here in October. Lobby is very spacious. Several staff were available for check in which was nice for such a large hotel. They were very friendly and spoke fluent English. Room was clean, well furnished. Nice flat screen tv with clear reception. Free wifi in rooms. Room was very quiet, no street noise. Beds and pillows were on the hard side, but I've found this to be the norm in Japan. There are several restaurants in this hotel. Only had breakfast in 2 of them while there which was buffet style and served western and Japanese fare. There is a small shop/convenient store on the ground level which was nice for anything that you may have forgotten or for a quick snack/gift. The hotel is located close to the main Shinjuku subway station which allows for easy travel to all parts of Tokyo.

Shinjuku is the heart of Tallinn and Keio Plaza is in the heart of Shinjuku. Hotel has very nice view over Tokyo, and is high enough to be separated from street noise (which is not too bad in Tokyo). Very good hotel!

This is a very pleasant hotel. The main problem is for travellers arriving early in the morning. There is nowhere to wash/freshen up and your room is not available until 2 pm. We arrived at 10 am and were simply told to come back at 2 pm. There is no wifi in the public areas or lobby area and minimal seating so not a very comfortable waiting experience. It would also be good to let guests know when certain restaurants are not open for breakfast.

Very nice hotel, great service, We had originally booked non smoking but were given smoking, you do notice the smell when you enter the room. Apart from that, it was very clean and spacious compared to other hotels we stayed in Japan. It's a short walk from the shops and restaurants and 5-10mins to the station. The location is perfect though as it's in the quieter part of Shinjuku. A

We booked a great deal for two renovated superior south tower rooms with buffet breakfast via agoda and was not disappointed. Centrally located in Shinjuku, Keio Plaza Hotel is walking distance to Shinjuku Train Station. The Narita Airport Express Limousine Bus service stops directly at the hotel and the hotel also provides free Good Neighbor shuttle to Disney resorts upon reservation with the front desk/ guest relations. The hotel is near many restaurants, convenience stores, and shopping centers, but is located on a relatively quiet street. Before even arriving, the hotel staff were already very helpful in answering several queries we made via e-mail. Upon arrival, we experienced first hand how polite and helpful their English speaking staff really were. Everyone was welcoming and very accommodating. Check-in was organized and timely, and our requests for adjacent non-smoking rooms were accommodated. Our room, while a bit dated in terms of design (not old, but just not as modern looking as other hotels I've stayed at) was spacious, clean, and comfortable. The toilet and bath which I personally am very particular about was spotless. The beds and amenities were adequate and comfortable. My only complaint is that housekeeping failed to take out some trash and empty water bottles which we had packed neatly and placed beside the trash can (it was too big to fit inside as the bin was on the small side) for two days straight. Despite this oversight, the rest of the room and the bathroom were cleaned adequately. The breakfast buffet could be had at three different restaurants within the hotel depending on their opening hours. Food was essentially the same and selection was simple and did not change for the duration of our entire stay. It would have been nice to have had a variety or some changes to the menu and perhaps include traditional Japanese breakfast fare. Still, the food was freshly prepared and service was very good. Will definitely stay here again given the opportunity.

We were booked for 5D/4N at the Keio Plaza Hotel inclusive of daily breakfast. Its bell service and frontdesk staff were helpful and accommodating albeit Japanese English barrier. Based on reviews, I chose the newly-renovated room at the main tower. Our room was spotless and had a fresh toilet with daily request of make-up. We had a good view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building but failed to visit its observatory deck due to elevator's long queue. Keio is a walking distance to two major metro stations, electronic stores, foodies, convenience stores, bars, among other things. The hotel is one of the pick-up/drop-off points to/from the airports and Disney shuttle's friendly neighbor hotel. Cons: There were 7 restaurants to choose from to eat breakfast but are not open at the same time. There's only one restaurant which opens at 5:00AM; others open at 6Am, 7AM & 8AM. However, there were still long queues in all restaurants and you have to be patient for your turn. I will consider staying here again if and when I visit Tokyo again.

Only stayed 1 night due to transfer elsewhere. Excellent position within walking distances to the shops, bars and restaurents. Train station also nearby. Had breakfast on the 44 th floor with extensive views. Very friendly staff. Good sized room and comfy bed.

The good: We stayed four nights at the Keio Plaza Hotel in a Superior room (September 2014). We booked our room directly with the hotel. The room was clean, spacious, we had a view of Mt Fuji (bonus) and the airport limosine bus leaves directly from this hotel. The hotel is in a good location, with many restaurants, shops and Shinduku station within easy walking distance.The ordinary: The hotel is massive and on arrival around 10:30am reception was extremely busy. We did not expect to have access to our room before 2:00pm but thought we would be able to complete the admistrative check in. This was not the case, we were asked to leave the cue and advised we could not complete check-in until 2:00pm so were required to stack our luggage with nets over them in the hotel foyer and wait until 2:00pm.The ugly: When we did complete check-in we were allocated a room in the South Tower. On stepping into the lift I noticed there was no lift security and on reaching the 18th floor the corridors smelt stuffy and old as did our room. The furniture was old, chipped and flimsy. The bed was the worst being like sleeping on a cardboard box which aggravated my sciatic nerve pain. The bathroom had a great toilet, but a shower bath. The standard was not what I would expect from a four star hotel.I was very disappointed in the standard of our room and because our friends were staying in the same hotel in the North Tower, I was able to compare the South Tower and North Tower rooms. Our room rate for the first night stay was the same as our friends who were allocated a much higher standard room in the North Tower. I wouldn't recommend this hotel to friends and recommend if you do stay to ask for the renovated rooms in the North Tower.

We stayed five nights at the Keio Plaza Hotel. As most of the reviews are positive about the hotel we had some high expectations. Sadly when we arrived at our room (in the Southern Tower) we noticed that the room was not as pretty as the hotel website shows on their pictures. Of course, I know that these pictures are made in their best condition, but our room felt a bit too basic. If you can imagine the cheapest IKEA furniture, you get the point. The bed felt like it was carved from rock. Maybe if you stayed a few days at a Ryokan, the bed may feel like an improvement, but I experienced better beds at cheaper hotels.As for the other facilities of the hotel. We tried breakfast once, but it's better (and cheaper) to go outside and try one the restaurants in the neighbourhood. The gym felt smaller than the superior rooms. Only if your idea of working out is walking/running on a treadmill or elliptical trainer it's decent. Is it all so bad? Well, the location of the hotel is great. It's in a perfect walking distance from Shinjuku station. Also the rooms were always clean and the free daily paper felt like a nice gesture. I wouldn't recommend the hotel to friends or family, though if they insist on staying there I would recommend them to ask for the newer rooms as they look more comfortable (and reading the reviews here, probably are).

Ok people @ Keio, I wrote a feedback to you guys earlier but was disappointed not to hear any from you guys.The reason why I booked direct with you guys and paid MORE was because I was hoping that you guys will do something special to celebrate our 12th wedding anniversary at your hotel. We have notified you several times about this celebration. We do not expect a big hooha, but a nice "Happy Anniversary" card would have been appreciated or even a swan-made towels.. but no, nothing! Boo... (Incidentally, other establishments during our trip that went out of the way to make us feel special!)We arrived early at your hotel and waited patiently until it was time for check-in. We would have been happy to wait BUT for the fact that we felt that there were differential treatment in how your reception dealt with Caucasian guests as compared to Asian guests. This will be the first time I'm submitting photos to tripadvisor but I think I have to resort to doing this to you as proof. Any Asian guests were always told to wait... but there were at least 2 caucasian familes that came and had their rooms readied for them and keys given to them.... WHY?!?!?! And one of them did not even have a reservation... it was a walk-in. If I knew that walk-ins had rooms quicker, I would not have reserved a room with you guys beforehand.And after waiting and arriving at our appointed room... LO and BEHOLD, I see a raspberry on the floor.... given the Japanese culture of having high standards of hygiene, I am aghast to see that fruit on the floor. It makes me wonder now exactly how clean your room would be. Also, how come the people before us had a fruit basket but not us?!?! Is this another preferential treatment?Thank God our other Japan encounters made up for our trip.... yours was the worst!!! The only redeeming factor were your wonderful bellboys who were utterly helpful to help us with our request. The rest of your staff were courteous but curt. How you received the Disney-friendly hotel, I wouldn't know... Here's to never ever staying at your hotel ever again!

This hotel has an unbeatable location. We picked this hotel because the airport limousine bus would pick up and drop off right at the hotel, the tours also would pick up from this hotel; and it was only a 5 minutes walk to the Shinjuku station from it's West Exit. Along the road from the hotel to the station, there are lots of restaurants, cafes and shops. There is a huge electrical store around that area where we got our camera!This hotel is huge. We have never been in a line just to wait for the check in. There are at least 6 check in counters but there were all full. There was actually a staff standing in front of the line to tell us which counter is available for check in! The staff was helpful and speak good English.You can also buy the airport limousine tickets at their vending machine.There are two parts of the hotel. The South wing and the main building. We stayed at both side. Although the south wing' s room are bigger but is old. On the other hand, rooms in the main building is modern and new but a little smaller in size. We preferred the room in main building. All rooms are clean and the bath room were in a good size with enough amenities. I personally like the way they would provide little hair bands.We love the complimentary high speed wifi in the room. However it won't work at the lobby!The negative part about this hotel is the rate was a little steep. We were paying USD350 per night. Perhaps this is what you will have to pay if you are staying in the heart of Tokyo!Our room rate doesn't include a breakfast （ we think is ridiculous - with that price we paid, we didn't even get breakfast! ) so I am not able to comment if the breakfast is good.

Stayed at this hotel twice, and were not disappointed either time.The rooms that we were assigned to were spacious and clean. The location of the hotel is excellent. In the heart of Shinjuku, near 2 MRT stations, and easy to grab food and necessities. There were good restaurants not far from the hotel, and 2 supermarkets as well. One of the other main reasons why I really like this hotel is that this is one of the hotels whereby there is a Disney shuttle that takes you directly to and from Disneyland and/or Disneysea. This makes it very convenient and saves travel time.The only downside is being a big hotel, front desk service for check-in and check-out could be long at times.I could not recommend this hotel enough to family and friends.

We stayed for 6 nights in this hotel. Clean and nice newly renovated rooms. Triple sharing with 3 beds. Everyone was comfortable! Nice location walking distance to restaurant and malls. Easy access to shinjuku station. Highly recommended!! We will surely be back soon :)

We stayed for 6 nights in a renovated Deluxe Room in the Main tower. The room itself was spacious, clean and comfortable with some great city views. It was also quiet and located near 2 subway stations (Shinjuku and Tochocae). Other major hotels such as the Hilton and Hyatt are located nearby so its a very safe area to stay.The standard of English was not great for an International hotel of this standard. In addition, there were 10 restaurants of varying country cuisines that were on the whole very expensive, average standard and very small servings. We had to rely on MacDonalds and the nearby Sizzlers restaurant to avoid being broke and hungry. The only other saviour was the convenience store that stayed open until 2.30 am each night within the hotel itself.Staff at the concierge desk were only marginally helpful.WIFI was complimentary but dropped out on a regular and frustrating basis.Overall, a comfortable hotel but the food aspect lets this hotel down very badly.

The hotel is near Shinjuku station, where there are metro and train lines to almost every place in Tokyo. I chose a business package directly from the hotel website without using online travel agencies. Breakfast was included, the room was "premier". These rooms are located among the 35th and the 39th floor in the main tower. They are new and large...very comfortable. The breakfast was ok, not much choice.

I was there in September for my first time in Japan and during my honeymoon.We were at the 29th floor.Just wonderful.Excellent hotel, wonderful view and very polite service.The bar at the 45th floor is just amazing!!! Wonderful location as well, the metro is very close.Don't think twice, just book here

Stayed fara couple of nights at this hotel. Would not recommend it since it felt very basic. It was booked as a superior hotel, but there wasn't anything superior about it. Standard beds, standard room which seemed kind of worn down. The only plus was the proximity to Shinjuku station and the view of Mount Fuji, but I suppose you can get that at other hotels.

Spent our first 4 nights in Japan at this hotel. We got an upgrade to a room on a high floor so had fantastic views. Room was very comfortable and larger than expected. Great location, so easy to find, only a short walk from Shinjuku train station. Shinjuku station is a hive of humanity which all seems to work.A lot of great places to eat very near the Hotel, so whenever ate there.Would highly recommend Hotel Keio Plaza.

I have stayed several times at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo over a number of years. It has been consistently good and this last stay was incredible. The service at any hotel is paramount and this hotel does not disappoint. There are many restaurant choices at the hotel and my favorite is the buffet. The hotel is a convenient 10 minute walk to the train station.

Its probably not fair to say Pleasant Surprise but I was not expecting the high level of service that I received at the Keio Plaza so it was a bit of a surprise.The location is very convenient and accessible - sometimes Hotels with this advantage depend on it too heavily and fall down in other areas - not so for the Keio Plaza.The staff was very friendly and helpful, my room was on the 36th floor which is one of the Plaza Premier rooms and it was a real delight. Large with a king bed and sitting area, nice bathroom even a Nespresso coffee maker for a morning espresso!The breakfast buffet was quite good although not quite as extravagant as many of the large Asian hotels provide - still very nice.Their are a number of varied dinner restaurants on the lower level and even a small convenience store.The airport buses from both Narita and Haneda stop and pick-up right at the door.Very good stay - would definitely return again!

In a good location near the train station, shopping, and restaurants. Service was impeccable as is usually the case in Japan. Rooms are nice, clean, etc.There is a great convenience store on the lower level.The hotel has a reputation for being "Japanese". Not sure what that means because it was quite easy for me--a non-Japanese speaker--to stay there. There were few English-language tv offerings, and in the fitness room, the CNN feed was dubbed over into Japanese. Don't bother with breakfast in the hotel. Pretty basic offerings. Go to the Shinjuku West neighborhood, which is steps from the door--the one with the taxis, and enjoy the tons of offerings there. Asian, middle-eastern, American food is available.Don't come here for the fitness room, either, which is rudimentary, small, with few machines and stations. The CNN, ESPN feeds on the few machines they had were dubbed over in Japanese. There was no charge, however. Pool is outdoor only and closed in winter.

We stayed there with more than 70 people . Family tour with offices staff in the month of July , 2013. Sorry I hold it long Just recovered from digital phobia.Love their breakfast buffet , great choices and freshness; cons were the very weak wifi..

Best hotel service I've experienced. All the staff have been so very helpful and always always going the extra mile for us. They helped entertain my son when checking in took a while because we arrived with two full buses of tourists. They helped us with maps and guides and made sure we got all the information about places we inquired about. They also offered reminder calls/ wake up calls for the day of our departure. The room was always perfectly cleaned with all our things put back where we left them. The room shows a bit of wear but it was very well maintained. This was our second stay at Keio. the first one was November 2013. I am looking forward to coming back this April 2015. :)

This is a large, busy, yet quiet and comfortable hotel convenient to train station, restaurants, and shopping. Our room had upscale central lighting controls that also operated the large room darkening shade with the touch of a button. The separate vanity area was convenient to help two women maximize the use of time and space in getting ready for the day, the beds were comfortable, and the room had an eastern flair while still accommodating our American appliances and preferences. One slight negative was the lack of adequate seating areas in the main lobbies. We rarely found a place to sit while waiting for our tour group to gather. Our three night stay here was enjoyable as we explored Tokyo, Mount Fuji, and surrounding areas. Transfers to Tokyo Narita Airport were easily arranged, too.

We stayed a few nights at Keio Plaza during early October. We found the accommodation to be very spacious and clean. The American breakfast buffet was good and the small convenience store on the lower level was a terrific bonus. The hotel's location is very handy to transport and shopping.

My family went there a few days ago and i thought of writing this review to help tourist like me decide. Location- perfect bec it is near the railway, shops and restos. Convenience- perfect since the limousine service to and from the airport stops here; free shuttle service to disneyland; they have maps and sheets with instructions on how to get to a tourist spot. Five stars for customer satisfaction

Keio Plaza Hotel location is nice. Walking to the West Exit of Shinjuku Station about 10 minutes from hotel. If you want to go to department stores or restaurants, it's very convenient. There is nice service, comfortable and cleaning room in hotel. But it's a pity that the decor is a little bit old. However he is one of Tokyo Disney Resort Good Neighbor Hotels and offers a free shuttle bus to Disneyland Tokyo. There is also a Limousine Bus Station, you can take or get off the airport bus in front of hotel. This hotel should be a very good choice for family trips. But you have a better choice to young couples or backpackers, such as Shinjuku Prince Hotel near Kabukicho.

We went on a trip to Japan. We stayed here for 3 nights. I don't care for tokyo; but the hotel lobby is gorgeous. We stayed in south tower where the room outdated. They buffet breakfast was nice. I don't think I would stay here upon my return to Japan

The Keio Plaza Hotel is located in Tokyo, Japan, a short 5 minute walk from the Shinjuku Railway station,and close to many restaurants and department stores. My wife and I had a large comfortable room on the 34th. floor in the South tower with a view of Mount Fuji . We had a package which included 3 nights accommodation, a one way airport transfer from Narita airport and a morning tour of Tokyo ( Aus $441-00 per person ). The Hotel is quite large with some 1500 rooms and many restaurants.The staff is very helpful and polite and all speak English ,but other languages are also spoken, Russian , Italian , Spanish , Mandarin.We enjoyed our stay at the Keio and would recommend it .

I have stayed at this hotel several times before so for this trip I stayed there again, with my Father in a twin room. We stayed in deluxe grade twin rooms in the main tower. We actually stayed there twice during trip, 3 nights at the start of the holiday and 7 nights at the end.We accessed the hotel using the Limobus service from Haneda airport which was very easy (which is what you want after a long flight!). At the end we used the same service to get out to the airport and this is easily bookable via a desk in the corner of the hotel lobby. Personally i prefer this to the rail options as it means you are not trying navigate the busy rail system with heavy suitcases.When we checked in the second time the hotel was very busy and seemed to be suffering from some inefficiencies in the checkin process, (the employees doing the checkin seemed to have to do quite a bit of paper work after the person checking in left the counter which seemed to slow down the process). The extra 400yen/night tax payment is rather annoying. The staff are helpful and speak good English. I would also note that it was simple to leave our main luggage with this hotel whilst we travelled around Japan and to collect it when we rechecked in later in the month. The convenience store on the second floor is useful for grabbing drinks and snacks.The deluxe rooms are nice but I question the removal of wired internet access from the rooms since our last visit. The wifi generally worked but was not as reliable as the previous wired connection (particularly for things like Skype). There was also differences in equipment between rooms, (our first room had a DVD player hooked up to the TV but the second had some form of DVD/music system (with iPod dock) which, whilst it said it supported DVDs did not actually have a HDMI cable plugged into it connected to the TV). The deluxe rooms are huge, not just by the standard of Japanese hotel rooms and are fairly quiet (although our second room was just off the elevator lobby on our floor so was slightly more noisy due to other guests). The cleaners did manage to leave a window cleaning cloth on the window sill for a couple of days during our second stay :)The hotels location in Shinjuku is good with easy access to the Shinjuku station west gate (via the tunnel accessed from the road outside the end of the second floor) and to the rest of the station and Shinjuku itself by taking the road opposite the rear of the hotel (which also has a Post Office with ATMs which work with international cards (if yours are setup with your bank to work) on it and a nice little restaurant opposite the Post Office).I expect we will stay at this hotel again in the future.

Keio Plaza hotel is nicely located in the heart of Shinjuku, accessible to shopping, restaurants and bars. It is next to Tokyo Metropolitan Government office building with free observatory tower till 11pm nightly.The South tower rooms are spacious though a bit run down furnitures, but comfortable and adequate size bathrooms. The Main tower rooms are small though with nicer furnitures. I prefer the South Tower because the spacious room. You have a few choices of breakfast, but I prefer buffet breakfast in second floor and also buffet breakfast in 47th floor with nice views. Highly recommended hotel.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza for 3 days at the beginning and 1 day at the end of our 2 week trip. The first 3 days we had a room in the South Tower and the 4th night a room in the Main building.Both check-ins were efficient and personable. All the staff spoke good English and were politely encouraging of my attempts at basic Japanese. We were offered upgrades each time. The check in time is 2.00pm and this was brought forward to 1.00pm for us but don’t expect it to be much earlier. The hotel looks after your luggage until your room is ready.The room in the South Tower was showing signs of wear and the walls a little scuffed. There was a note apologising in advance for any noise that may be caused by renovations. There was no noise at all. Judging by the papers outside each room in the morning the hotel was fairly full but we heard no noise at all throughout our stays. We enjoyed 4 great night sleeps at the Keio.We asked for twin beds throughout our stay in Japan as we wanted to avoid a possibility of having one side against a wall. The room was large and the beds were firm and comfortable, with good linen. There were two chairs and a small table, the bathroom was compact and adequate with a separate dressing ante-room next to it. The view was to an office block across the road. I think a list of bathroom amenities is on the website. Only tea was included in the room so if you start the day with another beverage there is a well stocked convenience store on the lower ground.There was a range of restaurants for breakfast and we ate in the Glass Court each morning. No sign of large groups, mainly couples and small families and a few business people. It was busy but did not feel crowded. There was a large choice of food, both western and local. Not inspiring, but certainly a convenient way to start the day.We ate at the Italian restaurant the first evening and it was excellent. Both the waitress and chef were helpful in ensuring our vegetarian requirements were met.The location is excellent, close to the Shinjuko railway station. There is a bustling little area between the hotel and the station, full of restaurants (many with English menus if you ask). This area is not touristy at all. You will get lost in the station, there are several ways out, and a couple will get you back to the Hotel easily. A tip, take note of the staircase number you go down and look for that on the way out. If you do get lost, relax and go shopping. The stations are all well stocked with daily essentials, food and clothing.The last night of a trip we were given a room on the 35th Premium Plaza floor of the main building. It was gorgeous and appreciated. A huge window overlooking the bright lights, nespresso, push button everything and lots of roomI summation, I was a little nervous about staying in such a large hotel but everything was peaceful and worked well so I would stay here again.

I arranged this booking for my teenaged daughters & their friend. I understand the hotel wanted to be paid with a credit card. I had secured the room with my credit card over the phone. The girls however wanted to pay in cash (Japanese Yen) They were then chastised & told it needed to be paid with a credit card. No wonder... because the amount the hotel wanted to process on my daughters mastercard debit card was for a much higher amount!!?? (The initial quote was in yen and the amount of yen they were wanting to transact was the equivalent of around $700aud more than was quoted for their 9 night stay)Please note this was for payment IN ADVANCE of their stay upon check in. So be very wary if you indeed pay with a credit card. Check the exchange rates carefully! Fortunately they refused to process this inflated amount on my daughters mastercard debit card (the type that will only work if you have sufficient funds preloaded in it.) They insisted it be paid with a regular visa or mastercard. What difference does this make??I sought help from my local Flight Centre (travel agency) & they were very helpful.They tried to talk with hotel staff in order to sort this out. (even though I had made the booking privately with the hotel & flight centre had nothing to gain from this but my gratitude) Hotel management flatly refused to negotiate & insisted on being paid with a regular credit card. So I offered to put the correct amount as quoted on my own credit card. The very same card they'd happily accepted as security for the booking in the first place. You guessed it, this too was declined. They insisted the card needed to be physically produced!So the flight centre girl generously offered to help us this way. She said if I could pay the cash to flight centre on the spot (& I was able to entertaint this option even though it was a substantially high amount - I was fortunate to have sufficient funds at my disposal.) she'd use flight centre's own company credit card to pay on our behalf. The hotel even refused this! apparently even this offer from Australia's biggest travel agency was not good enough! The hotel manager still insisted on having a physical card presented at their reception desk!Crazy. How come a credit card over the phone was sufficient to secure the room in the first place then? Eventually, hotel management relented & said they would accept cash after all - but not before the girls were extremely upset by the whole debacle and tearful at the prospect of perhaps being without a place to stay for the duration of their 9 day stay in Tokyo. I never received a satisfactory answer as to why they could not simply process my credit card of which they had details & I consented to authorize. This would have saved so much anguish.Despite being expert swimmers, these 19 & 1/2 year olds were not allowed to use the hotel pool. Too young! Seriously? Apparently you need to be at least 20 years old to swim or be with a guardian. I know about the age of accountability in Japan and yes I informed management that neither of the girls had reached the age of 20 at the time of booking directly with the hotel. I was assured this posed no problem. At least the girls saved the $23 Aud charge PER PERSON PER ENTRY to the pool charge! So let me get this straight, they can stay without a guardian but they can't swim without a guardian? Their room was supposed to have been a renovated room (yes at extra cost) Renovated when...1989??! Tired, dull & dated sums up their asigned room. At least, it was clean... which is the only reason one star is justified!

My husband and I decided on this hotel as a stopover on the way back from Europe. My friend and her son who live in Osaka, met us at the hotel and spent the 2 nights with us. I am in a wheelchair and the fact that this hotel has 7 rooms was very comforting. The room was quite well laid out for wheelchair access, and reasonably spacious as Japanese hotel rooms go.This hotel is in a great location, close to shops and the exciting spots in Tokyo. The breakfast option of 3 restaurants is great, we decided on the restaurant which had both Western and Japanese breakfast which gave us the opportunity to eat a Japanese breakfast and for my friend to have bacon.

I attended an international conference. Conference facilities were little out of date. The hotel was huge and many good restaurants. Even Sky Bar on the 45th floor. Everybody was very polite, but level of English is poor.Breakfast was dissappointment very little selection. Good hotel if you attend conference, but I would not recommend to families.

My wife and I stayed at this property in September 2014. In our 3 visits to Japan (the others being in 2002 and 2007), Keio Plaza has always been our home away from home in some capacity. The hotel's biggest plus in my opinion is its location. It really is centrally located in the heart of Shinjuku and it's about a 5-7 minute walk to Shinjuku Station if you know where it is (it's very close to Tochomae Station as well). For this year's visit, we stayed at the hotel for 9 days - the longest we've ever stayed at this or any other hotel. In that time, we found that Keio Plaza had not changed much from our previous visits, which some could say is good, while others might say that fact is disappointing. It's true that the hotel could probably stand some renovation, but the fact remains that great customer service, hospitality, and value are more important to me and this hotel still excels at that. We stayed in a Superior, non-smoking room and I thankfully could not detect anything that suggested that someone had disobeyed this rule as some other reviews state. We also selected a package that included breakfast, which was served in the lounge near the front counter. Although the food was generally good, staying with the hotel for that long really had us yearning for some alternative offerings. Some of the offerings included eggs, cereal, bacon, scrambled eggs, smoked salmon, bread, fruit, etc. Again, the food was good, but it would have been nice to see some different items on the menu every couple of days. Speaking of food, don't overlook the fact that there is a convenience store on one of the lower levels. This is EXTREMELY convenient when you want a late night meal or snack and don't want to venture out of the hotel. I THINK it is open 24 hours, but don't quote me on that as I think the latest we went down there was close to midnight. I communicated with the staff in both English and Japanese during our visit and found that their English was quite good, but sometimes we encountered staff that would defer us to another staff member if they weren't comfortable answering something complex. They were always polite though. Keio Plaza also benefits from being the starting place for a number of tours that are run through companies, such as Sunrise Tours. It was very nice to just head to the lobby where our tour guide was waiting for tour participants rather than having to meet them at a station (which we had to do on some other tours). In conclusion, Keio Plaza remains a wonderful property and is perfect for both newcomers and experienced visitors. You can't beat the location and the price of the rooms is very reasonable (good size rooms too). If there is one negative thing to say about the hotel, it's probably that it's a good 2 hours (with traffic) from Narita Airport if you plan to take transportation such as the airport limo. Consider taking the Narita Express train instead as your arrival time into Shinjuku is at least 30 minutes faster and it's cheaper ($15 per person vs. $30). Plus, it's a straight shot from the West exit of Shinjuku Station, so it's very easy to find.

We stayed here at the beginning and end of a tour of Japan. Having stayed in Tokyo some years ago I was surprised by the good size of the rooms in this hotel. An excellent location - near but not too near the station, and with easy access to countless restaurants. The restaurant on the 45th floor is a great place to take breakfast.The rooms are immaculate and well equipped - hard to think of anything else that could be included - and the standard of service is excellent.

We had a lovely spacious room on the 25th floor in the south tower. The view was fantastic overlooking the government building with Mount Fuji visible on clear days in the distance. The maid service was excellent and the room cleaned immaculately each day. The reception staff were helpful and spoke good English especially the lady who helped us out by phoning our tour guide with a query about pick up times. There are plenty of restaurants and shops in the hotel and Shinjuku station is only a few minutes away. it was easy to get to Shinjuku from Keio Plaza just by taking a side exit from the lower lobby which leads to a covered walkway to the station where you can get the metro, buses or overland trains to anywhere you want to go. We stayed for 6 nights at Keio Plaza and it was great

This is an upmarket establishment with great restuarants and a small shopping area. The staff were friendly and spoke English which was a great help in a country where the language is generally not spoken. The were rooms spacious and had everything that was to be expected in such an establishment. The hotel is situated a few blocks from Shinjuku station and close to the downtown buzz of the area.

Room sizes have a bad rap in Japan, and for good reason. Spend the (little) extra and upgrade and normally you won't be disappointed. Service is fantastic and staff are very helpful. The hotel is centrally located with many alternate restaurant options close by. Plentiful shopping options close by. And for the women, Susheido products stock the bathrooms!!!! Good for families.

Tokyo is one of my favourite cities and this hotel is fantastic. The city is expensive but worth every yen! The hotel is close to the biggest metro's in the world, Shinjuku station.from here you can easily visit every place in this big metropol.

We stayed here just recently, like 3 days ago. The booking was made by our travel agent and i was not aware of the renovated/unrenovated rooms. Our agent booked the unrenovated standard room with twin beds... Upon learning that, i decided to email the hotel and asked if we could get the renovated room instead, they replied and said if we want an upgrade of course we need to make additional payment. I decided not to pay extra since we'll be out most of the time but instead requested for a high floor and non-smoking room in the main tower. When we arrived at the hotel, 2 ladies helped us with our luggage to our room. They are so nice and polite. Before leaving the room they greeted us Happy Wedding Anniversary. We went out and came back at night and was surprised to see a box of yummy donut-like cakes with a greeting card from the 2 ladies. I havent seen them since then and never had the chance to say thank you. So i want to give a shout out to Bell Ishioka and Ohashi, that was really thoughtful. We appreciate it.Now back to the room... though it was only a standard and unrenovated it was surprisingly clean contrary to what i read here about the unrenovated rooms. It was not really big but comfortable enough for 3 people. It has a good view of the sorroundings, Tokyo Metropolitan Building and Hyatt which are just across the street. Aircon is quiet. But poor wifi. But not a problem to us since we have portable wifi....Toilet is clean and complete with basic amenities, blow dryer etc., even have facial wash....The shuttle bus service is good going to and from the airport, disneyland and disney sea. Always on time.There's a lot of nearby shops/resto around the Hotel, like Denny's (24 hrs), McDonald's(24Hrs), Subway, KFC, 7-11/Family Mart, local ramen/noodle shop.... you can find this in the street going to Jr Line (Keio Mall) from the Hotel.The only thing that i dont like in this Hotel is they dont have a complimentary bottled water. The mini bar has 2 bottled water and 2 asahi beer which are overly priced.... Aside from that everything is okay.

The Keio Plaza was definitely a higher standard than the places we usually stay, but the prices were very good. We booked online 2 months ahead and got a discount. The rooms are very large by Japanese standards, and have nice fittings and a fancy marble bathroom. The beds are firm and comfortable and the shower was great too. We were on the 26th floor and had impressive views of the city stretching to the horizon with only a couple of tall buildings near by. Free wifi was great. The bar on floor 45 is worth checking out! The staff were very polite and helpful and assisted us in booking tickets to things and also made a doctors appointment for us. The location is great, not far from Shinjuku station which is a major train hub from which you can pretty much get anywhere. From the airport however we got a bus from Airport Limousine Transfers which took us directly to the hotel and was very easy. There are so many food options nearby, and convenience stores, and it's all very safe (but then I never felt unsafe in Japan).Would definitely recommend this hotel and will probably return one day!

Stayed there 3 nights for a meeting. It's quite pricy and the negotiated price was more expensive that the online one! The hotel is well located and quite comfortable but services are expensive. The most frustrating was the Internet. It kept cutting out and in the meeting room it was ridiculous. It's ok to charge a high price but then services have to follow. It's crazy to have bad internet in Tokyo!

The Keio Plaza Hotel is easily reached from the West exit of the Shinjuku station. When you exit the station you will see a roundabout. Keep to the left, following the contour of the road. There are signs in the station showing the direction of the hotel, but once you reach the exit it's not as clear. There is a long covered walkway (similar to an underground walkway). It's a healthy 10 to 15 minute walk. The hotel will be on your left as you approach the open air.  Entering the lower floor next to the bakery go upstairs on the escalator to the large open lobby area. This is one of the nicer aspects of the hotel.  We found our room reasonably nice. It was spacious, had a good view and the beds were comfortable. The room was quiet. The decor was older and perhaps leaned a little bit toward shabby (wrinkles in the wallpaper and slightly discolored). We found the staff, the bell captain and the servers in the restaurant courteous and respectful.  If you exit directly opposite the bottom of the escalators by the cloak room there are far more choices of restaurants in the next couple of blocks. In fact, if you exit and take the road perpendicular to this side of the hotel (just to the right of the exit doors is a crosswalk), walk straight and you will almost come directly to the Odakyu Station, where you can get your free pass for a trip to Hakone.
