We also visited Kawagoe (an Edo era town/city) from the train station alongside the Prince Hotel, which is about 10 minutes from the Keio Plaza Hotel. Hakone is 1 1/2 hours by Romance train and I believe Kawagoe was about 45 minutes. Both worthwhile jaunts for a daytrip. Breakfast is served at a number of locations. The buffet on the lower floor is the best though a visit to the Sky restaurant for a simpler breakfast is good for the view. Your breakfast coupon will specify a location for breakfast. You can always ask the manager for a change of venue.

Keio Plaza is located within walking distance from Shinjuku Station. The airport bus from Narita and Haneda stops at this hotel. A huge hotel with plenty of restaurants. Rooms are big when compared to other hotels in the area. Wifi is also available in the room. There is also a metro station just a few steps away from the hotel which goes straight to Tsukiji Fish market. There is also a convenient store at the basement which closes at 2am. I enjoyed the stay very much. The mattress is too hard for me though.

Pros:• Top-notch customer service• Spacious room with amazing view of the city• Short walk away from Shinjuku train station and surrounded by shops & restaurants• Airport transfer bus service availableCons:• Breakfast closes at 9:30 am even on weekends, which is a bit early

Stayed at the Keio Plaza on my first trip to Tokyo and could not have been more pleased. I found everything, from the large room to location and couteous staff, to be perfect for a tourist in lively Shinjuku.I chose to pay a bit extra for the Plaza Premier rooms and it was well worth it for access to breakfast and lounge facilities.Room was large, comfortable and refurbished, with the bathroom having the best amenities of any hotel. Bath bombs were appreciated to treat tired feet!The concierge staff were excellent and were able to confirm bookings for tours for me. Check in staff had conversational english skills and I did not find communication to be a problem.Proximity to Shinjuku station made getting around a breeze with a Pasmo card.A big plus for this hotel is that is is a shuttle bus stop for both the Airport Limousine Bus and Disney Good Neighbour bus, which made transport to and from the airport and disneyland incredibly easy and efficient.The hotel restaurants are not cheap, with the exception of the one on the 42nd floor - steak dinner for aud$19 was perfect the night before an early flight. Would not hesitate in booking the Keio again for my next visit to Tokyo.

Stayed in the king room which was spacious and very clean. Great location near the main train station and shopping area.Airport bus service drop off at the hotel. We got a package deal with breakfast and booked early for a reasonable price. Great place to stay for a few days if you can get the right deal.

Shinjuku is a great place to stay as it's centrally located. The Keio Plaza hotel is always a nice hotel with a wonderful staff! Everything was in its place and the staff members were always nice. What a lovely place!

Stayed in July 2014, 5 adult family, booked two rooms side by side. Rooms were quite roomy, third bed was a proper bed and not a roll out. Bath in each room and replenished toiletries each day. View from room was of Shinjuku was just lovely. This hotel is within walking distance to Shinjuku station and also the streets of intense shopping that surround the station. Also park opposite street. Very happy with room and position. Also, staff were able to assist us with shipping back excess shopping. Don't swim at hotel though, they charge extra to use pool. For us this wasn't a problem as weather was cool. Most things within the hotel were expensive, but so much else to choose from just outside your door. Would stay again.

My weeklong stay at Keio Plaza was fine. You can't beat the location just a few minutes from Shinjuku station. The staff was helpful, courteous, and spoke enough English to communicate perfectly well. There are many dining options, a little convenience store, and a great bakery all on site. My room in the main tower (3111) had a wonderful view, was spacious, and was spotlessly clean except for the carpet which is badly in need of cleaning. The downside to the room was the constant beep-beep-beep of the signal allowing cars to pull out of the lower level parking area. The beeping finally stops late at night but it is incredible irritating. If it is that loud on the 31st floor, I'd hate to be lower!The bus from the airport drops you off right at the front door and is easier than taking the train. I would stay at this hotel again on a future trip.

Nice hotel in the middle of BUSY Shinjuku. The rooms are large and amenities good. In walking distance to the train station. It would be nice if they had wifi in areas of the hotel outside of the hotel rooms.

We were booked in to this hotel by our cruise operator Princess for a 2 night stay that ended up being four nights due to a typhoon. The hotel is excellently located in Shinjuku and is a large hotel with lots of eating options (expensive versus eating in Shinjuku or anywhere else in Tokyo). We stayed in room 3105 - a big room and well appointed. We would have no hesitation in staying here again particularly if staying more than one night - there are, of course, cheaper options. If you find yourself in the area, the train station is an easy walk, as is the ATM at the Post Office. Many places to eat but do go to Stand Up Sushi - we loved it!

The Hotel was very flashy, all the bells and whistles, made an impact on arrival and the location was great- close to Shinjuku Station as well as subways but it lacked the friendly atmosphere you would expect in an International Hotel. The staff could hardly speak English , including check in and check out staff. We stayed for a week and could not get into any of the Hotel restaurants. The room service menu was not to good either- nothing for children except a hamburger, unfortunately not the type of hamburger a child would eat from Western country. We got a newly renovated room.... sorry not sure what they consider renovated or new- hideous bathroom that you could hardly move in, wallpaper was peeling and the dust! Housekeeping was not exactly on the ball at this Hotel. Overall average - fantastic location but I would never stay there again.

A very large hotel close to Shinjuku station. Our room was large and provided an introduction to Japanese all singing and dancing loos!! There were plenty of amenities in the room, although coffee would be useful in addition. The breakfast buffet was extensive, providing western and Japanese choices. A chef was in hand to make omelettes to suit. The fruit selection was the best of all places used in our tour of Japan. We also had a meal at the buffet in the evening. Again there was a great choice of food, especially the starters and desserts. However, there are plenty of places to eat nearby. The staff tried to be helpful and many spoke a little English.

The Keio Plaza hotel is just 3 minutes walking distance from Shinjuku Station, the main station in Tokyo. You can easily access the station, then shopping and dinning. From Nareta airport, we took the Limousine bus, which took us to the hotel's door. We don't need to take the luggage taking the train. The hotel equips with several optional for breakfast, which are too good to choose one per day. The room are big with two beds and sofa, nice view. The last problem you may say it’s expensive? No, we booked via the airline package and the cost was fare. I’ll choose Keio Plaza next time.

Stayed there for 7nights for our family holiday, they decided to stick us in the south tower, old, smelly and uninspiring as we got shown into the room. Felt like screaming as the following 7 nights in that room seemed so long n dark. Couldn't wait to get out of the place every morning.

Keio Plaza Hotel is located conveniently in Shinjuku, a few minutes walk from all the activity. It is also right next to Tochomae station. It is close enough to the centre of Shinjuku to be accessible whilst far enough for it not to be among the hustle and bustle at night. The location is definitely key to Keio Plaza Hotel.The hotel provides ample amenities and is well decorated however for the price I feel Keio lacks that something to make it distinctive.Saying that Keio Plaza Hotel performs well all round with good size rooms (especially for Japanese standards), good furnishings and service.

I stayed here for two nights on business with three people in a room with two double beds and a pull-out couch -- needless to say it was quite crowded! Although space was tight, it was not necessarily uncomfortable and I was able to get a good night's sleep. The location of the hotel is perfect for tourists and offers a great view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. The hotel catered all of the meals which consisted of mostly bland Western-style meals. I think you will have better luck going out on your own and finding some place to eat, since the restaurants in the hotel are quite overpriced. There is a convenience store on the lower floor of the hotel which is good for a quick snack. The common areas and lobby of the hotel were clean and pleasant to be in. My only complaint is that they would not allow guests to use the stairs, even though queues for the elevator exceeded 20 minutes at times.

We were on our honeymoon, so we wanted some luxury. And I think we got what we wanted. Nice, big and clean room, good service and great location. Shinjuku station was very close so it was easy to move from place to place. There is also a lot of restaurants nearby. And we really liked the fast paced city and all the lights at night. There is a fast internet acces for free. We tried one of the hotels many restaurants: Teppan-Yaki restaurant Yamanami. It was worth it! We booked a table the night before so we got to sit next to the chefs and it was nice to watch them work and do their magic. Food was great. We also went to have a drink at the Skybar Polestar on the 45th floor. What a scenery! (Even thought it says on my review that we stayed on october 2013, we really stayed on august 2013.)

Overall the hotel is good for its strategic location, nearby subway, eateries, shopping and etc. The hotel is located at West exit at subway, about 5 mins walk from station. However, there are East, West, South, North exit and the station is huge, you might got lose at the station if you are first timer. There is airport limo bus stand nearby. However, ticket are available at the hotel. They provide Disneyland and Disneysea free shuttle bus everyday. But you can to prebook early as the last bus always fully booked 2 days in advance. Sunrise tour can arrange pick up to daytour, which is convenient for those who want to join local tour. One complaint is that the air cond will be auto switched off from 1-3am, it is a bit stuffy and I woke up few days to adjust the temperature. However, it could not be done. The amenities are good and moisturising, feel free to use it. Staff can speak English and they help you whenever you ask them for itinerary recommendation. They provide print out guide as well.

Extremely clean with great rooms.Only a short walk to the subway station . It's a really grand hotel at downtown Tokyo but very quiet inside. The restaurants in the hotel are lilltle bit expensive but worthy.

Good size room for family travel in Tokyo city. Breakfast is great. We can have a choice of buffet spread or the typical Japanese Breakfast. I must say the overall service standard deteriorates during each of stay.This is sometime really lacking in Japanese service standard as the staff are not that friendly and courteous. Everyone is just rushing to get their job done. I choose the hotel when I visit Tokyo with my family each year is mainly due to the location and the good room size.The reception staff really need to brush up in their deliverance of guest service and live up to the Japanese culture and mannerism.

Spent 4 nites in this lovely hotel. Definitely a good rest after a 5 hrs shinkasen ride from Takayama/Nagoya.Choose this hotel becos the location and convenience.- Near to Shinjuku station, about 8 mins underground walk to the hotel- Convenient airport shuttle of 2460YEN to Haneda Airport- Free Good neighbourhood of Disney so was able to stay till the park close and catch the last bus @ 10.30pm back to hotel- Pick-up point for japanican toursRoom- Big and spacious room with full amenities, clean and quiet- Love the long counter for using the notebook with 2 arm chair and small table for meals- Bathroom is also huge

Fair location if you like shinjuku, expensive restaurants in the hotel but it has a good gift shop in the basement. Not too kid friendly and we spent three nights there. Do not provide sufficient shuttles to Disneyland. Breakfast spread is fine. Shops and eateries outside the hotel are ok. I would expect better rooms for that price even though it was clean and the service was good.

The hotel is a short, direct walk to Shinjuku station, making the Narita Express and using the subways a winning proposition. The area is also filled with cheap, easy dining options and convenience stores.Location is the prime reason I booked this hotel. I stayed before in 2008, and it was as good as I remember. But for the rate paid, don't expect too many frills. I liked the size of my room (Deluxe, in the main tower), and the view was great. However, the rooms need updating. Plus, the bathroom is same quality as you might find at a Toyoko Inn (for fraction of price!)The other detractor was how pricey room service is at the hotel. Definitely venture out or use the online food delivery options, such as Domino's. There are restaurants in the hotel, but they are very pricey. It is Tokyo, I know, but you can find more reasonable options outside.

This is an absolutely enormous hotel in the centre of Tokyo. It is clean, comfortable and efficiently run. There is free Wi Fi in the bedrooms and you are given full written instructions when checking in. In spite of its size it was very quiet and I had an excellent nights sleep.

Very convenient spot. Make sure you go one level below lobby and exit EAST entrance, cross the below ground-level road and head east, with no more traffic and direct 4 minutes walkway to Shinjuku station of Tokyo Metro. From there, you can go anywhere metro or out of metro. Rooms are quiet, large and comfortable. Good quality and fast free wifi. Well worth the extra money. Color coded railway map from the hotel would help unless you can read Japanese maps posted in the railway station hall, though once in trains, all stations are listed in Japanese and English and anouncements in tourist popular lines are all bilingual.

We spent two nights at the Keio Plaza in Tokyo in a Western-style room. We were pleasantly surprised that the room was a good size, and very quiet. The hotel is located in the quieter West Shinjoku, not far from the JR station; however we still got lost once when returning from central Tokyo. Breakfast in the top-floor restaurant was very good, with a magnificent view from all sides. The layout wasn't terribly efficient at peak times, as the buffet was ranged around four sides of a square bar, with only one-way traffic. A big thank you to the Concierge who managed to find me some English teabags for a welcome cuppa. We recommend this hotel.

We have just spent five nights at this excellent hotel. Fantastic location, nice and spotless room with great views. Plentiful western breakfast. Despite the amount of rooms and people moving around, the rooms were perfectly isolated from any kind of noise.I would like to thank particularly the Guests Relationship Manager (whose name I don't remember) who arranged us a private tour to Nikko at a very short notice, when all the tours were completely full. We found the staff highly efficient, helpful and professional.I strongly recommend this hotel.

i just love this hotel and its facilities. ever since i stayed there in 2008, my brother and i have joined their Executive membership. we were going to Tokyo often and the points chalked up and could be sued for rooms and F7B which was very nice. however since the Tsunami incident we have stopped visiting Tokyo and i think our points would have lapsed. it would be good for them to retain our points and encourage us to stay at their other hotels in other parts of Japan, like Sapporo. the hotel is modern and the rooms are so spacious we just love it. the room is equipped with everything we want and if you are ever short of anything they will bring them to you in a buzz. membership also brings the conceige and checking in/out at special counter too. the restaurants are first class and we have tried all of them. we seldom eat at a hotel's restaurants but at keio Plaza we do that quite often they have bus rides to Tokyo Disneyland too as an excellent service once when we brought our nieces and in-laws as well to visit Tokyo. the hotel is situated near a sgort walk to Shinjuku train Station where you can connect to almost anywhere to other parts of the city. across the street you find cafes and also lots of ramen shops. also nearby at i think Mitsubishi building they have on the top floor the best miyazaki beef ever !!!

I stayed for 4 night on business trip. Great location, spacious room, very clean and quiet. Wifi in the room is very strong. Airport Limo service right at the hotel door (to/from Narita & Haneda), couldn't be more convenient. Subway station is around the corner of the hotel, Shinjuku station is only a short walk.Hotel staff is very helpful and polite, they all speak fluent English. There are lots of restaurants and one convenient store inside the hotel.

Nice friendly hotel well placed in the city centre. Rooms well appointed. Very nice American breakfast Buffet served on the 45th floor with great views across the city, Not so many facilities but nice pool open in summer. Can't really find any fault with the hotel.

This is a lovely and very well equipped hotel, especialy for the first time visitor to Japan and, more specifically Tokyo. There is an airport limosene bus service (a very nice way of saying a bus service) direct from Narita Airport to the front door of the hotel which is situated smack bang in the middle of Shinjuku with all its shops, offices, bars, parks and restaurants. But you don't really need to leave the hotel as it has a vast array of restaurants and facilities too should the weather be inclement. Not being able to speak Japanese is no barrier - the staff are very attentive and polite. I was there for a conference and everything wenty like clockwork.

This hotel has a great location in Tokyo. It is right in the Shinjuku area, close to train stations and taxis. It is a walking distance to lots of bars, restaurant and ofcourse karaoke! It has maginificant sky bar with great views of Tokyo. It was my second stay at this hotel in 8 years and I must say that nothing really changed in terms of the decor and look and feel of rooms. The rooms are decent but needs modernisation and wifi is non existent in the lobby, only in the hotel room. So these 2 aspects need to be improved.

Stayed for 4 nights while on business in Japan. The Keio is conveniently located near Shinjuku station, so you can easily commute using the Tokyo public transportation. You can expect a good sized room, the mattress is on the hard side. There is an electric teapot, and tea; if you want coffee, it can be bought in the convienence store on the second floor.There are lots of restaurants in the hotel, but those are rather pricey. Being located in Shinjuku, you get lots of eating (and shopping) options nearby.We had a package that included breakfast, it was a small, but convenient buffet with fruit, eggs, cold cuts, cereal and pastries. Good, but nothing really memorable.Expect excellent service from everyone working there.

A great hotel in a very handy location, located beside many reatuarants and about a 3 minute walk from Shinjuku statiom and the Odakyu Line. The hotel is modern and with olenty of nice features. I stayed on level 38 wtih a room facing the Goverment Tower. Fantastic view, large size rooms and very quiet. I will always stay at Keio Plaza moving forward.

The room just like other Japanese room, small and got high tech closet. The hotel is located in shinjuku area and surrounded with office building.The breakfast was not so great, they have a small sized restaurant even though they opened other restaurant to accommodate the guest but still the queue was massive and both restaurant didn't serve the same menu.

Located in one of the most representatives neighbourhoods in Tokyo, near one of the most crowded stations of the world, this luxury hotel is situated in the ancient skyscraper in Shinjuku-ku. There you can find many good restaurants (from Japanese, Korean food to Italian and french specialities cooked with semplicity and care), shops, a gym and a pool (which requires an admittance fee of 1200 yen). The staff is efficent and english speaking (which is not so easy to find in Japan), they will give you all the information you need. From the hotel itself daily trips can be organized within and outside Tokyo and there's also a bus service with will allow you to get to the Narita Airport in less than two hours. The closest supermarket is near Tochomae metro station (not very far from the hotel really, the Maruetsu supermarket it's about 20 minutes by walk) but there's a little supermarket in the hotel, even though it's a little more expensive). The rooms are very comfortable, incredibly clean and provided with all you might need and more. The breakfast is quite an experience if your package includes the continental one: it's served in the Jazz bar on the main floor in a very relaxing room and it consists of a very fine buffet. In case you choose the Japanese breakfast, you'll be asked to go to the restaurant on the 45th floor where a wider buffet is disposed, but I think it's a little inferior in quality and, besides, you can't enjoy the same atmosphere of the other type of breakfast.

We had a fantastic time for a week in this hotel as a base to explore Tokyo. We had a refurbished Executive room which was wonderful , great size, lovely bathroom (mad flashy toilets!!) with a great executive lounge which had canapés, beer and wine in the evenings with the most stunning views over Tokyo. WE also had an executive breakfast deal which was brilliant with a good selection of breakfast things in a lovely set up and personal service.Perfect for jet lag! We tried several of the restaurants which were surprisingly good value. The coffee house on the 45th floor of main tower was fantastic. Great value , wonderful service and an even better view. NOT a coffee house to me just lovely! The Italian was great and good value although wine a bit pricey and the Teppanaki great taste and experience but rather expensive. The other small restaurants there however looked a real find when we went past on our last night so I would suggest you go and look at them as they looked really different and not what I was expecting .Finding the hotel was easy thanks to advice from another Tripadvisor review which is a big help....you can get there either by the Narito Express to Shinjuko and then follow the signs to the WEST exit. Walk out of there and follow signs to the government metropolitan building and you will bump into the hotel in under ten minutes...it's opposite the GMB! The Haneda bus stops at the hotel door so that is also fantastic! The final note is the staff in this place. I read some reviews saying that they did not speak english or were not helpful and I cannot disagree more. The staff here are amazing...every person was so help and polite from the bell girl who helped us with our bags and the girl on reception to the managers and the team who showed you in at breakfast. I was bowled over and we cannot compliment the team on their service more. What wonderful charming people. Great hotel but also location good with loads in walking distance and a couple of smaller western places opposite e.g. a stark bar called Sizzlers which is good to go to until you are feeling brave about trying more adventurous food!Well done Keio Plaza Hotel your staff are fantastic!

I have stayed here many times. The staff has good English skills. Hotel has many policies for frequent guests. One I really like is being able to store luggage here for return trips. It saves so much packing and unpacking if you are a frequent visitor to Tokyo. Restaurants excellent. Walking distance to shinjiku station one of the busiest in the world. Rooms small but very comfortable. WiFi in rooms. Easy computer set up. Good business center . had business cards made in Japanese on back in 24 hours. All my business contacts know hotel location without directions. Very well known business hotel.

Location; only 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station. Walking distance to Isetan, Takashamaya, Keio Plaza, lots of shopping options!Food: The sushi restaurant in the hotel is amazing! Expensive but amazingConsLuxe Lounge is not very Luxe, you can have coffee and a pastry, view is quite nice but not the kind of club access that you would expect at a 5 start hotel.Rooms are nice but nothing special, good size for japan but beds were not that comfortable. (we stayed in the newly renovated South Wing)Room service was not very impressive, experience and food not great.

Location is good and nearby metro but pricy. Don't take normal room, it is not worth it because the normal room just like 4 starts hotel room. Better to take Premier room if you look for 5 Stars hotel.

I have stayed in this hotel on number of occasions and have always enjoyed my stay up until my recent visit. I must have been allocated one of the most dated rooms they had available (it was like a trip into the 80s). It had an awful stale smell as the room has not been updated in decades. When I complained about the smell and asked to be moved into a different room, staff were extremely unhelpful and argued with me over the phone that the room does not smell. After a long debate, they moved me to a different room that was pretty much the same.Beware when booking this hotel, that some of the rooms are incredible (in main tower) but some in a south tower are awful! Location of this hotel is perfect if you want to stay in Shinjuku, with so many restaurants, shops and train station within walking distance.Overall, the stay was very disappointing as I know from previous experience they can do much better.

Had a wonderful 2 weeks, place lovely, people great, very friendly and warm. You make the effort to speak the language, they are fantastic in helping back. Would recommend Japan to anyone wanting to travel. Busy, interesting, lots of buildings, but well worth it.

We stayed in a 4 person room that was pretty large and had an amazing view of Tokyo. Staff was excellent. Food was very good although expensive but there are many many other food options nearby. Location is excellent. Shuttle to Disney was a great plus. I would definitely stay here again.

My wife and I stayed here from August 16-24. From day 1 to the end of our stay, we have enjoyed its service, its cleanliness, the level of service, and their ability to make guests feel welcome.We have read previous reviews complaining about how the hotel was old. I think we were lucky to have been assigned rooms in one of the newer wings so we didn't feel that it was an old hotel at all. There was just a hiccup around day 3 to day 6 when their internet connection became faulty. Fortunately they were aware of the problem and quickly had people to fix it. If we had any complaints, it was the lack of variety in the breakfast food they served. While they provided 4 different restaurants to choose from for breakfast, the food they served pretty much the same food in all of them. But it is only a minor issue which we are willing to overlook and will not allow it to affect the great experience we had in this hotel.

The Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo was our choice for a quick trip to Tokyo. It is a modern hotel very conveniently located, close to Shinjuku station. The rooms are large for a Japanese standard and clean, but no special views.The hotel has many restaurants at the hotel, all very expensive. But there are also many options and a convenience store nearby.We chose the hotel mainly because of the swimming pool but we were told it was closed.Disappointing.

The Hotel is placed in the lively and picturesque neighborhood of Shinjunku. When the night life explodes only a few blocks away from the hotel, you can find all the kind of restaurants you'd like and crazy Japaneese night clubs or characteristic Love Hotels not far away. But the Keio Plaza Hotel is absolutely quiete and silent for all kinds of needs. The staff is very helpful and professional, even though the baggage carriers barely speak English as almost everyone in Japan unfortunately. The hotel is close enough to the Shijunku Gyoen National Garden, very nice to see, and also to the other very lively and young neighborhood Shibuya, with the famous crossing, the most popular in Tokyo for the quantity of people crossing every time.

I stayed in this hotel in Dec 2013. The airport limousine bus stops directly at this hotel, and if you are hotel guest, you can book your airport return trip from the dedicated counter just beside the concierge, all within 10mins, very easy. The check-in process was a little slow, there were many guests checking in at the same time. We booked a triple room (3 single beds), and the room is very spacious! We didn't have the time to check out the gym or pool, but the room is very clean, and the room service ladies are very polite! This hotel is conveniently located in Shinjuku area, just opposite the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. Shinjuku station is just a 5-10mins walk away (5-mins walk if you do the Japanese pace, 10mins walk for the average tourist!). There is also the Odeo subway line (exit just below the Metro. Govt. Buildiing), which is much closer to the hotel. There are a couple of 24hr convenience stalls nearby within walking distance.The hotel is located on the west side of Shinjuku station, so do make sure you get out from the correct exit (there are many!!), if not you might spend quite some time 'exploring' the station! In the 6 days I've stayed there, I've got lost in the station twice!Do make time to visit the Tokyo Metropolitan Govt. Building, they have a free observatory on the top level! Shopping and food places are in abundance within Shinjuku area, so you almost never have to leave the area.Do check out Don Quixote, its 24hours and they sell lots of quirky items (from household cleaning items to second-hand luxury bags!), and BIG camera for electronics!

The Hotel is very well located, close to Shinjuku station. Standard comfort room clean.From the room we got, we had the chance to see the Fuji Mount, amazing experience.Personnel extremely kind, more than the average, already high standards in Japan.There are several options of restaurants and even a small convenience store in the hotel basement area.

We split our stay in Tokyo so we could stay in a couple of different areas. We stayed a few nights in the Keio Plaza and moved to the Ginza area for the end of our trip to Japan. The Keio Plaza was at a great location next to the Shinjuku station and shopping malls. Very large and modern hotel with a nice outdoor pool. Staff were so polite and helpful just like all the other hotels we stayed in Japan. Also within walking distance to the Golden Gai bars and the Robot Restaurant. Only downside was the swimming pool charge-14 EUR per person is a bit excessive. Would still recommend the hotel regardless and it was also suggested by other friends who previously visited Tokyo.

Stayed for 8 nights recently. Premier room which is worth the extra $. Overall this hotel is looking tired, gym hardly worth it and where else anywhere do they charge hotel guests to use the swimming pool?! But service is very good and location convenient. Have a drink at the top level bar - great view!

This is a big hotel, but the rooms, amenities and service are all of a high standard. The hotel is next to a major subway station for easy travel to other Tokyo neighborhoods. It is also next to Tokyo City Hall, which offers a great view of the city from its 45th floor. For rainy days the hotel provides many Japanese and international dining options. We liked the Duo French and Italian restaurant, the soba noodle shop, and the Glass Court buffet of western and Asian dishes.

My second time staying in this hotel. Great location...just minutes away from Shinjuku JR station with many shopping and restaurants around the area. They even provide free shuttle service to Disneyland/Disneysea which is very convenient for us as we are travelling with a 3 year old. Stayed at the main building, the hotel room is spacious considering how tiny hotel rooms can be in Tokyo. Would definitely stay there again.

I brought my mom to Tokyo for summer holiday. This hotel is at its perfect location. Bus from Haneda Airport stopped right at the entrance of this hotel. Though this is a massive hotel and check in can be very busy, they are well organised and you will get your room in no time! Very efficient. We had the newly renovated room which was excellent. Book any tours from Sunrise Tours and you get pick up at the lobby. Since its in Shinjuku area,you couldnt asked for a better location. Malls,train station and restaurants are within minutes by walk. I recommend highly on this hotel. For what you are paying,you get a nice decent room too,as in Japan,rooms can be really tiny. I will definitely come back to Keio Plaza!!!

Great location. The hotel is very convenient to access from Shinjuku JR Station and meet standard requirement. BUT if you are non smoker, please consider again to book this hotel because they don't care for non smokers even you requested for non smoking room in advance. Non smoking room is something on request only for this hotel and not guaranteed that you will get it. It was my real experience here. I was stayed here for 2 period, and my first stay I was in a smoking room where I almost die with the cigarette smell in the room. I suffered a lot for a whole night. And when I checked out I told the staff who checked out for me to book me on non smoking room for next visit he said NOT GUARANTEE and ON REQUEST ONLY (My original booking also requested for non smoking room in advance).When I checked in for the 2nd period, I got a smoking room again. My request was useless. So I asked the staff who checked in for me for non smoking room. She said need to wait, I will get it if available. So almost 20 minutes at the counter I got the non smoking room finally. This is shown that my advance requested is useless. The hotel never care for non smokers at all.

This was my first visit to Tokyo. The location was perfect for both for walking around and getting to other parts of Tokyo for business.The room was comfortable and the bathroom was amusing for the heated, self-cleaning facilities. I had no issues with the WiFI.The two things I enjoyed most were the breakfast area, where I had a great 3 hour breakfast meeting in comfortable surroundings, and the wide variety of restaurants in the hotel. While there are number of good restaurants in the area, I particularly enjoyed the Kagari restaurant. It introduced me to a number of dishes I had not seen in the SF Bay Area at any of the local Japanese restaurants.

Excellent location within 5-6 minutes of Shinjuku Station, giving you ready access to everything Tokyo has to offer with buzzing nightlife right there.Hotel building is large, probably built in the 1980's with functional public areas - though not particularly memorable. Feels a bit impersonal (but that is after staying at Hotel Okura, so may not be a fair comparison).Stayed in a Superior renovated room on the 31st floor. Room is large and very comfortable.We booked a package that included breakfast which was served in the lounge just off the lobby. Breakfast was "western" style and very good.I would absolutely stay here again when in the Tokyo area.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel for a total of 5 nights in July.My only complaint would be that for an international hotel very little English is understood even booking in one resorts to charades and pointing at pictures and maps.The standard below average. My one saving grace was a bellboy Oshiro who had studied in USA for 2 years so had some command of the English language.If staff cannot communicate at least have an interpreture that can.I was booked into a standard single room and one could not complain more than enough room with a double bed in fact I was on the 24 th floor of the Main Tower and looked over the Govt Offices over the road.I had requested a non smoking room but was given a smoking room but could not detect smoke so stayed in that room.On my return visit of 1 night I was given a non smoking room on the 19th floor of the Main Tower and overlooked the pool.For travellers just be aware of the Accomodation Tax which is paid on departure from the hotel It is calculated on a scale of Hotel Room Charge (per person per night) less than Y1000 free,Y10000 - 14999 Tax Y100 and Y15000 and over tax Y200per night I was unaware of this and paid Y900 on departure and my fellower travellers for what ever reason did not have to pay !!!! go figure.I thought that I had checked every thing out but missed this little detail and my travel agent did not inform me either .The tax is collected so as to cover expenses for tourism promotion.My room on both occasions was excellant the bathroom great and well appointed with toiletries as well as disposable slippers.If you look in the draw you will find a Kimono I am not sure of the cost to purchase but one can have fun playing dress ups.

I was very Disappointed when i arrived to my room.It was very old, and had bad smell.It had Lame bathroom and shower, bad bed, and the WIFI was very slow.The location is great but there are many other better hotels in this area.Not worth the price.

We had the superior renovated room with 3 single beds. Our room was on the 28th floor and faces the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. Free viewing gallery is on the 45th floor, go there at night will see the night scenes of Tokyo. It closes at 10.30pm, we managed to go up there on our last night. There's a direct pass from the hotel to go over, just ask the concierge to show you. Location is great, if you walk above the ground, it will takes you about 8 mins to the world's busiest station - Shinjuku. Get out of the station using the WEST exit. Mind you, Shinjuku is huge, depending on which subway line you take, you could end up exiting at different exit at the WEST exit each time.Luckily Keio Plaza is opposite Tokyo Metropolitan Building, so looking for the signboard that says "Tokyo Metropolitan" helps tremedously. There is an underpass linking the hotel to the Shinjuku station, we managed to use that 1 of the day, but subsequently, we didn't manage to locate this exit. But walking above the ground is better, shorter and able to enjoy the sights and the many skyscrappers in that area. The staff were very helpful and give very good advices on how to go to the places of interest.The best thing about this hotel is that they are 1 of the Good Neighbour of Disneyland, so there's a free shuttle that brings you to the resort. However, there's only 3 timing and you have to make reservation in advance. If you can, write to the hotel and make your reservation for the Disney shuttle. Having the shuttle to send us back from Disney Resort to the hotel is so good, especially after a long and fun day, just need to wait at the bus stop for the shuttle bus. Otherwise, you have to make your own way back, having to hop on the subway and transfer to different lines .There were 3 of us in the room, and we were so impressed and touched when we saw that the housemaid left 3 different colour tooth brush each day ! It is these action that make this hotel special. We really can't fault the Japanese, the service is first class.The airport limo calls at the hotel and there's a convenience store within the hotel. What more can you ask. Overall, we are very happy with our stay. We will be back at this hotel again, I'm very sure.

Location in shinjuku is fantastic. Only 10 mins walk to the station, and en route you have plenty of shops to view. Hotel is rather older - but is under renovation i think. Room size is very good. Bed is comfortable and for the price, i'd say fantastic. The breakfast in the hotel comes in 3 styles in 3 different restaurants for our choice - japanese, continental and cafe style. Worth the money.

I stayed at Keio Plaza, Shinjuku from 24th to 28th July. I was really impressed by the comfort of the room and the service provided by the staff. The room came with everything you can think of to make it a home away from home. The appearance, view, bedding, linen, lighting, amenities, toileteries, slippers, bath robes, kimonos, etc. etc. etc were all of very good quality and standard. Toilet seats were heated to exact body temperature! The staff were extremely friendly and spoke English very well. Only thing I missed was the English Breakfast Tea. But the 'Roasted Tea' provided compensated well. As many reviews before this said the location of the hotel makes it a great place in terms of accessability to public transport services too. I will stay there when I visit Tokyo next time. And I can recommend it to anyone who is looking for luxury at affordable prices.
user_name:
Nilmin P
Riyadh Province, Saudi Arabia

review_body: My family of 4 stayed in a 4 bedded family room that was spacious and we had a beautiful view of the Tokyo skyline from our room window at level 31. The room has 2 bathrooms . I would highly recommend families of four to stay in the family room category. There is free wifi in the rooms.Our room came with breakfast. I would recommend taking the international Buffett breakfast at the GlassCourt cafe. You will have a wide selection of breakfast menu that includes a choice of American and Japanese breakfast menu.Housekeeping was excellent and so was the hotel check in and porters. The staff speaks fluent English and was very helpful in giving directions and maps to get to the various locations by train.The proximity of the Shinjuku train station (it's really a huge station and about a 8-10 mins walk from the hotel ) was a bonus . There are several big departmental stores that are built above the station and needless to say restaurants , cafés and convenience stores are aplenty at the station. Getting to and from the airport is a breeze as the airport shuttle limo bus picks up passengers from the hotel lobby. You can buy the limo bus shuttle tickets from the porters. Most major tour operators like Sunrise Tours Japan also pick up and drop off tourists who sign up for their day tours at the hotel - a very convenient feature.The only downside is this hotel is expensive and they are very strict on checkout time which is at 11a.m. We requested for a later checkout but was told its ¥5000 for every hour extended time. My kids (teenagers ) loved the hotel and we would certainly stay there again.

This is my second time staying in this hotel, first time was 8 years ago my first time visiting Japan and first hotel. It is still a great hotel despite being over 40 years old rooms are excellently maintained like new. Great breakfast can select between western restaurant or Japanese restaurant for the buffet breakfast. Staff are all very helpful. For a hotel of age you get pretty big rooms unlike the new hotels smaller rooms.Location is excellent, close to many restaurants and shopping malls and of course the busiest rail station in the world Shinjuku Station.

We stayed for 5 nights in this hotel the location is fantastic there is everything you need around the hotel, restaurants, grocery stores, buses, trains, parks. You can walk underground from the hotel to anywhere great in the wet and the heat of Japan's summer.We stayed in a Double Standard Room non-smoking in the main tower on the 19th floor we had a great view, the room had plenty of space, the king bed was very comfortable (although the pillows were not), the bathroom was a good size, the air conditioning worked well which being summer we needed the room was great. The train station is 3 minutes walking to which you can get the trian to anywhere and very safe at night. The bus stop is across the road.The Concierge were so helpful nothing was too much trouble the language barrier was never an issue we always managed to work through it such a pleasure to deal with everyone in this hotel. All the staff are a credit to this hotel and to themselves, be proud of yourself for making our stay so memorable.The Glass restaurant for breakfast was good, the Sky bar a good place for a pre dinner drink and the view amazing, the bakery has good pastries and the coffee lounge on the lobby level is an excellent place to relax after a long day. We also ate in the French restaurant and the Japanese on the 7th Floor both are a little pricy being in the hotel but worth it we highly recommend the food it was glorious we would eat there again.All the staff could not do enough to help us, the laundry service was fantastic and the packing of your clothes on return was way above expectation thank you.We filled in the Questionnaire as you do then thought well that will be that, a few days after we returned home we got an email from the hotel acknowledging what we had said which shows they do read them and care what we think that impressed us.We will stay in this hotel whenever we return to Japan and highly recommend to anyone staying in Tokyo to stay here, it is very central to the all the sights you would be seeing.We can't thank the staff enough for our wonderful stay. We recommend the Keio Plaza Hotel and we will return one day.We wish you good luck and safe travels.Dallas and Leah Rowland

Stayed here for a week during a business trip to Japan. Nice sized room, good bed, quiet, good location, great view, a 10 except for the front desk staff. Everything we asked was a big deal. They gave me a hard time about upgrading to a better room, although I was willing to pay more money. They gave us a hard time about getting a breakfast voucher for a different restaurant in the hotel. They gave us a hard time about a late checkout. Their VIP fruit plate was a banana, a kiwi, an orange and a bottle of water. But, good sized room for a decent price, so yes, I would stay there again.

Stayed here for twelve nights mid to end of May. Location perfect Shinjuku station few minute walk and subway on the doorstep excellent for commuting to any part of Tokyo. Also subway very clean safe and inexpensive. We had a Plaza Premier room which was in the main tower between 35th and 39th floor. The room was large and equipped with everything you would ever want including free Wi Fi. The views were fantastic out of the full length glass wall which was fitted with electric curtains I do mean this room had everything. Fantastic value for money in Tokyo. Concierge service were very helpful and informative. Yes it is a large hotel but the service we found to be excellent i.e. when my broadband access code ran out after ten days I called reception and was told they would attend to it, much to my surprise two minutes later a young girl was at my door hand delivering a new code now that's service. The room was spotless every day when we returned and the housekeeping were attentive to every detail. I would recommend this hotel to anyone pay the extra for Plaza Premier room money well spent and for Tokyo prices a bargain. One last thing on returning home I received a letter from Toru Higashi of the Housekeeping department thanking me for filling in the Questionnaire in the room I have filled in these questionnaires in hotels all over the world and this is the first time anyone has thanked me for doing so. So this hotel does care what you think. Thank you all at Keio Plaza Hotel for making our stay very enjoyable. Will we be back YES

The rooms are nice but the location is the best thing. It's a 5 minute walk to the Shinjuku station. From there you have access to a plethora of travel options. You can even walk from the station to the hotel in and underground walkway. This was nice when it was raining.We had breakfast a few times at the buffet in the coffee shop. Not cheap but we enjoyed it.WiFi in the room. Good air conditioning (Important in the summer).I will be staying here on my next trip to Tokyo

Visited Tokyo again in Dec 13 for 2 weeks and stayed in a Plaza Luxe Double. The room was big for Tokyo's standard and the view from the room was magnificent, overlooking the nearby park. The complimentary access to the lounge (which i believe was only for those staying on the Plaza Luxe) on the 24th floor was a nice plus, to rest the tired legs with free beers, soft drinks, packet milk for the kids, and snacks. And given the price, i thought it was a great deal altogether.One thing which i would have done more was perhaps to dine at the various restaurants on the way from the hotel to the Shinjuku station than at the hotel itself. While the food at the hotel's restaurant was reasonable, the prices were abit high imo. My previous stay in Tokyo was at Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku. Comparing the two, i definitely go back to Keio again even though it is slightly pricier - for its big rooms which are suitable for small families, and also the free bus rides to Tokyo Disney Land.

Great hotel. Excellent bedding, bath, Wifi, and restaurants. Although the hotel restaurants are expensive you can always find a good eatery across the street. It's a short walk to the Shinjuku station. Learn the easy subway system and you can travel anywhere in and out of the city.The staff is friendly but there are some language barriers. I certainly will return to this hotel. Airport bus stops in front of hotel.

visited this hotel for the first time...good location, the room a little bit old with an old lcd television...but cozy enough for rest. the breakfast is good ,there are many variations.in my op it is recommended hotel

Very near to shinjuku station, very easy acces to haneda and narita airport, the most think i like is the free shuttle to disneyland and disney sea. ( but of courceu have to book very early in advance )I stay there for almost 2 weeks. Room quite big for japanese standard.

This was my fifth stay at Keio Plaza, which I personally regard as the best choice in Shinjuku given its proximity to train stations and shopping areas. The room rates are not cheap, but you get decent sized rooms. There are no trendy and hip design as it's actually an older hotel compared to others, but everything was in good order. Also it's a big and busy hotel with 1000+ rooms so you won't experience much personal touch in the service, but staff are very efficient.My previous stays were in Plaza Premier floors in the Main Tower but this time I chose the newly renovated Plaza Luxe room in the South Tower. The rooms were comfortable and clean as usual, My only negative comment is the rather small size of the TV, but this is actually quite common in Japanese hotels.My stay package this time included breakfast at the coffee lounge on the ground floor and a dinner at the Japanese restaurant. The breakfast featured a smaller buffet than the one offered in the buffet restaurant, but I actually preferred the coffee lounge because it's much quieter and the service was more attentive. The dinner was nice too.The hotel website mentions Plaza Luxe guests could use the lounge located on the top floor of the South Tower, but I was told a coupon was needed for entry. I didn't bother to argue anyway.

Awesome service when arriving to the hotel. Most employees understand English which is a huge plus, definitely when needing directions. The only upset that we had here was going to the pool, having a tattoo will prohibit you to enter. Also, if you're an adult, you got to pay roughly $20 to get in. Overall, besides the pool, a great experience.

Perfect business/convention style hotel as far as location. Rooms were standard - ours was in the older tower/floors- clean and good size shower. Again everything being relevant to Japan size accommodations. Location can't be beat though - few blocks to Shinjuku station above or below ground. Loved that being home base to explore Tokyo while husband was at conference. Restaurants and bars are good - not cheap though - so often left hotel for GREAT meals - much cheaper. Would defiantly stay again.

The location is very practical. However there are several drawbacks to this hotel. The rooms are very mediocre and old fashioned. Bed is hard and trimmings could all do with a makeover. The western breakfast is only served until 9:30am and the range of food is neither particularly fresh nor exciting and the coffee was awful. I hurt my leg and went up to the clinic and the staff couldn't speak any English and couldn't even understand what I was saying. The gym was not cool enough and the range of gym equipment hasn't been upgraded in years. I know this for a fact as I used the gym almost 10 years ago and exactly the same equipment is in place. All this would be ok if the price met the quality level of 3 star but it's definitely overpriced in my opinion.

I love this hotel in term of location. Good location, easy to access from Shinjuku station using underway. The hotel lobby was nice and big. But...The room was pathetic. Very small for 4 stars hotel, bedding was poor, hard, the funiture very old, carpet look not clean because of old, bathroom also old style, overall very pathetic room. For the price almost $200 a night, that was so rudiculous.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is a large facility that is very suitable for business travel and meetings. I shared with a roommate and our room was adequately sized to be comfortable for both of us. The bathroom was clean, contained several amenities, and had a very modern toilet with features. The concierge service was adequately staffed and readily available to provide assistance. As a first time visitor to Japan, I did not like the hotel location because it seemed too far from things I wanted to do but since Tokyo is so vast, according to others the proximity to the subway is a real plus. Room service seemed excessively expensive but there is a convenience shop on the lower level with a wide range of toiletries, beverages, snacks, etc. at very reasonable and affordable prices. The hotel pool was my major disappointment. First and foremost, it is not free to guests. Coming from the U.S., my experience has always been that those staying at a hotel are always able to utilize the outdoor pool. The Keio Plaza charges an additional $20 to go to the pool, even if you just plan to sit outside. (We got the impression based upon observation that there were different prices for different people.) In any event, if you have any tattoo, you are not allowed to go out there. I understood in advance that tattoos are generally forbidden at traditional Japanese onsen or natural hot mineral baths but feel it was overly restrictive and inconvenient for a modern tourist hotel to turn away guests from an average concrete swimming pool in the middle of Summer. I would not stay there on future trips.

I've stayed in this hotel twice.one conclusion:excellent and comfortable !!Rooms in this hotel is very great. the environment is clean and the bed is very comfortable to sleep on.When it comes to breakfast.there might not be many choices,but all of them are delicious !!And this hotel is close to the metro and JR station,it's also convenient to go everywhere you want to go to !

Chose this hotel for two reasons : 1) It's one of the drop off/pick up points for the airport coach but make sure you book a place for your return to the airport because the coaches are not as frequent and they can be full on certain days and certain times. 2) Near to Shinjuku station.Take the hotel's east exit, cross the road and it's a straight walk of less than 10 mins. In fact we stayed here twice - at the beginning of our trip and then on the return leg. Booked the Superior Twin non smoking room in both cases and they were spacious and comfortable. However I reckoned we had a better room the first time round in the Main tower because it felt larger and more modern. Second time we were in the South wing. The difference was that it said ‘renovated ’in the booking details for the Main Tower room.Free Wi-fi in the rooms with excellent signal strength. We took the breakfast option which was served in the Cocktail & Tea Lounge. As its name suggests it's really a lounge and tea venue with low coffee tables and a bit awkward for eating breakfast. On the plus side it's a very relaxing area with ceiling to wall glass windows giving a view of the mini waterfall outside. Breakfast was a decent (but not extensive) western buffet spread. They have a super buffet at the Glass Court on the 2nd floor which is where you will also find a slew of restaurants (French, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Chinese and a coffee house)Hotel has a convenience store on 2F in the South Tower that opens from 5.00 am – 2.30 amOn our last night in Tokyo we had drinks and snacks at the hotel's 45th floor skybar with a splendid view of the city lightsNo complaints and plenty of reasons to stay here again.

Third time at Keio Plaza Shinjuku. Stayed in a refurbished Luxe room. Very nice view from 32nd floor. Everything is clean and nice and comfortable. Safe, free wifi, hairdryer, minibar, coffee maker, ironing facilities. Everything works at Keio and everything is near. A great location for exploring both Shinjuku and whole Tokyo. Shinjuku station just 5-10 min walk away.Breakfast was not included to our room rate this time. There's a Royal Host cafe in the next building, which was a good option (great value) if you want to eat breakfast outside your hotel.Can't wait to go back.

Excellent location being walking distance to the buzz of Shinjuku and easy access to trains. Unfortunately my room was straight out of the 80's. Literally old school. The rest of the hotel was very modern so guessing I was in a wing that had yet to be upgraded as it was in direct contrast to the look and feel of the wider of the hotel. Ok for the 1 night I stayed.

I stayed in this hotel for 3 nghts. The hotel is in a good location. I arrived at Narita and went to Hotel by shuttle bus that just dropped me right in the hotel. The room is quite big for 3 persons. Just only have a little problem when we checked in but the rest was excellent. Fully recommended for the tourist which is the first time visiting Japan.

I stayed again in this hotel last May 2014. This time I took the premier room. Here are the verdicts :Pros: Premier Room- Fast Check in designated premier counter - Spacious room 35 sqm if not mistaken- Nicely refurbished modern style room- Nice lighting- clean and full blown amenitiesGeneral - Well located in Shinjuku- Good service and guest relation officerCons: - No tolerance for late check out (common for hotels in Japan)- Bit pricey but worth it with its quality of serviceHighly recommended and surely will stay again

Stayed at the Keio Plaza, Shinjuku, Tokyo for five nights, I thought it useful to upgrade to receive access to the Executive Club. Don't bother! The club doesn't open til after 10am and offer not much more than an average coffee and limited selection of beer. The food is limited (pretzels and nuts). For the price you pay for access, I say don't bother. The room we received was very basic and the hotel staff are not very friendly or personable. We stayed at other hotel chains throughout our trip to Japan and I should have continued for this leg of our trip. Trust the big chains.

very good and friendly staff, nice and clean hotel. good location, i will chose to stay here again!we stayed in triple bed room, its an extra bed but very comfortable and soft, it's very nice and quiet hotel!

Me, my wife and our daughter can not speak Japanese. We try to get direction in the hotel and every time we got great help. Not that we got answer but each staff in this hotel will try very hard to help is what I want to point out. The hotel is a little old but their staff knows how to and they want to provide good service make the hotel better than the other which is newer.

The Keio Plaza may have been a top Tokyo hotel at one point, but today it is dated and tired. The whole place needs a major refurbishment. And I was not very happy that the receptionist tried to convince me that my room was DEFINITELY a non-smoking room, when there were several ashtrays in the room... On the plus side, the hotel is in a good location, close to Shinjuku Station, and there are lots of lovely small traditional restaurants in the neighbouring streets. I'll try someplace different next time that I am in Tokyo though.

Spacious room with two double bed. Top toiletries. Professionally cleaned room.The view is fabulous. We were there in January and loved the snow view from our room in the high floor. Nice bar and restaurant in the hotel. Department stores, all kinds of restaurants and Subway stations are all within walking distance (pretty close). We had a very good relaxing holiday time there.

I have not been to Tokyo before, am an older single woman and had a difficult time trying to decide where to stay in Tokyo. I had thought I would avoid a western chain type hotel and only had 2 nights so thought this would be a good hotel. I'm also prepared to take a few risks so I caught the rapid Nex train from the airport to Shinjuku Station. It didn't look far to walk but I got lost and it was a little further than it looks. Anyway got there in the end. Lobby and look of the hotel and service was all good. I had booked a luxe room and use of the club lounge. The room was adequate but looked over a very ugly part of the city, was a bit dark and ordinary. The bathroom was fine. Going to sleep was a nightmare. The bed was hard, the pillows even harder despite asking for a softer one. The club lounge was not worth it. I decided I would check elsewhere as I wanted a good sleep. The Hyatt Regency down the road was the same price without the lounge access and I was so glad that I left. I felt much more comfortable there, the bed and pillows were great and the view out of the window was much better. I can't fault the service at Keio but I was not happy and it did spoil my view of how I experienced Tokyo especially when I only had a couple of days stopover on my way home. Next time if I come back to Tokyo I would stay in the central Tokyo district, the Nex (Narita Express) stops there first and its a nicer area if you don't have too much time, plus there is the big park which includes the Imperial Palace just close to the station. I guess it all depends on what you are looking for.

Brief review: - Location? Pretty good. Shinjuku Station is a few stops away from Tokyo Station, making it a good base from which to explore Tokyo. - English-speaking staff? Mostly, yes. Even the bellboys! :) Not to say that all the staff spoke marvellous English, but it was sufficient. - Free wifi? Yes! *thumbs up* Longer review: I stayed here with my mother for 4 nights, and overall it was a good experience. The staff were generally able to speak English (even if it was obvious that it was a bit difficult for some of them). One guy in particular was very helpful in answering our questions about going to Disneyland, and about having our luggage sent ahead of us, but unfortunately I don't know his name so I can't give him the praise that's due to him. :( (He also spoke really good English.) The hotel can be a *little* bit tricky to find, but we managed to get there and after that, finding it again was a breeze. It's about 5 minutes' walk from Shinjuku Station, which is okay if you don't have luggage with you, but if you do then it'll feel much longer than that. Plenty of convenience stores nearby the hotel, which is useful! We arrived a few hours before check-in time and managed to get some preliminary signing-in done, but as our room wasn't ready the hotel kept our bags for us whilst we went out to explore Tokyo for a bit. When we came back several hours later, the room was ready and we found that they'd also moved our luggage into the room for us! +1 right there. The room was rather a pleasant shock - it was pretty large, much larger than I'd expected. The interior design was good; it felt very modern and also kind of soothing. The large space helped, of course. (We booked the room via the hotel's website instead of through Agoda or other channels because there was a discount for a 4-night stay that suited us just fine.)They also had a good selection of TV channels - most of the major Japanese TV channels, and also several English-language ones like CNN, BBC and Cartoon Network.

Rooms are very basic. Location is great for walking & catching the train. Concierge was very helpful. All staff polite & helpful. You are charged for local calls made from room. They are strict about checking out on time but are happy to hold your luggage for you. Go to Keio department store basement for good food option & vegetables that seem to be pretty rare in Tokyo.

This hotel conveniently looked in Shinjuku near to other hotels like Hilton,Hyatt and to the train station.The check in time is 2 pm...hence lot of people in the lobby from 12 noon always awaiting room allocation....quite crowded.The currency exchangeThe currency exchange is through a machine..very low rates..hence never use the same ..better to get the exchange at the airport itself.The rooms are good larger than normal Tokyo hotels but smaller than Hilton. Break fast is served in three restaurants... But unable to make out the difference between the cuisines.The best part is break fast coupons can also be used for lunch or dinner for a pre fixed amount...you can part pay lunch/ dinner through these coupons if you don't use them for break fast. This hotel is patronise more by Japanese tourists than international tourists.Over all ok experience

Well, the structure is a very old one (it seems like my parents had their honeymoon there!). In recent years they have been remodeling the rooms so right now there are new rooms with modern decor whilst the Jurassic rooms still remain. Go to the hotel web-site and investigate thoroughly before you make a decision.This time we booked a Plaza Luxe Room which is located in the South Tower (in other reviews, reviewers call it the ugly tower with elevators NOT directly behind the front desk). In fact one thing to clarify and be careful. There are remodeled rooms in the south tower whilst there are also Jurassic rooms in the main tower. So the tower is not the focus... the room type is. The Plaza Luxe rooms give the guests a nice feeling yet be careful. They have three types of bedding - King/ Queen/ Twin. We booked Queen and it was perhaps a personal mistake. I don't know. I wish I had a tape measure. I found the bed very small. Of course we expected it to be smaller than King but it just felt very small when both of us were sleeping on it.The Plaza Luxe Lounge on the south tower is a new addition to the hotel and is nice. Not a lot of food choices but pleasant enough. We had a Japanese style fresh cream cake which was good.This is also a popular hotel with constantly lots of guests and lots of events. They had some kind of a graduation dinner thing going on during our stay. The basement even has a convenience store which is indeed very convenient. Location wise, around 5-10 mins walk from Shinjuku Station West Exit or they have a complicated underground pass which leads you to a side entrance of the hotel, but we found the street walk much more pleasant than the underground pass.Given the astronomical price tags of other real 5-star international chains, I think we did get a reasonable value out of the USD200 we paid. It's Tokyo after all. But next time I think I must choose a renovated room with a King bed!

My husband and I have stayed at Keio Plaza for 4 nights in our first trip to Japan. We stayed in the main tower and our room was excellent ! service is very good , and one of the big advantages of the hotel is that it is serviced by the limousine bus ! we arrived at Haneda and 50 minutes later were at the hotel ! although it is a big hotel we did not experience any delay at front desk or restaurants . The location is very good , near to Shinjuku station , the most busy subway station in Tokyo ! this region of tokyo is very beautiful , with enormous skyscrappers , parks , hotels , and we loved it !There are numerous restaurants at the hotel , which is convenient , we tried the Tempura and the Italian , and although expensive , they were very good !

We were upgraded to a renovated room, and got both a great room and a wonderful view. The location is good, although a bit boring in the bureaucratic part of Shinjuku. But it is really convenient to be next door to Shinjuku station, and it is also walking distance to Shibuya as well as to Roppongi Hills, so there is not much to complain about. There is a gym, but - as most Asian gyms - it is not great. It is far too hot inside, there is a lack of equipment, such as heavier weights, and it has no atmosphere whatever. To me that is a big minus, since I like to work out every day when I travel (and at home). On the other hand, there is a great skybar, which almost makes up for the gym...;-) And, as mentioned before, it is superconvenient to live right next to Shinjuku station! We took the train to Narita Airport, and it took us exactly 1 hour and 20 minutes from door to door (I cannot understand what some other reviewers said about the train - it takes a lot less time than the hotel limo). We also took the subway to Disneyland, since the hotel shuttle was fully booked. It was incredibly easy and did not take more than 40 minutes, which was also faster than the shuttle.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza during a stay in June 2014 and there are not many things that I can complain about, the hotel gives an extremely nice first impression. We were specific about wanting to have one of the newly renovated rooms in the Main Tower and ended up on the 25th floor with an amazing view over both the Shinjuku station area (which is just as much a shopping area) and the Tokyo skyline (day and night) including the Tokyo Skytree broadcasting tower. Generally speaking the hotel has given the best service I have ever experienced; fresh toothbrushes, combs, slippers and razors every day. Apart from that, the service at the hotel is impeccable: We had quite a few inquiries to the Guest relations office and they served us impeccably every time. They even had readily made maps and how-to guides for guests wanting to take daily trips to either the neighbouring areas Hakone or Yokohama.I can do nothing but recommend this hotel and will most definitely stay there again when I visit Tokyo again

We were booked in here by our travel agent and she failed badly. Yes, the photos look okay but they are very smartly taken to make very old rooms look good!The tip: there are two towers to this hotel - a new one and an old one. You check in (at the semi out of date desk) and they will direct you to either the new lifts which are directly behind the check in desk OR they take you on a short stroll to the old lifts and old tower. Unfortunately this was where we ended up after a 10 hr flight and first stop on our holiday. The room was old, very dated, kind of dirty and the internet was through a router you had to plug in 'on loan' from the hotel! I told my gf not to unpack as we would not be staying in the room. After going back to reception and the staff showing me printed photos of the different rooms, we were able to be moved to the new tower (for a small fee). The new room was good and saved the next 4 days - great view, modern, very clean and comfortable. Location of the hotel is excellent - close to bars, restaurants and amazing shopping. Price was also good but make sure you get a new room!

Staying at the Keio Plaza was pleasant and a good experience. The room was large enough, wifi worked beautifully and the hotel is very well located 5 minutes from Shinjuku station and many restaurants, shops and department stores in the vicinity. We found staff friendly and knowledgable and would be happy to return.

We stayed at the Keio Plaza for 4 nights at the end of June and beginning of July. The lobby in the hotel is large, open and clean. The staff on the front desk all speak good English and were always polite and helpful. Since we were on honeymoon they upgraded us to a Plaza Lux room on the 32nd floor with a direct view of the Tokyo Government building. Our room was a very good size with a decent sized bathroom. The bathroom has a shower\bath combo and come well equipped with a razor, comb, soap etc... The bed was large (king size maybe) and soft with a handy control panel by the side of it for setting alarms, radio and charging point. Our room came with power adapters for you to use which is not something I've seen in a hotel before (even some of the 5 star ones). You get the standard dressing gown, but you also get 4 traditional Japanese gowns (not Kimonos) the name of which escapes me at the moment! The wifi is free, easy to setup and quick. The hotel is located about 10 minutes from Shinjuku station which can be reached either from the front of the hotel and walking towards Keio shopping centre or through the back and through an underpass. There are a few selections for breakfast, but we found there was always a queue and you had to wait for up to 15 minutes. The breakfast was good, but I have marked it down due to the waiting times.

Location - Keio Plaza Hotel is located in Shinjuku a 5min walk from the Shinjuku railway station. The limousine bus comes directly to the Keio Hotel from Narita International Airport & takes approx. 1hr depending on the traffic conditions. We were attending a conference in Arcadia Itchigaya which was handy for getting to by Taxi from Keio Plaza Hotel.Room - We booked a Plaza Premier room 3614 which was 36sqm on the 36th floor.The spacious room had fabulous city views, king size bed, TV (CNN, BBC ,ESPN, Discovery and movie channels, sofa, working desk, mini bar, free Wi-Fi internet, & coffee machine. Bathroom - Shower over bath with super duper Japanese toilet ! L’Occitane’s bath amenities, shaving cream, razor, hairbrush etc. Breakfast - Due to our room we enjoyed breakfast in the glass Court which was very nice with a selection of Western & Japanese food. Restaurants - We tried most of the restaurants in the hotel & there are many - Chinese, Japanese, Teppan-yaki, Tempura, Korean to French & Italian. The Kagari Japanese we found the service to be very slow & food pricey. Facilities - The Aurora Lounge located in the Main Tower 45F offers spectacular views over Tokyo & is definitely worth going up for a late night drink. An outdoor pool is located on the seventh floor of the main building & a well equipped gym. A Convenience Store (South Tower 2F) is excellent too for buying grog or smaller items. Overall: We thought this hotel to be excellent due to its facilities, large spacious rooms, & location.

Hotel is conveniently located near Shinjuku station. Lots of nearby places to eat/shop. Hotel room was renovated and can accommodate 3 persons. Hotel staff was also nice. We left our camera at the bus from Narita and they helped us to get it back. Would definitely come back! :D

I had been warned that Japanese hotels were small, so I packed small suitcases, only to find we had quite generously sized rooms and bathrooms.There was even a kettle, which is a bonus as I drink herbal tea.We were on the 29th floor, south tower, and had terrific views over the city skyline. We went to Hakone one night and came back for our remaining days and stayed on the opposite side of the floor to different views.I had a problem with our flight and they were very helpful with ringing the local number for us, as well as holding our cases for the one night we were away.I would stay there again.

We stayed here for three nights at the end of May. I requested a wheelchair accessible room with a roll in shower. The bathroom was accessible but had the usual shower over a bath. Staff were incredibly apologetic and did some minor modifications to a much larger room to make it suit for the period of our stay. Hotel was a great location close to Shinjuku station and good value. Fabulous views, clean rooms - although my carers room reeked of cigarette smoke despite being non smoking. Not the hotels fault that some people are inconsiderate enough to smoke in a non smoking space! Would happily recommend for value and location.

The hotel is about a 7 minute walk from the Shinjukiu station. There's a covered walking area that connects the station to the hotel which is great if you have to lug luggage. Otherwise, you can walk through the Omoide Yokocho area and browse the different eateries. Being close to the Shinjuku station is good and bad. Good because so many trains go through Shinjuku: subway, JR, and Odakyu. Bad because the station is so big and busy. Lots of walking and lots of signs. By the second day, we kind of got the hang of it so we didn't take many wrong turns. Even then, there's still a lot of walking because the station is so big.The lobby area of the hotel is more impressive than the guest rooms. Although my family's two rooms were comfortable, they could benefit from an update.; the nightstand had a really old built-in radio system and the furniture looked a bit tired. The size of our room was fine; not too small.For breakfast, we enjoyed the Japanese and Western buffet at the Glass Court restaurant as well as the Japanese buffet at the Kagari restaurant. It was nice to have a variety of really good food and drinks to pick from. I'm generally not a fan of vegetable juice but the one they served at breakfast was really good. Great way to start the day. We usually ate enough that we didn't need to have lunch. The next time I'm in Tokyo, I think I'd stay at a different hotel that's near the Shinjuku station.

Large hotel with numerous restaurants and shops within it and close to Shinjuku station. The room was modern and well equipped. The 'guest lounge' was similar to an airport lounge and nothing to write home about but had complimentary drinks and snacks which was a nice touch. I got the feeling the hotel was a little empty and soulless due to the size of it but would still recommend as a good solid base for exploring Tokyo.

Stayed at Keio Plaza for 6 nights on 18-24 June. I requested a non-smoking room and found out that although the room was indeed non-smoking, the room, sheets and towels reeked of smoke. Apart from this, I have to say that the rooms are huge and well appointed. There was a large wardrobe and a chaise lounge in the room. We were on the 37th floor with views of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building which is across the road.There were plenty of restaurants across the road from the hotel, so finding something to eat was never a problem.
