If your room rate does not include breakfast, there is a coffee joint and 2 Lawson's where you can get food (again across the road). Shinjuku station is about 5 mins walk straight ahead from the doors of the hotel. It was a little confusing from the subway back to the hotel underground so it took a while before we could get our bearings.As we were going to travel a few days I needed to do laundry. I asked the staff at the lobby for a nearby coin laundry and she told me that the hotel has the facility. I was surprised because I read earlier that the hotel does not have coin laundry facilities. Turns out that she was asking me to use the hotel laundry service. I had to stress again that it was coin laundry that I need. Then she fished out a map that the hotel has prepared, which has 4 options. She directed me to the one easiest to find which was about 5 mins walk from the hotel.We were issued the wifi password on check in and the wifi signal in the room was very good. I did have to keep reconnecting which was rather annoying. I think for the price, the room size and location, it was overall a very good stay. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone who visits Tokyo.

I booked thru Agoda and requested a non-smoking room and twin beds and it's great that they were able to accommodate our request. If you're coming from Narita Airport, all you need to ride is the Airport Limousine and it drops you right at the doorstep of the hotel. I wouldn't say that the hotel is at the center of Shinjuku, you would have to walk a bit, 15 minute walk to the department stores and the train is also located right below Keio Plaza. It's also great that they offer free shuttle bus to Disney resorts but keep in mind that you would need to book in advance to secure a seat. We booked the renovated room that has free lounge access and being able to check in different hotels, I usually get the club room (with lounge access) and it's quite different here because breakfast is NOT included. This is by far the 1st hotel I checked-in which does not offer free breakfast for those who has free access to the lounge. Quite disappointing. The lounge at Keio Plaza Hotel is okay, it gets a bit crowded from 5pm onwards. Selections are also limited, and you have to be very alert because once they bring out the cakes and canapes, people start getting all at once and it takes awhile before they refill the small plate. They have bowls of nuts, pretzels and dark chocolate available. But that's about it. By far the most disappointing lounge I have been to. Checking in was fast although there was a very long line. Staffs spoke good english. The room is nice and very modern. Beds are comfortable. The lobby is very classy and elegant, staffs are helpful and they have all the maps you need to navigate in Tokyo. If you're taking the airport limousine back to the airport, you can make a reservation through the bell desk, very convenient. Overall, I would say it was a pleasant stay and I might consider going back here in the near future.

Hotel is clean and comfortable. Rooms are good sized and bathrooms are well appointed. Has some nice touches like robes, slippers and hot water pot for tea. Service was wonderful. Most of the staff spoke at least some English, with the Front Desk staff being very fluent. There are some bus tours that leave from this hotel and the Concierge was happy to help set up my joining these tours. Location is very convenient. There are many stores and restaurants within a short walk, and it's not very far to walk to the train/subway station. Also, there is a convenience store in the bottom floor of the hotel where you can get quick snacks and more for a reasonable price. We did not eat at any of the hotel restaurants as they seemed very expensive. .

I booked this hotel for my son and guest and they reported back that all was wonderful. They especially noted the very professional and kind service they received. The room was very clean, well maintained (nothing needing repair or replacement) and had a very modern minimalist decor that was beautiful. They also loved the location being right at the heart of Shinjuku.

This is a huge hotel and there are maps available to show location of restaurants, etc. We booked a refurbished room and were pleased with our plaza luxe room on level 29. Very roomy for a Japanese hotel. Bathroom had been renovated. Both the room and bathroom were spotless. Amenities in the room were also great.The club lounge is relatively small but staff are very welcoming and helpful (they are a great asset to the hotel). Not a huge selection of canapés in the evenings or nibbles during the day on offer but still a very pleasant place to relax and look at the view of Tokyo from level 34. Breakfast for club members is on the ground floor in the bar area. Whilst breakfast was OK, for the duration of our stay there was absolutely no variation in breakfast offerings - some little changes would have been appreciated.Fantastic location to explore the Shinjuku area and, as noted by others, it is within easy walking distance of Shinjuku station, shopping and local restaurants.Concierge staff are very helpful and, given the size of the hotel and the number of people staying there, check in/out is extremely well managed.

It's the third time we stay at the Keio as a family. The rates are not cheap( japan is never cheap anyway), but I must say the location is fantastic, good food abundance just a 5 min walk away, shopping malls are 10 mins away. My only complain is that the free wifi signal are not so strong. For families that intend to visit Disneyland, they have a direct free shuttle. Overall we will stay here again

The room is simple and clean, 10 mins walk to Shinjuku station.opposite Tokyo metropolitan office, it has an observation deck(free admission)However, since it is such a big hotel, try to avoid the peak hour to have breakfast. I have the breakfast at 8am,all of the 3 restaurants are long queue.Wifi is available in room only. There is no wifi in the lobby.

I always stay at Keio plaza whenever in Tokyo due to the fact that it is a nice comfortable hotel and in an area i like. The rooms are always good, spacious and clean and all amenities provided.This time around some set backs. Checked in early but told rooms not ready till 4pm which was way past their standard check in time.. However, we went out, came back and treid out luck at 1.30pm and found out that the 2 non smoking rooms that we had booked was full and the hotel was completely sold out and only smoking rooms were available. Knowing how bad smoking rooms can be plus personal allergies this did not go down well. Weirdly after being told the hotel was sold out....they offered us a higher room type that was non smoking for Yen 2000 per night more. Fine with me as i really could not stay in the smoking rooms.On check out (standard 11am) we asked if we could have one room till 12noon as a compensation for our original non smoking not available and having to upgrade to a higher room type. We were promptly told that we had to pay extra. To be honest, that is fair but as may be the front could have been more lenient and not so robotic. Not even did they say let me see or let me check for you etc etc.I probably would stay here again. I just hope this issue does not happen again. For the hotel to consider.....if you advertise all non smoking rooms when we make the booking, please keep that promise.

I travelled with my family to Tokyo last June12 to June 15. We decided to book this hotel because of its reviews and its free disney shuttle service. The reviews, were definitely right! This hotel provided us with a pleasant to superb service all the way. It has its own assortment of restaurants and shops that gives you a taste of Tokyo's unique culture. You don't need to travel far to buy souvenirs. You could just simply shop then and there at the comfort of your hotel. Also, all hotel staff are just simply polite and accommodating. I will definitely recommend this hotel to those who will travel to Tokyo!!!

We stayed in this hotel between 2nd to 7th June 2014 for 5 nights. Booked a triple room for 3 adults and 1 child.Room is spacious and clean. Main reason why I chose this hotel is it provide free shuttle bus to Disneyland and Disneysea. The free shuttle bus is indeed very convenient for us especially when after a long, tiring day of fun in Disneyland. The journey stated was 60mins but we actually reached Disneyland in 40 mins much to our delight! I liked that they also provide fabric refresher in their closet which we sprayed generously on our recycled jeans when we got back the hotel. If ever visit Tokyo again, Keio Plaza is definitely my choice!

It is a big hotel and can be very busy in the morning when all the tour groups depart, so be careful if you are in a rush to check-put. We had a ‘non-renovated’ room but it was not too bad. It was reasonably big and had all the amenities. Unlike hotels in other countries, they however do not provide any body/hand lotion. The concierge desk in the lobby can provide decent assistance with directions and touring sites. It also has some very good neighbourhood map that you would want to have. They even booked show for us as we do not speak Japanese. We also signed up for the ‘executive membership’ when we booked the hotel as it was free. It entitled us to have access to the business lounge which was very good. The lounge had a good selection of drinks (including alcohol) and treats at various time of the day. Be sure to visit the washroom and watch the automated toilet does its show. Breakfast for the ‘executive member’ however was a disappointment. Japanese dishes are usually low in protein and for the breakfast in the executive area on the first floor, there was hardly anything worth eating, more like a continental breakfast. We did not try the buffet breakfast so we cannot comment on it. The hotel is centrally located with great shopping facilities close by and the subway station about 5-minute walk away. Go to the Keio department store at around 6 pm and down to the food floor. It is jam packed with shoppers buying ready-to-eat food to take home around that time. They provide food samples very much like some of the grocery stores here in North American, allowing you to taste various dishes. Some of them are really nice. The prices of many food items also drop by 20 to 50% after the crowd is gone and one can easily buy lots of food, heat it up with the microwave on site and take it back to the hotel room. There are however, plenty of restaurants between the hotel and Keio department store where the subway system is located, so food is never an issue. Similarly, many of the bakeries in the shopping mall underneath the department store also have their baked products on sale in the early evening before closing. You can easily satisfy your carbohydrate rush that way. Another thing one has to watch out for is foreign exchange. Unlike other hotels, this one does not provide currency exchange service. There are currency machines on site that provides rates not too bad as compared to currency exchange stores that can be found close by. Forget about banks for currency exchange as all of them around the hotel only have banking machines with no teller service. The only one with teller service does not provide currency exchange.

This hotel is up market, without being ridiculously posh. It is well used by westerners and Japanese alike. Smack bang in the centre of the bustling Shinjuku district with bars, shops restaurants only 100m away (24/7) yet for all that it is extremely secluded and tranquil. The staff are plentiful on Reception, Concierge and in the various restaurants and obsequiously polite and respectful at all times - wish the UK was like this. Nothing was ever too much trouble and there seemed to be an established and well-oiled procedure mapped out for every eventuality from check-in through to limousine shuttle back to Narita airport. Nothing seemed to have been left to chance. I guess if you like laid back spontaneity you'd find KPH a bit regimented. But for an ex-military type who admires respect, hierarchy, good order and procedural efficiency this hotel is as good as they come. Also very close to Shinjuku Metro/Bus/Train station (5 Mins walk). I happen to have been here on business but would readily return to the same hotel as a tourist. My only grip is that since this hotel is based on twin towers with 20+ floors each, stairs are not an option which can mean a slow route to and from breakfast at peak times.

We have stayed at this marvellous hotel six times over the past few years , and simply cannot fault the place .The staff are ultra efficient and always keen to assist , plus the rooms and the hotel in general are always immaculate .The amenities within the hotel are comprehensive, the location is brilliant , as is the convenience of being a stopping point of The Friendly Airport Limousine BusWe certainly would not hesitate to stay here again 10 / 10 :)

We stayed here a week as part of a three week trip in Asia. We picked this hotel after reading the reviews here, and found the hotel to be as good as recommended. Rooms were small as expected, but well appointed and very clean. Location was good with an underground walkway to the station if needed (more interesting above ground but the walkway was useful when it rained). We ate a few times in the hotel and found prices reasonable and quality good. Got a bit sick of the breakfast after a week of the same things, although choice was ok- food was generally warm rather than hot. There were lots of coffee shops around, so I would recommend not taking the breakfast option. All in all would stay again.

Initially overwhelmed by size of this hotel but staff have been wonderful. When I complained about very uncomfortable mattress I was upgraded to a room refurbished facilities . As a single female ( until husband returned) I used hotel restaurants. Pricey but of a very high standard. Good breakfast options. Hotel very central to all the big dept stores and very close to Shinjuku station for sightseeing.We were looking for a small fishing shop and staff took time and effort to draw maps to get us there . This hotel ticks all the boxes.

Convenient location near Shinjuku station. Very large, business oriented hotel. Club lounge is relatively small and modestly appointed. Club breakfast - served just off the lobby not in the club lounge - was excellent. Very nice rooms. Had a misfire in that first room we were taken to had been recently smoked in. Bell person was very understanding and immediately handled getting us a new room. Kudos to her. The pricing was quite reasonable given all of the amenities offered.

Those positive reviews are all true. Although it's a huge and impersonal place, the service is very good, the location is convenient (though finding your way around the nightmarish Shinjuku station is no treat). Rooms are big and comfortable with impressive urban views. For breakfast, the Glass Court is far superior to the Coffee House. Having the airport 'limousine' right there is a big plus.

This hotel is very good. Its 3-5 minutes walk from Shinjuku station which gives you access to the entire city through metro or train. Theres a bus that goes directly to and from the hotel to Narita airport.The hotel staff is very friendly and speak english very well. They make sure you're taken care of throughout your entire stay. I had a Luxe room in the south tower and that was a a big room with high standards.It was clean and there were nothing negative to say about the room.Room service was also fast and not too expensive.Theres also high speed free wi-fi in the room. However theres no wi-fi down in the lobby,The hotel got a lots of really good restaurants, including several which have Kobe steak on the menu, which is good if you want to take it easy at evening. The hotel also got several bars and lounges and also a small convenience store ith all you need of basic supplies. It also got an ATM to get some extra Yen if neededAnd as a guest at the hotel you get 10% discount on most restaurants and bars at the hotel.This hotel is something i would absolutely recommend for anyone going to Tokyo!

We stayed for 3 nights. I purposely choose this hotel because of the easy access from and to Airport (Haneda Airport JPY1,230 / Narita Airport around JPY3,000). The limousine bus stop in front of the hotel. There are a lot other hotel that has limousine service bus as well but I choose Keio Plaza Hotel because the room looks bigger and more spacious and my partner don't like small room. I booked through the hotel direct and managed to get cheaper rate. We requested for high floor, non smoking, nice view, and renovated room and surprised, they even upgrade us to deluxe room at 28th floor with amazing view. Bath room is ok and they have everything (soap, lotion, shaver, shave foam, body wash towel and they even have cotton yukata robe for sleep in the drawer and Japanese toilet (those with seat warmer and flushing sound).Staff are very friendly and efficient, all of them can speak English pretty well, you just need to speak slowly. I tried the room service (Indonesian fried rice) which the taste quite ok. There are lots of restaurants at this hotel (Japanese, western, French, Italian, Chinese, indian), bread shop and mini market (open until 2.30am).They also have free bus to Disneyland. We took 1 day trip to Mt Fuji - Hakone through the local tour and the hotel staff happily arranged for us with reasonable price.Distance to Shinjuku station is about 10 to 15 mins walking and you can see a lot of ramen restaurant, pharmacy, mini market around. Its very convenient and if you plan to travel by train, Shinjuku station is the easiest way.Overall, very satisfied with this hotel and I prefer to pay slightly more and I got spacious room and I can have good sleep after long walk everyday. I definitely recommend this hotel and when im in Tokyo, I will stay here again..

Had a "Luxe" room on the 29th floor, which was very comfortable.The hotel is located within walking distance from Shinjuku station, so getting around is a breeze. The "Limousine bus" from Narita directly to the hotel and back was also very convenient.Service was excellent all around, as in my experience service in Japan generally is.There are a number of good restaurants in the hotel. I had an excellent meal of wagyu steak at one of them. Highly recommended, well worth the high price.

The Keio Plaza is a perfect hotel for international tourists! The hotel is massive but clean and the rooms are spacious! Many of the workers can speak some English so that's helpful as an English speaking tourist. The best part is the location! It's located in shinjuku which is an excellent city especially for younger adults like myself. There are plenty of bars and restaurants near by, the station is super close which is even more convenient and than the government building is behind the hotel! For me this hotel gets extra points for the location! Loved my stay here.
user_name:
Emma C
Blackheath, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: First time I've stayed here at this hotel. Very conveniently located near a park so I can go running. Also close to shinjuku station. Service has been good. I've tried two of their restaurants and food has been good. Shops are a bit overpriced but hey, this is Tokyo

This hotel is a hop skip and a jump to Shinjuku station. Got a very nice room that overlooked the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. I got to see a Tokyo sunset right from my window. You can easily access the hotel from the underground pedestrian tunnel that connects to Shinjuku West Exit. Check-in was easy and had a very nice sleep. There's really nothing much to say. The only interaction I had with the staff was during check-in and check-out. The hotel is huge. There were a lot of tour groups from different countries when I arrived. So, this is popular with tourists.There are a variety of nice eating places right outside the hotel, so I wouldn't waste my money dining in the restaurants that's housed within.
user_name:
J Lee S
Los Angeles, California

review_body: We stayed at Keio for 5 nights in April 2014. This is a great spot to stay in because you are right next to Shinjuku station. I saw a few reviews that sort of complained the hotel was far from the station. It is only .4 km above ground, but if you exit out of the hotel on the North side there is an underground tunnel about 20 meters from the door. Many tour companies meet at this hotel. There is a free shuttle bus to Tokyo Disney. (Disney shuttles requires reservations and they fill up so plan early). There are several restaurants in the hotel with varied menus as well as a hotel shop that offered snacks / small meals (cup of noodles!). There are many restaurants in Shinjuku station not to mention Sizzler and Denny's very close to the hotel. I found the staff to be very helpful and most had a rudimentary grasp of English and if they didn't they would find someone who did. The room size was big for Japan standards and this made it comfortable to be able to unpack for the 5 nights we stayed. There were good amenities in the room e.g. shampoo, conditioner, face cleanser, razors, slippers and yukatas. The hotel has a laundry service. The maid service was exceptional. I highly recommend this hotel.

Keio Plaza is a huge hotel with many facilities. Everything is well organized, staff is friendly and efficient. The location between Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building and Shinjuku station is very convenient. For transportation from/to the airport, the "Friendly Limousine Service" (which is actually a big bus) is the best choice, fast, easy, comfortable, leaving the hotel every hour.The rooms on the executive floor are spacious, modern and well maintained. The view is fantastic (Mt. Fuji!).For breakfast they give you vouchers and I could choose between a rather simple Western style breakfast (boring) at the Cafe next to the reception, or a fully Japanese breakfast at one of the Japanese restaurants in the basement (delicious).I would stay there again.

Great location near Shinjuku Station and night life. Many restaurants and shopping nearby. Lovely accommodations- the room size was spacious and comfortable, affording great views of Tokyo. Service was and the food was very good, the ample breakfast buffet was offered in several locations.

We stayed 3 nights at this hotel and were very pleased. The beds were comfortable, the room was large and the bathroom was amazing!!! We had vouchers for breakfast each morning and there were 3 restaurants to choose from. Two were buffet and 1 you could order off the menu. We were able to pick up our tours at this hotel and it was very tourist friendly. There was a metro station, less than a block away and also a train station, the same distance. The hotel staff provided very good directions.

Older hotel with spacious rooms and great service.The staff at this hotel are the most entusiastic, hard working and diligent that I have seen in my life.The hotel has a great location. The rooms are spacious, well appointed and meticulously clean.Had a room at the top with great views. Great location for transport and shopping.My stop in Tokyo.

It's a big Hotel, about 1500 rooms I was told. But Vegas with many hotels at 3000 plus rooms provide better service and atmosphere. Reception here was a long queue. Receptionist seemed like robotic trained. Smile, bow, click click click ,print print print and bye. I feel happier being served by a Vending Machine.Waiting for elevators to go to your room, Queue. Breakfast every morning for 5 mornings and with 4 different restaurants to cater to different pallets, queue, queue queue. 20 minutes at least. And service is like the receptionist. Robotic at best. Getting any of the waiter or attendants for assistance draws twitched eye brows, corked heads, shrugged shoulders. Their understanding of English at this 5 star establishment is maybe good enough for Mr Bean. Try using a lot hands to describe what you want. But beware! If they still don't understand you they become rude. They're Japanese. If they don't understand us then we've explained it wrongly Such Arrogance. Complaints to Duty Managers are futile . They bow a lot, twitched their eyes, shake their heads and apologies. His duty is done. No follow up, nothing. So I think they are all birds of a feather.

Spent a week in Keio Plaza on a business trip. Location close to Shinjuku station is very convenient and the big department stores around the station are close by.The service is excellent, as can be expected in Japan.Rooms were not anything special, though the view from my 42nd floor riom was quite nice ;-)

Great hotel for exploring Shinjuku area if walking, or to access the Shinjuku station for the metro and mainline services. Rooms are spacious and well apportioned.If you are flying into Narita then I would recommend the airport Limosine bus service which is efficient and reasonably priced, the best advantage is that it drops you at the hotel lobby. Using the train means you have to drag your luggage one block from Shinjuku station.

Wow! This is a massive hotel. It looks the business though. It manages to feel 5 star without feeling intimidating and snobbish. Initially I was disappointed to be away from the centre of Tokyo but quickly realized the Shinduku area is the norm for tourists to stay in. It has a great selection of restaurants and some shops in the hotel too. Residents get a discount at most of them. No vending machines but the supermarket shop stays open to 02:30 and re-opens at 05:30! You could live in this hotel and never need to go out. Close to some attractions too. Loved the 45th floor bars. Polstar was more relaxed and still had great views. The sky bar has views of the major city sites though. Initial room was a smoker and although a good size and clean is no good for a non smoker like me. Staff very helpful and friendly and quickly arranged move. Got superb room with fab view. They are great. Nothing is a problem. Bell staff exemplary. As a solo traveller felt very welcome indeed.

I was staying at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo on 24-25 May'14 (01 night only). And this is our Company trip.Even though is just 01 night, but their service is pretty good!When I want to go somewhere, we just need to ask them and they show you the direction with very clear explanation. Not only that, the way they talk to us is very professional and very friendly!At first i thought that the staff at there may not be speak good english. But i was wrong!They will reply to us in beautiful English!The room is comfortable and nice for us. And the breakfast have three choices, Japanese style, American style and also mixed style. Various choices food for us.But the only bad thing is they only provide the wifi in the Room only. In the lobby do not have any wifi.Beside that, the location of this hotel is very nice.when you go out from the front door, in front of it is a Tochomae Building which can go to the 45 floor to have Tokyo City view for free.And also can walk along the underground straight away can reach Shinjuku Station and can start your shopping time.

This is a first class hotel located in the Shinjuku section of Tokyo. It is a block from the shopping area. The hotel contains a variety of restaurants. The one drawback is that it four or five blocks from the Shinjuku railway station which can be a consideration of you have luggage.

Room was great, comfortable beds, great view. Meals expensive. Lucky macdonald just down the road from main entrance, plus plenty of restaurants with English menus. Great food, very good price, plus wine was reasonable. When to there happy hour. $10 drinks, a glass of wine, most were a nip of wine. Should of had gin and tonic at least you got a glass full. Snacks were dried peas. If you want a descent happy hours eaton club/ eaton hotels are the best. Free drinks, any type, from baileys, champs, gin etc, plus beautiful snacks, fruit plates, cheese, coffee, water soft drinks. Plus daily buffet breakfast all included.

A great hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. Close to the station, shops and restaurants. One side of the hotel looks over the Tokyo skyline, the other into the impressive Tokyo Metropolitan government building. (You can also see Mt Fuji on a clear day)Its pricey but its location is what you are paying for.

This hotel had everything. It was clean, good customer service, restaurants and shops on site, etc. Its in an excellent location, near so many little eateries, it's hard to choose from. Lots of shopping nearby, including large department stores. Near transportation hub. Has free shuttle to Tokyo Disneyland, but you should reserve the shuttle in advance (of arriving) because the seats get booked up fast. We waited until we arrived and all good times were gone.

We chose this hotel based on the location. We didn't know anything about Shinjuku but it looked pretty central.What a great spot it turned out to be!Just a short walk to the restaurants, bars, and night time action.But also located between a couple of lovely Japanese gardens, that were only a 10 minute walk in either direction.The hotel has a number of high quality restaurants as well and the staff were very courteous and efficient.Only gripe, the bathrooms are very small and out of proportion to the size of the rooms.I would definitely recommend this hotel, and would stay there again.

The hotel is located in the less busy part of Shinjuku. It’s just 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station and nearby shopping malls such as Keio, Takashimaya and etc. There are also a few convenience stores, which open 24 hours around the area. We took N-EX (Narita Express) train from Narita Airport to Shinjuku as there was a 50% off promotion going on and the journey took about 2 hours. However, on the way back from hotel to Narita airpot, we decided to use shuttle bus service instead. It costs JPY 3,100 each way per person but it was a lot more convenient because the shuttle bus came to pick us up right in front of the hotel. And I believe the journey took less time, 1.5 hours only. The hotel staff are friendly and helpful. We stayed in the renovated Plaza Luxe Double room with free lounge access. The room was spacious and to our surprise, on the clear day, we could see the Mt. Fuji from our window! Our overall stay was enjoyable and we will definitely stay here again.

The Keio Plaza hotel is located right next to the Shinjuku train station in Tokyo, Japan. It is a very nice western style hotel in the heart of the Shinjuku business district of Tokyo. It is a single train ride from Narita airport so easy to get to and centrally located. The hotel has very nice rooms and the staff is very helpful. Inside the hotel there are numerous restaurants, shops and even convenience shops. IThe breakfast is ok but it is easy, quick. If you are staying a long time you will find it is the same food every day.

Our room was elegant and spacious. The bed was comfortable, bathroom very well equipped and large. This hotel was a great welcome to Japan. It is well located near a central railway station, Shinjuku. The staff were very well trained, helpful and welcoming at reception and in the restaurants. There is great shopping, cafés and restaurants close by.

Work brought my husband here so we had a nice hotel room with spacious bathroom and on a higher floor. The hotel lobby is beautiful and the restaurants there are unbeatable. The breakfast there was a wonderful way to start the day and I thoroughly enjoyed my made to order omelet. The hotel is very close to the station and you would have no trouble accessing it. I would stay here again as the service was lovely, the bedroom was large and comfortable, and our stay was pleasant.

The hotel is located in the less busy part of Shinjuku and it’s only just 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station. You can easily find café, restaurants and convenience stores around the area. Most department stores are only just 10 minutes walk from the hotel.The hotel is easily accessible from Narita Airport, the shuttle bus journey was 1.5 hour each way. The bus service was excellent as it dropped us off straight at the hotel. The shuttle bus costs JPY 3,100 each way.The hotel staff are helpful and attentive. We love the room as it’s bright, spacious and has a lovely city view. However, we are disappointed with the bed as it’s quite a tiny double bed (it’s even smaller than a queen sized bed). We actually requested a twin bedroom but due to the long weekend in Tokyo, we could only check in a hotel room with double bed. The toilet is quite small. There is a lack of English TV channels available. But one plus point is that there is free wifi access within the hotel room.My overall impression towards this hotel is good and I will definitely come back when I visit Tokyo again in the near future.

From the moment you enter until you leave you experience a superior and stylish hotel. The rooms are excellent, very modern and clean. The lobby and bars are great. We went for work and so dined in seperate areas and so I did not visit the restaurants but the food we had was excellent. 5 minutes walk from the went ground exit of shinjuku station yet strangely quiet! Brilliant hotel and would recommend.

There are a lot of good restaurants, bars, and shopping areas that are walking distance/short cab ride from the hotel. You can sort of have a full Tokyo experience in this area alone.ShoppingThere's the Takashimaya and Isetan department stores just 20 minutes away on foot. For more "interesting" shopping there's also Tokyu Hands and Don Quijote in the area. NightlifeThe Park Hyatt is only a 10 min walk away and their happy promo is excellent. Whiskey bar Zoetrope and the Golden Gai is a short cab ride away with lots of eateries nearby that stay open 'til late.TransportShinjuku station is only a 10 min walk and on the way you will find lots of izakayas and restaurants. It's pretty much the busiest station in Tokyo and it's a great starting point to move around the city and surrounding towns and cities. The limousine bus service to the airport is also super convenient as you can get dropped off and picked up at the lobby.

If you are going to take cabs everywhere, then this hotel is great. However if you are not you will most likely start every trip with the less than pleasant Shinjuku Station experience. It seems to take around 20 minutes to get out of it, there are thousands of people busy rushing to work and if you get lost!!! The hotel itself is fantastic. It's huge size does make it feel a little impersonal. If you do decide to stay, check out the Whiskey Bar on the 45th floor. Very special, unless you are sitting next to someone with a cigar

I booked this hotel in Feb and stayed in April this year. I stayed 4 nights in Plaza Luxe with queen bed on 30th floor (south building). It allows me to access lounge room to enjoy free beers, wines and snacks. Hotel is close to west gate of Shinjuku station by 5 minute walking. There are restaurants, department stores (Keio, Odakyu) in this area. Hotel restaurants are very good but avoid dinner cause it is double price than lunch. Room is very clean. I really enjoyed sunrise (adjusting my time) and night view (can see Sky Tree).Staffs are friendly and speak good English. I was surprised it doesn't accept Yen traveler's cheques any more. So I called Amex agency in Tokyo and was told to exchange it in Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ without service charge. This bank is close to hotel in underground walkway (staff gave me a map).If you are planning your first Tokyo trip, you won't regret to book this hotel.

For the price I paid, it was worth it! I book a renovated superior room and gotten a deluxe room! The room was very big and was a very nice place to stay.The check in was very fast ( Maybe there is no grouops at that time) and the customer service team was very helpful. You can get them to book you any restaurants u would want to go and they will help you out! First class service!It is also a 5 minute walk to the Shinjuku station.The only downside to this was that my room was facing east and the moring sun comes in at about 4 something in the morning! :)

Keio Plaza Hotel Shinjuku has been my favourite choice for short breaks. We usually stayed at its Superior Room for a few dollars more in return for much more space inside the bedroom and bathroom. The hotel has quite a few restaurants specialising in different cuisines: traditional Japanese, sushi and tempura, Korean, Chinese, buffet, French and Italian. Its bar on the top floor provides a good view, especially at night. It takes only five minutes walking to the Shinjuku station and several major shopping malls and rows of local shops including a large store selling electronics, audio visual equipment, cameras, IT equipment and electric appliances. Most, if not all, of the staff we met could understand and speak English.

Great place to start the holiday after a long flight. Large room so easy to spend our 4 nights. Had dinner one night at the teppenyaki restaurant, expensive but amazing food.Walked to a different area each day and night, great spot to base yourself. Traditional restaurants, street food and department stores around the corner. Particularly close to the bright lights of Shinjuku.

The hotel was centrally located and walkable distance from Shinjuku station. The room was very spacious, we had 3 single beds and heaps of room for our suitcases. The staff were very friendly. However to check in and check out most of the time there was a queue - which understandable given that the hotel has numerous rooms. We had a room in the main tower which is more modern and more recently renovated than the south tower. A friend of mine stayed in the south tower and I would recommend to pay the extra $ because there is a huge difference between the 2 rooms.The bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was spacious too.

Anyone who has been to Tokyo knows how small and how expensive hotel rooms can be. The Keio Plaza offers good value for money. The rooms, especially the renovated ones, are of good size and tastefully decorated. The hotel itself is very large and can be a bit impersonal at times but these do not detract from the value that this hotel offers. There are many restaurants within the hotel including a Teppanyaki, a French, an Italian, a Chinese and a Korean restaurant. The breakfast buffets are large and varied, there being three different breakfast buffets to choose from. I would suggest trying the Japanese breakfast buffet at least once. The hotel is very well located. It is just a short walk to the Shinjuku station and to many restaurants, bars, lounges and department stores.

The Plaza Premier rooms are really nice! Especially the ones with king bed. They have excellent view from the 36th Floor! And they come with L'occitane amenities! The hotel is located less than 5minutes from the Shinjuku train station. Truly convenient especially if you have young children. Would definitely come back again!

We stayed at this hotel during our honeymoon trip to Japan. We chose this hotel because of its strategic location within Shinjuku and free bus ride to Disneyland. The hotel is within walking distance to shops and train station. The room was great and kept immaculatelyThe only complaint I have of this hotel is the level of service by some of its staff. There were some staff that showed no smile or politeness when asked a question

I stayed in Shinjuku in April 2014. This hotel is huge and is like a very big corporate chain hotel. The building also has a number of restaurants, shops, etc in the complex. So if you're looking for local or boutique, this isn't it.The hotel staff were friendly and welcoming, though check in seemed to take longer than it needed to. All the staff we encountered spoke decent English.The room was reasonable size-wise (bigger than other hotel rooms we stayed in in Japan). The decor was nice and everything was clean and comfortable, including the bathroom and the bed. Toiletries were included, along with a safe, bathrobe, a few English channels on the TV, etc. We went for a deluxe room which had a nice view and also access to the Lounge on 31F, where there was free tea, coffee, soft drinks, beer and wine and a nice view from the opposite side of the hotel to our room. We stayed in room 3161.Location-wise, this hotel is very easy. There's not much around the hotel itself, but it's about a five minute walk from the West / Nishi-Shinjuku exit of Shinjuku station, which is on several Tokyo Metro and JR Lines. So it's easy to get everywhere from there. Also, it's about a 10-12 minute walk through Shinjuku station to the shopping and nightlife side of Shinjuku (including thde Golden Gai area and Shinjuku Park. Do not underestimate, however, the size and scale of Shinjuku station. It is enormous and incredibly busy. Hotels in Tokyo are expensive, but relatively speaking, we thought this one was reasonable based on the standard of the hotel and the location. I would describe it as a really good 4 star hotel. I would recommend it as a good base in Tokyo. We were in Tokyo meeting friends who stayed in Ginza and in Asakasa and to be honest, we all spent most of our non-sightseeing time around Shinjuku and Shibuya so I think our hotel location was better than theirs. We did not eat in any of the restaurants so I can't comment on those.Local tip - If you're feeling a little adventurous, head to Omoide-Yokocho which is on the West side of Shinjuku Station opposite the huge Uniqlo and Odakya Bic Camera stores. Its a couple of little laneways packed full of yakitori stalls and bars that's a lot of fun!

4 star hotel with spacious room (as compared to Japan standard). Breakfast is of good quality and taste. About 10 mins walking distance to nearest train station. One of the direct airport transfer stops. The only con is extremely unstable wifi. The connection is lost the second you got connected.

The officious and unpleasant man ordering around the guests into a queue at check-in was a sign of things to come. Queue again at the bell desk to book the bus to the airport and again at the front desk to pay for it. Queue for breakfast at 6.20 on a Saturday morning for more than 10 minutes and get only half way to the front, despite the restaurant not being full. Some of the staff were efficient and pleasant, Some (like the one making the breakfast queue get even longer by not letting people in) just worked slowly and looked unhappy. But there were not enough of them anywhere. The room was ok, though not very large. Having a shower steamed up the room window. The location is good, but there are many hotels in the area, and it is hard to believe that there are not many better ones.

It's in the heart of Shinjiku, convenient location, no doubt. Their F&B is amazing, so many different types of breakfast for choosing. Additional, their Chinese dinner is pretty good even better than the ones in China. Very international feeling, well trained staffs are efficient to solve all kinds of problems for you.

The hotel is perfect, near the shinjuku station and the rooms have a great view. The staff were very friendly and helpful. On arrival our check in bags did not arrive and the airline said they would deliver to the hotel the next morning, but it did not arrive and the staff went out of their way to help us call the airline and translate for us to find out where are bags were.

My husband and I recently stayed five nights in a Plaza Premier room at Keio Plaza. In all it was an excellent hotel - the room was huge, it had every convenience we could ever need, staff were very efficient and friendly, and the place was spotlessly clean. We arrived very early in the morning and caught the Airport Limousine bus to the hotel. This turned out to be a very simple process and I'm glad we didn't choose to attempt the Tokyo train system with our luggage after a long flight. The Airport Limousine dropped us at the door and cost around $30.The room had amazing views across Tokyo, and was very comfortable. All modern conveniences were installed such as wifi, electric blinds and of course the luxury Japanese electronic toilet. The bathroom was quite large but was a pre fabricated room so it didn't share the luxurious feel that the rest of the hotel conveyed. It came equipped with L'Occitane products, hairbrush, toothbrushes, toothpaste and big, fluffy towels.During our stay we visited the bakery downstairs on numerous occasions, picking up well priced snacks. We also spent one night enjoying the Yamanami Teppan-yaki restaurant, if you have the time to do this I would highly recommend you do, while it was pricey the food was delicious and having your own personal chef preparing it in front of your eyes was incredible. We also ate an American style buffet breakfast downstairs, this was nice but a little odd being served poached eggs on crispbread. We spent another amazing evening at the Polestar Bar. The views from the Polestar Bar are just beautiful, especially at night. On the night we were in the bar a big thunderstorm rolled across the city and it was amazing watching it roll in and then fade away from our seats at the bar. The bar had a huge range of drinks, my husband enjoyed a few glasses of Whisky and I sampled some of the cocktails.Location-wise the hotel is very close to Shinjuku Station, this made sightseeing very easy. The station was enormous and it did take quite some time for us to find our way in and out at the right exits. An express train was available to Tokyo station which took about 15 minutes.In all a wonderful stay. I would definitely stay at Keio Plaza again in the future and would recommend it to my friends without hesitation.

THE hotel is perfect. near SHINJUKU STATION, just across the road. But you have to walk underground to reach the middle of the station. ITS THE HEART OF THE CITY.You have free ride to go to DISNEYLAND.

From the outside,the building looked impressive and as soon as we came in,it was. Our rooms were nice and we were able to have interconnecting rooms.The first morning,we slept so well in our beds that we missed the buffet breakfasts in glass court and jurin,so we had a nice breakfast à la carte. That day, we found out that there were quite a few shops in the hotel and found what we were looking for. The same night,we went to one of many bars which was good but service could have been improved. Next morning ,we went to the glass court buffet breakfast.There was a long queue and the buffet was very nice.On our final day,we had buffet breakfast at jurin which was lovely but was short of choice.A stay that definitely earned 4 stars

We stayed for 5 nights in early April and aside for the warm room temperature which may be standard for japan's cool weather, we didn't have anything to complain. We arrived late in the evening so check-in was a breeze. We stayed at the main tower and bought some instant noodles at the ground floor of the south tower for our late dinner. The room was large for japan standards. Their free breakfast buffet that came with our room was good and we tried their different restaurants except that we missed a day because of the long queue at their japanese restaurant and we had to catch our scheduled early free shuttle bus for Disney Resorts. What I love about this hotel is the location to different japanese restaurants across the hotel. The train station is just a few walks besides the hotel and we explored Shinjuku by foot --shopping areas, dining areas, Tokyo Metropolitan Govt Bldg and Shinjuku Gyoen Park (beautiful park, with beautiful cherry blossom trees). If you want to get tours from english-speaking volunteers, try to be at the Tokyo Metro Bldg early to secure a slot. We also got a Mt Fuji Tour from Japanican.com and it was one of the best tour we had. Michiko, our tour guide, was so friendly, funny and informative. Visiting Tokyo with my family was a great vacation! From the food, accommodation, tours, weather and people, we were sad to go home but hope to come back again in the near future to explore other districts and cities.

Stayed for 3 nights at the Plaza Luxe Room. We were on Level 33 which gave us fantastic views of the city. Great amenities available in the room & the mattresses are nice & firm which is what we like for a good night sleep.The Luxe Lounge has to be one of the worst lounges we have been to. It doesn't give you the feeling of exclusivity instead it felt like a canteen with nicer furnishings. The saving grace is that they serve breakfasts for Plaza Luxe Guests at the Lobby Lounge where it has the atmosphere of a luxury hotel & the feeling of special treatment. Staff at the hotel were superb, ever so polite, ever so helpful and we don't speak a word of Japanese.Location of hotel is great. Close proximity to Shinjuku Station and also walking distance to the shopping area. We wouldn't have a problem of recommending Keio Plaza to our friends.

Keio Plaza is a large and busy hotel. Despite the number of people that occupy the hotel they manage to maintain a homey feeling. Nice rooms and great customer service. It's located in a quiet area of Shinjuku which I like but still not very far from shopping, restaurants, the bus and train stations. If you are tired and don't want to go far from the hotel for dinner there are very good restaurants in the hotel complex or a short 5-10 minute walk from the hotel. I would definitely stay there again.

We stayed here for 4 days, 3 nights, liked it and have a few suggestions:a. If you are doing breakfast as part of your plan, be prepared for 12-25 minute lines. There are a LOT of others doing the breakfast plan in addition to you so be aware of this and plan accordingly.b. There is good moderate price access (3100 Y) from both Tokyo airports. We appreciate that, using it one way.c. There are several good department stores within 5-7 minutes walk from the hotel, if this interests you. Once you are clear about where they are, they are easy to find.d. Wi-fi is free and can take a little while to figure out - but it does work well.e. Concierge is very helpful - they can be busy but if you want help they ARE pleasant and skillful.f. The rooms on the north side are spacious and nice. Can't speak about the south tower.g. There is a Sizzler restaurant 1 block away with one of the best salad bars we've ever seen in the US or any other country. A lot of Japanese people eat there. Ok, Sizzler is not a restaurant we usually eat at but this was a darn good restaurant with (for Tokyo) moderate prizes. It's rightly praised in separate reviews elsewhere on Trip Advisor.h. We tried for another highly regarded reservation but found you need to make reservations more than a day in advance.i. Breakfast quality was ok - not the best among the 4 hotel restaurants we stayed at during our 10 days in Japan.Overall, a nice big hotel.

Great, spacious, nicely-hard matrass and washroom. Just problematic that check in time is 2pm and before that the officers wouldnt let you check in. (arrived at 11am so I wandered around and return to hotel, queue again to check in at 2pm). They only have 1 room available and told us that we needed to check in again for the second room. while the line up was getting longer and longer. So we got angry and finally got two rooms ready after the staff made several attempts through her computer. Overal, rooms are spacious, concierge is helpful and it is a hotel which has direct access to Airport Limousine Bus. So we were dropped in and departed exactly in hotel lobby. Location is 5 minute walk from Shinjuku station and some shopping area.

Overnighting in Tokyo after a cruise. Hotel is well situated and would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel. Very central an close to the shinjuku station rail and underground. Lots of places to eat and department stores within easy walking distance.

友たちと一緒に泊まったけど、朝10時くらいに先に到着しちゃって、そのままお荷物係にフロントまでエスコートされてて。それならチャックインしちゃっても大丈夫って感じ？と思いながらフロントに英語でチェックインのお願いしたら、チェックイン時間は2時ですっと冷たく返事された。仕方なく、お荷物を預けてしばらくふらふらしようと思って周辺マップを頼んだら、また冷たく対応されました。最初話しかけた時に冷たい目差しをされて、マップも片手で渡された。すごく不愉快でした。チェックイン手続きをしたときも英語なんですけど、お部屋をエレベータ近くにしてほしいとお願いしたら、もちろんです！大丈夫だよ！と明るくに返事したけど、一番奥のお部屋でした…エレベータからお部屋まではすごく疲れる。たぶん英語ではあまり通じでなかったのかとすごく思いました。でもお荷物係とハウスキーピングの対応はすごく早くてよかったです。お部屋自体は結構よかったんです。ただ語学が中途半端です。 まずはきちんと英語が通じるようにしてください。I arrived too early in the morning, and I knew that the check-in time is 2PM, but the bell escort me to the front desk right after I exit the bus. So I thought maybe I can do the check-in process first? But when I ask Front Desk to check-in, I got rejected coldly, saying that the Check-in was 2PM, and was not offered alternative option....Therefore, I had no other options but to hang around in the area until the check-in time. When I asked the Guest Relation staff for the area map, I was given a icy cold eye-contact, and handed the map to me with a single hand. Throughout all these time, he remain sitted on his station . No staff was engaging me, and no service was delivered.When we came back to check-in in the afternoon, we asked for a room that is near by the elevator (didn't want to go all the way to the end of the hallway) the Front Desk agent confirmed immediately that our whole stay is going to be in the same room we requested. But then we soon discovered that our room is IN THE VERY END of the hallway. Maybe the staff cannot truely understood our request, but they did not bother to double confirm with us.....The room itself was actually spacious and nice, though. And the Bell staffs and Housekeeping provides very good and efficient service. But the Front Desk Staff needs to work on the language skill since they need to deal with lots of foreigners.

We stayed for 7 nights in the Plaza Luxe in the South Tower of Keio Plaza. Close to Shinjuku station, clean, complimentary bottled water, beautiful view, on a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji, free wi-fi.It perhaps does not have the "wow" factor, but it is a very comfortable hotel. There is a small supermarket in the south tower. All in all, very convenient for our wishes.We did not have breakfast / dinner in the hotel because there are a lot of bakeries etc. nearby.

We stayed 4 nights at the hotel. We had a renovated room in the South tower. It had a nice view, and we even saw Mt. Fuji out the window on clear days. The room was sizeable for Tokyo. All these things were included: slippers, yukata cotton robes, toiletries, Tokyo Times newspaper, wifi. There is a small fridge/mini bar and a safe too. They provide 2 bottles of complimentary water daily. The hotel has around 1500 rooms so don't expect personalized attention, but the staff was nice when we briefly interacted with them. There is direct bus service from Narita airport to the hotel and back, and it drops off and picks up at the front lobby. Very convenient. Buy a ticket at the airport and again at the hotel. Bus times are posted at the hotel at the bell hop desk. There is a subway stop directly in back of the hotel, the stop is Tochomae. It is very convenient to use to get around. There is a Starbucks across the street from the hotel's back entrance in a plaza. We did not dine at the Keio Plaza hotel, but it has several restaurants on site. There was usually a line at the breakfast restaurant when we walked by, as well. We did not use the small gym, which had several treadmills. We enjoyed tea and light snacks at the hotel lounge, which had a city view and some interesting Japanese topic books to browse in gardens, Kyoto, kaiseki, art, etc. I would stay here again.

I stayed in March, 2014 for 5 days. Great location in Shinjuku, staff very helpful and very comfortable room. Go to the Government Building very close to the hotel, where you can have a great view of Tokyo from the 45th floor, free!

Pretty disappointing. On checking we were told we'd been 'upgraded'. Our. ' upgraded' room was extremely dated and contrasted very poorly with the cheaper hotel we'd stayed at on our arrival in Japan. After going down to reception to complain, we were allocated one of the 'luxe' rooms. Whilst this was a distinct improvement, it was no better than our standard room in the first hotel we'd stayed in. I noticed that when we first checked in someone else was requesting a room change for similar reasons.The breakfast, included in our package, was also pretty average. In summary, I wouldn't recommend the hotel and certainly wouldn't stay there again when there are clearly better quality, cheaper hotels in Tokyo.

I stayed here recently for four nights, the hotel has all the facilities that I needed.It is a massive complex, and can be very busy, reception staff are very helpful, but be prepared to wait in busy times, so if you have transport booked - give yourself plenty of time!The concierge were great with advise about places to visit, and arranging trips etc.The room was more than adequate, good facilities including a safe, tea/coffee, tv with English news.There is free wifi in the hotel and rooms, with an easy access business centre too.The 2nd floor is full of restaurants covering several countries, there is also a great Kyubey restaurant on the 7th floor. The sky lounge serves meals too and from the 45th floor you have great views over Tokyo.Breakfast at the Garden Court was an excellent buffet but very busy.From the airport you can take the Airport Limousine bus only 3100 yen and it will deliver you direct to the hotel (alternatively you can take the bus to the Shinjuku station and take a 10 min walk), you can book your return at the hotel as well.the Shinjuku station is only 10 mins from the hotel, with great access to other areas of Tokyo and further afield.I found this hotel more than idea for my stay, it was clean, tidy and comfortable, and if returning to Tokyo would not hesitate to stay here again.

This is the second time we stayed at Keio Plaza. A most pleasant stay. Room was clean, they upgraded us to the "Exec" floors at 28th floor and South tower that has been renovated. There was a nice view to the east and I could see the Skytree in the morning. Hotel is close to everything, just 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku JR station. There are lots of restaurants near the hotel and a couple of convenience stores. Citibank was just around the corner of Shinjuku station south exit so that's a big plus.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is vast. I was unimpressed that after a 12 hour flight, time taken to get through the usual airport formalities and a one and a half hour transfer I could not get to my room for another four hours! Bad start. The hotel was quite comfortable with a wide range of facilities but my room was beginning to show its age (wall paper beginning to peel of the wall). The hotel staff were good, staff in the restaurants less so. I would not go back.

Adjacent to Shinjuku station and close to the Keio Sky Gardens for great food shopping. The Goyen National Gardens are a short walk away and was spectacular with the cherry blossoms and other blooming trees. Room was well-sized for the two of us and the higher floors have great views. There is a bustling electronics precinct nearby as well as many eateries. It was our second stay and though a little pricey was a great 3-day stay.

This is a nice Japanese hotel, rooms are nice sized and very clean. Hotel staff is very helpful with good English. Lots of travelers and families.The breakfasts are great, I've eaten in two of the restaurants for the Western/Japanese buffet and they have eggs in about every preparation as well as some Japanese breakfast items. The pastries, croissants, and danishes are some of the better ones I've had in Japan. If your hotel booking includes breakfast then you are in great shape!The walk to Shinjuku main station is a bit long to get to the West entrance. When I came into Tokyo the Narita Express stops at the Shinjuku South exit, and I wasn't too prepared to navigate from there (the hotel's directions are from the West exit which is nearly 4 blocks North). I must have looked just lost enough that a local helped point me in the right direction.The Oedo line is also at the southeast Shinjuku exit, so you can shortcut by heading directly that way instead of heading to the main station. The Tochomae metro stop on paper looks like it would be closer but is nearly as far a walk in the opposite direction.

This had to be at least my 12th stay at this hotel and I'm always happy here.We got a Plaza Premiere room on the 37th floor facing Shinjuku station. We always request a room on a high floor facing Shinjuku station and always get one. The room was a king bed room and was spacious and clean. We were on a smoking floor and could barely detect the smell of cigarettes. The room came equipped with an air purifier which we welcomed being you can't open the windows.The hotel staff here are mostly very nice, especially the concierge at the desk in the lobby. The hotel is very convenient to everything and Shinjuku station is second to none.We had breakfast at the hotel everyday. We ate at the Jurin coffee house twice. I was disapointed that they only offered a buffet for breakfast. There were not that many items available that were tasty. The eggs were watery and the bacon flabby. I wish they would offer their a la carte menu which was better. We also ate at the Glass Court super buffet for breakfast and although this buffet had many more choices, almost everything we put in our plates was cold by the time we got back to our table. Again, runny scrambled eggs and flabby bacon. I did try a made to order omlette one morning but it was runny inside and inedible. I guess I have to learn the japanese words for "please cook it well done" before my next stay. Lol.We visited the lounge on the 34th floor in the Southern building during our stay as we had free access to it because we booked as EIC members. The lounge was spacious and very pleasant. There was beer, water, soda and a choice of a red and a white wine along with some snacks. I'm not sure if mixed drinks were available as we didn't ask. We enjoyed our time here and will visit the lounge every night before dinner when we return later in the year.Overall, we really enjoyed our stay here and will continue to be repeat customers.

Located in Shinjuku, one of the funniest areas en Tokyo, this Hotel can offer you an excellent location for going out and walk, have a nice see sight, for dinner or if you prefer there are some places around where you can take a drink.The hotel is really comfortable, luxury, and the rooms are big enough and I can confirm you will have a perfect stay after hard working day.Service is good and the price is OK for the service you will receive.

Spent a week here in March of 2014 on a business trip. Excellent location and service. Close to the main train lines. English speaking staff. Great service. Several dining choices right in the hotel but so much more just a short walk away.
user_name:
Glenn_Van_Sickle
Cedar Park, Texas, United States

review_body: My 4th time staying in this hotel. Stayed in deluxe the main, although the room is not very newer, it was well kept. Larger room compare with many hotels. Provide all amenities. Great check in and out process. Will for sure stay here again. Recommended for traveller with kids.

Stayed here for a week and was amazed by the service every day. It's not cheap, but then again nothing in Tokyo is cheap. Location is central to everything, absolutely perfect. Did I mention the staff are amazing?
user_name:
Brian S
Lake in the Hills, Illinois

review_body: My husband and I stayed here for 3 nights and found that the location of the hotel was very convenient. Shinjuku station is a few steps away and allowed us the flexibility to go anywhere in Tokyo. The hotel did seem to have quite a few business clientele but that did not bother us.Room was clean and hotel staff was very welcoming. I highly recommend eating at the hotel restaurants. They were excellent!! They made the sushi you order right in front of your eyes. The fish was so fresh and the ambiance was traditional Japanese style. As for the Teppan-yaki restaurant.. was also quite excellent and we were able to enjoy Kobe beef. I highly recommend having Kobe beef if you have not tried it before!All in all, would stay here again.

Business quality hotel located well just east of Shinjuku station - one of the best locations in Tokyo for nightlife. Do be aware the hotel are strict with their 2pm check in policy, and if you get there on the early flights in, you don't have access to any lounges or courtesy rooms. Luxe rooms are recently refurb and had access to the luxe lounge - worth a few free drinks of an evening given tokyo prices! Easily accessed from Shinjuku station, which is easier once you get your eye in - look at the overhead signs, and pay attention to whether you want JR lines, metro etc. recommend heading north of the station for the little food joints seating 8 people max, great atmosphere, and keeps going late into the night. NB pool here is summer only!

The room i had was very spacious with two twin beds, plenty of space for suitcases. When I first walke in, I almost couldn't believe I was in a hotel in Japan. The bed was very comfortable, one of my best sleep in hotels. The only downside was in the breakfast restaurants. I went to both of their breakfast restaurants for my 2 nights stay, and the same thing happened in both places. 'Cuz I was alone, so when I left my table to get more food or tea, the staff assumed I had finished so went on and clear my table. (I made sure the "reservation card" on the table stands. As I was told, this in Japan shows that someone is/will be using the table). When this happend the first time, I was nearly full so I just left. But the next morning in their western style breakfast restaurant, it happened again not long after I got in( there was a long queue). I put the food I picked on my table and went to get some tea. In this less than a minute time, my table was cleaned again! I felt bad about all those un-touched food being wasted, even though the waitress, after she knew I was just away to get a cup of tea, helped me get almost exactly the same thing I had on my plate again. The impacable Japanese way of service. With her quite limited English, it sounds like it was the floor manager who directed her to do that. I don't know if they just tried to make the table turning go faster since there was a queue. Althought I am sure they didn't do this on purpose, but still...two consecutive days with the same trouble is not a pleasant thing.But still, a great hotel

We stayed at Keio Plaza in Shinjuku for several nights on a recent trip for our family of four with two elementary school age children. It was overall a great experience and an enjoyable hotel. It is centrally located, right near the station in Shinjuku, so it is easy to get around the city. They also have a special shuttle bus that takes you right to Disney Land and Disney Sea. There are a number of shops and restaurants in walking distance of the hotel. They also have several great restaurants right in the hotel. The room was clean, spacious and perfect for us. The service was very good. It is a larger hotel, so a bit impersonal, but still very good. Our only real complaint is that the breakfast is quite expensive (although really great for both adults and kids) unless you have a special ticket, so we recommend in the future that you negotiate to have breakfast included in your stay.
user_name:
Familyof4nyc
New York City, New York

review_body: This is a very huge hotel building, can be quite confusing. We stayed in the newly revonated Plaza Biz Plus Main twr with Free WIFI in room. There was NO free mineral water but there were supermarkets nearby. There is a sheltered walkway from hotel directly to Shinjuku station (the long is very very long). Shinjuku Station is huge and we found it easier to navigate above ground rather than underground, especially with the stroller/luggage. Hotel is near the Tokyo Govt Building, cheap to have lunch there.

This hotel is in a great location. It is close to the train stations and near a lot of significant buildings in the city. A lot of shops are nearby and the restaurants located in the hotel made it easy to grab breakfast before sightseeing or a late dinner afterwards.We were in the older tower but the rooms were still really nice. The beds were comfortable and the bathroom was spacious. I noticed that the beds did not reek of bleach like in some hotels here in the states. It made for a very restful night.The small market in the hotel also was great for buying water and snacks. The hotel provided a lot of amenities and the staff were so helpful and nice. They offer a free shuttle to Disney and Disney Sea which was convenient. You just have to be sure to make a reservation as seats fill up quickly.

Very nice and clean hotel and very conveniently located. Very helpful staff and the presence of a variety of restaurants on site meant I had good dinner choices after a full day's work. The hotel restaurants are a bit on the pricey side but during check in the hotel gives a number of discount coupons that can be used. Right across the hotel is also the Shinjuku downtown area with a lot of entertainment and dining options.Only drawback is lack of wi-fi in the lobbies and public spaces, so you cannot get online outside of your room. there is a business lounge on the 34th floor of the south tower with internet connection.
user_name:
AC233
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: You could probably do better than this hotel in Tokyo, but you also could probably do much worse. The Keio Plaza is old and could use some sprucing up, but the rooms are big enough, everything is clean, it has all the amenities one would expect of a reputable hotel, and is centrally located. There are shops and restaurants all around, and the subway station is 2 blocks away. Stayed here for the annual Tokyo Marathon and it was perfect as the starting line was 5 mins away on foot.

I was surprised when I arrived to check-in at Keio Plaza, because the queue at front desk looked like an airport check-in! There were at least 10-12 people ahead of me. Luckily I was asked to check-in at a separate counter and within minutes was given my key.I booked a renovated club level room, thinking that it would include the typical breakfast, afternoon tea and evening cocktails bit. It turned out that the lounge is only open after 10AM (no breakfast fare). Access to club is by showing coupons given at check in.The wifi speed is very good at times, but not very consistent. Toiletries are nicely scented and the heated toilet is a nice touch!

After exiting customs check in Haneda, approach the airport limousine transfer counter in the departure hall's waiting area. It's located to the left. There you can opt for the bus that stops at the Keio Plaza. Be warned though - with the route that it takes means that it will be about an hour before you reach Keio plaza, if you don't run into traffic. If you choose to take a train, be warned! Shinjuku station is huge, if you don't know the most direct and convenient way to the Keio you will be lugging your luggage all over the place before you get there, and it can be quite a pain!My friend and I took the refurbished room in the old tower. It was well appointed and large for a room in Japan. Two queen sized beds, with lots of space to move around. My room faced the metropolitan government offices so it was quiet and had a nice view of the park. There's a convenience store in the basement and several others around the area if you need supplies or cheap food stuff.The Keio also has a fine teppanyaki restaurant which I tried. I opted for the one with nice serving of Kobe wagyu beef. The meal was excellent and service was impeccable.

My son and I stayed here twice in March 2014 on our way to and from Hakuba. It had been recommended by Liquid tours. It was a five minute walk, even pulling baggage, from the Shinjuku rail station. Apart from the enormity of the foyers, the check in was timely (and in broken english).Seeing the different views from the two rooms demonstrated the enormity of the metropolis.The rooms/ bathrooms were clean and well stocked. There is a tiny convenience store in the basement. The only drawback to this establishment was the high cost of food incl, breakfast which was about $US30.00 when we were there. It is near impossible to stomach $30 cereal with a cup of milk. Check out was also efficient. The hotel has buses outside to ferry you to/from the airport and /or Tokyo Disneyland( for guests only).

All the reviews here say the same thing about the Keio, here are some tips for future visitors:1. The Shinjuku station isn't that close. Rolling a lot of luggage from the station for 15 minutes to the hotel isn't so fun after a 14-hour flight. Take the buses operated by Friendly Company and they have direct HAN or NRT route that delivers you to the lobby of the Keio. The bus logo is yellow and orange. Cost about $30usd one-way.2. There is an underground passage leading direct to Keio from Shinjuku. Look for Toei-Eido line exit going towards Tokyo City Metropolitan Building. 3. This hotel hates answering email and calling Japan is a pain. Use Keio's little-known number for their Los Angeles office: 1-213-362-7767 for any requests. I stayed here for approx $255usd per night.
user_name:
bombo20012001
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed here for three nights last week on a business trip. The hotel is massive with an extremely busy lobby so the check in process is fast, professional and somewhat cold. Once I got to my room, I found everything to be in order, was very clean and no issues to be had.As I had breakfast coupons for the cafe in the main lobby beside registration, I went there for breakfast and the assortment was good and fairly plentiful. No real complaints there.If I can sum up my stay there, it was largely forgettable, though completely fine and suited its purpose. Nothing made me feel as if I would want to go back there, however didn't feel as if I wouldn't either. That said, easy access to Shinjuku district and station is excellent so if that is what you are looking for, you won't be disappointed. You will be nothing more than a number there, but what can you expect from such a large hotel?

We stayed three nights in this Hotel located in Shinjuku during March 2014 before traveling to Yokohama to board the Queen Elizabeth for a cruise. It was fairly easy to catch the airport limousine bus from Haneda airport to the Hotel and cost JPY1,200 per person one way.Arriving at the hotel, we had to carry our own luggage from the airport limousine bus into the reception lobby. The check-in was swift. Immediately after the check-in formalities, a porter takes you and your luggage to your designated room. No welcome drink or towels to refresh you. But in spite of having a busy morning, the staff was cheerful, very polite, and all smiles.Keio Hotel has some 1,435 guest rooms with various room packages to choose from with some that can include a buffet breakfast. We had a room on the 29th floor facing East in the South Tower and enjoyed beautiful sunrises besides watching the moon rising in the evenings through huge glass windows in the spacious room.The bed is firm and the soft pillows ensure good sleep quality. The room has plentiful amenities from tooth brushes with tooth paste, disposable shavers, to weighting scales, from bath robes to ironing boards and steam iron. No effort is spared to ensure a comfortable stay with a home-away-from-home hospitality. The hotel provides 24-hour complimentary high speed internet . At the bedside there is a central light control, including a floor night light, and reading lights. The air conditioning is silent and a thermostat is provided to control the room temperature. The in-room safe is the largest I have ever seen in any hotel! No problems to place your laptop, iPad, and whatever other valuables you need into the safe- it’s huge!A buffet breakfast was include in our room rate and we had breakfast in the Cocktail and Tea Lounge. Some guests have the option to eat a Japanese breakfast on the second floor. The breakfast spread is adequate, more continental than usual with few hot items available. Limited fruit selection but a good variety of juices. The Hotel has lots of restaurants and even a convenience store. There’s a swimming pool on the 7th floor of the Main Tower which is opened only in the summer months, and on the same floor is a fitness room.Our room package also includes a “Luxe Lounge” invitation for free tea and bar drinks through out the duration of our stay, on the 34th floor in the South Tower.We chose this Hotel because the Hotel has an excellent location being in the heart of Tokyo city and only minutes away from the most popular shopping and entertainment spots. It’s a five minute walk from the Hotel's west exit to the Shinjuku station. The Observatory building is just across the road. There are also many restaurants and eating places within walking distance from the hotel. The hospitality here and the service is very good, especially at the Information Counter, where service is immediate and with a smile. I would return here if I have future visits to Tokyo, and do certainly recommend this hotel. This hotel also can be booked with the iPrefer program.

Very friendly welcome efficient check in room quite basic but adequate. First experience of the luxury toilet ! Kimonos in room a great touch. Very clean all round . Hotel has so many bars and dining areas we could have spent a whole day exploring .. But a visit to bars on the 57 the floor ( think it was) we'll worth the time view of Tokyo amazing. Location rest for station and plenty to see around the areas.

Since 2008 I've been a customer with my hus. Never a miss except one time with some strange manager dude with bad attitude.We stay here about a week every year while my hus visits HQ & I visit my brother family.Best CP esp considering the space & $, hence, highly recommened.For 2013 & 2014 I stayed @ Century Hyatt, and compared to that, although CH is a bit more pricy, the quality I got seems the same as KP. But it doesn't mean KP is better overall because I bought different plans, and it's hard to compare.One thing I can say is both hotels are quite suitable for middle class folks. If you want cheaper, go to Shinjyuku Prince @ Seibu Shinjyuku, but not recommended unless you don't mind love hotel quality (please search for the meaning). Sorry I don't know more expensive hotels to recommend since I have no experiences (after all, I am in working class & Bo-bin)Enjoy your stay in Shinjyuku; a lot to offer!The submitted photes are from Dec., 2010

Keio Plaza staff are amazing!!! Friendly and go above and beyond to assist. I had a medical emergency and they found an english speaking doctor within minutes. The hotel is beautiful and all amenities are clean and bedding is comfortable. Price for food and beverage is high but you get that in this high end hotel.Great location to Shinjuku train station and to many restaurants, bars and shopping. Definitely worth staying here

This is our third stay at this hotel and we will be back! First, the hotel staff is outstanding - very friendly and always helpful.
