Second, the hotel is on the bus route - from the airport - drop off right at the front door. Third, it is ideally located in Shinjuku - shopping and wonderful restaurants. Fourth, the Japanese breakfast is exceptionally good. Fifth, the amazing view of the city from the top floor bar. We only have positive things to say. Look forward to our next stay!

If you mentally prepare yourself for the check-in process then you'll enjoy your stay. It's long and they're insistent about seeing copies of bookings vouchers, which our other hotels hadn't been - that meant rummaging through our suitcase in the middle of the lobby - not great when you're tired and have been traveling. Everything else was perfect. We got a free room upgrade to Plaza Luxe, which meant our room was huge and we had access to the Luxe Lounge, which was a quiet oasis.We loved the Teppanyaki restaurant and the service and Kobe beef were phenomenal.Queues are long for each breakfast buffet so we popped across the road to outside restaurants most mornings.A good, clean hotel.

Stayed here as my friend was running in the marathon and it was one of the elected hotels. Having been my first visit to Tokyo, I cannot compare it to other hotels. I know we were in the older part of the hotel and yes, the rooms could do with updating, but perfectly functional, spotlessly clean and lovely and quiet. The convenience shop in the basement is very reasonably priced and the hotel is superbly located very close to Shinjuku Station with an undercover walkway for those who don't want to venture outside. The staff we came across spoke very impressive English compared to what we encountered outside (but we actually loved the fact that hardly anyone spoke English as it added to the adventure. must say, everyone so incredibly friendly and helpful even if we were unable to converse lol). The bar is absolutely superb. I love my manhattan cocktails and am very choosy as to how it is adapted to my preference, but the barmen listened to me and produced some of the best manhattans outside of my apartment! we also ate one evening in the hotel's Chinese restaurant which again was very good and very reasonable for indining in a 5 star. Would definitely stay again but would like to see the refurbished rooms
user_name:
Louise H
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Not sure which rooms the other reviews are coming from with comfy beds, but our deluxe double room in the South Tower had a rock hard mattress! I actually felt sorry for all the marathon runners staying there having run a marathon first. Afterwards we moved on to a traditional Ryoken for skiing and the futon mattress on the floor there proved much softer and more comfortable ... Otherwise couldn't really fault the hotel, it was clean, the bars upstairs were really nice if you can get past the smokiness.

Our room in this hotel was enormous by Japanese standards. It was well furnished and the bed was extremely comfortable yielding a good night's sleep. Bathroom though was on the small side and the low ceiling would be a problem for very tall people, especially when using the shower. Rooms were well cleaned and staff were generally quite helpful. The location of the hotel is also good, about 350 meters from Shinjuku station, with lots of eating places close by. Breakfast at the hotel was quite extensive catering for both Western and Japanese taste. Given the size of the hotel, it does lack individual personality, and sometimes there can be a wait for services and amenities.

Hotel Keio Plaza Toyko – Stayed 2 nights for a work function – clean, comfortable, and can’t really comment on the value. Overall Japan is expensive when compared to the USA. I paid about $220.00 USD per night. The service overall is better / faster / cheaper than the USA. Note bell hops and service people don’t expect tips – I had to force tipping person bringing bags up to my room. Acted like I shouldn’t have tipped. One minor problem is normally I iron / press my own shirts & slacks once I’m in hotel room. No iron or board in the room - same for the two other hotels I stayed in. Other than my wrinkly clothes I didn’t experience any issues.

We stayed here because we ran the Tokyo Marathon and it was one block from the start of the race. The room was surprisingly big (we had a kind size bed) and comfortable. There is a convenience store at the basement of this hotel and starbucks is just across the street from the East entrance (sorry, my husband has a mocha addiction).I stayed here on a corporate rate so I have no complaints at all about this hotel. Had I stayed at the rack rate, I would complain that it's overpriced but compared to the hotels of NYC, this is still a bargain.The service is on par with other Japanese 4 star hotels....excellent.

Highly recommended in Shinjuku area. Good location, clean & well size room. Restaurants & grocery store easily accesible. 4 minutes walk to Tochomae station 10 minutes to Shinjuku station (not strolley friendly; staircase up & down; bring light weight strolley). Walking distance to major shopping distance e.g. Isetan, Takashimaya, etc. Conclusion "Value for money".

I did not enjoy my stay at all at this hotel. The lobby is beautiful and certainly makes you feel like you are at a 5 star hotel until you get into the rooms...Negatives:- Looked like my grandmas house, very 1960/70's style- Smelled like stale smoke- Bed as hard as a concrete block- Not work the money paidPositives- Centrally located- Good customer service- Rooms were very largeI would not stay there again nor would I recommed it.

We really enjoyed our stay at Keio Plaza Hotel. The rooms were huge in comparison to most Japanese hotels and included a comfortable king sized bed, a coffee table and couch area and a good sized desk and chair. The rooms were nicely decorated and well maintained and we were pleased to find a number of power-point adapters for different countries provided in the desk draws.The staff were very polite and helpful and added to what was already a very pleasant experience.

This is our 4th stay at Keio for holidays in Tokyo. Service was good and location was excellent. Limousine bus service stops at hotel enroute to the Hilton and Hyatt at Shinjuku. We normally choose the Plaza Biz room in the main tower on 24-26 floor with view of the MET government building and free nepresso coffee. This is a big hotel with over 1000 rooms and therefore crowds from tour buses and families with little children can be expected at dining and common areas. We choose this place is because of its easy and covered underground walking distance to Isetan Shinjuku.

Spent 3 nights at their Luxe Plaza. Resonable price, spacious room, good service and great location in Shinjuku. A very commercial, smoothly operated and standard 5 star international hotel. This hotel does not have anything to surpise or disappoint you. The breakfast buffet served at their premier lounge (just beside the check in counter) was delicate but choices are very limited.

Location is convenient to the Shinjuku station (Narita Express). However, I don't see myself returning to the hotel any time soon. The rooms were cold. The bedding was very uncomfortable: hard mattresses, covered with sheets that felt like cardboard and terrible pillows. The breakfasts buffet was barely ok - nothing like the beautiful and rich offering at the Imperial Hotel. The fitness center is small but functional.

Good location and great service. However, breakfast was not that great. Nearby to Lawsons and just 15 mins walk to Takashimaya and Shinjuku station (underground passage). Rooms are big and spacious. Great view through window.

I stayed at Keio Plaza in January 2014. The location was ok-good. But the service was great. We spilled coffee onto your bed middle of the night so had to call housekeeping to change our duvet cover. They came very quick and professionally change our duvet cover and bed sheet very politely.The service concierge was very helpful as well. They help us book many restaurants even before we arrived the hotel via email.Thank you so much for your great hospitality!

This is a large hotel in a convenient location about 10min walk along a path from Shinjuku station. There are many restaurants on the premises, although we didn't visit any of them since we were in a huge international City with many awesome restaurants in it. I read the guy's review who noted the long check-in time and aged room.... My wife and I got lucky and checked in quickly, however every other time I was in the lobby, it was packed with a long disneyland-style line of people trying to conduct business at the front desk. We got lucky but not everyone does, apparently. We had specifically booked a renovated room and when we showed up we were initially led to a non-renovated room. The manager was able to correct the problem quickly and upgrade us, but WOW, what a difference. Our renovated room was beautiful, clean, modern, and filled with great amenities. We loved it and enjoyed our stay. The non-renovated room should have gone through two rounds of upgrades before it got to that point. It had marked walls, a terrible bed, a comical clock/radio, used slippers, no safe, no complimentary water, and the hallway had extremely dated carpet that was stained and depressing. The bathroom was upgraded and looked new. The used slippers and different amenities in the non-renovated room confirms Art9999's review that those rooms must be pretty much ignored.There is a nice gym with several cardio machines and weights. Our experiences with staff at the hotel were all positive, although I had an interesting conversation with someone at the front desk before we got there. Our flight was delayed and we missed our arranged shuttle from the airport, so I called to notify the hotel we'd be late and ask what I should do regarding transportation. The guy I talked to said we'd be fine checking in late but he didn't know about transportation, they don't deal with that. I was little confused by that reply and ended up laughing it off, but GEEZ! The "not my problem" answer is uncommon in from hotels in my experience. The trains in Japan are very good and we were able to figure it out, no big deal. I'm sure hundreds of people a day travel to Keio Plaza from Haneda/Narita... maybe I can help them out and put together a train route or list of shuttles so that they can be more helpful and less helpless if someone asks how to get to their hotel. Maybe it was a language barrier. Maybe I've just gotten lucky in the past with consistently extra-ordinarily helpful hotel staff? hahaMy review and rating is based on our pleasant experience with a new room and swift service, but beware if you don't request/pay for the nicer upgraded room or if you don't feel comfortable with public transportation. My wife and I had a lovely stay in a fabulous room and had kind service by the front desk, manager, concierge, and bell staff. We would certainly stay again and we recommend the Keio Plaza.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza for a few nights with a group tour. The hotel was large and had many different restaurants available for breakfast. The food was pretty good. It was convenient to have a money Exchange machine although I'm not sure how good the rate was.The staff was quite friendly and the room was clean and the location was very convenient. Right across the street there was shopping and restaurants so you could take a nice stroll.Would recommend.

We had a "nice" stay here, neither good nor bad. However, it was memorable in that it wasn't memorable at all-- just average.This hotel looks huge, impersonal and corporate... And the lobby is austere and flavorless. If you're looking for the quintessential Japanese experience, look elsewhere (a smaller hotel maybe). The rooms seem in good working order and are more spacious than some other double-bed-size rooms we've stayed in in Tokyo (we stayed in the renovated tower), but decoration isn't much to look at and the bathrooms aren't notable in any way. Two bottles of water are left in the room a day and cleaning seems good and thorough.Hotel staff is very kind (meets expectations) and location is good: Steps to Shinjuku Station and some fun areas. There's a DVD player in the room which actually turned out to be helpful. The money exchanging at the hotel is a HUGE rip-off, however, and not at all what I would expect from a "luxury" hotel. Other hotels would allow you to exchange at the desk and would give you a good rate. Here, they make you use an impersonal machine which skims off 7 or 8% all together.

I don't usually write a review as I find most stays at hotels to be true to what has been reviewed.I came here around 4 years ago with my family and we had a pleasant time as the hotel is spacious and the location is quite ideal.I decided to bring my fiancée to Japan for a little getaway over the long weekend in our country. It was natural that I would looked at Keio Plaza as I had a pleasant stay here last time. We booked a 3 night stay starting 14 Feb (Today) to 17 Feb 2014. Arriving here to check in we were faced with a huge crowd at the check in counter. It took almost an hour for us to check in to our room. I booked a No Smoking Deluxe Room with a King size bed. The room we got was rather "aged" and not particularly well maintained. Furthermore, the room we got was a Smoking Room with Twin beds. We guessed that it may have been a mistake since the check in staff were very busy. Trying to be understanding despite our hour long wait to check in, we were treated quite unprofessionally when we called Front Desk to request to change our room to match what we booked. The staff who we spoke to just made us feel that he didn't want be 'disturbed', so we requested to speak his manager. Lo and behold, we were already speaking to the manager, or he may have just informed us he was the manager. Being a manager may bring a lot of responsibilities, but surely, customer service and ensuring a positive experience for the guests, should be pretty high on his priorities. We asked to come down to speak to him. He just said nothing is going to change, there's nothing he could do, the hotel is fully booked, making sure to let us know with his tone that we were a bother and he is not willing to do anything. Determined not to let the incompetency and 'don't give a cr_p' attitude of the manager ruined our holidays, we decided to move the 2 beds together into a single large bed. We found rubbish behind and under bed side table between the twin beds, specifically, it was some plaster wrapper or sanitary napkin wrapper. Under the bed nearest the window, there was more uncollected garbage, this time it looked like a sugar sachet or something. We took some photos and will try to upload them after this review. In conclusion, despite the ideal location and spacious interior, the hotel is ruined by an incompetent manager who just didn't bother to even try to be nice, let alone, please a returned guest. Not only did he failed in his guest relation duties, the uncollected garbage we found speaks for his failing to manage his housekeeping staff. Running a hotel is a big responsibility, and if this is just too much, other career choices may be wiser for both the guests' and the manager's peace of mind.

Just back from a 5D/4N stay at the KPH with my 3 teenage kids.Its a very nice 4-star hotel located less than 400M from the Shinjuku station.Most of the staff speak some English and were efficient at what they do.We had requested an early check-in as our flight reached Narita about 7:00am,but this was not available and we had to wait till 1:00pm which was the best that they could do.We got into shinjuku via the Narita Express (NEX) which costs Y3150 per person for a 1-way trip (Green car).A short 10-minute walk and we reached the hotel,which was easy to find.We stayed in 2 superior rooms in the south wing and although a little bit old,the rooms were very clean and spacious.Heated toilet seat with bidet was a welcome in the cold weather! Beds were comfy and you had everything you would need....auto water dispenser/heater,flat-screen TV,etc....although most channels were in japanese!More importantly for the kids,there was free wifi (umlimited amount of devices) which the kids loved.speed was a good.We opted for the daily buffet breakfast (for an extra fee) when booking via Agoda,and this turned out to be a mistake.Breakfast was served at the Club Lounge on the Lobby Level (3) and although service was good,the spread was very limited.Basically,just scrambled eggs,bacon,sausages,cereal,salad,bread,pastries and fruits.We had the same fare for 3 straight mornings and decided to skip it on our 4th morning! We should have just gone to the many restaurants and fast food outlets nearby.Also,breakfast was up to 9:30am and when the japanese say 9:30am...they mean 9:30am! Getting around Tokyo was very easy with Shinjuku station less than 400M away and ample taxis just outside the front door 24/7.1-way trips to various tourist spots around Tokyo averages abt 3,000yen with the most expensive ride being to Divercity (Y6500)Would have preferred to walk but the cold (it actually snowed in Tokyo Bay!) made us decide to take taxis most of the time.The rooms were cleaned daily and everything in the room worked.room-service was also good and check-out was fast.A very good 4-star hotel and we'll definitely stay here again!

I stayed here in Dec-Jan this year with my wife and teenage daughter. It is a very plush classy place and is centrally located in Shinjuku right on top of the Shinjuku subway station. Our room was on the 31st floor which meant we had amazing views across Tokyo and on a clear day we could see Mt Fuji. The room was immaculate, as was the entire hotel. The staff spoke both English and Japanese and could not have been more helpful.the restaurants in the the hotel were too expensive for us but it is a short walk outside to literally hundreds of cheaper places to eat. The hotel is near department stores, electronics shops, post office, McDonalds... almost anything you might need.There is a 7/11 type store on the second floor of the hotel where you can get cheap snacks, drinks and souvenirs. You can buy meals from there which they will heat up in the microwave for you and you can take back to your room.The room we had had a hot water urn and tea/coffee making facilities.I would definitely stay here again and would recommend it to others.

Huge hotel, excellent restaurants but be prepared to pay around $80 - $100 per meal, typical business hotel. Very close to the Shinjuku train station, nice clean rooms, convenience shop located on level 2 which stocks pretty much everything. Free bus to Tokyo Disneyland. Shinjuku is a great area to stay in, if your looking for a night out on the town try the Golden Gai lots of small bars filled with friendly people and very reasonably priced drinks.

We stayed four nights with our family of four in early January 2014. We did have a luxury quad room which was very nice. Two bathrooms and four large beds and quite a nice outlook to the Metropolitan Government offices. I beleive the regular rooms are a bit tired looking and I think it is worth paying the extra to upgrade.The location was very convenient to Shinjuku Station and it can be accessed by underground walkway if the weather is inclement.It was just a short taxi ride to the Park Hyatt where we enjoyed drinks on 52nd Floor overlooking Tokyo (Lost in Translation bar).I would probably stay there again for the location.

KeioPlaza The first thing that hits you is that the hotel is overwhelmingly huge and kinda corporate. I found it somewhat cold and emotionless, very touristy, busy and lost in terms of brand identity. Check in was busy and took a while to do. Every time I went past the reception it was busy. Service was very good. Everyone was very happy to help even if English was a barrier. I really should have learnt some key Japanese words before I visited. I was on the 31st floor in a Plaza Luxe suite. Whilst the view was ok it was not amazing though the sunrise was lovely. My room was fine, not as good as other 'luxe' rooms I've stayed in at other hotels of which I've stayed at many. There was a small closet space and a bathroom that you could barley, comfortably dry yourself in without the door closing on you or you banging into the hi-tech toilet. The interior was fine, very clean, quite corporate mixing oatmeal and dark wood throughout. The iron that they kindly loaned me free of charge (organized efficiently by email pre my stay) was bizarre. It was like something you charge and then use?! Not that good at pressing either but was ok when used a few times. The good things were the water pressure of the shower that was so intense it felt great. You felt instantly clean and awake. The complimentary 2 water bottles were very much welcomed. Teas and coffees are ok but nothing special but the mini bar was quite empty. No snacks?! Room cleaning was great. The robes (too small) and towels were a tad scratchy but the array of them was useful. The hair dryer was good and there were plenty of all those little bathroom accompaniments such as hair brush, ear buds etc etc. The hotel has a few small shops within it and many restaurants. Book if you wanna use them as they have limited space. I would recommend you try the lobby bar and the main tower top bar called Polestar to drink in. But avoid eating, I found the food was disappointing, I even went plain and tried a club sandwich that was tasteless. Polestar has a wonderful view of the city, nicely lit ambience, serves good drinks too, plus you can smoke in there but I won't even get started on smoking in Japan as it's all quite strange and confusing. Its the hotels gym facility I was most disappointed in. The hotel is enormous so you'd think they'd have a gym that reflected the potential number of users. The gym is two very, very small rooms, equipped with a few running machines, 2 cross trainers, a small rack of weights, a bench, chest press and leg press. It's reasonably ok for a very small workout but a full body work out was difficult for me especially underneath the dreadful office strip lighting!! It's hideously decorated and generally unloved. WARNING: Don't lunge on the floor mats as they are not stuck to the floor and quickly slip from under you. There is a water machine and small towels provided but don't forget to sign the disclaimer!?! Breakfast was ok. I think our room level/type reflected the quality of the breakfast we got. I say this because others who attended the same work event as us had rooms on lower levels of the hotel and received a different standard of breakfast in a totally different breakfast room, not like ours. The breakfast we had was pretty standard of an average to good hotel. The usual plethora of cereal, juice, fruit, yoghurt and pastries were on offer and were ok quality. The cooked stuff looked processed to me, sausages, bacon and mass produced scrambled egg are not my thing. The breakfast room is the same as the evening lobby bar so very nice and relaxing to sit in. The last day of our visit this breakfast room was closed so we were asked to use the downstairs breakfast room. Wow what a change. In total contrast to the plush lobby room and it's wide selection of food, this was a drab looking, utterly grim canteen. The selection was super limited and the quality much, much lower than before. The 3 cereals looked like dust and I've never seen french fries served for breakfast. There was a table display of grey vegetables. Appetising? Avoid. It was very unpleasant. Would I recommend the hotel? Not really unless your working in the area. It's well located, close to the main station, very near to the place I was working and it was short walk over to a few drinking and eating areas so this was great. I managed to use the tube and that was super efficient and everything felt quite close by with the varying express services. I also took a taxi to the designer shopping district and that only took 15 minutes, so not bad at all. In short, the Keio Plaza needs to fine tune some aspects. It's big enough to have a great gym. It's expensive enough to serve a great breakfast. Rooms should have quality robes and decent pressing equipment or discounted pressing services, plus more hangers for long staying guests. It's the little things that I feel it lacks but it's these can really make the difference between being average and excellent. For the price you can get better elsewhere.

While in Japan last week we stayed four nights at the Keio Plaza Tokyo (also three nights in Kyoto at the Westin Miyako - very pleasant too). We booked a Plaza Luxe room which is worth the extra charge as along with a spacious renovated room you also have access to an attractive small private lounge with complimentary snacks and drinks and a spectacular view of Tokyo from the 35th floor. The Japanese service is excellent and very stress-free with no tipping which is a big relief for us Americans always worried about looking like the stupid fools we usually are while traveling :-) The location is very close to the Shinjuku Station and shopping. There is a convenience store in the hotel that sells beer, wine, snacks and ice which is great. Concierge was helpful.

We booked Keio for a short stay in Tokyo before heading to Niigata. Not expected too much before I arrived, as Keio is popular for tours. Located very close to Shinjuku Station but still a quiet environment. We stayed at the renovated deluxe room, which was very spacious with a cosy touch. Really like the room. We had good quality of rests.The only disappointment came from the breakfast, which I really think it did not worth the price. They have three restaurants serving breakfast which ee tried two, one with served both Japanese and Western breakfast which I think only reached 3 stars B&B; and another one only served Japanese breakfast. Both with limited choices of food, though the environment are nice. I will recommend friends to stay @ this hotel but excluding the breakfast!

We stayed at the Hotel on the way to skiing at Hakuba and on our return to Tokyo. Having stayed here before we found the same consistent service throughout the hotel. Check in and check out seemed to be more streamlined this time which was good. It is in a great location to access trains and there is plenty of shopping nearby. We used the free Disneyland shuttle service which is a bonus.The staff were very helpful and arranged an early check in for us on our arrival ( from our experience this is not normal in Japan)

We stayed at the Plaza Luxe room- which is very nice. On the 34th floor, the luxe lounge serves coffee and juices from 10am - 5pm, then shifts to different kinds of beers and wines with appetizers until 9:30pm. The view from the luxe lounge was very nice. It is walking distance to family marts and lawtons and many very good restaurants.It's a bit of walk though to Takashimaya. We stayed at Century Southern last year and it was a short walk to the department store. But Keio is much nearer the good restaurants and bars.Check in and check out was very fast. And being in Tokyo, the service was excellent. There is a free shuttle to Disneyland for hotel guests- which is very good- but need to book in advance. The bus ride was very comfortable and does not make several hotel stops- just goes straight to Disney.There are also a lot of tour which starts in Keio Hotel- so it's convenient to go on tours.The lobby is a little outdated though- but very clean and large.Love the heated toilet seats - which I believe is normal in Tokyo hotels.I would stay here again.PS- I found the pillows quite hard....

Though we did not sleep over, this hotel was the meeting point for our Walking Tour.In the few hours that we stayed thereUpside:1. Lobby was busy with travelers - yet remained clean and organized2. Staff are friends and accommodating3. Concierge, very helpful and even allowed us to leave our shopping bags + kids knapsacks with them so we can be hands-free while doing the walking tours.4. Excellent location, near everything!5. Great art collection6. Clean smoking room available 7. Toilets are big and clean

I stayed here in last week on Jan 14, Found it value for money. Location is good, connection with train and airport is good. Staff behaviour is good. Overall good experience.I also recommend the breakfast provided in this hotel. You can either choose Japanese cuisine or western style as your wish.

It's a great place to stay for business trip or family trip. I love the room, especially the size, cleanliness and the domestic decoration. I also recommend the breakfast provided in this hotel. You can either choose Japanese cuisine or western style as your wish.

This hotel is truly an excellent place to stay. The rooms are spotless, spacious, in excellent condition. The staff were polite, courteous and so lovely. Our daughter (10yrs) wrote a note to the cleaning staff to thank them for cleaning our room, the staff replied on her note thanking her for the note. This combined with helpful staff who were able to give us clear and concise directions to all of the great sights, book bus trips to Disnyland and Disneysea, help us with any queries and assisted us with any problems. A central and ideal place to stay

This is a massive hotel right in the middle of Shinjuku. It really is enormous and is built into a pair of massive tower blocks too so feels even bigger. No issues at all with this hotel, everything is there, everyone is nice it is just that it is so big that it doesnt care. We arrived at 10am - check in is at 2pm. We asked at reception just in case any rooms were ready and were told check in is at 2pm. That is it. Thats fine, thats what the rules say, thats what we paid for but they could have tried a little harder. To be fair, we came back at 2pm and they apologised and upgraded us to a Plaza Premier room which was nice of them. No problems, central location, got all you need just dont expect to matter to them!

I have stay at this hotel many times already. But for my last trip, I have terrible experienced with this hotel.First, I check in at the Executive counter and it took me half hour waited there for her to look for a non-smoking room. Of course I did booked with non- smoking room every time. The concierge service is not so good compare with other hotels in Tokyo especially the girl with name tag 'Chow 周' was extremely impatient and not polite which shown very unprofessional. So try not to look for her help.At last, the guy who came to my room to pick up my two luggages who was suppose to help me with the limousine bus. But while I went to the bus he kept saying 'bus cannot wait so he cannot put my luggages in the limousine bus!' I was so confused cause I was there already and the bus was suppose few more minutes to go. That's very ridiculous cause he almost made me miss the bus to the airport.This hotel is making me totally disappointed now and I will try not to stay at this hotel anymore.

I stayed at the Keio Plaza for 6 nights last week for business. The hotel is located on the west side of the Shinjuku station where the Shinjuku business district it situated. It is about 5 minutes walk from the front door of the hotel to the JR station. The shopping district of Shinjuku is within 10 to 15 minutes walking distance. In terms of proximity, I rate this higher than places like the Century Southern Tower and Shinjuku Hyatt which I have stayed at and of comparable standard. The slight drawback is that it can be quite difficult to find for the first time from the JR station.The price I paid for was around 21000 yen per night and I happened to have stayed at both the Main Tower and South Tower. The hotel in itself is just huge with 2 towers and multiple restaurants. The rooms are also fairly big in Japan standard as well. The room at the Main Tower is renovated whilst the one in the South Tower is slightly older (looks like those from the 80s). So if you have a choice ask for the newly renovated room.My rooms came with free breakfast and there were lots of different varieties to choose from: western buffet; Japanese buffet; American breakfast and Japanese set menu breakfast. But in terms of taste I would rate it average.Staff are very friendly and the ones I have run into all speak English.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is a twin tower hotel and it may be an older hotel but between it and the Hyatt Regency which is across the road (more or less) the Keio is a far better layed out hotel .The rooms are a nice size with a fantastic view over the city, which mite be blocked a little by the Tokyo Government building but it is a fantastic building (and it is kinda nice eating your breakfast watching the Government workers rushing to there work lol).The bath is a nice normal hotel size (not too big but not too small). The staff are like 95% of all Japanese staff ,they are very friendly and super helpful (when my wife and I checked in the porter brought us and our bags to our room ,give us a little tour and showed us the mini bar and said the food and beer was cheaper in the Convenience Store (South Tower 2F) lol and he also refused a tip (which is the norm for Japan)The lobby is beautiful and very well lade out with a nice gift shop and pay to use internet/computers with printers.My favourite thing about the Keio has to be the Polestar bar on the 45th floor,sitting down to a nice glass of Yamazuki looking over the lights of Tokyo city after a hard day sight seeing,what more could you ask for. Even when I am not staying in the Keio I still go to the Polestar for a few drinks.

Stayed in the Keio for five nights in a superior quad share room which was huge with two bathrooms, fantastic for our family. Staff were friendly, rooms clean, fantastic location couldn't fault it in any way. Easy access to and from the subway, JR, shops and everything you could possibly need, definitely recommend .

We recently stayed in a Plaza Premier room at the Keio Plaza. There is a separate check in area in the lobby which was convenient. The room was spacious, luxurious and well appointed with beautiful views over the city. The bathroom was clean and stocked daily with lovely L'Occitane toiletries. There is a store in the South Tower which contains various snacks and goods to purchase.From the rear entrance, cross the road and there are several small affordable restaurants to eat at, or the Royal Host next door which was nice for breakfast.An added benefit was the free Disney shuttle to Disneyland and DisneySea. I would recommend booking in advance and arriving early. There was a bit of a wait at the front gate but it was well worth it, as the waiting time was minimal for the rides.Close to the station where you can catch a bus to the Gotemba Premium outlets.A short walk to the other side of the railway takes you to a plethora of shops and department stores.The only issue (which is not major) is that the spa did not offer massages. These needed to be booked through a separate number and were only provided in room.The pool was also closed due to the winter season.Would highly recommend this hotel and would stay again. Recommend the Plaza Premier room.

Close to Shinjuku station and all that goes on in and around there, this hotel is great for first time visitors. it is easy to find and on the drop off/pick up list for tour operators and airport limo. There are rooms in two towers and it might be better to try for a room in the main tower if you want to use the gym-well set up and open 5am to 10pm-as then you don't have to change towers to get to it. Food in the 2nd floor restaurants it delicious and well priced for a quick bite-of course no end of choices if you walk around all that is on offer in Shinjuku. The good thing about the hotel is there is English translations to go with what you are about to eat and this is not common in the little shops and cafes. Great convenience store also with low prices and most of what you need.Rooms are comfortable and very clean and quiet. Only green tea provided but little urn on the boil so buy your own instant coffee/tea bags and milk from the shop on floor 2

The first hotel in Japan for the family and we were pleasantly surprised. Check in was painless and the porters were quick to help. We had adjoining rooms that were reasonably sized, the bathrooms were a bit tight but had a great range of amenities. The Hotel is well located with cheap eats just down the road and close to the JR station, take note of the different routes so you can take the easiest one when lugging the suitcases back. We utilised the free bus to Tokyo Disney but book on arrival and the Mt Fuji tour also departs from Keio. The restaurants seem to be full so make a reservation if you fancy one and the little in house 7/11 is great for drinks and eats for the room fridge. All in all a great experience and we would return if in Shinjuku.

* The room itself is nice. I got a business room so there is lots of extra desk space for my work. The rooms are quiet and clean. * The annoying part is the food - it's extremely expensive to eat anything in this hotel. And the breakfast isn't particularly exciting. The breakfast coupon apparently only covers a western style breakfast. Excuse me, I am in Japan and want to try every food I've never experienced before. Please pass me the chopsticks. I refused to eat there and had the less-than-average Japanese breakfast instead. * This hotel lobby is the biggest I've seen, and not necessarily easy to navigate. There are 2 main floors with restaurants, check-in counter (always busy) and other shops. There is a lot of traffic. The lobby does not have wifi either, which means that as an American with no Japanese cell phone, I need to go to my room to check my email and communicate with people. Not convenient. * This place has a chaotic feel about it that puts me on edge once I leave my room. I stayed at the Hilton Tokyo last year, just down the street. I highly recommend the Hilton Tokyo over the Keio Plaza Hotel. Superior breakfasts, rooms, and service. And you don't notice the large amounts of people like you do at the Keio Plaza Hotel.

There's so much to say but it's quicker to say what I didn't like- nothing. Everything thing from the service, dining, shopping, rooms, and cleanliness was excellent. The lobby is luxurious and always buzzing with activity. The fitness center is nice and the shopping lobby is huge. The proximity to wonderful sites like local parks, the fun store of Tokyo Hands, and pachino lounges.

I was there during my end year vacation. As like others Japan's hotel whose functional interior, so this it. But Keio Hotel is one of hotel whose bigger room class than others. They had 2 restaurant for breakfast, and the Japan's restaurant better than another one. There are a lot of choices of food near the hotel. There are many restaurants at the downstair of lobby, which sell food start from 2,000 JPY per person, or you can walk around 1 block from hotel and find Japannes authentic restaurant which open 24 hours and sell food start from 100 JPY. This hotel loated near MTR station, you can reach Shinjuku station from Tocomae station which located 100 metres from hotel. This hotel provide local tours to Mount Fuji-Hakone area, Tokyo sight seeing and many more. This hotel also provide bus to bring you to Disneyland Tokyo, Haneda and Narita's airports. And this hotel has guess relation who standby 24 hours to help you to get direction anywhere of Japan. Such as great Hotel!

I stayed here at the beginning and at the end of my trip, and the hotel was kind enough to store my large luggage while I was travelling elsewhere. Service was great from the moment of check-in - Hotel staff escorted us and our bags directly to our room. The renovated rooms in the main tower are definitely better than the older looking rooms in the south tower. I also liked the hotel's location - A 5 min walk from Shinjuku JR station. There are a number of camera stores and restaurants nearby.All in all, a very nice place to base yourself in Tokyo.

I normally stay at Park Hyatt in tokyo. I couldnt get in so i stayed at Keio. Im in the Plaza Luxe rooms. They seem to be brand new rooms. Its absolutely faultless!! ive also got views of the snow covered mountains.Full points for roomFull points for breakfastFull points for serviceFail with the gym (sorry Keio!!)I would highly recommend this place and stay here again.(there is very good convience store on ground floor too)

The breakfast concept of giving choices is good - able to pick different restaurants serving different breakfast meals was refreshing; traditional Japanese breakfast, international buffet breakfast, or very early morning American breakfast at the café.Pleasantly surprised at the concierge desk where this young lady helped me with detailed instructions on getting to my meetings. The venues were in English, she googled the location in the map, printed it out the map in Japanese, highlighted the path, circled the train stations, and wrote the English names next to landmarks (in case I walked there), even printed out the train station lines, which train to take and which of the 3 lines, names of the stations (in case I missed the station and travelled the other way). I showed the map with the Japanese/English wordings to the taxi driver and he easily found the way. The clarity and time saved was invaluable. Many customer friendly lifts, hardly have to wait long during peak hours for lifts to arrive. Nice spacious room layout similar to studio setting with sofa next to bed and window seats. Liked the full set of amenities.

My first stay at Keio Plaza Hotel was 31 years ago which was very impressive experience. From the first stay long time ago, I've decided to stay at Keio Plaza during my latest trip during early December 2013, and I booked the room for 12 nights, 9 months in advance. everything chages! The hotel is very crowded, the front desk staff who did a check in for me is very unfriendly and ask me for several nonsense questions. The room is clean. But the floor and ceiling are crap! A room above me has several kids kept running and jumping, and I can hear the noise very clear until 22:00. This really terrible! When I told the staff, no one took any actions! I made a complain several time until Duty Manager came to just say sorry. My experience in 5-star hotel in other countries were totally different. In this case, good hotel will change the room for me, or even upgrade. The lunch buffet is also time wasting. I made a big mistake to choose Keio Plaza Hotel for my family trip.One thing I've got to mention here is that one of the front desk staff name "Ogawa" is very friendly and helpful.

Keio Plaza is within walking distance to Shinjuku station which makes it easy to travel around Tokyo once you have mastered the routes. Location wise you could not ask for a better place to stay. This hotel was recommended by our travel agent for this reason but also because we could get a reasonably priced room to sleep our family of four. Although the rooms had most of the elements you would expect from a luxury hotel in regards to toiletries, service etc they are quite old fashioned and outdated. The bathroom and toilet are combined which was challenging at times with two teenager girls and two adults to share. It was also very small but did feature a heated western toilet which was quite a highlight during the cold nights that we were visiting. My major complaint from our stay at Keio was the beds and the Manchester. The beds themselves were extremely hard and the linen matched equally. To the point that I found myself tossing and turning most of the night and waking up sore from a night of slumber. Everyone else in the family did the same and because of the stiffness of the sheets this was noted by everyone during the night. Overall, this was a great choice of hotel location wise but something needs to be done with the bedding. Although the bathrooms were small and could be better layed out, it did include everything we needed. Would I stay here again? For convenience sake and a short visit maybe but I would schedule a chiropractic visit for when I returned home.

Stayed at keio plaza hotel for 3 nights. Conviniently located near shinjuku station. Access is via covered path.Breakfast was normal.Staff was okRoom allocated to us had 4 beds and 2 bathroom. Had a huge tv and also middle table and chairs.Very comfortable room. Has a convenient store that opens early and close late.

Positive : Good location, spacious and clean room, lots of food and shops around the hotel, warm closet with bidet, good service, airport limousine bus stop at the hotel.Negative : the AC temperature sets to warm for our family, the bed a bit hard, the two will not stop us to visit the hotel again

Keio Plaza Hotel Shinjuku is an excellent hotel - in terms of its service and location. We stayed there in 2011 and again in 2013 during our trip to Disneyland Tokyo. Their service standard is exemplary. For e.g., we wanted to take a train to a prefecture some distance away and the bell counter staff tried their best to assist us even though we had almost gave up on the trip. Also, the hotel provides free WiFi, which is a plus.Location wise, the hotel is near a shopping and dining belt so that made it very convenient for us to simply walk there every day. There are sushi and curry rice shops, 7-11 and Starbucks within minutes from the hotel. A free shuttle service to Disneyland Tokyo is also provided.We will definitely stay there again the next time we are in Shinjuku.

My wife and I stayed on our wedding night the 24th of December. We used the check in at the premier counter and had a lovely start from the beginning. The receptionist had great control of English and treated us with the utmost respect. The room was beautiful with an unparalleled view. We also enjoyed our time in the sky lounge with a relaxing atmosphere and a very polite staff. Next time I want to feel taken care of in Tokyo I plan on returning to Keio Plaza Hotel.

Just back from a short stay in Shinjuku, I was really glad to have stayed at this hotel. There is a subway stop right around the corner that connects to everywhere you want to go. My premier room was very large and immaculately clean. It was very quiet except for the dinging of a bell outside in the front circle to warn cars coming up from the car park. This was extremely annoying as from inside it sounded like someone's alarm clock going off every few minutes. The exchange/currency converter machine in the lobby, the staff who all speak English, and the many restaurants in the hotel make it a particularly easy place to stay for a first time tourist. The staff were extremely helpful with directions and suggestions. There is a bus between Narita and the hotel that leaves about every hour and cost about $30. US. It's a 1-1/2 to 2 hour trip so plan accordingly.

We had a pleasant experience of our stay in this hotel. Convenience of the location made it a perfect choice for our family. And they had a free shuttle to the Disney Resort. The only thing is that the breakfast food offered everyday was the same. Since we stayed for six days, eating the same breakfast everyday made it boring that we didn't look forward to it. Other than that, our stay was perfect.

The hotel is located near to the Shinjuku station, about 5-10mins walk, but can be a bit difficult to get bearing from the station as Shinjuku station is huge. The way to the hotel is via the West exit, or alternatively, there's a bus directly from the airport (Narita) which cost 3000 yen per-person. The bus and train trip takes about the same time 80-85 mins, bus trip of course depends on the traffic.The hotel itself is very big, room is considered large for Japanese hotels. Very clean and although the building is relatively old, the room fittings and facilities are very modern. The beds are also very comfortable, guests have the option for the bed linens everyday if they want by placing a card on the bed, to let housekeeping know you want it changed. The bathroom is a little bit small, but clean and well maintained. The gym is small, with a few cardio machines and free weights, opens from 5am in the morning, till about 10pm. There are quite a few restaurants in the hotel (on level 2F and 7F), but always busy, so do make advance reservation. The coffee house is always avaialable, and have good food as well.We stayed 4D 3N at this hotel, and it was very enjoyable, and due to its location, is really great for those who wishes to explore Tokyo easily from the main station, Shinjuku.

This is a great hotel for overseas travelers or first-timers, especially those from English-speaking countries. Lobby has a currency converter which was a big help. Slip cash in, yen comes out. Also, every place here took credit cards, even the mini-grocer on lower level. Hotel has three different buffet breakfasts and free WiFi. Staff know enough English to help you with just about any request and everything you need is walking distance, including the train station. Negatives? Well, the rooms are a bit dated and challenging for anyone over six-feet, but that's a minor gripe. My windows were also drafty but with a programmable thermostat it was manageable. Overall a very positive experience and the airport shuttle made getting to and fro relatively painless. Oh, and if you're a sushi fan, hit the sushi bar on the seventh floor. It was amazing.

Keio Plaza was a great find. Our Deluxe Room was modern, spacious with a good view on a high floor. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel who consider all the above with wif-fi in room, a good location and an excellent choice of breakfast as standard. The Executive Lounge was not snooty about children as some of the others. The service was impeccable and worthy of the stars!

This is our 3rd time at this hotel when we visit Tokyo. We really like this hotel because of its location which is a nice 5 minutes walk to Shinjuku train station (JR and Metro). The Airport limousine bus bring you to and from the front door of this hotel and this hotel provides free shuttle bus to Disney Resort. So it is very convenient if you are travelling with young kids or elders. Breakfast at the hotel was ok if you have it included with your room. They don't change their menus so you get pretty bored after a couple of days but doesn't worth JPY2900/pax if you have to pay extra. There were always line waiting at breakfast so expect 15 minutes wait if you are going to their main buffet (the Glass Court). They have other 2 restaurants, Jurin coffee shop and the Japanese restaurant for breakfast as well. The deluxe room we stayed at was comfortable we pushed the 2 twin beds together so me, my wife and our 2 kids can sleep on one big bed. Rooms are cleaned nicely and bathroom amenities replenished daily. Nice supermarket at the basement floor or Lawson a block away. Many local restaurants scattered within 3-4 blocks from the hotel.

Stayed here for 4 nights in April 2013. Secured with reasonable rates from its Club membership (I prefer) at Plaza Biz Plus room (25 sq.m renovated). lil miscommunication happened at check-in process, but solved easily. The room is good enough, spacious, clean, complete amenities, just good enough for everything inside. This hotel is best at its location for those who want to be in the centre of Shinjuku, just 5 minutes walk to the resto, cafe and convenient stores that are open around the clock in Shinjz.The Shinjuku station is about 10 minute walk from the hotel. Cons: 1. An incident happened one time when our room was cleaned and no towel provided (strange), but just by one call, the towels were delivered in our room within 5 minutes2. the rate can be so pricey at certain seasons, such as this last November, that made me to book other hotelLocation is best for this Hotel in Shinjku

This was my 3rd stay at the Keio Plaza and it seems the management and staff have been focusing on bring back that more traditional Japanese service level that was lacking on my previous visits. This is particularly noticeable in the main reception which has in the past felt a little 'off hand' in their attitude to customers. The good news is this has changed and there is now a more pleasant and service oriented atmosphere throughout the hotel. The location is still great, very close to Shinjuku station and the rooms are both large by Tokyo standards, and comfortable with everything you need, including free Wi-Fi (another improvement!) and great views over the city. My only problem in the room was the bed which was actually comfortable but for some reason made my back ache. Yes, the rooms are a little tired but not a problem in reality. There is a choice of breakfast restaurants with typical large hotel food - i.e. does the job, looks very nice, almost shiny, but actually is very bland. This is particularly true of the scrambled egg which actually tasted of nothing Didn't eat in the hotel any evening so cannot comment on the dinner arrangements. Overall a pleasant, good value and functional 4 night stay.

Rooms are large for Tokyo standard. The main tower is newer but we stayed at both towers without problems. I would request main tower but not a strong preference.Location is excellent. Minutes from Shinjuku JR and different subways. Do make sure you know which exit to take from the subway because the east and west ends are 15 minutes (walking) apart.Free buffet breakfast features a wide variety of food. Glass court restaurant is the busiest but the coffee shop serve similar food items except omelet station.Exercise facility is very small and not well cleaned (surprising for Japan). Be prepared to clean the equipment yourself. It has a nice view of the metropolitan office though.Front desk staff speaks minimal English but concierge staff speaks better english and can give simple instructions for subway.One of the rooms was filled with cigarette smoke when we checked in. We requested to switch to another room and staff was prompt with our request.

We stayed here to finish our two weeks in Japan and found it very comfortable. At first I was a little disappointed it wasn't in the "heart" of Tokyo but quickly found that the Shinjuku district to have all we needed included the crazy neon lights (check out "Electric Ave. near hotel) Tokyo is known for. Shinjuku train station is 2 blocks east and there are moving walkway beneath the streets to get you right to the front (or side) door of the Keio. The rooms all seem to have amazing views and are very contemporary in their design which is nice. We were on the 38th floor and I kind of slept the the earthquake everyone was discussing the next morning. Walk one block west of hotel to go up to the observation decks of the govt. building for some very nice views if its clear. If you're pressed for time go only to the one on the left (south) as it offers at least some distant views of Mt. Fuji on a clear day. The other (north?) tower has a fancy restaurant which takes up some of these prime views. Great park for running very close by (Shinjuku Chuo Park). Not much for distance but you can loop a few times then hit the streets if you need more miles.

This hotel is extremely convenient, next to the bustling (and massive) Shinjuku train station in central Tokyo. There are many subway and rail lines in the immediate vicinity, making getting around Tokyo very easy. The hotel is immaculate, with very good service. The rooms are pleasant and comfortable. The concierge booked us a trip to Mt. Fuji, which was wonderful. The only criticism I would have is that the hotel's restaurants are extraordinarily expensive, even by New York City standards. Perhaps this is because this is Tokyo, one of the most expensive cities in the world, but the prices were simply breathtaking. There is no informal place to have coffee or light snacks (like a Starbucks) as in every other hotel of this caliber. The hotel does have a fairly large convenience store in the basement, where one can buy yogurt, juices, snacks etc. at normal prices. Outside the hotel, near and in the station and in the huge Keio Department store on top of the station, there are many nice (and reasonable) places to eat. Except for the food options, this hotel is highly recommended.

It's an old hotel, you can tell from the equipment in the room. But the rooms are spacious and clean. The hotel is located close to the heart of Shinjuku (walking distance) and you'll never be bored. Highly recommended if you're in Japan for business or pleasure.The breakfast buffet was also good with a wide variety of both Japanese and Western food.

Almost two hours on bus from Narita to here. No doubt this was a old fashion hotel but they kept the cleaning standard so good.The check in was easy and fast. Walking inside the room, I was expecting a small cranky room, but surprisingly is was not that bad after all. My room was facing The Government Metropolitan Building.Convenience store was plenty along the way to Shinjuku Station, dine out was also easy with a choice from standing sushi bar, ramen, and several fast food such as McD, KFC, Starbucks.Getting everywhere is quite easy, as long as you can read their railway map. Your can easily go to Harajuku, Shibuya and even Disneyland. The good thing about this hotel is they are Disneyland neighbor hotel, so we can catch a free shuttle bus from the lobby straight to Disneyland and Disneysea. Just don't forget to reserved first at the front desk near the main lobby. The staff speaks or at least understand english quite well. So it wont be a hassle.Talking about the room, now they provide free wifi access inside our room, and don't worry about charging your devices, they prepare 3 kinds of adapters in the drawer under the old fashion flat thick TV. No mineral water for free so be prepared. The toiletries was not bad, the razor was well designed, not a cheap plastic stick with a sharp knife on it. And of course the toilet bowl was special for non Japanese people.Overall, my 5 night staying here was not bad, even there were nothing special about this hotel. But one thing that I observed in this hotel is, if your don't put your rubbish in the bin, they will not remove any thing on the table even a single inch.

Excellent location and proximity to restaurants and shopping. Very good concierge who understood the needs of a tourist in English. For example, we got directions to take the subway to a place of interest. When we studied the subway map, we realized that there was an alternative route that involved fewer stops. We tried that alternative route, and found that it involved a fairly complicated change of line that could have gone badly wrong for someone unfamiliar with the place. When we returned via the route recommended, we found the change of line was simply crossing the platform. It took slightly longer, but was definitely the more "tourist-friendly" way to get there. Service was great throughout. But rooms were functional and ours was too warm as the air-conditioner was turned off (central heating for winter), although our children's room was very cold. Shower head was impossible as it kept pointing away from where you needed it to be.
We moved to this hotel after one night of bad experience with another 'recommended' locationIt was a real delightCleanliness, sleeping quality, location... - superbThis is no cheap deal but worth it

Rooms :Liked this place a lot. It's nice for having a not to expensive, yet comfortable stay at Tokyo. They have rooms for every wallet. We booked one of the cheapest rooms, which was quite small, but didn't lack in comfort at all. We stayed three days. Rooms were cleaned very fast and very attentive.Hotel itself :The hotel has an inviting lobby and amongst many other nice restaurants and bars a very recommendable 1-Star Sushi restaurant. A nice night skyline can be enjoyed at the sky bar on one of the top floors of the building. Unfortunately even the standard drinks are quite expensive at that bar, but the view makes more or less up for that. Not that interesting on misty days though ;-)Location :The Keio is only 5-10 minutes of walking distance away from Shinjuku train station from where you can spread out to the different parts of Tokyo. It is also related to the Shinjuku underground pedestrian tunnel system, which can come in handy on very rainy days. A lot of 24/7 conveneys, smaller shops, restaurants, and bars around.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel for a five day business trip. The location is fantastic (right by Shinjuku station) and the rooms were very large and modern - on par for North American standards. I stayed in the main tower in a superior room and it was very comfortable (remote black out blinds, cable tv, wifi, great bathroom toiletries and a very comfortable bed) There is only wifi in the bedrooms which means the common areas of the hotel do not have any internet access (unless you go to the business centre and pay money to use desktop computers). Surprisingly, I was disappointed with the hotel breakfasts (I ate at the Japanese restaurant a few mornings and it's all vegetarian cold/luke warm options - I've had much better japanese breakfast buffet options at other hotels and expected the same but it fell short. The restaurant by the lobby also had an executive/western/continental buffet breakfast but again the food was luke warm and bland. The bar downstairs stays open late (until 2am - for those of you who are jet lagged) but the bars on the 43/7th? floor closes around 11pm. Overall, I'm a bit disappointed by the food in the hotel (restaurants, catered business dinner and room service) a bit of a let down (Tokyo is a food city!) and the hotel food it was very average (at best) and quite pricey - for those of you who have the time, I would venture around the hotel - many great restaurants/options down the street. Also, I wished there was more of an atmosphere in the common areas/lobby (no seating - just a few chairs near check in desk and a very dated look, wasted space) but by no means a deal breaker and overall it was a very comfortable hotel.

My son & I stayed 7 nights @ the Keio Plaza Hotel during the last month of October. The location is excellent. It's an easy 10 minute walk to Shinjuku Station. Our room was in the Main Tower. We had a Superior Room, which offered enough amenities & size to be comfortable. The overall experience was positive. The room layout & bathroom were fine. The beds were comfortable. The view was outstanding as we were on the 21st floor. The room rate was reasonable because of our timing & length of stay.The hotel staff as is the Japanese custom, was exemplary. All staff were courteous & we could communicate through broken English & Japanese greetings. We never did dine at any of the Hotel restaurants. We ate out because there were so many great places to eat in the Shinjuku area. The only complaint I have was being put into a Smoking Room when we requested a Non-smoking room. We were too tired to switch upon arrival / jet lag & we settled in once the proverbial smoke cleared. We had a great trip sans the rainy weather & the subway congestion which is to be expected. I would recommend the Keio Plaza Hotel to all.

Pros :• Excellent location: 7 minutes walk to Shinjuku Station, from where you can get everywhere you want in Tokyo. For me one of the best locations for sightseeing.• Rooms: if you happen to have booked the Plaza Premier Rooms, you will probably be happy. The rooms are modern, recently renovated, good design. For Tokyo quite large rooms. Free WIFI. There is also a separate reception so you do not have to queue for check-in.• Good value for money : for Tokyo very reasonably pricedCons :• Huge hotel with many groups, so sometimes the lobby is crowded like a train station• The decor of the hotel is somewhat outdated.• Service: OK, but typical 4-star big hotel service, very impersonal – do not expect much of individual service.Conclusion:Great location, Plaza Premier rooms very good, good value for money -> I can recommend it mainly due to location!

A lovely big room which I was not expecting! Big beds. Lots of bits in the bath room. The breakfast was first class but let down by the queue to get into the main restaurant, I would recommend using the coffee shop at the end of the corridor which served Japanese and western breakfasts with buffet service. A very big hotel with 2 towers (make sure you get in the right lift!)

Keio Plaza's location is ideal, although in Tokyo there are many such ideal areas due to the sheer expanse of the city. But this corner of Shinjuku is great.This is a massive hotel and the check-in throng, assuming you catch it, could put one off. But do not worry, this is possibly your last contact with e multitude of other guests.Once in your room in the South Tower, which is the remodelled one, you will find large rooms for Tokyo standards with all the amenities and style even a discriminating traveller would appreciate. Large bed, spacious (Tokyo standard) bathroom, high-end amenities, wi-fi and caring chambermaids.The breakfast we were assigned involved two restaurants. One was Japanese which was authentic from the delighted of the patrons. Another was the more western-style continental breakfast by the lobby overlooking a garden and a little lagoon. We alternated and liked each one for different reasons. One for the food and another for the ambience.If I were ever to stay in Shinjuku in the future I would certainly stay here.Oh, one more thing, the airport limousine bus stops right at this hotel and that is a terrific convenience.

Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo is really close to the Shinjuku Station. From the Airport Limousine Bus Stop (at the Shinjuku Station) or the Keio Shopping Centre, walk all the way straight and under 10 minutes you will arrive at the hotel - with all straight roads so lugging your luggage or bags will not be a problem. We were moving across cities, and before staying in Keio itself, we went to Hakone. The hotel gladly allowed us to leave our bags with them with no extra charge or fuss. In fact, we had a little hiccup where wrong bags were taken. The airline coordinated directly with the hotel to help us collect and deliver the bags while we were at Hakone! This was very very helpful and they didn't even make us feel bad for having to do this. We have stayed at other hotels nearby with 3 adults in the room previously, and we were glad that the room at this hotel is more spacious, and the "spare" bed is a proper bed and not a camping bed. This is a very convenient hotel - to access the station, and also as a stop for the airport limousine. Being in the heart of Shinjuku, there are plenty of eateries, convenience shops, shopping malls around the area so there are plenty to do just in this area alone.

This hotel was very easy to get to from Narita airport. The airport limo drops you off right in front for about 3,000 Yen/person. Totally worth it. The hotel also arranged the airport limo to pick us up to take us back to the airport.Our room was very big (as far as Japanese hotels rooms go). We made sure to ask for the Plaza Premier King rooms. These are on the 35-38 floors. Room was very clean with view over Shinjuku. My only complaint is that I did not find a full length mirror in our room. The hotel is a short walk to the Shinjuku Station. There are many things to do around Shinjuku Station. You could spend a whole day/night exploring.It looks like there are many restaurants in the hotel as well. We didn't try any because there are many food options close to the hotel. Also, we discovered an underground walkway right in back of the hotel that takes you to the Shinjuku subway. This would be super helpful in the rain or other bad weather.

This is an excellent hotel. The buffet breakfast is hot with eggs cooked to order. It was the only one to present hot food on a 14 day tour. We arrived after an 11 hour overnight flight from U.K. and the rooms were not ready for the next 4.5 hours. THERE IS NO GUEST LOUNGE and you have to hunt for somewhere to sit, even on upper floors! Other than this the hotel can not be faulted.

Good value for a 4 star hotel, just a 7-10 minute walk from Shinjuku train station. The rooms are good sized for Tokyo, clean and well kept. The lobby area is nice with various shops and eateries, what you expect for a 4 star hotel. Would say that the Keio Plaza is equivalent to the nearby Hyatt Regency in terms of value-for-money.

I spent 2 nights here at separate times. It is very conveniently located, about an hour and a half to Narita airport and about 30 minutes to Haneda airport. There is always alot of activity happening in Shinjuku and if you want to go somewhere else, the train station has easy access to many other cities. This hotel is large, yet the service is good, prompt and polite. The room was large, very clean and with all the modern ammenities and bathroom toiletries, and depending on which floor you are staying on, the view is nice. I did not dine in the restaurants, but there were a few to choose from, if you did not feel like going out.

To Monique A, are you sure you checked in at keio plaza hotel Tokyo? Shinjuku? I'm surprised with you're review about the hotel ! That's not the Keio hotel we stayed in Tokyo recently? By the way, our room was located in the south wing fronting the Tokyo City Hall. Our room was spacious as well as the bathrooms not comparable to the hotels we stayed in Osaka and Kyoto. A free wifi was provided in the room, the restaurants in the basement were good enough, a convenient store too, the hotel has openings in all four sides making it convenient for hotel guest to go in from what ever direction you're are coming from, north south east west. And for such a big hotel like this, we were given a very reasonable rate. I highly recommend this hotel and surely in our next trip to Tokyo, we will stay here again .

We traveled through Friendly Planet and were set up in this hotel. It was incredible, especially given the amount of money we paid. My husband and I had separate twin beds, which is customary in Japan - but no big deal. Shinjuku is a great place for tourists to stay and it's close to a lot of night life and to the subway system. The breakfast buffet was amazing - it was included in our stay, but I'm not sure if that is normal or if it was just part of the Friendly Planet tour. The staff were very friendly and most of them spoke a great deal of English! Overall a great experience!

I recently stayed 4 nights at the Keio Plaza, three in a Premier room (about $250 a night) and one night in a regular room in the South Tower. I had emailed the hotel about our late arrival (around 11pm or later) and about our wifi delivery as well as requesting the shuttle to Disney. Email correspondence was VERY easy with the hotel. If you are going to Disney, email them about 30 days before to book the shuttle, they will drop you off and bring you back to the hotel, for FREE. The Premier room was wonderful, we were in a large room on the 39th floor with a good view. Amenities are nice in a Premier room, PJ's, slippers, robes, high end soaps, lovely tea cups, FREE WIFI!, a great bed, a safe, to name just a few of the niceties provided. South Tower (which costs me more because I missed a sale by booking too late), was OK (Noisy, I could hear lots of noise from adjoining rooms unlike the Premier which must be soundproof). We had the same view just 20 floors lower so looked directly into a building next door. Bed was not as nice, and of course the amenities were of a much lower class, and we had a safe as well. We had a WiFI delivered from Global Communications and at check in, they said I had no packages. I was certain I should have, but told them I would contact Global. About 5 minutes after we were in our room the phone rang, and sure enough, they found the package. We used the Limousine bus to get from Narita to Keio, since our arrival was so late at night. But the hotel is fairly easy to find from Shinjuku station, just follow to the West Exit towards the Tokyo Government building and you'll find it. We didn't eat in any of the restaurants. We tried to eat at the buffet, the Golden Corral, we walked up and they invited us in and said there was no menu, it was buffet. They asked us to take a look which we did, it looked OK, but when I showed the host we had a 10% coupon, he told us it was reservation only! The buffet was about $35 per person, so I guess the savings of $3.50 meant more to them than my business. If you do stay at this hotel I recommend you join IPrefer rewards and book EARLY to get a good rate in the Premier Deluxe rooms.

This hotel well located but the rooms look like motel rooms from 20 to 30 years ago.The walls are damaged, the room does not have a safe, I just arrived from Indonesia, Malysia and Borneo, this Hotel makes Japan look like a third world country. If you reserve, ensure you are in the main tower, RENOVATED room.

Stayed for 3 nights with my husband, the staff were helpful and polite. Arrived early in the morning after our flight, whilst unable to allow us early access (seemingly against Japanese custom to stray from a plan) they did allow us into the bridal suite to change and refresh and then held our bags. The rooms are modern, well appointed and sized and the staff spoke good English and were helpful in organising a trip to Mt. Fuji. Would absolutely stay here again.

If Tokyo is your entry point to Japan, Kieo Plaza would be a perfect place to touchdown. The first plus is that it is on the route of the Friendly Bus Limo Service which deposits you to the hotels doorstep. Keeping in mind that a taxi from the airport could cost anything upto 300 USD, this is a hugh plus.Check-in was efficient but be warned that the check-in time is 14.00 hrs and no amount of pleading will get you a room before time unless you have a an early chek-in booking for which there is a charge. My wife and myself had travelled on a overnight flight so waiting till 2PM was tough considering we were at the hotel at 10.30.Once this hurdle had been crossed it was smooth sailing all the way. The staff is polite and ever-helpful, location is excellent - plenty of restaurants and bars withen 5 mins walk, so also the Shinjuku station. Its a hugh hotel with 2 towers called Main and South Block. The main block has been refurbished but the room was decididly smaller that the South Block where we stayed on our return from Kyoto. South block is ,however, in need of an upgrade but still clean and comfortable due to the size. So if you have lots of luggage stay in the South.Many interesting restaurants in the hotel but a tad expensive. Better to walk out and eat you can also experience Shinjuku area with all its atmosphere and activity.No security safes in the room but a efficiently run round-the clock safe deposit center at the reception.Please do feel free to buy from the convenience store...its well stocked and not any more expensive than the stores on the road.The japanese people are the politest race i have met in all my travels. This hotel embodies that trait. If you want something xtra try and be more polite than them- its difficult but works. I got my early check-in by being just that :)

It took me a while to really decide on the hotel to stay in Tokyo with my daughter and my 89 year old Mom. The location was superb. You can walk to many smaller eateries, shops and get on the biggest subway station in the City. Pushing my Mom on her portable transport chair around the vicinity was convenient, although there will be times when you have to walk a little further for ADA accessible ramps = more exercise for you! Staff was friendly, courteous and professional. The hotel is very large with lots of high-end priced restaurants below ground. We preferred eating outside walking distance from the hotel with the locals. The subway station's various wings have tons of eateries to choose from, as well. There are also some coffee shops just outside of the hotel where you can get very good hot breakfast sandwiches and coffee that is of European standard. There are 2 large malls several blocks away. Our hotel room was high enough to witness one of the most spectacular sunrise for which Japan is known for. There were 3 of us, so the room had 3 slightly larger/wider than twin sized beds. Tokyo is one of the fascinating favorite Cities of mine and the people go above & beyond to help you. Japanese are very prompt, similar to Swiss. So, when the shops & restaurants open, they open on the dot. We'll most likely stay at this hotel again.

Fantastic location. Close to the major train stations and quite a few 24 hour shops nearby for you to explore the local flavors. On some parts it can be a bit dated, but you're staying here for good access as opposed to enjoy the room. Free Wifi is always welcome, and the staff were extremely polite and helpful. Check-in was a wee bit slow though.

Pros: great location (5 minute walk to the station and the shopping district, as well as the business buildings), free wifi, huge rooms (for Japanese standards), small convenience store opens late (5am to 2:30am), friendly staff, room service prices were lower than other Japanese hotels, Narita airport bus comes straight hereCons: hotel from the outside looks old and a little worn down, the shower was interesting...I'm not that tall (5'10") and my head was about 5 inches from the ceiling (which felt odd), not as many taxis available here compared to other hotels (had to wait a couple of minutes...NOT a big deal)

Our first trip to Tokyo, japanese people are so polite and Japan itself is so clean, we loved our experience here. The hotel was built in the 1980's however you wouldn't notice with the impressively huge building and the large lobby. I've read many reviews on TA and upon check in, I made sure we were in a renovated room. We were on the 25th floor and my husband and I found that the room was spacious compared to many other Tokyo hotels. The bathroom was okay, a little on the small size and feels a bit old. We found many stains throughout the room on the carpet and on the cushions however housekeeping did a good job making sure it was clean. There was an in-room safe, kettle, a travel adapter (if you forgot yours) and a mini refrigerator which was great however the mini fridge didn't close properly so our food/drinks was not cold. The hotel is situated near many restaurants but be forewarned tourists aren't as welcomed as you think and language barrier can be an issue. This hotel is situated on the west side of Shinjuku so its quieter and we always felt safe, there was a Lawsons and 7-11 about 5 minutes away from the hotel. There was so much to see/do/explore and this hotel was great for that since you have to walk everywhere (be prepared to walk!). Concierge was also great as they offer free umbrellas when its raining. Pros: 1. The room is pretty spacious compared to many other Tokyo hotels 2. This hotel is a Disneyland good neighbour hotel which offers free shuttle to Disneyland and/or Disneysea which we took advantage of 3. Close to many restaurants 4. Next to a covered walkway which leads to Shinjuku station 4. Staff spoke decent english 5. Airport limousine drop-off/pick-up right in front of hotel 6. There's an in-room safe which a lot of other hotels are not availableCons: 1. Needs a renovation 2. Bathroom was a bit small and dated 3.
