There are many exits from this hotel so it can be confusing 4. The mini refrigerator didn't close properly so our drinks/food wasn't coldTIP: We landed at the Nartia airport, we took the airport limousine and with traffic it took us 2 hours to reach our hotel. Many people advised us that if you come from the Haneda airport, it will only take 30 minutes

I strongly recommend this hotel to anyone. Its lobby is excellently decorated; its rooms are spacious; its location is unbeatable. The staff is courteous. It has hundreds of restaurants within walking distance not to mention several high-end ones in the hotel itself. The hotel has very good Italian/French, Chinese and Japanese restaurants. We ate in all of them. No complaints. I would give this hotel 5 stars hands down. The rates were very reasonable.

Top spot in Shinjuku. Walk to the subway and parks close by as well as to Kabuchiko district to see the Robot show. Reasonably expensive by western standards but Tokyo is dear anywhere. Stay if possible in North Tower on top floors for view to Mt Fuji. Breakfast included which was excellent

We choose this hotel for our annual family vacation. We travel with two adult daughters (no boyfriends). In Japan, hotel rooms accommodate two adults. You may be able to get three in a room, but four is impossible. This hotel has a four-bedded room with two bathrooms. It was perfect for us.It is located across from the government buildings so the staff accommodates international clients. They all speak english and the service is first class. It has many restaurants to choose from and one cafe is open until 11pm, which is good when your flight arrives at 10pm. There is a fairly good convenience store in the hotel with decent selection of drinks and spirits open until midnight, I believe.The in-room amenities are very good with large bottles of shampoo/conditioner, body wash and face wash. Not those silly little bottles. You also get razors, shower caps and toothbrush w/toothpaste. The supplies are daily. theer is also a hot pot for water, and they supply instant coffee and green tea.We also used the laundry service. If you call them before 10am, your laundry is picked up and delievered to your room the same day, in the afternoon. This was very helpful as we were caught in the middle of the typhoon and our jeans got soaked.I would return to this hotel on my next trip and I would recommend it to anyone going to Tokyowho doesn't speak Japanese. You are able to get along fine. They also helped us with ground transportation reservations back to the airport. I was able to cash American Express traveler's checks at the front desk for yen. There is also a foreign exchange machine that will disburse japanese yen for your country's currency.If you need to draw cash from an atm, the post office is only a block away. In Japan, you have to go to a post office for international atm transactions.This hotel is very famous in Tokyo. ANY cab driver knows where the Keio Plaza in Shinjuku is. SO you don't have to worry. LOve this hoetl.

Im not one to rant on tripadvisor but my experience with keio plaza hotel was the straw that broke the camels back. On my maiden trip to tokyo. I stayed in the keio hotel.plaza luxe rooms. Plaza luze rooms apparently recently.renovated and the official website promises so much. While clearly stating that ALL plaza luxe rooms gets lounge access. This was not the case. Although i booked the room through agoda, it was clearly communicated via agoda that lounge access was guaranteed. Either there is poor communication between 3rd party bookings or something seriously wrong with keio plaza. On top of that, a twin room was issued instead of a double room. While that was rectified after 2 trips up and down 33 floors. I feel sorry for the the dude who was magnimously polite and professional throughout this ordeal. As mentioned, while rectified. It was with great reluctance for some bizarre reasons due to the fact that the double rooms are cheaper than twin rooms on keios official website. Arent i saving the hotel monet???Still, the aging hotel has class and its near everything. I will however give it a miss in the future due to this unpleasant experience. For the same price. There are other luxury hotels which can do better. Japan is extensively connected by trains which might take a little to get used to but you will soon find out that no matter how secluded your hotel be. Like the hilton etc... you are never too far from everything. Approach this hotel with no expectations. And do not trust the official website. There is some serious miscommunication going on.

There are so many good places to stay in Tokyo. In the Shinjuku area, this hotel is ideal especially if you can get a reasonable rate with the breakfast coupon included. The staff at this hotel are well trained and proficient in English and courteous and helpful. They have several restaurants and at least 4 different places for breakfasts. The rooms were nice and well maintained with new fixtures, lcd tv, mini refrig, etc. Overall appearance was clean and newly refurbished. Only thing (for me) was that the bed is on the firm side (typical of bedding in Japan). Maybe the deluxe rooms have more cushiony beds. You can find some hotels in Tokyo which are located right next to the subway station. Keio is located a block or so from the Shinjuku station so the walk back and forth with shopping bags may longer than other places. Over the years (from 30+ years ago), I've never had any problems staying here.

I love the location of this hotel as it is adjacent to a covered walkway that leads directly to Shinjuku station. Although it is not inexpensive there are deals to be had and anything between $150 - $200 a night should be considered a fair market rate for this class of hotel.

The hotel is close to the rail and bus station. During my stay, my travelers stay in the hotel because of hiking Fuji trip. There are bbc and CNN but no English movie channel.Many restaurants and convenient stores are just around the corner. The hotel is a bit old but well maintained.

We stayed there for 5 nights in a Superior room which was very spacious considering a typical hotel room size in Tokyo. Breakfast was lovely as we could choose from 3 - 4 different restaurants each day. The concierge was also very helpful and gave us good tips on how to traverse Tokyo's complicated metro system. Being a Disney resort good neighbor hotel was very useful as we could utilize the complimentary shuttle bus. Shinjuku station is 5-10 min walk away with many shops and eating establishments nearby.

As my first hotel in Japan I was a little disappointed, when you enter the hotel it looks very impressive but the room we had in the south tower perhaps need a little updating. However it was clean and a good size. The beds unfortunately where not very comfortable but now having finished two weeks travellering around Japan I have come to the conclusion that they do not go in for comfortable beds. Very convenient for the railway station.

Stayed here for 2 nights,large room,plenty of space.Usual tv etc,like most hotels in Japan you get BBC News or CNN.Take your own tea/coffee,they provide green tea.Great location,can walk out to good selection of restaurants,depends which door you leave by!rear door takes you to good area including post office,good restaurant opposite post office on corner,they have those plates in window showing their menu.Hotel near Sinjuku station,if you have spare couple of hours go across to the Observatory,large goverment office with 2 towers.Lift to top,we went in south tower,free entry,coffee shop on top,great views.Breakfast buffet had good selection,would stay again.

Huge 40 years old hotel where at least rooms in the main tower been renovated. When coming by train from Narita airport take West Exit and walk ten minutes to the hotel. Lots of modern skyskrapers around this hotel.Was staying in Premier Room which was on 34th floor with great view. Room was large enough and modern but without character. WLAN works very well. Daily english newspaper was provided every morning.

From the large hotel inventories in Tokyo, Keio Plaza was a superb choice. Extremely comfortable, very well maintained and luxurious hotel. The staff is incredibly helpful and friendly. Plus, this hotel's location allows one to stay in a well located, upscale and upbeat neighborhood, but one can still get plenty of rest! It's a great choice!

i went with my wife on may 2013 and find everything is good except the breakfast.. the food is not my taste, better you find another food outside with cheaper price and also better taste pros : - the place is near underground exit connected to shinjuku station , next to the side hotel door- close to yodobashi camera and LABI so if you a gadget mania like me, it's like heaven- the price is reasonable cheap compare to others great hotel- keio plaza is a disney neighborhood hotel so you just need to register in front counter and the disney bus will pick you up but BETTER TO RESERVE IT IN ADVANCE or the bus will full, they have limited seat for each day schedule- you also can reserve shuttle to airport either NARITA or HANEDA , it very helpful especially to far NARITA airportcons :- the breakfast is not recommended, better find better food outside

We are a family of 4 and had to get 2 rooms as there were no family rooms, so this made the stay kind of expensive, but really it only worked out to be about $180 per night per room so I guess that really isn't that much for the location of this hotel.The room on the surface looked quite nice, but everything was a bit rough around the edges...wall paper peeling, carpet grubby, mould around the bathroom that you could smell in the bedroom. Bathroom products were ok, bed comfortable, nespresso machine was nice but no espn channel as stated on the website. We were on the 25th floor and had a nice outlook over the city.Staff at check in/out were efficient but not friendly and at the bell counter I stood there for 10 minutes without anyone making eye contact or saying "be with you soon".Easy undercover walk to the train station and shopping centres made this hotel very convenient, but I would probably try a different hotel next time.

People value aspects and features of hotels differently depending on their preferences and objectives. I like to stay at 2-3 different hotels in Tokyo depending on the purpose of my stay. When I am in Tokyo with a group of MBA students, a large hotel with several restaurants within the hotel or nearby and easy access to/from train and subway stations is needed. This large hotel is in Shinjuku with a vibrant night life, within a few minutes walking distance from the Shinjuku train station. Nearby there is a Starbucks. Also, there is a post office with ATM machines to withdraw cash which is almost always the cheapest way to purchase Yen (let your bank know you will be using the ATM card in Japan, just like you do with your credit card issuing banks). Keio Plaza has two towers; depending on the floor, rooms can be very large and recently renovated. There is a small fitness center with two treadmills from the past century but they get the job done. On the same 7th floor of the main tower, there are several restaurants; one of them is a branch of Kyubey, a great sushi bar. There is a convenience store at the basement of the hotel. There are too many restaurants to list them all here. There are two bars at the top with excellent views. In addition, you are within walking distance to Park Hyatt which has the New York Bar (featured in the Lost in Translation) with even better views and live jazz music every evening. You will be far away from the financial center of the town (Marinouchi, Nihombashi, east of the Imperial Palace in general) so if that is your objective then it makes sense to stay in that area. If not, Keio Plaza is a very nice option.

I would only recommend this hotel is location is a priority. Which for me location is at the top of the list when traveling. Steps from Shinjuku station it is very convenient to get to all the major sites in Tokyo. It is a very large hotel with several towers. The hotel, like many area hotels, will store your luggage at no cost if you plan to take the bullet train around Japan. This was very helpful for us!

This hotel is has a great location. It seems that they thought about everything to make your stay convenient and pleasant. I indeed recommend this hotel. The price is high but this is how things are in Japan.

Wow, what a disappointment! The Keio was the first hotel I ever stayed at in Asia, about fourteen years ago and I remember being really impressed by it. Of course I was at the start of fourteen years of hotel stays in Asia and Europe and perhaps more easily impressed. I had a four night stay in Tokyo last week and was booked for all four nights at the Keio. The place now has the feeling of a dinosaur. It reminded me a lot of the Waldorf Astoria in New York. Formerly great, but now it's just tired, a little bloated and very, very run down. When I walked into my room in the South Tower, I had that immediate sinking feeling that this was not going to go well. Just looking at the state of the carpet - stained, uncleaned, worn - and the walls in the entryway - scuffed, worn wallpaper - was enough to convince me that this was a bad bet. That was before I got to the basically undecorated, scruffy room with furnishings from the 1980s, a bed that was as lumpy as it was solid, and the final insult; the bloodstain on the bathroom wall. I kid you not. And all this for the one low price of between $150 and $350 per night (sliding scale based on the fact that it was a holiday weekend). I stayed one night due to tiredness, slept not a single moment on the most uncomfortable bed in the world, used the - it must be said adequate - gym in the morning and checked out. I moved to the ANA Intercontinental in Roppongi for the remaining three nights, which was a much better bet. Very poor, Keio. I do not recommend this hotel.

Great Hotel! Large but close to Restaurants, subway, shopping. Rooms were very clean and spacious with fabulous city views from the upper floors. Safe and easy walk from train station. Only negative was you had to pay to use the pool, which was very strange. Took train to downtown and took hop on hop off bus around Toyko. Very convenient way to see the city.

The service is unbelievable A++ quality and they don't accept tips. Location: It is business location and you see a lot of business people around the area. Close to Train station is a super plus. It's a main train station so you can go anywhere. It is bit far to walk to the red light district to have a drink after you walk all day sightseeing, but not bad maybe 20-25mins walk? Restaurants at Hotel: Buffet was OK taste and not much selection. Service was OK. Lots of people there.The Bourbon bar there has low seating really interesting. Drinks are good. Service is good.We also went to the sky bar in that hotel. It was very foggy that night we can't see anything but the drinks were delicious. Service was good.If you are looking for A++++ Service, this hotel is amazing.

Stayed at the Keio Plaza in Shinjuku for four nights. It's a very grand hotel, however, it's quite dated, the rooms are not modern at all except for the television. Don't get me wrong the bed was fantastic, but the fixtures and fittings and overall presentation of the hotel did not speak to me at all. You can never really fault japanese service, and the same goes for Keio Plaza, but I think it's past due for a little revitalising.

I stayed here for 5 nights, booked 2 rooms. Upon arrival, the Q was draggy, and the receptionists were helpful enough with the basic English, no communication issue. Make sure you ask for wifi router in order for you to have the internet connection routed, if you do not request they will not inform you about this. The room was a tad outdated and cold in the winter, the portable heater was not good enough. And I had electrical problem whenever I turned on the heater causing black out in the room. Bathroom was okay, nothing special, with hollow partition wall so you still able to hear noises from your neighbour. There is a convenient store down the hotel at basement which is very helpful at night when your suffer from night food craving.Hotel is not too far from Tokyo Metropolitan Building about 5mins away, and around 10mins to Shinjuku and accessible from west exit if you are getting off at Shinjuku station. And if you and your family are planning to visit Disneyland, better make your way fast to the Bellboy counter and book for your seats because they are limited. The schedules are installed on the wall at the bellboy counter.

This hotel is located in the financial district, but close to the mall, public transportation (subway and LR), restaurants and shoppes. From the outside, the hotel is impressive but the rooms are small and the furniture and bathrooms are extremely dated. Having spent the preceding days in a Kempenski property in Beijing, the difference in decor was dramatic and depressing. The furniture is straight out of the 70s and in need of an immediate upgrade. The room is small and, for a king-sized room, the desk is oddly positioned in the middle of the floor instead of against the window or wall (we quickly rectified this by rearranging the furniture - I'm sure this happens quite a lot). But the hotel rooms were clean and well attended, the bed was comfortable and the front desk staff was friendly and helpful. Although outdated and looking a little worse for wear, the chair in the room was a recliner which was very comfortable on the rare occasion we were in the room. Our room rate included breakfast which is offered at one of three restaurants; our favorite offering both the Asian and Western breakfast options was very good. There are many restaurant options inside the hotel itself, all that are much more expensive than exterior restaurants just steps away but convenient with great service. Not to be missed is the view from the lounge/bar on the 45th floor, a great place to relax and reflect on the events of the day with friends.

We stayed here in janurary and it was perfect. The rooms were large by japanese standard and the hotel was in a good location. A must in to have a beer in their bar on the top floor. The staff were very helpful. It is ideal because the airport bus drops you right at the front door. It is the best way to get from narita to the airport.

We stayed for 3 nights and the location, amenities and service were very good. Their facial liquid soap was Sheseido and they had hair elastics for women (quite useful for me with long hair). Their liquid body gel, shampoo and conditioner weren't the run of the mill kind so I truly enjoyed using those. They had a sofa bed apart from the comfortable beds and the rooms are also wifi ready. Staff are fast, efficient and courteous, considering that Keio is a very busy hotel, with a lot of group check ins everyday.

great location, great pricegreat view... it's a 1400 room hotel... & am sure it's a old one... but good fr tokyo.., big rooms for tokyo standard. quite a loveable place.. hotel itself t be explored... small things matter... like a convenience store etc

I have read some reviews prior to my stay at Keio Plaza and I know I would probably not be disappointed. We had 2 rooms right next to the elevator, but it was so quiet for the 2 nights we were there we did not hear anything and I'm a light sleeper so it's important to me that the room is quiet. I noticed that the elevators in Japan don't make that ding noise when they stop. This is true for all 7 hotels I stayed from this trip.I also want to mention that we had set the wake up call and some how the phone was not hang up properly in my 2 daughter's room and the call did not go through, they even send someone to ring the door bell to make sure they were up. I think that's excellent service. I love when they have doorbells for every room so you don't hear room service or housekeeping knocking on the doors around you.I would like to recommend everyone to get the package with the breakfast buffet. Lots of selections to choose from.

Our 4D/3N stay in this hotel together with our insurance co. client executives and co-brokers was a pleasant and memorable experience in all aspects. From the hotel room, services, the courteous and friendly hotel staff and most particularly the bountiful and wide array of choices of food from the three restaurants.We all ended up with full stomachs everytime we dine :). I wish I could bring my family someday.

Enjoyed this hotel. Really nice rooms and big for Tokyo. Reasonably close to train station and restaurants and shopping centres close by. It is in a nice part of the city. Staff were helpful. I would certainly recommend this hotel highly.

Great hotel in a central location. All facilities and the service by staff is excellent. All restaurants attached to the hotel offer great variety. Close to shopping and public transport. Has medical centre on the upper level. Great reception area with staff very experienced and willing to assist. Shuttle bus to airport is an excellent service.Really enjoyed the stay.

I've visited Tokyo several times but this is first time I stayed at this hotel. The room is HUGE by Japan standards, and in its capital too!However breakfast selection is quite limited in both the Western and Japanese restaurants. I would have given it 5 stars if the breakfast has wider selection.

Overall I had an excellent stay. The Hotel was centrally located - near public transport, restaurants and convenience stores. I always had an impression that hotels in Tokyo would be expensive and small. But Keio was spacious enough for myself, wife and 1.5 year old daughter, was definitely also value for money. The rooms also had almost everything you could want in terms of amenities.Service was excellent. I had left an item in my room after checking out. Speaking via phone to their housekeeping staff, they were able to quickly help return the item.Would definitely stay here again.

We took the Narita express in from the airport, 90 min to Shinjuku station. You arrive just a few meters from the South Gate. A taxi cost just NZ$10 to the hotel and all done from getting out of the train in under ten minutes.The hotel is only five minutes walk through vibrant restaurant and electronic shops to the station.We have found the whole experience very courteous and helpful in the hotel without exception. The breakfast buffet is a good mix of options. It cost NZ$35 for two peopleThe room is very spacious with a very comfortable bed and lovely duvet. The bathroom has L'Occitaine products in generous quantities all replaced each dayThe only very small con would be the shower which is over the bath - totally adequate but just not up to the standard of the rest of itIt is blissfully quiet in the room with a silent air con system.This hotel is ideal for a stay in Tokyo's Shinjuku.

We stayed for a total of 4 nights at Keio plaza with a trip to mt fuji for a night in between. Keio plaza rooms were comfortable, though we were out on a smoking floor for our first 3 nights, which was not very pleasant for non smokers. On out return we requested a non smoking room however and staff were more than willing to oblige. Staff were very helpful and extremely friendly. Location is great, short walk to shinjuku station and many restaurants. Breakfast was very average and overpriced, would recommend walking to cafe's close by for breakfast if you stay here.

Good location and a myriad of amenities! An audio player, boiled water waiting for us to drink some hot matcha after checking in.. On top of that, speedy wifi connection and a well-stocked convenient store on the 2nd floor within the building. The rooms are authentically user friendly, great choice for those who enjoy the comfort of feeling at home away from home.

We usually stayed in Keio when we went to Tokyo. However, I'm ready to try another hotel. The location is very convenient & close to shops. Their staff are very polite & friendly but the guests from Mainland China are horrible. A big family cut in front of us at elevators & ignored the others who have waited there. Sometimes, you could hear the children running & shouting along the corridor.

Keio plaza hotel, Shinjuku has the best location with very convenient transportation. Our method is to use the hotel as the base to visit other famous areas / cities in 8 days. The hotel's facilitiy is complete and the room is very large & comfortable with kind service. We have already stayed at Keio hotel twice during last two years. It takes about 10 minutes from the hotel to the MRT / subway station on foot.There are several big shoping departments in the neighborhood. We found many different articles in there. Except the Shinjuku, we have also visited Shibyuya, Akihabara, Ueno, Asakusa, Tokyo Sky Tree, Harajuku and Ginza. Ginza is a very very beautiful city especially at night. This is a very interesting travel experience. We are planning to visit Tokyo again soon to see more.

On the first part of my trip, I stayed at the Hotel Century Souther Tower and thought the location was good. This one is GREAT!GETTING HERE:- Walk 2-3 blocks from the CENTRAL WEST exit of the Shinjuku station on the street level or take a cab for about 750-800 yen (Right now, that's about $7-$8 USD).- If you are taking a limo bus (shuttle bus) from the airport, this is one of the hotels they stop at.LOCATION:- The surrounding area has everything you need from convenient stores, restaurants, souvenir shopping and etc. Make sure you check out the Standing Sushi Bar for some cheap ane excellent sushi.AMENITIES:- It was one of the very few hotels with an outdoor pool but you have to pay 2000 yen.- Limo buses arrive and depart here. We were able to buy our limo bus ticket to the airport right in the lobby.ROOM:- We had a room on the 35th floor, south tower. Very modern. Great views of the city.Overall, I would pick this hotel over the Hotel Century Southern Tower but it is a little bit more expensive.

A massive Hotel in nthe central area of Tokyo. Very close to the shopping streets with numerous amounts of electronic shops in the close vicinity of the hotel.Underground walkways lead you towards numerous amounts of shopping malls, if you are into that ! Don't let your wife go in town with your credit car, please !Good sized rooms but don't expect interconnecting doors. Tried to book in advance, but no chance ! They should though be available.If you are looking for the 21 century, then please think twice. Two things wre not available in our rooms. Coffee & Wifi!!! A must in the hotels we normally stay in ! Based on the layout & facilities, I would describe the hotel as dated & maybe soon up for a slight upgrade, Ie Coffee & Wifi & a new TV/Clockntercating system, whic most likely seems to be dated as well.Anyway, rooms are clean & well maintained, but dated!

This hotel was great! The room was spacious, well appointed and close to Shinjuku station. We were given a room on the premier floor which was beautiful. The complimentary toiletries were from L'Occitane. The free wi-fi worked well. The outdoor pool was nice, but there was a charge. The free gym was small, but adequate for a regular workout.On the downside, the restaurants and bars closed relatively early. The Skybar was underwhelming and the cocktails unpalatable. We did not use the hotel breakfast.All in all, I would happily stay at this hotel again, but would not use any of the catering facilities. There are plenty of bars and restaurants in the near vicinity.

Normally I don't do surveys but for this hotel I will make an exception.Together with my daughter we had a perfect stay. We can look back on a beautiful, well organized and clean hotel where people still know what real service is.

we stayed in plaza biz hotel for 2 nites and were so happy we choose this hotel. very good location, with lots of cafe, eateries, minimarts just a doorstep. i wonder why people still bother to eat in the hotel where there are so many choices close by.hotel's room is very modern, spacious, bathroom very clean. bed is comfy although we still prefer hyatt regency for the bed. all in all it will be a good base hotel for exploring tokyo, the shinjuku station is close by. service was great, it is a big hotel and can got very crowded at busy hour, however the service level was good and standard four star.

A comfortable bed, a clean and well decorated room, excellent service. But this is a massive international style hotel and does at time feel rather impersonal. I will certainly stay there again, because it's convenient and pleasant - it's just a bit nondescript, that's all.
user_location: Weston on the Green, United Kingdom
user_name:
JCCMOxford
Weston on the Green, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed at the Keio Plaza hotel for 4 nights in July 2013 and although the hotel is very beautiful and clean i would not recommend this hotel to travellers in Tokyo on vacation.good points - The hotel is very well located.Its only a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station which in itself is something to behold.Its easy to get anywhere in Tokyo from Shinjuku station.Its also a 10 minute walk from the main Shinjuku and Kabukicho area which has a vibrant night life filled with restaurants and entertainment.The Metropolitan Government Office is 5 minutes walk away which has free entrance to a very nice observatory.The hotel itself is very clean and the hotel rooms are quite spacious and clean as well.The staff are quite friendly and accommodating.They also have a free Disney resort shuttle which was great.The convenience store on the bottom floor was also very handy.The bad points - Although the staff are friendly the whole hotel seemed catered more for business travelers and because it was such a large hotel the service seemed impersonal.We couldn't believe that there was an extra charge of 2000 Yen for the pool.I have never in my life come across a hotel that charges extra for the usage of the pool.With Tokyo being so hot in the summer we booked this hotel making sure they had a pool.As you can imagine we were quite disappointed when we arrived at the entrance to the pool area.We asked the concierge if they could arrange a taxi to the Tsukiji fish market at 4 am as the subway was closed that early and because we wanted to go early to catch the tuna auction.Now this was half my fault for not checking online but the Fish market was closed due to a National Holiday.Surely the Concierge at the hotel could of told us it was a National holiday in Japan and that the market would of been closed for the day.We were stuck in the area until the subway opened and we could go back to the hotel as we were not prepared to pay another 2000 yen for a taxi.The resturants and bars in the hotel are grossly overpriced.Why would anybody eat at the hotel for those prices when there are countless great resturants that are better priced only 10 minutes walk away in the main Shinjuku entertainment area?All in all i would definatly look for another smaller hotel in the Shinjuku area next time that could provide a better and more personal service.

The hotel is big and outdated room. The plus point was it provided extra bed without additional cost since I travelled with kid. Nevertheless the room needs to be refurbished. The location is a litlle bit far from Shinjuku station. There are 2 starbucks near hotel to grab coffee and sandwhices? The room is not big but I think it's a standard in Tokyo.

I booked this hotel simply because it's the Sunrise Tour pick up point for the Mt Fuji Climb. 1st impression - it's big, and the room (I had a corner room in the South Tower) and bathroom are spacious, especially by Japan standards. We had a great view of the city from our 30th floor room.The room has a big closet, I can even open my big luggage in there. There's a nice 2 seater with coffee table, and a study table with multi-plug adapter in the drawer. We had a King bed which was great!The complimentary 2 sachets of coffee and tea was very nice. But you have to pay if you want extras.Bathroom: There's a long bath which we never used, and ample counter top area for both my husband and my toiletries. Reception staff can be curt (seems they are very full as it's super peak period) but not rude. We booked 2 rooms but they were not able to put us on the same floor which was a bummer. The bell desk was definitely very efficient and speaks good English. Don't fall for the Concierge's recommendation to dine at their Japanese Restaurant. It was a rip off - very expensive, and the chef kept hurrying us off as they wanted to give our counter seats to other guests. The sushi chef rush through our orders and the sushi was so badly made the rice crumbled when we picked it up. Location is convenient as many has already commented. Just a trivia: SIA crew stays here as well.

We stayed in this -quite huge- hotel for one week. When we arrived we kindly received an upgrade of our room to a superior double room, in the Main Tower, with a nice view from the 29th floor. The room was new, very spacious and nicely decorated (contrary to other reviews of people with old rooms, so please make sure where you are going to be). The hotel is very close to the Shinjuku station which is a good departure point to any location in Tokyo, and is surrounded by many restaurants, bars and convenience stores if you do not feel like travelling long distances. The hotel has a small but nice gym and an outdoor pool which we both used, and a huge number of restaurants, a convenience store, gift shops and many other services. Both checking in and -out at the reception were done very quickly and efficiently. When we got back to the airport on departure date we could also use the limousine bus service to the airport that left from the hotel.

Abbiamo trascorso una settimana presso il keio hotel plaza.non conoscevamo Tokyo e ci siamo fidati dei giudizi letti e riscontrati su trip al momento della prenotazione. Abbiamo trovato un'ottimA offerta.Camere spaziosossime ,pulizia eccellente. Staff disponibile.posizione centrale,a pochissimi minuti dalla stazione shinjiuku.Consigliato.We spent 1week in this hotel. We didnt know it at the moment of reservation and we trust on the comments already found on trip advisor.we found a very good relationship between price and services. Our room was very big,every day cleaned with all of the confort needed.The staff was good. The Position is perfect,few minutes walking by shinjiuku station. Suggested!.Stefania

The Keio Plaza is a great place to stay if you want somewhere central to everything in Shinjuku. It is a 5 minute walk from Shinjuku Station and just across the road from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building which offers fantastic views over Tokyo.We stayed in a Premier Plaza Suite in the Main Tower and found it to be of a large size by Japanese standards. It was certainly big enough for the 3 of us.These rooms also offered free Wi-Fi for the duration of our visit which was great.Keio Plaza is also one of Disney's Good Neighbour Hotels so if you are planning on visiting either Disneyland or Disneysea you can catch the free shuttle which runs from the hotel each day.The dining options were good also, with Japanese, Chinese, Korean and Western being some of the options available including buffets in some of the restaurants.The staff were all very polite, courteous and the majority spoke English.If we were to stay in Tokyo again I wouldn't hesitate to return to the Keio Plaza.

The Keio Plaza is in a very good location, within 3-5 minute walking distance from lots of restaurants, bars and shopping in Shinjuku (and convenient to several). However, I would not recommend staying here for the following reasons:- This is a very large, and therefore impersonal, hotel. Be prepared for large conference groups who will occupy most of the staff's time/attention.- Hotel is rundown. The two nicest places are the lobby and the Luxe Lounge on the 34th Floor in the South Tower. Elsewhere, expect dirty carpets, peeling paint/wallpaper, and other signs of wear and tear.- For the most part, staff do not speak English (concierge and some reception staff are the exception). This is especially true at the restaurants. It seems that they are catering for local tourists and businesspeople more than foreigners.- Housekeeping was hit or miss. One day they left my half-eaten food tray from the night before. - Customer service is not their forte. For example, they would not allow us into the restaurants for breakfast unless we had a meal coupon (some of us had already eaten and just wanted to join our coworkers afterwards - it shouldn't have mattered since it was open buffet anyway).- Food itself was edible but not great. Would definitely recommend eating out rather than at one of the many hotel restaurants.- Fitness room had nice machines but no air conditioning.- Use of the pool incurs an extra fee even for hotel guests (I didn't use it so cannot comment beyond this).On the plus side, we had a 3-day executive meeting and the service was impeccable. And the convenience store in the basement is open until 2:30am - much appreciated :-)I would definitely try another hotel next time I am in Tokyo, and recommend that my company explore other options as well.

Had a chance to visit Tokyo last 21-24 April 2013, we stayed for 4-days in this hotel. The location is great (lots of things to do, place to visit, exploring nearby area would not complete our 4-days trip) very near in Shinjuku station should you wish to explore the city, the hotel lobby is good, our room is very good, spacious with comfy bed and cool and quiet aircon, equipped with LED cable TV (with limited foreign channels). Comfort room is excellent with automatic lavatory and bowl and with bathtub should you need to relax after a long day of journey. Only one exception is the WIFI, you should request this to Front desk and they will configure this mini-WIFI device and it will be activated by their staff, it's a minor issue but Overall experience in this hotel is VERY GOOD.Thank you Keio Plaza Hotel for the warm reception, you completed my first ever Tokyo Trip!

Great location, good rooms, good service. Very good restaurants. Near Shinjuku Station and good shops. And if you have kids, they provide a free shuttle to Disney Tokyo Resort. An excellent choice for tourists in Tokyo. There is a complimentary internet at your room. Ask for the device to provide the wifi connection.

The hotel is located nearby Shinjuku metro station and train station, about 10 minutes by walking.A grand and beautiful hotel, the room is spacious and very well kept and clean.Hotel offers various dining options like Japanese, Western, Chinese food.

The room was really good - great view and blissfully quiet. The hotel is pleasant though perhaps starting to feel a little tired around the edges. We particularly liked the cocktail bar upstairs and had a nightcap there every evening of our stay. The hotel restaurants were quite expensive with meals from the chef's grill potentially costing around £90 per head. Enough to put us off sampling.

Keio Plaza Hotel is recommended for those who are first in Tokyo for either individual or family travel. Located in downtown area, it is easy for the guests here to go to any sightseeing spot in Tokyo by metro or bus. What's more, if you want to have a visit to Tokyo Disneyland, you can get a free ride provided by Keio Plaza Hotel by making a reservation in advance. Of course, the seats are limited, so don't forget to book one as soon as you decide to go there by bus.

This hotel is perfectly located close to the Shinjuku train station which is a major transportation hub (metro, JR train lines, airport "friendly" limousine and highway buses). Nearby, you'll find plenty of little electronics shops, restaurants, convenience stores and shopping centers.The hotel itself is very large and rather impersonal. I would classify it as mid-upper range. The rooms are large, clean and modern and provide a fantastic view over Tokyo (the upper the floor, the better the view).The good: Free wifi internet in the room (make sure there is a router installed in the room), Nespresso coffee machine with 4 free capsules provided each day. Lots of restaurants. Very nice sky bar and laounge on the 45th floor with a great view (but they both close early). Nice outdoor pool on 7th floor. The bad: The bathroom is not super modern and feels rather cheap (mostly made of plastic). The pillows are hard and heavy. I prefer light and soft but that may be a matter of personal taste.

This is the best experience I've ever had regardless of price. I've stayed at hotels all over Asia and little in Europe half the price and 3x the price.I've arrived at the above opinion 1 day into my 3 day stay, it was THAT good and it only got better even after I checked-out!Upon arrive we were notified the grade of our room was full and was upgraded without hesitation. I'm constantly surprised how many hotel try to hesitate on this obviously only thing to do.The term "Hotel" in Japan means a different thing than in the West, and I can assure you no matter where you come from this hotel will not be considered "small" like others in Japan. This is a proper Western sized hotel.We got a huge room with a large queen bed with wall to wall floor to ceiling window view of the whole Shinjuku district, to get a better view you probably have to go to the Shinjuku Gov building's observation floor.I could go into infinity details, but I will just say, the Japanese are really into details. In a totally anal sense, and the room was prepared and equipped to the best of their abilities. There are things and service in the room that you wouldn't think of needing, because they've thought about everything. For those of you backpackers who think you just need a room, you need to find something 1/2 of this price or else you are not getting good value. For those traveling with family like me, we need service! Like letting our 8yr old stay in the room without extra charge. Having a convenience store in the hotel. Airport shuttle at the lobby. Bath products that will make all the ladies scream. Close but not in the middle of it all in Shinjuku so we can have a relaxing stay, but also a covered conveyor belt walk way into the metro station, that make a huge difference during the rain!The whole service got even better after we checked out. I accidently left 2 expensive polo shirts and worse of all a stack of cash and only set of car keys in the room. I didn't realized this until I've returned to my home country's airport. After contacting housekeeping, they mailed all my things NEXT DAY without asking for shipping payment upfront! YES EVEN THE STACK OF CASH I left!Absolutely the best experience I had anywhere in the world even compare to the famous W, FOUR SEASONS, Sherton, and Westin!If you got the budget for Keio, go for it! This will be my go to hotel in Japan in the future when I'm traveling with family and if my other fav which is 1/2 much is not available.

This is a lovely hotel, close to Shinjuku station, alot of restaurants near it and shops close by, It has it's own convenience store and an abundance of in hotel restaurants.We stayed here for a week and enjoyed out stay, We got room service one night which was so yummy, we almost wanted to get it every night, but it's obviously not a very cost effective way to eat.

The hotel seems very average: not that good and not that bad. The room is also commonplace where everything can be found at others. The good parts are the quality of food and the option of choosing breakfast restaurant. Still, its overall quality is common.

It is more like 3.5 rather then 3. I'd rated it 4 but the smoking rooms are located next to non smoking ones and we could smell the smoke. Overall a good hotel for a foreign traveler if you get a good rate. Convenient location with transportation options at Shinjuku station. Hotel restaurants are horribly overprices but there are multiple options with in 5 min walk on the way to the station and at the station itself. There is continence shop on the lowers floor (floor #2, the lobby is floo3 #3) where you can get snack, sandwiches, beer, sake, toiletries, etc. There are also Lawsons continence store across the street and couple of Starbucks. The rooms are reasonably well maintained but the shower curtain has seen better days. On the other hand, the water pressure in the shower was impressive. The room seemed small upon arrival (after 20 hr travel day) but it grew on us and the two of us had plenty of space. We enjoyed complementary hot tea and coffee in the room daily. The bed was on the firmer side but not too uncomfortable. Internet connection was stable but slow at times. We were in tower 1, 25th floor.

Everyone I knew seems to experienced this hotel, they said it's the hotel to stay with relative big rooms and easy access to disneyland. We decided to stay here on March 2013 for 4 nights... The minutes we entered the hotel lobby, actually before we found the hotel, on the way from the subway station to the hotel we already realized this was a wrong choice. The hotel not really near the subways, it take at least 10-15minutes walking a long ways from the station to the hotel. With 2kids in tow, it really not that convinient. The hotel was really big and old.. There were so many people helping in the front desk... They worked quick but lack of human feeling... More like robots. We didnt have to wait long until we got our room. Yes it was roomy, but can't shake the old feeling... It's clean, very clean but old room from the early 80's... no wifi, there was an internet plug with cable. They said they can lend the reuter free but not until our last night we got it. We had trouble planning our trip around Tokyo since we couldn't access internet. Thinking that we were in Tokyo, Japan having trouble with internet was the least we expected. Starbuck was across the street, some restaurant also there and along the way to the subs station. Some mini market also there and there was 1at the hotel which was much more expensive.This certainly not our type of hotel. It's far from the station, it's old, it didnt provide wifi in the room it just wrong for us. feel like back to the 80's...

We stayed 6 nights in this hotel in Tokyo. It was close walking distance to Shinjuku station, lots of restaurants in the area, great location for sight seeing. Upon check in, we were allocated the wrong room with 2 twin beds, when we approached staff about this they promptly upgraded us to a larger room with a king bed and city view on the Plaza Premier floor with free wifi. Would definitely recommend staying on this floor.

We spend 3 nights in this hotel and was comfortable, good location great service. I didn't tryed other hotels in this area but we hade a great experience. This hotel are really big maybe a little bit to much. Nice view!

Disappointed with this hotel My friend and I stayed in this hotel as Agoda rated it a 4 star hotel. We were really disappointed. The room showed in Agoda is nothing like what we were actually staying in. Yes old 50s furniture. No complimentary tea or coffee. I was told to buy from the shops at the hotel! The reception staff was most unfriendly and that was uncommon given our previous encounters on the same leg at Hyatt Regency and Renaissance Sapporo were excellent.The only plus to this hotel is the location.

We travelled to Tokyo previously and enjoyed Shinjuku so that is why we choose this hotel because of the location. Easy to find from train station and a good location to find shopping, dinner and other attractions. Considering how big the hotel was it didn't feel that huge. We enjoyed have a choice of restaurants to choose from for breakfast. Rooms were a good size and we were happy with our stay. Nothing to complain about! An added bonus was the view of Mt Fuji from our room.

overall the hotel was "fine", although it is quite tired now. the location is quite central and easy walk to the main Shinjuku area, lots of restuarants locally.breakfast quality, for the price, not good

My family stayed in two rooms next to each other (couldn't get adjoining) on the 20th floor over the past few days. The smallish rooms smelled of smoke and much of the furniture looked like it came from the 50s. The front desk and bell personnel were very nice and helped us get a portable router in our room so we could use our wifi devices. The location of the hotel was good as we needed to get to various places in Tokyo, but it is not a leisure area (across from Tokyo Metropolitan Government buildling). The staff are used to helping foreigners, and there seemed to be lots of tour groups at the hotel. The Limo Bus from Haneda stops here so that was very convenient.There was an advertised exercise facility, but my daughter discovered it was actually a former room with a few pieces of exercise equipment - which was not air conditioned. There is a pool but it is 2000 yen per person to swim.I would not stay here again nor would I recommend this property.

Came to Tokyo on a whim.Well it wasn't a whim but more like the realization of a last minute trip my coworker and I had talked about over many coffee breaks.So having never stayed at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Tokyo, I decided to book two rooms for late April.The rain was already there when we arrived at Shinjuku Station.The showers that follow the falling cherry blossoms was here to take the remaining petals off their branches as well as hurry us to the hotel.I was a little sad the season came early this year but at least it opened up our schedules.And since I was shifting roles from coworker to tour guide, I found it a little relieving to have more free time for our week in Japan.In the 10-minute cab ride to the hotel, I was anxious as to what my coworker was expecting.You see, my co-worker is old school. Maybe classical old school if there exists such an old school. The kind of old school who talks about 10-hour flights from the West Coast to Hawaii, quotes Cary Grant, and knows a Benny Goodman tune about 20 seconds after the first instrument plays. But the way his face lit up when we arrived told me that I had made the right selection when it came to where we staying for the week. The Keio Plaza is about a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku Station and has everything one needs while staying in Tokyo. There is a nice selection of restaurants, English-speaking staff, various gift shops, Free in-room WIFI- which I did not encounter any problems with, a great bar on the 45th floor to unwind after those long adventurous days, and of course the convenience store on the lower level. The latter of which is a great place to pick up something to enjoy the sunrise with from your room's window. Staff were also very helpful when my coworker locked himself out of the room three times. After the second time, they had his room key already made out at the deskThroughout our week in Tokyo, the Keio Plaza wasn't only our hotel but our haven from the bustling city. We got into the routine of waking up early, heading out into the city, returning to nap, and then I would venture out again while my coworker slept. Shinjuku has a nice park not too far from the hotel. There are also a lot of great shops and restaurants to look for souvenirs, experience new foods, or just stroll around and admire not how different we are from one another but how similiar we each are to each other. At the end of our trip, I made my way to Haneda Airport and elsewhere in Asia while my coworker went to Narita Airport. The Limo Bus for both airport stops directly in front of the hotel so it is very convenient.If you have not decided where to stay yet, I highly suggest the Keio Plaza. It is great for anyone visiting Tokyo to make money, see things, or create memories to talk about during coffee breaks not with a coworker but with a once-in-a-lifetime friend.

Everything is clean and smells good. Service is prompt (like less than 5 minutes after you called). It is also very close to the mall and train station. Everybody is hospitable and they speak good English!

We spent 6 nights at the Keio Plaza in June and stayed in the main tower. We were very pleased with how large the room was. We arrived about 9 PM and check in was quick and easy. Never had to touch our bags until we unpacked in our room. The baggage folks were at the limo bus to take them for us and waited while we checked in. The lobby does get busy during the day , but hey this a very large hotel. The Guest Relation desk helped us on several occasions with dinner reservations and taxi service. Great location for train connections and exploring Shinjuku itself. We didn't bring our laptop but they have a business center where you can use the hotels computer for only 100 yen for 15 minutes. The hotel has many places to eat and we enjoyed their dinner buffet . But there are numerous places to eat within an easy walk including a Sizzler about a 100 yards from the front door . The staff was always friendly and helpful , loved the folks at the guest relations desk. As we walked in one evening after exploring shinjuku one of the Hotel staff greeted us with " welcome home " , ya , how nice.

First of all, the bell boys, the clean staff, and the restaurant staff are all very polite. However, the very poor service from the front desk gave you a bad experience for the rest of the stay. This poor front service has been commented by other reviewers. The front desk staff are robotic, impersonal, and inflexible to the nth degree. The inflexibility, the "I don't care you are my customer" attitude, is a real turn off.
user_name:
Dis D
New York City, New York

review_body: My second trip to the Keio Plaza in the heart of Shinjuku. This is a large and sometimes impersonal hotel, with two very large towers. If you get a room on higher floors (I was on the 29th) you do get a great view over Tokyo, or save up and try a drink in the penthouse bar. This offers typical Tokyo prices in this style of hotel bar, which, as the location suggests are sky-high. The rooms are big enough and well equipped, although the Wi-Fi, which to operate you have to get a router from reception, is random. I only got it two work one evening out of three. The location is great, right in the heart of things and next to Shinjuku station. Breakfast is good in either the coffee house next to reception of in one of the lower floor restaurants. However, the service at reception didn't have that usual Japanese friendly and efficient feel to it I have experienced in other hotels in Japan. Overall a good hotel in a good location. Not cheap - but where is in this city? Recommended if you need rail travel and the bright lights of Shinjuku.

Very large hotel ( 2 mega towers). If you're on a higher floor you get a fantastic view from your room (or the bars at the top). There was quite a queue for check-in and all terribly impersonal but reasonably efficient. Our room was spacious particularly compared with other Tokyo rooms I've seen but not quite up there with Century Southern Tower. Our wi-fi didn't work but they came up within minutes and gave us an alternative. It is very well located in Shinjuku. The weather wasn't great so we didn't get chance to have a look at the pool. Overall, reasonable value and well located but pretty soulless.

I booked through booking.com, when I arrived the checked in counter, it seemed to me my booking was not existed. After a few calls, the manager Nakanishi-san came back to me and arranged a room, it's on the south wing. When the elevator door opened, I immediately felt uncomfortable as the hallway was very dodgy. Entered the room, I immediately yelled "I am not staying here!!" given the price I couldn't accept the quality of the room, not mention I had to be there for 4 nights. It was max a 3-star setting. I went down and negotiated with Nakanishi san again, he looked quite uneasy, but after my complaints, he arranged another room on the main building for me... It was a lot better with all the advanced deco and nice view. However, I still found the room a bit tiny as I booked Superior Double. I called the front, and asked what type of room it was, the guy told me it was Business Standard and supposed to be slightly expensive than Superior Double. I was a bit pissed but I didn't want to ruin my holiday so that's it.On the day when we checked out, they charged me a higher rate, saying that the hotel manager had already told me it was a room with higher rate. I couldn't hold my anger. I discovered the room size was not right that's why I called the front desk to verify.It was indeed a nice hotel, great location at centre of Shinjuku. However, lucky or not, the checkin checkout experience was not great. I would have 2nd thought if I ever want to go back...

Stayed at Keio Plaza during the mid June period. Just as what most reviewers had mentioned - its location (near the West Exit of Shinjuku Station) is a major strength, particularly if you're going to travel frequently via railway. The hotel's also a drop-off/pick-up point for the Airport Limousine bus service. There're many reasonably priced eateries, restaurants, convenience stores around the hotel especially If you head east from the hotel towards Yodabashi Camera & Club Sega. If you're into Bento sets, pastries etc, check out Odakyu's Basement 1 (Odakyu's a shopping centre that's connected to the West exit). Although most don't give Takashimaya Times Square's Kinokuniya a miss, Odakyu has a good bookstore on one of its upper levels too. My partner & I'd stayed in a high floor superior room in the South Tower. My non-smoking room was clean, quiet and spacious. Air-con was working fine. Dunno about Wifi for I'd brought my own portable router. I couldn't see Mount Fuji but my room had a great view of the surrounding buildings, roof top gardens and people making their way to work. The cleaning staff on my level were very meticulous. The other staff were friendly and helpful. The only complain I have about the hotel is its 'strictly no check-in before 2 pm' policy unless I join its Executive International Club.

Just go back from weekend trip to Tokyo with two "first timers" from the US, a daughter and nephew. Hotel is extremely convenient to everything, a short walk from the JR Shinjuku train station, fun pedestrian areas, the mysterious Golden Goi bar area and many, many excellent restaurants. We walked almost everywhere, but that is the way we roll. There are metro stops all around the hotel and while cabs are a little expensive, they are great for evening dinner runs.The hotel hosts many large, chaotic tour groups from all over Asia so the lobby can be chaotic, but fun. We were the only Westerners in the place except for an Italian football team and a rugby team.High Points: Great location, helpful staff, cleanliness, "easy of use", direct bus trip from Narita.Just Okay: Room size, food selection, price point/value, ambianceNeeds Work: All the bars and restaurants are extremely expensive. Just walk out the front door and there are dozens of excellent venues for Western or Asian food, including breakfast, for about 10% of the cost, so not a big deal, but irritating.

Location is fantastic, and the rooms are nice, clean and comfortable.My room had an amazing view of nearby buildings which was stunning at night time.Hotel is a little overwhelming in its size, but that's all part of the adventure of Tokyo!

My husband, 7 year old son and I stayed in the standard room in the main tower, 30th floor. There were twin beds and a foldable bed. The room was spacious as compared with other hotels in Japan we stayed in before. We usually remove the bed covers and put them aside. There wasn't a bed sheet over the quilt and on closer look realized the quilts were yellow with age and stained (including old blood stains). On the 2nd morning at reception area, I requested from the manager on duty - change the quilts and a coffee maker for our room. I didn't want to dial the housekeeping department in case they didn't understand my requests due to language barrier. So he said he will arrange to change the quilts. We got back to the hotel late and didn't pay much attention to the quilts that had been replaced. Next morning, on closer look, we saw old blood stains but my husband said he wasn't going to bother about it since the stains on the quilt were at the end of the bed. It was interesting to see the quilt with initial "TC" handwritten with a marker. Perhaps most guests will keep the bedcover on the bed so the stained quilt is not seen. Regarding the coffee maker, the manager apologized that only premier rooms had this facility. We bought instant coffee from the convenience store nearby.The hotel is very near to the train station and on a rainy night, we managed to walk using the underground walkways from train station right to the hotel, all sheltered.We used the Friendly Airport Limousine bus from airport to hotel and back. Very convenient.

The Keio Plaza is one of the oldest tall building in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo, a landmark. It's kept up well, and is spacious and elegant. The service level is very high, and its very conveniently located if you have business in most of the Tokyo area. I stayed here with my family, kids in a room that adjoined our own room, and we had a great vacation.

Staying here for a business meeting and the location is perfect. It is close to the train and the metro. There is so much to do just I the blocks around the hotel, shopping,restaurants, bars and so much more. The hotel is very nice and the staff is very helpful. Most do no seem to have with English. We stayed not he premier floor allowing for a bigger room since we were here for a full week. There is a krueig coffee pot in the room along with tea. My only complaint is the rug, it is a light color and it stained everywhere. I would have thought it would have been taken off. It is very off putting to such a nice room.

This hotel is simply too gigantic to feel yourself comfortable in it. Rooms have quite unwelcoming and depressing design and are in the urgent need of updating. There is a smell of the old carpet in hallways and in a room. For internet users there is only ethernet in room, and unfortunately at the reception they have only very limited amount of rentable wifi routers, so every time I asked for them, there was none left. They could come with a very easy solution - ethernet to USB adapters. It is small, cheap and would solve problems of many costumers using modern computers most of which, especially among netbooks, do not have ethernet socket. It would be much better solution than wifi routers as it also requires no time for set up. But what can I say about such an innovation if even the phones in the room look like if they are from 1980s in the best case and TV is most probably from early 1990s.
user_name:
RaulF_13
New York City, New York

review_body: In the heart of West Shinjuke skyscraper area, close to Shinjuku Station and shopping and restaurant activities. Limousine bus service to/from two Tokyo airports. Our room had a great view of metropolitan Tokyo to the east. Clean and comfortable rooms. However, hallway had some sign of water leakage. Restaurants in the hotel are much more expensive compared to more affordable and good restaurants within a few minutes walking distance. After all, Shinjuku is full of excellent and affordable restaurants around. We ate sushi and sea food two successive nights at a sea food restaurant along the walk way next to the Hotel. Front, bell captains, and concierge were helpful. Mini-mart shop in the hotel was great, offering very economical selection of foods and soft drinks.

the location is fantastic. the staff very helpfull. breakfast they got 4 different restaurant to serve everyday with chosen variaion of breakfast type: American type or Japanese.only one thing irritating me: the WIFI is not working at time im staying

we stayed there for 2 days before and after our cruise to kyushu and south korea from yokohama.we stayed at south tower which was better than the main tower.the rooms are a bit dated especially the main tower.wireless hi fi in south tower only.for some reason i was given a disabled room.toilets in japan are amazing ! the restaurants in the hotel are very expensive.had breakfast on the ship and the departure lounge at narita airport.all the staff were very helpful.language is a big problem though ! all in all it was a good experience.

It is one of the oldest hotels in the area but that also means it features among the biggest rooms you have in the heart of Tokyo.I know there is a newer wing but we were put into the older wing. The furniture is really dated and the beds not exactly comfortable.It was priced well as we got an ok deal on Agoda for 3 people in one room. The location is hard to beat, just a stone's throw from Shinjuku.

Recently stayed four nights at this hotel. Enjoyed each of the restaurants for breakfast which was included in my travel package, but chose to eat at other locations for lunches and dinners. My room was very basic and plain, and the bed was not particularly comfortable. The lobby and public areas were really fancy and modern, and I guess I was expecting the rooms to be consistent with the lobby. I did enjoy my stay here, and would stay there again due to the cleanliness, the various dining selections in and near the hotel, and the convenience to Shinjuku Station.

we stayed in this hotel April 2013 (I am a little late writing the review). It was a great experience. Although it is a huge hotel, it did not feel that way. There were always plenty of staff available to help. Check-in and Check-out were quick and efficient.The concierge was wonderful and spoke perfect English. She even has a map of the subway system with the stop names written in English. This was extremely helpful.  We paid a little extra to stay in a Primer room. It was worth it. The room was very large, and not just large by Japan hotel standards. It was completely renovated. Plus, our view was incredible with an entire wall of large windows. Also, it was spotless.My only complaint, and its very minor, was the internet. Our room was suppose to have free wifi but it never worked. I had to get a wireless router from the front desk, which was not available the first day. So I had to go back a few times to keep asking for one. But once it was available, it worked perfectly.The location is also great. It is a five minute walk from the Shinjuku station west exit. Plus, you could walk to tons of shops, restaurants and bars. There are lots of tourist attractions within the area or a short subway ride.If I return to Tokyo, I will stay here again without hesitation. It was truly wonderful.

It is a fairly short walk from Shinjuku Station to the hotel. The hotel is also quite near to the subway station. It was quite busy when we arrived so we had to wait a bit to check in but the staff were very helpful, especially the porter who took our bags. We had a Plaza Premier room which was pretty big with a massive bed. The room had huge windows with amazing views towards the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building. This hotel is quite a bit cheaper than some of the luxury hotels in Tokyo but the size of the room and the amazing views compare very favourably. Recommended!

I would rate it 2 star but to be fair i think i am being picky so am giving it 3 star for its average qualityCannot dispute the fact it is super convenient to subway station. That's the only positive.Good looking hotel lobby but overly crowded, seems like you're in a market. Hectic hotel lobby.Hotel room we had was super outdated in the early 80s style, I called the reservation to request to pay for a renovated room but all rooms were booked, bummer. I am not a big fan of outdated bathroom or bedroom style, doesn't feel comfortable or clean.Would not likely to stay unless I am guaranteed a remodeled room.Breakfast restaurants had lines at every restaurant the hotel offers, again, seem like the hotel itself is a market or an amusement park, does not give a comfortable soothing feeling, too hecticDon't let me started on the box they sell for 500yen. We bought too much stuff at toyko so needed a box, they sell it - super flimsy and cheap quality, We later checked it in the plane and it was dented - good thing we put extra tape all the way around, keio hotel was kinda cheap about using their duck tape to tape the 500yen box we purchased from them.We later on moved to Park Hyatt 2 blocks away, it was night and day. Park Hyatt had beautiful room in a non-hectic hotel, excellent customized service. We bought a box as well at park hyatt for 400Yen, that one was extremely sturdy and good quality. Even generously gave us a full roll of duck tape to use!! Talk about night and day for even basic little thing.I am sure it is a good hotel and many people like it, just not for me.Would not be returning to stay unless it is really cheap AND guarantees a remodeled room for me. The hectic hotel is too much for me.

We stayed in a Plaza Premier king room in the main tower. I understand that the hotel has many different room types and your experience will be considerably different depending on the room you book. For us, it could not have been better. We were on a high floor with a view of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building, a landmark in itself (don't miss their free observatories!) and excellent views of Shinjuku. The room was huge and comfortable. I loved the mattress! There were bathrobes and cotton yukatas, as well as two types of slippers. There was a mini bar and an expresso machine as well as a water boiler. Free bottled water was offered daily. The toiletries were high quality (L'Occitane) and there were other amenities in the bathroom such as hair brush and even hair bands! I had never seen that before. The wi-fi was hit or miss when trying to connect with the phone but with the laptop it worked fine. The hotel is easily accesible from the Shinjuku station walkway, just follow the directions to the Metropolitan Government Building. My only complaint was with the cleaning service. Even though they clean rooms until 3 pm, every day at noon we would get a note under the door saying they had been unable to clean the room due to the "do not disturb" button so we had to call room service to let them know they could clean the room. Other than that I absolutely loved the hotel and would go back in a heartbeat.

I chose this location for transport links to the airport and was not disappointed with the area. It is a busy area with large department stores only minutes away and very central.The hotel was adjacent to the walkway for the station and there were plenty of places to eat locally, including the hotel. The room was large, clean and comfortable. I booked tours from the hotel and found the staff very helpful. The underground system was confusing to begin with but my confidence was boosted with the clear explicit directions from the kind staff at the Reception Desk. I would not hesitate to stay at this hotel again and have no problem recommending it to others. The heated toilet seats, along with their multi functions are amazing!!

Location is in the heart of Tokyo's shopping district with several restaurants. The hotel interior is dated, the carpeted hallways dirty. The rooms was a standard size, comfortable bed, very clean. Hotel service was average, the hotel lobby very uncomfortable. Large open area with minimal sitting area. Airport Limo bus to Hanaeka and Narita stop at this location. Would not be my first choice if returning to Japan, but was good value for the price I paid.

Stayed here in the Plaza Premier room in May. The room was a good size and well fitted out, the Locataine products were a very nice touch.Arrived by bus straight from the airport (nice and easy to do)- delivered straight to the hotel door (about 90 minutes from Narita airport). The lobby of this hotel is huge but check in was quick and easy. Got to the room, had a quick shower then went and explored Shinjuku's restaurants, which are an easy 2 minute walk from the hotel. There is a cocktail bar upstairs which has a great view over Tokyo city but has a very simple (maybe read boring) cocktail list; beware the man taking you to your seats, you can see him get visibly grumpy with tourists who do not wear their Sunday best to the bar (as the Japanese do)- he didn’t say anything, just wasn’t friendly at all.The room came with internet, which is always nice, but the internet was flaky; don’t try and watch youtube with it.Also, it's not widely publicised, but if you are transferring to another hotel (we were heading to Kyoto) just drop your bag off in the lobby and they will transfer them for you; this service cost about Y1800 per bag- far better than trying to get your bags through Shinjuku station.Book early through the hotel's own website for a great discount.

Like most reviewers, my husband and I like the location of this hotel. About 5 minutes to Shinjuku Station and perhaps a 10 minute walk to the East exit of the station (which is the shopping belt of Shinjuku). Staff were most helpful - My husband and I had 2 nights in Hakone after our stay in Tokyo. The hotel actually allowed us to leave our huge luggages at the concierge (for 2 nights) despite us having already checked out of the hotel. Without their help, we would have to lug our luggages to Shinjuku Station and then transfer to a Romance Car (shudder to even just think of it!)! Another plus is that they provide limousine bus that takes tourists to the airport! Highly recommended!

I stayed here mid-May 2013. Nice hotel and the service was very good. I had an excellent view from my room of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Bldg. I received a free breakfast and it was nice. Easy access to the Shinjuku Station. This hotel has many restaurants and shops. I liked the convenience store.

We stayed for four nights as part of a package deal. It is a big hotel and a bit corporate & that is reflected at the service areas which are very efficient & business like. Every request made was dealt with very quickly. Our room (3 adults) was on the 20th floor and spacious enough with a great view out over the government buildings & nearby parks. It was clean & with a good sized bathroom. Free Wifi was available but you had to ask for the connections with came with no instructions. The lobby is huge and is a meeting place for many tour groups & the limo buses which leave for various airports, so it can be very busy in the morning.The location is great with Shinjuku station nearby as well as many department stores & shops of every description. There are many eateries in the surrounding streets as well as the convenience stores which sell nearly everything. The is also a convenience store downstairs at the hotel.My main complaint would be the range & price of breakfasts. As we had early starts on a number of day we had to eat at the hotel and the best we could do was $17 for orange juice, coffee & toast. We could have a really good evening meal at nearby restaurants for less than this. It seems that a full buffet breakfast as part of a package is rare in Tokyo.Overall we had a good stay, it is very convenient to many things and we would stay here again.

It is a very nice hotel. The rooms were spacious and far bigger than I had expected to find in such a well located hotel in Tokyo. The amenities in the room were all of very good quality. Hotel staff was very courteous. Tour buses pick up tourists from the hotel. There are a number of eateries, grocery shops and electronics outlets within a few minutes walking distance from the hotel. Railway station is only five minutes away and a covered pathway connects the hotel with the station. I will certainly recommend this hotel to my friends.

Stayed here again for 3 nights in a Plaza Premium room in the original wing. Room was of good size. Great amenities and 2 complimentary bottle water were provided each day. Room in very good condition. Check-in was quick and this was one of few hotels that someone always escorted you to your room and explained every feature in the room including the emergency escape route. My package was to include daily breakfast but the coupon was only valid at the cafe in the lobby. The selections were somewhat limited. The hotel is very well located with many shops and restaurants nearby. The Shinjuku metro and JR stations are only about 3 blocks away. Staff was friendly and helpful. Recommended.

Stayed here for one night with family. Liked the location as you also have many convenient stores nearby and the subway isn't that far. Rooms were big enough and managed to fit all of us in (2 adults and 3 small kids). Breakfast was ok but nothing to shout about.Very convenient hotel where location is good and travel is easy.

Everything about this hotel is terrible except it's location. I stayed here twice only bcoz of it's location. Its a huge hotel compared to many others in Tokyo. So, expect it to be very crowded and annoyingly noisy. On the floors that I've stayed, there were over 30 rooms on each floor. So, expect the hallways to be very noisy 24 hrs a day. Not to mention noises from other rooms too bcoz of its very poor sound proof structure. This is definitely not the hotel for you if you're expecting to have a quiet and relaxing holiday. Or even a business trip if you don't really need to be exactly at it's location. There are many better hotels nearby or just a few blocks away. As for the rooms, the nightmare starts with the temperature of the rooms. The controls in the rooms are actually only for decorating purpose only bcoz even if you set the temp. to 18c, it stays at 25-28•c... It gets so HOT not warm and you can even sweat in your sleep. Good for the cold winter and for people who are trying to lose some excess fat by sweating a lot(kidding).The beds are sub-standard and not a bit comfortable. Its actually worst than those in the cheap motels. The bathroom is as usual, very small as with all the hotels in Japan. The rooms smell like hell as they allow guests to smoke even in non-smoking rooms. The first few rooms they gave me actually smelled like ashtrays until They change them after my consistent complains... Buy they'd actially insist that the rooms are non-smoking. The size of the rooms are fairly big but the room rates justify the size..And BEWARE of the change of rates if you would need to extend your stay for a day or two.... they'll literary rob you by raising the room rates for 30 to as much as 200%. Make sure to plan your stay. I would never recommend anyone to stay in this hotel. Not even my enemies !!!

Stayed here for 4 nights in late May.Nice large hotel.Clean, fairly large room(by Japanese standards) on 38th floor in the Main Tower.Check in was a bit slow and despite booking being done on the net and paid for, it still took like forever being checked in!!!Location is excellent being close to all facilities including Shinjuku rail station.Staff were helpful generally, and when we needed assistance for our sick grandchild,they arranged for us to see a doctor right away.However, front desk staff could be more welcoming!!!
