My wife and I recently spent four nights at the Keio Plaza. We enjoyed it, but must note that much of our enjoyment may have hinged on a room upgrade that we received at check-in. We booked a "Biz" room, but were upgraded to a "Premium" room on a mid-30s floor. The Premium room, which looked to have been recently remodeled, was fantastic. Huge, by Tokyo standards. Great views. Nice furnishings. A couple of other nice touches: First, a business center with free printing and at least one computer left on an English-language setting. I know, a business center seems pretty mundane, but not all the hotels we stayed at in Japan had one. Second, on the ground floor there's a convenience store that's open late. Although the shops of Shinjuku aren't far away (among them, a 7-11 is about two blocks east of the hotel), it was nice to have a source of Cokes, etc., so close by. Finally, although it's pretty easy to get to the subway via surface roads, the hotel also connects to a tunnel that goes straight to the Shinjuku hub. Some minor critiques: The fitness center is pretty small, has no free weights over 20 lbs or so, and is mostly geared toward cardio exercise. The pool was closed, and it was mid-May and pretty warm out. The hotel gets lots of tour groups, so the lobby is probably going to be pretty crowded during your stay, at least much of the time. Finally, although the hotel is very close to the sights and sounds of Shinjuku, which are pretty awesome at night, it's a ways from Harajuku and other tourist destinations in Tokyo. So, overall, we would definitely stay again if guaranteed an upgrade to the room class we occupied. Otherwise, we probably would stay again, but might try something a little closer to downtown.

Rooms are big by japanese standards. But rooms were stuffy when we visited during winter. The walkway was cooler than my room. Coming from a hot climate country we had problem adjusting to the stuffy air in the room. The room came with faulty coffee machine and the technician took some time to fix it before replacing the unit. Near to the train station thus very convenient.

I stay for 3 nights. Although the hotel is huge, they have 2 towers, their service is excellent. You can take the limousine bus direct from Narita airport to hotel. It takes approximate 1.5 hours, it depends on traffic (JPY3,000), if you have plenty of lugguage, it is very good idea to choose it. Actually, from the hotel to Shinjuku station is approximate 5 mins walking, without the luggage its easy...They provide the shuttle bus to Disneyland, it's very convenience for the people first time in Tokyo and want to go to Disneyland. If you take the JR, it's complicated, and a looooong walk in Tokyo station during transit. The breakfast is average, I prefer the Japanese one, but not everyone likes it. in between the station and hotel, plenty of restaurant for your choosing. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

This hotel was perfect for me. Excellent location near Shinjaku Station just 3 blocks away where you can get subway and train to anywhere in Tokyo. Checking at hotel was very easy even though clerks are not fully bi-lingual japanes-english. Got a room on 31st floor with great view of the city. Lots of amenities and detail, very large safe box, you can even keep a backpack in it, iron and table, cloth bruch, shoe shine step and even pijamas. Toilet with bidet and bathroom mirrow that do not gt vaporized. TV set is good but unless yo know japanes, the only english channels are CNN and BBC London. Movies are US$10 each.Room is quite good size, recliner and desk, king size bed.Breakfast is excellent, cost US$29. Near the hotel you find subway and McDonalds and also small market for snacks and sodas. Internet is free but extremely week signal, so forget Skype and mail attachments. You can book tours at the lobby with independent providers with the advantage that if you travel solo as I do lots of times, you can sign fo just one person and they make the tour (with people from other hotels).Plenty of transportation available, taxis in fron of hotel and buses just two blocks away. Plenty of japanes food available very inexpensive around the hotel.I wll recommend this hotel. In Japan english is scare but "Find a Japones that looks like a nice person, show yor map wih detination ad he/she will do whatever to help you"

This felt like a huge step up after staying in the Keio Plaza in Hachioji. In truth, the lobby was five stars, and the room was 3 1/2 stars. It is definitely a full service hotel, and I was even able to get an in-room hour long massage for $50 at midnight. The biggest plus was being less than a five minute walk away from Shinjuku train station and all of the shopping available there. At night, the streets were lit up like what you think Tokyo looks like when you see it in movies. I would be OK staying here for work again, but if traveling for vacation I would try to see what their five star hotels are like. Internet was free in the room. Maybe this is the norm, but it was refreshing after always being charged in the U.S.

(Based on a 5 night stay). The Keio Plaza Hotel Shinjuku was an amazing hotel to stay at. I'm not a big traveller, but Japan was my dream holiday and I wanted some good hotels, and the Keio Plaza was as good I could have hoped for. Of course, all people are different, so no experience is the same, but I highly recommend this hotel if you're staying in Tokyo for a few nights! Here are some of my top highlights:1. External services around the hotel. They are amazing! It is literally a 3 minute walk to the Shinjuku Station, which will take you everywhere you want to go (but be careful of rush hour!). There is also hotel drop off service available, and they will organise to take you back to the airport if needed. I didn't go to Disneyland, but I know there were pick-up services right from the hotel for it, so that would be handy for holiday-ers.2. Hotel Services. Incredible! The staff were all friendly, helpful and spoke beautiful english. We had a very nice boy bring our heavy luggage up to our room for us, and the man who served us at the desk was friendly, quick and got us through quick. Check out was even more simple. Just hand over the keys and go! If you're looking for tours - got straight to JTB, they are the no. 1 specialists! There is even a dedicated meeting point in the middle of the hotel with a big sign you can't miss when you check in.3. Rooms/Room Cleaning. The rooms were a typical western design for a rather classy hotel. They were beautifully clean and neat, and the room amenities were all rather helpful. The cleaning services are very good - they even repacked our shampoos for us. Although we did notice at the end of our trip they had eaten some of the lollies my friend had had sitting out. We didn't mind - we though it more cute then annoying! And yes - the toilets are the weird Japan-tech design with the 'butt-washer'. Watch out when you sit down because water automatically sprays into the toilet (and kinda on to you) rather loudly and it scared the crap out of me (nearly literally ;P)! Oh yes, and the view - I was worried I'd get a crap view, but I had nothing to worry about! Our view looked over towards Shinjuku Station and we got an amazing view of the Tokyo Nightlife - we even had a direct view of Tokyo Skytree!!4. Shops. We didn't buy anything for shopping there or restaurants, but we did go to the convenience store for milk and snacks. The store was packed with all sort of things and had everything we needed. There was even a dedicated section to Hello Kitty! (Who I love!!). If you're looking for milk for breakky you may have brought over - the brand is 'Meiji' and you can get it in a carton for 140 yen!Now, some of the downers of the hotel (noticed only 4/5 points?)1. Interent. I'm a technological teen (a.k.a I am a wuss and needed to Skype my mother), and I sort of need a little dose of internet to survive. Unfortunately - I got no internet anywhere in Tokyo. This was a little disappointing as it is such an advanced city, I was hoping to score some - but alas I didn't. I do know other people in the hotel got it fine, so either it was just my bad luck, or it was my computer. There is wifi in the lobby, but I never stayed in there long enough to try it out. Maybe if I'd been down lower in the hotel... damn my love of high rooms!2. I did have another one... I cannot for the life of me remember what it was... Oh well, I'll remember it in a minute and curse myself!Things I have no info on: restaurants, gym, spa, breakfast, dinner, weddings etc.

I stayed for the second time since my last trip to Japan in 2004. This hotel had really surprised me at that time. Unfortunately It has been disappointing from different angles. First I would not recommend staying in Shijuku but to stay at Shibuya (more activities day and night) and there are very good options at the same price of even better price.The hotel is absolutely driven by millions of tourists so it is a constant flow of people. 0 personalization, no compromise with the traveler,poor service in general. Every service is extremely expensive. In few words do yourself a gift and look for some other hotel for the same price.

We stayed in KP Shinjuku at the beginning and end of an intensive tour. Really comfortable rooms with all we needed, except English Tea Bags (!). My wife enthused over the wild Japanese Washlet toilet - you have to experience them to understand how technology can make life more pleasant!!

A large hotel, clearly oriented to business travellers, conferences and executive "belly-rubs." The rooms were the standard L-shape with bathroom cut-out. The general air of the place was that it would not been out of place in central London or Frankfurt. The hotel is very busy, so it was important to get down fairly early for breakfast, otherwise there are long and tedious queues for the main restaurants, although not, I noticed, for the Chinese breakfast. Having said that it provided an adequate base for a three-night stay at the beginning of a Cox and Kings tour of Japan. The location is near to Shinjuku main station and convenient for department stores such as Isetan.

We stayed for 6 nights.We arrived late at the hotel because our flight to Tokyo was delayed. We were checked in really fast and the front desk person was really helpful.We got the Plaza Premier room type because a friend recommended it, and true enough - the room was quite big! It was comfortable - considering we were 3adults and 1child. The amenities in the room were impressive - they had a coffee maker that used UCC pods and the toiletries are all L'Occitane which they keep refilling everyday! One observation though, when I moved a side table (because I was looking for an outlet on my side of the bed) I noticed that the wall behind it wasn't cleaned because there were dust that had accumulated (since I don't know when!) The room is quite pricey - but I guess its all worth it since the room is really big! Our room had wifi - but I had a hard time logging in because my iPhone kept rejecting the password. So, I never used the hotel's wifi. Good thing I rented a portable wifi device from Global Advanced (they delivered it through post and the package was given to me upon check in)The room has a safe that has an outlet inside (I don't know why it has an outlet!) They also have adaptors for you to use for your plugs - and an extension cord too! Brilliant right?The housekeeping was really accommodating to my every request of extra towels and toiletries. Location is really good - there are a lot of restuarants near the back entrance. Ask the front desk for a map of nearby restaurants and they will give you one with correct plotting. The Shinjuku Station is about a 10 - 15 minute walk from the hotel (I was reading reviews here that it was 5 minute walk - yeah, I guess if you brisk walk!) There are a LOT of malls near the Shinjuku Station so you won't need to go far. There's a Yodobashi Camera in the area too!Another thing that I liked with the hotel is that they have a FREE shuttle service going to Disneyland. You'd just need to book in advance because apparently - it gets full quickly. I reserved a month before I arrived - I wanted to make sure we had a slot. There's a convenience store on the floor below the lobby that closes really late. The prices there are not as bad as I thought - its even a bit cheaper compared to Lawson or Family Mart (but i can't really confirm)The concierge was really helpful in keeping my ice packs frozen and keeping our stroller. They even accommodated my request for packing tape (even if they gave me duct tape).Was really happy that we chose this hotel. I will stay here again in case we decide to go back to Tokyo.I won't post any pictures anymore as the site's images are quite accurate already.You can sign up for their EIC membership - it says on the website that you can get free breakfast and a special check in counter. I signed up for this BUT wasn't given the privileges because they said I didn't book using their EIC rate (we got the 45days early bird rate).

Stayed for a few nights in April to catch the cherry blossom season of Tokyo. Close proximity to the subway, which proved essential in the cool weather! 2 blocks away from the hotel is an area complete with every type of Japanese food you'll look for, it has yakiniku or the regular plated sushi / sashimi, ramen or even the convenience stores for water or other essentials.The hotel has it's own restaurants but of course they tend to be on the pricier end since its in the hotel. The same restaurants hold the breakfast buffet, you need to line up when it's really early, but the line vanishes as the morning goes. Average breakfast but it's what you would expect in a buffet - cereals, breads, bacon, ham, juices, fruits.The proximity to the malls and the train stations is the real plus, since taxi cab rides in Tokyo is similar to the experience of getting held hostage.A little pricier than most hotels in the area, but of course you'd expect hotels to be fully booked given that it's cherry blossom season. Will definitely recommend to friends and others!

Near the metro station. however its hard to find as shinjuku is skyscraper city. bring on your map fellas..! :)i just knew hotel rooms in japan usually small in size even in town city. do strain your eyes looking on room size before make the final booking. :)Halal food quite around- thought so. hmm however you can try on shushi dishes. roppongi have lots of kebabs or even nasi briyani (>_<)

This hotel has a great location close to Shinjuku station and close to shopping and restaurants. Not that the hotel doesn’t have its own restaurant options there are about 7 or 8 offering a good variety from teppanyaki (which we had and was amazingly nice), traditional Japanese and tempura restaurant - also the cocktail bars within the hotel are really nice and have a great view over the city. We had the breakfast included too and that was nice everything was hot and a really nice variety of items. My only complaint is you sit at kind of lounge chairs to eat breakfast and I find that a bit uncomfortable, you knock you knees on the low tables and I just found it a bit of a bizzar set up for eating breakfast.Also the staff just sort of hang around too and you sometimes feel a bit watched and it’s not like they are watching to clear your plate they are watching you while you cook bread and that sort of thing It made me feel a little uncomfortable at times.All in all a nice hotel and the guy who bought our bags up to our room was super nice, and a complimentary upgrade who can complain really.Also an added bonus with this hotel is for overseas visitors some of the tours leave from the lobby so that’s super convenient if you are staying there!

Great location....hotel is huge...small room...breakfast....day by day..we must queue....cause so many restaurant and could be we have in function room.....breakfast not so variaty...but if can take a seat in restaurant...breakfast will nice...if in function room....shock breakfast.

This is a large, nice, comfy and busy hotel in a great location in Shinjuku, a busy district in Tokyo. the hotel is 8-10 min walk from Shinjuku JR station; Odakyu department store which has a colourful, mouth watering, albeit a bit pricey food section in the basement; Big Camera electronic mega-store; and a lot of lovely eateries popular with locals, and office workers in the area. The huge high-end Takashimaya, Isetan department stores are 5-10min further from Shinjuku station. The Government Observatory building is two blocks west of the hotel and offers free, great view of the city at 220m. On a clear day, you can see Mt Fuji from 100km away. So if you have time and want to take a break from sight-seeing while in Tokyo, then exploring the area around Keio Plaza hotel is a pleasant experience in itself.On the need-improvement side, the hotel has no WIFI, no late checkout, small TV in room, an unheated outdoor swimming pool (useless unless in summer), and the bed and doona are not as comfy as other hotels in Japan.

Really enjoyed this hotel. Wonderful location close to Shinjuku station and lots of shopsThis is avery large hotel but the only time we noticed this was between 9-10 in the morning at rush hour. Very difficult to get an elevator!,,We had a room in the main tower lovely large room very clean and very comfortable beds! Really enjoyed having cocktails at Polestar fabulous view and fantastic cocktails too! We ate out but used the downstairs convenience store. We also took advantage of the Disneyland shuttle a great service.

I booked online and got a good deal, then an upgrade and early checkin. Very polite staff, which is quite common in Japan, and a cavernous room on the 35th floor meant spectacular views and a comfortable stay. We were so delighted we booked again for a few days later. Perfect position near Shinjuku station as well. We will definitely stay here again on our next visit. Keep in mind however that Japanese beds are generally harder than we would be familiar with in Australia.

We stayed in a deluxe room in the Main Tower. The room was comfortable (except for the bed) but nothing impressive as there was a large stain on the carpet. The room was incredibly spacious for Tokyo. The Lobby was really nice but huge and impersonal.Off the lobby is a sort of concourse where there are numerous restaurants, Unfortunately, we didn't have a chance to try them due to fatigue after packed days of sightseeing. For breakfast, we found essentially two restaurants. At the Chinese one which seemed to be included in tour group packages (we were not in a tour group), I had scrambled eggs from the buffet and they were awful (tasted like powdered eggs or something). Everything else, including the orange juice was not much better. We then discovered the restaurant next-door to the Chinese restaurant- Jurin, I think it was called, where they served much more of a western-type breakfast and it was far better ( at approx. 30 US per person) so we ate there for the rest of our week's stay. The only problem for us was these restaurants didn't open until 7 AM. For dinner, due to fatigue, we ordered room service every night and we found the food decent or terrible. I would not do that again.The staff knew basic English but not much more (quite typical actually of Japan except in Kyoto). As a result, I wanted to mail something and the person couldn't even tell me where I could mail it. I discovered there was a mailbox right at Reception.There were three reasons I had picked this hotel: 1) the airport limousine bus from Narita Airport stops at this hotel 2) I thought Shinjuku would be a fairly good spot for sightseeing and 3) a variety of restaurants in the area. The airport limousine bus worked out great but Shinjuku was not a great location for sightseeing. We spent a lot of time travelling across the city. From what I know now, I would stay in Ginza which is much more central for sightseeing and actually has some good affordable hotels as well. As for the restaurants: yes, there were some different options but it was freezing while we were there and we were too wiped at the end of every day to explore.

We booked directly through hotel website & got a great price so we pleasantly surprised at the standard of this hotel. Amazing foyer, friendly English speaking staff & spacious rooms. The restaurants in the hotel were expensive but many great local restaurants within 5 min walk. Short walk to Shinjuku station & shops & highway bus station. We caught a bus to Kawaguchi to see Mt Fuji. Free entry to observation deck of Metropolitan Government Building (2 minutes walk away)plus fee English speaking guide there. Just as good a view as Tokyo tower.I would love to stay here again if lucky to visit Tokyo!

This was my first stay at Keio Plaza, though I knew it well--the house I where I grew up in Tokyo had a good view of it while it was under construction in 1970, when it was briefly the tallest building in Tokyo at 49 stories. The room was spacious and very comfortable, but the bathroom was stuck in 1970--very small by today's standards and lacking the separate shower stall that is currently expected in good hotels. I also hated the step up to the bathroom--it's easy to forget and trip over it. Service was excellent--a little too good at times, such as when my room service meal arrived 15 minutes earlier than promised, when I was still in the shower. But when I needed drops for an eye infection, I was promptly assisted by the concierge, who took me to the hotel pharmacy to get the right ones. Whether you stay at the Keio Plaza depends on how much you like being in Shinjuku, a major hub whose station is a jumping-off point for many train and subway lines. (The station is a brisk 5-minute walk through the west concourse of the station, and the fact that it's enclosed makes a big difference in a rainy country.) Personally, I much prefer to be near the Ginza, which is more walkable and less high-rise, and features the Kabuki-za and Hibiya Park. But any business traveler would appreciate the Keio Plaza's convenient location and comfortable rooms.

Arriving at the Keio Plaza after almost 24 hours travelling was like coming across an oasis in the desert. The reception lobby was a vast marbled area with so many staff anxious to be of service. Our room was large, spotlessly clean and very well appointed. We had to queue for about 10 minutes for our first breakfast but it was well worth the wait with an impressive selection of both western and Japanese food on offer. A wonderful start to a memorable holiday.
user_name:
Carol P
Cruden Bay, Scotland, United Kingdom

review_body: Keio plaza offers excellent service, as you can expect normally in Japan, but you will also find a good choice of restaurants in house and a comfortable room and an excellent spa. Every time I go to Tokyo I like to stay at this hotel because it is so well situated for both business and leisure. It is walking distance from Shibuya, the place where I do business. Shinjuku is, as far as I am concerned, the best place to stay in Tokyo.

It was a very short 2-day visit to Shinjuku, but it was made more enjoyable with the comfort offered by Keio Plaza Hotel. The room size is just right; bed, drapes and toilet are very clean and orderly.No moldy room odor at all. High-speed internet is complimentary (much appreciated!) and there is a cable provided in every room, but it can be improved with the presence of wifi (a simple router setup per floor ought to do it) - they should improve on this as there are various mobile devices in use now by their customers. Keio Hotel is strategically located, close to many affordable dining places and entertainment bars. If you are a ramen enthusiast, a 5-minute walk will reveal dozens of small restaurants offering many ramen varieties. The area is also littered with many convenience stores for quick purchases of bottled water, canned drinks, Japanese bread, pre-packed bentos and ice cream.When booking a room, try getting one with a view of the Tokyo metropolitan government building as this will show a good view of the western side of Tokyo. Be aware of directions inside the hotel because it has a couple of wings which can confuse first-timers.Overall, I would definitely want to come back to Keio Shinjuku. Highly recommended to friends.

I & my hubby haven't been in Tokyo since a decade, as we didn't find a hotel which was convenient to shop around. Until we visited Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo Shinjuku during our Chinese New Year (February 2013). The Hotel is neat & with big interior room space, unexpected, it's also closed to JR stations in walking distance only 5 minutes, we could go to every tourist spots within a short traveling, we love it, & planning to go visit Tokyo & stay in Keio Plaza again in coming Christmas & New Year holidays.

My first night staying at the hotel now. Not a good experience so far. It took forever to walk from the shinjuku station to the hotel. Good luck trying to find the West Exit. Even after you find it, theres another 20 min walk thru that long walk way filled with homeless people at night. And with all the luggages, makes the walk way more longer than it already is. I really don't see the convience in this hotel, just that theres a few restuarants outside.So I checked in and they told me they will upgrade me for free to a bigger room, really?!!! Its turns out its a dirty handicap room, cracked wall, nasty bathroom. And then, like a few other reviewers mentioned, I also had Wifi problems. They gave me some equipment thing to plug into the cable in the room. Really??? Who still does that??? this is such a big hotel, there should just be Wi-fi for all guests. So the nice lady that works at the hotel tried numerous time to fix it and had no luck. Great- that means I can change to another room. So got to experience the famous "renovated room". Ehhh... Its ok. The bathroom feels really tight, meaning I can tip toe and touch the ceiling. This hotel is just not cup of tea. That whole Wi-fi experience was just disappointing. If you are traveling and rely on wifi- Dont stay here.

They have a very busy reception, but they can check you in very fast. Reserved a renovated room through Preferred Hotels site, but not available when we checked in; so they gave us free breakfast coupons and upgraded us to an enormous suite. Even though it was straight out of the 70's, and smelled a little like smoke, it was huge (two bathrooms, dining table, couches, etc..)and had a crazy view over Shinjuku. The room had a better view than the observation deck at the Metro Building next door (worth going to).We took a taxi from the Shinjuku station, and it's worth every bit of the 780 yen if you have big suitcases. We had two great dinners in the pedestrian/entertainment area that is about 2 minutes away from the hotel. There are tons of restaurants in the hotels, but really $$$.The Odeo metro line is about 1 minute away from the entrance of the hotel..really easy to use.So if you like Shinjuku, this is a solid option.

I seldom give a poor review just so it's Tokyo and people are known to be really nice and polite. So imagine my disappointment when I stayed 5 nights in this hotel. And we only booked this hotel as my favoured hotel was fully booked since this was quite a last minute trip. Anyway after reading the reviews, my sister decided to give it a try as it was (1) recommended by her colleague who stayed here before (2) the free shuttle service to Disneyland/Sea. My first impression of the hotel was it was huge. There were tour groups, air crew and just crowded most of the time. After we checked in, we went to our room (Plaza Biz Plus) and was surprise by the size of it. Really tiny for the price but since we don't stay in the room that much, it is fine. So we tried connecting the wifi numerous times following the instruction in the room and it was still not working. We called front desk for assistance and they sent someone up the room to check. This guy was working at the front desk as I remembered seeing him when we were checking in. When he came, he appeared very disgruntled as if he was not suppose to be doing this but got sent up anyway. So while he was trying to solve the issue, my sister asked him if there was a business center and he gave a very curt "No' reply. He got the wifi working and left and then my sister found out that the business center was in the lobby of the main tower where we were at. Now, either he didn't understand the question which I highly doubt or he was just being really unprofessional and rude. To me, this sets the tone for the rest of my stay in the hotel. And by the way, the wifi sucks and didn't work most of the time. The bed and pillow was also quite uncomfortable at least for me.As the hotel stay came free with 1 breakfast, we decided to try it out. As it was a huge hotel, there were numerous cafes/restaurants where they assign you for your breakfast. We went to the lobby cafe and had our breakfast there. The variety was ok, but again, the service was just not to par. Nobody clears the cutleries and it looks like the cafe was understaffed. So there were uncleared cutleries on tables and nobody to clear them immediately. And then there was a line of people waiting. Thank goodness we didn't wait long for a table as we were there pretty early. As for location of the hotel, I can only say it is not as ideal as I thought it would be as it is situated quite a distance from the West entrance of Shinjuku station, and it does take awhile to walk although we got used to it after 5 days! You do need some time to orientate yourself due to the numerous exits and entrances. There were quite a number of food places around the hotel but that is it. The only plus for us is the free disney shuttle bus to and fro from Disneysea. Otherwise, this hotel is just way too impersonal, cold and unwelcoming. Overall, I would not stay here again for the unprofessional service rendered, the location and the price.

Stay away from this hotel. The location is pretty boring, it claims to be near Shinjuku station, and it is but the station is huge and spans a large area of Shinjuku, so don't use that as a guide.There is nothing near, you have to go back through Shinjuku station to get to the good stuff, so why not stay on the other side of the station.The staff are almost rude! They understand checkin and checkout, nothing else so don't try and complain about anything as you will only anger yourself more. Guest relations service desk is no better, we asked them for help for over 30minutes over some issues that came up during our stay and nothing was resolved. For the price we paid i expected a much better and friendlier service.The bed is very, very hard! Very uncomfortable.We upgraded to the Premium room with a bigger room and concierge service as well as an amazing view, of other buildings :)The room really was huge, and fairly clean, but the service was appalling and there are plenty of other hotels to stay at that are in a more convenient location. The room service is overpriced, and really really not worth it.You do get free wifi in the room but only if you stand close to the tv, i have no idea how they managed to restrict it that much, or if it was just our room, but we were not able to use the wifi anywhere else in the room, very bizarre.

This is my first time to this hotel. Its location is great, within walking distance to Shinjuku train station and other shopping attractions. Hotel room is consider larger compare to other hotel in the same area. I arrived in early morning and thought to refresh myself after a night long flight at its fitness bathroom, however, this is not possible and was turned down that there's no bathroom available, only have to wait for check-in after 14.00 hrs. Breakfast is available at many outlets on the ground floor, on some day, there was a wait line but I waited no longer than 5 mins. Service is excellent, baggages were delivered up to the room by bell captain (this is not avail at most hotels in Japan). Wifi router is free upon request for in-room usage.

We stayed in Keio 2 times breaking it into 2 stays. First was on March 23-26. Check in was not that smooth since there were large group of tourists coming in but it was ok. Room was huge with beds waiting for us. I chose the renovated room and they gave us free wifi router. We had breakfast and had to wait for around 15 minutes to be seated. This hotel is very popular with tour groups. Huge hotel, Main and south wing, we were on the south wing. our room was facting the road to the train station. Our second stay was on March 27 with 4 days on it. Upon checking in (9pm) , i asked for a wifi rouer and they said none was available. I argued bec i didnt have internet for two days and my hotel booking said there is a free wifi router. I asked to call their supervisor, lo and behold, the supervisor apologetically said there was one left. This after after several minutes of arguing ok! The girl told me there was no router available bec all the other customers got it.. Hello? im also a customer of this hotel. Dont i get the same treatment. To make the story short, the supervisor gave me a router. We went up to our room which was just the same room as the previous stay. I was so disappointed bec the router they gave me did not work! I was fuming mad this time. Called up front desk and they said they will let someone go up and check on the router. The bell hop came and tried his very best to solve the problem but he just cant. He went out and came back with a cable for the laptop, it worked but we need wifi for the smart gadgets. he really went out of his way and he came back again with a new wifi router. this was around 11pm. I salute to that bellhop for really helping us out. He knew i was so mad and disappointed already. Good thing the new router worked! As for the location, it was ok. Around 5 minute walk to the train station. Lots of eateries outside. They also have a disneyland shuttle which is really convienient. You just have to reserve ahead of time. Tours from Jtb picks you up in the hotel. No worries at all. The hotel is quite expensive but the rooms are huge, so that was ok. And i didnt have any l'occitane products in my room, although there was an electric kettle :)And i chose this hotel bec its in shinjuku plus the airport limo bus serves this hotel. No need to walk with luggages!

The hotel is relatively large compared to some of the hotels in Japan. Keio consists of two towers: Main Tower and South Tower. Amidst our stay, there were big tour groups and conferences. For such a bustling hotel, the staff were super-duper friendly and attentive. We stayed in one of the Plaza Premier rooms. I have to stay the room was amazingly comfortable. The room was bigger than I expected. Our window faced the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office Building and the Shinjuku Central Park. The room lavished us with L'occitane products, specifically the Verbena product line (i.e. shower gel, shampoo, conditioner, and body lotion). I'm quite a fan of the France-based products. Addition to the shower amenities, the room was equipped with a Keurig! I'm also a coffee junkie and have a Keurig at home. The fact that the Keio Plaza has these in the rooms earned them extra points upon our arrival.Did I mention its convenient location? It's a quick walk to one of the busiest train station in Tokyo (if not THE busiest): Shinjuku Station. Perks:- L'occitane shower products;- Keurig;- Comfortable room;- Terrific location; - Free Wifi;- Free shuttle ride to Tokyo Disneyland (yes, it's free);- Transporation service to Narita Airport (with a fee); and- Friendly staffCon:I wasn't crazy about the pink counter and bath tub, albeit-- that's more of a personal opinion though.I will definitely stay here again if I were to head back to Tokyo again. Heck, I was raving about the hotel so much when I came home that my sister and her boyfriend will be booking at the Keio Plaza when they visit Tokyo in July.

We have stayed here twice in the last 6 months (Dec 2012 and April 2013). We have stayed at the Hyatt and Hilton at shinjuku before but have moved to Keio because these travels were on personal vacation basis whereas the Hyatt and Hilton are on business reasons. Keio hotel is a large hotel and caters to big tour groups that's the only con but overall service and value is great. We always choose and stay at the Main Tower plaza biz floors (25/26), rooms are updated and modern but maybe a bit small by American standard (less than 30sqm) but not European standard. Location is unbeatable from Narita airport or to other parts of Tokyo with the metro.

This hotel was located 5 minutes walk away from the Shinjuku train station. The room sizing is comfortable. Bathroom was very average, but clean. The view was spectacular and the staff were friendly. This hotel was extremely busy!

This hotel was included in part of a air/hotel package that I had booked through a travel agency. The arrival process was painless, with check-in a breeze. The hotel is one of the larger in the city and I would classify it as a Tourist Grade hotel, it's not High End, but it's not budget either. The rooms are well appointed, with all you need for a basic stay, but don't expect frivolous over the top amenities or appointments. The room was good sized for Tokyo hotels, expect the same size as you would for a standard New York hotel. Not sure why some rooms were not without wi-fi as stated in other reviews, but there was free wi-fi service in our room without the need for a router (albeit a very slow service, but it's free). They have a variety of dining options as well, but as expected, the prices are higher than average because they are located in the hotel. Overall the rooms were clean, the service was impeccable and the experience was pleasant. We would recommend this for anyone who needs a good clean room located in the heart of the city with easy access to the Metro.

Stayed 3 nights with my wife at Keio Plaza Hotel. Family and friends we knew from Japan spoke highly of the Keio Plaza as it is seen to be a very grand and luxurious hotel for years. This is likely why the rate is quite expensive as it is living off reputation. All things considered you can likely find a similar/better experience for cheaper...may take a hit on location though.Front desk and lobby is quite nice and spacious. Service (like everywhere in Japan) was great and extremely accommodating. Once we got to our room however, although it was large the decor and furniture was quite dated and old. Nothing overly special. Location is one of the best things about Keio as it is walking distance (there is a direct path pretty much) from Shinjuku Station, which is the busiest station in all of Japan. So from Shinjuku you can pretty much get anywhere in Tokyo, including the N'EX (Narita Express) train to the airport. No transfers needed. There are some restaurants near by as well as shopping towards the station.Final notes: -there is wifi if requested. Front desk will give you a mini wifi router to plug into the room for wifi...if there are any available. I had no problem though.-If you are traveling to different hotels, or to the airport, people in Japan often send their luggage using courier services. It is reasonably priced and makes commuting on the subway much easier.

I have always stayed on the South side of Shinjuku and Keio Plaza on the West end is a bit of a walk to all the action - Isetan, Lumiere Est, Takashimaya etc. Keio Plaza Biz Plus rooms offer a good sized room byTokyo standards, however the bed, pillows and comforter were hard and uncomfortable. I stayed 4 nights and couldn't sleep until I knock myself out with sleeping pills on the last night. Other than that, there are no real complaints - service was good, prompt and friendly.

I have been to this hotel for more than 5-6 times. The price of the hotel room is not cheap but it is value for money, especially if you join their executive member club. As a member of their club, you can get late check out, breakfast, and free use of the lounge on the 36th floor where you can have a glass of wine or bottle of Asahi with biscuits and nuts, etc. all inclusive in the room rate. The options of having different breakfast (e.g Japanese, Western, Continental, etc) in the morning is great especially if you are staying there longer than a few days. There is a free shuttle bus to DIsney that is handy for many family tourists although this service must be booked in advance as they get fully booked easily.

We stayed here for two nights on a brief stopover in Tokyo. Our travel agent stuffed up our booking, but the staff were very helpful and did all they can. We were forced to take a smoking room which really really stunk... however the staff did all they could to try and get rid of the odour. Not that you could... we still had to wash every single item of clothing once we got home but I guess in countries like Japan that's what you get in a smoking room.Location is awesome, easy walking distance to the train station, most places we wanted to go were within a few stops. Metro station also nearby, along with plenty of great restaurants.We didn't eat at any of the hotel restaurants as they seemed pretty pricey. No wifi was a bit of a shame and a surprise, but plenty of other places we went had it.Beds were pretty comfortable, standard room was small but adaequate, plastic moulded bathroom was interesting but did the job. Hotel staff were lovely, very helpful and quite good english when we were asking about restaurants and attractions. Also very good the airport bus stops right at the hotel.Overall, I would stay again as is very convenient.

We love this place so it was the perfect place to spend our honeymoon. My wife and myself spent a relaxing 22 days in a beautiful Plaza premiere room as our base in Tokyo.  The hotel is in an extremely convenient location, with a large train station minutes away from its doors you'll find easy access to most of Tokyo. Since the hotel is also a designated stop for airport limousines and most tour groups,I found this an added bonus.  The premiere rooms are excellent I found them large and comfortable, they have free wifi.We didn't use any of the hotels restaurants as there is so many places to eat nearby. The only issue I had is the limited number of english channels on the T.V (only 3), but since I wasn't in Japan to watch tele it was only a minor issue, and with the free wifi I was able to use the net to watch shows or listen to Sydney radio.

Location: So this hotel is in Shinjuku - which is the area where all the electronics and cameras are sold in Tokyo but is also near the Golden Gai - a fabulous place for a night out (see my review). There are many good restaurants nearby and some great parks. BUT - I think if I had my time again I would stay in Shibuya - a bit more action and much more shopping. The Tokyo Government Building (which has a free observation deck) is only one street away and the hotel is a short 3-4 minute walk from Shinjuku station which has a lot of train lines running through it. The Room: A really good size, clean and modern. What you would expect from a standard hotel in Australia. The bathroom is a bit weird - it feel a little like something you would see on a large boat, moulded plastic and certainly not luxury but adequate. The room had a Nespresso coffee machine, which I loved (I have one at home) and the use of this is also free. King size bed was firm - I liked it - but if you like a soft bed be prepared. The Hotel: We didn't try any of the onsite food outlets - they seemed overpriced and there are so many great little places nearby. Hotel check in was easy, the desk staff spoke English (not fabulous but enough) and were friendly and polite. We took our own bags up so we didn't deal with the Bell Staff until we were checking out. On check out the staff assisted us with making a reservation for the Limousine Bus, we were able to pay for the tickets on our credit card and the staff member I dealt with spoke excellent English. Also this bus stops at the hotel - very convenient for getting to and from the airport. The Price: We paid about less than $200 per night for a Business Plus room which included Wifi and Gym Access (not that we used the latter) . These rooms are modern and in the main building with great views.

We loved everything about our stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel. The Premier Plaza room is spacious, modern and offered a superb view from the 37th floor. The hotel location couldn't be better. It is easily accessible from Narita airport using the Narita Express, is 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku station and also has a metro station right outside. The hotel is within walking distance of multiple convenience stores, restaurants and shops.
user_name:
Kate R
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Third time staying here. Good experience all 3 times. Recommend either the plaza premier or deluxe the main room. Although is not as new as what's on hotels site picture. But still good to stay in. Large room. Good for family with kids. Not recommend the breakfast buffer, there are lots to eat outside of the hotel with close distant. Overall, good stay, service is good. If you need wifi, try to bring your own mini wifi router. Hotel may run out of router.

The Keio Plaza is a large, modern, full-service hotel located just a few blocks from the Shinjuku subway and rail station, which made it very convenient to explore Tokyo. Our room was very comfortable.

The hotel is very close to the Keio train station and a few steps away from restaurants and shopping. Such a great location. I easily took the train from Narita airport to this hotel.The staff were very helpful, the bellman very kind and professional. A great hotel in the Shinjuku area of Tokyo.Also there is an EXCELLENT sushi restaurant in the hotel!

Its my dream to come here to tokyo...staying in this hotel didnt disappoint me...the service was exelent place is nice and clean...there are restaurants outside...and near to a train station... Convinience store is just near... one thing I dont like is the wifi connection in the 15th floor...

Stayed a couple of nigths on a business trip. The price was good, the location is good, but the hotel itself has surely seen better days. The south tower rooms were quite worn, the carpets in need of replacement. The rooms were large for Japan, and the bathroom was good and clean, as was all the bedlinen. Beds were comfortable, but the wifi had some slight problems.The breakfast at 2900 Yen in the buffet was outright robbery. Ok stay, if you don't mind a touch used feel of a place. The breakfast is not worth it's price if purchased on spot, If you have it in a package, your mileage may wary. The elevators were overburdened at certain times, as was the reception, so be prepared to wait a while if arriving/leaving at an rush hours. Lot of tour groups, which make instant rush hours as they move around.All in all, I would go back, but I'm not fussy.

Let me start by saying I really did like this hotel and the staff were lovely and super helpful, and service and location was very good. We stayed here on an overnight with a 6pm checkout and buffet breakfast in a king room(?) on the club floor which cost around $450, so it was not cheap by any means.The room was fantastic and very very spacious with great big celing to floor windows that framed a perfect tokyo skline, with electric window shutters that were great. The bed was massive and super comfortable and the bathroom toiletries were subperb by La Occitane. Had a fantastic coffee machine, lots of cupboard space, and a heated toilet seat! The cons; On exiting the elevator to our floor 38 I immediately noticed the carpets hadnt been vacummed, I would consider this unacceptable in any hotel especiallu considering this was the club floor. Then on entering the hotel room I noticed the carpets were heavily stained - not what you expect really from this type of establishment. Breakfast was another disappointment, generally when I have stayed on the club floor there is a separate restaurant which serves buffet breakfast especially for club floor guests which is always nice, although not a necessity, however we didnt even have the luxury of just entering the restuarant (located on the basement floor) without having to stand in a queue for 20 minutes! Im sorry but that is totally unacceptable especially for anyone who may have had a plane to catch or a meeting to attend. Then when we were shown to a tiny little table in amongst many other tiny little tables, we went to get our breakfast and returned to a rather flustered gentlemen advising us that we had to be shown to our table - um im pretty sure that just happened?? Nope he then showed us to another table and it was then we realised that there were about 6 tables unocccupied and we'd been waiting in line! along with about 30 others most of which were still waiting. Once again as with most Japanese hotels the television viewing was limited in english and you had to pay for movies and internet TV. All in all our room was tired and in need of some refurbishment, however it delivered a distant memory of luxury and class which lingers within its walls and too which I enjoyed. I would stay here again.Airport limousine from hotel to Narita 2 hours and 3000 yen ($250.00? by taxi?)

After the business meeting at The Capitol Hotel at Chiyoda, my wife and I moved to a more value-for-money hotel and we chose Keio Plaza at Shinjuku.The hotel is only 5 minutes walk to Shinjuku Station, so it was easy to go around. Nearby the hotel you can find several eating places, electronic stores, convenient stores, etc., easy to find what you need. The hotel was-quite busy, but the service was still great and efficient. From checking in, information provided, easy access to airport, and of course the well known high standard of room cleanliness. The hotel was a bit old, but well maintained. The only complaint my wife and I think of (and we had to think really hard), was the very busy lobby area, always fullof people. l guess, like us they were also looking for the great value the hotel had to offer.All in all a satisfying stay!

We stayed here for the first few days of our honeymoon (in fact we're just getting ready to check out now!)We chose the plaza based on the reviews in TA and haven't been disappointed.Our room was on the 38 floor facing the government building (go and have a look at Tokyo from their observatory - it's offers great views and its free) in the main tower. It was a Premier Plaza and was very nicely appointed.We didn't have dinner here but did have the Japanese breakfast as we couldn't be bothered to go out one morning- it was nice but probably a little overpriced. No more so than any London hotel however. Definately worth doing if you're going to be lazy!!!A definite must for the hotel is the Polestar bar- a dark and moody cocktail/ whiskey bar with a great view over the city - great for a nightcap. For the whiskey fan I'd wholeheartedly recommend the 18 yr old suntory whiskey (well you are in Japan and you can get great scots whiskey anywhere)- do remember to turn to whoever you're with and use the line from Lost in translation "For relaxing times.........make it....Suntory time" :-)Anyway back to the review proper- the hotel is within easy walking distance of shinjuku station and there are loads of bars and restaurants and izakayas to choose from when you get hungry. Unless you read kanji you won't know which is which but it doesn't matter- be brave and just plunge into one you like the look of. We tried 3 different places and weren't disappointed on any occasion.Basically can't fault the hotel at all- next stop hakuba!

I have been coming to Japan for business for almost 10 years and have stayed at the Keio on numerous occasions. On my last trip, with a glut of time on my hands, I spent perhaps too much of it navel-gazing about the future of Japan. The Keio Plaza seems to be a metaphor for Japan itself.Wonderful people, perhaps the best service culture you can come across. Good location, especially if you are familiar with Tokyo's vast and sophisticated public transport system. Very good for the newcomer who doesn't want to find their way in from the ridiculously-far-away-from-everything Narita (just hop on the Airport Limo). Lots of little restaurants in the Shinjuku area, especially the Natural Lawson for a little organic snack when you awake at 3 am.But the once grand and well-appointed hotel has aged. Just as the Japanese baby boomers can quickly recall the heady days of the past and it blinds them to Japan's major problem with demographics and debt, the hotel still demands top dollar as it did so many years ago. Breakfast was bustling with good variety of food, but too expensive. The room was threadbare and had an empty feel. And it won't get any better because decline is inevitable.

The location of this hotel is 10 minutes walking distance to the main part of the Shinjuku station. This and the Shibuya station are the main stations to get around Tokyo. If staying at this hotel, I recommend to get nothing less than a room in the Main Tower or better the Premier Plaza. The room we got in the South Tower was outdated and furnishings from the 1980s. We have paid for an upgrade and stayed at the Premier Plaza for the rest of our trip. The room was very spacious, and have great amenities (L'Occitane en Provence). We were very impressed :)The service at this hotel is commendable! The staff were very helpful, polite and friendly.

My husband, baby and I spent three nights in a suite in the main tower. We were absolutely delighted. The room was spacious, even with a cot, and had a luxe feel, especially the bathroom! It was cleaned very well everyday, and the customer service at the hotel was great. We also enjoyed the view from the 29th floor. The location in west shinjuku skyscraper district was awesome...a 5 min walk to shinjuku station, and right across the road from the Tokyo metro government offices, where we went for a wonderful view of Tokyo at the free observation deck. There was plenty of spots to eat at our doorstop, as well as the electronics district which we liked more than akihabara. The hotel was also a 20 min walk to the shinjuku national gyoen gardens, a must see. All up, we loved this hotel!!

If you are traveling to Tokyo and simply need a place to sleep which is convenient and close to the Shinjuku train/metro station, this could be your place. Make sure you book in the Main Tower as the South Tower is straight out of 1978 and in desperate need of refurbishing. If you are traveling to Tokyo on Business, do not stay at this hotel. The wifi is only accessible by a cord (and with my MAC it still didn't work in my room). I had to pay to use the internet in the business center. See above about the state of the rooms in the South Tower. I felt that the website was very deceiving for what the hotel actually was. The food is okay but, again, for business, I would stay somewhere a little nicer in the future.It wasn't terrible and the staff was very nice but I think there are better options in Shinjuku to make your stay in Tokyo more enjoyable.

Great hotel with a good location, just a five min walk from the shinjuku station west exit. Liked that it was near lots of amenities like restaurants and convenience stores. The convenience store within the hotel was also a bonus. While the hotel was huge and hosted many tour groups, the service was excellent and there were no long waiting times to see the counter staff. Also liked that there was a free shuttle service and pick up to tokyo disneyland. Staff were attentive and answered questions via email before i arrived. We stayed in a deluxe room in the main tower and altho the fittings showed some signs of wear, the room was exactly as advertised on the website. Spacious and clean. Also loved that they had full sized shampoo and shower gel bottles, so no need to spend time and effort squeezing from little miniatures!Planning a trip back to tokyo in november and im definitely staying here again!

I stayed for 6 nights on business and have to disagree with some of the comments made previously. I was given a wifi router by reception which worked well and also had access to the club lounge with wifi access as well as free drinks and snacks and a view over Shinjuku. My room was a "deluxe" one and was extremely large my Japanese standards. On the downside it is an absolutely enormous hotel (over 1500 rooms) with a ton of overpriced restaurants and lots of coachloads of tour groups. For price and location it is hard to beat however and if you book to include breakfast vouchers it is decent food. Staff are super helpful and welcoming I would definitely stay again.

A huge, clean & nice-contemporary deco hotel. Located in a very strategic & convenient place in Shinjuku area; near to subway train station. Receptionists are friendly & speak pretty well good English. Highly recommended.

The hotel is very big, it has two tower blocks of rooms, several entrances. I did not feel safe in this hotel. The staff could not monitor all the entrances and lifts. I never saw security during my stay.Decor is old and tired, rooms quite small. Not a hotel I would recommend for a business trip. No WiFi in public areas or restaurants. To have in room you have to request a cable and return it on departure.!As stated location is good in Shinjuko, but there are better options .Staff were ok but not willing to please the customer.I will not return to this hotel

The first impressions are quite good - nice lobby, friendly welcome and escorted with my luggage to the room.I stayed in a Plaza Comfort Room which was fine for the price, albeit a little dated and worn around the edges but nothing that bad. The bed was excellent though and the views spectacular from the 33rd floor (I was in the South Tower).The choice of restaurants and bars was very good, although the buffet breakfasts were a bit busy on a few occasions so not that relaxing first thing. We ate in a couple of times and out on others, and found restaurants somewhat more intimate and much cheaper in the vicinity (OK, easier admittedly if you have a local to take you there). The rooftop bars were very good in the main tower with great cocktails and whisky selections....had a lovely couple of evenings in Polestar, but on many nights it's best to book ahead.Getting to/from Shinjuku station is very easy even with luggage, and the Narita bus goes from the door (and they sort your luggage too) which was good.All in all a good stay - not much of a "wow" factor but more than acceptable

After spending 9 days skiing in Niseko, the end of our trip was 4 nights in Tokyo which we spent at the Keio Plaza Hotel. Upon arrival our bags were collected before we even made it to the check in counter. They also took our ski gear and stored it so we didn't have to put it in our room. On checkin, we were advised of a free upgrade to the platium floor, which I think was floor 37. Our room was very large for Japan standards. It even had a day bed infront of the tv. The bed was very comfortable and super big and all the bathroom ammenties were loccitaine and replenished daily. We had our own coffee machine and music system as well. We were very impressed, not to mention to the amazing view. Very clean place, was just what we needed. Also only a few minute stroll into the real party area of Shinjuku, so it was nice to have the seperation. Highly reccomend..

We visited in Keio Plaza Hotel in November. We had initially booked the Hilton hotel but was told that that is far from underground station and it's too chilly to walk back from the station in the evenings in November. We had been recommended this hotel by a Japanese friend. The hotel is very good located and few minutes walk to the centre and underground station. Because of the mixed views on TA, we had been careful in booking the room. We decided to go for the Plaza Business Plus. I am glad that we made the right decision. Room is modern and new decorated. Free wifi in the room. It's also very quiet and the bed is very comfortable. We haven't tried the restaurants in the hotel and so, we can't comment. Overall, I will recommend to anyone to stay here.

With all the ratings this receives not much I can say. Great location with access to the whole of Tokyo and plenty of food and drink nearby if you need or want it. Everyone recommends the main tower but the, south tower (could be wrong on the name) has a few floors with access to a complimentary lounge which serves light snacks, beer, wine and other beverages until 7 p.m. Tokyo is expensive so this is a nice happy hour. I can't talk about added cost but would be worth asking about.

We stayed at The Keio Plaza Hotel during The New Year holidays.We picked this hotel mainly for its location as it’s situated right bang in Shinjuku. There is a covered walkway to train station which is only 5-minutes away.The hotel is very old with the main lobby to match. However, the room was very nice and cozy and ok in size (remember this is Tokyo we’re talking about). The bathroom is still old school though. The service was fine and free in-room wifi was a bonus.Try the Sushi restaurant in the hotel – you won’t be disappointed.

We stayed at Keio Plaza Hotel for few nights in December to attend family wedding. Our room was good size and clean, but a little outdated for my taste. Same goes for their fitness center.The hotel itself, has great number of amazing traditional and modern restaurants, cocktail lounges with beautiful Tokyo views as well as a market for little snacks and things you might need. I went to the Hotel's hair salon and even though the stuff was very nice and friendly after paying around $100 for a simple blow out I had a line in my hair left by hot curlers. Over all it is a nice location if you want to explore Shinjuku and have some great local food with out going to far. Don't forget to visit the Yakitori Alley if you choose to stay at Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo.
user_name:
SK2288
New York City, New York

review_body: Spent 2 nights in keio Plaza on the way back from the snow. 38th floor lovely room, excellent people great service and nice little touches like free bottled water each day, free WIFI. A mass of places to eat close and plently of shopping for the retail therapists.

Good location, spacious room compare to near by similar grade hotel, standard service We checked out on 05 march 2013 with 4 nites at 0820, counter staff 木村is so cold and impoliteThis check out experience made me hesitate to stay again, as room is rather old with outdated amenities (I stayed in south tower)If you are not considering space of room, there are lot of choice with newer room and better service around shinjuku.

My sister ad I plus a few friends traveling with us stayed here while we where in Tokyo. We where suprised how nice this hotel was, decent sized rooms and facilities, restaurants and shops within the hotel is great. Within walking distance of two train stations.

I would definitely recommend this hotel if you are interested in staying in Shinjuku. It is conveniently located short walk from the station, or you can take a bus directly from Narita airport. Service is quite good, and there are all required facilities there. Rooms are quite spacious and comfortable, and there are plenty of restaurants with the hotel and a short walk away. I have stayed here traveling for both business and pleasure, and would definitely be staying there next time. If you have the choice, stay in the main tower as rooms are newer then in the south tower.

Stayed at the Hotel for 3 nights while travelling on Business! Firstly, the location is perfect and Shinjuku is the heart of Tokyo! My office was at walking distance from the office but otherwise too, everything is just a small walk away, including the Shinjuku Subway station.Service was very efficient for checkin/ checkout/ housekeeping etc. Rooms were clean and surprisingly spacious for Tokyo. I was in the 31st floor and the views were beautiful. I had access to the lounge and we had the best of beers/ wines & snacks every evening beore heading out for dinner. Only sad part was the lacklustre breakfast.Some nice places at Walking distance were Kabichicko & Takeshimaya Times Square. The In-house dinning menu was very global with Indonesian Nasi Goreng; Indian Chicken Curry; Sichaun Noodles besides the regular burger/pizza/salad stuff.Fianlly, the most convinient thing about the hotel was the transit from the Airport and the return via the Limousine Buses. It made the trip especially convinient.

An amazing hotel with the friendliest staff,located in a very good place,keio plaza has got to be one of the finest hotels in tokyo.the metro rail station was about 10 minutes away from the hotel,and there were book shops,gaming arcade for kids,and nice places around to visit.the lobby was huge and marvellous,we stayed on the 11th floor which had a large window,and the view was fantastic.very good for families and for short business trip.

I stayed here on business and I found everything to be excellent. I'm not sure whether I was in a renovated room or not, but everything was clean and in working order. There was no wireless available but the LAN cable in my room worked without a problem. The view from the 28th floor to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government towers across the street was amazing. The heated toilet seat and mirror with heater to dry condensation were nice touches. The bed and the desk furniture were comfortable. The minibar prices were expensive but a convenience store in the basement sold everything one could want at a reasonable cost. I didn't eat in the hotel restaurant because the breakfast at about $30 was expensive but within a 5 minute walk there were at least 2 Starbucks with decent breakfast muffin options for about $7 with coffee. I bought a lunch (ordered by vending machine) for about $10. Small pharmacies around carried every type of toiletry and snack food that one could want. I haven't stayed elsewhere in Tokyo but this seemed excellent to me, and I was told that the surrounding luxury hotels were considerably more expensive. I highly recommend this hotel.

This was my first trip to Tokyo, I've stayed on business on an excellent company rate. So the value for money was outstanding. The room was very spacious (stayed on the premium floors) and the views of the city at sunrise excellent. The hotel is ideally located, with a choice of metro lines that are 2-10 minutes walking distance. I was impressed by the choice of restaurants, even for breakfast you can go to three different places, starting as early as 5AM !The hotel is also directly serviced by the Airport Limousine Bus, so it is very convenient and cheap (3000Y) to get in/out from the airport.There are plenty of restaurants and shops in the neighborhood.I would definitely recommend to everyone this hotel. It is not the latest/fanciest building so you will not leave with a wow effect, but will definitely appreciate how well everything matches your needs (unless you are looking for a latest architectural wonderpiece)

First time staying at Keio Plaza Shinjuku . Having stayed at many other hotels in Tokyo , this is probably the worst.1. Rooms are tired looking, have not been renovated for a long time. 3 stars at best.2. House keeping was sub standard, they only made the beds, used cups not changed, rooms was not arranged up to standard. 3. We want to be environmentally friendly so we purposely hung the used towels so as not to have them changed, but it was. 4. Additional water bottle will be charged.The only consolation to the whole experience is that it's near the Shinjuku train station.If you have the budget, try Hilton.Hope it helps.

Wide selection of restaurants and great views from the 45th floor bar. Can be queues for the breakfast buffet. Great location near the central station, within easy walking distance. Adjacent to the Tokyo Government Building. Convenience store on lower ground floor. Bars close early and can be pricey, but generally in line for a four star hotel. Friendly and attentive staff.

In a single trip, I stayed both here and at one of the nearby American chain hotel. Both get mixed reviews from me for different reasons. For the Keio Plaza, the rooms are spacious (for Japan) and the location is good. While the property is well-maintained, it is past time for a modernization.Location: There are a number of restaurants, there is a convenience store, it is directly across the street from the government buildings, and is nearby a large number of restaurants. The Shinjuku station is less than a kilometer away and easy walking distance. There is a park not too far away that is about 1km around. You can easily pickup bus tours directly from the hotel.Rooms: The rooms were in pretty good condition and well-maintained, but older. If you don't have an ethernet port on you computer, you won't have internet (no wifi). The bedside clock and electronic controls were probably modern a couple of decades ago. Breakfast: If you have breakfast included in your rate, there are several options to choose from. I ate at the Jirin each morning and enjoyed the buffet-style breakfast with a variety of options, although no cook-to-order.Size: This is a monstrous hotel with lots of foot traffic in the hotel lobby.Staff: I found the staff at the front desk to be courteous, able to converse in English, and helpful. They are, however, very busy, so expect to wait behind about one person on average.

I was pleasantly surprised with Keio Plaza Shinjuku given that I travel to Japan yearly. Keio Plaza is strategically located - accessible to Shinjuku JR and metro, shopping, restaurants. Airport limousine bus services available that will take you directly in front of the hotel’s doorstep from either Narita or Haneda Airport complete with portering services. Rooms were spacious for 3 adults, clean, quiet, comfy with superb service. Wireless LAN service was provided upon request with daily new-paper provided. Hotels has a range of restaurants at various levels, although prices were a tatty on the pricey side. A hotel that I would definitely revisit should anyone that wants to stay in Tokyo and/or Shinjuku.

On the positive side, this hotel is very well located (I stayed there when running the Marathon, and the location couldn't possibly have been any better). It's a large hotel with many restaurants and very helpful staff. On the other it's really very "tired" now, and that shows. Make sure you get one of the recently refurbished rooms in the Main Tower, and even then don't set your expectations too high. The UN recently declared broadband Internet access to be a basic human right. It's very disappointing therefore that a large hotel in the centre of Tokyo can't deliver that throughout their property, and when they do (in areas) the service is very patchy and slow. Amazing!Would I return? If I wanted location at a (relative) budget cost then probably yes. If I wanted all the amienities that I think most travellers expect of a modern City Centre hotel, then probably not

This is my 3rd time at Keio Plaza Shinjuku. It is in a good location, accessible to many shops and restaurants. It is within walking distance ,about 10mins walk to both Shinjuku JR and Keio Stations. If you take the Narita Express (N'EX) then it will be the JR station. There is also airport limousine bus that will take you directly to the front of the hotel, good for those with many bags.I took the N'EX arrive at about 11.30am. I requested for early check-in and was given a room at no extra charge. I had to move to Keio Plaza Hahioji, and the hotel did my luggage transfer for no charge.The room is decent size and only wired LAN is provided. It was quiet and I always have good sleep there.

Spacious, clean, comfortable, internet access available upon request, close to Shinjuku station and most things that you want from a hotel. Their service was excellent and staff were very helpful to your needs. Best were comfortable. Because the hotel was so close to the station, it made it very easy for us to get around Tokyo. Would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone that wants to stay in Tokyo as Shinjuku is the centre to getting around in Tokyo.

This hotel is total in terms of offerings, the rooms are nice, clean and well laid out! The American Breakfast restaurant Jurin is a great place and the spread has good varitey and taste. There are other Italian, Chinese and Japanese restaurant too! This hotel also has a grocery store for small purchases and this is very convenient. The staff is courteous.

The hotel is a busy city hotel in Shinjuku and is two blocks from probably the busiest train station you'll ever see. There are 2 towers, the South and the Main tower, the former being the older rooms and basic and definitely in need of a refurb from our experience. The location for the hotel and the station are great but I have to say he lack of Internet access is really poor considering the amount of technology on the doorstep of the hotel. There's no wifi in the lobby and only LAN cables in the rooms.The rooms need more info about the area, maybe tokyo maps / guides etc as these are not easy to find around tokyo though there is a tourist info in the Metropolitan Government building behind the hotel (the observe ration deck on the top of its towers give an amazing view of Tokyo and the sun setting over Mount Fuji )Given the cost in comparison to other hotels around Asia I would expect a lot more facilities

Keio Plaza is located a short walk (5 minutes) from Shinjuku station from where you can go to almost all places in Tokyo and Japan. The airport shuttle-bus from Narita stops at this hotel.There are both smoking and non-smoking rooms so if you are non-smoker remember to ask for a non-smoking room. The hotel is a high-rise building and the rooms higher up have great views of Tokyo - you can see Mount Fuji on a clear day. The rooms are spacious and very comfortable with tea and coffee machine. Great bathrooms.  There are three breakfast restaurants, I would suggest that you eat at the western style restaurant as there are more options available there. It is not uncommon to line up for breakfast so be early if you wish to avoid waiting.

We arrived at Shinjuku Station and were able to quickly find our way to the Keio Plaza Hotel - it is marked on the district maps displayed at exits to the subway. It's only about a 3-5 minute walk from the Western side exit. And it's MASSIVE, so you'll see it as you approach! There are plenty of staff, available whenever you need them. Just ask at the front desk and they will give you a handy Tokyo booklet with maps of the various neighbourhoods etc - much easier than lugging around a massive guidebook all day! The restaurants within the hotel seemed very expensive, but there is a myriad of dining choices around the Shinjuku area, so you won't want to eat in the hotel anyway! Beds and bedding were comfortable. Room temperature was good - not boiling hot in the middle of the night like some other hotels! Bathroom was clean and comfortable. Wifi was easy to access and reliable. We purchased snacks and drinks from vending machines and just chilled them in our room service fridge. Free Nespresso in your room is a nice touch! All in all, it's a convenient, comfortable and clean accommodation option!

For more full review, please visit:http://ferrystraveladventures.blogspot.com/2013/01/hotel-review-keio-plaza-hotel-tokyo.htmlPrice: 9/10I think the price is OK and not too pricey and a lot of Indonesians stay at this hotel.Room: 10/10When I got to my room, the room has an average size, not very big and not too small. For me personally, it has the right amount of space. The room is clean, the bathroom is tidy and offers great comforts.Hotel Staffs: 8/10The hotel staffs are quite friendly and helpful in general.Location: (7/10)This hotel is located in Shinjuku area of Tokyo and next to Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. It's actually in the middle of a busy part of the city. However, since most of the time we walk in Tokyo, in the end it feels quite far from the public transportation. Some times, I felt too tired to go out again at night after returning from one whole day of walking.Views: (8/10)The hotel has a pretty good views of building surrounding the area. It's very urban and modern.Overall: (8.5/10)Overall, the hotel is pretty good and recommended. The hotel itself is quite old but they maintain it very well so it doesn't feel too old. There are also many restaurants inside the hotel that you can try.

This was quite a pricy option for a night in Tokyo but we did it as a treat and it was well worth the extra cash. The rooms were immaculate and spacious, space being something one rarely finds in a Tokyo hotel room. There were all the mod-cons we could needs and more. The roof-top pool was lovely, a very grand reception area and a good location to go off exploring the rest of the city.

My sister and i shared a twin share in the central tower of keio plaza in tokyo for 4 nights. We booked well in advance directly from their website which saved us a bit of money. Check in was simple and we had someone take our bags up to our room, she was very nice and extremely helpful as she came back with maps of things to see and do including all the best shopping areas. There is a tunnel from one side of the hotel that leads directly to shinjuku station which was very convenient, however, on that side of the building there is no ramp only stairs so we had to lug our bags up them. The beds were a bit hard but the room was huge compared to other hotels and very modern and we had an amazing view. They even brought a private wifi modem into our room so we could use internet on our phones as rooms only have a plug for laptops. They let us store our bags free of charge on the day we were leaving which was good so we could make the most of our last day. Everyone was very friendly and most had good english.

The hotel is located in shinjuku, within walking distance of the biggest train station in Japan which is practically the center of the city. The path to the train station is covered which protects from bad weather or cold which is a plus for us citizens of tropical countries. Since the train station is HUGE, it's a little hard to navigate the Shinjuku station itself though which means we got lost once or twice in the station. The hotel itself is very big with two wings. The wingwe stayed in, which was the South wing if I'm not mistaken, was the one that wasn't recently renovated so the room was a little old and dated in interiors. However, the large size of the room made up for it given that Japan is notorious for small rooms. The best part of this hotel is it is a pickup hotel for all the local tours (JTB Sunrise) and that was a huge convenience. I would go back next time.. but request a room in the Main Wing.
user_name:
Janice G
Cebu City, Cebu City, Philippines

review_body: I've stayed at the Keio Plaza several times over the past year on business trips to Tokyo. This is a clean, convenient hotel with friendly staff. It's about a 5 minute walk from the Shinjuku train station which is a main station in the Tokyo area and is also close to shopping and a good variety of restaurants.
