The Plaza Premier rooms are the best for business travelers because they offer free WiFi, Keurig coffee maker, king size bed, key pass security floor access and a great view of Tokyo. The standard rooms are also good but don't offer free WiFi and are smaller. My one word of caution is that the hotel does a lot of tour group business so the lobby and elevators can get congested at times.

2nd time @keio after many yrs- Stayed at main tower this time room 3726- a keycard is required to select the floor in the elevator.Room is good size, elegant and very comfy & super clean.All amenities are provided slippers, dressing gowns, lots of L'occtancine products, kettle, cutlery, dehumidifier, free wifi...everything, even the curtains are controlled by a button by the bed!!The location is also very close to town and the station- 10-20mins walk or so. We also made use of the hotels complimentary coach service to Disneyland/sea, coaches are comfy & clean & best free of charge!The service and the staff are friendly and efficient- lovely hotel, totally recommend anyone wanting to stay close to town!

stayed here some years ago and thoguht it was great value...so booked again for this trip. The hotel is tired and rooms need a revamp. Also, get wifi!! You can wire up to internet in your room if you are lugging a computer around...or you can use one of the 3 or 4 computers in the business centre...and pay per use....but seriously, for a technology leading country like Japan, not to have wifi...and please provide as part of the room cost....is very old.Even as a Keio Member I couldnt get a late checkout without paying by the hour.Service was otherwisse good - I guess they ae just abiding by management rules. Location is great but wont stay again.

Both both immediate and extended family stayed here for a week in early January. I'd read advice and asked my travel agent to ensure we had the main tower rooms but this had not been arranged. We were initially given rooms in the south tower. The standard rooms in the south tower are very dated. After spending 5 minutes in the rooms we decided to upgrade to the deluxe the the main tower. For only approx $40 per night the difference was amazing. The main tower rooms were of a high standard and nicely modernized, although the bathrooms are still a little quirky. Beds are a little hard for my liking but we found this common in Japan. We found the rooms warm and so left the blind open to cool them down. Got colder quickly in the Japanese winter.The location for this hotel is amazing and right on the doorstep of a hundred restaurants and very close to the station.The Polestar bar on the 45th floor is recommended just for the view alone. If you order some of the whiskeys they give you one solid single sphere of ice about as large as a baseball to cool your drink. Amazing.We ate at the teppan-yaki and the steak was great but the price is quite high for the more deluxe (kobe beef and lobster set).Disney shuttle service is fantastic. We went to both Disney Land and Sea. Just book the day before. Make sure you are not late coming back as they don't wait as we found out because we wanted to catch the last of the Disney Light show. You can just take the train back to the hotel anyway.Would stay here again just for the location but was very happy indeed with the overall service.

I stayed in the main tower and found the room to be quite adequate for my needs. The only complaint (and I was warned of this by other travelers) was the wifi was inconsistent, so I made sure to bring a wireless router and plug that into the room's ethernet port - it made a HUGE difference. I was there for 2 weeks and the service was always perfect. When my travel buddy lost his wallet in a cab, the staff went to every length to help us deal with the situation. The other big plus was the location. You are right beside Shinjuku station, which is very centrally located and services close to 4 million people / day (yes, really) and there are many places to eat within walking distance of the hotel. There are many eating choices within the hotel as well, but you'll pay quite a premium! Most of the time that I ate in the hotel, I was merely going down to the convenience store (another big plus) and buying some noodles or other snacks for the room.

Rooms need updating, Internet speed is slow and the room service is very expensive. The hotel itself is well located to transport, shops and places to eat. The hotel only caters for two English speaking channels, so bring your own entertainment.

Just back from Tokyo and stayed at our usual hotel Keio Plaza Hotel. The room is around 25sqm and this time we stayed at South Tower and upgraded us to Plaza comfort. The mattress is good and this gives me a very comfort and good sleep. I will recommend to request to stay at Main Tower which is newly renovated and much better than the South Tower. The South Tower really needs to renovate because all things are old and especially the carpet.Overall, Keio Plaza Shinjuku is a very easy access and convenient hotel.

This hotel is very well situated and immensely busy. However, not once did the staff drop the ball. Upon check in the bell staff and the reception staff were very well coordinated. The hotel provided the thoughtful touch of small tables next to each check in line for weary travellers to leave their shoulder bags and other heavy accessories. A small but appreciated facility. The concierge staff, Mr Kaneko, was especially excellent. Very helpful, precise, and efficient. He went beyond the call of duty in assisting with multiple enquiries per day and refused all tips that I tried to give him. The hotel also has several excellent restaurants, one of which is Kyubei and another the buffet restaurant in the 1st basement level (you won't have a shadow of a hope on weekends to eat there unless you have a reservation, even for hotel guests). The bar in the basement is pricey but has good ambiance and is cigar smoker friendly. The location of the hotel is excellent, being only 5 minutes walk away from the epicentre of busy Shinjuku. The room itself is nothing special. Very clean of course, as is the norm in Japan. An air purifier is provided. The air gets very dry in the winter due to the heater. No adaptors for foreign plugs are provided in the room.The TV channel selection is limited. A nespresso machine is provided with a limited amount of free capsules. All in all I would not hesitate to stay here again. Shinjuku is one of my favourite parts of Tokyo and the Keio Plaza is excellent value for money in an expensive city.

Centrally located, next to the train station, many eatery nearby & short walk to the malls. We booked a total of 9rooms for 5nights. Service was not great which may be due to the fact that its a really busy hotel. To access the internet you need to request for a pocket Wifi Router( only can be used in room) We were disappointed that we only managed to get the router after our 3rd night as they were all out. Hotel was clean and room spacious (pretty nice bathroom too).Buffet breakfast offers limited variety. The waiters at the breakfast area are anything but friendly. Hardly a smile in 5days. Not a great way to stay the day.Having said that its a good place to stay and we will stay again for its location and not anything else

it can be consider aaverage grade Hotel is Shinjuku or even in Toyko. it have shopping mall together with hotel. but the hotel lift or evalator to room are quite far from lobby and easy to get confuse if you are first time enter this hotel.However. thebell. boy or girl will guide you to your room andthey' are quite polite and helpfd.

The service is very efficient & courteous. The food is always fresh and the presentation is well done! The location is very convient. Near the Kei plaza for shopping also near the larsons convenient store. Can access the shinjuku lines for quick getaway to other parts of Japan.

I stayed here for 6 nights in December 2012 with my 2 daughters. The hotel was fabulous - right from the moment we entered the beautiful foyer which was all decked out for Christmas with a gorgeous tree,we were made to feel welcome.We had a Deluxe room overlooking the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building and views of Mt.Fuji. The room was quite generous in size and accommodated the three of us very comfortably. We felt very safe - even when we experienced an earthquake measuring 7.3 on the Richter Scale!Everything that you may need is available making the stay extremely pleasurable.The WiFi access was very good and the room were cleaned and serviced to a very high standard each day.I would highly recommend this hotel and will certainly stay here again on our next visit.

I stayed here twice in the past few years - most recently for 2 nights in December 2012. It is a grand and elegant hotel with impressive marble lobbies and relatively spacious rooms. Some - including mine - even have a view of Mt Fuji. There is excellent WiFi, an extensive breakfast buffet of both western and Japanese food, a small convenience store right in the hotel. The only drawback for me was the lack of a year-round pool or sports facilities. There is a very small exercise room with a few pieces of equipment. But overall it is an excellent place to stay in Shinjuku.

We stayed for 5 nights in a "business king" (this is the room type advertised on Orbitz), which was fantastic. All of the business king rooms are renovated and in the main tower. The decor was sleek and modern. Loved it. The room was a good size (not just for Japan, it was normal-sized by US standards) and had a super comfy king bed (firm, but with a pillow top). We had 2 rollers, but there was enough space for a larger suitcase as well. The HVAC worked well and we were neither too hot nor too cold. The bathroom had a full-size tub/shower combo and one of those awesome Japanese toilet/bidet combos with the heated seat. Fast, free wifi in the room. Hotel location is great. Shinjuku station (a direct link to Narita) is a 5 minute walk, there are hundreds of restaurants within a 10 minute walk, and Meiji Shrine is 25 minutes on foot (faster than trying to take the metro there). We were overall very very happy with our room and the hotel. Also, if you have questions, they have an office in LA that can take and verify requests for you (so you don't have to worry about the time difference or trans-Pacific phone connections). We did have to store our luggage since the check-in and check-out times were pretty rigid. However, this wasn't a problem as we had planned for it. Also, the bell hop had good-quality umbrellas that you could borrow in case of a downpour.

This is the second time I stayed at this hotel with my family. Everything is in walking distance from the hotel, subway, shopping, eating, supermarket etc. The hotel itself has more than 10 restaurants that you can choose. Japanese and Teppanyaki restaurants are quite good thoughRoom is quite spacious. There are many types of bedroom. If you are going with family, try 4-bed bedroom. It's quite amasing but you need to book well in advance. Staff are very polite ( as they are Japanese!).I will surely go back!

We stayed here several times last trip and were impressed with its location, size and quality of rooms and convenience for airport limo bus.Our room second time had a magnificent view of Mt Fuji and we were able to view a perfect sunset over Mt Fuji on our last night.Something to be aware of here is that they are very strict about booking you into your room after 2pm regardless of the fact that the room was ready. This meant that there were an awful lot of people waiting around in the public areas of the hotel prior to 2 with very limited seating. There are only 2 loungechairs, a couple of armchairs and a few dining chairs lining the walls.Not nearly enough for the amount of people waiting.Besides this inconvenience however I would recommend this hotel.

Had three separate short stays at the KP during recent 12 day Japan vacation. First two stays were in Plaza Premier level in the Main Tower. Rooms appeared to be upgraded. Free wifi (hotel website is confusing, mentions something about having to rent a wifi router, but that wasn't the case). Large room-length windows with nice views of the city. First stay we had east facing view. Second stay west-facing. Shame that the Tokyo Govt building is taller than the hotel and blocks Mt Fuji view!We paid approx 27,000 yen with no breakfast. Fair value for the room. Cant say the same for the ladt of our stays which was in South Tower (separate review). Staff were very helpful in making restaurant reservations outside the hotel. We took advantage of the convenience store on the lower level. Found it to be fairly priced and open almost 24h (5a to 2:30a).We ate at the tempura restaurant in the hotel. Bit overpriced as youd expect but food was very good. Polestar Lounge on the top floor was our favorite find - bit of a throwback vibe, sort of 80s meets 1960s whiskey bar. Decent city views and chill vibe for a nightcap.

I have been going to the Keio Plaza for years now. It is a cconsistenly good, clean hotel, helpful staff and convenient location - just a block from Shinjuku Station. Plus you can take the Limo bus straight from Narita to the hotel - door to door. No complaint really - just wish our dollar was worth more... a room cost me 20% more than the last time I was there.

Located at the west exit of Shinjuku Station, Keio Plaza enjoys a great location and excellent views of the Shinjuku skyscraper district. It has two towers, and is therefore incredibly busy, which may be why the service was a little lacking. We stayed in a Plaza Premier room for one and a half weeks, and had signed up for the Keio Plaza membership online, but when we reached the hotel, we were told we were unable to use any of the associated privileges (free breakfast, late checkout etc), because we hadn't booked through the correct systems. They were unyielding on this despite the length of our stay and the fact that it was our honeymoon. The guest relation services weren't particularly helpful during our stay either. We tried booking a restaurant through them and while this was done, it was in a somewhat reluctant manner.That said, the hotel was clean and the room spacious if somewhat unspectacular. It makes a great base and we will likely stay here again based on its location, but not for anything else.

Stayed 1 night with the hotel during my business trip to Japan.The hotel is surrounded with office buildings and roughly 5 minutes walk away from Shinjuku Train Station and other shopping centers, so it is great location for business travelers which their customer's offices might be around and for shoppers who wana do crazy shopping. The room was consider quite spacious and very clean & tidy. We are talking about the Japanese hospitality services & courtesies standard here. I was greeted & assisted all the way from the moment I step into hotel till I reach my room, never feel so pampered before.Definitely recommended for Business Travelers.

my wife and teenage daughter spent five nights at the Keio Plaza Hotel in Shinjuku . Our first visit to Japan so it was nice to stay in a good hotel . Room on the 24th floor with views to Fuji on a clear morning . Buffet breakfast was a great start to the day and the top floor bar with night views a great way to finish . The convenience shop in the basement great for beers and snacks . A five minute walk to Shinjuku station , it'a a bit daunting on the first visit but but it all works . Our room was a bit dated but all clean and tidy with good fittings and free stuff . The area has lots of restaurants and shops close by and the Metropolitan Building is over the road . It has observation near the top of each tower with free views the city day and night . We all enjoyed our stay at the Keio Plaza , it was a great start to a great holiday in Japan .

Great location next to Shinjuku station (west exit) and there isn't really anything to fault other than to say that the cheaper rooms are getting a bit old and shabby. I've stayed on two occasions and there was a big difference between the basic room on the 13th floor and the larger room on the 29th floor. Don't pay extra for the breakfast - overpriced and really terrible. There is a great bakery and convenience store in the basement of the hotel. Or plenty of coffee shops nearby.A big plus is that the Limosine bus from Narita airport goes directly to the hotel.

Great hotel. We will be back! Excellent location just a short walk from JR Shinjuku station. The staff are very friendly and helpful, and cannot do enough for you. We stayed for 7 nights and our room was great. Fantastic views over Tokyo from the 40th floor. The facilities in the hotel are excellent, even down to the convenience store where you can buy everyday items including food and drink. There are a number of restaurants offering a range of cuisines.

This is a 4 star hotel and I stayed for x3 nights on business. My issues with this hotel:1. There are 7 TV chanels. That's it. Only x2 are in English (CNN and BBC World). You can chose to pay for movies if you want but the descriptions are "New Release" or "Talked-about Movie" or "Around 100-minute Movie" or " Popular Action Movie" - how do I know if I want to watch one of these before I part with 1050 Yen? Hardly a state-of-the-art system for a technology driven nation.2. Breakfast is appalling. You have two choices of buffet. The first is in the restaurant "Jurin". This place opens at 6am. If you are familiar with English boarding school breakfasts of the 1970's you'll have an idea of what it's all about. Avoid it. The second option is the Glass buffet. This opens at 7am. Substantially better than Jurin but still way off the mark. Chef seems to prefer to waft food in the general direction of a convection fan heater rather than a grill or oven. The food is neither cooked nor hot.3. No wifi in public areas.No - it's no good, I've lost the will to carry on with this review and also to stay here again. Next time I'll be using the Hilton.

Great value for price, great location, wonderful view, cozy interiors and ..those beds! Single beds are more like double. Very quiet, close to subway station and the centrer of Shinjuku area. I rated great value for money based on my booking online, which was considerably cheaper (50% or so).

The hotel is located on the west side of Shinjuku station in the business district. There is better shopping, entertainment and sightseeing to be had on the east side, but it is only a short walk away.My standard double room was excellently appointed and large by Tokyo standards. My only complaint for the room was that Wifi required you collect additional cables from reception, and in my case didnt work at all and i had to plug in a cable. And this is technologically savvy Japan!Breakfast was OK - plenty of choices both japanese and western but a bit bland all round.At £150 per night, it is certainly not cheap, but that's Tokyo for you!

The hotel is in a very convenient location, just a few blocks from the JR Shinjuku station, the Airport Limousine bus stops right at the hotel and tons of shops and restaurants in the Shinjuku area are close by. We stayed in a standard twin room which we booked through a Japanese travel site and got a better rate than what was offered in the hotel's own website. Rooms were very comfortable and clean and a good size. We were even fortunate enough to see Mt Fuji in the distance from our room window. The only complaint we would have was that the rooms were very warm but we found this to be the case in other hotels and in the department stores and trains. Considering that the country is being very energy conservation conscious, we found this to be very surprising that the heat would be turned up so high. The convenience store in the hotel was a great benefit so that we could get snacks and drinks for our room. We had the buffet breakfast in the hotel on one day - although there was a good selection, we found it to be over-priced (even for Japan), the buffet was not beimg consistently stocked, none of the food was hot and the eggs at the omelet station were very undercooked (I don't even usually mind it when they are slightly runny). It would be ok if you're on a breakfast package but much better value elsewhere if you are paying separately for breakfast. Free wifi is available in the rooms although we did have to request a small router from the front desk. This may be just for the standard rooms but it was very easy to hook up and get online. I would probably stay at this hotel again when I return to Tokyo.

My husband and I stayed at Keio Plaza for 4 nights, under 2 different reservations (we had visited Hakone/Mt. Fuji) between these stays. The location is EXCELLENT -- a quick 5 minute walk to Shinjuku Train Station and lots of shopping! Service/staff were very helpful and courteous, and our overall experience met the standards of a 4 star hotel in most large international cities. Regarding the rooms:3 stars for the first two nights where we stayed in their Plaza Comfort room located in the South Tower. Although the room was large and generally clean, it was very old, stains were visible on the carpet, and the furniture/walls were obviously in need of some repairs. Overall, I was rather disappointed at the room as we paid $250 USD/night which was a "special" on-line for checking in on a Sunday. Pictures on-line do NOT accurately reflect what the room looks like. 5 stars for the second reservation (again two nights) where we stayed in the Plaza BIZ Plus room in the Main Tower. Although the room was smaller, it was updated, lighting was much brighter, the overall room was much more what I expected. We paid approx. $285 USD/night. Pictures on-line reflect what the room looks like. For $35 USD/night more between the two types of rooms -- stay in the Plaza BIZ Plus! Overall, we would recommend this hotel and will highly consider it the next time we come to Tokyo; however, we will happily pay a little more to stay in the Plaza BIZ over the Plaza Comfort room.

The Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo is the best hotel I have stayed in anywhere in the world.Centrally located,spotlessly clean,staff extremely courtious.But then again I have found the Japanese people to be courtious and gracious.Anyone that has a problem with this hotel really has a problem.Thinking of taking a trip to Japan,don't hesitate.If you intend to visit the many temples make sure you get fit as there is a lot of stair climbing.A visit to Hiroshima Museum would make anyone an Anti Nuclear supporter.My thoughts were when I did are was such an act necessary killing hundreds of thousands of men,women and worst of all children

Centrally located in Shinjuku and next to Shinjuku station. The rooms size are above standard of Tokyo hotels with good selection of L'Occitane amenities for a very decent price. The selection of restaurants is large and good. The staff are friendly and have assisted me in all matter as one would expect. Can not fault them in anyways. Would recommend to stay here.

again i spend 5 days in this hotel,and it is since so many years a good location in tokyo with a perfect service;just missing some good tv channel as hbo cinemathis is so strange for a good hotel like this not to have a free movie channelreally they must put onethe rest is all okby for nowff

We booked 5 nights stay in this "highly recommended" hotel which proved to be our worst experience in Japan!The staff especially the Duty Manager Niwano is inflexible and rude!Who on earth would expect such a highly regarded hotel not to provide basic thing like body lotion.After our 4 days stay In Nikko which we had great experience, we checked into Keio Plaza on 9 Nov 2012. As we had used up our body lotion, we called the front desk for assistance to provide body lotion for the night before we can replenish the next day.To our horror, the Duty Manager Niwano claimed that as our room type is "ONLY" Superior, they can't provide us with body lotion. Despite our plead for help just for the night, Niwano suggested us to buy the body lotion on 2nd floor. At 11pm, after a long day and shower, he expected us to get change again to buy body lotion???What happened to the friendly and polite culture of Japanese people???After we called him again and made our frustrations felt, Niwano continue to said that due to company policy, he can't do anything. We asked for his name and told him that we will write a review our our experience.About 10 mins later, he asked someone up to our room, who showed us a BLACK face and threw the body lotion on the floor in front of us!!! He only apologized after I lose my temper!!!If Japan wants to draw more tourists back, then I urge the government to bring back the polite culture to Keio Plaza staff!Song

We have chosen Keio purely because we didn't want the hassle of checking in into another hotel during our 9 days trip to Tokyo. The hotel has free shuttle to Disney and thus has certainly saved us some money in transport. However downside is the timing of pickup from Disneyland is quite rigid. We went to Disneyland for two days, third day in Disneysea. Our kids love the rides and enjoyed themselves wholeheartedly. The ride to Disneyland from hotel is about 60 min. One can take airport limousine directly to hotel and vice versa. Another plus point. We were lucky that weather was good throughout except our third day in Disneysea . That day rained intermittently. There are good ramen shops patronized by locals . V yummy yet not expensive in Japan's context. The hotel room is very spacious but having paid premium rate I found the photos differ from the room we stayed. Not as new as we thought it should be. There are no satellite channels too. There is a disappointing part. wifi is not readily available . But you can borrow a portable thumb drive - like router to connect free wifi.

The Keio Hotel is strategically located in the center of three department stores,so shopping is excellent. The restos are all around and their food are so interesting. Its a stone's throw from the Shinjuku Train Station. The staff are so welcoming and quite helpful, soft spoken and accommodating with all your questions. Yes, will recommend this hotel.

I just got back from a stay at the Keio Plaza and it really should be split into 2 separate reviews. I stayed for 2 nights in a Superior room (main tower) took a quick 1 night trip to Osaka and then came back for 2 more nights in a Plaza Premier (also main tower).The superior room was extremely dated. It was actually quite disappointing when I first walked in. You could tell the carpet and furniture had not been changed in quite some time. While the room itself was clean, you couldnt help but shake the dingy/dusty feel to it since everything was so old. The plaza premier was much better as the bedding and furnishings were updated. There was a minor hiccup of sorts as I had booked a King bed but upon entering the room was surprised to find 2 doubles. At that point I was a bit too worn out from all the day traveling to go back downstairs to complain, so I just made it into a euro style super king and took 2 minutes to push the 2 beds together.As others had mentioned, the location of the hotel was fairly convenient from Shinjuku station. There is a decent amount of restaurants, bars within short walking distance from the hotel, just west of the station. The walk to the more bustling side of Shinjuku (east/north) is also no more than a 15 minute walk.I didnt book breakfast with the hotels but ended up eating at the hotel once for convenience. Bad mistake. The breakfast buffet was terrible, and also a terrible value at approx 3,000Y. Honestly, I've had better breakfasts at Denny's or any other cheap diner. Even for the japanese offerings, the cheap breakfast we grabbed at one of the numerous little shops at the train station was much better (not to mention 10-20% of the price). Oh well... lesson learned.

Arrived to Tokyo by Train from Kyoto and loved how we could get to the Hotel through the underground. Check-in was a breese and had a Deluxe in the Main on the 27th floor overlooking Shinjuku Station. The room was a great size for Tokyo and included everything you could want. The only drawback was the amount of English Channels on the Television but then again I did not come to Tokyo to watch television. Definitely many choices for dining if a bit pricy but that is a hotel for you. Just outside there are many other options if you are a budget watcher. Beds were extremely comfortable and the bathroom had plenty of towels. We were able to exchange US Dollars to Yen with no problem as well as set up any tours, directions and return transportation to Narita. I would definitely stay here again.

This is the prototype that I have in my head for the Japanese big box hotel. Stayed here for 2 nights on business. Huge hotel, easy to find close to Shinjuku station (exit from south or west). Stayed in a "deluxe" room in the main tower building. Dated look from the 70s (it's an older building), large but rooms, fairly pricey as expected for Shinjuku. Huge TV. Polite service. Pricey restaurant. 4/5 overall.

We stayed 2 nights in a Plaza Comfort room in the South Tower. We had requested a non smoking room on a high floor and were given as requested, our room on the 33rd floor had great views of the city.The room itself was spacious but really dated. It didn't look or feel like a 4 star hotel and it could do with a refurbishment. Still, it was very clean. Based on other reviews, I think the Premier rooms or those in the Main tower may have been better. That said, we got a good deal online and given the space and location, I can't complain.The location of the hotel is fantastic. Lots of food choices around and many convenience stores too. Easy 350m walk from the JR Shinjuku station if you get the correct exit. We walked double the distance after getting the wrong exit. No real need change trains to get to Tochomae station, which is next to the hotel.Best part is that the hotel is right next to the Tokyo metropolitan government building which is a sight to behold (for architecture buffs) and has the free observatory on L45 which is open till 11pm every night. We strolled across after dinner on our first night and waited no more than 10mins in the queue.Lastly, those planning to visit Disneyland might find it useful to know that this is a partner hotel and there is a free shuttle bus to Disneyland!

This is a Airport Limousine Bus drop/pick up location hotel. Very good hotel, large and usually crowded. Easy access to Narita (1.5-2 hrs) and Hinode (1hr) airports. I have stayed here 3 times in the past 4 years, all good experiences. Rooms are clean, bath well appointed, rooms are quiet. I had to switch rooms on my recent stay because they do not enforce rules in non-smolling rooms. Italian restaurant was good for dinner. Breakfast buffet is VERY crowded, but a huge selection (Japanese and American). Easy 5 min walk to Shinjuku station, nice shopping at the Keio Shopping center at the train station.

As part of our trip to Japan this October we stayed in the Keio Plaza, Shinjuku twice (with time spent elsewhere in Japan inbetween). Both times were in Deluxe rooms in the Main Tower. We had stayed at this hotel previously during other holidays and it was a simple choice to return.The hotel's location is ideal for accessing public transport in Tokyo. It is a short walk from the back of the hotel to the main Shinjuku station South Entrance or, by using the North second floor exit and the pedestrian tunnel, the Shinjuku station West Entrance. In both cases you are looking at a 5-10min stroll. We flew into (and out from) Narita and the Airport Limobus service from there has a drop-off/pick-up point at the Keio Plaza which makes getting to and from the hotel and the airport a complete doddle, even easier than by train as you don't have to get to and from the station to the hotel with your luggage. You can make reservations and buy tickets for using this service back to the airport from the Keio Plaza's bell desk.Our room looked just like the publicity picture of a deluxe twin room on the hotels website and had a great view over Shinjuku towards the station. The room was modern and had all the facilities you could want (well a DVD player would have been nice to go with the big LCD TV) plus a rather nice little music system.The staff were very helpful when we needed to ask them things and having a little convenience store down on the second floor is very useful.The only area I could mark the hotel down on is the price of it's restaurants ... they are expensive and it's possible to find good, but cheaper, places to eat in the city.

Very well located, within 5 to 10 minutes walk to Shinjuku Station. The hotel has two towers, the Main tower and the South tower. Another reviewer had mentioned that the South Tower needed some upgrading, and the guest should request to stay in the Main Tower. I did, but with no success. According to the front desk the room I requested (two twin beds) was located in the South Tower. It was hard to believe that a hotel that big would not have (twin bed) rooms in the Main Tower. The room itself was clean and OK, but it needed some serious upgrading on the decor. It was like stepping into the 70's. For a city that is so electronically forward, with sensors for everything (faucets, toilets) where you don't need to touch much, that room decor was very dated. The beds were comfortable enough, the shower was clean, the room size was OK. There was also free internet. There is a shop on the 2nd floor that sells water, snacks, food, etc, which was very convenient (considering that the smallest bottle of water from the mini bar was $4). Overall the hotel was average, but the location, helpful and very polite staff made up for it.

Stayed twice in one week travelling through Japan. Excellent location near Shinjuku station. First stay were in an upgraded room on a higher floor which had free wifi and much nicer amenities. On the lower floor the trip up and down the elevator was much slower. Wired internet only on the lower floors but they provided a free mifi unit which worked fine. Several really good (and expensive) restaurants. Had excellent Sukiyaki/Shabu-Shabu and Korean BBQ meals. Save time and money for breakfast and walk 3 min to a Shinjuku cafe. Concierge desk very helpful and all spoke adequate English. Right on the Bus Limousine route for both Haneda and Norita airports.

I stayed here for 3 nights mainly because of its location. It was very close to Shinjuku station and the stores, restaurants and bars. The room was a bit dated, but it served its purpose. The staff were most helpful and friendly. We didn't eat breakfast in the hotel, but there were plenty of coffee shops close by but well hidden.

Stayed there 3 nights two adults with two small children (3 and 6 years). I would call ourselves experienced in the region as we live in Korea and travel a lot - business and private. Compared to other places in East asia where we've been we were really shocked as we experienced queues everywhere: reception - just because only one counter out of *many* were opened in the evening when many guest arrive; buffet restaurant for breakfast - only one waiter for allocating the guest. That's not what I call service in this price range. Well you may call it typical in Japan at least. Staff is helpful and speaks english but you have to be prepared to be patient until you get what you want.Interior of the rooms is a little outdated. Facilities: No sauna, swimming pool only in summer (outdoor) and not available for early birds as business guests as it opens only 9am.Breakfast buffet (we just tried the western one) does not offer a big variety.Location is great Shinjuku station is 10 min by walk - could not find the car/bus service which was mentioned. But it is not really necessary when you travel with small luggage.In total it is just overpriced even for Tokyo. Would not stay there again but give the chance to another.

Per other reviews, it's a "classic," meaning older hotel. No WiFi (free wired internet...instead I rented a pocket MiFi router), no voicemail (a blinking message light meant the front desk had a paper message for you). Staff was very friendly, willing to help and spoke sufficient English. But it's clean, the rooms are spacious by Japanese standards, the amenities are good, shops and restaurants inside. We were a party of three (mom and two adult sons) and had two twin beds (which were comfortable) and a sofa bed (not so comfy) yet still had room to move around. Closet and drawer space OK for two; tight for three. But if you're on vacation, you shouldn't be spending that much time in the room! I LOVE the convenient location. Easy walking distance to Shinjuku train station, the artery for virtually every mode of public transportation. (Straight shot if leaving out the south exit.) A few short blocks away from the Government Building (free scenic views of the city), several shopping areas on the west side and the nightlife of east Shinjuku. Free shuttle bus to Tokyo Disney (must reserve seat), Airport Limo bus stops at their front door (and they have a vending machine that sells return tickets to the airport). Good price through hotels.com. Very decent place. You can pay more for something nicer, but why?

This is an old hotel but good enough if you just need a place to sleep. Internet connection is archaic - no wifi - but rooms are more spacious then your regular hotel. I would often prefer a more contemporary hotel. Location is good as close by the other large hotels like Hyatt n local noodle restaurants.

The Keio Plaza Hotel is a luxury hotel located in the Shinjuku neighborhood in west central Tokyo. The rooms are small but very comfortable. They include a small refrigerator and a hot water tea kettle (no coffee but you can buy instant, milk, & sugar for the room at a convenient store like we did. The hotel is expensive, but a deal by Tokyo standards. The restaurants in the hotel are also high, but any of the 3 breakfast buffets are worth it for a good start in this busy city. The shops in the hotel are actually cheaper than stores on surrounding streets (wine was a good buy, and so were the wide choice of ethic souvenirs). You can charge hotel meals on your credit card, but not anything in the hotel shops (cash only). The hotel is only a couple blocks from the massive Shinjuku railroad/subway station for good access to all of Tokyo. The Tokyo Municipal Building with it's 2 free observation decks is next door.

Good position, clean large room on the 23 floor. free wi fi for I pad with router supplied from front desk.Bus direct from Narita. have stayed there before, must look for offers.Staff very helpful, asked for coffee in the room as only green tea...no problem.There within 3 mim....good service.

I have stayed at Keio Plaza several times, always a great stay, great location and great buffet breakfast. The hotel is a 5 minute walk from the JR Train Station and the Airport Limo bus stops at the hotel.

Service was of a high standard, all staff were well trained to make stay memorable.We enjoyed breakfast served in our room each morning, dining in the evening a choice of French, Korean, Japanese and Chinese were available set in surrounding of there country. Close to the local train station of Shinjuku gave access to other parts of Tokyo.

Keio Plaza Hotel is ideally located, a short walk along the street or underground from Odakyu Department store and Shinjuka station. The hotel is huge and clearly in the process of being upgraded. I stayed in the South tower on the 20th floor. The room was clean and had everything you would expect from a large city hotel , however it was somewhat shabby and old fashioned and in need of a make over. The bed and bed linen were disappointingly uncomfortable and in this day and age I expect better quality pillows. The highlight however was the view of Mount Fuji from the bedroom window, despite this being my second trip to Tokyo this is the first time I have ever seen this majestic icon. It truly was an awesome sight.A colleague was staying the the main tower on the 38th floor. These are significantly better rooms with modern decor, a fully stocked mini bar, luxury bathroom products, free wifi and comfortable beds and bed linen. For very little difference in price the difference in quality was huge.The hotel has a swimming pool which did not look particularly inviting and a small fitness room. The fitness room has three treadmills, two cross trainers and an exercise bike. There is a set of hand weights from 1kg to 10kg (no bench) and a leg press and chest press machine, enough to do a basic workout.We tried the coffee shop downstairs for one lunch and one breakfast, food was reasonable but we found it to be quite expensive. If you can find the coffee shop called Paul Bossett nearby, use that for coffee and breakfast, the pancakes there were to die for.The Polestar cocktail bar is a great place to relax with a drink after a long day shopping. Outstanding service and great cocktails. The view from this restaurant in the 45th floor is outstanding, you do not need to go to the ubiquitous Park Hyatt and pretend you are Scarlett Johansson or Bill Murray.Overall the location and cleanliness of this hotel make up for its shortcoming.

We stayed at this hotel for a week for business trip. We arrived in Shinjuku at night, and were lost for 45 minutes trying to find the way out from the massive train station. There was no sign board directed to the hotel, the only landmark near to the hotel was Tokyo Goverment Office. Hence, if you are looking for the hotel signboard at Shinjuku station, you are not going to find it! Typical to Japanese fashion, the check in was done quickly and efficiently, and we were ushered to our room in less than 15 minutes. The room was quite small, but I guess compared to Japan compact standard, it is acceptable. Loved the toileteries, very generous with the shampoo, shower gel and even has Shiseido face soap at your disposal. Tea and coffee making facilities are good, and had fun time making coffee daily. The only downside was the TV channels, which has limited choices and all are either in Japanese or Mandarin, except for BBCN and CNN....but after a while, you get really bored with both channels. Hotel food are expensive, only order when you are desperate. If not, there are many delighful restaurants, cafes around the area, especially in the Shinjuku station itself. You can also buy food from the deparmental store, they give discount after 6 pm
